The off switch is in there somewhere.

00:08:23.590 --> 00:08:25.169
I'm telling you -- it's there.

00:08:25.193 --> 00:08:28.437
Part of the art of designing
a simple, good interface,

00:08:28.461 --> 00:08:31.945
is knowing when to use
which one of these features.

00:08:31.969 --> 00:08:35.494
So, here is the log-off
dialogue box for Windows 2000.

00:08:35.518 --> 00:08:38.018
There are only four choices,

00:08:38.042 --> 00:08:41.098
so why are they in a pop-up menu?

00:08:41.122 --> 00:08:44.438
It's not like the rest of the screen
is so full of other components

00:08:44.462 --> 00:08:46.934
that you need to collapse the choices.

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:48.934
They could have put them all out in view.

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:51.934
Here's Apple's take
on the exact same dialogue box.

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:53.361
(Applause)

00:08:53.385 --> 00:08:56.934
Thank you -- yes, I designed
the dialogue box. No, no.

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:59.573
Already, we can see
that Apple and Microsoft

00:08:59.597 --> 00:09:02.934
have a severely divergent
approach to software design.

00:09:03.757 --> 00:09:07.090
Microsoft's approach
to simplicity tends to be:

00:09:07.114 --> 00:09:09.934
let's break it down;
let's just make it more steps.

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:11.934
There are these "wizards" everywhere.

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:15.197
And you know, there's a new version
of Windows coming out this fall.

00:09:15.221 --> 00:09:18.276
If they continue at this pace,
there's absolutely no telling

00:09:18.300 --> 00:09:20.446
where they might wind up.

00:09:20.470 --> 00:09:22.808
[Welcome to the Type a Word Wizard]

00:09:22.832 --> 00:09:24.000
(Laughter)

00:09:24.024 --> 00:09:27.314
(Applause)

00:09:27.338 --> 00:09:29.123
"Welcome to the Type a Word Wizard."

00:09:29.147 --> 00:09:30.362
Ok, I'll bite.

00:09:30.386 --> 00:09:32.934
Let's click "Next" to continue.

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:35.261
(Laughter)

00:09:35.285 --> 00:09:37.132
(Applause)

00:09:37.156 --> 00:09:40.506
From the drop-down menu, choose
the first letter you want to type. Ok.

00:09:40.530 --> 00:09:42.863
(Laughter)

00:09:42.887 --> 00:09:45.426
So there is a limit
that we don't want to cross.

00:09:45.450 --> 00:09:46.601
So what is the answer?

00:09:46.625 --> 00:09:50.701
How do you pack in all these features
in a simple, intelligent way?

00:09:50.725 --> 00:09:53.430
I believe in consistency, when possible,

00:09:53.454 --> 00:09:54.756
real-world equivalents,

00:09:54.780 --> 00:09:58.003
trash can folder, when possible,
label things, mostly.

00:09:58.027 --> 00:10:00.203
But I beg of the designers here

00:10:00.227 --> 00:10:03.798
to break all those rules
if they violate the biggest rule of all,

00:10:03.822 --> 00:10:05.011
which is intelligence.

00:10:05.035 --> 00:10:06.338
Now what do I mean by that?

00:10:06.362 --> 00:10:08.053
I'm going to give you some examples

00:10:08.077 --> 00:10:11.409
where intelligence makes something
not consistent, but it's better.

00:10:11.433 --> 00:10:13.820
If you are buying something on the web,

00:10:13.844 --> 00:10:15.725
you're supposed to put in your address,

00:10:15.749 --> 00:10:18.583
and you're supposed to choose
what country you're from, ok?

00:10:18.607 --> 00:10:20.385
There are 200 countries in the world.

00:10:20.409 --> 00:10:22.917
We like to think of the Internet
as a global village.

00:10:22.941 --> 00:10:24.312
I'm sorry; it's not one yet.

00:10:24.336 --> 00:10:26.940
It's mainly like, the United States,
Europe, and Japan.

00:10:26.964 --> 00:10:29.315
So why is "United States" in the "U"s?

00:10:29.339 --> 00:10:30.705
(Laughter)

00:10:30.729 --> 00:10:33.658
You have to scroll, like,
seven screensful to get to it.

00:10:33.682 --> 00:10:36.934
Now, it would be inconsistent
to put "United States" first,

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:38.429
but it would be intelligent.

00:10:38.453 --> 00:10:41.086
This one's been touched on before,

00:10:41.110 --> 00:10:44.934
but why in God's name do you
shut down a Windows PC

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:47.357
by clicking a button called "Start?"

00:10:47.381 --> 00:10:51.449
(Laughter)

00:10:51.473 --> 00:10:54.934
Here's another pet one of mine:
you have a printer.

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:58.827
Most of the time, you want to print
one copy of your document,

00:10:58.851 --> 00:11:01.103
in page order, on that printer.

00:11:01.127 --> 00:11:05.387
So why in God's name do you see
this every time you print?

00:11:05.752 --> 00:11:08.220
It's like a 747 shuttle cockpit.

00:11:08.244 --> 00:11:09.807
(Laughter)

00:11:09.831 --> 00:11:13.599
And one of the buttons at the bottom,
you'll notice, is not "Print."

00:11:13.623 --> 00:11:17.934
(Laughter)

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:21.228
(Applause)

00:11:21.252 --> 00:11:25.181
Now, I'm not saying that Apple
is the only company who has embraced

00:11:25.205 --> 00:11:27.761
the cult of simplicity.

00:11:27.785 --> 00:11:30.765
Palm is also, especially in the old days,
wonderful about this.

00:11:30.789 --> 00:11:34.147
I actually got to speak to Palm
when they were flying high in the '90s,

00:11:34.171 --> 00:11:36.375
and after the talk,
I met one of the employees.

00:11:36.399 --> 00:11:39.580
He says, "Nice talk." And I said,
"Thank you. What do you do here?"

00:11:39.604 --> 00:11:42.245
He said, "I'm a tap counter."
I'm like, "You're a what?"

00:11:42.269 --> 00:11:44.301
He goes, "Well Jeff Hawkins,
the CEO, says,

00:11:44.325 --> 00:11:48.534
'If any task on the Palm Pilot
takes more than three taps of the stylus,

00:11:48.558 --> 00:11:51.556
it's too long,
and it has to be redesigned.'

00:11:51.580 --> 00:11:52.934
So I'm the tap counter."

00:11:53.372 --> 00:11:55.134
So, I'm going to show you an example

00:11:55.158 --> 00:11:57.780
of a company that does not
have a tap counter.

00:11:57.804 --> 00:11:59.067
(Laughter)

00:11:59.091 --> 00:12:00.662
This is Microsoft Word.

00:12:00.686 --> 00:12:04.820
Ok, when you want to create
a new blank document in Word --

00:12:04.844 --> 00:12:05.996
it could happen.

00:12:06.020 --> 00:12:11.368
(Laughter)

00:12:11.392 --> 00:12:14.851
You go up to the "File" menu
and you choose "New."

00:12:14.875 --> 00:12:17.074
Now, what happens when you choose "New?"

00:12:17.098 --> 00:12:19.127
Do you get a new blank document?

00:12:19.151 --> 00:12:20.342
You do not.

00:12:20.366 --> 00:12:25.057
On the opposite side of the monitor,
a task bar appears,

00:12:25.081 --> 00:12:28.843
and somewhere in those links --
by the way, not at the top --

00:12:28.867 --> 00:12:33.311
somewhere in those links is a button
that makes you a new document.

00:12:33.335 --> 00:12:36.328
Ok, so that is a company
not counting taps.

00:12:36.352 --> 00:12:40.156
You know, I don't want to just stand
here and make fun of Microsoft ...

00:12:40.180 --> 00:12:41.482
Yes, I do.

00:12:41.506 --> 00:12:42.934
(Laughter)

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:46.553
(Applause)

00:12:46.577 --> 00:12:47.951
The Bill Gates song!

00:12:47.975 --> 00:12:49.403
(Piano music)

00:12:49.427 --> 00:12:52.862
I've been a geek forever

00:12:52.886 --> 00:12:55.126
and I wrote the very first DOS.

00:12:57.126 --> 00:13:00.661
I put my software and IBM together;

00:13:00.685 --> 00:13:03.934
I got profit and they got the loss.

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:06.636
(Laughter)

00:13:06.660 --> 00:13:11.278
I write the code
that makes the whole world run.

00:13:11.302 --> 00:13:15.715
I'm getting royalties from everyone.

00:13:15.739 --> 00:13:20.365
Sometimes it's garbage,
but the press is snowed.

00:13:20.389 --> 00:13:22.958
You buy the box; I'll sell the code.

00:13:26.071 --> 00:13:30.934
Every software company
is doing Microsoft's R&D.

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:35.090
You can't keep a good idea
down these days.

00:13:35.114 --> 00:13:37.293
Even Windows is a hack.

00:13:37.317 --> 00:13:39.643
We're kind of based loosely on the Mac.

00:13:39.667 --> 00:13:42.375
So it's big, so it's slow.
You've got nowhere to go.

00:13:42.399 --> 00:13:44.934
I'm not doing this for praise.

00:13:45.600 --> 00:13:49.886
I write the code
that fits the world today.

00:13:50.441 --> 00:13:54.147
Big mediocrity in every way.

00:13:54.662 --> 00:13:58.934
We've entered planet domination mode.

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:02.480
You'll have no choice; you'll buy my code.

00:14:04.860 --> 00:14:09.958
I am Bill Gates and I write the code.

00:14:12.131 --> 00:14:19.072
(Applause)

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:22.660
But actually, I believe
there are really two Microsofts.

00:14:22.684 --> 00:14:25.763
There's the old one, responsible
for Windows and Office.

00:14:25.787 --> 00:14:29.801
They're dying to throw the whole thing
out and start fresh, but they can't.

00:14:29.825 --> 00:14:33.525
They're locked in, because so many add-ons
and other company stuff

00:14:33.549 --> 00:14:36.170
locks into the old 1982 chassis.

00:14:36.194 --> 00:14:37.784
But there's also a new Microsoft,

00:14:37.808 --> 00:14:41.299
that's really doing good,
simple interface designs.

00:14:41.323 --> 00:14:42.879
I liked the Media Center PC.

00:14:42.903 --> 00:14:44.659
I liked the Microsoft SPOT Watch.

00:14:44.683 --> 00:14:47.636
The Wireless Watch
flopped miserably in the market,

00:14:47.660 --> 00:14:50.708
but it wasn't because it wasn't
simply and beautifully designed.

00:14:50.732 --> 00:14:51.978
But let's put it this way:

00:14:52.002 --> 00:14:54.493
would you pay $10 a month to have a watch

00:14:54.517 --> 00:14:57.775
that has to be recharged
every night like your cell phone,

00:14:57.799 --> 00:15:00.338
and stops working
when you leave your area code?

00:15:00.362 --> 00:15:02.960
(Laughter)

00:15:02.984 --> 00:15:05.485
So, the signs might indicate

00:15:05.509 --> 00:15:08.346
that the complexity crunch
is only going to get worse.

00:15:08.370 --> 00:15:10.023
So is there any hope?

00:15:10.047 --> 00:15:12.746
The screens are getting smaller,
people are illuminating,

00:15:12.770 --> 00:15:14.167
putting manuals in the boxes,

00:15:14.191 --> 00:15:16.934
things are coming out at a faster pace.

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:20.351
It's funny -- when Steve Jobs
came back to Apple in 1997,

00:15:20.375 --> 00:15:23.200
after 12 years away,
it was the MacWorld Expo --

00:15:23.224 --> 00:15:26.366
he came to the stage
in that black turtleneck and jeans,

00:15:26.390 --> 00:15:27.542
and he sort of did this.

00:15:27.566 --> 00:15:29.934
The crowd went wild,
but I had just seen --

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:31.884
I'm like, where have I seen this before?

00:15:31.908 --> 00:15:33.717
I had just seen the movie "Evita" --

00:15:33.741 --> 00:15:36.826
(Laughter)

00:15:36.850 --> 00:15:38.008
with Madonna,

00:15:38.032 --> 00:15:39.780
and I'm like, you know what?

00:15:39.804 --> 00:15:42.901
I've got to do one about Steve Jobs.

00:15:42.925 --> 00:15:43.933
(Music)

00:15:43.957 --> 00:15:46.973
It won't be easy.
You'll think I'm strange.

00:15:46.997 --> 00:15:48.141
(Laughter)

00:15:48.165 --> 00:15:50.474
When I try to explain why I'm back,

00:15:50.498 --> 00:15:53.589
after telling the press
Apple's future is black.

00:15:53.613 --> 00:15:56.208
You won't believe me.

00:15:56.232 --> 00:16:00.934
All that you see is a kid in his teens
who started out in a garage

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:03.934
with only a buddy named Woz.

00:16:03.958 --> 00:16:05.510
(Laughter)

00:16:05.534 --> 00:16:07.267
You try rhyming with garage!

00:16:07.291 --> 00:16:09.733
(Laughter)

00:16:09.757 --> 00:16:12.632
Don't cry for me, Cupertino.

00:16:12.656 --> 00:16:13.978
(Laughter)

00:16:14.002 --> 00:16:16.934
The truth is, I never left you.

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:20.493
I know the ropes now,
know what the tricks are.

00:16:20.517 --> 00:16:23.934
I made a fortune over at Pixar.

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:24.997
(Laughter)

00:16:25.021 --> 00:16:27.672
Don't cry for me, Cupertino.

00:16:28.140 --> 00:16:31.453
I've still got the drive and vision.

00:16:31.477 --> 00:16:34.929
I still wear sandals in any weather.

00:16:34.953 --> 00:16:36.934
It's just that these days,

00:16:36.958 --> 00:16:38.934
they're Gucci leather.

00:16:38.958 --> 00:16:40.934
(Laughter)

00:16:40.958 --> 00:16:47.866
(Applause)

00:16:48.216 --> 00:16:49.374
Thank you.

00:16:49.773 --> 00:16:54.481
So Steve Jobs had always believed
in simplicity and elegance and beauty.

00:16:54.505 --> 00:16:56.402
And the truth is,

00:16:56.426 --> 00:16:58.554
for years I was a little depressed,

00:16:58.578 --> 00:17:00.851
because Americans
obviously did not value it,

00:17:00.875 --> 00:17:03.152
because the Mac had
three percent market share,

00:17:03.176 --> 00:17:05.033
Windows had 95 percent market share --

00:17:05.057 --> 00:17:07.934
people did not think it was worth
putting a price on it.

00:17:07.958 --> 00:17:09.749
So I was a little depressed.

00:17:09.773 --> 00:17:11.330
And then I heard Al Gore's talk,

00:17:11.354 --> 00:17:13.893
and I realized I didn't know
the meaning of depressed.

00:17:13.917 --> 00:17:14.934
(Laughter)

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:16.695
But it turns out I was wrong, right?

00:17:16.719 --> 00:17:18.452
Because the iPod came out,

00:17:18.476 --> 00:17:21.094
and it violated every bit
of common wisdom.

00:17:21.118 --> 00:17:24.094
Other products cost less;
other products had more features,

00:17:24.118 --> 00:17:26.855
they had voice recorders
and FM transmitters.

00:17:26.879 --> 00:17:30.101
The other products were backed
by Microsoft, with an open standard,

00:17:30.125 --> 00:17:31.839
not Apple's propriety standard.

00:17:31.863 --> 00:17:34.435
But the iPod won --
this is the one they wanted.

00:17:34.459 --> 00:17:36.722
The lesson was: simplicity sells.

00:17:36.746 --> 00:17:39.620
And there are signs that the industry
is getting the message.

00:17:39.644 --> 00:17:43.235
This is a little company that's done
very well with simplicity and elegance.

00:17:43.259 --> 00:17:44.998
The Sonos thing -- it's catching on.

00:17:45.022 --> 00:17:46.720
I've got just a couple examples.

00:17:46.744 --> 00:17:50.420
Physically, a really cool,
elegant thinking coming along lately.

00:17:50.444 --> 00:17:52.397
When you have a digital camera,

00:17:52.421 --> 00:17:55.664
how do you get the pictures
back to your computer?

00:17:55.688 --> 00:17:58.030
Well, you either haul around a USB cable,

00:17:58.054 --> 00:18:00.210
or you buy a card reader
and haul that around.

00:18:00.234 --> 00:18:01.821
Either one, you're going to lose.

00:18:01.845 --> 00:18:04.304
What I do is, I take out the memory card,

00:18:04.328 --> 00:18:09.673
and I fold it in half,
revealing USB contacts.

00:18:09.697 --> 00:18:12.355
I just stick it in the computer,
offload the pictures,

00:18:12.379 --> 00:18:13.918
put it right back in the camera.

00:18:13.942 --> 00:18:15.742
I never have to lose anything.

00:18:15.766 --> 00:18:17.303
Here's another example.

00:18:17.327 --> 00:18:20.397
Chris, you're the source of all power.
Will you be my power plug?

00:18:20.421 --> 00:18:23.161
Chris Anderson: Oh yeah.
DP: Hold that and don't let go.

00:18:23.185 --> 00:18:25.606
You might've seen this,
this is Apple's new laptop.

00:18:25.630 --> 00:18:27.654
This the power cord.
It hooks on like this.

00:18:27.678 --> 00:18:31.075
And I'm sure every one of you has done
this at some point in your lives,

00:18:31.099 --> 00:18:32.274
or one of your children.

00:18:32.298 --> 00:18:35.123
You walk along -- and I'm
about to pull this onto the floor.

00:18:35.147 --> 00:18:36.483
I don't care. It's a loaner.

00:18:36.507 --> 00:18:37.690
Here we go. Whoa!

00:18:37.714 --> 00:18:40.783
It's magnetic -- it doesn't pull
the laptop onto the floor.

00:18:40.807 --> 00:18:44.934
(Applause)

00:18:44.958 --> 00:18:46.927
In my very last example --

00:18:46.951 --> 00:18:50.927
I do a lot of my work
using speech recognition software.

00:18:50.951 --> 00:18:53.181
And I'll just --
you have to be kind of quiet

00:18:53.205 --> 00:18:54.808
because the software is nervous.

00:18:55.482 --> 00:18:57.562
Speech recognition
software is really great

00:18:57.586 --> 00:19:00.116
for doing emails very quickly; period.

00:19:00.140 --> 00:19:02.779
Like, I get hundreds of them
a day; period.

00:19:02.803 --> 00:19:06.094
And it's not just what I dictate
that it writes down; period.

00:19:06.118 --> 00:19:09.308
I also use this feature
called voice macros; period.

00:19:10.878 --> 00:19:12.060
Correct "dissuade."

00:19:15.957 --> 00:19:17.111
Not "just."

00:19:19.206 --> 00:19:20.888
Ok, this is not an ideal situation,

00:19:20.912 --> 00:19:23.451
because it's getting the echo
from the hall and stuff.

00:19:23.475 --> 00:19:27.711
The point is, I can respond to people
very quickly by saying a short word,

00:19:27.735 --> 00:19:29.807
and having it write out
a much longer thing.

00:19:29.831 --> 00:19:32.197
So if somebody
sends me a fan letter, I'll say,

00:19:32.221 --> 00:19:33.378
"Thanks for that."

00:19:33.402 --> 00:19:35.909
[Thank you so much
for taking the time to write ...]

00:19:35.933 --> 00:19:36.934
(Laughter)

00:19:36.958 --> 00:19:39.934
(Applause)

00:19:39.958 --> 00:19:44.396
And conversely, if somebody
sends me hate mail --

00:19:44.420 --> 00:19:46.722
which happens daily --

00:19:46.746 --> 00:19:48.798
I say, "Piss off."

00:19:51.466 --> 00:19:52.783
(Laughter)

00:19:52.807 --> 00:19:55.279
[I admire your frankness ...]

00:19:55.303 --> 00:19:56.934
(Laughter)

00:19:56.958 --> 00:20:02.311
(Applause)

00:20:02.335 --> 00:20:04.934
So that's my dirty little secret.
Don't tell anyone.

00:20:04.958 --> 00:20:06.073
(Laughter)

00:20:06.097 --> 00:20:08.934
So the point is --
this is a really interesting story.

00:20:08.958 --> 00:20:10.836
This is version eight of this software,

00:20:10.860 --> 00:20:13.058
and do you know what they put
in version eight?

00:20:13.082 --> 00:20:16.144
No new features. It's never
happened before in software!

00:20:16.168 --> 00:20:17.899
The company put no new features.

00:20:17.923 --> 00:20:21.538
They just said, "We'll make
this software work right." Right?

00:20:21.562 --> 00:20:24.778
Because for years, people had bought
this software, tried it out --

00:20:24.802 --> 00:20:26.603
95 percent accuracy was all they got,

00:20:26.627 --> 00:20:28.523
which means one in 20 words is wrong --

00:20:28.547 --> 00:20:30.174
and they'd put it in their drawer.

00:20:30.198 --> 00:20:31.778
And the company got sick of that,

00:20:31.802 --> 00:20:34.638
so they said, "This version,
we're not going to do anything,

00:20:34.662 --> 00:20:36.395
but make sure it's darned accurate."

00:20:36.419 --> 00:20:37.768
And so that's what they did.

00:20:37.792 --> 00:20:40.380
This cult of doing things right
is starting to spread.

00:20:40.404 --> 00:20:43.900
So, my final advice for those of you
who are consumers of this technology:

00:20:43.924 --> 00:20:47.934
remember, if it doesn't work,
it's not necessarily you, ok?

00:20:47.958 --> 00:20:50.292
It could be the design
of the thing you're using.

00:20:50.316 --> 00:20:53.104
Be aware in life
of good design and bad design.

00:20:53.128 --> 00:20:55.995
And if you're among the people
who create this stuff:

00:20:56.019 --> 00:20:57.338
Easy is hard.

00:20:57.362 --> 00:20:59.696
Pre-sweat the details for your audience.

00:20:59.720 --> 00:21:00.934
Count the taps.

00:21:00.958 --> 00:21:03.901
Remember, the hard part
is not deciding what features to add,

00:21:03.925 --> 00:21:05.694
it's deciding what to leave out.

00:21:05.718 --> 00:21:08.915
And best of all, your motivation is:
simplicity sells.

00:21:09.569 --> 00:21:11.236
CA: Bravo. DP: Thank you very much.

00:21:11.260 --> 00:21:12.411
CA: Hear, hear!

00:21:12.435 --> 00:21:14.910
(Applause)

title: Greening the ghetto
transcript: If you're here today — and I'm very happy that you are — you've all heard about how sustainable development will save us from ourselves. However, when we're not at TED, we are often told that a real sustainability policy agenda is just not feasible, especially in large urban areas like New York City. And that's because most people with decision-making powers, in both the public and the private sector, really don't feel as though they're in danger.The reason why I'm here today, in part, is because of a dog — an abandoned puppy I found back in the rain, back in 1998. She turned out to be a much bigger dog than I'd anticipated. When she came into my life, we were fighting against a huge waste facility planned for the East River waterfront despite the fact that our small part of New York City already handled more than 40 percent of the entire city's commercial waste: a sewage treatment pelletizing plant, a sewage sludge plant, four power plants, the world's largest food-distribution center, as well as other industries that bring more than 60,000 diesel truck trips to the area each week. The area also has one of the lowest ratios of parks to people in the city.So when I was contacted by the Parks Department about a $10,000 seed-grant initiative to help develop waterfront projects, I thought they were really well-meaning, but a bit naive. I'd lived in this area all my life, and you could not get to the river, because of all the lovely facilities that I mentioned earlier. Then, while jogging with my dog one morning, she pulled me into what I thought was just another illegal dump. There were weeds and piles of garbage and other stuff that I won't mention here, but she kept dragging me, and lo and behold, at the end of that lot was the river. I knew that this forgotten little street-end, abandoned like the dog that brought me there, was worth saving. And I knew it would grow to become the proud beginnings of the community-led revitalization of the new South Bronx.And just like my new dog, it was an idea that got bigger than I'd imagined. We garnered much support along the way, and the Hunts Point Riverside Park became the first waterfront park that the South Bronx had had in more than 60 years. We leveraged that $10,000 seed grant more than 300 times, into a $3 million park.And in the fall, I'm going to exchange marriage vows with my beloved.(Audience whistles)Thank you very much.(Applause)That's him pressing my buttons back there, which he does all the time.(Laughter)(Applause)But those of us living in environmental justice communities are the canary in the coal mine. We feel the problems right now, and have for some time. Environmental justice, for those of you who may not be familiar with the term, goes something like this: no community should be saddled with more environmental burdens and less environmental benefits than any other.Unfortunately, race and class are extremely reliable indicators as to where one might find the good stuff, like parks and trees, and where one might find the bad stuff, like power plants and waste facilities. As a black person in America, I am twice as likely as a white person to live in an area where air pollution poses the greatest risk to my health. I am five times more likely to live within walking distance of a power plant or chemical facility, which I do. These land-use decisions created the hostile conditions that lead to problems like obesity, diabetes and asthma. Why would someone leave their home to go for a brisk walk in a toxic neighborhood? Our 27 percent obesity rate is high even for this country, and diabetes comes with it. One out of four South Bronx children has asthma. Our asthma hospitalization rate is seven times higher than the national average. These impacts are coming everyone's way. And we all pay dearly for solid waste costs, health problems associated with pollution and more odiously, the cost of imprisoning our young black and Latino men, who possess untold amounts of untapped potential. Fifty percent of our residents live at or below the poverty line; 25 percent of us are unemployed. Low-income citizens often use emergency-room visits as primary care. This comes at a high cost to taxpayers and produces no proportional benefits. Poor people are not only still poor, they are still unhealthy.Fortunately, there are many people like me who are striving for solutions that won't compromise the lives of low-income communities of color in the short term, and won't destroy us all in the long term. None of us want that, and we all have that in common. So what else do we have in common?Well, first of all, we're all incredibly good-looking.(Laughter)Graduated high school, college, post-graduate degrees, traveled to interesting places, didn't have kids in your early teens, financially stable, never been imprisoned. OK. Good.(Laughter)But, besides being a black woman, I am different from most of you in some other ways. I watched nearly half of the buildings in my neighborhood burn down. My big brother Lenny fought in Vietnam, only to be gunned down a few blocks from our home. Jesus. I grew up with a crack house across the street. Yeah, I'm a poor black child from the ghetto. These things make me different from you. But the things we have in common set me apart from most of the people in my community, and I am in between these two worlds with enough of my heart to fight for justice in the other.So how did things get so different for us? In the late '40s, my dad — a Pullman porter, son of a slave — bought a house in the Hunts Point section of the South Bronx, and a few years later, he married my mom. At the time, the community was a mostly white, working-class neighborhood. My dad was not alone. And as others like him pursued their own version of the American dream, white flight became common in the South Bronx and in many cities around the country. Red-lining was used by banks, wherein certain sections of the city, including ours, were deemed off-limits to any sort of investment. Many landlords believed it was more profitable to torch their buildings and collect insurance money rather than to sell under those conditions — dead or injured former tenants notwithstanding.Hunts Point was formerly a walk-to-work community, but now residents had neither work nor home to walk to. A national highway construction boom was added to our problems. In New York State, Robert Moses spearheaded an aggressive highway-expansion campaign. One of its primary goals was to make it easier for residents of wealthy communities in Westchester County to go to Manhattan. The South Bronx, which lies in between, did not stand a chance. Residents were often given less than a month's notice before their buildings were razed. 600,000 people were displaced. The common perception was that only pimps and pushers and prostitutes were from the South Bronx. And if you are told from your earliest days that nothing good is going to come from your community, that it's bad and ugly, how could it not reflect on you? So now, my family's property was worthless, save for that it was our home, and all we had. And luckily for me, that home and the love inside of it, along with help from teachers, mentors and friends along the way, was enough.Now, why is this story important? Because from a planning perspective, economic degradation begets environmental degradation, which begets social degradation. The disinvestment that began in the 1960s set the stage for all the environmental injustices that were to come. Antiquated zoning and land-use regulations are still used to this day to continue putting polluting facilities in my neighborhood. Are these factors taken into consideration when land-use policy is decided? What costs are associated with these decisions? And who pays? Who profits? Does anything justify what the local community goes through? This was "planning" — in quotes — that did not have our best interests in mind.Once we realized that, we decided it was time to do our own planning. That small park I told you about earlier was the first stage of building a Greenway movement in the South Bronx. I wrote a one-and-a-quarter-million dollar federal transportation grant to design the plan for a waterfront esplanade with dedicated on-street bike paths. Physical improvements help inform public policy regarding traffic safety, the placement of the waste and other facilities, which, if done properly, don't compromise a community's quality of life. They provide opportunities to be more physically active, as well as local economic development. Think bike shops, juice stands. We secured 20 million dollars to build first-phase projects. This is Lafayette Avenue — and that's redesigned by Mathews Nielsen Landscape Architects. And once this path is constructed, it'll connect the South Bronx with more than 400 acres of Randall's Island Park. Right now we're separated by about 25 feet of water, but this link will change that.As we nurture the natural environment, its abundance will give us back even more. We run a project called the Bronx [Environmental] Stewardship Training, which provides job training in the fields of ecological restoration, so that folks from our community have the skills to compete for these well-paying jobs. Little by little, we're seeding the area with green-collar jobs — and with people that have both a financial and personal stake in their environment. The Sheridan Expressway is an underutilized relic of the Robert Moses era, built with no regard for the neighborhoods that were divided by it. Even during rush hour, it goes virtually unused. The community created an alternative transportation plan that allows for the removal of the highway. We have the opportunity now to bring together all the stakeholders to re-envision how this 28 acres can be better utilized for parkland, affordable housing and local economic development.We also built New York City's first green and cool roof demonstration project on top of our offices. Cool roofs are highly-reflective surfaces that don't absorb solar heat, and pass it on to the building or atmosphere. Green roofs are soil and living plants. Both can be used instead of petroleum-based roofing materials that absorb heat, contribute to urban "heat island" effect and degrade under the sun, which we in turn breathe. Green roofs also retain up to 75 percent of rainfall, so they reduce a city's need to fund costly end-of-pipe solutions — which, incidentally, are often located in environmental justice communities like mine. And they provide habitats for our little friends![Butterfly](Laughter)So cool!Anyway, the demonstration project is a springboard for our own green roof installation business, bringing jobs and sustainable economic activity to the South Bronx.[Green is the new black ...](Laughter) (Applause)I like that, too.Anyway, I know Chris told us not to do pitches up here, but since I have all of your attention: We need investors. End of pitch. It's better to ask for forgiveness than permission. Anyway —(Laughter)(Applause)OK. Katrina.Prior to Katrina, the South Bronx and New Orleans' Ninth Ward had a lot in common. Both were largely populated by poor people of color, both hotbeds of cultural innovation: think hip-hop and jazz. Both are waterfront communities that host both industries and residents in close proximity of one another. In the post-Katrina era, we have still more in common. We're at best ignored, and maligned and abused, at worst, by negligent regulatory agencies, pernicious zoning and lax governmental accountability. Neither the destruction of the Ninth Ward nor the South Bronx was inevitable. But we have emerged with valuable lessons about how to dig ourselves out. We are more than simply national symbols of urban blight or problems to be solved by empty campaign promises of presidents come and gone. Now will we let the Gulf Coast languish for a decade or two, like the South Bronx did? Or will we take proactive steps and learn from the homegrown resource of grassroots activists that have been born of desperation in communities like mine?Now listen, I do not expect individuals, corporations or government to make the world a better place because it is right or moral. This presentation today only represents some of what I've been through. Like a tiny little bit. You've no clue. But I'll tell you later, if you want to know.(Laughter)But — I know it's the bottom line, or one's perception of it, that motivates people in the end. I'm interested in what I like to call the "triple bottom line" that sustainable development can produce. Developments that have the potential to create positive returns for all concerned: the developers, government and the community where these projects go up.At present, that's not happening in New York City. And we are operating with a comprehensive urban-planning deficit. A parade of government subsidies is going to propose big-box and stadium developments in the South Bronx, but there is scant coordination between city agencies on how to deal with the cumulative effects of increased traffic, pollution, solid waste and the impacts on open space. And their approaches to local economic and job development are so lame it's not even funny. Because on top of that, the world's richest sports team is replacing the House That Ruth Built by destroying two well-loved community parks. Now, we'll have even less than that stat I told you about earlier. And although less than 25 percent of South Bronx residents own cars, these projects include thousands of new parking spaces, yet zip in terms of mass public transit. Now, what's missing from the larger debate is a comprehensive cost-benefit analysis between not fixing an unhealthy, environmentally-challenged community, versus incorporating structural, sustainable changes. My agency is working closely with Columbia University and others to shine a light on these issues.Now let's get this straight: I am not anti-development. Ours is a city, not a wilderness preserve. And I've embraced my inner capitalist. And, but I don't have —(Laughter)You probably all have, and if you haven't, you need to.(Laughter)So I don't have a problem with developers making money. There's enough precedent out there to show that a sustainable, community-friendly development can still make a fortune. Fellow TEDsters Bill McDonough and Amory Lovins — both heroes of mine by the way — have shown that you can actually do that. I do have a problem with developments that hyper-exploit politically vulnerable communities for profit. That it continues is a shame upon us all, because we are all responsible for the future that we create. But one of the things I do to remind myself of greater possibilities, is to learn from visionaries in other cities. This is my version of globalization.Let's take Bogota. Poor, Latino, surrounded by runaway gun violence and drug trafficking; a reputation not unlike that of the South Bronx. However, this city was blessed in the late 1990s with a highly-influential mayor named Enrique Peñalosa. He looked at the demographics. Few Bogotanos own cars, yet a huge portion of the city's resources was dedicated to serving them. If you're a mayor, you can do something about that. His administration narrowed key municipal thoroughfares from five lanes to three, outlawed parking on those streets, expanded pedestrian walkways and bike lanes, created public plazas, created one of the most efficient bus mass-transit systems in the entire world. For his brilliant efforts, he was nearly impeached. But as people began to see that they were being put first on issues reflecting their day-to-day lives, incredible things happened. People stopped littering. Crime rates dropped, because the streets were alive with people. His administration attacked several typical urban problems at one time, and on a third-world budget, at that. We have no excuse in this country, I'm sorry. But the bottom line is: their people-first agenda was not meant to penalize those who could actually afford cars, but rather, to provide opportunities for all Bogotanos to participate in the city's resurgence. That development should not come at the expense of the majority of the population is still considered a radical idea here in the U.S. But Bogota's example has the power to change that.You, however, are blessed with the gift of influence. That's why you're here and why you value the information we exchange. Use your influence in support of comprehensive, sustainable change everywhere. Don't just talk about it at TED. This is a nationwide policy agenda I'm trying to build, and as you all know, politics are personal. Help me make green the new black. Help me make sustainability sexy. Make it a part of your dinner and cocktail conversations. Help me fight for environmental and economic justice. Support investments with a triple-bottom-line return. Help me democratize sustainability by bringing everyone to the table, and insisting that comprehensive planning can be addressed everywhere. Oh good, glad I have a little more time!Listen — when I spoke to Mr. Gore the other day after breakfast, I asked him how environmental justice activists were going to be included in his new marketing strategy. His response was a grant program. I don't think he understood that I wasn't asking for funding. I was making him an offer.(Applause)What troubled me was that this top-down approach is still around. Now, don't get me wrong, we need money.(Laughter)But grassroots groups are needed at the table during the decision-making process. Of the 90 percent of the energy that Mr. Gore reminded us that we waste every day, don't add wasting our energy, intelligence and hard-earned experience to that count.(Applause)I have come from so far to meet you like this. Please don't waste me. By working together, we can become one of those small, rapidly-growing groups of individuals who actually have the audacity and courage to believe that we actually can change the world. We might have come to this conference from very, very different stations in life, but believe me, we all share one incredibly powerful thing. We have nothing to lose and everything to gain.Ciao, bellos!(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:12.958 --> 00:00:14.364
If you're here today --

00:00:14.388 --> 00:00:16.322
and I'm very happy that you are --

00:00:16.346 --> 00:00:18.699
you've all heard about
how sustainable development

00:00:18.723 --> 00:00:20.685
will save us from ourselves.

00:00:20.709 --> 00:00:24.208
However, when we're not at TED,
we are often told

00:00:24.232 --> 00:00:28.141
that a real sustainability policy agenda
is just not feasible,

00:00:28.165 --> 00:00:30.934
especially in large urban areas
like New York City.

00:00:31.387 --> 00:00:34.623
And that's because most people
with decision-making powers,

00:00:34.647 --> 00:00:36.877
in both the public and the private sector,

00:00:36.901 --> 00:00:39.187
really don't feel
as though they're in danger.

00:00:39.536 --> 00:00:43.629
The reason why I'm here today,
in part, is because of a dog --

00:00:43.653 --> 00:00:46.931
an abandoned puppy I found
back in the rain, back in 1998.

00:00:46.955 --> 00:00:49.934
She turned out to be
a much bigger dog than I'd anticipated.

00:00:50.389 --> 00:00:54.364
When she came into my life, we were
fighting against a huge waste facility

00:00:54.388 --> 00:00:56.850
planned for the East River waterfront

00:00:56.874 --> 00:00:59.384
despite the fact that
our small part of New York City

00:00:59.408 --> 00:01:03.766
already handled more than 40 percent
of the entire city's commercial waste:

00:01:03.790 --> 00:01:08.934
a sewage treatment pelletizing plant,
a sewage sludge plant, four power plants,

00:01:08.958 --> 00:01:11.293
the world's largest
food-distribution center,

00:01:11.317 --> 00:01:15.499
as well as other industries that bring
more than 60,000 diesel truck trips

00:01:15.523 --> 00:01:16.679
to the area each week.

00:01:17.076 --> 00:01:21.044
The area also has one of the lowest ratios
of parks to people in the city.

00:01:21.068 --> 00:01:23.361
So when I was contacted
by the Parks Department

00:01:23.385 --> 00:01:27.543
about a $10,000 seed-grant initiative
to help develop waterfront projects,

00:01:27.567 --> 00:01:30.481
I thought they were really
well-meaning, but a bit naive.

00:01:30.505 --> 00:01:34.172
I'd lived in this area all my life,
and you could not get to the river,

00:01:34.196 --> 00:01:37.489
because of all the lovely facilities
that I mentioned earlier.

00:01:37.513 --> 00:01:39.773
Then, while jogging
with my dog one morning,

00:01:39.797 --> 00:01:42.908
she pulled me into what I thought
was just another illegal dump.

00:01:43.564 --> 00:01:47.341
There were weeds and piles of garbage
and other stuff that I won't mention here,

00:01:47.365 --> 00:01:48.579
but she kept dragging me,

00:01:48.603 --> 00:01:51.475
and lo and behold, at the end
of that lot was the river.

00:01:51.499 --> 00:01:53.600
I knew that this forgotten
little street-end,

00:01:53.624 --> 00:01:56.628
abandoned like the dog that brought
me there, was worth saving.

00:01:56.652 --> 00:01:59.248
And I knew it would grow
to become the proud beginnings

00:01:59.272 --> 00:02:02.256
of the community-led revitalization
of the new South Bronx.

00:02:02.280 --> 00:02:06.259
And just like my new dog, it was an idea
that got bigger than I'd imagined.

00:02:06.283 --> 00:02:08.418
We garnered much support along the way,

00:02:08.442 --> 00:02:11.602
and the Hunts Point Riverside Park
became the first waterfront park

00:02:11.626 --> 00:02:14.025
that the South Bronx had had
in more than 60 years.

00:02:14.049 --> 00:02:17.415
We leveraged that $10,000 seed grant
more than 300 times,

00:02:17.439 --> 00:02:19.679
into a $3 million park.

00:02:19.703 --> 00:02:24.631
And in the fall, I'm going to exchange
marriage vows with my beloved.

00:02:24.655 --> 00:02:25.655
(Audience whistles)

00:02:25.679 --> 00:02:26.947
Thank you very much.

00:02:26.971 --> 00:02:31.513
(Applause)

00:02:31.537 --> 00:02:34.934
That's him pressing my buttons
back there, which he does all the time.

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:37.422
(Laughter)

00:02:37.446 --> 00:02:40.763
(Applause)

00:02:40.787 --> 00:02:43.565
But those of us living
in environmental justice communities

00:02:43.589 --> 00:02:45.144
are the canary in the coal mine.

00:02:45.168 --> 00:02:48.579
We feel the problems right now,
and have for some time.

00:02:49.248 --> 00:02:52.934
Environmental justice, for those of you
who may not be familiar with the term,

00:02:52.958 --> 00:02:54.158
goes something like this:

00:02:54.182 --> 00:02:57.173
no community should be saddled
with more environmental burdens

00:02:57.197 --> 00:02:59.863
and less environmental benefits
than any other.

00:02:59.887 --> 00:03:03.934
Unfortunately, race and class
are extremely reliable indicators

00:03:03.958 --> 00:03:06.995
as to where one might find the good stuff,
like parks and trees,

00:03:07.019 --> 00:03:10.751
and where one might find the bad stuff,
like power plants and waste facilities.

00:03:10.775 --> 00:03:14.010
As a black person in America,
I am twice as likely as a white person

00:03:14.034 --> 00:03:17.631
to live in an area where air pollution
poses the greatest risk to my health.

00:03:17.655 --> 00:03:20.438
I am five times more likely
to live within walking distance

00:03:20.462 --> 00:03:22.371
of a power plant or chemical facility,

00:03:22.395 --> 00:03:23.552
which I do.

00:03:24.107 --> 00:03:26.738
These land-use decisions
created the hostile conditions

00:03:26.762 --> 00:03:29.754
that lead to problems like obesity,
diabetes and asthma.

00:03:29.778 --> 00:03:33.679
Why would someone leave their home to go
for a brisk walk in a toxic neighborhood?

00:03:33.703 --> 00:03:36.614
Our 27 percent obesity rate
is high even for this country,

00:03:36.638 --> 00:03:38.051
and diabetes comes with it.

00:03:38.075 --> 00:03:40.583
One out of four South Bronx
children has asthma.

00:03:40.607 --> 00:03:42.422
Our asthma hospitalization rate

00:03:42.446 --> 00:03:44.729
is seven times higher
than the national average.

00:03:44.753 --> 00:03:46.704
These impacts are coming everyone's way.

00:03:46.728 --> 00:03:48.934
And we all pay dearly
for solid waste costs,

00:03:48.958 --> 00:03:51.934
health problems associated
with pollution and more odiously,

00:03:51.958 --> 00:03:54.947
the cost of imprisoning
our young black and Latino men,

00:03:54.971 --> 00:03:57.726
who possess untold amounts
of untapped potential.

00:03:57.750 --> 00:04:00.830
Fifty percent of our residents
live at or below the poverty line;

00:04:00.854 --> 00:04:02.609
25 percent of us are unemployed.

00:04:02.633 --> 00:04:06.656
Low-income citizens often use
emergency-room visits as primary care.

00:04:06.680 --> 00:04:10.579
This comes at a high cost to taxpayers
and produces no proportional benefits.

00:04:10.603 --> 00:04:14.446
Poor people are not only still poor,
they are still unhealthy.

00:04:14.470 --> 00:04:18.255
Fortunately, there are many people
like me who are striving for solutions

00:04:18.279 --> 00:04:19.779
that won't compromise the lives

00:04:19.803 --> 00:04:22.303
of low-income communities of color
in the short term,

00:04:22.327 --> 00:04:24.433
and won't destroy us all in the long term.

00:04:24.457 --> 00:04:26.943
None of us want that,
and we all have that in common.

00:04:26.967 --> 00:04:28.606
So what else do we have in common?

00:04:28.630 --> 00:04:31.408
Well, first of all,
we're all incredibly good-looking.

00:04:31.432 --> 00:04:32.619
(Laughter)

00:04:32.643 --> 00:04:35.430
Graduated high school, college,
post-graduate degrees,

00:04:35.454 --> 00:04:38.766
traveled to interesting places,
didn't have kids in your early teens,

00:04:38.790 --> 00:04:41.408
financially stable, never been imprisoned.

00:04:42.646 --> 00:04:43.806
OK. Good.

00:04:43.830 --> 00:04:45.169
(Laughter)

00:04:45.193 --> 00:04:46.800
But, besides being a black woman,

00:04:46.824 --> 00:04:49.486
I am different from most of you
in some other ways.

00:04:49.510 --> 00:04:52.901
I watched nearly half of the buildings
in my neighborhood burn down.

00:04:52.925 --> 00:04:54.888
My big brother Lenny fought in Vietnam,

00:04:54.912 --> 00:04:57.817
only to be gunned down
a few blocks from our home.

00:05:00.950 --> 00:05:02.205
Jesus.

00:05:02.229 --> 00:05:05.175
I grew up with a crack house
across the street.

00:05:06.754 --> 00:05:09.453
Yeah, I'm a poor black child
from the ghetto.

00:05:10.742 --> 00:05:12.909
These things make me different from you.

00:05:12.933 --> 00:05:14.796
But the things we have in common

00:05:14.820 --> 00:05:17.559
set me apart from most
of the people in my community,

00:05:17.583 --> 00:05:19.409
and I am in between these two worlds

00:05:19.433 --> 00:05:22.320
with enough of my heart
to fight for justice in the other.

00:05:23.273 --> 00:05:25.281
So how did things get so different for us?

00:05:25.305 --> 00:05:28.636
In the late '40s, my dad --
a Pullman porter, son of a slave --

00:05:28.660 --> 00:05:31.527
bought a house in the Hunts Point
section of the South Bronx,

00:05:31.551 --> 00:05:33.566
and a few years later, he married my mom.

00:05:33.590 --> 00:05:37.071
At the time, the community was a mostly
white, working-class neighborhood.

00:05:37.095 --> 00:05:38.621
My dad was not alone.

00:05:38.645 --> 00:05:42.082
And as others like him pursued
their own version of the American dream,

00:05:42.106 --> 00:05:44.635
white flight became common
in the South Bronx

00:05:44.659 --> 00:05:46.659
and in many cities around the country.

00:05:46.976 --> 00:05:50.609
Red-lining was used by banks,
wherein certain sections of the city,

00:05:50.633 --> 00:05:54.622
including ours, were deemed
off-limits to any sort of investment.

00:05:54.646 --> 00:05:58.114
Many landlords believed it was more
profitable to torch their buildings

00:05:58.138 --> 00:06:02.309
and collect insurance money rather
than to sell under those conditions --

00:06:02.333 --> 00:06:04.773
dead or injured former tenants
notwithstanding.

00:06:04.797 --> 00:06:07.639
Hunts Point was formerly
a walk-to-work community,

00:06:07.663 --> 00:06:11.589
but now residents had neither
work nor home to walk to.

00:06:11.613 --> 00:06:14.799
A national highway construction boom
was added to our problems.

00:06:14.823 --> 00:06:15.974
In New York State,

00:06:15.998 --> 00:06:19.781
Robert Moses spearheaded
an aggressive highway-expansion campaign.

00:06:19.805 --> 00:06:22.001
One of its primary goals was
to make it easier

00:06:22.025 --> 00:06:27.050
for residents of wealthy communities
in Westchester County to go to Manhattan.

00:06:27.074 --> 00:06:30.149
The South Bronx, which lies in between,
did not stand a chance.

00:06:30.173 --> 00:06:32.723
Residents were often given
less than a month's notice

00:06:32.747 --> 00:06:34.377
before their buildings were razed.

00:06:34.401 --> 00:06:36.725
600,000 people were displaced.

00:06:36.749 --> 00:06:38.059
The common perception was

00:06:38.083 --> 00:06:41.934
that only pimps and pushers
and prostitutes were from the South Bronx.

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:44.888
And if you are told
from your earliest days

00:06:44.912 --> 00:06:47.529
that nothing good is going to come
from your community,

00:06:47.553 --> 00:06:48.704
that it's bad and ugly,

00:06:48.728 --> 00:06:50.818
how could it not reflect on you?

00:06:51.293 --> 00:06:53.811
So now, my family's property
was worthless,

00:06:53.835 --> 00:06:56.477
save for that it was our home,
and all we had.

00:06:56.501 --> 00:07:00.227
And luckily for me, that home
and the love inside of it,

00:07:00.251 --> 00:07:05.393
along with help from teachers, mentors
and friends along the way, was enough.

00:07:05.417 --> 00:07:07.106
Now, why is this story important?

00:07:07.130 --> 00:07:08.940
Because from a planning perspective,

00:07:08.964 --> 00:07:12.681
economic degradation
begets environmental degradation,

00:07:12.705 --> 00:07:15.221
which begets social degradation.

00:07:15.245 --> 00:07:18.308
The disinvestment that began
in the 1960s set the stage

00:07:18.332 --> 00:07:20.934
for all the environmental
injustices that were to come.

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:24.934
Antiquated zoning and land-use
regulations are still used to this day

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:28.001
to continue putting polluting
facilities in my neighborhood.

00:07:28.025 --> 00:07:31.803
Are these factors taken into consideration
when land-use policy is decided?

00:07:31.827 --> 00:07:34.423
What costs are associated
with these decisions?

00:07:34.447 --> 00:07:36.683
And who pays? Who profits?

00:07:36.707 --> 00:07:40.326
Does anything justify
what the local community goes through?

00:07:40.350 --> 00:07:42.644
This was "planning" -- in quotes --

00:07:42.668 --> 00:07:44.936
that did not have
our best interests in mind.

00:07:44.960 --> 00:07:48.375
Once we realized that, we decided
it was time to do our own planning.

00:07:48.399 --> 00:07:50.343
That small park I told you about earlier

00:07:50.367 --> 00:07:53.645
was the first stage of building
a Greenway movement in the South Bronx.

00:07:53.669 --> 00:07:57.021
I wrote a one-and-a-quarter-million
dollar federal transportation grant

00:07:57.045 --> 00:07:59.153
to design the plan
for a waterfront esplanade

00:07:59.177 --> 00:08:00.907
with dedicated on-street bike paths.

00:08:00.931 --> 00:08:04.389
Physical improvements help inform
public policy regarding traffic safety,

00:08:04.413 --> 00:08:06.658
the placement of the waste
and other facilities,

00:08:06.682 --> 00:08:10.154
which, if done properly, don't compromise
a community's quality of life.

00:08:10.178 --> 00:08:12.892
They provide opportunities
to be more physically active,

00:08:12.916 --> 00:08:15.349
as well as local economic development.

00:08:15.373 --> 00:08:16.945
Think bike shops, juice stands.

00:08:16.969 --> 00:08:19.840
We secured 20 million dollars
to build first-phase projects.

00:08:19.864 --> 00:08:21.738
This is Lafayette Avenue --

00:08:21.762 --> 00:08:24.919
and that's redesigned
by Mathews Nielsen Landscape Architects.

00:08:24.943 --> 00:08:27.964
And once this path is constructed,
it'll connect the South Bronx

00:08:27.988 --> 00:08:30.337
with more than 400 acres
of Randall's Island Park.

00:08:30.361 --> 00:08:34.335
Right now we're separated by about 25 feet
of water, but this link will change that.

00:08:34.359 --> 00:08:38.623
As we nurture the natural environment,
its abundance will give us back even more.

00:08:38.647 --> 00:08:42.458
We run a project called the Bronx
[Environmental] Stewardship Training,

00:08:42.482 --> 00:08:45.789
which provides job training in the fields
of ecological restoration,

00:08:45.813 --> 00:08:48.614
so that folks from our community
have the skills to compete

00:08:48.638 --> 00:08:49.977
for these well-paying jobs.

00:08:50.001 --> 00:08:53.338
Little by little, we're seeding
the area with green-collar jobs --

00:08:53.362 --> 00:08:56.221
and with people that have both
a financial and personal stake

00:08:56.245 --> 00:08:57.402
in their environment.

00:08:57.426 --> 00:09:00.069
The Sheridan Expressway
is an underutilized relic

00:09:00.093 --> 00:09:01.292
of the Robert Moses era,

00:09:01.316 --> 00:09:04.692
built with no regard for the neighborhoods
that were divided by it.

00:09:04.716 --> 00:09:07.485
Even during rush hour,
it goes virtually unused.

00:09:07.509 --> 00:09:10.181
The community created
an alternative transportation plan

00:09:10.205 --> 00:09:12.831
that allows for the removal
of the highway.

00:09:12.855 --> 00:09:15.978
We have the opportunity now to bring
together all the stakeholders

00:09:16.002 --> 00:09:18.590
to re-envision how this 28 acres
can be better utilized

00:09:18.614 --> 00:09:21.656
for parkland, affordable housing
and local economic development.

00:09:21.680 --> 00:09:26.507
We also built New York City's first green
and cool roof demonstration project

00:09:26.531 --> 00:09:27.919
on top of our offices.

00:09:27.943 --> 00:09:31.408
Cool roofs are highly-reflective
surfaces that don't absorb solar heat,

00:09:31.432 --> 00:09:33.535
and pass it on to
the building or atmosphere.

00:09:33.559 --> 00:09:35.591
Green roofs are soil and living plants.

00:09:35.615 --> 00:09:38.862
Both can be used instead
of petroleum-based roofing materials

00:09:38.886 --> 00:09:41.657
that absorb heat, contribute
to urban "heat island" effect

00:09:41.681 --> 00:09:43.006
and degrade under the sun,

00:09:43.030 --> 00:09:44.252
which we in turn breathe.

00:09:44.276 --> 00:09:46.934
Green roofs also retain
up to 75 percent of rainfall,

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:50.617
so they reduce a city's need to fund
costly end-of-pipe solutions --

00:09:50.641 --> 00:09:52.461
which, incidentally, are often located

00:09:52.485 --> 00:09:54.706
in environmental justice
communities like mine.

00:09:54.730 --> 00:09:58.030
And they provide habitats
for our little friends!

00:09:58.054 --> 00:09:59.211
[Butterfly]

00:09:59.235 --> 00:10:00.458
(Laughter)

00:10:00.482 --> 00:10:01.665
So cool!

00:10:01.689 --> 00:10:04.195
Anyway, the demonstration
project is a springboard

00:10:04.219 --> 00:10:06.343
for our own green roof
installation business,

00:10:06.367 --> 00:10:09.869
bringing jobs and sustainable
economic activity to the South Bronx.

00:10:09.893 --> 00:10:11.269
[Green is the new black ...]

00:10:11.293 --> 00:10:15.436
(Laughter) (Applause)

00:10:15.460 --> 00:10:17.111
I like that, too.

00:10:17.135 --> 00:10:20.831
Anyway, I know Chris told us
not to do pitches up here,

00:10:20.855 --> 00:10:22.735
but since I have all of your attention:

00:10:22.759 --> 00:10:24.346
We need investors. End of pitch.

00:10:24.370 --> 00:10:26.758
It's better to ask
for forgiveness than permission.

00:10:26.782 --> 00:10:27.938
Anyway --

00:10:27.962 --> 00:10:29.422
(Laughter)

00:10:29.446 --> 00:10:34.365
(Applause)

00:10:34.389 --> 00:10:36.652
OK. Katrina.

00:10:37.842 --> 00:10:40.866
Prior to Katrina, the South Bronx
and New Orleans' Ninth Ward

00:10:40.890 --> 00:10:42.079
had a lot in common.

00:10:42.103 --> 00:10:44.857
Both were largely populated
by poor people of color,

00:10:44.881 --> 00:10:48.176
both hotbeds of cultural innovation:
think hip-hop and jazz.

00:10:48.200 --> 00:10:51.534
Both are waterfront communities
that host both industries and residents

00:10:51.558 --> 00:10:53.444
in close proximity of one another.

00:10:53.468 --> 00:10:56.516
In the post-Katrina era,
we have still more in common.

00:10:56.540 --> 00:11:00.018
We're at best ignored,
and maligned and abused, at worst,

00:11:00.042 --> 00:11:03.389
by negligent regulatory agencies,
pernicious zoning

00:11:03.413 --> 00:11:05.586
and lax governmental accountability.

00:11:05.610 --> 00:11:10.038
Neither the destruction of the Ninth Ward
nor the South Bronx was inevitable.

00:11:10.062 --> 00:11:12.198
But we have emerged with valuable lessons

00:11:12.222 --> 00:11:14.495
about how to dig ourselves out.

00:11:14.519 --> 00:11:18.321
We are more than simply
national symbols of urban blight

00:11:18.345 --> 00:11:21.651
or problems to be solved
by empty campaign promises

00:11:21.675 --> 00:11:23.285
of presidents come and gone.

00:11:23.309 --> 00:11:26.128
Now will we let the Gulf Coast
languish for a decade or two,

00:11:26.152 --> 00:11:27.414
like the South Bronx did?

00:11:27.438 --> 00:11:28.922
Or will we take proactive steps

00:11:28.946 --> 00:11:31.883
and learn from the homegrown resource
of grassroots activists

00:11:31.907 --> 00:11:34.753
that have been born of desperation
in communities like mine?

00:11:34.777 --> 00:11:37.420
Now listen, I do not expect individuals,

00:11:37.444 --> 00:11:40.229
corporations or government
to make the world a better place

00:11:40.253 --> 00:11:42.077
because it is right or moral.

00:11:42.554 --> 00:11:46.834
This presentation today only represents
some of what I've been through.

00:11:46.858 --> 00:11:48.934
Like a tiny little bit. You've no clue.

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:51.054
But I'll tell you later,
if you want to know.

00:11:51.078 --> 00:11:52.143
(Laughter)

00:11:52.167 --> 00:11:56.457
But -- I know it's the bottom line,
or one's perception of it,

00:11:56.481 --> 00:11:58.217
that motivates people in the end.

00:11:58.241 --> 00:12:01.163
I'm interested in what I like to call
the "triple bottom line"

00:12:01.187 --> 00:12:03.411
that sustainable development can produce.

00:12:03.435 --> 00:12:07.357
Developments that have the potential
to create positive returns

00:12:07.381 --> 00:12:10.483
for all concerned:
the developers, government

00:12:10.507 --> 00:12:12.943
and the community
where these projects go up.

00:12:12.967 --> 00:12:15.507
At present, that's not happening
in New York City.

00:12:16.269 --> 00:12:19.934
And we are operating with a comprehensive
urban-planning deficit.

00:12:20.316 --> 00:12:22.411
A parade of government subsidies

00:12:22.435 --> 00:12:25.987
is going to propose big-box and stadium
developments in the South Bronx,

00:12:26.011 --> 00:12:29.094
but there is scant coordination
between city agencies

00:12:29.118 --> 00:12:32.868
on how to deal with the cumulative effects
of increased traffic, pollution,

00:12:32.892 --> 00:12:35.417
solid waste and the impacts on open space.

00:12:35.441 --> 00:12:39.821
And their approaches to local economic
and job development are so lame

00:12:39.845 --> 00:12:41.016
it's not even funny.

00:12:41.040 --> 00:12:43.239
Because on top of that,

00:12:43.263 --> 00:12:47.686
the world's richest sports team
is replacing the House That Ruth Built

00:12:47.710 --> 00:12:50.527
by destroying two
well-loved community parks.

00:12:50.551 --> 00:12:53.662
Now, we'll have even less
than that stat I told you about earlier.

00:12:53.686 --> 00:12:57.004
And although less than 25 percent
of South Bronx residents own cars,

00:12:57.028 --> 00:13:00.702
these projects include
thousands of new parking spaces,

00:13:00.726 --> 00:13:03.980
yet zip in terms of mass public transit.

00:13:04.004 --> 00:13:06.036
Now, what's missing from the larger debate

00:13:06.060 --> 00:13:07.989
is a comprehensive cost-benefit analysis

00:13:08.013 --> 00:13:11.412
between not fixing an unhealthy,
environmentally-challenged community,

00:13:11.436 --> 00:13:15.043
versus incorporating structural,
sustainable changes.

00:13:15.067 --> 00:13:18.298
My agency is working closely
with Columbia University and others

00:13:18.322 --> 00:13:19.908
to shine a light on these issues.

00:13:19.932 --> 00:13:23.131
Now let's get this straight:
I am not anti-development.

00:13:23.155 --> 00:13:25.563
Ours is a city, not a wilderness preserve.

00:13:25.587 --> 00:13:28.626
And I've embraced my inner capitalist.

00:13:28.650 --> 00:13:30.127
And, but I don't have --

00:13:30.151 --> 00:13:31.776
(Laughter)

00:13:31.800 --> 00:13:34.396
You probably all have,
and if you haven't, you need to.

00:13:34.420 --> 00:13:38.190
(Laughter)

00:13:38.214 --> 00:13:41.630
So I don't have a problem
with developers making money.

00:13:41.654 --> 00:13:44.604
There's enough precedent out there
to show that a sustainable,

00:13:44.628 --> 00:13:49.019
community-friendly development
can still make a fortune.

00:13:49.043 --> 00:13:52.115
Fellow TEDsters Bill McDonough
and Amory Lovins --

00:13:52.139 --> 00:13:56.108
both heroes of mine by the way --
have shown that you can actually do that.

00:13:56.132 --> 00:13:58.934
I do have a problem
with developments that hyper-exploit

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:01.125
politically vulnerable
communities for profit.

00:14:01.149 --> 00:14:03.997
That it continues is a shame upon us all,

00:14:04.021 --> 00:14:06.962
because we are all responsible
for the future that we create.

00:14:06.986 --> 00:14:10.233
But one of the things I do
to remind myself of greater possibilities,

00:14:10.257 --> 00:14:12.391
is to learn from visionaries
in other cities.

00:14:12.415 --> 00:14:14.447
This is my version of globalization.

00:14:14.471 --> 00:14:16.004
Let's take Bogota.

00:14:16.028 --> 00:14:19.821
Poor, Latino, surrounded by
runaway gun violence and drug trafficking;

00:14:19.845 --> 00:14:22.683
a reputation not unlike
that of the South Bronx.

00:14:22.707 --> 00:14:25.934
However, this city was blessed
in the late 1990s

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:29.982
with a highly-influential
mayor named Enrique Peñalosa.

00:14:30.006 --> 00:14:31.787
He looked at the demographics.

00:14:31.811 --> 00:14:33.542
Few Bogotanos own cars,

00:14:33.566 --> 00:14:37.604
yet a huge portion of the city's resources
was dedicated to serving them.

00:14:37.628 --> 00:14:40.013
If you're a mayor, you can
do something about that.

00:14:40.037 --> 00:14:44.293
His administration narrowed key municipal
thoroughfares from five lanes to three,

00:14:44.317 --> 00:14:46.580
outlawed parking on those streets,

00:14:46.604 --> 00:14:49.383
expanded pedestrian walkways
and bike lanes,

00:14:49.407 --> 00:14:51.338
created public plazas,

00:14:51.362 --> 00:14:54.229
created one of the most efficient
bus mass-transit systems

00:14:54.253 --> 00:14:55.735
in the entire world.

00:14:55.759 --> 00:14:59.533
For his brilliant efforts,
he was nearly impeached.

00:15:00.144 --> 00:15:03.850
But as people began to see
that they were being put first

00:15:03.874 --> 00:15:06.084
on issues reflecting
their day-to-day lives,

00:15:06.108 --> 00:15:07.439
incredible things happened.

00:15:07.463 --> 00:15:08.855
People stopped littering.

00:15:08.879 --> 00:15:12.764
Crime rates dropped, because the streets
were alive with people.

00:15:12.788 --> 00:15:16.667
His administration attacked several
typical urban problems at one time,

00:15:16.691 --> 00:15:18.802
and on a third-world budget, at that.

00:15:18.826 --> 00:15:21.525
We have no excuse
in this country, I'm sorry.

00:15:21.549 --> 00:15:24.390
But the bottom line is:
their people-first agenda

00:15:24.414 --> 00:15:28.328
was not meant to penalize
those who could actually afford cars,

00:15:28.352 --> 00:15:32.217
but rather, to provide opportunities
for all Bogotanos to participate

00:15:32.241 --> 00:15:33.863
in the city's resurgence.

00:15:33.887 --> 00:15:36.047
That development should not come

00:15:36.071 --> 00:15:38.658
at the expense of the majority
of the population

00:15:38.682 --> 00:15:41.452
is still considered
a radical idea here in the U.S.

00:15:41.476 --> 00:15:43.934
But Bogota's example
has the power to change that.

00:15:44.285 --> 00:15:47.778
You, however, are blessed
with the gift of influence.

00:15:47.802 --> 00:15:51.524
That's why you're here and why you
value the information we exchange.

00:15:51.548 --> 00:15:52.898
Use your influence

00:15:52.922 --> 00:15:56.222
in support of comprehensive,
sustainable change everywhere.

00:15:56.525 --> 00:15:58.220
Don't just talk about it at TED.

00:15:58.943 --> 00:16:03.053
This is a nationwide policy agenda
I'm trying to build,

00:16:03.077 --> 00:16:05.680
and as you all know,
politics are personal.

00:16:06.076 --> 00:16:08.050
Help me make green the new black.

00:16:08.550 --> 00:16:10.687
Help me make sustainability sexy.

00:16:10.711 --> 00:16:14.108
Make it a part of your dinner
and cocktail conversations.

00:16:14.132 --> 00:16:17.235
Help me fight for environmental
and economic justice.

00:16:17.259 --> 00:16:19.934
Support investments
with a triple-bottom-line return.

00:16:19.958 --> 00:16:24.498
Help me democratize sustainability
by bringing everyone to the table,

00:16:24.522 --> 00:16:27.871
and insisting that comprehensive
planning can be addressed everywhere.

00:16:27.895 --> 00:16:29.803
Oh good, glad I have a little more time!

00:16:29.827 --> 00:16:33.772
Listen -- when I spoke to Mr. Gore
the other day after breakfast,

00:16:33.796 --> 00:16:38.544
I asked him how environmental justice
activists were going to be included

00:16:38.568 --> 00:16:40.794
in his new marketing strategy.

00:16:40.818 --> 00:16:43.126
His response was a grant program.

00:16:44.650 --> 00:16:48.392
I don't think he understood
that I wasn't asking for funding.

00:16:50.694 --> 00:16:52.466
I was making him an offer.

00:16:54.191 --> 00:17:00.703
(Applause)

00:17:01.941 --> 00:17:06.305
What troubled me was that this
top-down approach is still around.

00:17:07.218 --> 00:17:09.108
Now, don't get me wrong, we need money.

00:17:09.132 --> 00:17:10.544
(Laughter)

00:17:10.568 --> 00:17:14.675
But grassroots groups
are needed at the table

00:17:14.699 --> 00:17:17.517
during the decision-making process.

00:17:17.541 --> 00:17:21.585
Of the 90 percent of the energy
that Mr. Gore reminded us

00:17:21.609 --> 00:17:23.031
that we waste every day,

00:17:23.055 --> 00:17:26.225
don't add wasting our energy, intelligence

00:17:26.249 --> 00:17:30.092
and hard-earned experience to that count.

00:17:30.116 --> 00:17:35.579
(Applause)

00:17:35.603 --> 00:17:42.071
I have come from so far
to meet you like this.

00:17:43.394 --> 00:17:45.769
Please don't waste me.

00:17:47.586 --> 00:17:48.740
By working together,

00:17:48.764 --> 00:17:53.742
we can become one of those small,
rapidly-growing groups of individuals

00:17:53.766 --> 00:17:55.973
who actually have the audacity and courage

00:17:55.997 --> 00:17:58.628
to believe that we actually
can change the world.

00:17:59.196 --> 00:18:00.966
We might have come to this conference

00:18:00.990 --> 00:18:03.522
from very, very different
stations in life,

00:18:03.546 --> 00:18:08.146
but believe me, we all share
one incredibly powerful thing.

00:18:10.475 --> 00:18:14.005
We have nothing to lose
and everything to gain.

00:18:15.633 --> 00:18:16.809
Ciao, bellos!

00:18:16.833 --> 00:18:23.301
(Applause)

title: The best stats you've ever seen
transcript: About 10 years ago, I took on the task to teach global development to Swedish undergraduate students. That was after having spent about 20 years together with African institutions studying hunger in Africa, so I was sort of expected to know a little about the world. And I started in our medical university, Karolinska Institute, an undergraduate course called Global Health. But when you get that opportunity, you get a little nervous. I thought, these students coming to us actually have the highest grade you can get in Swedish college systems — so I thought, maybe they know everything I'm going to teach them about. So I did a pre-test when they came. And one of the questions from which I learned a lot was this one: "Which country has the highest child mortality of these five pairs?"I put them together, so that in each pair of country, one has twice the child mortality of the other. And this means that it's much bigger a difference than the uncertainty of the data. I won't put you at a test here, but it's Turkey, which is highest there, Poland, Russia, Pakistan and South Africa. And these were the results of the Swedish students. I did it so I got the confidence interval, which is pretty narrow, and I got happy, of course: a 1.8 right answer out of five possible. That means that there was a place for a professor of international health and for my course.(Laughter)But one late night, when I was compiling the report, I really realized my discovery. I have shown that Swedish top students know statistically significantly less about the world than the chimpanzees.(Laughter)Because the chimpanzee would score half right if I gave them two bananas with Sri Lanka and Turkey. They would be right half of the cases. But the students are not there. The problem for me was not ignorance; it was preconceived ideas.I did also an unethical study of the professors of the Karolinska Institute, that hands out the Nobel Prize in Medicine, and they are on par with the chimpanzee there.(Laughter)This is where I realized that there was really a need to communicate, because the data of what's happening in the world and the child health of every country is very well aware.We did this software which displays it like this: every bubble here is a country. This country over here is China. This is India. The size of the bubble is the population, and on this axis here, I put fertility rate. Because my students, what they said when they looked upon the world, and I asked them, "What do you really think about the world?" Well, I first discovered that the textbook was Tintin, mainly.(Laughter)And they said, "The world is still 'we' and 'them.' And 'we' is Western world and 'them' is Third World." "And what do you mean with Western world?" I said. "Well, that's long life and small family, and Third World is short life and large family."So this is what I could display here. I put fertility rate here: number of children per woman: one, two, three, four, up to about eight children per woman. We have very good data since 1962 — 1960 about — on the size of families in all countries. The error margin is narrow. Here, I put life expectancy at birth, from 30 years in some countries up to about 70 years. And 1962, there was really a group of countries here that was industrialized countries, and they had small families and long lives. And these were the developing countries: they had large families and they had relatively short lives. Now, what has happened since 1962? We want to see the change. Are the students right? Is it still two types of countries? Or have these developing countries got smaller families and they live here? Or have they got longer lives and live up there?Let's see. We stopped the world then. This is all U.N. statistics that have been available. Here we go. Can you see there? It's China there, moving against better health there, improving there. All the green Latin American countries are moving towards smaller families. Your yellow ones here are the Arabic countries, and they get longer life, but not larger families. The Africans are the green here. They still remain here. This is India; Indonesia is moving on pretty fast.(Laughter)In the '80s here, you have Bangladesh still among the African countries. But now, Bangladesh — it's a miracle that happens in the '80s: the imams start to promote family planning. They move up into that corner. And in the '90s, we have the terrible HIV epidemic that takes down the life expectancy of the African countries and all the rest of them move up into the corner, where we have long lives and small family, and we have a completely new world.(Applause)(Applause ends)Let me make a comparison directly between the United States of America and Vietnam. 1964. America had small families and long life; Vietnam had large families and short lives. And this is what happens: the data during the war indicate that even with all the death, there was an improvement of life expectancy. By the end of the year, the family planning started in Vietnam; they went for smaller families. And the United States up there is getting for longer life, keeping family size. And in the '80s now, they give up Communist planning and they go for market economy, and it moves faster even than social life. And today, we have in Vietnam the same life expectancy and the same family size here in Vietnam, 2003, as in United States, 1974, by the end of the war. If we don't look in the data, I think we all underestimate the tremendous change in Asia, which was in social change before we saw the economical change.Let's move over to another way here in which we could display the distribution in the world of the income. This is the world distribution of income of people. One dollar, 10 dollars or 100 dollars per day. There's no gap between rich and poor any longer. This is a myth. There's a little hump here. But there are people all the way. And if we look where the income ends up, this is 100 percent the world's annual income. And the richest 20 percent, they take out of that about 74 percent. And the poorest 20 percent, they take about two percent. And this shows that the concept of developing countries is extremely doubtful. We think about aid, like these people here giving aid to these people here. But in the middle, we have most of the world population, and they have now 24 percent of the income.We heard it in other forms. And who are these? Where are the different countries? I can show you Africa. This is Africa. 10% the world population, most in poverty. This is OECD. The rich country. The country club of the U.N. And they are over here on this side. Quite an overlap between Africa and OECD. And this is Latin America. It has everything on this Earth, from the poorest to the richest in Latin America. And on top of that, we can put East Europe, we can put East Asia, and we put South Asia.And how did it look like if we go back in time, to about 1970? Then there was more of a hump. And we have most who lived in absolute poverty were Asians. The problem in the world was the poverty in Asia. And if I now let the world move forward, you will see that while population increases, there are hundreds of millions in Asia getting out of poverty and some others getting into poverty, and this is the pattern we have today. And the best projection from the World Bank is that this will happen, and we will not have a divided world. We'll have most people in the middle.Of course it's a logarithmic scale here, but our concept of economy is growth with percent. We look upon it as a possibility of percentile increase. If I change this, and take GDP per capita instead of family income, and I turn these individual data into regional data of gross domestic product, and I take the regions down here, the size of the bubble is still the population. And you have the OECD there, and you have sub-Saharan Africa there, and we take off the Arab states there, coming both from Africa and from Asia, and we put them separately, and we can expand this axis, and I can give it a new dimension here, by adding the social values there, child survival. Now I have money on that axis, and I have the possibility of children to survive there. In some countries, 99.7% of children survive to five years of age; others, only 70. And here, it seems, there is a gap between OECD, Latin America, East Europe, East Asia, Arab states, South Asia and sub-Saharan Africa. The linearity is very strong between child survival and money.But let me split sub-Saharan Africa. Health is there and better health is up there. I can go here and I can split sub-Saharan Africa into its countries. And when it burst, the size of its country bubble is the size of the population. Sierra Leone down there. Mauritius is up there. Mauritius was the first country to get away with trade barriers, and they could sell their sugar — they could sell their textiles — on equal terms as the people in Europe and North America.There's a huge difference between Africa. And Ghana is here in the middle. In Sierra Leone, humanitarian aid. Here in Uganda, development aid. Here, time to invest; there, you can go for a holiday. It's a tremendous variation within Africa which we rarely often make — that it's equal everything. I can split South Asia here. India's the big bubble in the middle. But a huge difference between Afghanistan and Sri Lanka. I can split Arab states. How are they? Same climate, same culture, same religion — huge difference. Even between neighbors. Yemen, civil war. United Arab Emirates, money, which was quite equally and well used. Not as the myth is. And that includes all the children of the foreign workers who are in the country.Data is often better than you think. Many people say data is bad. There is an uncertainty margin, but we can see the difference here: Cambodia, Singapore. The differences are much bigger than the weakness of the data. East Europe: Soviet economy for a long time, but they come out after 10 years very, very differently. And there is Latin America. Today, we don't have to go to Cuba to find a healthy country in Latin America. Chile will have a lower child mortality than Cuba within some few years from now. Here, we have high-income countries in the OECD.And we get the whole pattern here of the world, which is more or less like this. And if we look at it, how the world looks, in 1960, it starts to move. This is Mao Tse-tung. He brought health to China. And then he died. And then Deng Xiaoping came and brought money to China, and brought them into the mainstream again. And we have seen how countries move in different directions like this, so it's sort of difficult to get an example country which shows the pattern of the world.But I would like to bring you back to about here, at 1960. I would like to compare South Korea, which is this one, with Brazil, which is this one. The label went away for me here. And I would like to compare Uganda, which is there. And I can run it forward, like this. And you can see how South Korea is making a very, very fast advancement, whereas Brazil is much slower.And if we move back again, here, and we put on trails on them, like this, you can see again that the speed of development is very, very different, and the countries are moving more or less in the same rate as money and health, but it seems you can move much faster if you are healthy first than if you are wealthy first. And to show that, you can put on the way of United Arab Emirates. They came from here, a mineral country. They cached all the oil; they got all the money; but health cannot be bought at the supermarket. You have to invest in health. You have to get kids into schooling. You have to train health staff.
