00:03:27.966 --> 00:03:31.146
And what we saw were buildings
that were very generic, and worse --

00:03:31.170 --> 00:03:32.868
not only were they very generic --

00:03:32.892 --> 00:03:35.634
so, not only does the reading room
look like the copy room

00:03:35.658 --> 00:03:37.156
look like the magazine area --

00:03:37.180 --> 00:03:40.906
but it meant that whatever issue
was troubling the library at that moment

00:03:40.930 --> 00:03:44.445
was starting to engulf every other
activity that was happening in it.

00:03:44.469 --> 00:03:46.718
And in this case,
what was getting engulfed

00:03:46.742 --> 00:03:49.758
were these social responsibilities
by the expansion of the book.

00:03:49.782 --> 00:03:51.997
And so we proposed
what's at the lower diagram.

00:03:52.021 --> 00:03:55.108
Very dumb approach:
simply compartmentalize.

00:03:55.132 --> 00:03:57.585
Put those things whose evolution
we could predict --

00:03:57.609 --> 00:04:01.192
and I don't mean that we could say
what would actually happen in the future,

00:04:01.216 --> 00:04:05.102
but we have some certainty of the spectrum
of what would happen in the future --

00:04:05.126 --> 00:04:07.376
put those in boxes designed
specifically for it,

00:04:07.400 --> 00:04:10.094
and put the things that we can't
predict on the rooftops.

00:04:10.118 --> 00:04:11.365
So that was the core idea.

00:04:11.389 --> 00:04:13.083
Now, we had to convince the library

00:04:13.107 --> 00:04:16.773
that social roles were
equally important to media,

00:04:16.797 --> 00:04:18.576
in order to get them to accept this.

00:04:18.600 --> 00:04:21.600
What you're seeing here is actually
their program on the left.

00:04:21.624 --> 00:04:25.661
That's as it was given to us
in all of its clarity and glory.

00:04:25.685 --> 00:04:29.973
Our first operation was to re-digest it
back to them, show it to them and say,

00:04:29.997 --> 00:04:31.934
"You know what? We haven't touched it,

00:04:31.958 --> 00:04:35.345
but only one-third of your own program
is dedicated to media and books.

00:04:35.369 --> 00:04:37.318
Two-thirds of it is already dedicated --

00:04:37.342 --> 00:04:40.453
that's the white band below,
the thing you said isn't important --

00:04:40.477 --> 00:04:42.486
is already dedicated to social functions."

00:04:42.510 --> 00:04:44.691
So once we had presented
that back to them,

00:04:44.715 --> 00:04:47.286
they agreed that this sort
of core concept could work.

00:04:47.310 --> 00:04:49.664
We got the right to go back
to first principles --

00:04:49.688 --> 00:04:50.898
that's the third diagram.

00:04:50.922 --> 00:04:52.128
We recombined everything.

00:04:52.152 --> 00:04:54.110
And then we started making new decisions.

00:04:54.134 --> 00:04:57.007
What you're seeing on the right
is the design of the library,

00:04:57.031 --> 00:04:58.952
specifically in terms of square footage.

00:04:58.976 --> 00:05:03.934
On the left of that diagram, here,
you'll see a series of five platforms --

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:05.934
sort of combs, collective programs.

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:08.363
And on the right are the more
indeterminate spaces;

00:05:08.387 --> 00:05:09.638
things like reading rooms,

00:05:09.662 --> 00:05:12.347
whose evolution in 20, 30, 40 years
we can't predict.

00:05:12.371 --> 00:05:14.680
So that literally was the design
of the building.

00:05:14.704 --> 00:05:16.839
They signed it, and to their chagrin,

00:05:16.863 --> 00:05:19.934
we came back a week later,
and we presented them this.

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:22.855
And as you can see, it is literally
the diagram on the right.

00:05:22.879 --> 00:05:23.880
(Laughter)

00:05:23.904 --> 00:05:26.334
We just sized -- no, really,
I mean that, literally.

00:05:26.358 --> 00:05:28.720
The things on the left-hand side
of the diagram,

00:05:28.744 --> 00:05:29.934
those are the boxes.

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:32.887
We sized them into five compartments.
They're super-efficient.

00:05:32.911 --> 00:05:34.783
We had a very low budget to work with.

00:05:34.807 --> 00:05:36.387
We pushed them around on the site

00:05:36.411 --> 00:05:38.624
to make very literal
contextual relationships.

00:05:38.648 --> 00:05:40.961
The reading room
should be able to see the water.

00:05:40.985 --> 00:05:43.766
The main entrance should have
a public plaza in front of it

00:05:43.790 --> 00:05:45.911
to abide by the zoning code, and so forth.

00:05:46.355 --> 00:05:48.808
So, you see the five platforms,
those are the boxes.

00:05:48.832 --> 00:05:51.261
within each one, a very discrete
thing is happening.

00:05:51.285 --> 00:05:53.632
The area in between
is sort of an urban continuum,

00:05:53.656 --> 00:05:57.006
these things that we can't predict
their evolution to the same degree.

00:05:57.448 --> 00:05:59.934
To give you some sense
of the power of this idea,

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:02.934
the biggest block
is what we call the book spiral.

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:05.292
It's literally built
in a very inexpensive way --

00:06:05.316 --> 00:06:07.934
it is a parking garage for books.

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:11.445
It just so happens to be on the 6th
through 10th floors of the building,

00:06:11.469 --> 00:06:14.744
but that is not necessarily
an expensive approach.

00:06:14.768 --> 00:06:17.594
And it allows us to organize
the entire Dewey Decimal System

00:06:17.618 --> 00:06:21.489
on one continuous run; no matter how it
grows or contracts within the building,

00:06:21.513 --> 00:06:25.934
it will always have its clarity
to end the sort of trail of tears

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:28.687
that we've all experienced
in public libraries.

00:06:28.711 --> 00:06:29.934
(Laughter)

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:31.689
And so this was the final operation,

00:06:31.713 --> 00:06:34.834
which was to take these blocks
as they were all pushed off kilter,

00:06:34.858 --> 00:06:36.934
and to hold onto them with a skin.

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:39.934
That skin serves double duty,
again, for economics.

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:42.934
One, it is the lateral stability
for the entire building;

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:44.220
it's a structural element.

00:06:44.244 --> 00:06:46.871
But its dimensions were designed
not only for structure,

00:06:46.895 --> 00:06:49.146
but also for holding on
every piece of glass.

00:06:49.170 --> 00:06:51.934
The glass was then --
I'll use the word impregnated --

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:55.370
but it had a layer of metal
that was called "stretched metal."

00:06:55.394 --> 00:06:57.232
That metal acts as a microlouver,

00:06:57.256 --> 00:07:00.637
so from the exterior of the building,
the sun sees it as totally opaque,

00:07:00.661 --> 00:07:03.335
but from the interior,
it's entirely transparent.

00:07:03.359 --> 00:07:06.106
So now I'm going to take you
on a tour of the building.

00:07:06.829 --> 00:07:08.203
Let me see if I can find it.

00:07:08.227 --> 00:07:11.496
For anyone who gets
motion sickness, I apologize.

00:07:12.191 --> 00:07:13.619
So, this is the building.

00:07:15.987 --> 00:07:19.844
And I think what's important is,
when we first unveiled the building,

00:07:19.868 --> 00:07:23.934
the public saw it as being
totally about our whim and ego.

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:26.800
And it was defended,
believe it or not, by the librarians.

00:07:26.824 --> 00:07:28.848
They said, "Look,
we don't know what it is,

00:07:28.872 --> 00:07:31.237
but we know it's everything
that we need it to be,

00:07:31.261 --> 00:07:34.397
based on the observations
that we've done about the program."

00:07:37.043 --> 00:07:39.027
This is going into one of the entries.

00:07:39.051 --> 00:07:42.412
So, it's an unusual building
for a public library, obviously.

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:49.559
So now we're going
into what we call the living room.

00:07:49.583 --> 00:07:52.455
This is actually a program
that we invented with the library.

00:07:52.479 --> 00:07:54.396
It was recognizing that public libraries

00:07:54.420 --> 00:07:57.205
are the last vestige of public free space.

00:07:57.229 --> 00:08:00.657
There are plenty of shopping malls
that allow you to get out of the rain

00:08:00.681 --> 00:08:01.837
in downtown Seattle,

00:08:01.861 --> 00:08:04.788
but there are not so many free places

00:08:04.812 --> 00:08:06.633
that allow you to get out of the rain.

00:08:06.657 --> 00:08:10.243
So this was an unprogrammed area where
people could pretty much do anything,

00:08:10.267 --> 00:08:12.376
including eat, yell,
play chess and so forth.

00:08:12.400 --> 00:08:16.406
Now we're moving up into what we call
the mixing chamber.

00:08:16.430 --> 00:08:19.358
That was the main
technology area in the building.

00:08:19.382 --> 00:08:21.958
You'll have to tell me
if I'm going too fast for you.

00:08:26.159 --> 00:08:27.309
And now up.

00:08:32.524 --> 00:08:35.153
This is actually the place
that we put into the building

00:08:35.177 --> 00:08:37.210
so I could propose
to my wife, right there.

00:08:37.234 --> 00:08:39.353
(Laughter)

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:41.117
She said yes.

00:08:41.141 --> 00:08:43.141
(Laughter)

00:08:44.551 --> 00:08:47.132
I'm running out of time,
so I'm actually going to stop.

00:08:47.156 --> 00:08:48.934
I can show this to you later.

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:52.241
But let's see if I can very quickly
get into the book spiral,

00:08:52.265 --> 00:08:54.329
because I think it's,
as I said, the most --

00:08:54.353 --> 00:08:57.670
this is the main reading room --
the most unique part of the building.

00:08:58.726 --> 00:08:59.892
You dizzy yet?

00:09:01.099 --> 00:09:02.924
Ok, so here, this is the book spiral.

00:09:08.353 --> 00:09:10.286
So, it's very indiscernible,

00:09:10.310 --> 00:09:13.811
but it's actually
a continuous stair-stepping.

00:09:13.835 --> 00:09:15.827
It allows you to, on one city block,

00:09:15.851 --> 00:09:18.546
go up one full floor,
so that it's on a continuum.

00:09:23.449 --> 00:09:26.934
Ok, now I'm going to go back,
and I'm going to hit a second project.

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:29.221
I'm going to go very,
very quickly through this.

00:09:29.245 --> 00:09:30.925
Now this is the Dallas Theater.

00:09:30.949 --> 00:09:34.297
It was an unusual client for us,
because they came to us and they said,

00:09:34.321 --> 00:09:36.027
"We need you to do a new building.

00:09:36.051 --> 00:09:39.477
We've been working
in a temporary space for 30 years,

00:09:39.501 --> 00:09:41.224
but because of that temporary space,

00:09:41.248 --> 00:09:44.111
we've become an infamous theater company.

00:09:44.135 --> 00:09:47.096
Theater is really focused in New York,
Chicago and Seattle,

00:09:47.120 --> 00:09:50.217
with the exception
of the Dallas Theater Company."

00:09:50.241 --> 00:09:52.937
And the very fact that they worked
in a provisional space

00:09:52.961 --> 00:09:55.404
meant that for Beckett,
they could blow out a wall;

00:09:55.428 --> 00:09:59.170
they could do "Cherry Orchard" and blow
a hole through the floor, and so forth.

00:09:59.194 --> 00:10:02.226
So it was a very daunting task
for us to do a brand-new building

00:10:02.250 --> 00:10:04.304
that could be a pristine building,

00:10:04.328 --> 00:10:06.347
but keep this kind of experimental nature.

00:10:06.371 --> 00:10:07.569
And the second is,

00:10:07.593 --> 00:10:10.471
they were what we call
a multi-form theater,

00:10:10.495 --> 00:10:13.101
they do different kinds
of performances in repertory.

00:10:13.125 --> 00:10:15.934
So they in the morning
will do something in arena,

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:18.451
then they'll do something
in proscenium and so forth.

00:10:18.475 --> 00:10:20.824
And so they needed to be able
to quickly transform

00:10:20.848 --> 00:10:22.774
between different theater organizations,

00:10:22.798 --> 00:10:24.483
and for operational budget reasons,

00:10:24.507 --> 00:10:26.670
this actually no longer
happens in pretty much

00:10:26.694 --> 00:10:28.934
any multi-form theater
in the United States,

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:31.433
so we needed to figure out
a way to overcome that.

00:10:31.457 --> 00:10:34.280
So our thought was to literally
put the theater on its head:

00:10:34.304 --> 00:10:36.614
to take those things
that were previously defined

00:10:36.638 --> 00:10:38.313
as front-of-house and back-of-house

00:10:38.337 --> 00:10:40.345
and stack them above house
and below house,

00:10:40.369 --> 00:10:42.568
and to create what we called
a theater machine.

00:10:42.592 --> 00:10:45.075
We invest the money
in the operation of the building.

00:10:45.099 --> 00:10:47.921
It's almost as though the building
could be placed anywhere,

00:10:47.945 --> 00:10:49.097
wherever you place it,

00:10:49.121 --> 00:10:51.851
the area under it is charged
for theatrical performances.

00:10:51.875 --> 00:10:54.197
And it allowed us to go back
to first principles,

00:10:54.221 --> 00:10:57.803
and redefine fly tower, acoustic
enclosure, light enclosure and so forth.

00:10:57.827 --> 00:10:59.297
And at the push of a button,

00:10:59.321 --> 00:11:02.948
it allows the artistic director
to move between proscenium, thrust,

00:11:02.972 --> 00:11:06.763
and in fact, arena
and traverse and flat floor,

00:11:06.787 --> 00:11:09.182
in a very quick transfiguration.

00:11:09.206 --> 00:11:12.628
So in fact, using
operational budget, we can --

00:11:12.652 --> 00:11:14.844
sorry, capital cost --
we can actually achieve

00:11:14.868 --> 00:11:17.339
what was no longer achievable
in operational cost.

00:11:17.856 --> 00:11:19.809
And that means that the artistic director

00:11:19.833 --> 00:11:22.198
now has a palette that he or she
can choose from,

00:11:22.222 --> 00:11:25.720
between a series of forms
and a series of processions,

00:11:25.744 --> 00:11:28.868
because that enclosure around the theater
that is normally trapped

00:11:28.892 --> 00:11:31.934
with front-of-house and back-of-house
spaces has been liberated.

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:35.227
So an artistic director has the ability
to have a performance

00:11:35.251 --> 00:11:37.366
that enters in a Wagnerian procession,

00:11:37.390 --> 00:11:39.725
shows the first act in thrust,

00:11:39.749 --> 00:11:42.934
the intermission in a Greek procession,

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:44.776
second act in arena, and so forth.

00:11:45.212 --> 00:11:47.563
So I'm going to show you
what this actually means.

00:11:47.587 --> 00:11:49.355
This is the theater up close.

00:11:49.379 --> 00:11:52.465
Any portion around the theater
actually can be opened discretely.

00:11:54.473 --> 00:11:58.371
The light enclosure can be lifted
separate to the acoustic enclosure,

00:11:58.395 --> 00:12:00.879
so you can do Beckett
with Dallas as the backdrop.

00:12:02.104 --> 00:12:03.269
Portions can be opened,

00:12:03.293 --> 00:12:06.936
so you can now actually have motorcycles
drive directly into the performance,

00:12:06.960 --> 00:12:09.362
or you can even just have
an open-air performance,

00:12:09.386 --> 00:12:10.552
or for intermissions.

00:12:11.052 --> 00:12:13.785
The balconies all move to go
between those configurations,

00:12:13.809 --> 00:12:15.094
but they also disappear.

00:12:15.475 --> 00:12:17.595
The proscenium line can also disappear.

00:12:18.087 --> 00:12:19.928
You can bring enormous objects in,

00:12:19.952 --> 00:12:21.943
so in fact, the Dallas Theater Company --

00:12:21.967 --> 00:12:24.618
their first show will be a play
about Charles Lindbergh,

00:12:24.642 --> 00:12:26.934
and they'll want to bring in
a real aircraft.

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:29.569
And then it also provides them,
in the off-season,

00:12:29.593 --> 00:12:34.799
the ability to actually rent out
their space for entirely different things.

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:38.613
This is it from a distance.

00:12:40.879 --> 00:12:43.867
Open up entire portions
for different kinds of events.

00:12:43.891 --> 00:12:45.042
And at night.

00:12:47.050 --> 00:12:50.928
Again, remove the light enclosure;
keep the acoustic enclosure.

00:12:51.634 --> 00:12:53.512
This is a monster truck show.

00:12:53.536 --> 00:12:55.427
I'm going to show now the last project.

00:12:55.451 --> 00:12:56.934
This also is an unusual client.

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:59.431
They inverted the whole idea
of development.

00:12:59.455 --> 00:13:02.282
They came to us and they said --
unlike normal developers --

00:13:02.306 --> 00:13:03.843
they said, "We want to start out

00:13:03.867 --> 00:13:06.616
by providing a contemporary
art museum in Louisville.

00:13:06.640 --> 00:13:07.844
That's our main goal."

00:13:07.868 --> 00:13:11.463
And so instead of being a developer
that sees an opportunity to make money,

00:13:11.487 --> 00:13:14.508
they saw an ability to be
a catalyst in their downtown.

00:13:14.532 --> 00:13:18.112
And the fact that they wanted to support
the contemporary art museum

00:13:18.136 --> 00:13:19.693
actually built their pro forma,

00:13:19.717 --> 00:13:21.034
so they worked in reverse.

00:13:21.389 --> 00:13:22.934
And that pro forma led us

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:25.934
to a mixed-use building
that was very large,

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:28.262
in order to support
their aspirations of the art,

00:13:28.286 --> 00:13:30.833
but it also opened up opportunities
for the art itself

00:13:30.857 --> 00:13:33.077
to collaborate, interact
with commercial spaces

00:13:33.101 --> 00:13:35.861
that actually artists more
and more want to work within.

00:13:36.314 --> 00:13:39.339
And it also charged us
with thinking about how to have

00:13:39.363 --> 00:13:41.327
something that was both a single building

00:13:41.351 --> 00:13:43.934
and a credible sort of sub-building.

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:46.501
So this is Louisville's skyline,

00:13:46.525 --> 00:13:49.205
and I'm going to take
you through the various constraints

00:13:49.229 --> 00:13:50.422
that led to the project.

00:13:50.446 --> 00:13:51.985
First: the physical constraints.

00:13:52.009 --> 00:13:54.410
We actually had to operate
on three discrete sites,

00:13:54.434 --> 00:13:57.315
all of them well smaller
than the size of the building.

00:13:57.339 --> 00:14:01.022
We had to operate next to the new
Muhammad Ali Center, and respect it.

00:14:01.046 --> 00:14:03.344
We had to operate
within the 100-year floodplain.

00:14:03.368 --> 00:14:05.683
Now, this area floods
three to four times a year,

00:14:05.707 --> 00:14:07.444
and there's a levee behind our site,

00:14:07.468 --> 00:14:09.748
similar to the ones
that broke in New Orleans.

00:14:10.645 --> 00:14:14.847
Had to operate behind the I-64 corridor,

00:14:14.871 --> 00:14:17.787
a street that cuts through the middle
of these separate sites.

00:14:17.811 --> 00:14:22.377
So we're starting to build a sort of
nightmare of constraints in a bathtub.

00:14:22.401 --> 00:14:25.790
Underneath the bathtub
are the city's main power lines.

00:14:26.657 --> 00:14:29.458
And there is a pedestrian corridor
that they wanted to add,

00:14:29.482 --> 00:14:32.432
that would link a series
of cultural buildings,

00:14:32.456 --> 00:14:35.422
and a view corridor --
because this is the historic district --

00:14:35.446 --> 00:14:37.994
that they didn't want to obstruct
with a new building.

00:14:38.018 --> 00:14:39.058
(Laughter)

00:14:39.082 --> 00:14:41.655
And now we're going to add
1.1 million square feet.

00:14:42.083 --> 00:14:45.298
And if we did the traditional thing,
that 1.1 million square feet --

00:14:45.322 --> 00:14:46.994
these are the different programs --

00:14:47.018 --> 00:14:50.982
the traditional thing would be to identify
the public elements, place them on sites,

00:14:51.006 --> 00:14:53.181
and now we'd have a really
terrible situation:

00:14:53.205 --> 00:14:55.934
a public thing in the middle
of a bathtub that floods.

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:59.555
And then we would size
all the other elements --

00:14:59.579 --> 00:15:01.234
the different commercial elements:

00:15:01.258 --> 00:15:03.401
hotel, luxury housing,
offices and so forth --

00:15:03.425 --> 00:15:04.630
and dump it on top.

00:15:04.654 --> 00:15:07.618
And we would create
something that was unviable.

00:15:07.642 --> 00:15:11.387
In fact -- and you know this -- this
is called the Time Warner Building.

00:15:11.411 --> 00:15:13.085
(Laughter)

00:15:13.109 --> 00:15:14.934
So our strategy was very simple.

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:18.069
Just lift the entire block,

00:15:18.093 --> 00:15:19.728
flip some of the elements over,

00:15:19.752 --> 00:15:22.562
reposition them
so they have appropriate views

00:15:22.586 --> 00:15:24.222
and relationships to downtown,

00:15:24.246 --> 00:15:27.699
and make circulation connections
and reroute the road.

00:15:27.723 --> 00:15:29.250
So that's the basic concept,

00:15:29.274 --> 00:15:31.604
and now I'm going to show you
what it leads to.

00:15:32.874 --> 00:15:35.429
Ok, it seems a very formal,
willful gesture,

00:15:35.453 --> 00:15:38.001
but something derived entirely
out of the constraints.

00:15:38.025 --> 00:15:41.006
And again, when we unveiled it,
there was a sort of nervousness

00:15:41.030 --> 00:15:43.467
that this was about an architect
making a statement,

00:15:43.491 --> 00:15:47.083
not an architect who was attempting
to solve a series of problems.

00:15:47.107 --> 00:15:49.401
Now, within that center zone, as I said,

00:15:49.425 --> 00:15:51.580
we have the ability to mix
a series of things.

00:15:51.604 --> 00:15:54.327
So here, this is sort of an x-ray --

00:15:54.351 --> 00:15:56.286
the towers are totally developer-driven.

00:15:56.310 --> 00:15:58.760
They told us the dimensions,
the sizes and so forth,

00:15:58.784 --> 00:16:01.281
and we focused on taking
all the public components --

00:16:01.305 --> 00:16:02.597
the lobbies, the bars --

00:16:02.621 --> 00:16:05.934
everything that different commercial
elements would have,

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:08.934
and combined it in the center,
in the sort of subway map,

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:12.676
in the transfer zone that would also
include the contemporary art museum.

00:16:12.700 --> 00:16:16.765
So it creates a situation like this,
where you have artists who can operate

00:16:16.789 --> 00:16:20.667
within an art space that also has
an amazing view on the 22nd floor,

00:16:20.691 --> 00:16:24.148
but it also has proximity that the curator
can either open or close.

00:16:24.172 --> 00:16:27.378
It allows people
on exercise bicycles to be seen,

00:16:27.402 --> 00:16:29.077
or to see the art, and so forth.

00:16:29.101 --> 00:16:32.821
It also means that if an artist wants
to invade something like a swimming pool,

00:16:32.845 --> 00:16:35.555
they can begin to do their exhibition
in a swimming pool,

00:16:35.579 --> 00:16:38.216
so they're not forced to always
work within the confines

00:16:38.240 --> 00:16:39.775
of a contemporary gallery space.

00:16:39.799 --> 00:16:40.966
So, how to build this.

00:16:40.990 --> 00:16:42.934
It's very simple: it's a chair.

00:16:42.958 --> 00:16:46.390
So, we begin by building the cores.

00:16:46.414 --> 00:16:49.958
As we're building the cores, we build
the contemporary art museum at grade.

00:16:49.982 --> 00:16:53.048
That allows us to have
incredible efficiency and cost efficiency.

00:16:53.072 --> 00:16:54.773
This is not a high-budget building.

00:16:54.797 --> 00:16:56.646
The moment the cores get to mid level,

00:16:56.670 --> 00:16:59.865
we finish the art museum; we put
all the mechanical equipment in it;

00:16:59.889 --> 00:17:01.634

This is how they build

title: Let's teach religion -- all religion -- in schools
transcript: It's wonderful to be back. I love this wonderful gathering. And you must be wondering, "What on earth? Have they put up the wrong slide?" No, no. Look at this magnificent beast, and ask the question: Who designed it?This is TED; this is Technology, Entertainment, Design, and there's a dairy cow. It's a quite wonderfully designed animal. And I was thinking, how do I introduce this? And I thought, well, maybe that old doggerel by Joyce Kilmer, you know: "Poems are made by fools like me, but only God can make a tree." And you might say, "Well, God designed the cow."But, of course, God got a lot of help. This is the ancestor of cattle. This is the aurochs. And it was designed by natural selection, the process of natural selection, over many millions of years. And then it became domesticated, thousands of years ago. And human beings became its stewards, and, without even knowing what they were doing, they gradually redesigned it and redesigned it and redesigned it. And then more recently, they really began to do reverse engineering on this beast and figure out just what the parts were, how they worked and how they might be optimized — how they might be made better.Now, why am I talking about cows? Because I want to say that much the same thing is true of religions. Religions are natural phenomena — they're just as natural as cows. They have evolved over millennia. They have a biological base, just like the aurochs. They have become domesticated, and human beings have been redesigning their religions for thousands of years. This is TED, and I want to talk about design. Because what I've been doing for the last four years — really since the first time you saw me — some of you saw me at TED when I was talking about religion — and in the last four years, I've been working just about non-stop on this topic. And you might say it's about the reverse engineering of religions. Now that very idea, I think, strikes terror in many people, or anger, or anxiety of one sort or another. And that is the spell that I want to break.I want to say, no, religions are an important natural phenomenon. We should study them with the same intensity that we study all the other important natural phenomena, like global warming, as we heard so eloquently last night from Al Gore. Today's religions are brilliantly designed — brilliantly designed. They are immensely powerful social institutions and many of their features can be traced back to earlier features that we can really make sense of by reverse engineering. And, as with the cow, there's a mixture of evolutionary design — designed by natural selection itself — and intelligent design — more or less intelligent design — and redesigned by human beings who are trying to redesign their religions.You don't do book talks at TED, but I'm going to have just one slide about my book, because there is one message in it which I think this group really needs to hear. And I would be very interested to get your responses to this. It's the one policy proposal that I make in the book, at this time, when I claim not to know enough about religion to know what other policy proposals to make. And it's one that echoes remarks that you've heard already today.Here's my proposal, I'm going to just take a couple of minutes to explain it: Education on world religions for all of our children — in primary school, in high school, in public schools, in private schools and in home schooling. So what I'm proposing is, just as we require reading, writing, arithmetic, American history, so we should have a curriculum on facts about all the religions of the world — about their history, about their creeds, about their texts, their music, their symbolisms, their prohibitions, their requirements. And this should be presented factually, straightforwardly, with no particular spin, to all of the children in the country. And as long as you teach them that, you can teach them anything else you like. That, I think, is maximal tolerance for religious freedom. As long as you inform your children about other religions, then you may — and as early as you like and whatever you like — teach them whatever creed you want them to learn. But also let them know about other religions.Now, why do I say that? Because democracy depends on an informed citizenship. Informed consent is the very bedrock of our understanding of democracy. Misinformed consent is not worth it. It's like a coin flip; it doesn't count, really. Democracy depends on informed consent. This is the way we treat people as responsible adults. Now, children below the age of consent are a special case. Parents — I'm going to use a word that Pastor Rick just used — parents are stewards of their children. They don't own them. You can't own your children. You have a responsibility to the world, to the state, to them, to take care of them right. You may teach them whatever creed you think is most important, but I say you have a responsibility to let them be informed about all the other creeds in the world, too.The reason I've taken this time is I've been fascinated to hear some of the reactions to this. One reviewer for a Roman Catholic newspaper called it "totalitarian." It strikes me as practically libertarian. Is it totalitarian to require reading, writing and arithmetic? I don't think so. All I'm saying is — and facts, facts only; no values, just facts — about all the world's religions. Another reviewer called it "hilarious." Well, I'm really bothered by the fact that anybody would think that was hilarious. It seems to me to be such a plausible, natural extension of the democratic principles we already have that I'm shocked to think anybody would find that just ridiculous. I know many religions are so anxious about preserving the purity of their faith among their children that they are intent on keeping their children ignorant of other faiths. I don't think that's defensible. But I'd really be pleased to get your answers on that — any reactions to that — later.But now I'm going to move on. Back to the cow. This picture, which I pulled off the web — the fellow on the left is really an important part of this picture. That's the steward. Cows couldn't live without human stewards — they're domesticated. They're a sort of ectosymbiont. They depend on us for their survival. And Pastor Rick was just talking about sheep. I'm going to talk about sheep, too. There's a lot of serendipitous convergence here. How clever it was of sheep to acquire shepherds!(Laughter)Think of what this got them. They could outsource all their problems: protection from predators, food-finding ...(Laughter)... health maintenance.(Laughter)The only cost in most flocks — not even this — a loss of free mating. What a deal! "How clever of sheep!" you might say. Except, of course, it wasn't the sheep's cleverness. We all know sheep are not exactly rocket scientists — they're not very smart. It wasn't the cleverness of the sheep at all. They were clueless. But it was a very clever move. Whose clever move was it? It was the clever move of natural selection itself.Francis Crick, the co-discoverer of the structure of DNA with Jim Watson, once joked about what he called Orgel's Second Rule. Leslie Orgel is a molecular biologist, brilliant guy, and Orgel's Second Rule is: Evolution is cleverer than you are. Now, that is not Intelligent Design — not from Francis Crick. Evolution is cleverer than you are. If you understand Orgel's Second Rule, then you understand why the Intelligent Design movement is basically a hoax.The designs discovered by the process of natural selection are brilliant, unbelievably brilliant. Again and again biologists are fascinated with the brilliance of what's discovered. But the process itself is without purpose, without foresight, without design. When I was here four years ago, I told the story about an ant climbing a blade of grass. And why the ant was doing it was because its brain had been infected with a lancet fluke that was needed to get into the belly of a sheep or a cow in order to reproduce. So it was sort of a spooky story.And I think some people may have misunderstood. Lancet flukes aren't smart. I submit that the intelligence of a lancet fluke is down there, somewhere between petunia and carrot. They're not really bright. They don't have to be. The lesson we learn from this is: you don't have to have a mind to be a beneficiary. The design is there in nature, but it's not in anybody's head. It doesn't have to be. That's the way evolution works. Question: Was domestication good for sheep? It was great for their genetic fitness.And here I want to remind you of a wonderful point that Paul MacCready made at TED three years ago. Here's what he said: "Ten thousand years ago, at the dawn of agriculture, human population, plus livestock and pets, was approximately a tenth of one percent of the terrestrial vertebrate landmass." That was just 10,000 years ago. Yesterday, in biological terms. What is it today? Does anybody remember what he told us? 98 percent. That is what we have done on this planet.Now, I talked to Paul afterwards — I wanted to check to find out how he'd calculated this, and get the sources and so forth — and he also gave me a paper that he had written on this. And there was a passage in it which he did not present here and I think it is so good, I'm going to read it to you: "Over billions of years on a unique sphere, chance has painted a thin covering of life: complex, improbable, wonderful and fragile. Suddenly, we humans — a recently arrived species no longer subject to the checks and balances inherent in nature — have grown in population, technology and intelligence to a position of terrible power. We now wield the paintbrush." We heard about the atmosphere as a thin layer of varnish. Life itself is just a thin coat of paint on this planet. And we're the ones that hold the paintbrush. And how can we do that?The key to our domination of the planet is culture. And the key to culture is religion. Suppose Martian scientists came to Earth. They would be puzzled by many things. Anybody know what this is? I'll tell you what it is. This is a million people gathering on the banks of the Ganges in 2001, perhaps the largest single gathering of human beings ever, as seen from satellite photograph. Here's a big crowd. Here's another crowd in Mecca. Martians would be amazed by this. They'd want to know how it originated, what it was for and how it perpetuates itself.Actually, I'm going to pass over this. The ant isn't alone. There's all sorts of wonderful cases of species which — in that case — A parasite gets into a mouse and needs to get into the belly of a cat. And it turns the mouse into Mighty Mouse, makes it fearless, so it runs out in the open, where it'll be eaten by a cat. True story. In other words, we have these hijackers — you've seen this slide before, from four years ago — a parasite that infects the brain and induces even suicidal behavior, on behalf of a cause other than one's own genetic fitness.Does that ever happen to us? Yes, it does — quite wonderfully. The Arabic word "Islam" means "submission." It means "surrender of self-interest to the will of Allah." But I'm not just talking about Islam. I'm talking also about Christianity. This is a parchment music page that I found in a Paris bookstall 50 years ago. And on it, it says, in Latin: "Semen est verbum Dei. Sator autem Christus." The word of God is the seed and the sower of the seed is Christ. Same idea. Well, not quite. But in fact, Christians, too ... glory in the fact that they have surrendered to God. I'll give you a few quotes. "The heart of worship is surrender. Surrendered people obey God's words, even if it doesn't make sense." Those words are by Rick Warren. Those are from "The Purpose Driven Life."And I want to turn now, briefly, to talk about that book, which I've read. You've all got a copy, and you've just heard the man. And what I want to do now is say a bit about this book from the design standpoint, because I think it's actually a brilliant book. First of all, the goal — and you heard just now what the goal is — it's to bring purpose to the lives of millions, and he has succeeded. Is it a good goal? In itself, I'm sure we all agree, it is a wonderful goal. He's absolutely right. There are lots of people out there who don't have purpose in their life, and bringing purpose to their life is a wonderful goal. I give him an A+ on this.(Laughter)Is the goal achieved? Yes. Thirty million copies of this book. Al Gore, eat your heart out.(Laughter)Just exactly what Al is trying to do, Rick is doing. This is a fantastic achievement. And the means — how does he do it?It's a brilliant redesign of traditional religious themes — updating them, quietly dropping obsolete features, putting new interpretations on other features. This is the evolution of religion that's been going on for thousands of years, and he's just the latest brilliant practitioner of it. I don't have to tell you this; you just heard the man. Excellent insights into human psychology, wise advice on every page. Moreover, he invites us to look under the hood. I really appreciated that. For instance, he has an appendix where he explains his choice of translations of different Bible verses. The book is clear, vivid, accessible, beautifully formatted. Just enough repetition. That's really important. Every time you read it or say it, you make another copy in your brain. Every time you read it or say it, you make another copy in your brain.(Laughter)With me, everybody —(Audience and Dan Dennett) Every time you read it or say it, you make another copy in your brain.Thank you.And now we come to my problem. Because I'm absolutely sincere in my appreciation of all that I said about this book. But I wish it were better. I have some problems with the book. And it would just be insincere of me not to address those problems. I wish he could do this with a revision, a Mark 2 version of his book. "The truth will set you free." That's what it says in the Bible, and it's something that I want to live by, too.My problem is, some of the bits in it I don't think are true. Now some of this is a difference of opinion. And that's not my main complaint, that's worth mentioning. Here's a passage — it's very much what he said, anyway: "If there was no God we would all be accidents, the result of astronomical random chance in the Universe. You could stop reading this book because life would have no purpose or meaning or significance. There would be no right or wrong and no hope beyond your brief years on Earth." Now, I just do not believe that. By the way, I find — Homer Groening's film presented a beautiful alternative to that very claim. Yes, there is meaning and a reason for right or wrong. We don't need a belief in God to be good or to have meaning in us. But that, as I said, is just a difference of opinion. That's not what I'm really worried about.How about this: "God designed this planet's environment just so we could live in it." I'm afraid that a lot of people take that sentiment to mean that we don't have to do the sorts of things that Al Gore is trying so hard to get us to do. I am not happy with that sentiment at all. And then I find this: "All the evidence available in the biological sciences supports the core proposition that the cosmos is a specially designed whole with life and mankind as its fundamental goal and purpose, a whole in which all facets of reality have their meaning and explanation in this central fact." Well, that's Michael Denton. He's a creationist. And here, I think, "Wait a minute." I read this again. I read it three or four times and I think, "Is he really endorsing Intelligent Design? Is he endorsing creationism here?" And you can't tell. So I'm sort of thinking, "Well, I don't know, I don't know if I want to get upset with this yet."But then I read on, and I read this: "First, Noah had never seen rain, because prior to the Flood, God irrigated the earth from the ground up." I wish that sentence weren't in there, because I think it is false. And I think that thinking this way about the history of the planet, after we've just been hearing about the history of the planet over millions of years, discourages people from scientific understanding. Now, Rick Warren uses scientific terms and scientific factoids and information in a very interesting way.Here's one: "God deliberately shaped and formed you to serve him in a way that makes your ministry unique. He carefully mixed the DNA cocktail that created you." I think that's false. Now, maybe we want to treat it as metaphorical. Here's another one: "For instance, your brain can store 100 trillion facts. Your mind can handle 15,000 decisions a second." Well, it would be interesting to find the interpretation where I would accept that. There might be some way of treating that as true. "Anthropologists have noted that worship is a universal urge, hardwired by God into the very fiber of our being — an inbuilt need to connect with God." Well, the sense of which I agree with him, except I think it has an evolutionary explanation.And what I find deeply troubling in this book is that he seems to be arguing that if you want to be moral, if you want to have meaning in your life, you have to be an Intelligent Designer, you have to deny the theory of evolution by natural selection. And I think, on the contrary, that it is very important to solving the world's problems that we take evolutionary biology seriously. Whose truth are we going to listen to? Well, this is from "The Purpose Driven Life": "The Bible must become the authoritative standard for my life: the compass I rely on for direction, the counsel I listen to for making wise decisions, and the benchmark I use for evaluating everything." Well maybe, OK, but what's going to follow from this?And here's one that does concern me. Remember I quoted him before with this line: "Surrendered people obey God's word, even if it doesn't make sense." And that's a problem.(Sighs)"Don't ever argue with the Devil. He's better at arguing than you are, having had thousands of years to practice." Now, Rick Warren didn't invent this clever move. It's an old move. It's a very clever adaptation of religions. It's a wild card for disarming any reasonable criticism. "You don't like my interpretation? You've got a reasonable objection to it? Don't listen, don't listen! That's the Devil speaking." This discourages the sort of reasoning citizenship it seems to me that we want to have.I've got one more problem, then I'm through. And I'd really like to get a response if Rick is able to do it. "In the Great Commission, Jesus said, 'Go to all people of all nations and make them my disciples. Baptize them in the name of the Father, the Son and the Holy Spirit, and teach them to do everything I've told you.'" The Bible says Jesus is the only one who can save the world. We've seen many wonderful maps of the world in the last day or so. Here's one, not as beautiful as the others; it simply shows the religions of the world. Here's one that shows the sort of current breakdown of the different religions.Do we really want to commit ourselves to engulfing all the other religions, when their holy books are telling them, "Don't listen to the other side, that's just Satan talking!"? It seems to me that that's a very problematic ship to get on for the future. I found this sign as I was driving to Maine recently, in front of a church: "Good without God becomes zero." Sort of cute. A very clever little meme. I don't believe it and I think this idea, popular as it is — not in this guise, but in general — is itself one of the main problems that we face.If you are like me, you know many wonderful, committed, engaged atheists, agnostics, who are being very good without God. And you also know many religious people who hide behind their sanctity instead of doing good works. So, I wish we could drop this meme. I wish this meme would go extinct.Thanks very much for your attention.(Applause)

by reverse engineering.

00:03:26.291 --> 00:03:31.663
And, as with the cow, there's a mixture
of evolutionary design --

00:03:31.687 --> 00:03:33.656
designed by natural selection itself --

00:03:33.680 --> 00:03:36.787
and intelligent design --

00:03:36.811 --> 00:03:38.625
more or less intelligent design --

00:03:38.649 --> 00:03:40.347
and redesigned by human beings

00:03:40.371 --> 00:03:43.251
who are trying
to redesign their religions.

00:03:44.522 --> 00:03:48.102
You don't do book talks at TED,

00:03:48.126 --> 00:03:52.250
but I'm going to have
just one slide about my book,

00:03:52.274 --> 00:03:54.947
because there is one message in it

00:03:54.971 --> 00:03:57.135
which I think this group
really needs to hear.

00:03:57.159 --> 00:04:00.691
And I would be very interested
to get your responses to this.

00:04:02.008 --> 00:04:06.653
It's the one policy proposal
that I make in the book,

00:04:06.677 --> 00:04:10.040
at this time, when I claim
not to know enough about religion

00:04:10.064 --> 00:04:12.683
to know what other
policy proposals to make.

00:04:12.707 --> 00:04:17.255
And it's one that echoes remarks
that you've heard already today.

00:04:17.279 --> 00:04:18.438
Here's my proposal,

00:04:18.462 --> 00:04:21.392
I'm going to just take a couple
of minutes to explain it:

00:04:21.416 --> 00:04:26.960
Education on world religions
for all of our children --

00:04:26.984 --> 00:04:29.127
in primary school, in high school,

00:04:29.151 --> 00:04:32.416
in public schools, in private schools
and in home schooling.

00:04:33.479 --> 00:04:35.137
So what I'm proposing is,

00:04:35.161 --> 00:04:41.021
just as we require reading, writing,
arithmetic, American history,

00:04:41.045 --> 00:04:48.045
so we should have a curriculum on facts
about all the religions of the world --

00:04:48.069 --> 00:04:52.934
about their history,
about their creeds, about their texts,

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:57.619
their music, their symbolisms,
their prohibitions, their requirements.

00:04:58.952 --> 00:05:03.771
And this should be presented
factually, straightforwardly,

00:05:03.795 --> 00:05:09.259
with no particular spin,
to all of the children in the country.

00:05:10.465 --> 00:05:13.758
And as long as you teach them that,

00:05:13.782 --> 00:05:15.934
you can teach them anything else you like.

00:05:16.671 --> 00:05:20.663
That, I think, is maximal tolerance
for religious freedom.

00:05:21.321 --> 00:05:25.934
As long as you inform your children
about other religions,

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:29.104
then you may -- and as early as you like
and whatever you like --

00:05:29.128 --> 00:05:32.327
teach them whatever creed
you want them to learn.

00:05:32.914 --> 00:05:35.550
But also let them know
about other religions.

00:05:35.574 --> 00:05:37.958
Now, why do I say that?

00:05:39.323 --> 00:05:45.129
Because democracy depends
on an informed citizenship.

00:05:46.208 --> 00:05:51.958
Informed consent is the very bedrock
of our understanding of democracy.

00:05:53.888 --> 00:05:56.934
Misinformed consent is not worth it.

00:05:56.958 --> 00:06:00.181
It's like a coin flip;
it doesn't count, really.

00:06:00.205 --> 00:06:02.934
Democracy depends on informed consent.

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:08.291
This is the way we treat people
as responsible adults.

00:06:08.770 --> 00:06:15.508
Now, children below the age of consent
are a special case.

00:06:17.566 --> 00:06:23.157
Parents -- I'm going to use a word
that Pastor Rick just used --

00:06:23.181 --> 00:06:25.323
parents are stewards of their children.

00:06:26.117 --> 00:06:27.442
They don't own them.

00:06:28.244 --> 00:06:30.146
You can't own your children.

00:06:30.170 --> 00:06:33.853
You have a responsibility to the world,

00:06:33.877 --> 00:06:37.618
to the state, to them,
to take care of them right.

00:06:39.801 --> 00:06:45.848
You may teach them whatever creed
you think is most important,

00:06:45.872 --> 00:06:50.698
but I say you have a responsibility
to let them be informed

00:06:50.722 --> 00:06:53.254
about all the other creeds
in the world, too.

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:58.426
The reason I've taken this time
is I've been fascinated to hear

00:06:58.450 --> 00:06:59.958
some of the reactions to this.

00:07:01.621 --> 00:07:06.737
One reviewer for a Roman Catholic
newspaper called it "totalitarian."

00:07:08.807 --> 00:07:11.958
It strikes me as practically libertarian.

00:07:13.029 --> 00:07:16.052
Is it totalitarian to require
reading, writing and arithmetic?

00:07:16.076 --> 00:07:17.235
I don't think so.

00:07:17.259 --> 00:07:19.238
All I'm saying is --

00:07:19.262 --> 00:07:25.186
and facts, facts only;
no values, just facts --

00:07:25.210 --> 00:07:26.958
about all the world's religions.

00:07:28.641 --> 00:07:30.564
Another reviewer called it "hilarious."

00:07:31.858 --> 00:07:35.515
Well, I'm really bothered by the fact

00:07:35.539 --> 00:07:38.158
that anybody would think
that was hilarious.

00:07:38.182 --> 00:07:42.163
It seems to me to be such a plausible,

00:07:42.187 --> 00:07:46.583
natural extension of the democratic
principles we already have

00:07:46.607 --> 00:07:51.627
that I'm shocked to think anybody
would find that just ridiculous.

00:07:51.960 --> 00:07:55.477
I know many religions

00:07:55.501 --> 00:08:02.138
are so anxious about preserving the purity
of their faith among their children

00:08:02.162 --> 00:08:07.650
that they are intent on keeping
their children ignorant of other faiths.

00:08:09.103 --> 00:08:10.952
I don't think that's defensible.

00:08:12.142 --> 00:08:14.776
But I'd really be pleased
to get your answers on that --

00:08:14.800 --> 00:08:16.327
any reactions to that -- later.

00:08:16.351 --> 00:08:17.816
But now I'm going to move on.

00:08:18.498 --> 00:08:19.934
Back to the cow.

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:23.322
This picture, which I pulled
off the web --

00:08:23.346 --> 00:08:26.651
the fellow on the left is really
an important part of this picture.

00:08:26.675 --> 00:08:27.934
That's the steward.

00:08:28.263 --> 00:08:33.772
Cows couldn't live without human
stewards -- they're domesticated.

00:08:33.796 --> 00:08:36.534
They're a sort of ectosymbiont.

00:08:37.090 --> 00:08:41.732
They depend on us for their survival.

00:08:42.338 --> 00:08:45.681
And Pastor Rick
was just talking about sheep.

00:08:45.705 --> 00:08:47.404
I'm going to talk about sheep, too.

00:08:47.428 --> 00:08:50.411
There's a lot of serendipitous
convergence here.

00:08:50.965 --> 00:08:54.874
How clever it was of sheep
to acquire shepherds!

00:08:54.898 --> 00:08:57.231
(Laughter)

00:08:57.255 --> 00:08:59.040
Think of what this got them.

00:08:59.396 --> 00:09:01.934
They could outsource all their problems:

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:04.569
protection from predators,
food-finding ...

00:09:04.593 --> 00:09:05.600
(Laughter)

00:09:05.624 --> 00:09:06.959
... health maintenance.

00:09:06.983 --> 00:09:08.876
(Laughter)

00:09:09.670 --> 00:09:14.458
The only cost in most flocks --
not even this -- a loss of free mating.

00:09:16.623 --> 00:09:17.789
What a deal!

00:09:18.631 --> 00:09:20.507
"How clever of sheep!" you might say.

00:09:20.531 --> 00:09:23.032
Except, of course,
it wasn't the sheep's cleverness.

00:09:23.056 --> 00:09:27.445
We all know sheep are not exactly rocket
scientists -- they're not very smart.

00:09:28.385 --> 00:09:30.508
It wasn't the cleverness
of the sheep at all.

00:09:30.532 --> 00:09:31.934
They were clueless.

00:09:33.159 --> 00:09:35.093
But it was a very clever move.

00:09:35.117 --> 00:09:36.440
Whose clever move was it?

00:09:36.464 --> 00:09:39.934
It was the clever move
of natural selection itself.

00:09:40.776 --> 00:09:46.559
Francis Crick, the co-discoverer
of the structure of DNA

00:09:46.583 --> 00:09:48.346
with Jim Watson,

00:09:48.370 --> 00:09:51.187
once joked about what he called
Orgel's Second Rule.

00:09:51.536 --> 00:09:56.787
Leslie Orgel is a molecular
biologist, brilliant guy,

00:09:56.811 --> 00:09:58.181
and Orgel's Second Rule is:

00:09:58.205 --> 00:09:59.982
Evolution is cleverer than you are.

00:10:01.918 --> 00:10:07.321
Now, that is not Intelligent Design --
not from Francis Crick.

00:10:08.437 --> 00:10:10.128
Evolution is cleverer than you are.

00:10:10.152 --> 00:10:13.286
If you understand Orgel's Second Rule,
then you understand

00:10:13.310 --> 00:10:18.213
why the Intelligent Design movement
is basically a hoax.

00:10:20.174 --> 00:10:24.588
The designs discovered
by the process of natural selection

00:10:24.612 --> 00:10:26.992
are brilliant, unbelievably brilliant.

00:10:27.016 --> 00:10:31.934
Again and again biologists are fascinated
with the brilliance of what's discovered.

00:10:32.241 --> 00:10:35.406
But the process itself is without purpose,

00:10:35.430 --> 00:10:37.605
without foresight, without design.

00:10:38.316 --> 00:10:39.847
When I was here four years ago,

00:10:39.871 --> 00:10:42.792
I told the story about an ant
climbing a blade of grass.

00:10:42.816 --> 00:10:46.682
And why the ant was doing it
was because its brain had been infected

00:10:46.706 --> 00:10:51.878
with a lancet fluke that was needed
to get into the belly of a sheep or a cow

00:10:51.902 --> 00:10:54.276
in order to reproduce.

00:10:54.300 --> 00:10:55.934
So it was sort of a spooky story.

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:58.704
And I think some people
may have misunderstood.

00:10:58.728 --> 00:11:00.332
Lancet flukes aren't smart.

00:11:00.832 --> 00:11:05.066
I submit that the intelligence
of a lancet fluke is down there,

00:11:05.090 --> 00:11:07.270
somewhere between petunia and carrot.

00:11:07.294 --> 00:11:09.596
They're not really bright.
They don't have to be.

00:11:09.620 --> 00:11:11.207
The lesson we learn from this is:

00:11:11.231 --> 00:11:13.934
you don't have to have a mind
to be a beneficiary.

00:11:14.755 --> 00:11:19.247
The design is there in nature,
but it's not in anybody's head.

00:11:19.708 --> 00:11:20.934
It doesn't have to be.

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:22.641
That's the way evolution works.

00:11:23.593 --> 00:11:25.720
Question: Was domestication
good for sheep?

00:11:26.181 --> 00:11:28.228
It was great for their genetic fitness.

00:11:28.252 --> 00:11:30.934
And here I want to remind you
of a wonderful point

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:33.934
that Paul MacCready made
at TED three years ago.

00:11:34.955 --> 00:11:36.113
Here's what he said:

00:11:36.970 --> 00:11:39.601
"Ten thousand years ago,
at the dawn of agriculture,

00:11:39.625 --> 00:11:42.037
human population, plus livestock and pets,

00:11:42.061 --> 00:11:47.168
was approximately a tenth of one percent
of the terrestrial vertebrate landmass."

00:11:47.477 --> 00:11:49.335
That was just 10,000 years ago.

00:11:50.192 --> 00:11:52.236
Yesterday, in biological terms.

00:11:52.666 --> 00:11:55.442
What is it today? Does anybody
remember what he told us?

00:11:56.125 --> 00:11:58.168
98 percent.

00:11:58.597 --> 00:12:01.390
That is what we have done on this planet.

00:12:01.414 --> 00:12:04.483
Now, I talked to Paul afterwards --
I wanted to check to find out

00:12:04.507 --> 00:12:07.380
how he'd calculated this, and get
the sources and so forth --

00:12:07.404 --> 00:12:10.103
and he also gave me a paper
that he had written on this.

00:12:10.127 --> 00:12:12.949
And there was a passage in it
which he did not present here

00:12:12.973 --> 00:12:15.568
and I think it is so good,
I'm going to read it to you:

00:12:15.592 --> 00:12:18.732
"Over billions of years
on a unique sphere,

00:12:18.756 --> 00:12:21.597
chance has painted
a thin covering of life:

00:12:21.621 --> 00:12:24.984
complex, improbable,
wonderful and fragile.

00:12:25.008 --> 00:12:27.934
Suddenly, we humans --
a recently arrived species

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:31.406
no longer subject to the checks
and balances inherent in nature --

00:12:31.430 --> 00:12:34.248
have grown in population,
technology and intelligence

00:12:34.272 --> 00:12:36.215
to a position of terrible power.

00:12:36.239 --> 00:12:38.110
We now wield the paintbrush."

00:12:39.316 --> 00:12:42.705
We heard about the atmosphere
as a thin layer of varnish.

00:12:42.729 --> 00:12:45.934
Life itself is just a thin coat
of paint on this planet.

00:12:46.788 --> 00:12:48.868
And we're the ones
that hold the paintbrush.

00:12:49.534 --> 00:12:50.795
And how can we do that?

00:12:51.137 --> 00:12:54.331
The key to our domination
of the planet is culture.

00:12:55.515 --> 00:12:57.543
And the key to culture is religion.

00:12:58.948 --> 00:13:01.178
Suppose Martian scientists came to Earth.

00:13:01.916 --> 00:13:03.958
They would be puzzled by many things.

00:13:05.641 --> 00:13:08.355
Anybody know what this is?
I'll tell you what it is.

00:13:09.520 --> 00:13:14.813
This is a million people gathering
on the banks of the Ganges in 2001,

00:13:14.837 --> 00:13:18.299
perhaps the largest single gathering
of human beings ever,

00:13:18.323 --> 00:13:20.124
as seen from satellite photograph.

00:13:20.555 --> 00:13:21.707
Here's a big crowd.

00:13:21.731 --> 00:13:23.531
Here's another crowd in Mecca.

00:13:24.111 --> 00:13:26.919
Martians would be amazed by this.

00:13:26.943 --> 00:13:28.765
They'd want to know how it originated,

00:13:28.789 --> 00:13:31.376
what it was for
and how it perpetuates itself.

00:13:32.019 --> 00:13:34.344
Actually, I'm going to pass over this.

00:13:35.114 --> 00:13:36.369
The ant isn't alone.

00:13:36.393 --> 00:13:41.742
There's all sorts of wonderful cases
of species which -- in that case --

00:13:43.575 --> 00:13:47.281
A parasite gets into a mouse
and needs to get into the belly of a cat.

00:13:47.305 --> 00:13:50.166
And it turns the mouse
into Mighty Mouse, makes it fearless,

00:13:50.190 --> 00:13:52.973
so it runs out in the open,
where it'll be eaten by a cat.

00:13:52.997 --> 00:13:54.664
True story.

00:13:54.688 --> 00:13:56.700
In other words, we have these hijackers --

00:13:56.724 --> 00:13:59.208
you've seen this slide before,
from four years ago --

00:13:59.232 --> 00:14:03.118
a parasite that infects the brain
and induces even suicidal behavior,

00:14:03.142 --> 00:14:06.381
on behalf of a cause
other than one's own genetic fitness.

00:14:07.272 --> 00:14:08.893
Does that ever happen to us?

00:14:09.520 --> 00:14:12.282
Yes, it does -- quite wonderfully.

00:14:14.060 --> 00:14:16.067
The Arabic word "Islam"
means "submission."

00:14:16.091 --> 00:14:19.107
It means "surrender of self-interest
to the will of Allah."

00:14:19.575 --> 00:14:21.358
But I'm not just talking about Islam.

00:14:21.382 --> 00:14:23.531
I'm talking also about Christianity.

00:14:23.555 --> 00:14:26.893
This is a parchment music page
that I found in a Paris bookstall

00:14:26.917 --> 00:14:28.185
50 years ago.

00:14:28.209 --> 00:14:29.958
And on it, it says, in Latin:

00:14:31.486 --> 00:14:34.446
"Semen est verbum Dei.
Sator autem Christus."

00:14:34.470 --> 00:14:37.934
The word of God is the seed
and the sower of the seed is Christ.

00:14:38.376 --> 00:14:40.221
Same idea. Well, not quite.

00:14:40.579 --> 00:14:45.231
But in fact, Christians, too ...

00:14:45.255 --> 00:14:48.890
glory in the fact
that they have surrendered to God.

00:14:48.914 --> 00:14:50.262
I'll give you a few quotes.

00:14:50.286 --> 00:14:52.120
"The heart of worship is surrender.

00:14:53.131 --> 00:14:57.125
Surrendered people obey God's words,
even if it doesn't make sense."

00:14:58.140 --> 00:15:00.324
Those words are by Rick Warren.

00:15:00.760 --> 00:15:03.236
Those are from "The Purpose Driven Life."

00:15:03.856 --> 00:15:07.482
And I want to turn now, briefly,
to talk about that book, which I've read.

00:15:07.506 --> 00:15:08.849
You've all got a copy,

00:15:08.873 --> 00:15:11.065
and you've just heard the man.

00:15:11.089 --> 00:15:14.796
And what I want to do now
is say a bit about this book

00:15:14.820 --> 00:15:16.255
from the design standpoint,

00:15:16.279 --> 00:15:18.573
because I think it's actually
a brilliant book.

00:15:20.327 --> 00:15:23.542
First of all, the goal -- and you
heard just now what the goal is --

00:15:23.566 --> 00:15:26.877
it's to bring purpose to the lives
of millions, and he has succeeded.

00:15:26.901 --> 00:15:30.673
Is it a good goal? In itself, I'm sure
we all agree, it is a wonderful goal.

00:15:30.697 --> 00:15:31.848
He's absolutely right.

00:15:31.872 --> 00:15:35.680
There are lots of people out there
who don't have purpose in their life,

00:15:35.704 --> 00:15:38.514
and bringing purpose to their life
is a wonderful goal.

00:15:38.538 --> 00:15:40.130
I give him an A+ on this.

00:15:40.154 --> 00:15:41.978
(Laughter)

00:15:42.002 --> 00:15:43.605
Is the goal achieved?

00:15:45.780 --> 00:15:46.934
Yes.

00:15:48.224 --> 00:15:50.958
Thirty million copies of this book.

00:15:52.477 --> 00:15:53.934
Al Gore, eat your heart out.

00:15:53.958 --> 00:15:57.615
(Laughter)

00:15:57.639 --> 00:16:01.260
Just exactly what Al is trying
to do, Rick is doing.

00:16:01.284 --> 00:16:04.225
This is a fantastic achievement.

00:16:04.986 --> 00:16:08.101
And the means -- how does he do it?

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:11.934
It's a brilliant redesign
of traditional religious themes --

00:16:11.958 --> 00:16:15.259
updating them, quietly dropping
obsolete features,

00:16:15.283 --> 00:16:17.441
putting new interpretations
on other features.

00:16:17.465 --> 00:16:21.156
This is the evolution of religion that's
been going on for thousands of years,

00:16:21.180 --> 00:16:23.973
and he's just the latest
brilliant practitioner of it.

00:16:25.791 --> 00:16:28.347
I don't have to tell you this;
you just heard the man.

00:16:28.371 --> 00:16:32.934
Excellent insights into human psychology,
wise advice on every page.

00:16:34.037 --> 00:16:37.365
Moreover, he invites us
to look under the hood.

00:16:37.389 --> 00:16:38.738
I really appreciated that.

00:16:38.762 --> 00:16:41.206
For instance, he has an appendix
where he explains

00:16:41.230 --> 00:16:44.290
his choice of translations
of different Bible verses.

00:16:44.957 --> 00:16:49.958
The book is clear, vivid, accessible,
beautifully formatted.

00:16:51.281 --> 00:16:52.934
Just enough repetition.

00:16:53.486 --> 00:16:54.772
That's really important.

00:16:55.526 --> 00:16:59.218
Every time you read it or say it,
you make another copy in your brain.

00:17:00.829 --> 00:17:04.574
Every time you read it or say it,
you make another copy in your brain.

00:17:04.598 --> 00:17:05.606
(Laughter)

00:17:05.630 --> 00:17:06.874
With me, everybody --

00:17:06.898 --> 00:17:09.874
(Audience and Dan Dennett)
Every time you read it or say it,

00:17:09.898 --> 00:17:12.199
you make another copy in your brain.

00:17:12.223 --> 00:17:13.384
Thank you.

00:17:13.408 --> 00:17:15.701
And now we come to my problem.

00:17:15.725 --> 00:17:18.934
Because I'm absolutely sincere
in my appreciation

00:17:18.958 --> 00:17:20.934
of all that I said about this book.

00:17:21.518 --> 00:17:23.176
But I wish it were better.

00:17:23.200 --> 00:17:25.136
I have some problems with the book.

00:17:25.160 --> 00:17:28.939
And it would just be insincere of me
not to address those problems.

00:17:29.304 --> 00:17:33.067
I wish he could do this with a revision,

00:17:33.091 --> 00:17:35.522
a Mark 2 version of his book.

00:17:37.558 --> 00:17:39.074
"The truth will set you free."

00:17:39.494 --> 00:17:41.401
That's what it says in the Bible,

00:17:41.425 --> 00:17:43.933
and it's something
that I want to live by, too.

00:17:44.376 --> 00:17:49.039
My problem is, some of the bits in it
I don't think are true.

00:17:49.706 --> 00:17:52.417
Now some of this
is a difference of opinion.

00:17:54.131 --> 00:17:56.996
And that's not my main complaint,
that's worth mentioning.

00:17:57.020 --> 00:18:00.209
Here's a passage -- it's very much
what he said, anyway:

00:18:00.233 --> 00:18:02.732
"If there was no God
we would all be accidents,

00:18:02.756 --> 00:18:05.867
the result of astronomical
random chance in the Universe.

00:18:05.891 --> 00:18:09.269
You could stop reading this book
because life would have no purpose

00:18:09.293 --> 00:18:10.777
or meaning or significance.

00:18:10.801 --> 00:18:12.383
There would be no right or wrong

00:18:12.407 --> 00:18:14.553
and no hope beyond
your brief years on Earth."

00:18:14.577 --> 00:18:16.486
Now, I just do not believe that.

00:18:16.510 --> 00:18:22.690
By the way, I find -- Homer Groening's
film presented a beautiful alternative

00:18:22.714 --> 00:18:24.055
to that very claim.

00:18:24.819 --> 00:18:28.224
Yes, there is meaning and a reason
for right or wrong.

00:18:28.248 --> 00:18:34.482
We don't need a belief in God
to be good or to have meaning in us.

00:18:34.506 --> 00:18:38.767
But that, as I said,
is just a difference of opinion.

00:18:38.791 --> 00:18:40.934
That's not what I'm really worried about.

00:18:41.608 --> 00:18:44.537
How about this: "God designed
this planet's environment

00:18:44.561 --> 00:18:46.068
just so we could live in it."

00:18:47.171 --> 00:18:51.613
I'm afraid that a lot of people
take that sentiment to mean

00:18:51.637 --> 00:18:54.257
that we don't have to do
the sorts of things

00:18:54.281 --> 00:18:56.669
that Al Gore is trying so hard
to get us to do.

00:18:56.693 --> 00:18:58.934
I am not happy with that sentiment at all.

00:18:58.958 --> 00:19:03.530
And then I find this: "All the evidence
available in the biological sciences

00:19:03.554 --> 00:19:07.238
supports the core proposition that
the cosmos is a specially designed whole

00:19:07.262 --> 00:19:10.541
with life and mankind
as its fundamental goal and purpose,

00:19:10.565 --> 00:19:13.249
a whole in which all facets
of reality have their meaning

00:19:13.273 --> 00:19:15.290
and explanation in this central fact."

00:19:15.314 --> 00:19:17.573
Well, that's Michael Denton.
He's a creationist.

00:19:18.791 --> 00:19:21.934
And here, I think, "Wait a minute."
I read this again.

00:19:21.958 --> 00:19:23.997
I read it three or four times and I think,

00:19:24.021 --> 00:19:26.565
"Is he really endorsing
Intelligent Design?

00:19:26.589 --> 00:19:28.576
Is he endorsing creationism here?"

00:19:28.600 --> 00:19:29.835
And you can't tell.

00:19:29.859 --> 00:19:31.964
So I'm sort of thinking,
"Well, I don't know,

00:19:31.988 --> 00:19:34.385
I don't know if I want
to get upset with this yet."

00:19:34.409 --> 00:19:38.493
But then I read on, and I read this:
"First, Noah had never seen rain,

00:19:38.517 --> 00:19:42.374
because prior to the Flood, God irrigated
the earth from the ground up."

00:19:43.572 --> 00:19:47.934
I wish that sentence weren't in there,
because I think it is false.

00:19:48.495 --> 00:19:51.662
And I think that thinking this way
about the history of the planet,

00:19:51.686 --> 00:19:55.409
after we've just been hearing
about the history of the planet

00:19:55.433 --> 00:19:58.565
over millions of years,

00:19:58.589 --> 00:20:01.776
discourages people
from scientific understanding.

00:20:01.800 --> 00:20:08.345
Now, Rick Warren uses scientific terms

00:20:08.369 --> 00:20:12.475
and scientific factoids and information
in a very interesting way.

00:20:12.499 --> 00:20:15.863
Here's one: "God deliberately shaped
and formed you to serve him

00:20:15.887 --> 00:20:17.932
in a way that makes your ministry unique.

00:20:17.956 --> 00:20:21.599
He carefully mixed the DNA cocktail
that created you."

00:20:24.766 --> 00:20:26.934
I think that's false.

00:20:26.958 --> 00:20:29.656
Now, maybe we want to treat it
as metaphorical.

00:20:30.576 --> 00:20:34.155
Here's another one: "For instance,
your brain can store 100 trillion facts.

00:20:34.179 --> 00:20:37.224
Your mind can handle
15,000 decisions a second."

00:20:37.922 --> 00:20:40.596
Well, it would be interesting
to find the interpretation

00:20:40.620 --> 00:20:42.001
where I would accept that.

00:20:42.025 --> 00:20:44.691
There might be some way
of treating that as true.

00:20:45.469 --> 00:20:48.777
"Anthropologists have noted
that worship is a universal urge,

00:20:48.801 --> 00:20:51.456
hardwired by God into
the very fiber of our being --

00:20:51.480 --> 00:20:54.369
an inbuilt need to connect with God."

00:20:55.350 --> 00:20:57.518
Well, the sense of which I agree with him,

00:20:57.542 --> 00:20:59.922
except I think it has
an evolutionary explanation.

00:20:59.946 --> 00:21:03.767
And what I find
deeply troubling in this book

00:21:03.791 --> 00:21:07.544
is that he seems to be arguing
that if you want to be moral,

00:21:07.568 --> 00:21:09.737
if you want to have meaning in your life,

00:21:09.761 --> 00:21:12.228
you have to be an Intelligent Designer,

00:21:12.252 --> 00:21:15.773
you have to deny the theory of evolution
by natural selection.

00:21:15.797 --> 00:21:17.276
And I think, on the contrary,

00:21:17.300 --> 00:21:20.241
that it is very important
to solving the world's problems

00:21:20.265 --> 00:21:23.125
that we take evolutionary
biology seriously.

00:21:24.385 --> 00:21:26.296
Whose truth are we going to listen to?

00:21:27.607 --> 00:21:30.159
Well, this is from
"The Purpose Driven Life":

00:21:30.183 --> 00:21:33.476
"The Bible must become
the authoritative standard for my life:

00:21:33.500 --> 00:21:35.239
the compass I rely on for direction,

00:21:35.263 --> 00:21:38.080
the counsel I listen to
for making wise decisions,

00:21:38.104 --> 00:21:40.511
and the benchmark I use
for evaluating everything."

00:21:41.416 --> 00:21:45.803
Well maybe, OK, but what's going
to follow from this?

00:21:45.827 --> 00:21:47.969
And here's one that does concern me.

00:21:49.421 --> 00:21:51.774
Remember I quoted him
before with this line:

00:21:51.798 --> 00:21:55.595
"Surrendered people obey God's word,
even if it doesn't make sense."

00:21:57.293 --> 00:22:00.097
And that's a problem.

00:22:01.801 --> 00:22:02.801
(Sighs)

00:22:02.825 --> 00:22:04.469
"Don't ever argue with the Devil.

00:22:04.493 --> 00:22:06.224
He's better at arguing than you are,

00:22:06.248 --> 00:22:08.634
having had thousands
of years to practice."

00:22:08.658 --> 00:22:12.885
Now, Rick Warren
didn't invent this clever move.

00:22:12.909 --> 00:22:14.099
It's an old move.

00:22:14.607 --> 00:22:17.158
It's a very clever
adaptation of religions.

00:22:17.182 --> 00:22:20.778
It's a wild card for disarming
any reasonable criticism.

00:22:22.504 --> 00:22:24.226
"You don't like my interpretation?

00:22:24.250 --> 00:22:26.202
You've got a reasonable objection to it?

00:22:26.226 --> 00:22:27.722
Don't listen, don't listen!

00:22:28.279 --> 00:22:29.958
That's the Devil speaking."

00:22:31.143 --> 00:22:36.744
This discourages the sort
of reasoning citizenship

00:22:36.768 --> 00:22:38.820
it seems to me that we want to have.

00:22:39.626 --> 00:22:41.934
I've got one more problem,
then I'm through.

00:22:42.256 --> 00:22:46.563
And I'd really like to get
a response if Rick is able to do it.

00:22:47.551 --> 00:22:49.330
"In the Great Commission, Jesus said,

00:22:49.354 --> 00:22:52.216
'Go to all people of all nations
and make them my disciples.

00:22:52.240 --> 00:22:55.455
Baptize them in the name of the Father,
the Son and the Holy Spirit,

00:22:55.479 --> 00:22:57.746
and teach them to do
everything I've told you.'"

00:22:57.770 --> 00:23:01.086
The Bible says Jesus is the only one
who can save the world.

00:23:01.888 --> 00:23:05.934
We've seen many wonderful maps
of the world in the last day or so.

00:23:06.255 --> 00:23:08.581
Here's one, not as beautiful
as the others;

00:23:08.605 --> 00:23:10.934
it simply shows
the religions of the world.

00:23:12.024 --> 00:23:15.934
Here's one that shows the sort of current
breakdown of the different religions.

00:23:19.057 --> 00:23:23.567
Do we really want to commit ourselves

00:23:23.591 --> 00:23:28.511
to engulfing all the other religions,

00:23:28.535 --> 00:23:31.901
when their holy books are telling them,

00:23:31.925 --> 00:23:36.384
"Don't listen to the other side,
that's just Satan talking!"?

00:23:36.408 --> 00:23:42.745
It seems to me that
that's a very problematic ship

00:23:42.769 --> 00:23:44.934
to get on for the future.

00:23:45.708 --> 00:23:49.934
I found this sign as I was driving
to Maine recently,

00:23:49.958 --> 00:23:52.625
in front of a church:
"Good without God becomes zero."

00:23:52.649 --> 00:23:53.822
Sort of cute.

00:23:54.163 --> 00:23:56.212
A very clever little meme.

00:23:58.547 --> 00:24:04.151
I don't believe it and I think this idea,
popular as it is --

00:24:04.175 --> 00:24:06.266
not in this guise, but in general --

00:24:06.290 --> 00:24:09.543
is itself one of the main
problems that we face.

00:24:09.567 --> 00:24:16.238
If you are like me, you know
many wonderful, committed, engaged

00:24:16.262 --> 00:24:21.934
atheists, agnostics, who are being
very good without God.

00:24:21.958 --> 00:24:27.663
And you also know many religious people
who hide behind their sanctity

00:24:27.687 --> 00:24:29.456
instead of doing good works.

00:24:29.917 --> 00:24:33.512
So, I wish we could drop this meme.

00:24:33.536 --> 00:24:35.529
I wish this meme would go extinct.

00:24:35.553 --> 00:24:37.300
Thanks very much for your attention.

00:24:37.324 --> 00:24:39.858
(Applause)

title: A life of purpose
transcript: I'm often asked, "What surprised you about the book?" And I say, "That I got to write it." I would have never imagined that. Not in my wildest dreams did I think — I don't even consider myself to be an author. And I'm often asked, "Why do you think so many people have read this? This thing's selling still about a million copies a month."And I think it's because spiritual emptiness is a universal disease. I think inside at some point, we put our heads down on the pillow and we go, "There's got to be more to life than this." Get up in the morning, go to work, come home and watch TV, go to bed, get up in the morning, go to work, come home, watch TV, go to bed, go to parties on weekends. A lot of people say, "I'm living." No, you're not living — that's just existing. Just existing. I really think that there's this inner desire. I do believe what Chris said; I believe that you're not an accident. Your parents may not have planned you, but I believe God did. I think there are accidental parents; there's no doubt about that. I don't think there are accidental kids. And I think you matter.I think you matter to God; I think you matter to history; I think you matter to this universe. And I think that the difference between what I call the survival level of living, the success level of living, and the significance level of living is: Do you figure out, "What on Earth am I here for?" I meet a lot of people who are very smart, and say, "But why can't I figure out my problems?" And I meet a lot of people who are very successful, who say, "Why don't I feel more fulfilled? Why do I feel like a fake? Why do I feel like I've got to pretend that I'm more than I really am?" I think that comes down to this issue of meaning, of significance, of purpose. I think it comes down to this issue of: "Why am I here? What am I here for? Where am I going?" These are not religious issues. They're human issues.I wanted to tell Michael before he spoke that I really appreciate what he does, because it makes my life work a whole lot easier. As a pastor, I do see a lot of kooks. And I have learned that there are kooks in every area of life. Religion doesn't have a monopoly on that, but there are plenty of religious kooks. There are secular kooks; there are smart kooks, dumb kooks. There are people — a lady came up to me the other day, and she had a white piece of paper — Michael, you'll like this one — and she said, "What do you see in it?" And I looked at it and I said, "Oh, I don't see anything." And she goes, "Well, I see Jesus," and started crying and left. I'm going, "OK," you know? "Fine."(Laughter)Good for you.When the book became the best-selling book in the world for the last three years, I kind of had my little crisis. And that was: What is the purpose of this? Because it brought in enormous amounts of money. When you write the best-selling book in the world, it's tons and tons of money. And it brought in a lot of attention, neither of which I wanted. When I started Saddleback Church, I was 25 years old. I started it with one other family in 1980. And I decided that I was never going to go on TV, because I didn't want to be a celebrity. I didn't want to be a, quote, "evangelist, televangelist" — that's not my thing. And all of the sudden, it brought a lot of money and a lot of attention. I don't think — now, this is a worldview, and I will tell you, everybody's got a worldview.Everybody's betting their life on something. You're betting your life on something, you just better know why you're betting what you're betting on. So, everybody's betting their life on something. And when I, you know, made a bet, I happened to believe that Jesus was who he said he was. And I believe in a pluralistic society, everybody's betting on something. And when I started the church, you know, I had no plans to do what it's doing now. And then when I wrote this book, and all of a sudden, it just took off, and I started saying, now, what's the purpose of this? Because as I started to say, I don't think you're given money or fame for your own ego, ever. I just don't believe that. And when you write a book that the first sentence of the book is, "It's not about you," then, when all of a sudden it becomes the best-selling book in history, you've got to figure, well, I guess it's not about me. That's kind of a no-brainer. So, what is it for?And I began to think about what I call the "stewardship of affluence" and the "stewardship of influence." So I believe, essentially, leadership is stewardship. That if you are a leader in any area — in business, in politics, in sports, in art, in academics, in any area — you don't own it. You are a steward of it. For instance, that's why I believe in protecting the environment. This is not my planet. It wasn't mine before I was born, it's not going to be mine after I die, I'm just here for 80 years and then that's it.I was debating the other day on a talk show, and the guy was challenging me and he'd go, "What's a pastor doing on protecting the environment?" And I asked this guy, I said, "Well, do you believe that human beings are responsible to make the world a little bit better place for the next generation? Do you think we have a stewardship here, to take the environment seriously?" And he said, "No." I said, "Oh, you don't?" I said, "Let me make this clear again: Do you believe that as human beings — I'm not talking about religion — do you believe that as human beings, it is our responsibility to take care of this planet, and make it just a little bit better for the next generation?" And he said, "No. Not any more than any other species." When he said the word "species," he was revealing his worldview. And he was saying, "I'm no more responsible to take care of this environment than a duck is." Well now, I know a lot of times we act like ducks, but you're not a duck. You're not a duck. And you are responsible — that's my worldview. And so, you need to understand what your worldview is.The problem is most people never really think it through. They never really ... codify it or qualify it or quantify it, and say, "This is what I believe in. This is why I believe what I believe." I don't personally have enough faith to be an atheist. But you may, you may. Your worldview, though, does determine everything else in your life, because it determines your decisions; it determines your relationships; it determines your level of confidence. It determines, really, everything in your life.
