What we believe, obviously — and you know this — determines our behavior, and our behavior determines what we become in life.So all of this money started pouring in, and all of this fame started pouring in. And I'm going, what do I do with this? My wife and I first made five decisions on what to do with the money. We said, "First, we're not going to use it on ourselves." I didn't go out and buy a bigger house. I don't own a guesthouse. I still drive the same four year-old Ford that I've driven. We just said, we're not going to use it on us. The second thing was, I stopped taking a salary from the church that I pastor. Third thing is, I added up all that the church had paid me over the last 25 years, and I gave it back. And I gave it back because I didn't want anybody thinking that I do what I do for money — I don't. In fact, personally, I've never met a priest or a pastor or a minister who does it for money. I know that's the stereotype; I've never met one of them. Believe me, there's a whole lot easier ways to make money.Pastors are like on 24 hours-a-day call, they're like doctors. I left late today — I'd hoped to be here yesterday — because my father-in-law is in his last, probably, 48 hours before he dies of cancer. And I'm watching a guy who's lived his life — he's now in his mid-80s — and he's dying with peace. You know, the test of your worldview is not how you act in the good times. The test of your worldview is how you act at the funeral. And having been through literally hundreds if not thousands of funerals, it makes a difference. It makes a difference what you believe.So, we gave it all back, and then we set up three foundations, working on some of the major problems of the world: illiteracy, poverty, pandemic diseases — particularly HIV/AIDS — and set up these three foundations, and put the money into that. The last thing we did is we became what I call "reverse tithers." And that is, when my wife and I got married 30 years ago, we started tithing. Now, that's a principle in the Bible that says give 10 percent of what you get back to charity, give it away to help other people. So, we started doing that, and each year we would raise our tithe one percent. So, our first year of marriage we went to 11 percent, second year we went to 12 percent, and the third year we went to 13 percent, and on and on and on. Why did I do that? Because every time I give, it breaks the grip of materialism in my life.Materialism is all about getting — get, get, get, get all you can, can all you get, sit on the can and spoil the rest. It's all about more, having more. And we think that the good life is actually looking good — that's most important of all — looking good, feeling good and having the goods. But that's not the good life. I meet people all the time who have those, and they're not necessarily happy. If money actually made you happy, then the wealthiest people in the world would be the happiest. And that I know, personally, I know, is not true. It's just not true.So, the good life is not about looking good, feeling good or having the goods, it's about being good and doing good. Giving your life away. Significance in life doesn't come from status, because you can always find somebody who's got more than you. It doesn't come from sex. It doesn't come from salary. It comes from serving. It is in giving our lives away that we find meaning, we find significance. That's the way we were wired, I believe, by God. And so we began to give away, and now after 30 years, my wife and I are reverse tithers — we give away 90 percent and live on 10. That, actually, was the easy part. The hard part is, what do I do with all this attention? Because I started getting all kinds of invitations. I just came off a nearly month-long speaking tour on three different continents, and I won't go into that, but it was an amazing thing. And I'm going, what do I do with this notoriety that the book has brought?And, being a pastor, I started reading the Bible. There's a chapter in the Bible called Psalm 72, and it's Solomon's prayer for more influence. When you read this prayer, it sounds incredibly selfish, self-centered. He says, "God, I want you to make me famous." That's what he prays. He said, "I want you to make me famous. I want you to spread the fame of my name through every land, I want you to give me power. I want you to make me famous, I want you to give me influence." And it just sounds like the most egotistical request you could make, if you were going to pray. Until you read the whole psalm, the whole chapter. And then he says, "So that the king ..." — he was the king of Israel at that time, at its apex in power — "... so that the king may care for the widow and orphan, support the oppressed, defend the defenseless, care for the sick, assist the poor, speak up for the foreigner, those in prison." Basically, he's talking about all the marginalized in society.And as I read that, I looked at it, and I thought, you know, what this is saying is that the purpose of influence is to speak up for those who have no influence. The purpose of influence is not to build your ego. Or your net worth. And, by the way, your net worth is not the same thing as your self-worth. Your value is not based on your valuables. It's based on a whole different set of things. And so the purpose of influence is to speak up for those who have no influence. And I had to admit: I can't think of the last time I thought of widows and orphans. They're not on my radar. I pastor a church in one of the most affluent areas of America — a bunch of gated communities. I have a church full of CEOs and scientists. And I could go five years and never, ever see a homeless person. They're just not in my pathway. Now, they're 13 miles up the road in Santa Ana. So I had to say, ok, I would use whatever affluence and whatever influence I've got to help those who don't have either of those.You know, there's a story in the Bible about Moses, whether you believe it's true or not, it really doesn't matter to me. But Moses, if you saw the movie, "The Ten Commandments," Moses goes out, and there's this burning bush, and God talks to him, and God says, "Moses, what's in your hand?" I think that's one of the most important questions you'll ever be asked: What's in your hand? Moses says, "It's a staff. It's a shepherd's staff." And God says, "Throw it down." And if you saw the movie, you know, he throws it down and it becomes a snake. And then God says, "Pick it up." And he picks it back up again, and it becomes a staff again. Now, I'm reading this thing, and I'm going, what is that all about? OK. What's that all about? Well, I do know a couple of things. Number one, God never does a miracle to show off. It's not just, "Wow, isn't that cool?" And, by the way, my God doesn't have to show up on cheese bread. You know, if God's going to show up, he's not going to show up on cheese bread.(Laughter)Ok? I just, this is why I love what Michael does, because it's like, if he's debunking it, then I don't have to. But God — my God — doesn't show up on sprinkler images. He's got a few more powerful ways than that to do whatever he wants to do. But he doesn't do miracles just to show off.Second thing is, if God ever asks you a question, he already knows the answer. Obviously, if he's God, then that would mean that when he asks the question, it's for your benefit, not his. So he's going, "What's in your hand?" Now, what was in Moses' hand? Well, it was a shepherd's staff. Now, follow me on this.This staff represented three things about Moses' life. First, it represented his identity; he was a shepherd. It's the symbol of his own occupation: I am a shepherd. It's a symbol of his identity, his career, his job. Second, it's a symbol of not only his identity, it's a symbol of his income, because all of his assets are tied up in sheep. In those days, nobody had bank accounts, or American Express cards, or hedge funds. Your assets are tied up in your flocks. So it's a symbol of his identity, and it's a symbol of his income. And the third thing: it's a symbol of his influence. What do you do with a shepherd's staff? Well, you know, you move sheep from point A to point B with it, by hook or by crook. You pull them or you poke them. One or the other. So, he's saying, "You're going to lay down your identity. What's in your hand? You've got identity, you've got income, you've got influence. What's in your hand?" And he's saying, "If you lay it down, I'll make it come alive. I'll do some things you could never imagine possible." And if you've watched that movie, "Ten Commandments," all of those big miracles that happen in Egypt are done through this staff.Last year, I was invited to speak at the NBA All-Stars game. And so, I'm talking to the players, because most of the NBA teams, NFL teams and all the other teams have done this 40 Days of Purpose, based on the book. And I asked them, I said, "What's in your hand? So, what's in your hand?" I said, "It's a basketball. And that basketball represents your identity, who you are: you're an NBA player. It represents your income: you're making a lot of money off that little ball. And it represents your influence. And even though you're only going to be in the NBA for a few years, you're going to be an NBA player for the rest of your life. And that gives you enormous influence. So, what are you going to do with what you've been given?"And I guess that's the main reason I came up here today, to all of you very bright people at TED — it is to say, "What's in your hand?" What do you have that you've been given? Talent, background, education, freedom, networks, opportunities, wealth, ideas, creativity. What are you doing with what you've been given? That, to me, is the primary question about life. That, to me, is what being purpose-driven is all about. In the book, I talk about how you're wired to do certain things, you're "SHAPED" with — a little acrostic: Spiritual gifts, Heart, Ability, Personality and Experiences. These things shape you. And if you want to know what you ought to be doing with your life, you need to look at your shape — "What am I wired to do?" Why would God wire you to do something and then not have you do it? If you're wired to be an anthropologist, you'll be an anthropologist. If you're wired to be an undersea explorer, you'll be an undersea explorer. If you're wired to make deals, you make deals. If you're wired to paint, you paint.Did you know that God smiles when you be you? When my little kids — when my kids were little — they're all grown now, I have grandkids — I used to go in and sit on the side of their bed, and I used to watch my kids sleep. And I just watched their little bodies rise and lower, rise and lower. And I would look at them: "This is not an accident." Rise and lower. And I got joy out of just watching them sleep. Some people have the misguided idea that God only gets excited when you're doing, quote, "spiritual things," like going to church or helping the poor, or, you know, confessing or doing something like that. The bottom line is, God gets pleasure watching you be you. Why? He made you. And when you do what you were made to do, he goes, "That's my boy! That's my girl! You're using the talent and ability that I gave you."So my advice to you is: look at what's in your hand — your identity, your influence, your income — and say, "It's not about me. It's about making the world a better place."Thank you.
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:13.354 --> 00:00:15.782
I'm often asked,

00:00:15.806 --> 00:00:18.254
"What surprised you about the book?"

00:00:18.278 --> 00:00:20.435
And I say, "That I got to write it."

00:00:20.459 --> 00:00:22.613
I would have never imagined that.

00:00:23.288 --> 00:00:25.838
Not in my wildest dreams did I think --

00:00:25.862 --> 00:00:28.140
I don't even consider
myself to be an author.

00:00:29.247 --> 00:00:31.445
And I'm often asked,

00:00:31.469 --> 00:00:33.934
"Why do you think so many
people have read this?

00:00:33.958 --> 00:00:37.184
This thing's selling still
about a million copies a month."

00:00:38.958 --> 00:00:43.934
And I think it's because
spiritual emptiness

00:00:43.958 --> 00:00:46.846
is a universal disease.

00:00:46.870 --> 00:00:50.487
I think inside at some point, we put
our heads down on the pillow and we go,

00:00:50.511 --> 00:00:52.650
"There's got to be more
to life than this."

00:00:53.150 --> 00:00:55.891
Get up in the morning, go to work,
come home and watch TV,

00:00:55.915 --> 00:00:59.575
go to bed, get up in the morning, go
to work, come home, watch TV, go to bed,

00:00:59.599 --> 00:01:00.958
go to parties on weekends.

00:01:02.241 --> 00:01:06.928
A lot of people say, "I'm living." No,
you're not living -- that's just existing.

00:01:06.952 --> 00:01:08.471
Just existing.

00:01:08.495 --> 00:01:11.527
I really think that
there's this inner desire.

00:01:12.289 --> 00:01:16.226
I do believe what Chris said;
I believe that you're not an accident.

00:01:17.686 --> 00:01:21.136
Your parents may not have planned you,
but I believe God did.

00:01:21.160 --> 00:01:24.391
I think there are accidental parents;
there's no doubt about that.

00:01:24.415 --> 00:01:26.490
I don't think there are accidental kids.

00:01:27.656 --> 00:01:29.399
And I think you matter.

00:01:30.494 --> 00:01:33.511
I think you matter to God;
I think you matter to history;

00:01:33.535 --> 00:01:35.502
I think you matter to this universe.

00:01:36.907 --> 00:01:39.130
And I think that the difference

00:01:39.154 --> 00:01:43.934
between what I call the survival level
of living, the success level of living,

00:01:43.958 --> 00:01:45.934
and the significance level of living is:

00:01:45.958 --> 00:01:48.640
Do you figure out,
"What on Earth am I here for?"

00:01:49.482 --> 00:01:52.852
I meet a lot of people who are very smart,

00:01:52.876 --> 00:01:55.339
and say, "But why can't I
figure out my problems?"

00:01:55.958 --> 00:01:58.599
And I meet a lot of people
who are very successful,

00:01:58.623 --> 00:02:00.638
who say, "Why don't I feel more fulfilled?

00:02:01.337 --> 00:02:02.979
Why do I feel like a fake?

00:02:03.958 --> 00:02:09.695
Why do I feel like I've got to pretend
that I'm more than I really am?"

00:02:10.520 --> 00:02:14.266
I think that comes down to this issue
of meaning, of significance, of purpose.

00:02:14.854 --> 00:02:17.309
I think it comes down to this issue of:

00:02:17.333 --> 00:02:20.872
"Why am I here? What am I here for?
Where am I going?"

00:02:20.896 --> 00:02:23.072
These are not religious issues.

00:02:23.737 --> 00:02:26.070
They're human issues.

00:02:26.958 --> 00:02:30.934
I wanted to tell Michael before he spoke
that I really appreciate what he does,

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:34.108
because it makes my life work
a whole lot easier.

00:02:34.132 --> 00:02:37.934
As a pastor, I do see a lot of kooks.

00:02:38.354 --> 00:02:41.759
And I have learned that there are
kooks in every area of life.

00:02:42.402 --> 00:02:46.730
Religion doesn't have a monopoly on that,

00:02:46.754 --> 00:02:48.791
but there are plenty of religious kooks.

00:02:48.815 --> 00:02:52.202
There are secular kooks;
there are smart kooks, dumb kooks.

00:02:52.226 --> 00:02:54.837
There are people -- a lady
came up to me the other day,

00:02:54.861 --> 00:02:58.176
and she had a white piece of paper --
Michael, you'll like this one --

00:02:58.200 --> 00:03:00.026
and she said, "What do you see in it?"

00:03:00.050 --> 00:03:02.790
And I looked at it and I said,
"Oh, I don't see anything."

00:03:02.814 --> 00:03:05.786
And she goes, "Well, I see Jesus,"
and started crying and left.

00:03:05.810 --> 00:03:10.314
I'm going, "OK," you know? "Fine."

00:03:10.338 --> 00:03:12.498
(Laughter)

00:03:12.522 --> 00:03:13.672
Good for you.

00:03:16.408 --> 00:03:20.289
When the book became the best-selling book
in the world for the last three years,

00:03:20.313 --> 00:03:22.468
I kind of had my little crisis.

00:03:23.344 --> 00:03:25.958
And that was: What is the purpose of this?

00:03:27.729 --> 00:03:30.514
Because it brought in
enormous amounts of money.

00:03:30.538 --> 00:03:32.959
When you write the best-selling
book in the world,

00:03:32.983 --> 00:03:34.725
it's tons and tons of money.

00:03:35.852 --> 00:03:39.127
And it brought in a lot of attention,
neither of which I wanted.

00:03:39.151 --> 00:03:42.146
When I started Saddleback Church,
I was 25 years old.

00:03:42.567 --> 00:03:46.973
I started it with
one other family in 1980.

00:03:47.632 --> 00:03:49.934
And I decided that I was never
going to go on TV,

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:51.880
because I didn't want to be a celebrity.

00:03:51.904 --> 00:03:55.085
I didn't want to be a, quote,
"evangelist, televangelist" --

00:03:55.109 --> 00:03:56.958
that's not my thing.

00:03:57.854 --> 00:04:02.128
And all of the sudden, it brought a lot
of money and a lot of attention.

00:04:02.152 --> 00:04:03.692
I don't think --

00:04:03.716 --> 00:04:04.957
now, this is a worldview,

00:04:04.981 --> 00:04:07.431
and I will tell you,
everybody's got a worldview.

00:04:07.995 --> 00:04:10.054
Everybody's betting
their life on something.

00:04:10.078 --> 00:04:11.915
You're betting your life on something,

00:04:11.939 --> 00:04:15.343
you just better know why
you're betting what you're betting on.

00:04:15.367 --> 00:04:17.648
So, everybody's betting
their life on something.

00:04:18.616 --> 00:04:22.578
And when I, you know, made a bet,

00:04:22.602 --> 00:04:25.514
I happened to believe
that Jesus was who he said he was.

00:04:26.117 --> 00:04:29.076
And I believe in a pluralistic society,

00:04:29.100 --> 00:04:31.037
everybody's betting on something.

00:04:32.362 --> 00:04:35.460
And when I started the church,

00:04:35.484 --> 00:04:39.050
you know, I had no plans
to do what it's doing now.

00:04:40.129 --> 00:04:41.986
And then when I wrote this book,

00:04:42.010 --> 00:04:46.535
and all of a sudden, it just took off,

00:04:46.559 --> 00:04:49.146
and I started saying, now,
what's the purpose of this?

00:04:49.170 --> 00:04:50.891
Because as I started to say,

00:04:50.915 --> 00:04:53.111
I don't think you're given money or fame

00:04:53.135 --> 00:04:54.715
for your own ego, ever.

00:04:56.469 --> 00:04:57.746
I just don't believe that.

00:04:58.329 --> 00:05:01.516
And when you write a book
that the first sentence of the book is,

00:05:01.540 --> 00:05:03.962
"It's not about you,"

00:05:03.986 --> 00:05:07.366
then, when all of a sudden it becomes
the best-selling book in history,

00:05:07.390 --> 00:05:09.953
you've got to figure, well,
I guess it's not about me.

00:05:10.622 --> 00:05:12.265
That's kind of a no-brainer.

00:05:13.209 --> 00:05:14.825
So, what is it for?

00:05:15.701 --> 00:05:19.307
And I began to think about what I call
the "stewardship of affluence"

00:05:19.331 --> 00:05:21.934
and the "stewardship of influence."

00:05:22.392 --> 00:05:25.062
So I believe, essentially,
leadership is stewardship.

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:28.383
That if you are a leader in any area --

00:05:28.407 --> 00:05:31.923
in business, in politics,
in sports, in art,

00:05:31.947 --> 00:05:34.015
in academics, in any area --

00:05:34.039 --> 00:05:35.341
you don't own it.

00:05:36.722 --> 00:05:38.237
You are a steward of it.

00:05:38.867 --> 00:05:41.938
For instance, that's why I believe
in protecting the environment.

00:05:41.962 --> 00:05:43.522
This is not my planet.

00:05:43.546 --> 00:05:47.009
It wasn't mine before I was born,
it's not going to be mine after I die,

00:05:47.033 --> 00:05:50.204
I'm just here for 80 years
and then that's it.

00:05:50.228 --> 00:05:54.325
I was debating
the other day on a talk show,

00:05:54.349 --> 00:05:56.362
and the guy was challenging
me and he'd go,

00:05:56.386 --> 00:05:58.958
"What's a pastor doing
on protecting the environment?"

00:05:59.814 --> 00:06:03.591
And I asked this guy, I said,
"Well, do you believe

00:06:03.615 --> 00:06:07.498
that human beings are responsible

00:06:07.522 --> 00:06:11.283
to make the world a little bit better
place for the next generation?

00:06:11.307 --> 00:06:15.538
Do you think we have a stewardship here,
to take the environment seriously?"

00:06:16.292 --> 00:06:17.570
And he said, "No."

00:06:18.243 --> 00:06:19.397
I said, "Oh, you don't?"

00:06:19.421 --> 00:06:21.246
I said, "Let me make this clear again:

00:06:21.270 --> 00:06:25.216
Do you believe that as human beings --
I'm not talking about religion --

00:06:25.240 --> 00:06:28.112
do you believe that as human beings,
it is our responsibility

00:06:28.136 --> 00:06:29.478
to take care of this planet,

00:06:29.502 --> 00:06:32.425
and make it just a little bit better
for the next generation?"

00:06:32.449 --> 00:06:35.958
And he said, "No. Not any more
than any other species."

00:06:37.158 --> 00:06:40.745
When he said the word "species,"
he was revealing his worldview.

00:06:41.340 --> 00:06:42.534
And he was saying,

00:06:42.558 --> 00:06:46.573
"I'm no more responsible to take care
of this environment than a duck is."

00:06:47.845 --> 00:06:50.435
Well now, I know a lot
of times we act like ducks,

00:06:50.459 --> 00:06:51.657
but you're not a duck.

00:06:52.593 --> 00:06:53.763
You're not a duck.

00:06:54.501 --> 00:06:57.379
And you are responsible --
that's my worldview.

00:06:58.355 --> 00:07:02.630
And so, you need to understand
what your worldview is.

00:07:02.654 --> 00:07:06.154
The problem is most people
never really think it through.

00:07:06.741 --> 00:07:10.680
They never really ...

00:07:10.704 --> 00:07:14.037
codify it or qualify it or quantify it,

00:07:14.061 --> 00:07:18.143
and say, "This is what I believe in.
This is why I believe what I believe."

00:07:18.167 --> 00:07:21.165
I don't personally have
enough faith to be an atheist.

00:07:22.117 --> 00:07:24.443
But you may, you may.

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:29.047
Your worldview, though, does determine
everything else in your life,

00:07:29.071 --> 00:07:31.793
because it determines your decisions;

00:07:31.817 --> 00:07:34.206
it determines your relationships;

00:07:34.230 --> 00:07:36.469
it determines your level of confidence.

00:07:37.040 --> 00:07:39.715
It determines, really,
everything in your life.

00:07:40.235 --> 00:07:42.012
What we believe, obviously --

00:07:42.036 --> 00:07:44.743
and you know this --
determines our behavior,

00:07:44.767 --> 00:07:48.529
and our behavior determines
what we become in life.

00:07:50.870 --> 00:07:52.934
So all of this money started pouring in,

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:55.902
and all of this fame started pouring in.

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:58.958
And I'm going, what do I do with this?

00:08:00.497 --> 00:08:03.958
My wife and I first made five decisions
on what to do with the money.

00:08:05.039 --> 00:08:09.035
We said, "First, we're not
going to use it on ourselves."

00:08:09.708 --> 00:08:11.712
I didn't go out and buy a bigger house.

00:08:12.057 --> 00:08:13.832
I don't own a guesthouse.

00:08:13.856 --> 00:08:16.958
I still drive the same four year-old
Ford that I've driven.

00:08:17.577 --> 00:08:19.760
We just said, we're not
going to use it on us.

00:08:20.617 --> 00:08:23.288
The second thing was,

00:08:23.312 --> 00:08:26.740
I stopped taking a salary
from the church that I pastor.

00:08:27.240 --> 00:08:29.979
Third thing is, I added up
all that the church had paid me

00:08:30.003 --> 00:08:32.691
over the last 25 years,
and I gave it back.

00:08:33.668 --> 00:08:36.358
And I gave it back because
I didn't want anybody thinking

00:08:36.382 --> 00:08:38.690
that I do what I do for money -- I don't.

00:08:38.714 --> 00:08:42.358
In fact, personally, I've never met

00:08:42.382 --> 00:08:45.774
a priest or a pastor or a minister
who does it for money.

00:08:45.798 --> 00:08:48.853
I know that's the stereotype;
I've never met one of them.

00:08:48.877 --> 00:08:51.958
Believe me, there's a whole lot
easier ways to make money.

00:08:52.721 --> 00:08:56.539
Pastors are like on 24 hours-a-day call,
they're like doctors.

00:08:56.563 --> 00:09:00.007
I left late today -- I'd hoped
to be here yesterday --

00:09:00.031 --> 00:09:03.481
because my father-in-law
is in his last, probably, 48 hours

00:09:03.505 --> 00:09:04.831
before he dies of cancer.

00:09:05.244 --> 00:09:07.934
And I'm watching a guy
who's lived his life --

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:11.914
he's now in his mid-80s --
and he's dying with peace.

00:09:11.938 --> 00:09:17.019
You know, the test of your worldview
is not how you act in the good times.

00:09:17.513 --> 00:09:21.151
The test of your worldview
is how you act at the funeral.

00:09:22.310 --> 00:09:26.328
And having been through literally
hundreds if not thousands of funerals,

00:09:26.352 --> 00:09:27.677
it makes a difference.

00:09:28.129 --> 00:09:30.161
It makes a difference what you believe.

00:09:31.467 --> 00:09:35.332
So, we gave it all back,

00:09:35.356 --> 00:09:38.194
and then we set up three foundations,

00:09:38.218 --> 00:09:40.615
working on some of the major
problems of the world:

00:09:40.639 --> 00:09:46.489
illiteracy, poverty, pandemic diseases --
particularly HIV/AIDS --

00:09:46.513 --> 00:09:50.691
and set up these three foundations,
and put the money into that.

00:09:50.715 --> 00:09:54.056
The last thing we did is we became
what I call "reverse tithers."

00:09:54.493 --> 00:10:01.306
And that is, when my wife
and I got married 30 years ago,

00:10:02.029 --> 00:10:04.873
we started tithing.

00:10:04.897 --> 00:10:06.986
Now, that's a principle in the Bible

00:10:07.010 --> 00:10:10.093
that says give 10 percent
of what you get back to charity,

00:10:10.117 --> 00:10:11.958
give it away to help other people.

00:10:12.823 --> 00:10:16.819
So, we started doing that, and each year
we would raise our tithe one percent.

00:10:16.843 --> 00:10:19.341
So, our first year of marriage
we went to 11 percent,

00:10:19.365 --> 00:10:21.002
second year we went to 12 percent,

00:10:21.026 --> 00:10:23.772
and the third year we went to 13 percent,

00:10:23.796 --> 00:10:25.051
and on and on and on.

00:10:26.297 --> 00:10:27.503
Why did I do that?

00:10:27.527 --> 00:10:29.119
Because every time I give,

00:10:29.143 --> 00:10:31.958
it breaks the grip
of materialism in my life.

00:10:33.175 --> 00:10:37.779
Materialism is all about getting --
get, get, get, get all you can,

00:10:37.803 --> 00:10:40.526
can all you get, sit on the can
and spoil the rest.

00:10:41.557 --> 00:10:45.473
It's all about more, having more.

00:10:45.497 --> 00:10:49.592
And we think that the good life
is actually looking good --

00:10:49.616 --> 00:10:51.107
that's most important of all --

00:10:51.131 --> 00:10:54.815
looking good, feeling good
and having the goods.

00:10:55.712 --> 00:10:57.108
But that's not the good life.

00:10:57.490 --> 00:11:01.702
I meet people all the time who have
those, and they're not necessarily happy.

00:11:01.726 --> 00:11:03.934
If money actually made you happy,

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:06.911
then the wealthiest people
in the world would be the happiest.

00:11:06.935 --> 00:11:09.339
And that I know, personally,
I know, is not true.

00:11:09.841 --> 00:11:11.037
It's just not true.

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:15.789
So, the good life is not about looking
good, feeling good or having the goods,

00:11:15.813 --> 00:11:18.042
it's about being good and doing good.

00:11:19.060 --> 00:11:20.934
Giving your life away.

00:11:21.537 --> 00:11:25.205
Significance in life
doesn't come from status,

00:11:25.229 --> 00:11:28.112
because you can always find
somebody who's got more than you.

00:11:28.136 --> 00:11:29.652
It doesn't come from sex.

00:11:29.676 --> 00:11:31.492
It doesn't come from salary.

00:11:32.262 --> 00:11:33.934
It comes from serving.

00:11:34.616 --> 00:11:37.337
It is in giving our lives away
that we find meaning,

00:11:37.361 --> 00:11:38.749
we find significance.

00:11:39.448 --> 00:11:42.551
That's the way we were wired,
I believe, by God.

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:46.934
And so we began to give away,

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:48.934
and now after 30 years,

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:52.816
my wife and I are reverse tithers --
we give away 90 percent and live on 10.

00:11:54.013 --> 00:11:55.883
That, actually, was the easy part.

00:11:55.907 --> 00:11:58.636
The hard part is, what do I do
with all this attention?

00:11:59.120 --> 00:12:02.261
Because I started getting
all kinds of invitations.

00:12:02.285 --> 00:12:06.222
I just came off a nearly
month-long speaking tour

00:12:06.246 --> 00:12:08.051
on three different continents,

00:12:08.075 --> 00:12:10.765
and I won't go into that,

00:12:10.789 --> 00:12:12.752
but it was an amazing thing.

00:12:13.410 --> 00:12:17.281
And I'm going, what do I do
with this notoriety

00:12:17.305 --> 00:12:18.749
that the book has brought?

00:12:19.759 --> 00:12:23.013
And, being a pastor,
I started reading the Bible.

00:12:23.568 --> 00:12:26.337
There's a chapter in the Bible
called Psalm 72,

00:12:26.361 --> 00:12:30.106
and it's Solomon's prayer
for more influence.

00:12:30.130 --> 00:12:31.934
When you read this prayer,

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:35.918
it sounds incredibly
selfish, self-centered.

00:12:35.981 --> 00:12:38.517
He says, "God, I want you
to make me famous."

00:12:38.541 --> 00:12:39.981
That's what he prays.

00:12:40.005 --> 00:12:41.872
He said, "I want you to make me famous.

00:12:41.896 --> 00:12:44.729
I want you to spread the fame
of my name through every land,

00:12:44.753 --> 00:12:48.064
I want you to give me power.

00:12:48.088 --> 00:12:51.703
I want you to make me famous,
I want you to give me influence."

00:12:51.727 --> 00:12:54.958
And it just sounds like the most
egotistical request you could make,

00:12:54.982 --> 00:12:56.306
if you were going to pray.

00:12:57.402 --> 00:13:00.051
Until you read the whole psalm,
the whole chapter.

00:13:00.075 --> 00:13:02.693
And then he says,
"So that the king ..." --

00:13:02.717 --> 00:13:07.504
he was the king of Israel
at that time, at its apex in power --

00:13:07.528 --> 00:13:11.267
"... so that the king may care
for the widow and orphan,

00:13:11.291 --> 00:13:15.295
support the oppressed, defend
the defenseless, care for the sick,

00:13:15.319 --> 00:13:18.934
assist the poor,
speak up for the foreigner,

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:20.934
those in prison."

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:24.127
Basically, he's talking about
all the marginalized in society.

00:13:24.715 --> 00:13:26.304
And as I read that,

00:13:26.328 --> 00:13:29.758
I looked at it, and I thought, you know,

00:13:29.782 --> 00:13:33.729
what this is saying is that the purpose
of influence is to speak up

00:13:33.753 --> 00:13:35.824
for those who have no influence.

00:13:37.721 --> 00:13:40.410
The purpose of influence
is not to build your ego.

00:13:42.950 --> 00:13:44.102
Or your net worth.

00:13:44.126 --> 00:13:47.778
And, by the way, your net worth is not
the same thing as your self-worth.

00:13:47.802 --> 00:13:51.522
Your value is not based on your valuables.

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:55.255
It's based on a whole
different set of things.

00:13:55.690 --> 00:13:58.795
And so the purpose
of influence is to speak up

00:13:58.819 --> 00:14:00.359
for those who have no influence.

00:14:00.383 --> 00:14:02.297
And I had to admit:

00:14:02.321 --> 00:14:05.347
I can't think of the last time
I thought of widows and orphans.

00:14:05.371 --> 00:14:07.471
They're not on my radar.

00:14:08.219 --> 00:14:11.407
I pastor a church in one of the most
affluent areas of America --

00:14:11.431 --> 00:14:13.288
a bunch of gated communities.

00:14:13.312 --> 00:14:15.900
I have a church full
of CEOs and scientists.

00:14:17.598 --> 00:14:21.934
And I could go five years and never,
ever see a homeless person.

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:23.934
They're just not in my pathway.

00:14:24.337 --> 00:14:27.152
Now, they're 13 miles
up the road in Santa Ana.

00:14:28.825 --> 00:14:30.934
So I had to say, ok,

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:34.743
I would use whatever affluence
and whatever influence I've got

00:14:34.767 --> 00:14:38.337
to help those who don't have
either of those.

00:14:39.568 --> 00:14:42.299
You know, there's a story
in the Bible about Moses,

00:14:42.323 --> 00:14:45.902
whether you believe it's true or not,
it really doesn't matter to me.

00:14:45.926 --> 00:14:48.566
But Moses, if you saw the movie,
"The Ten Commandments,"

00:14:48.590 --> 00:14:51.873
Moses goes out, and there's this
burning bush, and God talks to him,

00:14:51.897 --> 00:14:55.652
and God says,
"Moses, what's in your hand?"

00:14:57.219 --> 00:15:01.060
I think that's one of the most important
questions you'll ever be asked:

00:15:01.084 --> 00:15:02.411
What's in your hand?

00:15:03.374 --> 00:15:07.537
Moses says, "It's a staff.
It's a shepherd's staff."

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:09.824
And God says, "Throw it down."

00:15:09.848 --> 00:15:14.561
And if you saw the movie, you know,
he throws it down and it becomes a snake.

00:15:16.188 --> 00:15:18.364
And then God says, "Pick it up."

00:15:19.110 --> 00:15:20.934
And he picks it back up again,

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:23.578
and it becomes a staff again.

00:15:24.315 --> 00:15:28.077
Now, I'm reading this thing,
and I'm going, what is that all about?

00:15:28.101 --> 00:15:31.414
OK. What's that all about? Well,
I do know a couple of things.

00:15:31.438 --> 00:15:34.553
Number one, God never does
a miracle to show off.

00:15:35.049 --> 00:15:37.092
It's not just, "Wow, isn't that cool?"

00:15:37.116 --> 00:15:40.331
And, by the way, my God doesn't
have to show up on cheese bread.

00:15:40.839 --> 00:15:44.734
You know, if God's going to show up,
he's not going to show up on cheese bread.

00:15:44.758 --> 00:15:45.951
(Laughter)

00:15:45.975 --> 00:15:48.850
Ok? I just, this is why I love
what Michael does,

00:15:48.874 --> 00:15:53.532
because it's like, if he's debunking it,
then I don't have to.

00:15:53.556 --> 00:15:57.004
But God -- my God --
doesn't show up on sprinkler images.

00:15:57.718 --> 00:16:01.934
He's got a few more powerful ways
than that to do whatever he wants to do.

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:05.040
But he doesn't do miracles
just to show off.

00:16:05.064 --> 00:16:07.363
Second thing is,
if God ever asks you a question,

00:16:07.387 --> 00:16:08.960
he already knows the answer.

00:16:09.640 --> 00:16:11.857
Obviously, if he's God,
then that would mean

00:16:11.881 --> 00:16:15.561
that when he asks the question,
it's for your benefit, not his.

00:16:15.585 --> 00:16:17.446
So he's going, "What's in your hand?"

00:16:17.470 --> 00:16:18.934
Now, what was in Moses' hand?

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:21.958
Well, it was a shepherd's staff.
Now, follow me on this.

00:16:22.995 --> 00:16:26.400
This staff represented
three things about Moses' life.

00:16:26.424 --> 00:16:29.963
First, it represented his identity;
he was a shepherd.

00:16:29.987 --> 00:16:33.286
It's the symbol of his own occupation:

00:16:33.310 --> 00:16:34.611
I am a shepherd.

00:16:35.177 --> 00:16:37.934
It's a symbol of his identity,
his career, his job.

00:16:38.327 --> 00:16:41.477
Second, it's a symbol
of not only his identity,

00:16:41.501 --> 00:16:45.656
it's a symbol of his income, because all
of his assets are tied up in sheep.

00:16:45.680 --> 00:16:50.077
In those days, nobody had bank accounts,
or American Express cards, or hedge funds.

00:16:50.101 --> 00:16:52.815
Your assets are tied up in your flocks.

00:16:53.235 --> 00:16:56.917
So it's a symbol of his identity,
and it's a symbol of his income.

00:16:56.941 --> 00:16:59.584
And the third thing:
it's a symbol of his influence.

00:17:00.306 --> 00:17:03.613
What do you do with a shepherd's staff?

00:17:03.637 --> 00:17:07.390
Well, you know, you move sheep
from point A to point B with it,

00:17:07.414 --> 00:17:09.055
by hook or by crook.

00:17:09.079 --> 00:17:12.127
You pull them or you poke them.
One or the other.

00:17:13.363 --> 00:17:15.291
So, he's saying,

00:17:15.315 --> 00:17:17.354
"You're going to lay down your identity.

00:17:17.378 --> 00:17:18.533
What's in your hand?

00:17:18.557 --> 00:17:21.430
You've got identity, you've got income,
you've got influence.

00:17:21.454 --> 00:17:22.611
What's in your hand?"

00:17:23.456 --> 00:17:26.385
And he's saying, "If you lay it down,
I'll make it come alive.

00:17:26.409 --> 00:17:28.984
I'll do some things
you could never imagine possible."

00:17:29.008 --> 00:17:31.502
And if you've watched that movie,
"Ten Commandments,"

00:17:31.526 --> 00:17:36.006
all of those big miracles that happen
in Egypt are done through this staff.

00:17:38.110 --> 00:17:43.165
Last year, I was invited to speak
at the NBA All-Stars game.

00:17:43.898 --> 00:17:46.934
And so, I'm talking to the players,

00:17:46.958 --> 00:17:51.259
because most of the NBA teams,
NFL teams and all the other teams

00:17:51.283 --> 00:17:54.132
have done this 40 Days of Purpose,
based on the book.

00:17:54.466 --> 00:17:57.958
And I asked them, I said,
"What's in your hand?

00:17:59.350 --> 00:18:02.527
So, what's in your hand?"
I said, "It's a basketball.

00:18:03.369 --> 00:18:07.086
And that basketball represents
your identity, who you are:

00:18:07.110 --> 00:18:08.584
you're an NBA player.

00:18:08.608 --> 00:18:10.180
It represents your income:

00:18:10.204 --> 00:18:12.783
you're making a lot of money
off that little ball.

00:18:13.140 --> 00:18:14.958
And it represents your influence.

00:18:15.603 --> 00:18:18.910
And even though you're only going
to be in the NBA for a few years,

00:18:18.934 --> 00:18:21.721
you're going to be an NBA player
for the rest of your life.

00:18:21.745 --> 00:18:23.840
And that gives you enormous influence.

00:18:24.212 --> 00:18:27.487
So, what are you going to do
with what you've been given?"

00:18:28.743 --> 00:18:33.232
And I guess that's the main reason
I came up here today,

00:18:33.256 --> 00:18:36.185
to all of you very bright people at TED --

00:18:36.209 --> 00:18:38.106
it is to say, "What's in your hand?"

00:18:40.114 --> 00:18:43.633
What do you have that you've been given?

00:18:44.564 --> 00:18:47.934
Talent, background, education,

00:18:47.958 --> 00:18:52.117
freedom, networks, opportunities,

00:18:52.141 --> 00:18:55.684
wealth, ideas, creativity.

00:18:55.708 --> 00:18:59.757
What are you doing
with what you've been given?

00:18:59.781 --> 00:19:03.671
That, to me, is the primary
question about life.

00:19:03.695 --> 00:19:06.777
That, to me, is what being
purpose-driven is all about.

00:19:07.957 --> 00:19:11.161
In the book, I talk about
how you're wired to do certain things,

00:19:11.185 --> 00:19:14.854
you're "SHAPED" with -- a little acrostic:
Spiritual gifts, Heart,

00:19:14.878 --> 00:19:17.266
Ability, Personality and Experiences.

00:19:17.290 --> 00:19:18.934
These things shape you.

00:19:19.378 --> 00:19:22.502
And if you want to know what you ought
to be doing with your life,

00:19:22.526 --> 00:19:25.263
you need to look at your shape --
"What am I wired to do?"

00:19:25.287 --> 00:19:28.605
Why would God wire you to do something
and then not have you do it?

00:19:28.629 --> 00:19:31.877
If you're wired to be an anthropologist,
you'll be an anthropologist.

00:19:31.901 --> 00:19:33.909
If you're wired to be
an undersea explorer,

00:19:33.933 --> 00:19:35.425
you'll be an undersea explorer.

00:19:35.449 --> 00:19:37.615
If you're wired to make deals,
you make deals.

00:19:37.639 --> 00:19:39.598
If you're wired to paint, you paint.

00:19:40.313 --> 00:19:42.958
Did you know that God smiles
when you be you?

00:19:44.532 --> 00:19:46.879
When my little kids --
when my kids were little --

00:19:46.903 --> 00:19:48.910
they're all grown now, I have grandkids --

00:19:48.934 --> 00:19:51.246
I used to go in and sit
on the side of their bed,

00:19:51.270 --> 00:19:53.038
and I used to watch my kids sleep.

00:19:54.110 --> 00:19:59.556
And I just watched their little bodies
rise and lower, rise and lower.

00:19:59.580 --> 00:20:02.435
And I would look at them:
"This is not an accident."

00:20:02.459 --> 00:20:04.165
Rise and lower.

00:20:05.205 --> 00:20:08.958
And I got joy out of just
watching them sleep.

00:20:10.958 --> 00:20:14.525
Some people have the misguided idea
that God only gets excited

00:20:14.549 --> 00:20:16.669
when you're doing, quote,
"spiritual things,"

00:20:16.693 --> 00:20:19.406
like going to church or helping the poor,

00:20:19.430 --> 00:20:22.783
or, you know, confessing
or doing something like that.

00:20:23.378 --> 00:20:27.736
The bottom line is, God gets pleasure
watching you be you.

00:20:27.760 --> 00:20:29.164
Why? He made you.

00:20:29.848 --> 00:20:32.245
And when you do what you were made to do,

00:20:32.269 --> 00:20:36.316
he goes, "That's my boy! That's my girl!

00:20:36.340 --> 00:20:39.725
You're using the talent
and ability that I gave you."

00:20:40.471 --> 00:20:42.351
So my advice to you is:

00:20:42.375 --> 00:20:44.105
look at what's in your hand --

00:20:44.129 --> 00:20:47.668
your identity, your influence,
your income --

00:20:48.819 --> 00:20:51.322
and say, "It's not about me.

00:20:51.346 --> 00:20:54.386
It's about making the world
a better place."

00:20:55.392 --> 00:20:56.542
Thank you.

title: My wish: A call for open-source architecture
transcript: I'm going to take you on a journey very quickly. To explain the wish, I'm going to have to take you somewhere where many people haven't been, and that's around the world. When I was about 24 years old, Kate Stohr and myself started an organization to get architects and designers involved in humanitarian work, not only about responding to natural disasters, but involved in systemic issues. We believe that where the resources and expertise are scarce, innovative, sustainable design can really make a difference in people's lives.So I started my life as an architect, or training as an architect, and I was always interested in socially responsible design, and how you can really make an impact. But when I went to architecture school, it seemed that I was a black sheep in the family. Many architects seemed to think that when you design, you design a jewel, and it's a jewel that you try and crave for; whereas I felt that when you design, you either improve or you create a detriment to the community in which you're designing. So you're not just doing a building for the residents or for the people who are going to use it, but for the community as a whole.And in 1999, we started by responding to the issue of the housing crisis for returning refugees in Kosovo. And I didn't know what I was doing — like I said, mid-20s — and I'm the Internet generation, so we started a website. We put a call out there, and to my surprise, in a couple of months, we had hundreds of entries from around the world. That led to a number of prototypes being built and really experimenting with some ideas. Two years later we started doing a project on developing mobile health clinics in sub-Saharan Africa, responding to the HIV/AIDS pandemic. That led to 550 entries from 53 countries. We also have designers from around the world that participate. And we had an exhibit of work that followed that. 2004 was the tipping point for us. We started responding to natural disasters and getting involved in Iran, in Bam, also following up on our work in Africa.Working within the United States — most people look at poverty and they see the face of a foreigner. But I live in Bozeman, Montana — go up to the north plains on the reservations, or go down to Alabama or Mississippi, pre-Katrina, and I could have shown you places that have far worse conditions than many developing countries that I've been to. So we got involved in and worked in inner cities and elsewhere;and also, I will go into some more projects. 2005: Mother Nature kicked our ass. I think we can pretty much assume that 2005 was a horrific year when it comes to natural disasters. And because of the Internet, and because of connections to blogs and so forth, within literally hours of the tsunami, we were already raising funds, getting involved, working with people on the ground. We run from a couple of laptops, and in the first couple of days, I had 4,000 emails from people needing help. So we began to get involved in projects there, and I'll talk about some others. And then of course, this year we've been responding to Katrina, as well as following up on our reconstruction work.So this is a brief overview. In 2004, I really couldn't manage the number of people who wanted to help, or the number of requests that I was getting. It was all coming into my laptop and cell phone. So we decided to embrace an open-source model of business — so that anyone, anywhere in the world, could start a local chapter, and they can get involved in local problems. Because I believe there is no such thing as Utopia. All problems are local. All solutions are local. So that means, you know, somebody who's based in Mississippi knows more about Mississippi than I do. So what happened is, we used Meetup and all these other Internet tools, and we ended up having 40 chapters starting up, thousands of architects in 104 countries. So the bullet point — sorry, I never do a suit, so I knew that I was going to take this off. OK, because I'm going to do it very quick.This isn't just about nonprofit. What it showed me is that there's a grassroots movement going on, of socially responsible designers who really believe that this world has got a lot smaller, and that we have the opportunity — not the responsibility, but the opportunity — to really get involved in making change.(Laughter)(Laughter)I'm adding that to my time.(Laughter)So what you don't know is, we've got these thousands of designers working around the world, connected basically by a website, and we have a staff of three. The fact that nobody told us we couldn't do it, we did it. And so there's something to be said about naïveté. So seven years later, we've developed so that we've got advocacy, instigation and implementation. We advocate for good design, not only through student workshops and lectures and public forums, op-eds; we have a book on humanitarian work; but also disaster mitigation and dealing with public policy. We can talk about FEMA, but that's another talk. Instigation, developing ideas with communities and NGOs, doing open-source design competitions. Referring, matchmaking with communities. And then implementing — actually going out there and doing the work, because when you invent, it's never a reality until it's built. So it's really important that if we're designing and trying to create change, we build that change.So here's a select number of projects. Kosovo. This is Kosovo in '99. We did an open design competition, like I said. It led to a whole variety of ideas. And this wasn't about emergency shelter, but transitional shelter that would last five to 10 years, that would be placed next to the land the resident lived in, and that they would rebuild their own home. This wasn't imposing an architecture on a community; this was giving them the tools and the space to allow them to rebuild and regrow the way they want to. We had from the sublime to the ridiculous, but they worked. This is an inflatable hemp house. It was built; it works.This is a shipping container. Built and works. And a whole variety of ideas that not only dealt with architectural building, but also the issues of governance, and the idea of creating communities through complex networks.So we've engaged not just designers, but also a whole variety of technology-based professionals. Using rubble from destroyed homes to create new homes. Using straw bale construction, creating heat walls. And then something remarkable happened in '99.We went to Africa originally to look at the housing issue. Within three days, we realized the problem was not housing; it was the growing pandemic of HIV/AIDS. And it wasn't doctors telling us this; it was actual villagers that we were staying with. And so we came up with the bright idea that instead of getting people to walk 10, 15 kilometers to see doctors, you get the doctors to the people. And we started engaging the medical community, and you know, we thought we were real bright sparks — "We've come up with this great idea: mobile health clinics, widely distributed throughout sub-Saharan Africa." And the medical community there said, "We've said this for the last decade. We know this. We just don't know how to show this." So in a way, we had taken pre-existing needs and shown solutions. And so again, we had a whole variety of ideas that came in.This one I personally love, because the idea is that architecture is not just about solutions, but about raising awareness. This is a kenaf clinic. You get seed and you grow it in a plot of land, and it grows 14 feet in a month. And on the fourth week, the doctors come and they mow out an area, put a tensile structure on the top, and when the doctors have finished treating and seeing patients and villagers, you cut down the clinic and you eat it. It's an eat-your-own-clinic.So it's dealing with the fact that if you have AIDS, you also need to have nutrition rates, and the idea of nutrition is as important as getting antiretrovirals out there. So you know, this is a serious solution. This one I love. The idea is it's not just a clinic, it's a community center. This looked at setting up trade routes and economic engines within the community, so it can be a self-sustaining project.Every one of these projects is sustainable. That's not because I'm a tree-hugging green person. It's because when you live on four dollars a day, you're living on survival and you have to be sustainable. You have to know where your energy is coming from, you have to know where your resource is coming from, and you have to keep the maintenance down. So this is about getting an economic engine, and then at night, it turns into a movie theater. So it's not an AIDS clinic. It's a community center. So you can see ideas. And these ideas developed into prototypes, and they were eventually built. And currently, as of this year, there are clinics rolling out in Nigeria and Kenya.From that, we also developed Siyathemba. The community came to us and said, "The problem is that the girls don't have education." And we're working in an area where young women between the ages of 16 and 24 have a 50 percent HIV/AIDS rate. And that's not because they're promiscuous, it's because there's no knowledge.And so we decided to look at the idea of sports, and create a youth sports center that doubled as an HIV/AIDS outreach center, and the coaches of the girls' team were also trained doctors. So that there would be a very slow way of developing confidence in health care. And we picked nine finalists, and then those nine finalists were distributed throughout the entire region, and then the community picked their design. They said, this is our design, because it's not only about engaging a community; it's about empowering a community, and about getting them to be a part of the rebuilding process.So, the winning design is here. And then, of course, we actually go and work with the community and the clients.So this is the designer. He's out there working with the first ever women's soccer team in KwaZulu-Natal, Siyathemba. And they can tell it better.(A cappella singing in a South African language)Video: Well, my name is Cee Cee Mkhonza. I work at the Africa Centre, I'm an IT user consultant. I'm also the national football player for South Africa, Banyana Banyana. And I also play in the Vodacom League, for the team called Tembisa, which has now changed to Siyathemba. This is our home ground.Cameron Sinclair: I'm going to show that later because I'm running out of time. I can see Chris looking at me slyly.This was a connection, just a meeting with somebody who wanted to develop Africa's first telemedicine center, in Tanzania. And we met, literally, a couple of months ago. We've already developed a design. The team is over there, working in partnership. This was a matchmaking, thanks to a couple of TEDsters — Sun [Microsystems], Cheryl Heller and Andrew Zolli, who connected me with this amazing African woman. And we start construction in June, and it will be opened by TEDGlobal. So when you come to TEDGlobal, you can check it out.But what we're known probably most for is dealing with disasters and development, and we've been involved in a lot of issues, such as the tsunami and also things like Hurricane Katrina. This is a 370-dollar shelter that can be easily assembled. This is a community-designed community center. And what that means is we actually live and work with the community, and they're part of the design process. The kids actually get involved in mapping out where the community center should be. And then eventually, the community, through skills training, end up building the building with us.Here is another school. This is what the UN gave these guys for six months — 12 plastic tarps. This was in August. This was the replacement; that's supposed to last for two years. When the rain comes down, you can't hear a thing, and in the summer, it's about 140 degrees inside. So we said, if the rain's coming down, let's get fresh water. So every one of our schools has a rainwater collection system. Very low cost: three classrooms and rainwater collection is 5,000 dollars. This was raised by hot chocolate sales in Atlanta. It's built by the parents of the kids. The kids are out there on-site, building the buildings. And it opened a couple of weeks ago, and there's 600 kids that are now using the schools.(Applause)So, disaster hits home. We see the bad stories on CNN and Fox and all that, but we don't see the good stories. Here is a community that got together, and they said "no" to waiting. They formed a partnership, a diverse partnership of players, to actually map out East Biloxi, to figure out who's getting involved. We've had over 1,500 volunteers rebuilding, rehabbing homes. Figuring out what FEMA regulations are, not waiting for them to dictate to us how you should rebuild. Working with residents, getting them out of their homes, so they don't get ill. This is what they're cleaning up on their own. Designing housing. This house is going in in a couple of weeks. This is a rehabbed home, done in four days. This is a utility room for a woman who is on a walker. She's 70 years old. This is what FEMA gave her. 600 bucks, happened two days ago. We put together, very quickly, a washroom. It's built, it's running and she just started a business today, where she's washing other people's clothes.These are the Calhouns. They're photographers who had documented the Lower Ninth for the last 40 years. That was their home, and these are the photographs they took. And we're helping, working with them to create a new building. Projects we've done. Projects we've been a part of, support. Why don't aid agencies do this? This is the UN tent. This is the new UN tent, just introduced this year. Quick to assemble. It's got a flap — that's the invention. It took 20 years to design this and get it implemented in the field. I was 12 years old. There's a problem here.Luckily, we're not alone. There are hundreds and hundreds and hundreds and hundreds and hundreds of architects and designers and inventors around the world that are getting involved in humanitarian work. More hemp houses — it's a theme in Japan, apparently. I'm not sure what they're smoking.(Laughter)This is a Grip Clip, designed by somebody who said, "All you need is some way to attach membrane structures to physical support beams." This guy designed for NASA, is now doing housing. I'm going to whip through this quickly, because I know I've got only a couple of minutes.So this is all done in the last two years. I showed you something that took 20 years to do. And this is just a selection of things that were built in the last couple of years. From Brazil to India, Mexico, Alabama, China, Israel, Palestine, Vietnam.The average age of a designer who gets involved in this project is 32 — that's how old I am. So it's a young — I just have to stop here, because Arup is in the room, and this is the best-designed toilet in the world. If you're ever, ever in India, go use this toilet.(Laughter)Chris Luebkeman will tell you why. I'm sure that's how he wanted to spend the party. But the future is not going to be the sky-scraping cities of New York, but this. And when you look at this, you see crisis. What I see is many, many inventors. One billion people live in abject poverty. We hear about them all the time. Four billion live in growing but fragile economies. One in seven live in unplanned settlements. If we do nothing about the housing crisis that's about to happen, in 20 years, one in three people will live in an unplanned settlement or a refugee camp. Look left, look right: one of you will be there. How do we improve the living standards of five billion people? With 10 million solutions.So I wish to develop a community that actively embraces innovative and sustainable design to improve the living conditions for everyone.Chris Anderson: Wait a sec — that's your wish?CS: That's my wish.CA: That's his wish!(Applause)CS: We started Architecture for Humanity with 700 dollars and a website. So Chris somehow decided to give me 100,000. So why not this many people? Open-source architecture is the way to go. You have a diverse community of participants — and we're not just talking about inventors and designers, but we're talking about the funding model. My role is not as a designer; it's as a conduit between the design world and the humanitarian world. And what we need is something that replicates me globally, because I haven't slept in seven years.(Laughter)Secondly, what will this thing be? Designers want to respond to issues of humanitarian crisis, but they don't want some company in the West taking their idea and basically profiting from it. So Creative Commons has developed the Developing Nations license. And what that means is that a designer can — The Siyathemba project I showed was the first ever building to have a Creative Commons license on it. As soon as that is built, anyone in Africa or any developing nation can take the construction documents and replicate it for free.(Applause)So why not allow designers the opportunity to do this, but still protect their rights here? We want to have a community where you can upload ideas, and those ideas can be tested in an earthquake, in flood, in all sorts of austere environments. The reason that's important is I don't want to wait for the next Katrina to find out if my house works. That's too late, we need to do it now. So doing that globally — and I want this whole thing to work multi-lingually. When you look at the face of an architect, most people think a gray-haired white guy. I don't see that; I see the face of the world. So I want everyone from all over the planet to be able to be a part of this design and development. The idea of needs-based competitions — XPRIZE for the other 98 percent, if you want to call it that.We also want to look at ways of matchmaking and putting funding partners together, and the idea of integrating manufacturers — fab labs in every country. When I hear about the $100 laptop and it's going to educate every child — educate every designer in the world. Put one in every favela, every slum settlement. Because you know what? Innovation will happen. And I need to know that. It's called the leap-back. We talk about leapfrog technologies.I write with Worldchanging, and the one thing we've been talking about is, I learn more on the ground than I've ever learned here. So let's take those ideas, adapt them, and we can use them. These ideas are supposed to be adaptable; they should have the potential for evolution; they should be developed by every nation in the world and useful for every nation in the world. What will it take?There should be a sheet. I don't have time to read this, because I'm going to be yanked off.CA: Let's just leave it up for a sec.CS: Well, what will it take? You guys are smart. So it's going to take a lot of computing power, because I want the idea that any laptop anywhere in the world can plug into the system and be able to not only participate in developing these designs, but utilize the designs. Also, a process of reviewing the designs. I want every Arup engineer in the world to check and make sure that we're doing stuff that's standing, because those guys are the best in the world. Plug. And so, you know, I want these —I just should note: I have two laptops and one of them is there, and that has 3000 designs on it. If I drop that laptop ... What happens? So it's important to have these proven ideas put up there, easy to use, easy to get ahold of. My mom once said, "There's nothing worse than being all mouth and no trousers."(Laughter)I'm fed up of talking about making change. You only make it by doing it. We've changed FEMA guidelines; we've changed public policy; we've changed international response — based on building things. So for me, it's important that we create a real conduit for innovation, and that it's free innovation. Think of free culture — this is free innovation. Somebody said this a couple of years back. I will give points for those who know it. But I think the man was maybe 25 years too early.So let's do it.Thank you.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:14.212
I'm going to take you
on a journey very quickly.

00:00:14.236 --> 00:00:17.085
To explain the wish, I'm going
to have to take you somewhere

00:00:17.109 --> 00:00:19.938
where many people haven't been,
and that's around the world.

00:00:19.962 --> 00:00:24.071
When I was about 24 years old, Kate Stohr
and myself started an organization

00:00:24.095 --> 00:00:27.735
to get architects and designers
involved in humanitarian work,

00:00:27.759 --> 00:00:30.402
not only about responding
to natural disasters,

00:00:30.426 --> 00:00:32.180
but involved in systemic issues.

00:00:33.394 --> 00:00:37.973
We believe that where the resources
and expertise are scarce,

00:00:37.997 --> 00:00:42.743
innovative, sustainable design can really
make a difference in people's lives.

00:00:44.076 --> 00:00:48.977
So I started my life as an architect,
or training as an architect,

00:00:49.001 --> 00:00:52.418
and I was always interested
in socially responsible design,

00:00:52.442 --> 00:00:54.334
and how you can really make an impact.

00:00:54.358 --> 00:00:56.304
But when I went to architecture school,

00:00:56.328 --> 00:00:59.279
it seemed that I was
a black sheep in the family.

00:00:59.303 --> 00:01:01.970
Many architects seemed to think
that when you design,

00:01:01.994 --> 00:01:05.775
you design a jewel, and it's a jewel
that you try and crave for;

00:01:05.799 --> 00:01:07.736
whereas I felt that when you design,

00:01:07.760 --> 00:01:10.415
you either improve
or you create a detriment

00:01:10.439 --> 00:01:12.502
to the community
in which you're designing.

00:01:12.526 --> 00:01:15.034
So you're not just doing
a building for the residents

00:01:15.058 --> 00:01:18.637
or for the people who are going to use it,
but for the community as a whole.

00:01:18.661 --> 00:01:25.087
And in 1999, we started by responding
to the issue of the housing crisis

00:01:25.111 --> 00:01:27.122
for returning refugees in Kosovo.

00:01:27.146 --> 00:01:30.758
And I didn't know what I was doing --
like I said, mid-20s --

00:01:30.782 --> 00:01:35.331
and I'm the Internet generation,
so we started a website.

00:01:35.355 --> 00:01:38.844
We put a call out there,
and to my surprise, in a couple of months,

00:01:38.868 --> 00:01:41.202
we had hundreds of entries
from around the world.

00:01:42.090 --> 00:01:44.263
That led to a number
of prototypes being built

00:01:44.287 --> 00:01:46.534
and really experimenting with some ideas.

00:01:47.230 --> 00:01:49.361
Two years later we started doing a project

00:01:49.385 --> 00:01:53.019
on developing mobile health clinics
in sub-Saharan Africa,

00:01:53.043 --> 00:01:55.594
responding to the HIV/AIDS pandemic.

00:01:57.376 --> 00:02:03.760
That led to 550 entries from 53 countries.

00:02:03.784 --> 00:02:08.534
We also have designers
from around the world that participate.

00:02:08.558 --> 00:02:12.204
And we had an exhibit
of work that followed that.

00:02:12.228 --> 00:02:14.642
2004 was the tipping point for us.

00:02:14.666 --> 00:02:16.687
We started responding to natural disasters

00:02:16.711 --> 00:02:19.332
and getting involved in Iran, in Bam,

00:02:19.356 --> 00:02:22.056
also following up on our work in Africa.

00:02:22.080 --> 00:02:23.928
Working within the United States --

00:02:23.952 --> 00:02:27.023
most people look at poverty
and they see the face of a foreigner.

00:02:27.047 --> 00:02:29.121
But I live in Bozeman, Montana --

00:02:29.145 --> 00:02:31.363
go up to the north plains
on the reservations,

00:02:31.387 --> 00:02:34.812
or go down to Alabama
or Mississippi, pre-Katrina,

00:02:34.836 --> 00:02:37.868
and I could have shown you
places that have far worse conditions

00:02:37.892 --> 00:02:40.198
than many developing countries
that I've been to.

00:02:40.222 --> 00:02:43.710
So we got involved in and worked
in inner cities and elsewhere;

00:02:43.734 --> 00:02:47.151
and also, I will go into
some more projects.

00:02:47.175 --> 00:02:50.069
2005: Mother Nature kicked our ass.

00:02:50.093 --> 00:02:54.846
I think we can pretty much assume
that 2005 was a horrific year

00:02:54.870 --> 00:02:56.537
when it comes to natural disasters.

00:02:56.561 --> 00:02:58.051
And because of the Internet,

00:02:58.075 --> 00:03:01.464
and because of connections
to blogs and so forth,

00:03:01.488 --> 00:03:05.940
within literally hours of the tsunami,
we were already raising funds,

00:03:05.964 --> 00:03:09.023
getting involved, working
with people on the ground.

00:03:09.564 --> 00:03:12.746
We run from a couple of laptops,
and in the first couple of days,

00:03:12.770 --> 00:03:15.533
I had 4,000 emails
from people needing help.

00:03:15.873 --> 00:03:18.746
So we began to get involved
in projects there,

00:03:18.770 --> 00:03:20.384
and I'll talk about some others.

00:03:20.408 --> 00:03:23.379
And then of course, this year
we've been responding to Katrina,

00:03:23.403 --> 00:03:25.847
as well as following up
on our reconstruction work.

00:03:25.871 --> 00:03:27.582
So this is a brief overview.

00:03:28.558 --> 00:03:32.975
In 2004, I really couldn't manage
the number of people who wanted to help,

00:03:32.999 --> 00:03:35.104
or the number of requests
that I was getting.

00:03:35.128 --> 00:03:37.659
It was all coming
into my laptop and cell phone.

00:03:37.683 --> 00:03:43.056
So we decided to embrace
an open-source model of business --

00:03:43.080 --> 00:03:46.247
so that anyone, anywhere in the world,
could start a local chapter,

00:03:46.271 --> 00:03:48.337
and they can get involved
in local problems.

00:03:48.361 --> 00:03:50.772
Because I believe there
is no such thing as Utopia.

00:03:50.796 --> 00:03:53.368
All problems are local.
All solutions are local.

00:03:53.392 --> 00:03:58.026
So that means, you know,
somebody who's based in Mississippi

00:03:58.050 --> 00:04:00.403
knows more about Mississippi than I do.

00:04:00.427 --> 00:04:06.534
So what happened is, we used Meetup
and all these other Internet tools,

00:04:06.558 --> 00:04:10.849
and we ended up having
40 chapters starting up,

00:04:10.873 --> 00:04:13.664
thousands of architects in 104 countries.

00:04:14.966 --> 00:04:18.407
So the bullet point --
sorry, I never do a suit,

00:04:18.431 --> 00:04:20.826
so I knew that I was going
to take this off.

00:04:20.850 --> 00:04:23.153
OK, because I'm going to do it very quick.

00:04:25.161 --> 00:04:27.184
This isn't just about nonprofit.

00:04:27.208 --> 00:04:30.382
What it showed me is that
there's a grassroots movement going on,

00:04:30.406 --> 00:04:32.980
of socially responsible designers
who really believe

00:04:33.004 --> 00:04:36.916
that this world has got a lot smaller,
and that we have the opportunity --

00:04:36.940 --> 00:04:39.096
not the responsibility,
but the opportunity --

00:04:39.120 --> 00:04:41.433
to really get involved in making change.

00:04:43.623 --> 00:04:46.705
(Laughter)

00:04:48.899 --> 00:04:52.923
(Laughter)

00:04:52.947 --> 00:04:54.746
I'm adding that to my time.

00:04:54.770 --> 00:04:57.571
(Laughter)

00:04:57.595 --> 00:04:59.534
So what you don't know is,

00:04:59.558 --> 00:05:02.582
we've got these thousands of designers
working around the world,

00:05:02.606 --> 00:05:05.637
connected basically by a website,
and we have a staff of three.

00:05:06.462 --> 00:05:10.876
The fact that nobody told us
we couldn't do it, we did it.

00:05:10.900 --> 00:05:13.248
And so there's something
to be said about naïveté.

00:05:13.272 --> 00:05:15.169
So seven years later, we've developed

00:05:15.193 --> 00:05:18.607
so that we've got advocacy,
instigation and implementation.

00:05:18.631 --> 00:05:22.276
We advocate for good design,
not only through student workshops

00:05:22.300 --> 00:05:24.622
and lectures and public forums, op-eds;

00:05:24.646 --> 00:05:26.867
we have a book on humanitarian work;

00:05:26.891 --> 00:05:30.074
but also disaster mitigation
and dealing with public policy.

00:05:30.098 --> 00:05:33.312
We can talk about FEMA,
but that's another talk.

00:05:33.994 --> 00:05:37.354
Instigation, developing ideas
with communities and NGOs,

00:05:37.378 --> 00:05:40.206
doing open-source design competitions.

00:05:40.230 --> 00:05:42.738
Referring, matchmaking with communities.

00:05:42.762 --> 00:05:46.069
And then implementing -- actually
going out there and doing the work,

00:05:46.093 --> 00:05:51.827
because when you invent,
it's never a reality until it's built.

00:05:52.296 --> 00:05:55.037
So it's really important
that if we're designing

00:05:55.061 --> 00:05:57.735
and trying to create change,
we build that change.

00:05:57.759 --> 00:05:59.819
So here's a select number of projects.

00:06:01.422 --> 00:06:02.644
Kosovo.

00:06:03.628 --> 00:06:05.300
This is Kosovo in '99.

00:06:05.665 --> 00:06:08.515
We did an open design
competition, like I said.

00:06:08.539 --> 00:06:10.933
It led to a whole variety of ideas.

00:06:10.957 --> 00:06:12.875
And this wasn't about emergency shelter,

00:06:12.899 --> 00:06:16.421
but transitional shelter
that would last five to 10 years,

00:06:16.445 --> 00:06:20.454
that would be placed next to the land
the resident lived in,

00:06:20.478 --> 00:06:22.605
and that they would rebuild
their own home.

00:06:22.629 --> 00:06:25.307
This wasn't imposing
an architecture on a community;

00:06:25.331 --> 00:06:28.453
this was giving them
the tools and the space

00:06:28.477 --> 00:06:32.166
to allow them to rebuild and regrow
the way they want to.

00:06:33.245 --> 00:06:36.165
We had from the sublime
to the ridiculous, but they worked.

00:06:36.189 --> 00:06:40.789
This is an inflatable hemp house.
It was built; it works.

00:06:41.558 --> 00:06:43.473
This is a shipping container.

00:06:44.638 --> 00:06:46.298
Built and works.

00:06:46.322 --> 00:06:47.672
And a whole variety of ideas

00:06:47.696 --> 00:06:51.203
that not only dealt with
architectural building,

00:06:51.227 --> 00:06:52.901
but also the issues of governance,

00:06:52.925 --> 00:06:56.336
and the idea of creating communities
through complex networks.

00:06:56.360 --> 00:06:58.182
So we've engaged not just designers,

00:06:58.206 --> 00:07:03.731
but also a whole variety
of technology-based professionals.

00:07:03.755 --> 00:07:07.362
Using rubble from destroyed homes
to create new homes.

00:07:07.386 --> 00:07:13.240
Using straw bale construction,
creating heat walls.

00:07:13.692 --> 00:07:15.860
And then something remarkable
happened in '99.

00:07:15.884 --> 00:07:19.657
We went to Africa originally
to look at the housing issue.

00:07:20.006 --> 00:07:22.793
Within three days, we realized
the problem was not housing;

00:07:22.817 --> 00:07:25.523
it was the growing pandemic of HIV/AIDS.

00:07:25.928 --> 00:07:27.781
And it wasn't doctors telling us this;

00:07:27.805 --> 00:07:30.472
it was actual villagers
that we were staying with.

00:07:30.829 --> 00:07:33.441
And so we came up with the bright idea

00:07:33.465 --> 00:07:37.660
that instead of getting people to walk
10, 15 kilometers to see doctors,

00:07:37.684 --> 00:07:39.523
you get the doctors to the people.

00:07:39.547 --> 00:07:42.415
And we started engaging
the medical community,

00:07:42.439 --> 00:07:45.542
and you know, we thought
we were real bright sparks --

00:07:45.566 --> 00:07:47.312
"We've come up with this great idea:

00:07:47.336 --> 00:07:51.918
mobile health clinics, widely distributed
throughout sub-Saharan Africa."

00:07:52.307 --> 00:07:54.751
And the medical community there said,

00:07:54.775 --> 00:07:57.241
"We've said this for the last decade.

00:07:57.265 --> 00:08:00.343
We know this. We just don't know
how to show this."

00:08:00.367 --> 00:08:05.611
So in a way, we had taken pre-existing
needs and shown solutions.

00:08:06.135 --> 00:08:10.092
And so again, we had a whole variety
of ideas that came in.

00:08:11.131 --> 00:08:12.974
This one I personally love,

00:08:12.998 --> 00:08:16.299
because the idea is that architecture
is not just about solutions,

00:08:16.323 --> 00:08:18.002
but about raising awareness.

00:08:18.026 --> 00:08:20.440
This is a kenaf clinic.

00:08:20.464 --> 00:08:23.534
You get seed and you grow it
in a plot of land,

00:08:23.558 --> 00:08:27.227
and it grows 14 feet in a month.

00:08:27.251 --> 00:08:30.403
And on the fourth week, the doctors
come and they mow out an area,

00:08:30.427 --> 00:08:32.506
put a tensile structure on the top,

00:08:32.530 --> 00:08:35.202
and when the doctors
have finished treating

00:08:35.226 --> 00:08:38.947
and seeing patients and villagers,

00:08:38.971 --> 00:08:40.843
you cut down the clinic and you eat it.

00:08:40.867 --> 00:08:42.534
It's an eat-your-own-clinic.

00:08:42.558 --> 00:08:45.912
So it's dealing with the fact
that if you have AIDS,

00:08:45.936 --> 00:08:47.880
you also need to have nutrition rates,

00:08:47.904 --> 00:08:50.760
and the idea of nutrition is as important

00:08:50.784 --> 00:08:52.618
as getting antiretrovirals out there.

00:08:52.642 --> 00:08:55.130
So you know, this is a serious solution.

00:08:56.001 --> 00:08:57.157
This one I love.

00:08:57.181 --> 00:09:00.006
The idea is it's not just a clinic,
it's a community center.

00:09:00.030 --> 00:09:02.053
This looked at setting up trade routes

00:09:02.077 --> 00:09:04.142
and economic engines within the community,

00:09:04.166 --> 00:09:06.380
so it can be a self-sustaining project.

00:09:06.404 --> 00:09:08.721
Every one of these projects
is sustainable.

00:09:09.134 --> 00:09:12.438
That's not because
I'm a tree-hugging green person.

00:09:12.462 --> 00:09:14.786
It's because when you live
on four dollars a day,

00:09:14.810 --> 00:09:17.833
you're living on survival
and you have to be sustainable.

00:09:18.185 --> 00:09:20.535
You have to know where
your energy is coming from,

00:09:20.559 --> 00:09:23.011
you have to know where
your resource is coming from,

00:09:23.035 --> 00:09:25.049
and you have to keep the maintenance down.

00:09:25.073 --> 00:09:27.161
So this is about getting
an economic engine,

00:09:27.185 --> 00:09:29.478
and then at night,
it turns into a movie theater.

00:09:29.502 --> 00:09:34.629
So it's not an AIDS clinic.
It's a community center.

00:09:34.653 --> 00:09:36.153
So you can see ideas.

00:09:36.867 --> 00:09:39.534
And these ideas developed into prototypes,

00:09:39.558 --> 00:09:41.349
and they were eventually built.

00:09:41.373 --> 00:09:42.880
And currently, as of this year,

00:09:42.904 --> 00:09:47.165
there are clinics rolling out
in Nigeria and Kenya.

00:09:48.934 --> 00:09:52.497
From that, we also developed Siyathemba.

00:09:52.521 --> 00:09:54.182
The community came to us and said,

00:09:54.206 --> 00:09:57.229
"The problem is that the girls
don't have education."

00:09:57.253 --> 00:09:58.603
And we're working in an area

00:09:58.627 --> 00:10:00.856
where young women
between the ages of 16 and 24

00:10:00.880 --> 00:10:03.156
have a 50 percent HIV/AIDS rate.

00:10:04.275 --> 00:10:07.037
And that's not
because they're promiscuous,

00:10:07.061 --> 00:10:08.711
it's because there's no knowledge.

00:10:08.735 --> 00:10:11.734
And so we decided to look
at the idea of sports,

00:10:11.758 --> 00:10:13.600
and create a youth sports center

00:10:13.624 --> 00:10:16.422
that doubled as an HIV/AIDS
outreach center,

00:10:16.446 --> 00:10:20.279
and the coaches of the girls' team
were also trained doctors.

00:10:20.303 --> 00:10:27.114
So that there would be a very slow way
of developing confidence in health care.

00:10:27.472 --> 00:10:29.917
And we picked nine finalists,

00:10:29.941 --> 00:10:33.750
and then those nine finalists were
distributed throughout the entire region,

00:10:33.774 --> 00:10:35.901
and then the community
picked their design.

00:10:35.925 --> 00:10:37.853
They said, this is our design,

00:10:37.877 --> 00:10:40.177
because it's not only
about engaging a community;

00:10:40.201 --> 00:10:41.895
it's about empowering a community,

00:10:41.919 --> 00:10:45.141
and about getting them to be
a part of the rebuilding process.

00:10:46.696 --> 00:10:48.978
So, the winning design is here.

00:10:50.558 --> 00:10:52.621
And then, of course,
we actually go and work

00:10:52.645 --> 00:10:54.328
with the community and the clients.

00:10:54.352 --> 00:10:55.550
So this is the designer.

00:10:55.574 --> 00:10:58.527
He's out there working
with the first ever women's soccer team

00:10:58.551 --> 00:11:01.448
in KwaZulu-Natal, Siyathemba.

00:11:01.829 --> 00:11:04.203
And they can tell it better.

00:11:04.972 --> 00:11:07.737
(A cappella singing
in a South African language)

00:11:26.463 --> 00:11:28.448
Video: Well, my name is Cee Cee Mkhonza.

00:11:28.472 --> 00:11:31.418
I work at the Africa Centre,
I'm an IT user consultant.

00:11:31.442 --> 00:11:35.926
I'm also the national football player
for South Africa, Banyana Banyana.

00:11:35.950 --> 00:11:42.685
And I also play in the Vodacom League,
for the team called Tembisa,

00:11:42.709 --> 00:11:44.856
which has now changed to Siyathemba.

00:11:46.019 --> 00:11:48.316
This is our home ground.

00:11:48.670 --> 00:11:52.409
Cameron Sinclair: I'm going to show that
later because I'm running out of time.

00:11:52.433 --> 00:11:54.754
I can see Chris looking at me slyly.

00:11:54.778 --> 00:11:57.715
This was a connection,
just a meeting with somebody

00:11:57.739 --> 00:12:02.487
who wanted to develop Africa's first
telemedicine center, in Tanzania.

00:12:02.511 --> 00:12:04.749
And we met, literally,
a couple of months ago.

00:12:04.773 --> 00:12:06.360
We've already developed a design.

00:12:06.384 --> 00:12:08.591
The team is over there,
working in partnership.

00:12:08.615 --> 00:12:11.899
This was a matchmaking,
thanks to a couple of TEDsters --
