is motivation.

00:04:09.164 --> 00:04:12.529
The motor in the brain begins to crank,
and you want this person.

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:15.822
And last but not least,
it is an obsession.

00:04:16.132 --> 00:04:19.934
Before I put these people
in the MRI machine,

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:21.934
I would ask them all kinds of questions.

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:25.123
But my most important question
was always the same.

00:04:25.147 --> 00:04:29.934
It was: "What percentage of the day
and night do you think about this person?"

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:31.848
And indeed, they would say,

00:04:31.872 --> 00:04:34.029
"All day. All night.

00:04:34.053 --> 00:04:36.394
I can never stop thinking
about him or her."

00:04:36.958 --> 00:04:38.768
And then, the very last question --

00:04:38.792 --> 00:04:41.391
I would always have to work
myself up to this question,

00:04:41.415 --> 00:04:42.982
because I'm not a psychologist.

00:04:43.006 --> 00:04:45.982
I don't work with people
in any kind of traumatic situation.

00:04:46.352 --> 00:04:48.257
My final question was always the same.

00:04:48.281 --> 00:04:50.934
I would say,
"Would you die for him or her?"

00:04:51.423 --> 00:04:53.494
And, indeed, these people would say "Yes!"

00:04:53.518 --> 00:04:55.629
as if I had asked them to pass the salt.

00:04:55.653 --> 00:04:58.347
I was just staggered by it.

00:04:59.592 --> 00:05:02.178
So we scanned their brains,

00:05:02.202 --> 00:05:04.312
looking at a photograph
of their sweetheart

00:05:04.336 --> 00:05:06.104
and looking at a neutral photograph,

00:05:06.128 --> 00:05:07.962
with a distraction task in between.

00:05:07.986 --> 00:05:12.934
So we could look at the same brain
when it was in that heightened state

00:05:12.958 --> 00:05:15.255
and when it was in a resting state.

00:05:15.827 --> 00:05:18.098
And we found activity
in a lot of brain regions.

00:05:18.122 --> 00:05:20.780
In fact, one of the most important
was a brain region

00:05:20.804 --> 00:05:24.012
that becomes active
when you feel the rush of cocaine.

00:05:24.615 --> 00:05:26.958
And indeed, that's exactly what happens.

00:05:27.608 --> 00:05:32.227
I began to realize that romantic love
is not an emotion.

00:05:32.251 --> 00:05:35.107
In fact, I had always thought
it was a series of emotions,

00:05:35.131 --> 00:05:36.837
from very high to very low.

00:05:36.861 --> 00:05:38.567
But actually, it's a drive.

00:05:38.591 --> 00:05:40.726
It comes from the motor of the mind,

00:05:40.750 --> 00:05:44.415
the wanting part of the mind,
the craving part of the mind.

00:05:44.439 --> 00:05:45.934
The kind of part of the mind

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:48.598
when you're reaching
for that piece of chocolate,

00:05:48.622 --> 00:05:52.460
when you want to win
that promotion at work.

00:05:52.864 --> 00:05:54.403
The motor of the brain.

00:05:54.427 --> 00:05:55.631
It's a drive.

00:05:55.655 --> 00:05:58.758
And in fact, I think it's more powerful
than the sex drive.

00:05:59.124 --> 00:06:01.607
You know, if you ask somebody
to go to bed with you,

00:06:01.631 --> 00:06:03.068
and they say, "No, thank you,"

00:06:03.092 --> 00:06:06.609
you certainly don't kill yourself
or slip into a clinical depression.

00:06:06.633 --> 00:06:09.826
But certainly, around the world,

00:06:09.850 --> 00:06:13.807
people who are rejected
in love will kill for it.

00:06:14.307 --> 00:06:15.442
People live for love.

00:06:15.466 --> 00:06:16.726
They kill for love.

00:06:16.750 --> 00:06:17.781
They die for love.

00:06:18.235 --> 00:06:21.813
They have songs, poems, novels,

00:06:21.837 --> 00:06:25.781
sculptures, paintings, myths, legends.

00:06:25.805 --> 00:06:27.954
In over 175 societies,

00:06:27.978 --> 00:06:32.762
people have left their evidence
of this powerful brain system.

00:06:32.786 --> 00:06:33.809
I have come to think

00:06:33.833 --> 00:06:36.421
it's one of the most powerful
brain systems on Earth

00:06:36.445 --> 00:06:39.022
for both great joy and great sorrow.

00:06:39.617 --> 00:06:41.054
And I've also come to think

00:06:41.079 --> 00:06:44.561
that it's one of three
basically different brain systems

00:06:44.586 --> 00:06:46.633
that evolved from mating and reproduction.

00:06:47.030 --> 00:06:50.085
One is the sex drive:
the craving for sexual gratification.

00:06:50.513 --> 00:06:53.934
W.H. Auden called it
an "intolerable neural itch,"

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:55.933
and indeed, that's what it is.

00:06:57.100 --> 00:06:59.680
It keeps bothering you
a little bit, like being hungry.

00:07:00.862 --> 00:07:03.808
The second of these three brain
systems is romantic love:

00:07:03.832 --> 00:07:05.934
that elation, obsession of early love.

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:08.314
And the third brain system is attachment:

00:07:08.338 --> 00:07:12.291
that sense of calm and security
you can feel for a long-term partner.

00:07:12.656 --> 00:07:15.468
And I think that the sex drive
evolved to get you out there,

00:07:15.492 --> 00:07:18.047
looking for a whole range of partners.

00:07:18.071 --> 00:07:20.856
You can feel it when you're just
driving along in your car.

00:07:20.880 --> 00:07:22.252
It can be focused on nobody.

00:07:22.276 --> 00:07:25.934
I think romantic love evolved
to enable you to focus your mating energy

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:27.934
on just one individual at a time,

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:30.790
thereby conserving mating time and energy.

00:07:30.814 --> 00:07:33.544
And I think that attachment,
the third brain system,

00:07:33.568 --> 00:07:37.110
evolved to enable you to tolerate
this human being

00:07:37.134 --> 00:07:41.187
at least long enough to raise
a child together as a team.

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:44.456
So with that preamble,

00:07:44.480 --> 00:07:50.511
I want to go into discussing
the two most profound social trends.

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:53.241
One of the last 10,000 years

00:07:53.265 --> 00:07:57.962
and the other,
certainly of the last 25 years,

00:07:57.986 --> 00:08:02.238
that are going to have an impact
on these three different brain systems:

00:08:02.262 --> 00:08:05.815
lust, romantic love
and deep attachment to a partner.

00:08:06.220 --> 00:08:10.681
The first is women working,
moving into the workforce.

00:08:13.291 --> 00:08:16.182
I've looked at 130 societies

00:08:16.206 --> 00:08:18.847
through the demographic yearbooks
of the United Nations.

00:08:18.871 --> 00:08:23.603
Everywhere in the world,
129 out of 130 of them,

00:08:23.627 --> 00:08:25.934
women are not only moving
into the job market --

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:29.934
sometimes very, very slowly,
but they are moving into the job market --

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:33.812
and they are very slowly closing
that gap between men and women

00:08:33.836 --> 00:08:37.633
in terms of economic power,
health and education.

00:08:37.657 --> 00:08:38.793
It's very slow.

00:08:38.817 --> 00:08:41.934
For every trend on this planet,
there's a counter-trend.

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:44.271
We all know of them, but nevertheless --

00:08:44.295 --> 00:08:50.691
the Arabs say, "The dogs may bark,
but the caravan moves on."

00:08:50.715 --> 00:08:53.042
And, indeed, that caravan is moving on.

00:08:53.066 --> 00:08:55.753
Women are moving back into the job market.

00:08:55.777 --> 00:08:58.934
And I say back into the job market,
because this is not new.

00:08:59.281 --> 00:09:02.947
For millions of years,
on the grasslands of Africa,

00:09:02.971 --> 00:09:06.121
women commuted to work
to gather their vegetables.

00:09:06.145 --> 00:09:09.805
They came home with 60 to 80 percent
of the evening meal.

00:09:09.829 --> 00:09:12.717
The double income family was the standard.

00:09:12.741 --> 00:09:16.171
And women were regarded
as just as economically,

00:09:16.195 --> 00:09:19.934
socially and sexually powerful as men.

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:23.761
In short, we're really
moving forward to the past.

00:09:24.181 --> 00:09:29.474
Then, women's worst
invention was the plow.

00:09:29.498 --> 00:09:33.172
With the beginning of plow agriculture,
men's roles became extremely powerful.

00:09:33.196 --> 00:09:37.632
Women lost their ancient
jobs as collectors,

00:09:37.656 --> 00:09:41.335
but then with the industrial revolution
and the post-industrial revolution

00:09:41.359 --> 00:09:43.302
they're moving back into the job market.

00:09:43.326 --> 00:09:48.453
In short, they are acquiring the status
that they had a million years ago,

00:09:48.477 --> 00:09:51.701
10,000 years ago, 100,000 years ago.

00:09:51.725 --> 00:09:56.296
We are seeing now one
of the most remarkable traditions

00:09:56.320 --> 00:09:58.653
in the history of the human animal.

00:10:00.624 --> 00:10:02.220
And it's going to have an impact.

00:10:02.244 --> 00:10:03.777
I generally give a whole lecture

00:10:03.801 --> 00:10:06.105
on the impact of women
on the business community.

00:10:06.129 --> 00:10:09.186
I'll say just a couple of things,
and then go on to sex and love.

00:10:09.210 --> 00:10:11.067
There's a lot of gender differences;

00:10:11.091 --> 00:10:13.267
anybody who thinks men and women are alike

00:10:13.291 --> 00:10:15.233
simply never had a boy and a girl child.

00:10:15.257 --> 00:10:18.450
I don't know why they want to think
that men and women are alike.

00:10:18.474 --> 00:10:19.997
There's much we have in common,

00:10:20.021 --> 00:10:22.934
but there's a whole lot
that we do not have in common.

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:24.934
We are -- in the words of Ted Hughes,

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:30.062
"I think that we are like two feet.
We need each other to get ahead."

00:10:30.086 --> 00:10:32.934
But we did not evolve
to have the same brain.

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:36.407
And we're finding more and more
gender differences in the brain.

00:10:36.431 --> 00:10:39.558
I'll only just use a couple
and then move on to sex and love.

00:10:39.582 --> 00:10:41.689
One of them is women's verbal ability.

00:10:41.713 --> 00:10:42.934
Women can talk.

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:46.934
Women's ability to find the right word
rapidly, basic articulation

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:49.336
goes up in the middle
of the menstrual cycle,

00:10:49.360 --> 00:10:50.931
when estrogen levels peak.

00:10:50.955 --> 00:10:54.573
But even at menstruation,
they're better than the average man.

00:10:55.057 --> 00:10:56.105
Women can talk.

00:10:56.613 --> 00:10:59.934
They've been doing it for a million years;
words were women's tools.

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:02.045
They held that baby
in front of their face,

00:11:02.069 --> 00:11:05.878
cajoling it, reprimanding it,
educating it with words.

00:11:05.902 --> 00:11:08.934
And, indeed, they're becoming
a very powerful force.

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:14.195
Even in places like India and Japan,

00:11:14.219 --> 00:11:17.616
where women are not moving rapidly
into the regular job market,

00:11:17.640 --> 00:11:19.473
they're moving into journalism.

00:11:19.497 --> 00:11:23.934
And I think that the television
is like the global campfire.

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:27.934
We sit around it and it shapes our minds.

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:32.042
Almost always, when I'm on TV,
the producer who calls me,

00:11:32.066 --> 00:11:34.209
who negotiates what we're going to say,

00:11:34.233 --> 00:11:35.288
is a woman.

00:11:35.312 --> 00:11:37.970
In fact, Solzhenitsyn once said,

00:11:37.994 --> 00:11:41.148
"To have a great writer
is to have another government."

00:11:41.640 --> 00:11:46.227
Today 54 percent of people
who are writers in America are women.

00:11:47.116 --> 00:11:49.789
It's one of many, many
characteristics that women have

00:11:49.813 --> 00:11:52.093
that they will bring into the job market.

00:11:52.117 --> 00:11:56.244
They've got incredible people skills,
negotiating skills.

00:11:56.268 --> 00:11:57.934
They're highly imaginative.

00:11:57.958 --> 00:12:02.537
We now know the brain circuitry
of imagination, of long-term planning.

00:12:02.561 --> 00:12:04.681
They tend to be web thinkers.

00:12:04.705 --> 00:12:07.490
Because the female parts
of the brain are better connected,

00:12:07.514 --> 00:12:10.688
they tend to collect more
pieces of data when they think,

00:12:10.712 --> 00:12:15.415
put them into more complex patterns,
see more options and outcomes.

00:12:15.439 --> 00:12:19.145
They tend to be contextual,
holistic thinkers,

00:12:19.169 --> 00:12:20.709
what I call web thinkers.

00:12:20.733 --> 00:12:22.738
Men tend to -- and these are averages --

00:12:22.762 --> 00:12:25.421
tend to get rid of what they regard
as extraneous,

00:12:25.445 --> 00:12:26.830
focus on what they do,

00:12:26.854 --> 00:12:32.780
and move in a more
step-by-step thinking pattern.

00:12:33.129 --> 00:12:35.231
They're both perfectly good
ways of thinking.

00:12:35.255 --> 00:12:37.487
We need both of them to get ahead.

00:12:37.511 --> 00:12:40.934
In fact, there's many more
male geniuses in the world.

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:43.679
And there's also many more
male idiots in the world.

00:12:43.703 --> 00:12:45.429
(Laughter)

00:12:45.453 --> 00:12:48.635
When the male brain works well,
it works extremely well.

00:12:48.659 --> 00:12:51.993
And what I really think
that we're doing is,

00:12:52.017 --> 00:12:54.303
we're moving towards
a collaborative society,

00:12:54.327 --> 00:12:57.129
a society in which the talents
of both men and women

00:12:57.153 --> 00:13:00.934
are becoming understood
and valued and employed.

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:03.721
But in fact, women moving
into the job market

00:13:03.745 --> 00:13:08.855
is having a huge impact
on sex and romance and family life.

00:13:09.566 --> 00:13:14.650
Foremost, women are starting
to express their sexuality.

00:13:14.674 --> 00:13:17.300
I'm always astonished
when people come to me and say,

00:13:17.324 --> 00:13:19.642
"Why is it that men are so adulterous?"

00:13:19.666 --> 00:13:22.379
"Why do you think
more men are adulterous than women?"

00:13:22.403 --> 00:13:23.974
"Well, men are more adulterous!"

00:13:23.998 --> 00:13:26.936
And I say, "Who do you think
these men are sleeping with?"

00:13:26.960 --> 00:13:28.364
(Laughter)

00:13:28.388 --> 00:13:30.116
And -- basic math!

00:13:30.140 --> 00:13:31.314
Anyway.

00:13:31.338 --> 00:13:34.934
In the Western world,

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:37.934
women start sooner at sex,
have more partners,

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:40.843
express less remorse
for the partners that they do,

00:13:40.867 --> 00:13:43.549
marry later, have fewer children,

00:13:43.573 --> 00:13:46.478
leave bad marriages
in order to get good ones.

00:13:46.502 --> 00:13:50.481
We are seeing the rise
of female sexual expression.

00:13:50.505 --> 00:13:55.226
And, indeed, once again we're moving
forward to the kind of sexual expression

00:13:55.250 --> 00:13:58.934
that we probably saw on the grasslands
of Africa a million years ago,

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:01.934
because this is the kind
of sexual expression that we see

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:04.216
in hunting and gathering societies today.

00:14:04.823 --> 00:14:08.799
We're also returning
to an ancient form of marriage equality.

00:14:09.378 --> 00:14:13.934
They're now saying that the 21st century

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:17.934
is going to be the century of what
they call the "symmetrical marriage,"

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:23.342
or the "pure marriage,"
or the "companionate marriage."

00:14:23.366 --> 00:14:26.934
This is a marriage between equals,

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:29.401
moving forward to a pattern

00:14:29.425 --> 00:14:32.559
that is highly compatible
with the ancient human spirit.

00:14:33.733 --> 00:14:36.272
We're also seeing a rise of romantic love.

00:14:36.744 --> 00:14:40.970
91 percent of American women
and 86 percent of American men

00:14:40.994 --> 00:14:45.597
would not marry somebody
who had every single quality

00:14:45.621 --> 00:14:47.437
they were looking for in a partner,

00:14:47.461 --> 00:14:50.224
if they were not in love with that person.

00:14:50.248 --> 00:14:53.767
People around the world,
in a study of 37 societies,

00:14:53.791 --> 00:14:57.428
want to be in love
with the person that they marry.

00:14:57.904 --> 00:15:03.958
Indeed, arranged marriages are
on their way off this braid of human life.

00:15:07.576 --> 00:15:10.370
I even think that marriages
might even become more stable

00:15:10.394 --> 00:15:14.148
because of the second great world trend.

00:15:14.172 --> 00:15:16.934
The first one being women
moving into the job market,

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:19.808
the second one being
the aging world population.

00:15:19.832 --> 00:15:22.259
They're now saying that in America,

00:15:22.283 --> 00:15:25.934
that middle age should be regarded
as up to age 85.

00:15:26.600 --> 00:15:31.479
Because in that highest
age category of 76 to 85,

00:15:31.503 --> 00:15:34.934
as much as 40 percent of people
have nothing really wrong with them.

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:38.340
So we're seeing there's a real
extension of middle age.

00:15:38.672 --> 00:15:43.934
For one of my books,
I looked at divorce data in 58 societies.

00:15:43.958 --> 00:15:48.189
And as it turns out, the older you get,
the less likely you are to divorce.

00:15:48.554 --> 00:15:52.155
So the divorce rate right now
is stable in America,

00:15:52.179 --> 00:15:54.513
and it's actually beginning to decline.

00:15:54.537 --> 00:15:56.139
It may decline some more.

00:15:59.091 --> 00:16:03.090
I would even say that with Viagra,

00:16:03.114 --> 00:16:06.929
estrogen replacement, hip replacements

00:16:06.953 --> 00:16:08.934
and the incredibly interesting women

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:12.063
-- women have never been
as interesting as they are now.

00:16:12.087 --> 00:16:15.545
Not at any time on this planet
have women been so educated,

00:16:15.569 --> 00:16:17.516
so interesting, so capable.

00:16:17.920 --> 00:16:23.299
And so I honestly think that if there
really was ever a time in human evolution

00:16:23.323 --> 00:16:27.188
when we have the opportunity to make
good marriages, that time is now.

00:16:28.474 --> 00:16:31.675
However, there's always kinds
of complications in this.

00:16:31.699 --> 00:16:36.416
These three brain systems --
lust, romantic love and attachment --

00:16:36.440 --> 00:16:37.794
don't always go together.

00:16:37.818 --> 00:16:39.517
They can go together, by the way.

00:16:39.541 --> 00:16:41.493
That's why casual sex isn't so casual.

00:16:41.517 --> 00:16:43.786
With orgasm you get a spike of dopamine.

00:16:43.810 --> 00:16:45.906
Dopamine's associated with romantic love,

00:16:45.930 --> 00:16:47.953
and you can just
fall in love with somebody

00:16:47.977 --> 00:16:49.840
who you're just having casual sex with.

00:16:49.864 --> 00:16:53.300
With orgasm, then you get a real rush
of oxytocin and vasopressin --

00:16:53.324 --> 00:16:55.355
those are associated with attachment.

00:16:55.379 --> 00:16:59.338
This is why you can feel such a sense
of cosmic union with somebody

00:16:59.362 --> 00:17:01.211
after you've made love to them.

00:17:01.235 --> 00:17:05.934
But these three brain systems:
lust, romantic love and attachment,

00:17:05.958 --> 00:17:08.439
aren't always connected to each other.

00:17:08.958 --> 00:17:12.209
You can feel deep attachment
to a long-term partner

00:17:12.233 --> 00:17:16.325
while you feel intense
romantic love for somebody else,

00:17:16.349 --> 00:17:21.802
while you feel the sex drive for people
unrelated to these other partners.

00:17:22.270 --> 00:17:27.299
In short, we're capable of loving
more than one person at a time.

00:17:27.672 --> 00:17:29.664
In fact, you can lie in bed at night

00:17:29.688 --> 00:17:32.934
and swing from deep feelings
of attachment for one person

00:17:32.958 --> 00:17:36.390
to deep feelings
of romantic love for somebody else.

00:17:36.414 --> 00:17:39.295
It's as if there's a committee meeting
going on in your head

00:17:39.319 --> 00:17:42.446
as you are trying to decide what to do.

00:17:42.470 --> 00:17:44.105
So I don't think, honestly,

00:17:44.129 --> 00:17:46.144
we're an animal
that was built to be happy;

00:17:46.168 --> 00:17:48.436
we are an animal
that was built to reproduce.

00:17:48.460 --> 00:17:51.395
I think the happiness we find, we make.

00:17:51.419 --> 00:17:54.901
And I think, however,

00:17:54.925 --> 00:17:57.592
we can make good relationships
with each other.

00:17:57.958 --> 00:18:00.063
So I want to conclude with two things.

00:18:00.087 --> 00:18:02.134
I want to conclude with a worry,

00:18:02.158 --> 00:18:05.087
and with a wonderful story.

00:18:06.245 --> 00:18:08.934
The worry is about antidepressants.

00:18:10.589 --> 00:18:15.721
Over 100 million prescriptions
of antidepressants

00:18:15.745 --> 00:18:18.566
are written every year
in the United States.

00:18:19.058 --> 00:18:21.623
And these drugs are going generic.

00:18:21.647 --> 00:18:24.130
They are seeping around the world.

00:18:24.701 --> 00:18:29.934
I know one girl who's been
on these antidepressants,

00:18:29.958 --> 00:18:33.934
SSRIs, serotonin-enhancing
antidepressants -- since she was 13.

00:18:33.958 --> 00:18:36.934
She's 23. She's been on them
ever since she was 13.

00:18:36.958 --> 00:18:40.474
I've got nothing against people
who take them short term,

00:18:40.498 --> 00:18:42.721
when they're going
through something horrible.

00:18:42.745 --> 00:18:45.100
They want to commit suicide
or kill somebody else.

00:18:45.124 --> 00:18:46.192
I would recommend it.

00:18:46.216 --> 00:18:48.675
But more and more people
in the United States

00:18:48.699 --> 00:18:51.083
are taking them long term.

00:18:51.107 --> 00:18:56.472
And indeed, what these drugs do
is raise levels of serotonin.

00:18:56.932 --> 00:19:01.753
And by raising levels of serotonin,
you suppress the dopamine circuit.

00:19:01.777 --> 00:19:03.339
Everybody knows that.

00:19:03.902 --> 00:19:06.797
Dopamine is associated with romantic love.

00:19:08.585 --> 00:19:11.735
Not only do they suppress
the dopamine circuit,

00:19:11.759 --> 00:19:13.626
but they kill the sex drive.

00:19:14.274 --> 00:19:18.098
And when you kill the sex drive,
you kill orgasm.

00:19:18.122 --> 00:19:19.313
And when you kill orgasm,

00:19:19.337 --> 00:19:23.204
you kill that flood of drugs
associated with attachment.

00:19:23.670 --> 00:19:25.934
The things are connected in the brain.

00:19:25.958 --> 00:19:28.614
And when you tamper with one brain system,

00:19:28.638 --> 00:19:30.583
you're going to tamper with another.

00:19:30.958 --> 00:19:35.712
I'm just simply saying that a world
without love is a deadly place.

00:19:36.696 --> 00:19:37.698
So now --

00:19:37.722 --> 00:19:41.934
(Applause)

00:19:41.958 --> 00:19:43.661
Thank you.

00:19:43.685 --> 00:19:45.170
I want to end with a story.

00:19:45.797 --> 00:19:47.097
And then, just a comment.

00:19:48.699 --> 00:19:53.478
I've been studying romantic love
and sex and attachment for 30 years.

00:19:55.732 --> 00:19:59.248
I'm an identical twin;
I am interested in why we're all alike.

00:19:59.883 --> 00:20:02.934
Why you and I are alike,
why the Iraqis and the Japanese

00:20:02.958 --> 00:20:05.958
and the Australian Aborigines
and the people of the Amazon River

00:20:05.982 --> 00:20:06.982
are all alike.

00:20:07.735 --> 00:20:10.044
And about a year ago,

00:20:10.068 --> 00:20:13.053
an Internet dating service,
Match.com, came to me

00:20:13.077 --> 00:20:16.729
and asked me if I would design
a new dating site for them.

00:20:16.753 --> 00:20:19.555
I said, "I don't know anything
about personality. You know?

00:20:19.579 --> 00:20:22.299
I don't know. Do you think
you've got the right person?"

00:20:22.323 --> 00:20:23.363
They said, "Yes."

00:20:23.387 --> 00:20:26.410
It got me thinking
about why it is that you fall in love

00:20:26.434 --> 00:20:28.166
with one person rather than another.

00:20:28.190 --> 00:20:31.633
That's my current project;
it will be my next book.

00:20:32.220 --> 00:20:33.759
There's all kinds of reasons

00:20:33.783 --> 00:20:36.536
that you fall in love
with one person rather than another.

00:20:36.560 --> 00:20:39.846
Timing is important.
Proximity is important.

00:20:39.870 --> 00:20:41.250
Mystery is important.

00:20:41.274 --> 00:20:44.003
You fall in love with somebody
who's somewhat mysterious,

00:20:44.027 --> 00:20:46.705
in part because mystery
elevates dopamine in the brain,

00:20:46.729 --> 00:20:49.495
probably pushes you
over that threshold to fall in love.

00:20:49.519 --> 00:20:50.948
You fall in love with somebody

00:20:50.972 --> 00:20:53.067
who fits within
what I call your "love map,"

00:20:53.091 --> 00:20:55.238
an unconscious list of traits

00:20:55.262 --> 00:20:57.576
that you build in childhood
as you grow up.

00:20:57.600 --> 00:21:00.642
And I also think
that you gravitate to certain people,

00:21:00.666 --> 00:21:03.934
actually, with somewhat
complementary brain systems.

00:21:03.958 --> 00:21:06.245
And that's what I'm now
contributing to this.

00:21:06.269 --> 00:21:09.934
But I want to tell you
a story, to illustrate.

00:21:09.958 --> 00:21:12.934
I've been carrying on here
about the biology of love.

00:21:13.667 --> 00:21:17.354
I wanted to show you a little bit
about the culture of it, too,

00:21:17.378 --> 00:21:18.545
the magic of it.

00:21:19.958 --> 00:21:23.307
It's a story that was told to me

00:21:23.331 --> 00:21:25.792
by somebody who had
heard it just from one --

00:21:25.816 --> 00:21:26.934
probably a true story.

00:21:28.466 --> 00:21:31.934
It was a graduate student --
I'm at Rutgers and my two colleagues --

00:21:31.958 --> 00:21:33.934
Art Aron is at SUNY Stony Brook.

00:21:33.958 --> 00:21:36.329
That's where we put our people
in the MRI machine.

00:21:36.958 --> 00:21:41.521
And this graduate student was madly
in love with another graduate student,

00:21:41.545 --> 00:21:43.918
and she was not in love with him.

00:21:45.164 --> 00:21:47.419
And they were
all at a conference in Beijing.

00:21:48.443 --> 00:21:51.477
And he knew from our work

00:21:51.501 --> 00:21:55.909
that if you go and do something
very novel with somebody,

00:21:55.933 --> 00:21:57.934
you can drive up
the dopamine in the brain,

00:21:57.958 --> 00:22:01.651
and perhaps trigger
this brain system for romantic love.

00:22:01.675 --> 00:22:03.832
(Laughter)

00:22:03.856 --> 00:22:07.742
So he decided he'd put science to work.

00:22:08.582 --> 00:22:11.916
And he invited this girl to go off
on a rickshaw ride with him.

00:22:12.767 --> 00:22:14.836
And sure enough -- I've never been in one,

00:22:14.860 --> 00:22:17.598
but apparently they go
all around the buses and the trucks

00:22:17.622 --> 00:22:20.440
and it's crazy and it's noisy
and it's exciting.

00:22:20.464 --> 00:22:22.750
He figured that this
would drive up the dopamine,

00:22:22.774 --> 00:22:24.306
and she'd fall in love with him.

00:22:24.330 --> 00:22:29.304
So off they go and she's squealing
and squeezing him

00:22:29.328 --> 00:22:31.845
and laughing and having a wonderful time.

00:22:31.869 --> 00:22:35.408
An hour later they get down
off of the rickshaw,

00:22:35.432 --> 00:22:39.012
and she throws her hands up and she says,

00:22:39.036 --> 00:22:41.348
"Wasn't that wonderful?"

00:22:41.372 --> 00:22:44.786
And, "Wasn't that rickshaw
driver handsome!"

00:22:44.810 --> 00:22:47.879
(Laughter)

00:22:47.903 --> 00:22:53.934
(Applause)

00:22:53.958 --> 00:22:55.120
There's magic to love!

00:22:55.144 --> 00:22:56.755
(Applause)

00:22:56.779 --> 00:23:00.399
But I will end by saying
that millions of years ago,

00:23:00.423 --> 00:23:02.755
we evolved three basic drives:

00:23:02.779 --> 00:23:05.298
the sex drive, romantic love

00:23:05.322 --> 00:23:07.662
and attachment to a long-term partner.

00:23:07.686 --> 00:23:10.765
These circuits are deeply
embedded in the human brain.

00:23:11.161 --> 00:23:15.564
They're going to survive
as long as our species survives

00:23:15.588 --> 00:23:18.296
on what Shakespeare called
"this mortal coil."

00:23:18.320 --> 00:23:19.326
Thank you.

00:23:19.350 --> 00:23:20.775
Chris Anderson: Helen Fisher!

00:23:20.799 --> 00:23:21.862
(Applause)

title: Happiness in body and soul
transcript: I bet you're worried.(Laughter)I was worried. That's why I began this piece. I was worried about vaginas. I was worried what we think about vaginas and even more worried that we don't think about them. I was worried about my own vagina. It needed a context, a culture, a community of other vaginas. There is so much darkness and secrecy surrounding them. Like the Bermuda Triangle, nobody ever reports back from there.(Laughter)In the first place, it's not so easy to even find your vagina. Women go days, weeks, months, without looking at it. I interviewed a high-powered businesswoman; she told me she didn't have time. "Looking at your vagina," she said, "is a full day's work."(Laughter)"You've got to get down there on your back, in front of a mirror, full-length preferred. You've got to get in the perfect position with the perfect light, which then becomes shadowed by the angle you're at. You're twisting your head up, arching your back, it's exhausting." She was busy; she didn't have time. So I decided to talk to women about their vaginas. They began as casual vagina interviews, and they turned into vagina monologues. I talked with over 200 women. I talked to older women, younger women, married women, lesbians, single women. I talked to corporate professionals, college professors, actors, sex workers. I talked to African-American women, Asian-American women, Native-American women, Caucasian women, Jewish women.OK, at first women were a little shy, a little reluctant to talk. Once they got going, you couldn't stop them. Women love to talk about their vaginas, they do. Mainly because no one's ever asked them before.(Laughter)Let's just start with the word "vagina" — vagina, vagina. It sounds like an infection, at best. Maybe a medical instrument. "Hurry, nurse, bring the vagina!"(Laughter)Vagina, vagina, vagina.It doesn't matter how many times you say the word, it never sounds like a word you want to say. It's a completely ridiculous, totally un-sexy word. If you use it during sex, trying to be politically correct, "Darling, would you stroke my vagina," you kill the act right there.(Laughter)I'm worried what we call them and don't call them. In Great Neck, New York, they call it a Pussycat. A woman told me there her mother used to tell her, "Don't wear panties, dear, underneath your pajamas. You need to air out your Pussycat."(Laughter)In Westchester, they call it a Pooki, in New Jersey, a twat. There's Powderbox, derriere, a Pooky, a Poochi, a Poopi, a Poopelu, a Pooninana, a Padepachetchki, a Pal, and a Piche.(Laughter)There's Toadie, Dee Dee, Nishi, Dignity, Coochi Snorcher, Cooter, Labbe, Gladys Seagelman, VA, Wee wee, Horsespot, Nappy Dugout, Mongo, Ghoulie, Powderbox, a Mimi in Miami, a Split Knish in Philadelphia ...(Laughter)and a Schmende in the Bronx.(Laughter)I am worried about vaginas. This is how the "Vagina Monologues" begins. But it really didn't begin there. It began with a conversation with a woman. We were having a conversation about menopause, and we got onto the subject of her vagina, which you'll do if you're talking about menopause. And she said things that really shocked me about her vagina — that it was dried-up and finished and dead — and I was kind of shocked. So I said to a friend casually, "Well, what do you think about your vagina?" And that woman said something more amazing, and then the next woman said something more amazing, and before I knew it, every woman was telling me I had to talk to somebody about their vagina because they had an amazing story, and I was sucked down the vagina trail.(Laughter)And I really haven't gotten off of it. I think if you had told me when I was younger that I was going to grow up, and be in shoe stores, and people would scream out, "There she is, the Vagina Lady!" I don't know that that would have been my life ambition.(Laughter)But I want to talk a little bit about happiness, and the relationship to this whole vagina journey, because it has been an extraordinary journey that began eight years ago. I think before I did the "Vagina Monologues," I didn't really believe in happiness. I thought that only idiots were happy, to be honest. I remember when I started practicing Buddhism 14 years ago, and I was told that the end of this practice was to be happy, I said, "How could you be happy and live in this world of suffering and live in this world of pain?" I mistook happiness for a lot of other things, like numbness or decadence or selfishness. And what happened through the course of the "Vagina Monologues" and this journey is, I think I have come to understand a little bit more about happiness.There are three qualities I want to talk about. One is seeing what's right in front of you, and talking about it, and stating it. I think what I learned from talking about the vagina and speaking about the vagina, is it was the most obvious thing — it was right in the center of my body and the center of the world — and yet it was the one thing nobody talked about. The second thing is that what talking about the vagina did is it opened this door which allowed me to see that there was a way to serve the world to make it better. And that's where the deepest happiness has actually come from. And the third principle of happiness, which I've realized recently:Eight years ago, this momentum and this energy, this "V-wave" started — and I can only describe it as a "V-wave" because, to be honest, I really don't understand it completely; I feel at the service of it. But this wave started, and if I question the wave, or try to stop the wave or look back at the wave, I often have the experience of whiplash or the potential of my neck breaking. But if I go with the wave, and I trust the wave and I move with the wave, I go to the next place, and it happens logically and organically and truthfully. And I started this piece, particularly with stories and narratives, and I was talking to one woman and that led to another woman and that led to another woman. And then I wrote those stories down, and I put them out in front of other people.And every single time I did the show at the beginning, women would literally line up after the show, because they wanted to tell me their stories. And at first I thought, "Oh great, I'll hear about wonderful orgasms, and great sex lives, and how women love their vaginas." But in fact, that's not what women lined up to tell me. What women lined up to tell me was how they were raped, and how they were battered, and how they were beaten, and how they were gang-raped in parking lots, and how they were incested by their uncles. And I wanted to stop doing the "Vagina Monologues," because it felt too daunting. I felt like a war photographer who takes pictures of terrible events, but doesn't intervene on their behalf.And so in 1997, I said, "Let's get women together. What could we do with this information that all these women are being violated?" And it turned out, after thinking and investigating, that I discovered — and the UN has actually said this recently — that one out of every three women on this planet will be beaten or raped in her lifetime. That's essentially a gender; that's essentially the resource of the planet, which is women. So in 1997 we got all these incredible women together and we said, "How can we use the play, this energy, to stop violence against women?" And we put on one event in New York City, in the theater, and all these great actors came — from Susan Sarandon, to Glenn Close, to Whoopi Goldberg — and we did one performance on one evening, and that catalyzed this wave, this energy.And within five years, this extraordinary thing began to happen. One woman took that energy and she said, "I want to bring this wave, this energy, to college campuses," and so she took the play and she said, "Let's use the play and have performances once a year, where we can raise money to stop violence against women in local communities all around the world." And in one year, it went to 50 colleges, and then it expanded. And over the course of the last six years, it's spread and it's spread and it's spread around the world.What I have learned is two things: one, that the epidemic of violence towards women is shocking; it's global; it is so profound and it is so devastating, and it is so in every little pocket of every little crater, of every little society that we don't even recognize it, because it's become ordinary. This journey has taken me to Afghanistan, where I had the extraordinary honor and privilege to go into parts of Afghanistan under the Taliban. I was dressed in a burqa and I went in with an extraordinary group, called the Revolutionary Association of the Women of Afghanistan. And I saw firsthand how women had been stripped of every single right that was possible to strip women of — from being educated, to being employed, to being actually allowed to eat ice cream. For those of you who don't know, it was illegal to eat ice cream under the Taliban. And I actually saw and met women who had been flogged for being caught eating vanilla ice cream. I was taken to the secret ice cream-eating place in a little town, where we went to a back room, and women were seated and a curtain was pulled around us, and they were served vanilla ice cream. And women lifted their burqas and ate this ice cream. And I don't think I ever understood pleasure until that moment, and how women have found a way to keep their pleasure alive.It has taken me, this journey, to Islamabad, where I have witnessed and met women with their faces melted off. It has taken me to Juarez, Mexico, where I was a week ago, where I have literally been there in parking lots, where bones of women have washed up and been dumped next to Coca-Cola bottles. It has taken me to universities all over this country, where girls are date-raped and drugged. I have seen terrible, terrible, terrible violence. But I have also recognized, in the course of seeing that violence, that being in the face of things and seeing actually what's in front of us is the antidote to depression, and to a feeling that one is worthless and has no value.Because before the "Vagina Monologues," I will say that 80 percent of my consciousness was closed off to what was really going on in this reality, and that closing-off closed off my vitality and my life energy. What has also happened is in the course of these travels — and it's been an extraordinary thing — is that every single place that I have gone to in the world, I have met a new species. And I really love hearing about all these species at the bottom of the sea. And I was thinking about how being with these extraordinary people on this particular panel, that it's beneath, beyond and between, and the vagina kind of fits into all those categories.(Laughter)But one of the things I've seen is this species — and it is a species, and it is a new paradigm, and it doesn't get reported in the press or in the media because I don't think good news ever is news, and I don't think people who are transforming the planet are what gets the ratings on TV shows. But every single country I have been to — and in the last six years, I've been to about 45 countries, and many tiny little villages and cities and towns — I have seen something what I've come to call "vagina warriors." A "vagina warrior" is a woman, or a vagina-friendly man, who has witnessed incredible violence or suffered it, and rather than getting an AK-47 or a weapon of mass destruction or a machete, they hold the violence in their bodies; they grieve it; they experience it; and then they go out and devote their lives to making sure it doesn't happen to anybody else.I have met these women everywhere on the planet, and I want to tell a few stories, because I believe that stories are the way that we transmit information, where it goes into our bodies. And I think one of the things about being at TED that's been very interesting is that I live in my body a lot, and I don't live in my head very much anymore. And this is a very heady place. And it's been really interesting to be in my head for the last two days; I've been very disoriented —(Laughter)because I think the world, the V-world, is very much in your body. It's a body world, and the species really exists in the body. And I think there's a real significance in us attaching our bodies to our heads, that that separation has created a divide that is often separating purpose from intent. And the connection between body and head often brings those things into union.I want to talk about three particular people that I've met, vagina warriors, who really transformed my understanding of this whole principle and species, and one is a woman named Marsha Lopez. Marsha Lopez was a woman I met in Guatemala. She was 14 years old, and she was in a marriage and her husband was beating her on a regular basis. And she couldn't get out, because she was addicted to the relationship, and she had no money. Her sister was younger than her, and she applied — we had a "Stop Rape" contest a few years ago in New York — and she applied, hoping that she would become a finalist and she could bring her sister. She did become a finalist; she brought Marsha to New York.And at that time, we did this extraordinary V-Day at Madison Square Garden, where we sold out the entire testosterone-filled dome — 18,000 people standing up to say "Yes" to vaginas, which was really a pretty incredible transformation. And she came, and she witnessed this, and she decided that she would go back and leave her husband, and that she would bring V-Day to Guatemala. She was 21 years old. I went to Guatemala and she had sold out the National Theater of Guatemala. And I watched her walk up on stage in her red short dress and high heels, and she stood there and said, "My name is Marsha. I was beaten by my husband for five years. He almost murdered me. I left and you can, too." And the entire 2,000 people went absolutely crazy.There's a woman named Esther Chávez who I met in Juarez, Mexico. And Esther Chávez was a brilliant accountant in Mexico City. She was 72 years old and she was planning to retire. She went to Juarez to take care of an ailing aunt, and in the course of it, she began to discover what was happening to the murdered and disappeared women of Juarez. She gave up her life; she moved to Juarez. She started to write the stories which documented the disappeared women. 300 women have disappeared in a border town because they're brown and poor. There has been no response to the disappearance, and not one person has been held accountable. She began to document it. She opened a center called Casa Amiga, and in six years, she has literally brought this to the consciousness of the world. We were there a week ago, when there were 7,000 people in the street, and it was truly a miracle. And as we walked through the streets, the people of Juarez, who normally don't even come into the streets, because the streets are so dangerous, literally stood there and wept, to see that other people from the world had showed up for that particular community.There's another woman, named Agnes. And Agnes, for me, epitomizes what a vagina warrior is. I met her three years ago in Kenya. And Agnes was mutilated as a little girl; she was circumcised against her will when she was 10 years old, and she really made a decision that she didn't want this practice to continue anymore in her community. So when she got older, she created this incredible thing: it's an anatomical sculpture of a woman's body, half a woman's body. And she walked through the Rift Valley, and she had vagina and vagina replacement parts, where she would teach girls and parents and boys and girls what a healthy vagina looks like, and what a mutilated vagina looks like.And in the course of her travel — she walked literally for eight years through the Rift Valley, through dust, through sleeping on the ground, because the Maasai are nomads, and she would have to find them, and they would move, and she would find them again — she saved 1,500 girls from being cut.And in that time, she created an alternative ritual, which involved girls coming of age without the cut. When we met her three years ago, we said, "What could V-Day do for you?" And she said, "Well, if you got me a jeep, I could get around a lot faster."(Laughter)So we bought her a jeep. And in the year that she had the jeep, she saved 4,500 girls from being cut. So we said to her, "What else could we do for you?" She said, "Well, Eve, if you gave me some money, I could open a house and girls could run away, and they could be saved." And I want to tell this little story about my own beginnings, because it's very interrelated to happiness and Agnes.When I was a little girl — I grew up in a wealthy community; it was an upper-middle class white community, and it had all the trappings and the looks of a perfectly nice, wonderful, great life. And everyone was supposed to be happy in that community, and, in fact, my life was hell. I lived with an alcoholic father who beat me and molested me, and it was all inside that. And always as a child I had this fantasy that somebody would come and rescue me. And I actually made up a little character whose name was Mr. Alligator. I would call him up when things got really bad, and say it was time to come and pick me up. And I would pack a little bag and wait for Mr. Alligator to come.Now, Mr. Alligator never did come, but the idea of Mr. Alligator coming actually saved my sanity and made it OK for me to keep going, because I believed, in the distance, there would be someone coming to rescue me.Cut to 40-some odd years later, we go to Kenya, and we're walking, we arrive at the opening of this house. And Agnes hadn't let me come to the house for days, because they were preparing this whole ritual.I want to tell you a great story. When Agnes first started fighting to stop female genital mutilation in her community, she had become an outcast, and she was exiled and slandered, and the whole community turned against her. But being a vagina warrior, she kept going, and she kept committing herself to transforming consciousness. And in the Maasai community, goats and cows are the most valued possession. They're like the Mercedes-Benz of the Rift Valley. And she said two days before the house opened, two different people arrived to give her a goat each, and she said to me, "I knew then that female genital mutilation would end one day in Africa."Anyway, we arrived, and when we arrived, there were hundreds of girls dressed in red homemade dresses — which is the color of the Maasai and the color of V-Day — and they greeted us. They had made up these songs that they were singing, about the end of suffering and the end of mutilation, and they walked us down the path. It was a gorgeous day in the African sun, and the dust was flying and the girls were dancing, and there was this house, and it said, "V-Day Safe House for the Girls."And it hit me in that moment that it had taken 47 years, but that Mr. Alligator had finally shown up. And he had shown up, obviously, in a form that it took me a long time to understand, which is that when we give in the world what we want the most, we heal the broken part inside each of us.And I feel, in the last eight years, that this journey — this miraculous vagina journey — has taught me this really simple thing, which is that happiness exists in action; it exists in telling the truth and saying what your truth is; and it exists in giving away what you want the most. And I feel that knowledge and that journey has been an extraordinary privilege, and I feel really blessed to have been here today to communicate that to you.Thank you very much.(Applause)

That's why I began this piece.

I was worried about vaginas.

00:00:24.723 --> 00:00:26.934
I was worried what we think about vaginas

00:00:26.958 --> 00:00:30.200
and even more worried
that we don't think about them.

00:00:30.612 --> 00:00:32.787
I was worried about my own vagina.

00:00:32.811 --> 00:00:37.243
It needed a context, a culture,
a community of other vaginas.

00:00:37.973 --> 00:00:41.678
There is so much darkness
and secrecy surrounding them.

00:00:41.702 --> 00:00:46.350
Like the Bermuda Triangle,
nobody ever reports back from there.

00:00:46.374 --> 00:00:47.476
(Laughter)

00:00:47.500 --> 00:00:51.293
In the first place, it's not so easy
to even find your vagina.

00:00:51.618 --> 00:00:54.626
Women go days, weeks, months,
without looking at it.

00:00:55.094 --> 00:00:57.419
I interviewed a high-powered
businesswoman;

00:00:57.443 --> 00:00:59.935
she told me she didn't have time.

00:00:59.959 --> 00:01:02.813
"Looking at your vagina,"
she said, "is a full day's work."

00:01:02.837 --> 00:01:03.934
(Laughter)

00:01:03.958 --> 00:01:07.054
"You've got to get down there
on your back, in front of a mirror,

00:01:07.078 --> 00:01:08.377
full-length preferred.

00:01:08.401 --> 00:01:11.503
You've got to get in the perfect position
with the perfect light,

00:01:11.527 --> 00:01:13.934
which then becomes shadowed
by the angle you're at.

00:01:13.958 --> 00:01:17.169
You're twisting your head up,
arching your back, it's exhausting."

00:01:17.193 --> 00:01:19.312
She was busy; she didn't have time.

00:01:19.836 --> 00:01:22.661
So I decided to talk to women
about their vaginas.

00:01:23.026 --> 00:01:25.994
They began as casual vagina interviews,

00:01:26.018 --> 00:01:28.698
and they turned into vagina monologues.

00:01:28.722 --> 00:01:30.942
I talked with over 200 women.

00:01:30.966 --> 00:01:33.367
I talked to older women, younger women,

00:01:33.391 --> 00:01:36.097
married women, lesbians, single women.

00:01:36.121 --> 00:01:40.934
I talked to corporate professionals,
college professors, actors, sex workers.

00:01:40.958 --> 00:01:44.465
I talked to African-American women,
Asian-American women,

00:01:44.489 --> 00:01:48.347
Native-American women,
Caucasian women, Jewish women.

00:01:48.720 --> 00:01:53.550
OK, at first women were a little shy,
a little reluctant to talk.

00:01:54.010 --> 00:01:56.682
Once they got going,
you couldn't stop them.

00:01:57.150 --> 00:02:00.416
Women love to talk
about their vaginas, they do.

00:02:01.079 --> 00:02:03.518
Mainly because no one's ever
asked them before.

00:02:03.542 --> 00:02:04.612
(Laughter)

00:02:04.636 --> 00:02:09.543
Let's just start with the word
"vagina" -- vagina, vagina.

00:02:09.958 --> 00:02:12.153
It sounds like an infection, at best.

00:02:12.838 --> 00:02:14.534
Maybe a medical instrument.

00:02:14.558 --> 00:02:16.318
"Hurry, nurse, bring the vagina!"

00:02:16.342 --> 00:02:17.403
(Laughter)

00:02:17.427 --> 00:02:18.998
Vagina, vagina, vagina.

00:02:19.022 --> 00:02:21.561
It doesn't matter how many times
you say the word,

00:02:21.585 --> 00:02:23.934
it never sounds like a word
you want to say.

00:02:24.265 --> 00:02:28.440
It's a completely ridiculous,
totally un-sexy word.

00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:32.029
If you use it during sex,
trying to be politically correct,

00:02:32.053 --> 00:02:35.264
"Darling, would you stroke my vagina,"

00:02:35.288 --> 00:02:37.381
you kill the act right there.

00:02:37.405 --> 00:02:39.075
(Laughter)

00:02:39.099 --> 00:02:42.397
I'm worried what we call them
and don't call them.

00:02:42.775 --> 00:02:45.509
In Great Neck, New York,
they call it a Pussycat.

00:02:45.533 --> 00:02:47.934
A woman told me there
her mother used to tell her,

00:02:47.958 --> 00:02:50.366
"Don't wear panties, dear,
underneath your pajamas.

00:02:50.390 --> 00:02:52.176
You need to air out your Pussycat."

00:02:52.200 --> 00:02:55.934
(Laughter)

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:58.648
In Westchester, they call it a Pooki,

00:02:58.672 --> 00:03:00.472
in New Jersey, a twat.

00:03:00.836 --> 00:03:05.146
There's Powderbox, derriere,
a Pooky, a Poochi, a Poopi,

00:03:05.170 --> 00:03:09.645
a Poopelu, a Pooninana,
a Padepachetchki, a Pal, and a Piche.

00:03:09.669 --> 00:03:11.121
(Laughter)

00:03:11.145 --> 00:03:16.545
There's Toadie, Dee Dee, Nishi,
Dignity, Coochi Snorcher,

00:03:16.569 --> 00:03:21.415
Cooter, Labbe, Gladys Seagelman, VA,

00:03:21.439 --> 00:03:25.934
Wee wee, Horsespot, Nappy Dugout,

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:32.164
Mongo, Ghoulie, Powderbox,
a Mimi in Miami,

00:03:32.188 --> 00:03:34.295
a Split Knish in Philadelphia ...

00:03:34.319 --> 00:03:35.406
(Laughter)

00:03:35.430 --> 00:03:37.316
and a Schmende in the Bronx.

00:03:37.340 --> 00:03:38.532
(Laughter)

00:03:38.556 --> 00:03:40.505
I am worried about vaginas.

00:03:41.596 --> 00:03:43.806
This is how the "Vagina
Monologues" begins.

00:03:44.402 --> 00:03:47.008
But it really didn't begin there.

00:03:47.032 --> 00:03:50.356
It began with a conversation with a woman.

00:03:50.681 --> 00:03:53.170
We were having a conversation
about menopause,

00:03:53.194 --> 00:03:55.225
and we got onto the subject of her vagina,

00:03:55.249 --> 00:03:57.598
which you'll do if you're
talking about menopause.

00:03:57.622 --> 00:04:00.560
And she said things that really
shocked me about her vagina --

00:04:00.584 --> 00:04:02.703
that it was dried-up
and finished and dead --

00:04:02.727 --> 00:04:03.980
and I was kind of shocked.

00:04:04.004 --> 00:04:05.678
So I said to a friend casually,

00:04:05.702 --> 00:04:07.756
"Well, what do you think
about your vagina?"

00:04:07.780 --> 00:04:09.798
And that woman said
something more amazing,

00:04:09.822 --> 00:04:12.256
and then the next woman said
something more amazing,

00:04:12.280 --> 00:04:14.524
and before I knew it,
every woman was telling me

00:04:14.548 --> 00:04:16.625
I had to talk to somebody
about their vagina

00:04:16.649 --> 00:04:18.276
because they had an amazing story,

00:04:18.300 --> 00:04:20.183
and I was sucked down the vagina trail.

00:04:20.207 --> 00:04:21.517
(Laughter)

00:04:21.541 --> 00:04:23.974
And I really haven't gotten off of it.

00:04:23.998 --> 00:04:26.106
I think if you had told me
when I was younger

00:04:26.130 --> 00:04:28.518
that I was going to grow up,
and be in shoe stores,

00:04:28.542 --> 00:04:31.408
and people would scream out,
"There she is, the Vagina Lady!"

00:04:31.432 --> 00:04:34.069
I don't know that that would have
been my life ambition.

00:04:34.093 --> 00:04:35.096
(Laughter)

00:04:35.120 --> 00:04:37.367
But I want to talk a little bit
about happiness,

00:04:37.391 --> 00:04:39.744
and the relationship
to this whole vagina journey,

00:04:39.768 --> 00:04:41.848
because it has been
an extraordinary journey

00:04:41.872 --> 00:04:43.564
that began eight years ago.

00:04:43.588 --> 00:04:45.854
I think before I did
the "Vagina Monologues,"

00:04:45.878 --> 00:04:48.682
I didn't really believe in happiness.

00:04:48.706 --> 00:04:51.732
I thought that only idiots
were happy, to be honest.

00:04:51.756 --> 00:04:55.550
I remember when I started
practicing Buddhism 14 years ago,

00:04:55.574 --> 00:04:58.777
and I was told that the end
of this practice was to be happy,

00:04:58.801 --> 00:05:02.149
I said, "How could you be happy
and live in this world of suffering

00:05:02.173 --> 00:05:03.985
and live in this world of pain?"

00:05:04.009 --> 00:05:07.934
I mistook happiness
for a lot of other things,

00:05:07.958 --> 00:05:11.236
like numbness or decadence or selfishness.

00:05:11.681 --> 00:05:14.648
And what happened through the course
of the "Vagina Monologues"

00:05:14.672 --> 00:05:17.209
and this journey is,
I think I have come to understand

00:05:17.233 --> 00:05:19.472
a little bit more about happiness.

00:05:19.496 --> 00:05:21.934
There are three qualities
I want to talk about.

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:25.871
One is seeing what's
right in front of you,

00:05:25.895 --> 00:05:28.353
and talking about it, and stating it.

00:05:28.377 --> 00:05:30.934
I think what I learned
from talking about the vagina

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:34.101
and speaking about the vagina,
is it was the most obvious thing --

00:05:34.125 --> 00:05:37.364
it was right in the center of my body
and the center of the world --

00:05:37.388 --> 00:05:40.164
and yet it was the one thing
nobody talked about.

00:05:40.188 --> 00:05:44.441
The second thing is that what talking
about the vagina did

00:05:44.465 --> 00:05:47.376
is it opened this door
which allowed me to see

00:05:47.400 --> 00:05:50.421
that there was a way to serve
the world to make it better.

00:05:50.445 --> 00:05:53.934
And that's where the deepest happiness
has actually come from.

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:57.665
And the third principle of happiness,
which I've realized recently:

00:05:57.689 --> 00:06:01.934
Eight years ago, this momentum
and this energy, this "V-wave" started --

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:05.188
and I can only describe it
as a "V-wave" because, to be honest,

00:06:05.212 --> 00:06:08.934
I really don't understand it completely;
I feel at the service of it.

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:11.934
But this wave started,
and if I question the wave,

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:15.396
or try to stop the wave
or look back at the wave,

00:06:15.420 --> 00:06:17.934
I often have the experience of whiplash

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:20.210
or the potential of my neck breaking.

00:06:20.234 --> 00:06:21.584
But if I go with the wave,

00:06:21.608 --> 00:06:24.002
and I trust the wave
and I move with the wave,

00:06:24.026 --> 00:06:28.533
I go to the next place, and it happens
logically and organically and truthfully.

00:06:28.557 --> 00:06:34.259
And I started this piece, particularly
with stories and narratives,

00:06:34.283 --> 00:06:37.117
and I was talking to one woman
and that led to another woman

00:06:37.141 --> 00:06:38.959
and that led to another woman.

00:06:38.983 --> 00:06:40.828
And then I wrote those stories down,

00:06:40.852 --> 00:06:43.054
and I put them out
in front of other people.

00:06:43.078 --> 00:06:45.650
And every single time
I did the show at the beginning,

00:06:45.674 --> 00:06:48.352
women would literally
line up after the show,

00:06:48.376 --> 00:06:50.611
because they wanted
to tell me their stories.

00:06:50.635 --> 00:06:53.945
And at first I thought, "Oh great,
I'll hear about wonderful orgasms,

00:06:53.969 --> 00:06:56.571
and great sex lives, and how women
love their vaginas."

00:06:56.595 --> 00:06:59.934
But in fact, that's not
what women lined up to tell me.

00:07:00.268 --> 00:07:03.360
What women lined up to tell me
was how they were raped,

00:07:03.384 --> 00:07:05.862
and how they were battered,
and how they were beaten,

00:07:05.886 --> 00:07:08.044
and how they were gang-raped
in parking lots,

00:07:08.068 --> 00:07:10.089
and how they were incested
by their uncles.

00:07:10.113 --> 00:07:12.811
And I wanted to stop doing
the "Vagina Monologues,"

00:07:12.835 --> 00:07:14.240
because it felt too daunting.

00:07:14.264 --> 00:07:17.731
I felt like a war photographer
who takes pictures of terrible events,

00:07:17.755 --> 00:07:20.114
but doesn't intervene on their behalf.

00:07:20.138 --> 00:07:24.355
And so in 1997, I said,
"Let's get women together.

00:07:24.379 --> 00:07:26.555
What could we do with this information

00:07:26.579 --> 00:07:29.123
that all these women are being violated?"

00:07:29.495 --> 00:07:32.680
And it turned out, after thinking
and investigating,

00:07:32.704 --> 00:07:36.101
that I discovered -- and the UN
has actually said this recently --

00:07:36.125 --> 00:07:38.934
that one out of every three
women on this planet

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:41.538
will be beaten or raped in her lifetime.

00:07:42.061 --> 00:07:43.625
That's essentially a gender;

00:07:43.649 --> 00:07:47.044
that's essentially the resource
of the planet, which is women.

00:07:47.068 --> 00:07:50.240
So in 1997 we got all these incredible
women together and we said,

00:07:50.264 --> 00:07:54.379
"How can we use the play, this energy,
to stop violence against women?"

00:07:54.729 --> 00:07:57.404
And we put on one event
in New York City, in the theater,

00:07:57.428 --> 00:08:00.019
and all these great actors
came -- from Susan Sarandon,

00:08:00.043 --> 00:08:01.853
to Glenn Close, to Whoopi Goldberg --

00:08:01.877 --> 00:08:04.717
and we did one performance on one evening,

00:08:04.741 --> 00:08:08.596
and that catalyzed this wave, this energy.

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:11.009
And within five years,

00:08:11.033 --> 00:08:13.498
this extraordinary thing began to happen.

00:08:13.522 --> 00:08:16.934
One woman took that energy and she said,
"I want to bring this wave,

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:19.523
this energy, to college campuses,"

00:08:19.547 --> 00:08:21.565
and so she took the play and she said,

00:08:21.589 --> 00:08:24.762
"Let's use the play and have
performances once a year,

00:08:24.786 --> 00:08:27.375
where we can raise money
to stop violence against women

00:08:27.399 --> 00:08:29.609
in local communities
all around the world."

00:08:29.633 --> 00:08:32.792
And in one year, it went to 50 colleges,
and then it expanded.

00:08:33.125 --> 00:08:35.405
And over the course of the last six years,

00:08:35.429 --> 00:08:38.705
it's spread and it's spread
and it's spread around the world.

00:08:39.348 --> 00:08:42.939
What I have learned is two things:

00:08:42.963 --> 00:08:48.934
one, that the epidemic of violence
towards women is shocking; it's global;

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:51.006
it is so profound
and it is so devastating,

00:08:51.030 --> 00:08:53.934
and it is so in every little pocket
of every little crater,

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:56.625
of every little society
that we don't even recognize it,

00:08:56.649 --> 00:08:58.149
because it's become ordinary.

00:08:58.812 --> 00:09:01.713
This journey has taken me to Afghanistan,

00:09:01.737 --> 00:09:04.466
where I had the extraordinary
honor and privilege

00:09:04.490 --> 00:09:08.815
to go into parts of Afghanistan
under the Taliban.

00:09:08.839 --> 00:09:12.483
I was dressed in a burqa and I went in
with an extraordinary group,

00:09:12.507 --> 00:09:15.876
called the Revolutionary Association
of the Women of Afghanistan.

00:09:15.900 --> 00:09:18.934
And I saw firsthand
how women had been stripped

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:23.123
of every single right that was possible
to strip women of --

00:09:23.147 --> 00:09:25.654
from being educated, to being employed,

00:09:25.678 --> 00:09:28.304
to being actually allowed
to eat ice cream.

00:09:28.681 --> 00:09:30.222
For those of you who don't know,

00:09:30.246 --> 00:09:32.594
it was illegal to eat ice cream
under the Taliban.

00:09:32.618 --> 00:09:36.394
And I actually saw and met
women who had been flogged

00:09:36.418 --> 00:09:38.729
for being caught eating vanilla ice cream.

00:09:38.753 --> 00:09:43.155
I was taken to the secret ice cream-eating
place in a little town,

00:09:43.179 --> 00:09:46.022
where we went to a back room,
and women were seated

00:09:46.046 --> 00:09:49.778
and a curtain was pulled around us,
and they were served vanilla ice cream.

00:09:49.802 --> 00:09:53.218
And women lifted their burqas
and ate this ice cream.

00:09:53.242 --> 00:09:56.362
And I don't think I ever understood
pleasure until that moment,

00:09:56.386 --> 00:09:59.934
and how women have found a way
to keep their pleasure alive.

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:02.506
It has taken me, this journey,
to Islamabad,

00:10:02.530 --> 00:10:06.167
where I have witnessed and met women
with their faces melted off.

00:10:06.191 --> 00:10:10.043
It has taken me to Juarez, Mexico,
where I was a week ago,

00:10:10.067 --> 00:10:12.688
where I have literally been
there in parking lots,

00:10:12.712 --> 00:10:14.561
where bones of women have washed up

00:10:14.585 --> 00:10:18.154
and been dumped next to Coca-Cola bottles.

00:10:18.630 --> 00:10:21.633
It has taken me to universities
all over this country,

00:10:21.657 --> 00:10:24.149
where girls are date-raped and drugged.

00:10:24.173 --> 00:10:27.934
I have seen terrible, terrible,
terrible violence.

00:10:28.334 --> 00:10:32.237
But I have also recognized,
in the course of seeing that violence,

00:10:32.261 --> 00:10:36.879
that being in the face of things
and seeing actually what's in front of us

00:10:36.903 --> 00:10:39.739
is the antidote to depression,

00:10:39.763 --> 00:10:42.934
and to a feeling that one
is worthless and has no value.

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:44.934
Because before the "Vagina Monologues,"

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:47.934
I will say that 80 percent
of my consciousness was closed off

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:50.792
to what was really going on
in this reality,

00:10:50.816 --> 00:10:55.138
and that closing-off closed off
my vitality and my life energy.

00:10:55.665 --> 00:10:58.475
What has also happened
is in the course of these travels --

00:10:58.499 --> 00:11:01.031
and it's been an extraordinary thing --

00:11:01.055 --> 00:11:03.945
is that every single place
that I have gone to in the world,

00:11:03.969 --> 00:11:05.381
I have met a new species.

00:11:05.405 --> 00:11:09.119
And I really love hearing about all
these species at the bottom of the sea.

00:11:09.143 --> 00:11:12.502
And I was thinking about how being
with these extraordinary people

00:11:12.526 --> 00:11:14.160
on this particular panel,

00:11:14.184 --> 00:11:16.934
that it's beneath, beyond and between,

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:19.934
and the vagina kind of fits
into all those categories.

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:21.420
(Laughter)

00:11:21.444 --> 00:11:23.934
But one of the things
I've seen is this species --

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:26.933
and it is a species,
and it is a new paradigm,

00:11:26.957 --> 00:11:29.591
and it doesn't get reported
in the press or in the media

00:11:29.615 --> 00:11:32.653
because I don't think
good news ever is news,

00:11:32.677 --> 00:11:35.320
and I don't think people
who are transforming the planet

00:11:35.344 --> 00:11:38.225
are what gets the ratings on TV shows.

00:11:38.249 --> 00:11:40.273
But every single country I have been to --

00:11:40.297 --> 00:11:43.202
and in the last six years,
I've been to about 45 countries,

00:11:43.226 --> 00:11:46.280
and many tiny little villages
and cities and towns --

00:11:46.304 --> 00:11:50.052
I have seen something what I've come
to call "vagina warriors."

00:11:50.076 --> 00:11:54.251
A "vagina warrior" is a woman,
or a vagina-friendly man,

00:11:54.275 --> 00:11:57.869
who has witnessed incredible
violence or suffered it,

00:11:57.893 --> 00:12:02.264
and rather than getting an AK-47
or a weapon of mass destruction

00:12:02.288 --> 00:12:04.728
or a machete,

00:12:04.752 --> 00:12:07.489
they hold the violence in their bodies;

00:12:07.513 --> 00:12:11.617
they grieve it; they experience it;
and then they go out

00:12:11.641 --> 00:12:15.874
and devote their lives to making sure
it doesn't happen to anybody else.

00:12:15.898 --> 00:12:18.618
I have met these women
everywhere on the planet,

00:12:18.642 --> 00:12:20.404
and I want to tell a few stories,

00:12:20.428 --> 00:12:23.934
because I believe that stories are the way
that we transmit information,

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:26.151
where it goes into our bodies.

00:12:26.175 --> 00:12:30.142
And I think one of the things about being
at TED that's been very interesting

00:12:30.166 --> 00:12:32.076
is that I live in my body a lot,

00:12:32.100 --> 00:12:34.342
and I don't live in my head
very much anymore.

00:12:34.366 --> 00:12:36.175
And this is a very heady place.

00:12:36.199 --> 00:12:38.645
And it's been really interesting
to be in my head

00:12:38.669 --> 00:12:41.387
for the last two days;
I've been very disoriented --

00:12:41.411 --> 00:12:42.412
(Laughter)

00:12:42.436 --> 00:12:45.934
because I think the world, the V-world,
is very much in your body.

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:49.786
It's a body world, and the species
really exists in the body.

00:12:49.810 --> 00:12:54.119
And I think there's a real significance
in us attaching our bodies to our heads,

00:12:54.143 --> 00:12:57.249
that that separation has created a divide

00:12:57.273 --> 00:13:00.779
that is often separating
purpose from intent.

00:13:00.803 --> 00:13:03.949
And the connection between body and head

00:13:03.973 --> 00:13:06.217
often brings those things into union.

00:13:06.693 --> 00:13:09.740
I want to talk about three
particular people that I've met,

00:13:09.764 --> 00:13:13.313
vagina warriors, who really
transformed my understanding

00:13:13.337 --> 00:13:15.297
of this whole principle and species,

00:13:15.321 --> 00:13:17.661
and one is a woman named Marsha Lopez.

00:13:18.209 --> 00:13:21.270
Marsha Lopez was a woman
I met in Guatemala.

00:13:21.294 --> 00:13:24.322
She was 14 years old,
and she was in a marriage

00:13:24.346 --> 00:13:27.346
and her husband was beating her
on a regular basis.

00:13:27.370 --> 00:13:28.839
And she couldn't get out,

00:13:28.863 --> 00:13:30.981
because she was addicted
to the relationship,

00:13:31.005 --> 00:13:32.283
and she had no money.

00:13:32.307 --> 00:13:34.776
Her sister was younger than her,
and she applied --

00:13:34.800 --> 00:13:38.934
we had a "Stop Rape" contest
a few years ago in New York --

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:41.934
and she applied, hoping
that she would become a finalist

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:43.800
and she could bring her sister.

00:13:43.824 --> 00:13:47.934
She did become a finalist;
she brought Marsha to New York.

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:49.203
And at that time,

00:13:49.227 --> 00:13:51.918
we did this extraordinary V-Day
at Madison Square Garden,

00:13:51.942 --> 00:13:55.003
where we sold out the entire
testosterone-filled dome --

00:13:55.027 --> 00:13:58.614
18,000 people standing up
to say "Yes" to vaginas,

00:13:58.638 --> 00:14:01.372
which was really a pretty
incredible transformation.

00:14:01.396 --> 00:14:03.215
And she came, and she witnessed this,

00:14:03.239 --> 00:14:06.325
and she decided that she would go back
and leave her husband,

00:14:06.349 --> 00:14:08.412
and that she would bring
V-Day to Guatemala.

00:14:08.436 --> 00:14:10.009
She was 21 years old.

00:14:10.033 --> 00:14:15.227
I went to Guatemala and she had sold out
the National Theater of Guatemala.

00:14:15.251 --> 00:14:19.685
And I watched her walk up on stage
in her red short dress and high heels,

00:14:19.709 --> 00:14:23.190
and she stood there and said,
"My name is Marsha.

00:14:23.214 --> 00:14:26.975
I was beaten by my husband for five years.
He almost murdered me.

00:14:26.999 --> 00:14:29.156
I left and you can, too."

00:14:29.514 --> 00:14:32.760
And the entire 2,000 people
went absolutely crazy.

00:14:33.283 --> 00:14:36.775
There's a woman named Esther Chávez
who I met in Juarez, Mexico.

00:14:36.799 --> 00:14:40.034
And Esther Chávez was
a brilliant accountant in Mexico City.

00:14:40.058 --> 00:14:43.113
She was 72 years old
and she was planning to retire.

00:14:43.485 --> 00:14:47.059
She went to Juarez
to take care of an ailing aunt,

00:14:47.083 --> 00:14:50.155
and in the course of it, she began
to discover what was happening

00:14:50.179 --> 00:14:53.548
to the murdered and disappeared
women of Juarez.

00:14:53.572 --> 00:14:56.294
She gave up her life; she moved to Juarez.

00:14:56.318 --> 00:15:00.411
She started to write the stories
which documented the disappeared women.

00:15:00.435 --> 00:15:04.050
300 women have disappeared in a border
town because they're brown and poor.

00:15:04.074 --> 00:15:06.336
There has been no response
to the disappearance,

00:15:06.360 --> 00:15:08.597
and not one person
has been held accountable.

00:15:08.621 --> 00:15:10.135
She began to document it.

00:15:10.159 --> 00:15:13.738
She opened a center called
Casa Amiga, and in six years,

00:15:13.762 --> 00:15:17.122
she has literally brought this
to the consciousness of the world.

00:15:17.146 --> 00:15:18.535
We were there a week ago,

00:15:18.559 --> 00:15:22.245
when there were 7,000 people
in the street, and it was truly a miracle.

00:15:22.269 --> 00:15:24.109
And as we walked through the streets,

00:15:24.133 --> 00:15:27.344
the people of Juarez, who normally
don't even come into the streets,

00:15:27.368 --> 00:15:29.146
because the streets are so dangerous,

00:15:29.170 --> 00:15:30.782
literally stood there and wept,

00:15:30.806 --> 00:15:33.347
to see that other people
from the world had showed up

00:15:33.371 --> 00:15:35.057
for that particular community.

00:15:35.768 --> 00:15:37.491
There's another woman, named Agnes.

00:15:37.515 --> 00:15:42.176
And Agnes, for me, epitomizes
what a vagina warrior is.

00:15:42.200 --> 00:15:44.950
I met her three years ago in Kenya.

00:15:44.974 --> 00:15:47.934
And Agnes was mutilated as a little girl;

00:15:47.958 --> 00:15:52.567
she was circumcised against her will
when she was 10 years old,

00:15:52.591 --> 00:15:54.091
and she really made a decision

00:15:54.115 --> 00:15:57.934
that she didn't want this practice
to continue anymore in her community.

00:15:57.958 --> 00:16:01.069
So when she got older,
she created this incredible thing:

00:16:01.093 --> 00:16:06.386
it's an anatomical sculpture
of a woman's body, half a woman's body.

00:16:06.410 --> 00:16:08.538
And she walked through the Rift Valley,

00:16:08.562 --> 00:16:11.934
and she had vagina
and vagina replacement parts,

00:16:11.958 --> 00:16:14.787
where she would teach girls
and parents and boys and girls

00:16:14.811 --> 00:16:18.267
what a healthy vagina looks like,
and what a mutilated vagina looks like.

00:16:18.291 --> 00:16:19.934
And in the course of her travel --

00:16:19.958 --> 00:16:22.997
she walked literally for eight years
through the Rift Valley,

00:16:23.021 --> 00:16:25.282
through dust, through sleeping
on the ground,

00:16:25.306 --> 00:16:27.481
because the Maasai are nomads,

00:16:27.505 --> 00:16:30.934
and she would have to find them,
and they would move,

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:32.596
and she would find them again --

00:16:32.620 --> 00:16:35.515
she saved 1,500 girls from being cut.

00:16:35.904 --> 00:16:38.485
And in that time, she created
an alternative ritual,

00:16:38.509 --> 00:16:41.834
which involved girls
coming of age without the cut.

00:16:41.858 --> 00:16:43.934
When we met her three years ago,

00:16:43.958 --> 00:16:45.871
we said, "What could V-Day do for you?"

00:16:45.895 --> 00:16:49.511
And she said, "Well, if you got me a jeep,
I could get around a lot faster."

00:16:49.535 --> 00:16:50.536
(Laughter)

00:16:50.560 --> 00:16:51.875
So we bought her a jeep.

00:16:51.899 --> 00:16:56.181
And in the year that she had the jeep,
she saved 4,500 girls from being cut.

00:16:56.508 --> 00:16:58.970
So we said to her,
"What else could we do for you?"

00:16:58.994 --> 00:17:01.256
She said, "Well, Eve,
if you gave me some money,

00:17:01.280 --> 00:17:03.430
I could open a house
and girls could run away,

00:17:03.454 --> 00:17:04.848
and they could be saved."

00:17:05.182 --> 00:17:08.063
And I want to tell this little story
about my own beginnings,

00:17:08.087 --> 00:17:12.381
because it's very interrelated
to happiness and Agnes.

00:17:12.405 --> 00:17:16.089
When I was a little girl --
I grew up in a wealthy community;

00:17:16.113 --> 00:17:19.334
it was an upper-middle class
white community,

00:17:19.358 --> 00:17:22.217
and it had all the trappings and the looks

00:17:22.241 --> 00:17:25.876
of a perfectly nice,
wonderful, great life.

00:17:26.217 --> 00:17:28.844
And everyone was supposed
to be happy in that community,

00:17:28.868 --> 00:17:30.449
and, in fact, my life was hell.

00:17:30.473 --> 00:17:32.006
I lived with an alcoholic father

00:17:32.030 --> 00:17:34.934
who beat me and molested me,
and it was all inside that.

00:17:34.958 --> 00:17:39.934
And always as a child I had this fantasy
that somebody would come and rescue me.

00:17:39.958 --> 00:17:43.578
And I actually made up a little character
whose name was Mr. Alligator.

00:17:43.602 --> 00:17:45.934
I would call him up
when things got really bad,

00:17:45.958 --> 00:17:48.121
and say it was time
to come and pick me up.

00:17:48.145 --> 00:17:51.934
And I would pack a little bag
and wait for Mr. Alligator to come.

00:17:51.958 --> 00:17:54.140
Now, Mr. Alligator never did come,

00:17:54.164 --> 00:17:58.638
but the idea of Mr. Alligator coming
actually saved my sanity

00:17:58.662 --> 00:18:00.424
and made it OK for me to keep going,

00:18:00.448 --> 00:18:02.179
because I believed, in the distance,

00:18:02.203 --> 00:18:04.934
there would be someone
coming to rescue me.

00:18:04.958 --> 00:18:07.427
Cut to 40-some odd years later,

00:18:07.451 --> 00:18:10.681
we go to Kenya, and we're walking,

00:18:10.705 --> 00:18:13.083
we arrive at the opening of this house.

00:18:13.448 --> 00:18:15.865
And Agnes hadn't let me come
to the house for days,

00:18:15.889 --> 00:18:18.042
because they were preparing
this whole ritual.

00:18:18.066 --> 00:18:19.656
I want to tell you a great story.

00:18:19.680 --> 00:18:21.302
When Agnes first started fighting

00:18:21.326 --> 00:18:23.827
to stop female genital mutilation
in her community,

00:18:23.851 --> 00:18:27.390
she had become an outcast,
and she was exiled and slandered,

00:18:27.414 --> 00:18:29.445
and the whole community
turned against her.

00:18:29.469 --> 00:18:31.827
But being a vagina warrior,
she kept going,

00:18:31.851 --> 00:18:35.200
and she kept committing herself
to transforming consciousness.

00:18:35.224 --> 00:18:36.832
And in the Maasai community,

00:18:36.856 --> 00:18:39.657
goats and cows are the most
valued possession.

00:18:39.681 --> 00:18:43.934
They're like the Mercedes-Benz
of the Rift Valley.

00:18:43.958 --> 00:18:46.844
And she said two days
before the house opened,

00:18:46.868 --> 00:18:49.731
two different people arrived
to give her a goat each,

00:18:49.755 --> 00:18:50.906
and she said to me,

00:18:50.930 --> 00:18:55.336
"I knew then that female genital
mutilation would end one day in Africa."

00:18:55.744 --> 00:18:59.442
Anyway, we arrived, and when we arrived,

00:18:59.466 --> 00:19:03.196
there were hundreds of girls
dressed in red homemade dresses --

00:19:03.220 --> 00:19:06.130
which is the color of the Maasai
and the color of V-Day --

00:19:06.154 --> 00:19:07.496
and they greeted us.

00:19:07.520 --> 00:19:09.972
They had made up these songs
that they were singing,

00:19:09.996 --> 00:19:12.549
about the end of suffering
and the end of mutilation,

00:19:12.573 --> 00:19:14.268
and they walked us down the path.

00:19:14.292 --> 00:19:16.657
It was a gorgeous day in the African sun,

00:19:16.681 --> 00:19:19.134
and the dust was flying
and the girls were dancing,

00:19:19.158 --> 00:19:23.684
and there was this house, and it said,
"V-Day Safe House for the Girls."

00:19:23.708 --> 00:19:29.010
And it hit me in that moment
that it had taken 47 years,

00:19:29.034 --> 00:19:31.637
but that Mr. Alligator
had finally shown up.

00:19:32.177 --> 00:19:34.059
And he had shown up, obviously,

00:19:34.083 --> 00:19:37.479
in a form that it took me
a long time to understand,

00:19:37.503 --> 00:19:42.609
which is that when we give in the world
what we want the most,

00:19:42.633 --> 00:19:45.934
we heal the broken part inside each of us.

00:19:46.441 --> 00:19:48.815
And I feel, in the last eight years,
