ungraspable by any mind,

00:03:09.439 --> 00:03:10.958
however superior?

00:03:12.380 --> 00:03:17.117
The history of science has been
one long series of violent brainstorms,

00:03:17.141 --> 00:03:20.241
as successive generations
have come to terms with

00:03:20.265 --> 00:03:23.108
increasing levels of queerness
in the universe.

00:03:23.821 --> 00:03:26.871
We're now so used to the idea
that the Earth spins,

00:03:26.895 --> 00:03:29.226
rather than the Sun moves across the sky,

00:03:29.250 --> 00:03:30.559
it's hard for us to realize

00:03:30.583 --> 00:03:34.065
what a shattering mental revolution
that must have been.

00:03:34.589 --> 00:03:37.792
After all, it seems obvious
that the Earth is large and motionless,

00:03:37.816 --> 00:03:39.595
the Sun, small and mobile.

00:03:39.619 --> 00:03:44.204
But it's worth recalling
Wittgenstein's remark on the subject:

00:03:44.228 --> 00:03:48.207
"Tell me," he asked a friend,
"why do people always say

00:03:48.231 --> 00:03:52.306
it was natural for man to assume
that the Sun went 'round the Earth,

00:03:52.330 --> 00:03:54.989
rather than that the Earth was rotating?"

00:03:55.836 --> 00:03:57.829
And his friend replied, "Well, obviously,

00:03:57.853 --> 00:04:01.447
because it just looks as though
the Sun is going round the Earth."

00:04:02.072 --> 00:04:05.834
Wittgenstein replied, "Well,
what would it have looked like

00:04:05.858 --> 00:04:09.370
if it had looked as though
the Earth was rotating?"

00:04:09.394 --> 00:04:13.369
(Laughter)

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:16.985
Science has taught us,
against all intuition,

00:04:17.009 --> 00:04:20.410
that apparently solid things,
like crystals and rocks,

00:04:20.434 --> 00:04:24.315
are really almost entirely
composed of empty space.

00:04:24.664 --> 00:04:28.959
And the familiar illustration
is the nucleus of an atom

00:04:28.983 --> 00:04:32.098
is a fly in the middle
of a sports stadium,

00:04:32.122 --> 00:04:35.149
and the next atom
is in the next sports stadium.

00:04:35.855 --> 00:04:39.042
So it would seem the hardest,
solidest, densest rock

00:04:39.066 --> 00:04:42.655
is really almost entirely empty space,

00:04:42.679 --> 00:04:47.253
broken only by tiny particles
so widely spaced they shouldn't count.

00:04:47.793 --> 00:04:51.928
Why, then, do rocks look and feel
solid and hard and impenetrable?

00:04:53.157 --> 00:04:57.832
As an evolutionary biologist,
I'd say this: our brains have evolved

00:04:57.856 --> 00:05:03.934
to help us survive within the orders
of magnitude, of size and speed

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:05.698
which our bodies operate at.

00:05:06.143 --> 00:05:09.026
We never evolved to navigate
in the world of atoms.

00:05:09.050 --> 00:05:12.375
If we had, our brains
probably would perceive rocks

00:05:12.399 --> 00:05:13.845
as full of empty space.

00:05:13.869 --> 00:05:16.313
Rocks feel hard and impenetrable

00:05:16.337 --> 00:05:20.934
to our hands, precisely because
objects like rocks and hands

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:22.835
cannot penetrate each other.

00:05:23.495 --> 00:05:25.287
It's therefore useful

00:05:25.311 --> 00:05:31.437
for our brains to construct notions
like "solidity" and "impenetrability,"

00:05:31.461 --> 00:05:34.934
because such notions help us
to navigate our bodies

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:39.205
through the middle-sized world
in which we have to navigate.

00:05:39.602 --> 00:05:41.379
Moving to the other end of the scale,

00:05:41.403 --> 00:05:44.793
our ancestors never had to navigate
through the cosmos

00:05:44.817 --> 00:05:47.181
at speeds close to the speed of light.

00:05:47.205 --> 00:05:51.811
If they had, our brains would be
much better at understanding Einstein.

00:05:52.723 --> 00:05:57.224
I want to give the name "Middle World"
to the medium-scaled environment

00:05:57.248 --> 00:05:59.646
in which we've evolved
the ability to take act --

00:05:59.670 --> 00:06:01.397
nothing to do with "Middle Earth" --

00:06:01.421 --> 00:06:02.572
Middle World.

00:06:02.596 --> 00:06:03.934
(Laughter)

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:06.967
We are evolved denizens of Middle World,

00:06:06.991 --> 00:06:10.467
and that limits what
we are capable of imagining.

00:06:10.491 --> 00:06:13.272
We find it intuitively easy
to grasp ideas like,

00:06:13.296 --> 00:06:16.061
when a rabbit moves
at the sort of medium velocity

00:06:16.085 --> 00:06:18.934
at which rabbits and other
Middle World objects move,

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:22.810
and hits another Middle World object
like a rock, it knocks itself out.

00:06:24.804 --> 00:06:30.566
May I introduce Major General
Albert Stubblebine III,

00:06:30.590 --> 00:06:34.923
commander of military
intelligence in 1983.

00:06:35.609 --> 00:06:40.681
"...[He] stared at his wall in Arlington,
Virginia, and decided to do it.

00:06:41.403 --> 00:06:46.262
As frightening as the prospect was,
he was going into the next office.

00:06:47.196 --> 00:06:50.966
He stood up and moved
out from behind his desk.

00:06:52.046 --> 00:06:55.878
'What is the atom mostly made of?'
he thought, 'Space.'

00:06:56.386 --> 00:07:01.552
He started walking. 'What am I
mostly made of? Atoms.'

00:07:02.298 --> 00:07:04.456
He quickened his pace,
almost to a jog now.

00:07:05.139 --> 00:07:07.484
'What is the wall mostly made of?'

00:07:07.508 --> 00:07:08.509
(Laughter)

00:07:08.533 --> 00:07:09.683
'Atoms!'

00:07:10.546 --> 00:07:13.808
All I have to do is merge the spaces.

00:07:15.014 --> 00:07:20.614
Then, General Stubblebine banged
his nose hard on the wall of his office.

00:07:21.297 --> 00:07:25.236
Stubblebine, who commanded
16,000 soldiers,

00:07:25.260 --> 00:07:29.187
was confounded by his continual failure
to walk through the wall.

00:07:29.211 --> 00:07:32.279
He has no doubt that this ability
will one day be a common tool

00:07:32.303 --> 00:07:33.930
in the military arsenal.

00:07:33.954 --> 00:07:37.769
Who would screw around with an army
that could do that?"

00:07:37.793 --> 00:07:39.762
That's from an article in Playboy,

00:07:39.786 --> 00:07:41.501
which I was reading the other day.

00:07:41.525 --> 00:07:43.132
(Laughter)

00:07:43.156 --> 00:07:45.052
I have every reason to think it's true;

00:07:45.076 --> 00:07:48.564
I was reading Playboy because I, myself,
had an article in it.

00:07:48.588 --> 00:07:54.449
(Laughter)

00:07:54.473 --> 00:07:59.123
Unaided human intuition,
schooled in Middle World,

00:07:59.147 --> 00:08:02.454
finds it hard to believe Galileo
when he tells us

00:08:02.478 --> 00:08:05.872
a heavy object and a light object,
air friction aside,

00:08:05.896 --> 00:08:07.872
would hit the ground at the same instant.

00:08:07.896 --> 00:08:11.450
And that's because in Middle World,
air friction is always there.

00:08:11.474 --> 00:08:12.823
If we'd evolved in a vacuum,

00:08:12.847 --> 00:08:15.653
we would expect them to hit
the ground simultaneously.

00:08:16.064 --> 00:08:17.577
If we were bacteria,

00:08:17.601 --> 00:08:20.916
constantly buffeted by thermal
movements of molecules,

00:08:20.940 --> 00:08:22.091
it would be different.

00:08:22.115 --> 00:08:25.393
But we Middle-Worlders are too big
to notice Brownian motion.

00:08:25.814 --> 00:08:29.164
In the same way, our lives
are dominated by gravity,

00:08:29.188 --> 00:08:32.483
but are almost oblivious
to the force of surface tension.

00:08:32.809 --> 00:08:35.634
A small insect would reverse
these priorities.

00:08:37.025 --> 00:08:39.478
Steve Grand -- he's the one on the left,

00:08:39.502 --> 00:08:41.057
Douglas Adams is on the right.

00:08:41.081 --> 00:08:44.779
Steve Grand, in his book,
"Creation: Life and How to Make It,"

00:08:44.803 --> 00:08:49.606
is positively scathing about our
preoccupation with matter itself.

00:08:50.656 --> 00:08:54.295
We have this tendency to think
that only solid, material things

00:08:54.319 --> 00:08:56.200
are really things at all.

00:08:56.769 --> 00:09:01.200
Waves of electromagnetic fluctuation
in a vacuum seem unreal.

00:09:01.708 --> 00:09:06.554
Victorians thought the waves
had to be waves in some material medium:

00:09:06.578 --> 00:09:07.728
the ether.

00:09:08.338 --> 00:09:10.705
But we find real matter comforting

00:09:10.729 --> 00:09:14.696
only because we've evolved
to survive in Middle World,

00:09:14.720 --> 00:09:17.466
where matter is a useful fiction.

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:22.196
A whirlpool, for Steve Grand,
is a thing with just as much reality

00:09:22.220 --> 00:09:23.370
as a rock.

00:09:24.936 --> 00:09:27.586
In a desert plain in Tanzania,

00:09:27.610 --> 00:09:30.800
in the shadow of the volcano
Ol Doinyo Lengai,

00:09:30.824 --> 00:09:32.881
there's a dune made of volcanic ash.

00:09:33.609 --> 00:09:36.609
The beautiful thing
is that it moves bodily.

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:39.165
It's what's technically known
as a "barchan,"

00:09:39.189 --> 00:09:43.393
and the entire dune walks
across the desert in a westerly direction

00:09:43.417 --> 00:09:46.417
at a speed of about 17 meters per year.

00:09:46.783 --> 00:09:51.274
It retains its crescent shape and moves
in the direction of the horns.

00:09:51.298 --> 00:09:55.274
What happens is that the wind blows
the sand up the shallow slope

00:09:55.298 --> 00:09:56.506
on the other side,

00:09:56.530 --> 00:10:00.275
and then, as each sand grain hits
the top of the ridge, it cascades down

00:10:00.299 --> 00:10:01.757
on the inside of the crescent,

00:10:01.781 --> 00:10:04.777
and so the whole horn-shaped dune moves.

00:10:06.761 --> 00:10:10.251
Steve Grand points out
that you and I are, ourselves,

00:10:10.275 --> 00:10:13.207
more like a wave than a permanent thing.

00:10:13.835 --> 00:10:15.686
He invites us, the reader,

00:10:15.710 --> 00:10:18.115
to think of an experience
from your childhood,

00:10:18.139 --> 00:10:19.697
something you remember clearly,

00:10:19.721 --> 00:10:22.755
something you can see,
feel, maybe even smell,

00:10:22.779 --> 00:10:24.494
as if you were really there.

00:10:24.518 --> 00:10:28.291
After all, you really were there
at the time, weren't you?

00:10:28.315 --> 00:10:30.419
How else would you remember it?

00:10:30.443 --> 00:10:33.101
But here is the bombshell:
You weren't there.

00:10:33.125 --> 00:10:35.542
Not a single atom
that is in your body today

00:10:35.566 --> 00:10:38.076
was there when that event took place.

00:10:38.100 --> 00:10:40.243
Matter flows from place to place

00:10:40.267 --> 00:10:43.195
and momentarily comes together to be you.

00:10:43.219 --> 00:10:44.571
Whatever you are, therefore,

00:10:44.595 --> 00:10:48.677
you are not the stuff
of which you are made.

00:10:48.701 --> 00:10:51.749
If that doesn't make the hair stand up
on the back of your neck,

00:10:51.773 --> 00:10:55.089
read it again until it does,
because it is important.

00:10:56.241 --> 00:11:00.335
So "really" isn't a word that we should
use with simple confidence.

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:03.230
If a neutrino had a brain,

00:11:03.254 --> 00:11:05.996
which it evolved
in neutrino-sized ancestors,

00:11:06.020 --> 00:11:10.021
it would say that rocks really
do consist of empty space.

00:11:10.791 --> 00:11:13.584
We have brains that evolved
in medium-sized ancestors

00:11:13.608 --> 00:11:15.608
which couldn't walk through rocks.

00:11:15.988 --> 00:11:20.608
"Really," for an animal, is whatever
its brain needs it to be

00:11:20.632 --> 00:11:22.632
in order to assist its survival.

00:11:23.033 --> 00:11:25.780
And because different species
live in different worlds,

00:11:25.804 --> 00:11:29.891
there will be a discomforting
variety of "reallys."

00:11:32.328 --> 00:11:36.565
What we see of the real world
is not the unvarnished world,

00:11:36.589 --> 00:11:40.870
but a model of the world,
regulated and adjusted by sense data,

00:11:40.894 --> 00:11:44.877
but constructed so it's useful
for dealing with the real world.

00:11:45.417 --> 00:11:48.575
The nature of the model depends
on the kind of animal we are.

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:52.591
A flying animal needs
a different kind of model

00:11:52.615 --> 00:11:55.315
from a walking, climbing
or swimming animal.

00:11:55.339 --> 00:11:59.759
A monkey's brain must have
software capable of simulating

00:11:59.783 --> 00:12:03.078
a three-dimensional world
of branches and trunks.

00:12:03.102 --> 00:12:07.479
A mole's software for constructing models
of its world will be customized

00:12:07.503 --> 00:12:09.455
for underground use.

00:12:09.479 --> 00:12:13.346
A water strider's brain
doesn't need 3D software at all,

00:12:13.370 --> 00:12:15.520
since it lives on the surface of the pond,

00:12:15.544 --> 00:12:17.864
in an Edwin Abbott flatland.

00:12:19.610 --> 00:12:23.639
I've speculated that bats may see
color with their ears.

00:12:24.348 --> 00:12:27.542
The world model that a bat needs
in order to navigate

00:12:27.566 --> 00:12:29.543
through three dimensions catching insects

00:12:29.567 --> 00:12:32.640
must be pretty similar to the world
model that any flying bird --

00:12:32.664 --> 00:12:36.542
a day-flying bird like a swallow --
needs to perform the same kind of tasks.

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:40.248
The fact that the bat uses
echoes in pitch darkness

00:12:40.272 --> 00:12:43.039
to input the current
variables to its model,

00:12:43.063 --> 00:12:45.832
while the swallow uses
light, is incidental.

00:12:46.414 --> 00:12:51.692
Bats, I've even suggested, use
perceived hues, such as red and blue,

00:12:51.716 --> 00:12:57.831
as labels, internal labels,
for some useful aspect of echoes --

00:12:57.855 --> 00:13:02.402
perhaps the acoustic texture of surfaces,
furry or smooth and so on --

00:13:02.426 --> 00:13:06.989
in the same way as swallows or indeed,
we, use those perceived hues --

00:13:07.013 --> 00:13:08.617
redness and blueness, etc. --

00:13:08.641 --> 00:13:11.513
to label long and short
wavelengths of light.

00:13:11.537 --> 00:13:14.864
There's nothing inherent about red
that makes it long wavelength.

00:13:15.705 --> 00:13:19.929
The point is that the nature of the model
is governed by how it is to be used,

00:13:19.953 --> 00:13:23.840
rather than by the sensory
modality involved.

00:13:24.829 --> 00:13:27.649
J.B.S. Haldane himself had
something to say about animals

00:13:27.673 --> 00:13:29.958
whose world is dominated by smell.

00:13:30.493 --> 00:13:36.327
Dogs can distinguish two very similar
fatty acids, extremely diluted:

00:13:36.351 --> 00:13:39.035
caprylic acid and caproic acid.

00:13:39.059 --> 00:13:40.457
The only difference, you see,

00:13:40.481 --> 00:13:43.765
is that one has an extra pair
of carbon atoms in the chain.

00:13:43.789 --> 00:13:48.277
Haldane guesses that a dog would probably
be able to place the acids

00:13:48.301 --> 00:13:51.745
in the order of their molecular
weights by their smells,

00:13:51.769 --> 00:13:54.891
just as a man could place
a number of piano wires

00:13:54.915 --> 00:13:58.120
in the order of their lengths
by means of their notes.

00:13:58.684 --> 00:14:02.471
Now, there's another
fatty acid, capric acid,

00:14:02.495 --> 00:14:04.107
which is just like the other two,

00:14:04.131 --> 00:14:06.685
except that it has two more carbon atoms.

00:14:07.439 --> 00:14:10.262
A dog that had never met
capric acid would, perhaps,

00:14:10.286 --> 00:14:13.239
have no more trouble imagining its smell

00:14:13.263 --> 00:14:16.419
than we would have trouble
imagining a trumpet, say,

00:14:16.443 --> 00:14:20.833
playing one note higher than we've heard
a trumpet play before.

00:14:23.507 --> 00:14:29.789
Perhaps dogs and rhinos and other
smell-oriented animals smell in color.

00:14:30.226 --> 00:14:33.091
And the argument would be exactly
the same as for the bats.

00:14:35.211 --> 00:14:38.898
Middle World -- the range
of sizes and speeds

00:14:38.922 --> 00:14:42.510
which we have evolved to feel
intuitively comfortable with --

00:14:42.534 --> 00:14:46.302
is a bit like the narrow range
of the electromagnetic spectrum

00:14:46.326 --> 00:14:49.154
that we see as light of various colors.

00:14:49.178 --> 00:14:51.498
We're blind to all
frequencies outside that,

00:14:51.522 --> 00:14:54.026
unless we use instruments to help us.

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:59.100
Middle World is the narrow
range of reality

00:14:59.124 --> 00:15:02.378
which we judge to be normal,
as opposed to the queerness

00:15:02.402 --> 00:15:05.962
of the very small, the very large
and the very fast.

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:09.807
We could make a similar
scale of improbabilities;

00:15:09.831 --> 00:15:12.442
nothing is totally impossible.

00:15:12.466 --> 00:15:15.727
Miracles are just events
that are extremely improbable.

00:15:16.188 --> 00:15:19.017
A marble statue could wave its hand at us;

00:15:19.041 --> 00:15:21.904
the atoms that make up
its crystalline structure

00:15:21.928 --> 00:15:24.145
are all vibrating back and forth anyway.

00:15:24.169 --> 00:15:25.827
Because there are so many of them,

00:15:25.851 --> 00:15:27.934
and because there's no
agreement among them

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:30.034
in their preferred direction of movement,

00:15:30.058 --> 00:15:34.123
the marble, as we see it
in Middle World, stays rock steady.

00:15:34.147 --> 00:15:36.757
But the atoms in the hand
could all just happen to move

00:15:36.781 --> 00:15:39.405
the same way at the same time,
and again and again.

00:15:39.429 --> 00:15:41.078
In this case, the hand would move,

00:15:41.102 --> 00:15:44.885
and we'd see it waving at us
in Middle World.

00:15:44.909 --> 00:15:47.495
The odds against it,
of course, are so great

00:15:47.519 --> 00:15:51.999
that if you set out writing zeros
at the time of the origin of the universe,

00:15:52.023 --> 00:15:55.038
you still would not have written
enough zeros to this day.

00:15:56.164 --> 00:15:59.192
Evolution in Middle World
has not equipped us

00:15:59.216 --> 00:16:02.843
to handle very improbable events;
we don't live long enough.

00:16:03.455 --> 00:16:08.146
In the vastness of astronomical space
and geological time,

00:16:08.170 --> 00:16:10.968
that which seems impossible
in Middle World

00:16:10.992 --> 00:16:13.241
might turn out to be inevitable.

00:16:15.093 --> 00:16:18.658
One way to think about that
is by counting planets.

00:16:18.682 --> 00:16:21.364
We don't know how many planets
there are in the universe,

00:16:21.388 --> 00:16:24.839
but a good estimate is about 10 to the 20,
or 100 billion billion.

00:16:25.332 --> 00:16:30.281
And that gives us a nice way to express
our estimate of life's improbability.

00:16:31.668 --> 00:16:35.361
We could make some sort of landmark points
along a spectrum of improbability,

00:16:35.385 --> 00:16:39.661
which might look like the electromagnetic
spectrum we just looked at.

00:16:40.526 --> 00:16:43.367
If life has arisen only once on any --

00:16:44.808 --> 00:16:50.031
life could originate once per planet,
could be extremely common

00:16:50.055 --> 00:16:52.619
or it could originate once per star

00:16:52.643 --> 00:16:57.635
or once per galaxy or maybe only
once in the entire universe,

00:16:57.659 --> 00:16:59.844
in which case it would have to be here.

00:16:59.868 --> 00:17:01.919
And somewhere up there would be the chance

00:17:01.943 --> 00:17:03.744
that a frog would turn into a prince,

00:17:03.768 --> 00:17:06.649
and similar magical things like that.

00:17:07.165 --> 00:17:11.033
If life has arisen on only one planet
in the entire universe,

00:17:11.057 --> 00:17:15.053
that planet has to be our planet,
because here we are talking about it.

00:17:15.077 --> 00:17:17.729
And that means that if we want
to avail ourselves of it,

00:17:17.753 --> 00:17:21.590
we're allowed to postulate chemical events
in the origin of life

00:17:21.614 --> 00:17:25.494
which have a probability as low
as one in 100 billion billion.

00:17:25.994 --> 00:17:28.627
I don't think we shall have
to avail ourselves of that,

00:17:28.651 --> 00:17:31.618
because I suspect that life
is quite common in the universe.

00:17:31.642 --> 00:17:34.680
And when I say quite common,
it could still be so rare

00:17:34.704 --> 00:17:38.829
that no one island of life
ever encounters another,

00:17:38.853 --> 00:17:40.433
which is a sad thought.

00:17:41.623 --> 00:17:44.886
How shall we interpret
"queerer than we can suppose?"

00:17:45.355 --> 00:17:47.610
Queerer than can in principle be supposed,

00:17:47.634 --> 00:17:51.072
or just queerer than we can suppose,
given the limitations

00:17:51.096 --> 00:17:55.358
of our brain's evolutionary
apprenticeship in Middle World?

00:17:55.958 --> 00:17:57.812
Could we, by training and practice,

00:17:57.836 --> 00:18:00.026
emancipate ourselves from Middle World

00:18:00.050 --> 00:18:04.693
and achieve some sort of intuitive
as well as mathematical understanding

00:18:04.717 --> 00:18:06.856
of the very small and the very large?

00:18:06.880 --> 00:18:08.992
I genuinely don't know the answer.

00:18:09.016 --> 00:18:12.650
I wonder whether we might help ourselves
to understand, say, quantum theory,

00:18:12.674 --> 00:18:15.934
if we brought up children
to play computer games

00:18:15.958 --> 00:18:17.540
beginning in early childhood,

00:18:17.564 --> 00:18:21.485
which had a make-believe world of balls
going through two slits on a screen,

00:18:21.509 --> 00:18:25.497
a world in which the strange goings-on
of quantum mechanics were enlarged

00:18:25.521 --> 00:18:27.415
by the computer's make-believe,

00:18:27.439 --> 00:18:31.284
so that they became familiar
on the Middle-World scale of the stream.

00:18:31.308 --> 00:18:33.862
And similarly, a relativistic
computer game,

00:18:33.886 --> 00:18:39.202
in which objects on the screen manifest
the Lorentz contraction, and so on,

00:18:39.226 --> 00:18:43.650
to try to get ourselves -- to get children
into the way of thinking about it.

00:18:44.082 --> 00:18:47.963
I want to end by applying
the idea of Middle World

00:18:47.987 --> 00:18:49.958
to our perceptions of each other.

00:18:50.693 --> 00:18:54.980
Most scientists today subscribe
to a mechanistic view of the mind:

00:18:55.004 --> 00:18:58.408
we're the way we are because our brains
are wired up as they are,

00:18:58.432 --> 00:19:00.084
our hormones are the way they are.

00:19:00.108 --> 00:19:02.619
We'd be different, our characters
would be different,

00:19:02.643 --> 00:19:06.506
if our neuro-anatomy and our
physiological chemistry were different.

00:19:06.826 --> 00:19:08.842
But we scientists are inconsistent.

00:19:09.382 --> 00:19:10.763
If we were consistent,

00:19:10.787 --> 00:19:14.100
our response to a misbehaving
person, like a child-murderer,

00:19:14.124 --> 00:19:15.458
should be something like:

00:19:15.482 --> 00:19:18.728
this unit has a faulty component;
it needs repairing.

00:19:18.752 --> 00:19:19.934
That's not what we say.

00:19:19.958 --> 00:19:24.121
What we say -- and I include
the most austerely mechanistic among us,

00:19:24.145 --> 00:19:25.359
which is probably me --

00:19:25.383 --> 00:19:29.193
what we say is, "Vile monster,
prison is too good for you."

00:19:29.217 --> 00:19:32.934
Or worse, we seek revenge,
in all probability thereby triggering

00:19:32.958 --> 00:19:36.528
the next phase in an escalating
cycle of counter-revenge,

00:19:36.552 --> 00:19:39.010
which we see, of course,
all over the world today.

00:19:39.454 --> 00:19:41.730
In short, when we're
thinking like academics,

00:19:41.754 --> 00:19:45.053
we regard people as elaborate
and complicated machines,

00:19:45.077 --> 00:19:47.222
like computers or cars.

00:19:47.621 --> 00:19:49.635
But when we revert to being human,

00:19:49.659 --> 00:19:53.370
we behave more like Basil Fawlty,
who, we remember,

00:19:53.394 --> 00:19:55.233
thrashed his car to teach it a lesson,

00:19:55.257 --> 00:19:57.532
when it wouldn't start on "Gourmet Night."

00:19:57.556 --> 00:19:58.909
(Laughter)

00:19:59.266 --> 00:20:03.250
The reason we personify things
like cars and computers

00:20:03.274 --> 00:20:06.642
is that just as monkeys live
in an arboreal world

00:20:06.666 --> 00:20:09.328
and moles live in an underground world

00:20:09.352 --> 00:20:13.166
and water striders live in a surface
tension-dominated flatland,

00:20:13.190 --> 00:20:15.319
we live in a social world.

00:20:15.343 --> 00:20:17.529
We swim through a sea of people --

00:20:17.553 --> 00:20:19.886
a social version of Middle World.

00:20:20.520 --> 00:20:24.235
We are evolved to second-guess
the behavior of others

00:20:24.259 --> 00:20:27.986
by becoming brilliant,
intuitive psychologists.

00:20:28.422 --> 00:20:29.814
Treating people as machines

00:20:29.838 --> 00:20:33.353
may be scientifically
and philosophically accurate,

00:20:33.377 --> 00:20:35.290
but it's a cumbersome waste of time

00:20:35.314 --> 00:20:38.475
if you want to guess what this person
is going to do next.

00:20:38.958 --> 00:20:41.934
The economically useful way
to model a person

00:20:41.958 --> 00:20:45.569
is to treat him as a purposeful,
goal-seeking agent

00:20:45.593 --> 00:20:48.009
with pleasures and pains,
desires and intentions,

00:20:48.033 --> 00:20:49.715
guilt, blame-worthiness.

00:20:50.414 --> 00:20:54.524
Personification and the imputing
of intentional purpose

00:20:54.548 --> 00:20:58.191
is such a brilliantly successful
way to model humans,

00:20:58.215 --> 00:21:01.336
it's hardly surprising
the same modeling software

00:21:01.360 --> 00:21:04.934
often seizes control when we're
trying to think about entities

00:21:04.958 --> 00:21:08.329
for which it's not appropriate,
like Basil Fawlty with his car

00:21:08.353 --> 00:21:13.294
or like millions of deluded people,
with the universe as a whole.

00:21:13.675 --> 00:21:15.934
(Laughter)

00:21:15.958 --> 00:21:19.099
If the universe is queerer
than we can suppose,

00:21:19.123 --> 00:21:21.625
is it just because
we've been naturally selected

00:21:21.649 --> 00:21:24.618
to suppose only what we needed to suppose

00:21:24.642 --> 00:21:26.958
in order to survive
in the Pleistocene of Africa?

00:21:27.821 --> 00:21:33.521
Or are our brains so versatile
and expandable that we can train ourselves

00:21:33.545 --> 00:21:36.200
to break out of the box of our evolution?

00:21:36.867 --> 00:21:41.280
Or finally, are there some things
in the universe so queer

00:21:41.304 --> 00:21:47.171
that no philosophy of beings,
however godlike, could dream them?

00:21:47.695 --> 00:21:48.847
Thank you very much.

00:21:48.871 --> 00:21:51.370
(Applause)

title: The freakonomics of crack dealing
transcript: You'll be happy to know that I'll be talking not about my own tragedy, but other people's tragedy. It's a lot easier to be lighthearted about other people's tragedy than your own, and I want to keep it in the spirit of the conference.So, if you believe the media accounts, being a drug dealer in the height of the crack cocaine epidemic was a very glamorous life, in the words of Virginia Postrel. There was money, there was drugs, guns, women, you know, you name it — jewelry, bling-bling — it had it all.What I'm going to tell you today is that, in fact, based on 10 years of research, a unique opportunity to go inside a gang — to see the actual books, the financial records of the gang — that the answer turns out not to be that being in the gang was a glamorous life. But I think, more realistically, that being in a gang — selling drugs for a gang — is perhaps the worst job in all of America. And that's what I'd like to convince you of today.So there are three things I want to do. First, I want to explain how and why crack cocaine had such a profound influence on inner-city gangs. Secondly, I want to tell you how somebody like me came to be able to see the inner workings of a gang — an interesting story, I think. And then third, I want to tell you, in a very superficial way, about some of the things we found when we actually got to look at the financial records, the books, of the gang.So before I do that, just one warning, which is that this presentation has been rated 'R' by the Motion Picture Association of America. It contains adult themes, adult language. Given who is up on the stage, you'll be delighted to know that, in fact, there'll be no nudity —(Laughter)Unexpected wardrobe malfunctions aside.(Laughter)So let me start by talking about crack cocaine, and how it transformed the gang. To do that, you have to actually go back to a time before crack cocaine, in the early '80s, and look at it from the perspective of a gang leader. Being a gang leader in the inner city wasn't such a bad deal in the mid-'80s — the early '80s, let me say.Now, you had a lot of power, and you got to beat people up — you got a lot of prestige, a lot of respect. But the thing is, there was no money in it. The gang had no way to make money. You couldn't charge dues to the people in the gang, because the people in the gang didn't have any money. You couldn't really make any money selling marijuana — marijuana's too cheap, it turns out. You can't get rich selling marijuana. You couldn't sell cocaine; cocaine's a great product — powdered cocaine — but you've got to know rich white people. And most of the inner-city gang members didn't know any rich white people, so couldn't sell to that market. You couldn't really do petty crime, either. Turns out, petty crime's a terrible way to make a living.As a result, as a gang leader, you had, you know, power — it's a pretty good life — but the thing was, in the end, you were living at home with your mother. And so it wasn't really a career. There were limits to how powerful and important you could be if you had to live at home with your mother.Then along comes crack cocaine. And in the words of Malcolm Gladwell, crack cocaine was the extra-chunky version of tomato sauce for the inner city.(Laughter)Because crack cocaine was an unbelievable innovation. I don't have time to talk about it today, but if you think about it, I would say that in the last 25 years, of every invention or innovation that's occurred in this country, the biggest one in terms of impact on the well-being of people who live in the inner city, was crack cocaine. And for the worse — not for the better, but for the worse. It had a huge impact on life.So what was it about crack cocaine? It was a brilliant way of getting the brain high. Because you could smoke crack cocaine — you can't smoke powdered cocaine — and smoking is a much more efficient mechanism of delivering a high than snorting it. And it turned out there was this audience that didn't know it wanted crack cocaine, but when it came, it really did. And it was a perfect drug; you could buy the cocaine that went into it for a dollar, sell it for five dollars. Highly addictive — the high was very short. So for fifteen minutes, you get this great high, and then when you come down, all you want to do is get high again.It created a wonderful market. And for the people who were there running the gang, it was a great way, seemingly, to make a lot of money. At least for the people on the top.So this is where we enter the picture. Not really me — I'm really a bit player in all this. My co-author, Sudhir Venkatesh, is the main character. He was a math major in college who had a good heart, and decided he wanted to get a sociology PhD, came to the University of Chicago. Now, the three months before he came to Chicago, he had spent following the Grateful Dead. And in his own words, he "looked like a freak." He's a South Asian — very dark-skinned South Asian. Big man, and he had hair, in his words, "down to his ass." Defied all kinds of boundaries: Was he black or white? Was he man or woman? He was really a curious sight to be seen.So he showed up at the University of Chicago, and the famous sociologist William Julius Wilson was doing a book that involved surveying people all across Chicago. He took one look at Sudhir, who was going to go do some surveys for him, and decided he knew exactly the place to send him, which was to one of the toughest, most notorious housing projects not just in Chicago, but in the entire United States.So Sudhir, the suburban boy who had never really been in the inner city, dutifully took his clipboard and walked down to this housing project, gets to the first building. The first building? Well, there's nobody there. But he hears some voices up in the stairwell, so he climbs up the stairwell, comes around the corner, and finds a group of young African-American men playing dice.This is about 1990, peak of the crack epidemic. This is a very dangerous job, being in a gang. You don't like to be surprised. You don't like to be surprised by people who come around the corner. And the mantra was: shoot first; ask questions later. Now, Sudhir was lucky — he was such a freak, and that clipboard probably saved his life, because they figured no other rival gang member would be coming up to shoot at them with a clipboard.(Laughter)So his greeting was not particularly warm, but they did say, well, OK — let's hear your questions on your survey. So — I kid you not — the first question on the survey that he was sent to ask was: "How do you feel about being poor and Black in America?"(Laughter)Makes you wonder about academics.(Laughter)So the choice of answers were:[A) Very Good B) Good C) Bad D) Very Bad](Laughter)What Sudhir found out is, in fact, that the real answer was the following: [A) Very Good B) Good C) Bad D) Very Bad E) Fuck you](Laughter)The survey was not, in the end, going to be what got Sudhir off the hook. He was held hostage overnight in the stairwell. There was a lot of gunfire, there were a lot of philosophical discussions he had with the gang members. By morning, the gang leader arrived, checked out Sudhir, decided he was no threat, and they let him go home. So Sudhir went home, took a shower, took a nap.And you and I, probably, faced with the situation, would think, "I guess I'm going to write my dissertation on The Grateful Dead, I've been following them for the last three months."(Laughter)Sudhir, on the other hand, got right back, walked down to the housing project, went up to the second floor, and said: "Hey, guys, I had so much fun hanging out with you last night, I wonder if I could do it again tonight." And that was the beginning of what turned out to be a beautiful relationship that involved Sudhir living in the housing project on and off for 10 years, hanging out in crack houses, going to jail with the gang members, having the windows shot out of his car, having the police break into his apartment and steal his computer disks — you name it. But ultimately, the story has a happy ending for Sudhir, who became one of the most respected sociologists in the country. And especially for me, as I sat in my office with my Excel spreadsheet open, waiting for Sudhir to come and deliver to me the latest load of data that he would get from the gang.(Laughter)It was one of the most unequal co-authoring relationships ever —(Laughter)But I was glad to be the beneficiary of it.So what did we find? What did we find in the gang? Well, let me say one thing: We really got access to everybody in the gang. We got an inside look at the gang, from the very bottom up to the very top. They trusted Sudhir, in ways that really no academic has ever — or really anybody, any outsider — has ever earned the trust of these gangs, to the point where they actually opened up what was most interesting for me — their books, the financial records they kept. They made them available to us, and we not only could study them, but we could ask them questions about what was in them.So if I have to kind of summarize very quickly in the short time I have what the bottom line of what I take away from the gang is, it's that, if I had to draw a parallel between the gang and any other organization, it would be that the gang is just like McDonald's, in a lot of different respects — the restaurant McDonald's.So first, in one way, which isn't maybe the most interesting way, but it's a good way to start — is in the way it's organized, the hierarchy of the gang, the way it looks. So here's what the org chart of the gang looks like. I don't know if you know much about org charts, but if you were to assign a stripped-down and simplified McDonald's org chart, this is exactly what it would look like. It's amazing, but the top level of the gang, they actually call themselves the "Board of Directors."(Laughter)And Sudhir says it's not like these guys had a very sophisticated view of what happened in American corporate life, but they had seen movies like "Wall Street," and they had learned a little bit about what it was like to be in the real world. Now, below that board of directors, you've got essentially what are regional VPs — people who control, say, the South Side of Chicago, or the West Side of Chicago.Sudhir got to know very well the guy who had the unfortunate assignment of trying to take the Iowa franchise, which, it turned out, for this black gang, was not one of the more brilliant financial endeavors they undertook.(Laughter)But the thing that really makes the gang seem like McDonald's is its franchisees. The guys who are running the local gangs — the four-square-block by four-square-block areas — they're just like the guys, in some sense, who are running the McDonald's. They are the entrepreneurs. They get the exclusive property rights to control the drug-selling. They get the name of the gang behind them, for merchandising and marketing. And they're the ones who basically make the profit or lose a profit, depending on how good they are at running the business.Now, the group I really want you to think about, though, are the ones at the bottom — the foot soldiers. These are the teenagers, typically, who'd be standing out on the street corner, selling the drugs. Extremely dangerous work. And important to note is that almost all of the weight, all of the people in this organization are at the bottom — just like McDonald's. So in some sense, the foot soldiers are a lot like the people who are taking your order at McDonald's, and it's not just by chance that they're like them. In fact, in these neighborhoods, they'd be the same people. So the same kids who are working in the gang were actually, at the very same time, typically working part-time at a place like McDonald's. Which already foreshadows the main result that I've talked about, about what a crappy job it was, being in the gang. Because obviously, if being in the gang were such a wonderful, lucrative job, why in the world would these guys moonlight at McDonald's?So what do the wages look like? You might be surprised. But based on being able to talk to them and to see their records, this is what it looks like in terms of the wages. The hourly wage the foot soldiers were earning was $3.50 an hour. It was below the minimum wage. And this is well-documented. It's easy to see by the patterns of consumption they have. It really is not fiction — it's fact. There was very little money in the gang, especially at the bottom.Now if you managed to rise up, say, and be that local leader, the guy who's the equivalent of the McDonald's franchisee, you'd be making 100,000 dollars a year. And that, in some ways, was the best job you could hope to get if you were growing up in one of these neighborhoods as a young black male. If you managed to rise to the very top, 200,000 or 400,000 dollars a year is what you'd hope to make. Truly, you would be a great success story.And one of the sad parts of this is that, indeed, among the many other ramifications of crack cocaine is that the most talented individuals in these communities — this is what they were striving for. They weren't trying to make it in legitimate ways, because there were no legitimate channels out. This was the best way out. And it actually was the right choice, probably, to try to make it out this way.You look at this, the relationship to McDonald's breaks down here. The money looks about the same. Why is it such a bad job? Well, the reason it's such a bad job is that there's somebody shooting at you a lot of the time. So, with shooting at you, what are the death rates? We found, in our gang — and admittedly, this was not really a standard situation; this was a time of intense violence, of a lot of gang wars, as this gang actually became quite successful. But there were costs. And so the death rate — not to mention the rate of being arrested, sent to prison, being wounded — the death rate in our sample was seven percent per person per year. You're in the gang for four years, you expect to die with about a 25 percent likelihood. That is about as high as you can get.So for comparison's purposes, let's think about some other walk of life you may expect might be extremely risky. Let's say that you were a murderer and you were convicted of murder, and you're sent to death row. It turns out, the death rates on death row from all causes, including execution: two percent a year.(Laughter)So it's a lot safer being on death row than it is selling drugs out on the street.That gives you some pause, for those of you who believe that a death penalty's going to have an enormous deterrent effect on crime. To give you a sense of just how bad the inner city was during crack — and I'm not really focusing on the negatives, but really, there's another story to tell you there — if you look at the death rates just of random, young black males growing up in the inner city in the United States, the death rates during crack were about one percent. That's extremely high. And this is violent death — it's unbelievable, in some sense.To put it into perspective: if you compare this to the soldiers in Iraq, for instance, right now fighting the war: 0.5 percent. So in some very literal way, the young black men who were growing up in this country were living in a war zone, very much in the sense that the soldiers over in Iraq are fighting in a war.So why in the world, you might ask, would anybody be willing to stand out on a street corner selling drugs for $3.50 an hour, with a 25 percent chance of dying over the next four years? Why would they do that? And I think there are a couple answers.I think the first one is that they got fooled by history. It used to be the gang was a rite of passage; that the young people controlled the gang; that as you got older, you dropped out of the gang. So what happened was, the people who happened to be in the right place at the right time — the people who happened to be leading the gang in the mid-to-late-'80s — became very, very wealthy. And so the logical thing to think was that they are going to age out of the gang like everybody else has, and the next generation is going to take over and get the wealth.There are striking similarities, I think, to the Internet boom. The first set of people in Silicon Valley got very, very rich. And then all of my friends said, "Maybe I should go do that, too." And they were willing to work very cheap for stock options that never came. In some sense, that's what happened, exactly, to the set of people we were looking at. They were willing to start at the bottom, just like, say, a first-year lawyer at a law firm is willing to start at the bottom, work 80-hour weeks for not that much money, because they think they're going to make partner. But the rules changed, and they never got to make partner.Indeed, the same people who were running all of the major gangs in the late 1980s are still running the major gangs in Chicago today. They never passed on any of the wealth, So everybody got stuck at that $3.50-an-hour job, and it turned out to be a disaster.The other thing the gang was very good at was marketing and trickery. And so for instance, one thing the gang would do is — the gang leaders would have big entourages, and they'd drive fancy cars and have fancy jewelry. So what Sudhir eventually realized as he hung out with them more, is that, really, they didn't own those cars — they just leased them, because they couldn't afford to own the fancy cars. And they didn't really have gold jewelry, they had gold-plated jewelry. It goes back to, you know, the real-real versus the fake-real.And really, they did all sorts of things to trick the young people into thinking what a great deal the gang was going to be. So for instance, they would give a 14-year-old kid a whole roll of bills to hold. That 14-year-old kid would say to his friends, "Hey, look at all the money I got in the gang." It wasn't his money — until he spent it, and then he was in debt to the gang, and was sort of an indentured servant for a while. So I have a couple minutes.Let me do one last thing I hadn't thought I'd have time to do, which is to talk about what we learned more generally about economics, from the study of the gang.So, economists tend to talk in technical words. Often, our theories fail quite miserably when we over the data, but what's kind of interesting is that in this setting, it turned out that some of the economic theories that worked not so well in the real economy worked very well in the drug economy, in some sense, because it's unfettered capitalism. Here's an economic principle. This is one of the basic ideas in labor economics, called a "compensating differential." It's the idea that the increment to wages that a worker requires to leave him indifferent between performing two tasks, one which is more unpleasant than the other. Compensating differential — it's why we think garbagemen might be paid more than people who work in parks.The words of one of the members of the gang, I think, make this clear. So it turns out — I'm sort of getting ahead of myself — it turns out, in the gang, when there's a war going on, they actually pay the foot soldiers twice as much money. It's exactly this concept. Because they're not willing to be at risk. And the words of a gang member capture it quite nicely, he says: "Would you stand around here when all this shit ..." — the shooting — "... if all this shit's going on? No, right? So if I gonna be asked to put my life on the line, then front me the cash, man." I think the gang member says it much more articulately than the economist, about what's going on.(Laughter)Here's another one. Economists talk about game theory, that every two-person game has a Nash equilibrium. Here's the translation you get from the gang member. They're talking about the decision of why they don't go shoot — One thing that turns out to be a great business tactic in the gang: if you go and just shoot guns in the air in the other gang's territory — people are afraid to go buy drugs there, they're going to come into your neighborhood.Here's what he says about why they don't do that: "If we start shooting around there, the other gang's territory, nobody, I mean, you dig it, nobody gonna step on their turf. But we gotta be careful, 'cause they can shoot around here too and then we all fucked."(Laughter)So that's the same concept. Then again, sometimes economists get it wrong. One thing we observed in the data is that it looked like — the gang leader always got paid. No matter how bad it was economically, he always got himself paid.We had some theories related to cash flow, and lack of access to capital markets, and things like that. Then we asked the gang member, "Why is it you always get paid and your workers don't always get paid?" His response is, "You got all these niggers below you who want your job, you dig? If you start taking losses, they see you as weak and shit." And I thought about it and said, "CEOs often pay themselves million-dollar bonuses, even when companies are losing a lot of money. And it never would really occur to an economist that this idea of 'weak and shit' could really be important."(Laughter)Maybe "weak and shit" is an important hypothesis that needs more analysis.Thank you very much.(Applause)

00:01:14.487 --> 00:01:18.195
First, I want to explain
how and why crack cocaine

00:01:18.219 --> 00:01:22.276
had such a profound influence
on inner-city gangs.

00:01:23.752 --> 00:01:25.559
Secondly, I want to tell you

00:01:25.583 --> 00:01:30.459
how somebody like me
came to be able to see

00:01:30.483 --> 00:01:33.840
the inner workings of a gang --
an interesting story, I think.

00:01:33.864 --> 00:01:36.774
And then third, I want to tell you,
in a very superficial way,

00:01:36.798 --> 00:01:38.385
about some of the things we found

00:01:38.409 --> 00:01:40.973
when we actually got to look
at the financial records,

00:01:40.997 --> 00:01:42.685
the books, of the gang.

00:01:42.709 --> 00:01:46.138
So before I do that, just one warning,

00:01:46.162 --> 00:01:49.896
which is that this presentation
has been rated 'R'

00:01:49.920 --> 00:01:52.194
by the Motion Picture
Association of America.

00:01:52.510 --> 00:01:55.289
It contains adult themes, adult language.

00:01:55.668 --> 00:01:58.368
Given who is up on the stage,
you'll be delighted to know

00:01:58.392 --> 00:02:00.934
that, in fact, there'll be no nudity --

00:02:00.958 --> 00:02:03.351
(Laughter)

00:02:03.375 --> 00:02:05.958
Unexpected wardrobe malfunctions aside.

00:02:05.982 --> 00:02:10.896
(Laughter)

00:02:10.920 --> 00:02:14.453
So let me start by talking
about crack cocaine,

00:02:14.477 --> 00:02:16.151
and how it transformed the gang.

00:02:16.459 --> 00:02:19.863
To do that, you have to actually go
back to a time before crack cocaine,

00:02:19.887 --> 00:02:23.297
in the early '80s, and look at it
from the perspective of a gang leader.

00:02:23.321 --> 00:02:29.261
Being a gang leader in the inner city
wasn't such a bad deal in the mid-'80s --

00:02:29.285 --> 00:02:30.778
the early '80s, let me say.

00:02:30.802 --> 00:02:33.701
Now, you had a lot of power,
and you got to beat people up --

00:02:33.725 --> 00:02:36.257
you got a lot of prestige,
a lot of respect.

00:02:36.281 --> 00:02:38.834
But the thing is,
there was no money in it.

00:02:38.858 --> 00:02:40.519
The gang had no way to make money.

00:02:40.543 --> 00:02:42.945
You couldn't charge dues
to the people in the gang,

00:02:42.969 --> 00:02:45.579
because the people in the gang
didn't have any money.

00:02:45.603 --> 00:02:48.211
You couldn't really make any money
selling marijuana --

00:02:48.235 --> 00:02:50.631
marijuana's too cheap, it turns out.

00:02:50.655 --> 00:02:52.521
You can't get rich selling marijuana.

00:02:52.545 --> 00:02:54.336
You couldn't sell cocaine;

00:02:54.360 --> 00:02:56.774
cocaine's a great product --
powdered cocaine --

00:02:56.798 --> 00:02:58.764
but you've got to know rich white people.

00:02:58.788 --> 00:03:02.281
And most of the inner-city gang members
didn't know any rich white people,

00:03:02.305 --> 00:03:03.844
so couldn't sell to that market.

00:03:03.868 --> 00:03:05.888
You couldn't really do
petty crime, either.

00:03:05.912 --> 00:03:08.587
Turns out, petty crime's
a terrible way to make a living.

00:03:08.611 --> 00:03:11.766
As a result, as a gang leader,
you had, you know, power --

00:03:11.790 --> 00:03:14.481
it's a pretty good life --
but the thing was, in the end,

00:03:14.505 --> 00:03:16.472
you were living at home with your mother.

00:03:16.496 --> 00:03:18.179
And so it wasn't really a career.

00:03:18.203 --> 00:03:21.041
There were limits to how powerful
and important you could be

00:03:21.065 --> 00:03:23.137
if you had to live at home
with your mother.

00:03:23.161 --> 00:03:25.871
Then along comes crack cocaine.

00:03:26.264 --> 00:03:29.279
And in the words of Malcolm Gladwell,

00:03:29.303 --> 00:03:33.734
crack cocaine was the extra-chunky
version of tomato sauce

00:03:33.758 --> 00:03:34.909
for the inner city.

00:03:34.933 --> 00:03:35.934
(Laughter)

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:38.462
Because crack cocaine
was an unbelievable innovation.

00:03:38.486 --> 00:03:41.707
I don't have time to talk about it today,
but if you think about it,

00:03:41.731 --> 00:03:43.574
I would say that in the last 25 years,

00:03:43.598 --> 00:03:46.734
of every invention or innovation
that's occurred in this country,

00:03:46.758 --> 00:03:48.537
the biggest one in terms of impact

00:03:48.561 --> 00:03:52.427
on the well-being of people
who live in the inner city,

00:03:52.451 --> 00:03:53.602
was crack cocaine.

00:03:53.626 --> 00:03:56.407
And for the worse --
not for the better, but for the worse.

00:03:56.431 --> 00:03:57.885
It had a huge impact on life.

00:03:57.909 --> 00:03:59.773
So what was it about crack cocaine?

00:03:59.797 --> 00:04:04.368
It was a brilliant way
of getting the brain high.

00:04:04.392 --> 00:04:09.934
Because you could smoke crack cocaine --
you can't smoke powdered cocaine --

00:04:09.958 --> 00:04:13.343
and smoking is a much more efficient
mechanism of delivering a high

00:04:13.367 --> 00:04:14.870
than snorting it.

00:04:14.894 --> 00:04:19.343
And it turned out there was this audience
that didn't know it wanted crack cocaine,

00:04:19.367 --> 00:04:21.139
but when it came, it really did.

00:04:21.163 --> 00:04:22.568
And it was a perfect drug;

00:04:22.592 --> 00:04:26.768
you could buy the cocaine
that went into it for a dollar,

00:04:26.792 --> 00:04:28.277
sell it for five dollars.

00:04:28.301 --> 00:04:30.629
Highly addictive --
the high was very short.

00:04:30.653 --> 00:04:33.325
So for fifteen minutes,
you get this great high,

00:04:33.349 --> 00:04:34.706
and then when you come down,

00:04:34.730 --> 00:04:37.426
all you want to do is get high again.

00:04:37.450 --> 00:04:39.340
It created a wonderful market.

00:04:39.364 --> 00:04:42.496
And for the people who were there
running the gang,

00:04:42.520 --> 00:04:45.934
it was a great way, seemingly,
to make a lot of money.

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:48.143
At least for the people on the top.

00:04:48.167 --> 00:04:50.025
So this is where we enter the picture.

00:04:50.049 --> 00:04:52.554
Not really me -- I'm really
a bit player in all this.

00:04:52.578 --> 00:04:55.443
My co-author, Sudhir Venkatesh,
is the main character.

00:04:55.467 --> 00:05:00.934
He was a math major in college
who had a good heart,

00:05:00.958 --> 00:05:03.719
and decided he wanted
to get a sociology PhD,

00:05:03.743 --> 00:05:05.372
came to the University of Chicago.

00:05:05.396 --> 00:05:08.026
Now, the three months
before he came to Chicago,

00:05:08.050 --> 00:05:10.581
he had spent following the Grateful Dead.

00:05:10.605 --> 00:05:14.072
And in his own words,
he "looked like a freak."

00:05:14.096 --> 00:05:17.958
He's a South Asian --
very dark-skinned South Asian.

00:05:18.308 --> 00:05:22.054
Big man, and he had hair,
in his words, "down to his ass."

00:05:22.753 --> 00:05:24.472
Defied all kinds of boundaries:

00:05:24.496 --> 00:05:26.734
Was he black or white?
Was he man or woman?

00:05:26.758 --> 00:05:29.425
He was really a curious sight to be seen.

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:32.093
So he showed up
at the University of Chicago,

00:05:32.117 --> 00:05:34.800
and the famous sociologist
William Julius Wilson

00:05:34.824 --> 00:05:39.958
was doing a book that involved
surveying people all across Chicago.

00:05:40.472 --> 00:05:44.096
He took one look at Sudhir, who was going
to go do some surveys for him,

00:05:44.120 --> 00:05:46.490
and decided he knew exactly
the place to send him,

00:05:46.514 --> 00:05:49.638
which was to one of the toughest,
most notorious housing projects

00:05:49.662 --> 00:05:52.153
not just in Chicago,
but in the entire United States.

00:05:52.177 --> 00:05:55.846
So Sudhir, the suburban boy who had never
really been in the inner city,

00:05:55.870 --> 00:06:00.773
dutifully took his clipboard
and walked down to this housing project,

00:06:00.797 --> 00:06:02.336
gets to the first building.

00:06:02.725 --> 00:06:05.198
The first building?
Well, there's nobody there.

00:06:05.222 --> 00:06:08.352
But he hears some voices
up in the stairwell,

00:06:08.376 --> 00:06:11.934
so he climbs up the stairwell,
comes around the corner,

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:16.039
and finds a group of young
African-American men playing dice.

00:06:17.251 --> 00:06:20.230
This is about 1990,
peak of the crack epidemic.

00:06:20.254 --> 00:06:22.412
This is a very dangerous job,
being in a gang.

00:06:22.436 --> 00:06:23.951
You don't like to be surprised.

00:06:23.975 --> 00:06:27.488
You don't like to be surprised
by people who come around the corner.

00:06:27.512 --> 00:06:30.836
And the mantra was:
shoot first; ask questions later.

00:06:30.860 --> 00:06:33.042
Now, Sudhir was lucky --
he was such a freak,

00:06:33.066 --> 00:06:35.277
and that clipboard
probably saved his life,

00:06:35.301 --> 00:06:37.524
because they figured no other
rival gang member

00:06:37.548 --> 00:06:40.043
would be coming up to shoot
at them with a clipboard.

00:06:40.067 --> 00:06:41.068
(Laughter)

00:06:41.092 --> 00:06:44.123
So his greeting was not particularly
warm, but they did say,

00:06:44.147 --> 00:06:47.790
well, OK -- let's hear
your questions on your survey.

00:06:48.218 --> 00:06:49.423
So -- I kid you not --

00:06:49.447 --> 00:06:53.234
the first question on the survey
that he was sent to ask was:

00:06:53.258 --> 00:06:55.964
"How do you feel about being
poor and Black in America?"

00:06:55.988 --> 00:06:59.119
(Laughter)

00:06:59.143 --> 00:07:00.834
Makes you wonder about academics.

00:07:00.858 --> 00:07:02.762
(Laughter)

00:07:02.786 --> 00:07:04.667
So the choice of answers were:

00:07:04.691 --> 00:07:08.338
[A) Very Good B) Good C) Bad D) Very Bad]

00:07:08.362 --> 00:07:10.363
(Laughter)

00:07:10.387 --> 00:07:13.892
What Sudhir found out is, in fact,
that the real answer was the following:

00:07:13.916 --> 00:07:16.791
[A) Very Good B) Good C) Bad
D) Very Bad E) Fuck you]

00:07:16.815 --> 00:07:18.412
(Laughter)

00:07:18.436 --> 00:07:21.956
The survey was not, in the end, going
to be what got Sudhir off the hook.

00:07:21.980 --> 00:07:25.460
He was held hostage
overnight in the stairwell.

00:07:25.484 --> 00:07:26.789
There was a lot of gunfire,

00:07:26.813 --> 00:07:30.432
there were a lot of philosophical
discussions he had with the gang members.

00:07:30.456 --> 00:07:32.206
By morning, the gang leader arrived,

00:07:32.230 --> 00:07:34.348
checked out Sudhir,
decided he was no threat,

00:07:34.372 --> 00:07:35.594
and they let him go home.

00:07:35.618 --> 00:07:38.746
So Sudhir went home,
took a shower, took a nap.

00:07:38.770 --> 00:07:43.569
And you and I, probably, faced
with the situation, would think,

00:07:43.593 --> 00:07:46.665
"I guess I'm going to write
my dissertation on The Grateful Dead,

00:07:46.689 --> 00:07:49.128
I've been following them
for the last three months."

00:07:49.152 --> 00:07:50.160
(Laughter)

00:07:50.184 --> 00:07:51.443
Sudhir, on the other hand,

00:07:51.467 --> 00:07:53.888
got right back, walked
down to the housing project,

00:07:53.912 --> 00:07:55.255
went up to the second floor,

00:07:55.279 --> 00:07:59.181
and said: "Hey, guys, I had so much fun
hanging out with you last night,

00:07:59.205 --> 00:08:01.183
I wonder if I could do it again tonight."

00:08:01.207 --> 00:08:04.838
And that was the beginning of what turned
out to be a beautiful relationship

00:08:04.862 --> 00:08:08.457
that involved Sudhir living in the housing
project on and off for 10 years,

00:08:08.481 --> 00:08:13.236
hanging out in crack houses,
going to jail with the gang members,

00:08:13.260 --> 00:08:15.798
having the windows shot out of his car,

00:08:15.822 --> 00:08:19.320
having the police break into his apartment
and steal his computer disks --

00:08:19.344 --> 00:08:20.502
you name it.

00:08:20.526 --> 00:08:23.342
But ultimately, the story
has a happy ending for Sudhir,

00:08:23.366 --> 00:08:26.609
who became one of the most
respected sociologists in the country.

00:08:26.633 --> 00:08:28.002
And especially for me,

00:08:28.026 --> 00:08:31.445
as I sat in my office
with my Excel spreadsheet open,

00:08:31.469 --> 00:08:34.806
waiting for Sudhir to come and deliver
to me the latest load of data

00:08:34.830 --> 00:08:36.716
that he would get from the gang.

00:08:36.740 --> 00:08:40.509
(Laughter)

00:08:40.533 --> 00:08:43.937
It was one of the most unequal
co-authoring relationships ever --

00:08:43.961 --> 00:08:44.981
(Laughter)

00:08:45.005 --> 00:08:48.496
But I was glad to be
the beneficiary of it.

00:08:48.520 --> 00:08:49.894
So what did we find?

00:08:50.347 --> 00:08:52.299
What did we find in the gang?

00:08:52.729 --> 00:08:54.415
Well, let me say one thing:

00:08:54.439 --> 00:08:58.042
We really got access
to everybody in the gang.

00:08:58.066 --> 00:09:02.390
We got an inside look at the gang,
from the very bottom up to the very top.

00:09:02.414 --> 00:09:07.400
They trusted Sudhir, in ways
that really no academic has ever --

00:09:07.424 --> 00:09:11.976
or really anybody, any outsider --
has ever earned the trust of these gangs,

00:09:12.000 --> 00:09:14.457
to the point where they actually opened up

00:09:14.481 --> 00:09:16.738
what was most interesting
for me -- their books,

00:09:16.762 --> 00:09:18.301
the financial records they kept.

00:09:18.325 --> 00:09:21.397
They made them available to us,
and we not only could study them,

00:09:21.421 --> 00:09:24.017
but we could ask them questions
about what was in them.

00:09:24.041 --> 00:09:27.467
So if I have to kind of summarize
very quickly in the short time I have

00:09:27.491 --> 00:09:31.441
what the bottom line of what
I take away from the gang is,

00:09:31.465 --> 00:09:34.175
it's that, if I had to draw
a parallel between the gang

00:09:34.199 --> 00:09:36.318
and any other organization,

00:09:36.342 --> 00:09:39.633
it would be that the gang
is just like McDonald's,

00:09:39.657 --> 00:09:42.506
in a lot of different respects --
the restaurant McDonald's.

00:09:42.530 --> 00:09:44.148
So first, in one way,

00:09:44.172 --> 00:09:47.787
which isn't maybe the most interesting
way, but it's a good way to start --

00:09:47.811 --> 00:09:50.457
is in the way it's organized,
the hierarchy of the gang,

00:09:50.481 --> 00:09:51.632
the way it looks.

00:09:51.656 --> 00:09:54.110
So here's what the org chart
of the gang looks like.

00:09:54.134 --> 00:09:56.341
I don't know if you know much
about org charts,

00:09:56.365 --> 00:10:00.072
but if you were to assign a stripped-down
and simplified McDonald's org chart,

00:10:00.096 --> 00:10:02.050
this is exactly what it would look like.

00:10:02.074 --> 00:10:04.268
It's amazing, but the top
level of the gang,

00:10:04.292 --> 00:10:06.919
they actually call themselves
the "Board of Directors."

00:10:06.943 --> 00:10:08.022
(Laughter)

00:10:08.046 --> 00:10:09.993
And Sudhir says

00:10:10.017 --> 00:10:13.411
it's not like these guys
had a very sophisticated view

00:10:13.435 --> 00:10:16.900
of what happened
in American corporate life,

00:10:16.924 --> 00:10:18.989
but they had seen movies
like "Wall Street,"

00:10:19.013 --> 00:10:22.388
and they had learned a little bit
about what it was like

00:10:22.412 --> 00:10:24.363
to be in the real world.

00:10:24.387 --> 00:10:26.221
Now, below that board of directors,

00:10:26.245 --> 00:10:28.650
you've got essentially
what are regional VPs --

00:10:28.674 --> 00:10:32.459
people who control, say, the South Side
of Chicago, or the West Side of Chicago.

00:10:32.483 --> 00:10:35.934
Sudhir got to know very well the guy
who had the unfortunate assignment

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:38.297
of trying to take the Iowa franchise,

00:10:38.321 --> 00:10:40.382
which, it turned out, for this black gang,

00:10:40.406 --> 00:10:44.504
was not one of the more brilliant
financial endeavors they undertook.

00:10:44.528 --> 00:10:45.782
(Laughter)

00:10:45.806 --> 00:10:50.102
But the thing that really makes the gang
seem like McDonald's is its franchisees.

00:10:50.126 --> 00:10:54.466
The guys who are running
the local gangs --

00:10:54.490 --> 00:10:57.441
the four-square-block
by four-square-block areas --

00:10:57.465 --> 00:11:00.967
they're just like the guys, in some sense,
who are running the McDonald's.

00:11:00.991 --> 00:11:02.460
They are the entrepreneurs.

00:11:02.484 --> 00:11:06.220
They get the exclusive property rights
to control the drug-selling.

00:11:06.244 --> 00:11:12.756
They get the name of the gang behind them,
for merchandising and marketing.

00:11:13.256 --> 00:11:16.597
And they're the ones who basically
make the profit or lose a profit,

00:11:16.621 --> 00:11:19.200
depending on how good
they are at running the business.

00:11:19.224 --> 00:11:22.129
Now, the group I really want you
to think about, though,

00:11:22.153 --> 00:11:24.406
are the ones at the bottom --
the foot soldiers.

00:11:24.430 --> 00:11:26.478
These are the teenagers, typically,

00:11:26.502 --> 00:11:29.526
who'd be standing out on the street
corner, selling the drugs.

00:11:29.550 --> 00:11:31.970
Extremely dangerous work.

00:11:31.994 --> 00:11:37.372
And important to note is that almost all
of the weight, all of the people

00:11:37.396 --> 00:11:40.453
in this organization are at the bottom --
just like McDonald's.

00:11:40.477 --> 00:11:43.437
So in some sense, the foot soldiers
are a lot like the people

00:11:43.461 --> 00:11:45.427
who are taking your order at McDonald's,

00:11:45.451 --> 00:11:47.889
and it's not just by chance
that they're like them.

00:11:47.913 --> 00:11:50.714
In fact, in these neighborhoods,
they'd be the same people.

00:11:50.738 --> 00:11:53.639
So the same kids who are working
in the gang were actually,

00:11:53.663 --> 00:11:56.422
at the very same time,
typically working part-time

00:11:56.446 --> 00:11:57.977
at a place like McDonald's.

00:11:58.001 --> 00:12:01.392
Which already foreshadows
the main result that I've talked about,

00:12:01.416 --> 00:12:04.506
about what a crappy job
it was, being in the gang.

00:12:04.530 --> 00:12:08.181
Because obviously, if being in the gang
were such a wonderful, lucrative job,

00:12:08.205 --> 00:12:11.449
why in the world would these guys
moonlight at McDonald's?

00:12:11.473 --> 00:12:14.521
So what do the wages look like?
You might be surprised.

00:12:14.545 --> 00:12:18.172
But based on being able to talk to them
and to see their records,

00:12:18.196 --> 00:12:20.666
this is what it looks
like in terms of the wages.

00:12:20.690 --> 00:12:24.780
The hourly wage the foot soldiers
were earning was $3.50 an hour.

00:12:24.804 --> 00:12:28.193
It was below the minimum wage.
And this is well-documented.

00:12:28.217 --> 00:12:31.080
It's easy to see by the patterns
of consumption they have.

00:12:31.104 --> 00:12:34.079
It really is not fiction -- it's fact.

00:12:34.103 --> 00:12:37.934
There was very little money in the gang,
especially at the bottom.

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:41.343
Now if you managed to rise up, say,
and be that local leader,

00:12:41.367 --> 00:12:44.104
the guy who's the equivalent
of the McDonald's franchisee,

00:12:44.128 --> 00:12:46.013
you'd be making 100,000 dollars a year.

00:12:46.037 --> 00:12:49.363
And that, in some ways,
was the best job you could hope to get

00:12:49.387 --> 00:12:53.045
if you were growing up in one of these
neighborhoods as a young black male.

00:12:53.069 --> 00:12:54.964
If you managed to rise to the very top,

00:12:54.988 --> 00:12:57.913
200,000 or 400,000 dollars a year
is what you'd hope to make.

00:12:57.937 --> 00:13:00.666
Truly, you would be a great success story.

00:13:00.690 --> 00:13:03.766
And one of the sad parts
of this is that, indeed,

00:13:03.790 --> 00:13:06.335
among the many other
ramifications of crack cocaine

00:13:06.359 --> 00:13:10.489
is that the most talented individuals
in these communities --

00:13:10.513 --> 00:13:12.244
this is what they were striving for.

00:13:12.268 --> 00:13:14.736
They weren't trying to make it
in legitimate ways,

00:13:14.760 --> 00:13:16.950
because there were
no legitimate channels out.

00:13:16.974 --> 00:13:18.347
This was the best way out.

00:13:18.371 --> 00:13:21.042
And it actually was
the right choice, probably,

00:13:21.066 --> 00:13:24.392
to try to make it out this way.

00:13:25.075 --> 00:13:26.359
You look at this,

00:13:26.383 --> 00:13:29.302
the relationship to McDonald's
breaks down here.

00:13:29.326 --> 00:13:31.261
The money looks about the same.

00:13:31.285 --> 00:13:32.727
Why is it such a bad job?

00:13:32.751 --> 00:13:36.467
Well, the reason it's such a bad job
is that there's somebody shooting at you

00:13:36.491 --> 00:13:38.053
a lot of the time.

00:13:38.077 --> 00:13:40.934
So, with shooting at you,
what are the death rates?

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:42.115
We found, in our gang --

00:13:42.139 --> 00:13:45.375
and admittedly, this was not really
a standard situation;

00:13:45.399 --> 00:13:49.841
this was a time of intense violence,
of a lot of gang wars,

00:13:49.865 --> 00:13:52.524
as this gang actually
became quite successful.

00:13:52.548 --> 00:13:53.784
But there were costs.

00:13:53.808 --> 00:13:55.553
And so the death rate --

00:13:55.577 --> 00:14:00.537
not to mention the rate of being arrested,
sent to prison, being wounded --

00:14:00.561 --> 00:14:05.266
the death rate in our sample
was seven percent per person per year.

00:14:05.290 --> 00:14:07.021
You're in the gang for four years,

00:14:07.045 --> 00:14:11.561
you expect to die
with about a 25 percent likelihood.

00:14:11.585 --> 00:14:13.687
That is about as high as you can get.

00:14:13.711 --> 00:14:15.558
So for comparison's purposes,

00:14:15.582 --> 00:14:20.584
let's think about some other walk of life
you may expect might be extremely risky.

00:14:20.608 --> 00:14:22.600
Let's say that you were a murderer

00:14:22.624 --> 00:14:25.825
and you were convicted of murder,
and you're sent to death row.

00:14:25.849 --> 00:14:29.818
It turns out, the death rates on death row
from all causes, including execution:

00:14:29.842 --> 00:14:30.998
two percent a year.

00:14:31.022 --> 00:14:32.023
(Laughter)

00:14:32.047 --> 00:14:35.680
So it's a lot safer being on death row

00:14:35.704 --> 00:14:38.264
than it is selling drugs
out on the street.

00:14:38.802 --> 00:14:41.680
That gives you some pause,
for those of you who believe

00:14:41.704 --> 00:14:46.387
that a death penalty's going to have
an enormous deterrent effect on crime.

00:14:47.514 --> 00:14:50.829
To give you a sense of just how bad
the inner city was during crack --

00:14:50.853 --> 00:14:53.587
and I'm not really focusing
on the negatives,

00:14:53.611 --> 00:14:56.531
but really, there's another story
to tell you there --

00:14:56.555 --> 00:15:00.293
if you look at the death rates
just of random, young black males

00:15:00.317 --> 00:15:02.704
growing up in the inner city
in the United States,

00:15:02.728 --> 00:15:05.504
the death rates during crack
were about one percent.

00:15:05.528 --> 00:15:06.680
That's extremely high.

00:15:06.704 --> 00:15:09.695
And this is violent death --
it's unbelievable, in some sense.

00:15:09.719 --> 00:15:14.449
To put it into perspective: if you compare
this to the soldiers in Iraq,

00:15:14.473 --> 00:15:18.139
for instance, right now
fighting the war: 0.5 percent.

00:15:18.163 --> 00:15:21.200
So in some very literal way,

00:15:21.224 --> 00:15:24.132
the young black men who were
growing up in this country

00:15:24.156 --> 00:15:25.969
were living in a war zone,

00:15:25.993 --> 00:15:32.763
very much in the sense that the soldiers
over in Iraq are fighting in a war.

00:15:32.787 --> 00:15:35.802
So why in the world, you might ask,

00:15:35.826 --> 00:15:39.621
would anybody be willing
to stand out on a street corner

00:15:39.645 --> 00:15:41.934
selling drugs for $3.50 an hour,

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:44.934
with a 25 percent chance of dying
over the next four years?

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:46.893
Why would they do that?

00:15:46.917 --> 00:15:49.288
And I think there are a couple answers.

00:15:49.764 --> 00:15:55.122
I think the first one
is that they got fooled by history.

00:15:55.471 --> 00:15:57.788
It used to be the gang
was a rite of passage;

00:15:57.812 --> 00:15:59.846
that the young people controlled the gang;

00:15:59.870 --> 00:16:02.555
that as you got older,
you dropped out of the gang.

00:16:03.421 --> 00:16:04.597
So what happened was,

00:16:04.621 --> 00:16:07.899
the people who happened to be
in the right place at the right time --

00:16:07.923 --> 00:16:13.339
the people who happened to be leading
the gang in the mid-to-late-'80s --

00:16:13.363 --> 00:16:15.322
became very, very wealthy.

00:16:15.346 --> 00:16:17.450
And so the logical thing to think

00:16:17.474 --> 00:16:20.598
was that they are going
to age out of the gang

00:16:20.622 --> 00:16:21.819
like everybody else has,

00:16:21.843 --> 00:16:24.958
and the next generation is going
to take over and get the wealth.

00:16:24.982 --> 00:16:27.967
There are striking similarities,
I think, to the Internet boom.

00:16:27.991 --> 00:16:31.217
The first set of people in Silicon Valley
got very, very rich.

00:16:31.241 --> 00:16:35.331
And then all of my friends said,
"Maybe I should go do that, too."

00:16:35.355 --> 00:16:39.959
And they were willing to work very cheap
for stock options that never came.

00:16:39.983 --> 00:16:42.357
In some sense,
that's what happened, exactly,

00:16:42.381 --> 00:16:45.895
to the set of people we were looking at.

00:16:45.919 --> 00:16:48.114
They were willing to start at the bottom,

00:16:48.138 --> 00:16:51.195
just like, say, a first-year
lawyer at a law firm

00:16:51.219 --> 00:16:53.390
is willing to start at the bottom,

00:16:53.414 --> 00:16:55.477
work 80-hour weeks
for not that much money,

00:16:55.501 --> 00:16:57.810
because they think
they're going to make partner.

00:16:57.834 --> 00:17:00.620
But the rules changed,
and they never got to make partner.

00:17:00.644 --> 00:17:04.503
Indeed, the same people who were running
all of the major gangs in the late 1980s

00:17:04.527 --> 00:17:06.933
are still running the major gangs
in Chicago today.

00:17:06.957 --> 00:17:08.840
They never passed on any of the wealth,

00:17:08.864 --> 00:17:11.708
So everybody got stuck
at that $3.50-an-hour job,

00:17:11.732 --> 00:17:13.651
and it turned out to be a disaster.

00:17:14.268 --> 00:17:18.531
The other thing the gang was
very good at was marketing and trickery.

00:17:18.555 --> 00:17:22.203
And so for instance,
one thing the gang would do is --

00:17:22.227 --> 00:17:24.459
the gang leaders would have
big entourages,

00:17:24.483 --> 00:17:27.695
and they'd drive fancy cars
and have fancy jewelry.

00:17:27.719 --> 00:17:30.805
So what Sudhir eventually realized
as he hung out with them more,

00:17:30.829 --> 00:17:34.089
is that, really, they didn't own
those cars -- they just leased them,

00:17:34.113 --> 00:17:36.792
because they couldn't afford
to own the fancy cars.

00:17:36.816 --> 00:17:40.278
And they didn't really have gold jewelry,
they had gold-plated jewelry.

00:17:40.302 --> 00:17:43.662
It goes back to, you know,
the real-real versus the fake-real.

00:17:43.686 --> 00:17:47.648
And really, they did all sorts
of things to trick the young people

00:17:47.672 --> 00:17:50.465
into thinking what a great deal
the gang was going to be.

00:17:50.489 --> 00:17:53.280
So for instance, they would give
a 14-year-old kid

00:17:53.304 --> 00:17:56.430
a whole roll of bills to hold.

00:17:56.454 --> 00:17:59.284
That 14-year-old kid
would say to his friends,

00:17:59.308 --> 00:18:01.515
"Hey, look at all the money
I got in the gang."

00:18:01.539 --> 00:18:03.516
It wasn't his money -- until he spent it,

00:18:03.540 --> 00:18:05.259
and then he was in debt to the gang,

00:18:05.283 --> 00:18:07.672
and was sort of an indentured
servant for a while.

00:18:07.696 --> 00:18:09.246
So I have a couple minutes.

00:18:09.270 --> 00:18:13.315
Let me do one last thing
I hadn't thought I'd have time to do,

00:18:13.339 --> 00:18:18.593
which is to talk about what we learned
more generally about economics,

00:18:18.617 --> 00:18:20.624
from the study of the gang.

00:18:20.648 --> 00:18:24.203
So, economists tend to talk
in technical words.

00:18:24.227 --> 00:18:27.828
Often, our theories fail quite miserably
when we over the data,

00:18:27.852 --> 00:18:30.638
but what's kind of interesting
is that in this setting,

00:18:30.662 --> 00:18:32.979
it turned out that
some of the economic theories

00:18:33.003 --> 00:18:35.138
that worked not so well
in the real economy

00:18:35.162 --> 00:18:37.352
worked very well in the drug economy,

00:18:37.376 --> 00:18:39.742
in some sense, because
it's unfettered capitalism.

00:18:39.766 --> 00:18:41.159
Here's an economic principle.

00:18:41.183 --> 00:18:43.525
This is one of the basic ideas
in labor economics,

00:18:43.549 --> 00:18:45.333
called a "compensating differential."

00:18:45.357 --> 00:18:48.799
It's the idea that the increment to wages
that a worker requires

00:18:48.823 --> 00:18:51.437
to leave him indifferent
between performing two tasks,

00:18:51.461 --> 00:18:53.566
one which is more unpleasant
than the other.

00:18:53.590 --> 00:18:57.236
Compensating differential -- it's why
we think garbagemen might be paid more

00:18:57.260 --> 00:18:58.794
than people who work in parks.

00:18:58.818 --> 00:19:04.740
The words of one of the members
of the gang, I think, make this clear.

00:19:04.764 --> 00:19:07.454
So it turns out -- I'm sort
of getting ahead of myself --

00:19:07.478 --> 00:19:10.631
it turns out, in the gang,
when there's a war going on,

00:19:10.655 --> 00:19:13.672
they actually pay the foot soldiers
twice as much money.

00:19:13.696 --> 00:19:14.985
It's exactly this concept.

00:19:15.009 --> 00:19:17.641
Because they're not willing to be at risk.

00:19:17.665 --> 00:19:20.687
And the words of a gang member
capture it quite nicely, he says:

00:19:20.711 --> 00:19:24.061
"Would you stand around here when all
this shit ..." -- the shooting --

00:19:24.085 --> 00:19:26.198
"... if all this shit's
going on? No, right?

00:19:26.222 --> 00:19:30.028
So if I gonna be asked to put my life
on the line, then front me the cash, man."

00:19:30.052 --> 00:19:32.600
I think the gang member says it
much more articulately

00:19:32.624 --> 00:19:34.641
than the economist, about what's going on.

00:19:34.665 --> 00:19:36.280
(Laughter)

00:19:36.304 --> 00:19:37.934
Here's another one.

00:19:37.958 --> 00:19:39.600
Economists talk about game theory,

00:19:39.624 --> 00:19:41.982
that every two-person game
has a Nash equilibrium.

00:19:42.006 --> 00:19:44.464
Here's the translation
you get from the gang member.

00:19:44.488 --> 00:19:47.841
They're talking about the decision
of why they don't go shoot --

00:19:47.865 --> 00:19:51.731
One thing that turns out to be a great
business tactic in the gang:

00:19:51.755 --> 00:19:55.637
if you go and just shoot guns in the air
in the other gang's territory --

00:19:55.661 --> 00:19:57.602
people are afraid to go buy drugs there,

00:19:57.626 --> 00:19:59.734
they're going to come
into your neighborhood.

00:19:59.758 --> 00:20:02.054
Here's what he says
about why they don't do that:

00:20:02.078 --> 00:20:05.099
"If we start shooting around there,
the other gang's territory,

00:20:05.123 --> 00:20:08.006
nobody, I mean, you dig it,
nobody gonna step on their turf.

00:20:08.030 --> 00:20:09.182
