But we gotta be careful,

00:20:09.206 --> 00:20:12.132
'cause they can shoot around here too
and then we all fucked."

00:20:12.156 --> 00:20:13.157
(Laughter)

00:20:13.181 --> 00:20:14.479
So that's the same concept.

00:20:14.503 --> 00:20:16.717
Then again, sometimes
economists get it wrong.

00:20:16.741 --> 00:20:21.412
One thing we observed in the data
is that it looked like --

00:20:21.436 --> 00:20:24.716
the gang leader always got paid.

00:20:24.740 --> 00:20:29.192
No matter how bad it was economically,
he always got himself paid.

00:20:29.216 --> 00:20:31.366
We had some theories related to cash flow,

00:20:31.390 --> 00:20:34.221
and lack of access to capital markets,
and things like that.

00:20:34.245 --> 00:20:35.681
Then we asked the gang member,

00:20:35.705 --> 00:20:39.058
"Why is it you always get paid
and your workers don't always get paid?"

00:20:39.082 --> 00:20:40.233
His response is,

00:20:40.257 --> 00:20:43.344
"You got all these niggers below you
who want your job, you dig?

00:20:43.368 --> 00:20:46.151
If you start taking losses,
they see you as weak and shit."

00:20:46.175 --> 00:20:47.723
And I thought about it and said,

00:20:47.747 --> 00:20:51.388
"CEOs often pay themselves
million-dollar bonuses,

00:20:51.412 --> 00:20:53.724
even when companies
are losing a lot of money.

00:20:53.748 --> 00:20:55.963
And it never would really occur
to an economist

00:20:55.987 --> 00:20:58.883
that this idea of 'weak and shit'
could really be important."

00:20:58.907 --> 00:21:02.173
(Laughter)

00:21:02.197 --> 00:21:07.934
Maybe "weak and shit" is an important
hypothesis that needs more analysis.

00:21:07.958 --> 00:21:09.109
Thank you very much.

00:21:09.133 --> 00:21:10.133
(Applause)

title: Choice, happiness and spaghetti sauce
transcript: I think I was supposed to talk about my new book, which is called "Blink," and it's about snap judgments and first impressions. And it comes out in January, and I hope you all buy it in triplicate.(Laughter)But I was thinking about this, and I realized that although my new book makes me happy, and I think would make my mother happy, it's not really about happiness. So I decided instead, I would talk about someone who I think has done as much to make Americans happy as perhaps anyone over the last 20 years, a man who is a great personal hero of mine: someone by the name of Howard Moskowitz, who is most famous for reinventing spaghetti sauce.Howard's about this high, and he's round, and he's in his 60s, and he has big huge glasses and thinning gray hair, and he has a kind of wonderful exuberance and vitality, and he has a parrot, and he loves the opera, and he's a great aficionado of medieval history. And by profession, he's a psychophysicist. Now, I should tell you that I have no idea what psychophysics is, although at some point in my life, I dated a girl for two years who was getting her doctorate in psychophysics. Which should tell you something about that relationship.(Laughter)As far as I know, psychophysics is about measuring things. And Howard is very interested in measuring things. And he graduated with his doctorate from Harvard, and he set up a little consulting shop in White Plains, New York. And one of his first clients was Pepsi. This is many years ago, back in the early 70s. And Pepsi came to Howard and they said, "You know, there's this new thing called aspartame, and we would like to make Diet Pepsi. We'd like you to figure out how much aspartame we should put in each can of Diet Pepsi in order to have the perfect drink." Now that sounds like an incredibly straightforward question to answer, and that's what Howard thought. Because Pepsi told him, "We're working with a band between eight and 12 percent. Anything below eight percent sweetness is not sweet enough; anything above 12 percent sweetness is too sweet. We want to know: what's the sweet spot between 8 and 12?" Now, if I gave you this problem to do, you would all say, it's very simple. What we do is you make up a big experimental batch of Pepsi, at every degree of sweetness — eight percent, 8.1, 8.2, 8.3, all the way up to 12 — and we try this out with thousands of people, and we plot the results on a curve, and we take the most popular concentration, right? Really simple.Howard does the experiment, and he gets the data back, and he plots it on a curve, and all of a sudden he realizes it's not a nice bell curve. In fact, the data doesn't make any sense. It's a mess. It's all over the place. Now, most people in that business, in the world of testing food and such, are not dismayed when the data comes back a mess. They think, "Well, you know, figuring out what people think about cola's not that easy." "You know, maybe we made an error somewhere along the way." "You know, let's just make an educated guess," and they simply point and they go for 10 percent, right in the middle. Howard is not so easily placated. Howard is a man of a certain degree of intellectual standards. And this was not good enough for him, and this question bedeviled him for years. And he would think it through and say, "What was wrong? Why could we not make sense of this experiment with Diet Pepsi?"And one day, he was sitting in a diner in White Plains, about to go trying to dream up some work for Nescafé. And suddenly, like a bolt of lightning, the answer came to him. And that is, that when they analyzed the Diet Pepsi data, they were asking the wrong question. They were looking for the perfect Pepsi, and they should have been looking for the perfect Pepsis. Trust me. This was an enormous revelation. This was one of the most brilliant breakthroughs in all of food science. Howard immediately went on the road, and he would go to conferences around the country, and he would stand up and say, "You had been looking for the perfect Pepsi. You're wrong. You should be looking for the perfect Pepsis." And people would look at him blankly and say, "What are you talking about? Craziness." And they would say, "Move! Next!" Tried to get business, nobody would hire him — he was obsessed, though, and he talked about it and talked about it. Howard loves the Yiddish expression "To a worm in horseradish, the world is horseradish." This was his horseradish.(Laughter)He was obsessed with it!And finally, he had a breakthrough. Vlasic Pickles came to him, and they said, "Doctor Moskowitz, we want to make the perfect pickle." And he said, "There is no perfect pickle; there are only perfect pickles." And he came back to them and he said, "You don't just need to improve your regular; you need to create zesty." And that's where we got zesty pickles. Then the next person came to him: Campbell's Soup. And this was even more important.In fact, Campbell's Soup is where Howard made his reputation. Campbell's made Prego, and Prego, in the early 80s, was struggling next to Ragù, which was the dominant spaghetti sauce of the 70s and 80s. In the industry — I don't know whether you care about this, or how much time I have to go into this. But it was, technically speaking — this is an aside — Prego is a better tomato sauce than Ragù. The quality of the tomato paste is much better; the spice mix is far superior; it adheres to the pasta in a much more pleasing way. In fact, they would do the famous bowl test back in the 70s with Ragù and Prego. You'd have a plate of spaghetti, and you would pour it on, right? And the Ragù would all go to the bottom, and the Prego would sit on top. That's called "adherence." And, anyway, despite the fact that they were far superior in adherence, and the quality of their tomato paste, Prego was struggling.So they came to Howard, and they said, fix us. And Howard looked at their product line, and he said, what you have is a dead tomato society. So he said, this is what I want to do. And he got together with the Campbell's soup kitchen, and he made 45 varieties of spaghetti sauce. And he varied them according to every conceivable way that you can vary tomato sauce: by sweetness, by level of garlic, by tomatoey-ness, by tartness, by sourness, by visible solids — my favorite term in the spaghetti sauce business.(Laughter)Every conceivable way you can vary spaghetti sauce, he varied spaghetti sauce. And then he took this whole raft of 45 spaghetti sauces, and he went on the road. He went to New York, to Chicago, he went to Jacksonville, to Los Angeles. And he brought in people by the truckload into big halls. And he sat them down for two hours, and over the course of that two hours, he gave them ten bowls. Ten small bowls of pasta, with a different spaghetti sauce on each one. And after they ate each bowl, they had to rate, from 0 to 100, how good they thought the spaghetti sauce was.At the end of that process, after doing it for months and months, he had a mountain of data about how the American people feel about spaghetti sauce. And then he analyzed the data. Did he look for the most popular variety of spaghetti sauce? No! Howard doesn't believe that there is such a thing. Instead, he looked at the data, and he said, let's see if we can group all these different data points into clusters. Let's see if they congregate around certain ideas. And sure enough, if you sit down, and you analyze all this data on spaghetti sauce, you realize that all Americans fall into one of three groups. There are people who like their spaghetti sauce plain; there are people who like their spaghetti sauce spicy; and there are people who like it extra chunky.And of those three facts, the third one was the most significant, because at the time, in the early 1980s, if you went to a supermarket, you would not find extra-chunky spaghetti sauce. And Prego turned to Howard, and they said, "You're telling me that one third of Americans crave extra-chunky spaghetti sauce and yet no one is servicing their needs?" And he said "Yes!"(Laughter)And Prego then went back, and completely reformulated their spaghetti sauce, and came out with a line of extra chunky that immediately and completely took over the spaghetti sauce business in this country. And over the next 10 years, they made 600 million dollars off their line of extra-chunky sauces.Everyone else in the industry looked at what Howard had done, and they said, "Oh my god! We've been thinking all wrong!" And that's when you started to get seven different kinds of vinegar, and 14 different kinds of mustard, and 71 different kinds of olive oil. And then eventually even Ragù hired Howard, and Howard did the exact same thing for Ragù that he did for Prego. And today, if you go to a really good supermarket, do you know how many Ragùs there are? 36! In six varieties: Cheese, Light, Robusto, Rich & Hearty, Old World Traditional — Extra-Chunky Garden.(Laughter)That's Howard's doing. That is Howard's gift to the American people.Now why is that important?(Laughter)It is, in fact, enormously important. I'll explain to you why. What Howard did is he fundamentally changed the way the food industry thinks about making you happy. Assumption number one in the food industry used to be that the way to find out what people want to eat, what will make people happy, is to ask them. And for years and years and years, Ragù and Prego would have focus groups, and they would sit you down, and they would say, "What do you want in a spaghetti sauce? Tell us what you want in a spaghetti sauce." And for all those years — 20, 30 years — through all those focus group sessions, no one ever said they wanted extra-chunky. Even though at least a third of them, deep in their hearts, actually did.(Laughter)People don't know what they want! As Howard loves to say, "The mind knows not what the tongue wants." It's a mystery!(Laughter)And a critically important step in understanding our own desires and tastes is to realize that we cannot always explain what we want, deep down. If I asked all of you, for example, in this room, what you want in a coffee, you know what you'd say? Every one of you would say, "I want a dark, rich, hearty roast." It's what people always say when you ask them. "What do you like?" "Dark, rich, hearty roast!" What percentage of you actually like a dark, rich, hearty roast? According to Howard, somewhere between 25 and 27 percent of you. Most of you like milky, weak coffee.(Laughter)But you will never, ever say to someone who asks you what you want that "I want a milky, weak coffee."So that's number one thing that Howard did. Number two thing that Howard did is he made us realize — it's another very critical point — he made us realize the importance of what he likes to call "horizontal segmentation." Why is this critical? Because this is the way the food industry thought before Howard. What were they obsessed with in the early 80s? They were obsessed with mustard. In particular, they were obsessed with the story of Grey Poupon. Used to be, there were two mustards: French's and Gulden's. What were they? Yellow mustard. What's in it? Yellow mustard seeds, turmeric, and paprika. That was mustard. Grey Poupon came along, with a Dijon. Right? Much more volatile brown mustard seed, some white wine, a nose hit, much more delicate aromatics. And what do they do? They put it in a little tiny glass jar, with a wonderful enameled label on it, made it look French, even though it's made in Oxnard, California.(Laughter)And instead of charging a dollar fifty for the eight-ounce bottle, the way that French's and Gulden's did, they decided to charge four dollars. And they had those ads. With the guy in the Rolls Royce, eating the Grey Poupon. Another pulls up, and says, "Do you have any Grey Poupon?" And the whole thing, after they did that, Grey Poupon takes off! Takes over the mustard business!And everyone's take-home lesson from that was that the way to make people happy is to give them something that is more expensive, something to aspire to. It's to make them turn their back on what they think they like now, and reach out for something higher up the mustard hierarchy.(Laughter)A better mustard! A more expensive mustard! A mustard of more sophistication and culture and meaning. And Howard looked to that and said, "That's wrong!" Mustard does not exist on a hierarchy. Mustard exists, just like tomato sauce, on a horizontal plane. There is no good mustard or bad mustard. There is no perfect mustard or imperfect mustard. There are only different kinds of mustards that suit different kinds of people. He fundamentally democratized the way we think about taste. And for that, as well, we owe Howard Moskowitz a huge vote of thanks.Third thing that Howard did, and perhaps the most important, is Howard confronted the notion of the Platonic dish.(Laughter)What do I mean by that?(Laughter)For the longest time in the food industry, there was a sense that there was one way, a perfect way, to make a dish. You go to Chez Panisse, they give you the red-tail sashimi with roasted pumpkin seeds in a something something reduction. They don't give you five options on the reduction. They don't say, "Do you want the extra-chunky reduction, or ...?" No! You just get the reduction. Why? Because the chef at Chez Panisse has a Platonic notion about red-tail sashimi. "This is the way it ought to be." And she serves it that way time and time again, and if you quarrel with her, she will say, "You know what? You're wrong! This is the best way it ought to be in this restaurant."Now that same idea fueled the commercial food industry as well. They had a Platonic notion of what tomato sauce was. And where did that come from? It came from Italy. Italian tomato sauce is what? It's blended; it's thin. The culture of tomato sauce was thin. When we talked about "authentic tomato sauce" in the 1970s, we talked about Italian tomato sauce, we talked about the earliest Ragùs, which had no visible solids, right? Which were thin, you just put a little bit and it sunk down to the bottom of the pasta. That's what it was. And why were we attached to that? Because we thought that what it took to make people happy was to provide them with the most culturally authentic tomato sauce, A. And B, we thought that if we gave them the culturally authentic tomato sauce, then they would embrace it. And that's what would please the maximum number of people.In other words, people in the cooking world were looking for cooking universals. They were looking for one way to treat all of us. And it's good reason for them to be obsessed with the idea of universals, because all of science, through the 19th century and much of the 20th, was obsessed with universals. Psychologists, medical scientists, economists were all interested in finding out the rules that govern the way all of us behave. But that changed, right? What is the great revolution in science of the last 10, 15 years? It is the movement from the search for universals to the understanding of variability. Now in medical science, we don't want to know, necessarily, just how cancer works, we want to know how your cancer is different from my cancer. I guess my cancer different from your cancer. Genetics has opened the door to the study of human variability. What Howard Moskowitz was doing was saying, "This same revolution needs to happen in the world of tomato sauce." And for that, we owe him a great vote of thanks.I'll give you one last illustration of variability, and that is — oh, I'm sorry. Howard not only believed that, but he took it a second step, which was to say that when we pursue universal principles in food, we aren't just making an error; we are actually doing ourselves a massive disservice. And the example he used was coffee. And coffee is something he did a lot of work with, with Nescafé. If I were to ask all of you to try and come up with a brand of coffee — a type of coffee, a brew — that made all of you happy, and then I asked you to rate that coffee, the average score in this room for coffee would be about 60 on a scale of 0 to 100. If, however, you allowed me to break you into coffee clusters, maybe three or four coffee clusters, and I could make coffee just for each of those individual clusters, your scores would go from 60 to 75 or 78. The difference between coffee at 60 and coffee at 78 is a difference between coffee that makes you wince, and coffee that makes you deliriously happy.That is the final, and I think most beautiful lesson, of Howard Moskowitz: that in embracing the diversity of human beings, we will find a surer way to true happiness.Thank you.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:12.473 --> 00:00:14.934
I think I was supposed
to talk about my new book,

00:00:14.958 --> 00:00:16.837
which is called "Blink,"

00:00:16.861 --> 00:00:19.605
and it's about snap judgments
and first impressions.

00:00:19.958 --> 00:00:23.749
And it comes out in January,
and I hope you all buy it in triplicate.

00:00:23.773 --> 00:00:25.247
(Laughter)

00:00:25.271 --> 00:00:26.934
But I was thinking about this,

00:00:26.958 --> 00:00:31.168
and I realized that although
my new book makes me happy,

00:00:31.192 --> 00:00:33.828
and I think would make my mother happy,

00:00:33.852 --> 00:00:36.310
it's not really about happiness.

00:00:36.334 --> 00:00:39.934
So I decided instead,
I would talk about someone

00:00:39.958 --> 00:00:43.637
who I think has done as much
to make Americans happy

00:00:43.661 --> 00:00:46.934
as perhaps anyone over the last 20 years,

00:00:46.958 --> 00:00:49.934
a man who is a great
personal hero of mine:

00:00:49.958 --> 00:00:52.934
someone by the name of Howard Moskowitz,

00:00:52.958 --> 00:00:56.058
who is most famous
for reinventing spaghetti sauce.

00:00:57.281 --> 00:01:01.934
Howard's about this high, and he's round,

00:01:01.958 --> 00:01:07.047
and he's in his 60s,
and he has big huge glasses

00:01:07.071 --> 00:01:08.864
and thinning gray hair,

00:01:08.888 --> 00:01:12.712
and he has a kind of wonderful
exuberance and vitality,

00:01:12.736 --> 00:01:15.744
and he has a parrot,
and he loves the opera,

00:01:15.768 --> 00:01:19.859
and he's a great aficionado
of medieval history.

00:01:20.161 --> 00:01:22.765
And by profession, he's a psychophysicist.

00:01:22.789 --> 00:01:27.426
Now, I should tell you that I have no idea
what psychophysics is,

00:01:27.450 --> 00:01:29.140
although at some point in my life,

00:01:29.164 --> 00:01:30.610
I dated a girl for two years

00:01:30.634 --> 00:01:32.874
who was getting
her doctorate in psychophysics.

00:01:32.898 --> 00:01:36.442
Which should tell you something
about that relationship.

00:01:36.466 --> 00:01:38.763
(Laughter)

00:01:38.787 --> 00:01:41.934
As far as I know, psychophysics
is about measuring things.

00:01:41.958 --> 00:01:44.589
And Howard is very interested
in measuring things.

00:01:44.613 --> 00:01:46.986
And he graduated
with his doctorate from Harvard,

00:01:47.010 --> 00:01:50.258
and he set up a little consulting shop
in White Plains, New York.

00:01:51.013 --> 00:01:53.371
And one of his first clients was Pepsi.

00:01:53.395 --> 00:01:56.473
This is many years ago,
back in the early 70s.

00:01:57.402 --> 00:01:59.314
And Pepsi came to Howard and they said,

00:01:59.338 --> 00:02:01.736
"You know, there's this new
thing called aspartame,

00:02:01.760 --> 00:02:03.644
and we would like to make Diet Pepsi.

00:02:03.668 --> 00:02:05.645
We'd like you to figure out

00:02:05.669 --> 00:02:09.175
how much aspartame we should put
in each can of Diet Pepsi

00:02:09.199 --> 00:02:10.956
in order to have the perfect drink."

00:02:11.679 --> 00:02:15.934
Now that sounds like an incredibly
straightforward question to answer,

00:02:15.958 --> 00:02:17.435
and that's what Howard thought.

00:02:17.459 --> 00:02:18.760
Because Pepsi told him,

00:02:18.784 --> 00:02:21.467
"We're working with a band
between eight and 12 percent.

00:02:21.491 --> 00:02:24.410
Anything below eight percent
sweetness is not sweet enough;

00:02:24.434 --> 00:02:27.673
anything above 12 percent
sweetness is too sweet.

00:02:27.697 --> 00:02:30.780
We want to know: what's the sweet
spot between 8 and 12?"

00:02:31.330 --> 00:02:35.291
Now, if I gave you this problem to do,
you would all say, it's very simple.

00:02:35.315 --> 00:02:38.934
What we do is you make up
a big experimental batch of Pepsi,

00:02:38.958 --> 00:02:43.444
at every degree of sweetness --
eight percent, 8.1, 8.2, 8.3,

00:02:43.468 --> 00:02:44.749
all the way up to 12 --

00:02:44.773 --> 00:02:47.262
and we try this out
with thousands of people,

00:02:47.286 --> 00:02:49.492
and we plot the results on a curve,

00:02:49.516 --> 00:02:52.497
and we take the most popular
concentration, right?

00:02:52.521 --> 00:02:53.776
Really simple.

00:02:53.800 --> 00:02:56.340
Howard does the experiment,
and he gets the data back,

00:02:56.364 --> 00:02:57.705
and he plots it on a curve,

00:02:57.729 --> 00:03:00.593
and all of a sudden he realizes
it's not a nice bell curve.

00:03:00.617 --> 00:03:02.571
In fact, the data doesn't make any sense.

00:03:02.595 --> 00:03:04.377
It's a mess. It's all over the place.

00:03:04.958 --> 00:03:09.571
Now, most people in that business,
in the world of testing food and such,

00:03:09.595 --> 00:03:12.412
are not dismayed
when the data comes back a mess.

00:03:12.436 --> 00:03:13.928
They think, "Well, you know,

00:03:13.952 --> 00:03:16.786
figuring out what people think
about cola's not that easy."

00:03:16.810 --> 00:03:19.635
"You know, maybe we made an error
somewhere along the way."

00:03:19.659 --> 00:03:21.856
"You know, let's just
make an educated guess,"

00:03:21.880 --> 00:03:24.265
and they simply point
and they go for 10 percent,

00:03:24.289 --> 00:03:25.364
right in the middle.

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:27.934
Howard is not so easily placated.

00:03:27.958 --> 00:03:30.870
Howard is a man of a certain degree
of intellectual standards.

00:03:30.894 --> 00:03:32.934
And this was not good enough for him,

00:03:32.958 --> 00:03:35.240
and this question bedeviled him for years.

00:03:35.264 --> 00:03:37.934
And he would think it through
and say, "What was wrong?

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:41.643
Why could we not make sense
of this experiment with Diet Pepsi?"

00:03:42.318 --> 00:03:44.934
And one day, he was sitting
in a diner in White Plains,

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:47.934
about to go trying to dream up
some work for Nescafé.

00:03:48.294 --> 00:03:51.778
And suddenly, like a bolt of lightning,
the answer came to him.

00:03:52.111 --> 00:03:54.785
And that is, that when they analyzed
the Diet Pepsi data,

00:03:54.809 --> 00:03:56.531
they were asking the wrong question.

00:03:56.555 --> 00:03:58.685
They were looking for the perfect Pepsi,

00:03:58.709 --> 00:04:01.672
and they should have been
looking for the perfect Pepsis.

00:04:02.772 --> 00:04:03.783
Trust me.

00:04:03.807 --> 00:04:05.934
This was an enormous revelation.

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:09.633
This was one of the most brilliant
breakthroughs in all of food science.

00:04:09.657 --> 00:04:11.375
Howard immediately went on the road,

00:04:11.399 --> 00:04:13.757
and he would go to conferences
around the country,

00:04:13.781 --> 00:04:15.339
and he would stand up and say,

00:04:15.363 --> 00:04:17.426
"You had been looking
for the perfect Pepsi.

00:04:17.450 --> 00:04:18.680
You're wrong.

00:04:18.704 --> 00:04:21.212
You should be looking
for the perfect Pepsis."

00:04:21.815 --> 00:04:24.251
And people would look at him
blankly and say,

00:04:24.275 --> 00:04:26.338
"What are you talking about? Craziness."

00:04:26.362 --> 00:04:27.934
And they would say, "Move! Next!"

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:30.172
Tried to get business,
nobody would hire him --

00:04:30.196 --> 00:04:31.580
he was obsessed, though,

00:04:31.604 --> 00:04:33.611
and he talked about it
and talked about it.

00:04:33.635 --> 00:04:35.428
Howard loves the Yiddish expression

00:04:35.452 --> 00:04:37.934
"To a worm in horseradish,
the world is horseradish."

00:04:38.499 --> 00:04:40.099
This was his horseradish.

00:04:40.123 --> 00:04:41.785
(Laughter)

00:04:41.809 --> 00:04:43.248
He was obsessed with it!

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:46.769
And finally, he had a breakthrough.

00:04:46.793 --> 00:04:48.934
Vlasic Pickles came to him,

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:53.607
and they said, "Doctor Moskowitz,
we want to make the perfect pickle."

00:04:53.631 --> 00:04:54.655
And he said,

00:04:54.679 --> 00:04:57.608
"There is no perfect pickle;
there are only perfect pickles."

00:04:58.289 --> 00:05:00.059
And he came back to them and he said,

00:05:00.083 --> 00:05:02.293
"You don't just need
to improve your regular;

00:05:02.317 --> 00:05:03.810
you need to create zesty."

00:05:03.834 --> 00:05:05.659
And that's where we got zesty pickles.

00:05:06.474 --> 00:05:08.934
Then the next person came to him:
Campbell's Soup.

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:10.958
And this was even more important.

00:05:10.982 --> 00:05:14.028
In fact, Campbell's Soup
is where Howard made his reputation.

00:05:14.378 --> 00:05:15.771
Campbell's made Prego,

00:05:15.795 --> 00:05:19.663
and Prego, in the early 80s,
was struggling next to Ragù,

00:05:19.687 --> 00:05:23.052
which was the dominant
spaghetti sauce of the 70s and 80s.

00:05:23.504 --> 00:05:26.347
In the industry -- I don't
know whether you care about this,

00:05:26.371 --> 00:05:28.371
or how much time I have to go into this.

00:05:28.395 --> 00:05:31.025
But it was, technically speaking
-- this is an aside --

00:05:31.049 --> 00:05:33.109
Prego is a better tomato sauce than Ragù.

00:05:33.133 --> 00:05:35.414
The quality of the tomato paste
is much better;

00:05:35.438 --> 00:05:37.258
the spice mix is far superior;

00:05:37.282 --> 00:05:39.768
it adheres to the pasta
in a much more pleasing way.

00:05:39.792 --> 00:05:41.869
In fact, they would do
the famous bowl test

00:05:41.893 --> 00:05:44.538
back in the 70s with Ragù and Prego.

00:05:44.562 --> 00:05:48.054
You'd have a plate of spaghetti,
and you would pour it on, right?

00:05:48.418 --> 00:05:53.063
And the Ragù would all go to the bottom,
and the Prego would sit on top.

00:05:53.087 --> 00:05:54.618
That's called "adherence."

00:05:54.642 --> 00:05:59.182
And, anyway, despite the fact
that they were far superior in adherence,

00:05:59.206 --> 00:06:01.977
and the quality of their tomato paste,

00:06:02.001 --> 00:06:03.370
Prego was struggling.

00:06:03.394 --> 00:06:06.396
So they came to Howard,
and they said, fix us.

00:06:06.769 --> 00:06:09.268
And Howard looked
at their product line, and he said,

00:06:09.292 --> 00:06:12.395
what you have is a dead tomato society.

00:06:13.141 --> 00:06:15.323
So he said, this is what I want to do.

00:06:15.347 --> 00:06:17.903
And he got together
with the Campbell's soup kitchen,

00:06:17.927 --> 00:06:21.388
and he made 45 varieties
of spaghetti sauce.

00:06:21.412 --> 00:06:24.265
And he varied them according
to every conceivable way

00:06:24.289 --> 00:06:25.934
that you can vary tomato sauce:

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:27.816
by sweetness, by level of garlic,

00:06:27.840 --> 00:06:31.055
by tomatoey-ness,
by tartness, by sourness,

00:06:31.079 --> 00:06:32.419
by visible solids --

00:06:32.443 --> 00:06:35.704
my favorite term
in the spaghetti sauce business.

00:06:35.728 --> 00:06:36.729
(Laughter)

00:06:36.753 --> 00:06:40.291
Every conceivable way
you can vary spaghetti sauce,

00:06:40.315 --> 00:06:42.094
he varied spaghetti sauce.

00:06:42.118 --> 00:06:45.851
And then he took this whole raft
of 45 spaghetti sauces,

00:06:45.875 --> 00:06:47.032
and he went on the road.

00:06:47.056 --> 00:06:48.935
He went to New York, to Chicago,

00:06:48.959 --> 00:06:50.888
he went to Jacksonville, to Los Angeles.

00:06:50.912 --> 00:06:54.674
And he brought in people
by the truckload into big halls.

00:06:54.698 --> 00:06:56.423
And he sat them down for two hours,

00:06:56.447 --> 00:06:59.774
and over the course of that two hours,
he gave them ten bowls.

00:06:59.798 --> 00:07:01.056
Ten small bowls of pasta,

00:07:01.080 --> 00:07:03.538
with a different spaghetti
sauce on each one.

00:07:04.143 --> 00:07:08.289
And after they ate each bowl,
they had to rate, from 0 to 100,

00:07:08.313 --> 00:07:10.934
how good they thought
the spaghetti sauce was.

00:07:11.448 --> 00:07:14.519
At the end of that process,
after doing it for months and months,

00:07:14.543 --> 00:07:16.086
he had a mountain of data

00:07:16.110 --> 00:07:19.934
about how the American people
feel about spaghetti sauce.

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:21.425
And then he analyzed the data.

00:07:21.449 --> 00:07:25.426
Did he look for the most popular
variety of spaghetti sauce?

00:07:25.450 --> 00:07:28.204
No! Howard doesn't believe
that there is such a thing.

00:07:28.228 --> 00:07:30.291
Instead, he looked
at the data, and he said,

00:07:30.315 --> 00:07:35.934
let's see if we can group all these
different data points into clusters.

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:38.410
Let's see if they congregate
around certain ideas.

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:41.163
And sure enough, if you sit down,

00:07:41.187 --> 00:07:44.752
and you analyze all this data
on spaghetti sauce,

00:07:44.776 --> 00:07:47.886
you realize that all Americans
fall into one of three groups.

00:07:48.298 --> 00:07:51.211
There are people
who like their spaghetti sauce plain;

00:07:51.235 --> 00:07:53.934
there are people
who like their spaghetti sauce spicy;

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:56.202
and there are people
who like it extra chunky.

00:07:56.887 --> 00:08:00.934
And of those three facts,
the third one was the most significant,

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:03.612
because at the time, in the early 1980s,

00:08:03.636 --> 00:08:05.136
if you went to a supermarket,

00:08:05.160 --> 00:08:08.475
you would not find
extra-chunky spaghetti sauce.

00:08:08.945 --> 00:08:10.958
And Prego turned to Howard, and they said,

00:08:10.982 --> 00:08:13.679
"You're telling me
that one third of Americans

00:08:13.703 --> 00:08:16.934
crave extra-chunky spaghetti sauce

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:19.457
and yet no one is servicing their needs?"

00:08:19.481 --> 00:08:20.505
And he said "Yes!"

00:08:20.529 --> 00:08:21.821
(Laughter)

00:08:21.845 --> 00:08:23.187
And Prego then went back,

00:08:23.211 --> 00:08:25.583
and completely reformulated
their spaghetti sauce,

00:08:25.607 --> 00:08:29.261
and came out with a line of extra chunky
that immediately and completely

00:08:29.285 --> 00:08:32.269
took over the spaghetti sauce
business in this country.

00:08:32.293 --> 00:08:36.696
And over the next 10 years,
they made 600 million dollars

00:08:36.720 --> 00:08:39.117
off their line of extra-chunky sauces.

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:43.448
Everyone else in the industry looked
at what Howard had done, and they said,

00:08:43.472 --> 00:08:45.879
"Oh my god! We've been
thinking all wrong!"

00:08:45.903 --> 00:08:49.173
And that's when you started to get
seven different kinds of vinegar,

00:08:49.197 --> 00:08:54.663
and 14 different kinds of mustard,
and 71 different kinds of olive oil.

00:08:54.687 --> 00:08:57.934
And then eventually
even Ragù hired Howard,

00:08:57.958 --> 00:09:01.149
and Howard did the exact same thing
for Ragù that he did for Prego.

00:09:01.173 --> 00:09:03.524
And today, if you go
to a really good supermarket,

00:09:03.548 --> 00:09:05.691
do you know how many Ragùs there are?

00:09:05.715 --> 00:09:06.715
36!

00:09:07.925 --> 00:09:09.495
In six varieties:

00:09:09.519 --> 00:09:12.569
Cheese, Light,

00:09:12.593 --> 00:09:15.695
Robusto, Rich & Hearty,

00:09:15.719 --> 00:09:17.029
Old World Traditional --

00:09:19.441 --> 00:09:21.158
Extra-Chunky Garden.

00:09:21.182 --> 00:09:22.934
(Laughter)

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:24.702
That's Howard's doing.

00:09:24.726 --> 00:09:26.934
That is Howard's gift
to the American people.

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:28.639
Now why is that important?

00:09:28.663 --> 00:09:30.934
(Laughter)

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:33.039
It is, in fact, enormously important.

00:09:33.063 --> 00:09:34.433
I'll explain to you why.

00:09:34.457 --> 00:09:38.578
What Howard did is he fundamentally
changed the way the food industry thinks

00:09:38.602 --> 00:09:40.023
about making you happy.

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:43.934
Assumption number one
in the food industry used to be

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:46.658
that the way to find out
what people want to eat,

00:09:46.682 --> 00:09:49.019
what will make people happy,
is to ask them.

00:09:49.586 --> 00:09:51.244
And for years and years and years,

00:09:51.268 --> 00:09:53.506
Ragù and Prego would have focus groups,

00:09:53.530 --> 00:09:55.990
and they would sit you down,
and they would say,

00:09:56.014 --> 00:09:57.887
"What do you want in a spaghetti sauce?

00:09:57.911 --> 00:09:59.986
Tell us what you want
in a spaghetti sauce."

00:10:00.010 --> 00:10:02.934
And for all those years -- 20, 30 years --

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:04.934
through all those focus group sessions,

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:07.979
no one ever said they wanted extra-chunky.

00:10:08.712 --> 00:10:12.163
Even though at least a third of them,
deep in their hearts, actually did.

00:10:12.187 --> 00:10:13.980
(Laughter)

00:10:14.654 --> 00:10:16.666
People don't know what they want!

00:10:16.690 --> 00:10:18.136
As Howard loves to say,

00:10:18.160 --> 00:10:20.912
"The mind knows not
what the tongue wants."

00:10:20.936 --> 00:10:22.088
It's a mystery!

00:10:22.112 --> 00:10:23.116
(Laughter)

00:10:23.140 --> 00:10:25.546
And a critically important step

00:10:25.570 --> 00:10:28.901
in understanding
our own desires and tastes

00:10:28.925 --> 00:10:32.557
is to realize that we cannot always
explain what we want, deep down.

00:10:33.200 --> 00:10:37.236
If I asked all of you, for example,
in this room, what you want in a coffee,

00:10:37.260 --> 00:10:38.588
you know what you'd say?

00:10:38.612 --> 00:10:42.851
Every one of you would say,
"I want a dark, rich, hearty roast."

00:10:43.513 --> 00:10:45.671
It's what people always say
when you ask them.

00:10:45.695 --> 00:10:48.227
"What do you like?"
"Dark, rich, hearty roast!"

00:10:48.251 --> 00:10:51.764
What percentage of you actually
like a dark, rich, hearty roast?

00:10:51.788 --> 00:10:54.836
According to Howard, somewhere
between 25 and 27 percent of you.

00:10:55.525 --> 00:10:57.720
Most of you like milky, weak coffee.

00:10:57.744 --> 00:10:58.745
(Laughter)

00:10:58.769 --> 00:11:02.101
But you will never, ever say
to someone who asks you what you want

00:11:02.125 --> 00:11:04.316
that "I want a milky, weak coffee."

00:11:04.340 --> 00:11:07.239
So that's number one thing
that Howard did.

00:11:08.486 --> 00:11:11.934
Number two thing that Howard did
is he made us realize --

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:13.934
it's another very critical point --

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:16.132
he made us realize the importance

00:11:16.156 --> 00:11:19.155
of what he likes to call
"horizontal segmentation."

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:20.973
Why is this critical?

00:11:20.997 --> 00:11:24.695
Because this is the way the food industry
thought before Howard.

00:11:24.719 --> 00:11:27.029
What were they obsessed with
in the early 80s?

00:11:27.053 --> 00:11:28.593
They were obsessed with mustard.

00:11:28.617 --> 00:11:31.934
In particular, they were obsessed
with the story of Grey Poupon.

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:35.159
Used to be, there were two mustards:
French's and Gulden's.

00:11:35.183 --> 00:11:36.676
What were they? Yellow mustard.

00:11:36.700 --> 00:11:37.715
What's in it?

00:11:37.739 --> 00:11:39.793
Yellow mustard seeds,
turmeric, and paprika.

00:11:39.817 --> 00:11:40.891
That was mustard.

00:11:40.915 --> 00:11:43.440
Grey Poupon came along, with a Dijon.

00:11:43.464 --> 00:11:44.652
Right?

00:11:44.676 --> 00:11:50.339
Much more volatile brown mustard seed,
some white wine, a nose hit,

00:11:50.363 --> 00:11:52.301
much more delicate aromatics.

00:11:52.325 --> 00:11:53.340
And what do they do?

00:11:53.364 --> 00:11:58.163
They put it in a little tiny glass jar,
with a wonderful enameled label on it,

00:11:58.187 --> 00:11:59.261
made it look French,

00:11:59.285 --> 00:12:01.386
even though it's made
in Oxnard, California.

00:12:01.410 --> 00:12:02.411
(Laughter)

00:12:02.435 --> 00:12:06.934
And instead of charging a dollar fifty
for the eight-ounce bottle,

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:08.931
the way that French's and Gulden's did,

00:12:08.955 --> 00:12:10.682
they decided to charge four dollars.

00:12:10.706 --> 00:12:11.918
And they had those ads.

00:12:11.942 --> 00:12:14.577
With the guy in the Rolls Royce,
eating the Grey Poupon.

00:12:14.601 --> 00:12:17.387
Another pulls up, and says,
"Do you have any Grey Poupon?"

00:12:17.411 --> 00:12:20.595
And the whole thing, after they did that,
Grey Poupon takes off!

00:12:20.619 --> 00:12:22.143
Takes over the mustard business!

00:12:22.167 --> 00:12:24.175
And everyone's take-home lesson from that

00:12:24.199 --> 00:12:28.934
was that the way to make people happy

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:32.352
is to give them something
that is more expensive,

00:12:32.376 --> 00:12:34.443
something to aspire to.

00:12:34.467 --> 00:12:38.610
It's to make them turn their back
on what they think they like now,

00:12:38.634 --> 00:12:42.053
and reach out for something
higher up the mustard hierarchy.

00:12:42.077 --> 00:12:43.078
(Laughter)

00:12:43.102 --> 00:12:45.314
A better mustard!
A more expensive mustard!

00:12:45.338 --> 00:12:48.501
A mustard of more sophistication
and culture and meaning.

00:12:48.525 --> 00:12:50.934
And Howard looked to that
and said, "That's wrong!"

00:12:51.597 --> 00:12:53.715
Mustard does not exist on a hierarchy.

00:12:54.176 --> 00:12:58.277
Mustard exists, just like tomato sauce,
on a horizontal plane.

00:12:58.737 --> 00:13:01.476
There is no good mustard or bad mustard.

00:13:01.500 --> 00:13:04.026
There is no perfect mustard
or imperfect mustard.

00:13:04.050 --> 00:13:07.795
There are only different kinds of mustards
that suit different kinds of people.

00:13:08.316 --> 00:13:13.151
He fundamentally democratized
the way we think about taste.

00:13:13.175 --> 00:13:17.394
And for that, as well, we owe
Howard Moskowitz a huge vote of thanks.

00:13:18.159 --> 00:13:21.652
Third thing that Howard did,
and perhaps the most important,

00:13:21.676 --> 00:13:24.515
is Howard confronted the notion
of the Platonic dish.

00:13:24.539 --> 00:13:25.540
(Laughter)

00:13:25.564 --> 00:13:26.706
What do I mean by that?

00:13:26.730 --> 00:13:28.286
(Laughter)

00:13:28.310 --> 00:13:30.410
For the longest time in the food industry,

00:13:30.434 --> 00:13:33.014
there was a sense that there was one way,

00:13:33.038 --> 00:13:35.766
a perfect way, to make a dish.

00:13:36.528 --> 00:13:38.243
You go to Chez Panisse,

00:13:38.267 --> 00:13:43.550
they give you the red-tail sashimi
with roasted pumpkin seeds

00:13:43.574 --> 00:13:45.427
in a something something reduction.

00:13:45.451 --> 00:13:47.934
They don't give you five options
on the reduction.

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:51.552
They don't say, "Do you want
the extra-chunky reduction, or ...?"

00:13:51.576 --> 00:13:52.584
No!

00:13:52.608 --> 00:13:54.155
You just get the reduction. Why?

00:13:54.179 --> 00:13:55.741
Because the chef at Chez Panisse

00:13:55.765 --> 00:13:58.353
has a Platonic notion
about red-tail sashimi.

00:13:58.377 --> 00:14:00.259
"This is the way it ought to be."

00:14:00.878 --> 00:14:04.934
And she serves it that way
time and time again,

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:07.220
and if you quarrel with her, she will say,

00:14:07.244 --> 00:14:08.846
"You know what? You're wrong!

00:14:09.426 --> 00:14:12.146
This is the best way it ought to be
in this restaurant."

00:14:12.170 --> 00:14:15.609
Now that same idea fueled
the commercial food industry as well.

00:14:16.252 --> 00:14:19.469
They had a Platonic notion
of what tomato sauce was.

00:14:19.493 --> 00:14:21.934
And where did that come from?
It came from Italy.

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:23.977
Italian tomato sauce is what?

00:14:24.333 --> 00:14:25.933
It's blended; it's thin.

00:14:26.489 --> 00:14:28.798
The culture of tomato sauce was thin.

00:14:28.822 --> 00:14:31.799
When we talked about "authentic
tomato sauce" in the 1970s,

00:14:31.823 --> 00:14:33.632
we talked about Italian tomato sauce,

00:14:33.656 --> 00:14:35.435
we talked about the earliest Ragùs,

00:14:35.459 --> 00:14:37.611
which had no visible solids, right?

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:40.075
Which were thin, you just put a little bit

00:14:40.099 --> 00:14:42.147
and it sunk down to the bottom
of the pasta.

00:14:42.171 --> 00:14:43.363
That's what it was.

00:14:43.387 --> 00:14:45.048
And why were we attached to that?

00:14:45.072 --> 00:14:47.810
Because we thought
that what it took to make people happy

00:14:47.834 --> 00:14:52.428
was to provide them with the most
culturally authentic tomato sauce, A.

00:14:52.452 --> 00:14:57.536
And B, we thought that if we gave them
the culturally authentic tomato sauce,

00:14:57.560 --> 00:14:58.988
then they would embrace it.

00:14:59.012 --> 00:15:01.746
And that's what would please
the maximum number of people.

00:15:02.246 --> 00:15:04.532
In other words,

00:15:04.556 --> 00:15:07.955
people in the cooking world
were looking for cooking universals.

00:15:08.294 --> 00:15:10.732
They were looking for one way
to treat all of us.

00:15:10.756 --> 00:15:13.336
And it's good reason for them
to be obsessed

00:15:13.360 --> 00:15:14.742
with the idea of universals,

00:15:14.766 --> 00:15:16.163
because all of science,

00:15:16.187 --> 00:15:18.436
through the 19th century
and much of the 20th,

00:15:18.460 --> 00:15:20.129
was obsessed with universals.

00:15:20.153 --> 00:15:24.141
Psychologists, medical scientists,
economists

00:15:24.165 --> 00:15:26.253
were all interested
in finding out the rules

00:15:26.277 --> 00:15:28.467
that govern the way all of us behave.

00:15:29.217 --> 00:15:30.615
But that changed, right?

00:15:30.639 --> 00:15:34.250
What is the great revolution
in science of the last 10, 15 years?

00:15:34.274 --> 00:15:37.789
It is the movement
from the search for universals

00:15:37.813 --> 00:15:39.662
to the understanding of variability.

00:15:40.297 --> 00:15:43.934
Now in medical science,
we don't want to know, necessarily,

00:15:43.958 --> 00:15:45.659
just how cancer works,

00:15:45.683 --> 00:15:48.934
we want to know how your cancer
is different from my cancer.

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:51.705
I guess my cancer different
from your cancer.

00:15:51.729 --> 00:15:55.817
Genetics has opened the door
to the study of human variability.

00:15:55.841 --> 00:15:57.936
What Howard Moskowitz
was doing was saying,

00:15:57.960 --> 00:16:02.071
"This same revolution needs to happen
in the world of tomato sauce."

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:05.530
And for that, we owe him
a great vote of thanks.

00:16:07.159 --> 00:16:10.001
I'll give you one last
illustration of variability,

00:16:10.025 --> 00:16:11.866
and that is -- oh, I'm sorry.

00:16:11.890 --> 00:16:15.378
Howard not only believed that,
but he took it a second step,

00:16:15.402 --> 00:16:20.554
which was to say that when we pursue
universal principles in food,

00:16:20.578 --> 00:16:22.198
we aren't just making an error;

00:16:22.222 --> 00:16:25.570
we are actually doing ourselves
a massive disservice.

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:27.768
And the example he used was coffee.

00:16:28.181 --> 00:16:32.226
And coffee is something he did
a lot of work with, with Nescafé.

00:16:32.704 --> 00:16:36.202
If I were to ask all of you to try
and come up with a brand of coffee --

00:16:36.226 --> 00:16:39.248
a type of coffee, a brew --
that made all of you happy,

00:16:39.272 --> 00:16:41.225
and then I asked you to rate that coffee,

00:16:41.249 --> 00:16:45.306
the average score in this room for coffee
would be about 60 on a scale of 0 to 100.

00:16:45.783 --> 00:16:49.406
If, however, you allowed me
to break you into coffee clusters,

00:16:49.430 --> 00:16:51.215
maybe three or four coffee clusters,

00:16:51.239 --> 00:16:55.934
and I could make coffee just
for each of those individual clusters,

00:16:55.958 --> 00:16:59.513
your scores would go from 60 to 75 or 78.

00:16:59.958 --> 00:17:05.195
The difference between coffee
at 60 and coffee at 78

00:17:05.219 --> 00:17:07.934
is a difference between coffee
that makes you wince,

00:17:07.958 --> 00:17:10.962
and coffee that makes you
deliriously happy.

00:17:11.648 --> 00:17:14.842
That is the final, and I think
most beautiful lesson,

00:17:14.866 --> 00:17:16.201
of Howard Moskowitz:

00:17:16.225 --> 00:17:19.934
that in embracing the diversity
of human beings,

00:17:19.958 --> 00:17:22.323
we will find a surer way
to true happiness.

00:17:22.727 --> 00:17:23.744
Thank you.

00:17:23.768 --> 00:17:24.934
(Applause)

title: The surprising science of happiness
transcript: When you have 21 minutes to speak, two million years seems like a really long time. But evolutionarily, two million years is nothing. And yet in two million years, the human brain has nearly tripled in mass, going from the one-and-a-quarter pound brain of our ancestor here, Habilis, to the almost three-pound meatloaf that everybody here has between their ears. What is it about a big brain that nature was so eager for every one of us to have one?Well, it turns out when brains triple in size, they don't just get three times bigger; they gain new structures. And one of the main reasons our brain got so big is because it got a new part, called the "frontal lobe." Particularly, a part called the "pre-frontal cortex." What does a pre-frontal cortex do for you that should justify the entire architectural overhaul of the human skull in the blink of evolutionary time?It turns out the pre-frontal cortex does lots of things, but one of the most important things it does is an experience simulator. Pilots practice in flight simulators so that they don't make real mistakes in planes. Human beings have this marvelous adaptation that they can actually have experiences in their heads before they try them out in real life. This is a trick that none of our ancestors could do, and that no other animal can do quite like we can. It's a marvelous adaptation. It's up there with opposable thumbs and standing upright and language as one of the things that got our species out of the trees and into the shopping mall.(Laughter)All of you have done this. Ben and Jerry's doesn't have liver-and-onion ice cream, and it's not because they whipped some up, tried it and went, "Yuck." It's because, without leaving your armchair, you can simulate that flavor and say "yuck" before you make it.Let's see how your experience simulators are working. Let's just run a quick diagnostic before I proceed with the rest of the talk. Here's two different futures that I invite you to contemplate. You can try to simulate them and tell me which one you think you might prefer. One of them is winning the lottery. This is about 314 million dollars. And the other is becoming paraplegic.(Laughter)Just give it a moment of thought. You probably don't feel like you need a moment of thought.Interestingly, there are data on these two groups of people, data on how happy they are. And this is exactly what you expected, isn't it? But these aren't the data. I made these up!These are the data. You failed the pop quiz, and you're hardly five minutes into the lecture. Because the fact is that a year after losing the use of their legs, and a year after winning the lotto, lottery winners and paraplegics are equally happy with their lives.Don't feel too bad about failing the first pop quiz, because everybody fails all of the pop quizzes all of the time. The research that my laboratory has been doing, that economists and psychologists around the country have been doing, has revealed something really quite startling to us, something we call the "impact bias," which is the tendency for the simulator to work badly. For the simulator to make you believe that different outcomes are more different than in fact they really are.From field studies to laboratory studies, we see that winning or losing an election, gaining or losing a romantic partner, getting or not getting a promotion, passing or not passing a college test, on and on, have far less impact, less intensity and much less duration than people expect them to have. This almost floors me — a recent study showing how major life traumas affect people suggests that if it happened over three months ago, with only a few exceptions, it has no impact whatsoever on your happiness.Why? Because happiness can be synthesized. Sir Thomas Brown wrote in 1642, "I am the happiest man alive. I have that in me that can convert poverty to riches, adversity to prosperity. I am more invulnerable than Achilles; fortune hath not one place to hit me." What kind of remarkable machinery does this guy have in his head?Well, it turns out it's precisely the same remarkable machinery that all off us have. Human beings have something that we might think of as a "psychological immune system." A system of cognitive processes, largely non-conscious cognitive processes, that help them change their views of the world, so that they can feel better about the worlds in which they find themselves. Like Sir Thomas, you have this machine. Unlike Sir Thomas, you seem not to know it.We synthesize happiness, but we think happiness is a thing to be found. Now, you don't need me to give you too many examples of people synthesizing happiness, I suspect. Though I'm going to show you some experimental evidence, you don't have to look very far for evidence. I took a copy of the New York Times and tried to find some instances of people synthesizing happiness. Here are three guys synthesizing happiness. "I'm better off physically, financially, mentally ... "I don't have one minute's regret. It was a glorious experience." "I believe it turned out for the best."Who are these characters who are so damn happy? The first one is Jim Wright. Some of you are old enough to remember: he was the chairman of the House of Representatives and he resigned in disgrace when this young Republican named Newt Gingrich found out about a shady book deal he had done. He lost everything. The most powerful Democrat in the country lost everything. He lost his money, he lost his power. What does he have to say all these years later? "I am so much better off physically, financially, mentally and in almost every other way." What other way would there be to be better off? Vegetably? Minerally? Animally? He's pretty much covered them there.Moreese Bickham is somebody you've never heard of. Moreese Bickham uttered these words upon being released. He was 78 years old. He'd spent 37 years in a Louisiana State Penitentiary for a crime he didn't commit. [He was ultimately released for good behavior halfway through his sentence.] What did he say about his experience? "I don't have one minute's regret. It was a glorious experience." Glorious! He is not saying, "Well, there were some nice guys. They had a gym." "Glorious," a word we usually reserve for something like a religious experience.Harry S. Langerman uttered these words, and he's somebody you might have known but didn't, because in 1949 he read a little article in the paper about a hamburger stand owned by two brothers named McDonalds. And he thought, "That's a really neat idea!" So he went to find them. They said, "We can give you a franchise on this for 3,000 bucks." Harry went back to New York, asked his brother, an investment banker, to loan him the $3,000, and his brother's immortal words were, "You idiot, nobody eats hamburgers." He wouldn't lend him the money, and of course, six months later Ray Kroc had exactly the same idea. It turns out people do eat hamburgers, and Ray Kroc, for a while, became the richest man in America.And then, finally, some of you recognize this young photo of Pete Best, who was the original drummer for the Beatles, until they, you know, sent him out on an errand and snuck away and picked up Ringo on a tour. Well, in 1994, when Pete Best was interviewed — yes, he's still a drummer; yes, he's a studio musician — he had this to say: "I'm happier than I would have been with the Beatles."Okay. There's something important to be learned from these people, and it is the secret of happiness. Here it is, finally to be revealed. First: accrue wealth, power, and prestige, then lose it.(Laughter)Second: spend as much of your life in prison as you possibly can.(Laughter)Third: make somebody else really, really rich. And finally: never ever join the Beatles.(Laughter) Yeah, right. Because when people synthesize happiness, as these gentlemen seem to have done, we all smile at them, but we kind of roll our eyes and say, "Yeah right, you never really wanted the job." "Oh yeah, right. You really didn't have that much in common with her, and you figured that out just about the time she threw the engagement ring in your face." We smirk because we believe that synthetic happiness is not of the same quality as what we might call "natural happiness."What are these terms? Natural happiness is what we get when we get what we wanted, and synthetic happiness is what we make when we don't get what we wanted. And in our society, we have a strong belief that synthetic happiness is of an inferior kind.Why do we have that belief? Well, it's very simple. What kind of economic engine would keep churning if we believed that not getting what we want could make us just as happy as getting it? With all apologies to my friend Matthieu Ricard, a shopping mall full of Zen monks is not going to be particularly profitable, because they don't want stuff enough.(Laughter)I want to suggest to you that synthetic happiness is every bit as real and enduring as the kind of happiness you stumble upon when you get exactly what you were aiming for. I'm a scientist, so I'm going to do this not with rhetoric, but by marinating you in a little bit of data.Let me first show you an experimental paradigm that is used to demonstrate the synthesis of happiness among regular old folks. And this isn't mine. It's a 50-year-old paradigm called the "free choice paradigm." It's very simple. You bring in, say, six objects, and you ask a subject to rank them from the most to the least liked. In this case, because this experiment uses them, these are Monet prints. So, everybody can rank these Monet prints from the one they like the most, to the one they like the least. Now we give you a choice: "We happen to have some extra prints in the closet. We're going to give you one as your prize to take home. We happen to have number three and number four," we tell the subject. This is a bit of a difficult choice, because neither one is preferred strongly to the other, but naturally, people tend to pick number three because they liked it a little better than number four.Sometime later — it could be 15 minutes; it could be 15 days — the same stimuli are put before the subject, and the subject is asked to re-rank the stimuli. "Tell us how much you like them now." What happens? Watch as happiness is synthesized. This is the result that has been replicated over and over again. You're watching happiness be synthesized. Would you like to see it again? Happiness! "The one I got is really better than I thought! That other one I didn't get sucks!" That's the synthesis of happiness.(Laughter)Now, what's the right response to that? "Yeah, right!" Now, here's the experiment we did, and I hope this is going to convince you that "Yeah, right!" was not the right response.We did this experiment with a group of patients who had anterograde amnesia. These are hospitalized patients. Most of them have Korsakoff's syndrome, a polyneuritic psychosis. They drank way too much, and they can't make new memories. OK? They remember their childhood, but if you walk in and introduce yourself, and then leave the room, when you come back, they don't know who you are.We took our Monet prints to the hospital. And we asked these patients to rank them from the one they liked the most to the one they liked the least. We then gave them the choice between number three and number four. Like everybody else, they said, "Gee, thanks Doc! That's great! I could use a new print. I'll take number three." We explained we would have number three mailed to them. We gathered up our materials and we went out of the room, and counted to a half hour.(Laughter)Back into the room, we say, "Hi, we're back." The patients, bless them, say, "Ah, Doc, I'm sorry, I've got a memory problem; that's why I'm here. If I've met you before, I don't remember." "Really, you don't remember? I was just here with the Monet prints?" "Sorry, Doc, I just don't have a clue." "No problem, Jim. All I want you to do is rank these for me from the one you like the most to the one you like the least."What do they do? Well, let's first check and make sure they're really amnesiac. We ask these amnesiac patients to tell us which one they own, which one they chose last time, which one is theirs. And what we find is amnesiac patients just guess. These are normal controls, where if I did this with you, all of you would know which print you chose. But if I do this with amnesiac patients, they don't have a clue. They can't pick their print out of a lineup.Here's what normal controls do: they synthesize happiness. Right? This is the change in liking score, the change from the first time they ranked to the second time they ranked. Normal controls show — that was the magic I showed you; now I'm showing it to you in graphical form — "The one I own is better than I thought. The one I didn't own, the one I left behind, is not as good as I thought." Amnesiacs do exactly the same thing. Think about this result.These people like better the one they own, but they don't know they own it. "Yeah, right" is not the right response! What these people did when they synthesized happiness is they really, truly changed their affective, hedonic, aesthetic reactions to that poster. They're not just saying it because they own it, because they don't know they own it.When psychologists show you bars, you know that they are showing you averages of lots of people. And yet, all of us have this psychological immune system, this capacity to synthesize happiness, but some of us do this trick better than others. And some situations allow anybody to do it more effectively than other situations do. It turns out that freedom, the ability to make up your mind and change your mind, is the friend of natural happiness, because it allows you to choose among all those delicious futures and find the one that you would most enjoy. But freedom to choose, to change and make up your mind, is the enemy of synthetic happiness.And I'm going to show you why. Dilbert already knows, of course. "Dogbert's tech support. How may I abuse you?" "My printer prints a blank page after every document." "Why complain about getting free paper?" "Free? Aren't you just giving me my own paper?" "Look at the quality of the free paper compared to your lousy regular paper! Only a fool or a liar would say that they look the same!" "Now that you mention it, it does seem a little silkier!" "What are you doing?" "I'm helping people accept the things they cannot change." Indeed.The psychological immune system works best when we are totally stuck, when we are trapped. This is the difference between dating and marriage. You go out on a date with a guy, and he picks his nose; you don't go out on another date. You're married to a guy and he picks his nose? He has a heart of gold. Don't touch the fruitcake! You find a way to be happy with what's happened.(Laughter)Now, what I want to show you is that people don't know this about themselves, and not knowing this can work to our supreme disadvantage.Here's an experiment we did at Harvard. We created a black-and-white photography course, and we allowed students to come in and learn how to use a darkroom. So we gave them cameras; they went around campus; they took 12 pictures of their favorite professors and their dorm room and their dog, and all the other things they wanted to have Harvard memories of. They bring us the camera; we make up a contact sheet; they figure out which are the two best pictures; and we now spend six hours teaching them about darkrooms. And they blow two of them up, and they have two gorgeous eight-by-10 glossies of meaningful things to them, and we say, "Which one would you like to give up?" "I have to give one up?" "Yes, we need one as evidence of the class project. So you have to give me one. You have to make a choice. You get to keep one, and I get to keep one."Now, there are two conditions in this experiment. In one case, the students are told, "But you know, if you want to change your mind, I'll always have the other one here, and in the next four days, before I actually mail it to headquarters" — Yeah, "headquarters" — "I'll be glad to swap it out with you. In fact, I'll come to your dorm room, just give me an email. Better yet, I'll check with you. You ever want to change your mind, it's totally returnable." The other half of the students are told exactly the opposite: "Make your choice, and by the way, the mail is going out, gosh, in two minutes, to England. Your picture will be winging its way over the Atlantic. You will never see it again." Half of the students in each of these conditions are asked to make predictions about how much they're going to come to like the picture that they keep and the picture they leave behind. Other students are just sent back to their little dorm rooms and they are measured over the next three to six days on their liking, satisfaction with the pictures. And look at what we find.First of all, here's what students think is going to happen. They think they're going to maybe come to like the picture they chose a little more than the one they left behind, but these are not statistically significant differences. It's a very small increase, and it doesn't much matter whether they were in the reversible or irreversible condition.Wrong-o. Bad simulators. Because here's what's really happening. Both right before the swap and five days later, people who are stuck with that picture, who have no choice, who can never change their mind, like it a lot! And people who are deliberating — "Should I return it? Have I gotten the right one? Maybe this isn't the good one? Maybe I left the good one?" — have killed themselves. They don't like their picture, and in fact even after the opportunity to swap has expired, they still don't like their picture. Why? Because the [reversible] condition is not conducive to the synthesis of happiness.So here's the final piece of this experiment. We bring in a whole new group of naive Harvard students and we say, "You know, we're doing a photography course, and we can do it one of two ways. We could do it so that when you take the two pictures, you'd have four days to change your mind, or we're doing another course where you take the two pictures and you make up your mind right away and you can never change it. Which course would you like to be in?" Duh! 66 percent of the students, two-thirds, prefer to be in the course where they have the opportunity to change their mind. Hello? 66 percent of the students choose to be in the course in which they will ultimately be deeply dissatisfied with the picture. Because they do not know the conditions under which synthetic happiness grows.The Bard said everything best, of course, and he's making my point here but he's making it hyperbolically: "'Tis nothing good or bad / But thinking makes it so." It's nice poetry, but that can't exactly be right. Is there really nothing good or bad? Is it really the case that gall bladder surgery and a trip to Paris are just the same thing? (Laughter) That seems like a one-question IQ test. They can't be exactly the same.In more turgid prose, but closer to the truth, was the father of modern capitalism, Adam Smith, and he said this. This is worth contemplating: "The great source of both the misery and disorders of human life seems to arise from overrating the difference between one permanent situation and another — Some of these situations may, no doubt, deserve to be preferred to others, but none of them can deserve to be pursued with that passionate ardor which drives us to violate the rules either of prudence or of justice, or to corrupt the future tranquility of our minds, either by shame from the remembrance of our own folly, or by remorse for the horror of our own injustice." In other words: yes, some things are better than others.We should have preferences that lead us into one future over another. But when those preferences drive us too hard and too fast because we have overrated the difference between these futures, we are at risk. When our ambition is bounded, it leads us to work joyfully. When our ambition is unbounded, it leads us to lie, to cheat, to steal, to hurt others, to sacrifice things of real value. When our fears are bounded, we're prudent, we're cautious, we're thoughtful. When our fears are unbounded and overblown, we're reckless, and we're cowardly.The lesson I want to leave you with, from these data, is that our longings and our worries are both to some degree overblown, because we have within us the capacity to manufacture the very commodity we are constantly chasing when we choose experience.Thank you. (Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:13.568 --> 00:00:15.529
When you have 21 minutes to speak,

00:00:15.553 --> 00:00:18.529
two million years seems
like a really long time.

00:00:18.553 --> 00:00:20.999
But evolutionarily,
two million years is nothing.

00:00:21.023 --> 00:00:22.976
And yet in two million years,

00:00:23.000 --> 00:00:26.755
the human brain
has nearly tripled in mass,

00:00:26.779 --> 00:00:30.988
going from the one-and-a-quarter pound
brain of our ancestor here, Habilis,

00:00:31.012 --> 00:00:32.774
to the almost three-pound meatloaf

00:00:32.798 --> 00:00:35.940
that everybody here
has between their ears.

00:00:36.470 --> 00:00:39.865
What is it about a big brain

00:00:39.889 --> 00:00:43.646
that nature was so eager
for every one of us to have one?

00:00:43.670 --> 00:00:45.905
Well, it turns out when
brains triple in size,

00:00:45.929 --> 00:00:49.444
they don't just get three times bigger;
they gain new structures.

00:00:49.468 --> 00:00:54.354
And one of the main reasons our brain got
so big is because it got a new part,

00:00:54.378 --> 00:00:55.710
called the "frontal lobe."

00:00:55.734 --> 00:00:58.362
Particularly, a part called
the "pre-frontal cortex."

00:00:58.851 --> 00:01:02.294
What does a pre-frontal cortex
do for you that should justify

00:01:02.318 --> 00:01:05.898
the entire architectural overhaul
of the human skull

00:01:05.922 --> 00:01:07.685
in the blink of evolutionary time?

00:01:07.709 --> 00:01:10.725
It turns out the pre-frontal
cortex does lots of things,

00:01:10.749 --> 00:01:16.639
but one of the most important things
it does is an experience simulator.

00:01:16.663 --> 00:01:18.991
Pilots practice in flight simulators

00:01:19.015 --> 00:01:21.570
so that they don't make
real mistakes in planes.

00:01:21.955 --> 00:01:24.551
Human beings have this
marvelous adaptation

00:01:24.575 --> 00:01:28.320
that they can actually have
experiences in their heads

00:01:28.344 --> 00:01:30.535
before they try them out in real life.

00:01:30.559 --> 00:01:33.082
This is a trick that none
of our ancestors could do,

00:01:33.106 --> 00:01:36.347
and that no other animal
can do quite like we can.

00:01:36.371 --> 00:01:37.901
It's a marvelous adaptation.

00:01:37.925 --> 00:01:41.792
It's up there with opposable thumbs
and standing upright and language

00:01:41.816 --> 00:01:45.236
as one of the things that got
our species out of the trees

00:01:45.260 --> 00:01:47.413
and into the shopping mall.

00:01:47.437 --> 00:01:49.349
(Laughter)

00:01:49.373 --> 00:01:50.653
All of you have done this.

00:01:50.677 --> 00:01:54.510
Ben and Jerry's doesn't have
liver-and-onion ice cream,

00:01:54.534 --> 00:01:57.942
and it's not because they whipped
some up, tried it and went, "Yuck."

00:01:57.966 --> 00:02:00.988
It's because, without
leaving your armchair,

00:02:01.012 --> 00:02:05.419
you can simulate that flavor
and say "yuck" before you make it.

00:02:07.610 --> 00:02:10.182
Let's see how your experience
simulators are working.

00:02:10.206 --> 00:02:12.045
Let's just run a quick diagnostic

00:02:12.069 --> 00:02:14.207
before I proceed
with the rest of the talk.

00:02:14.231 --> 00:02:17.946
Here's two different futures
that I invite you to contemplate.

00:02:17.970 --> 00:02:21.996
You can try to simulate them and tell me
which one you think you might prefer.

00:02:22.020 --> 00:02:27.554
One of them is winning the lottery.
This is about 314 million dollars.

00:02:27.578 --> 00:02:30.458
And the other is becoming paraplegic.

00:02:30.482 --> 00:02:31.500
(Laughter)

00:02:31.524 --> 00:02:33.152
Just give it a moment of thought.

00:02:33.176 --> 00:02:35.987
You probably don't feel
like you need a moment of thought.

00:02:36.011 --> 00:02:40.129
Interestingly, there are data
on these two groups of people,

00:02:40.153 --> 00:02:42.131
data on how happy they are.

00:02:42.155 --> 00:02:44.849
And this is exactly
what you expected, isn't it?

00:02:45.198 --> 00:02:47.972
But these aren't the data.
I made these up!

00:02:47.996 --> 00:02:49.186
These are the data.

00:02:49.672 --> 00:02:53.168
You failed the pop quiz, and you're hardly
five minutes into the lecture.

00:02:53.192 --> 00:02:57.364
Because the fact is that a year
after losing the use of their legs,

00:02:57.388 --> 00:03:02.115
and a year after winning the lotto,
lottery winners and paraplegics

00:03:02.139 --> 00:03:04.692
are equally happy with their lives.

00:03:05.314 --> 00:03:07.770
Don't feel too bad
about failing the first pop quiz,

00:03:07.794 --> 00:03:11.421
because everybody fails
all of the pop quizzes all of the time.

00:03:11.753 --> 00:03:14.142
The research that my laboratory
has been doing,

00:03:14.166 --> 00:03:17.499
that economists and psychologists
around the country have been doing,

00:03:17.523 --> 00:03:20.319
has revealed something
really quite startling to us,

00:03:20.343 --> 00:03:22.188
something we call the "impact bias,"

00:03:22.212 --> 00:03:25.381
which is the tendency
for the simulator to work badly.

00:03:25.753 --> 00:03:29.952
For the simulator to make you
believe that different outcomes

00:03:29.976 --> 00:03:32.335
are more different
than in fact they really are.

00:03:32.359 --> 00:03:34.642
From field studies to laboratory studies,

00:03:34.666 --> 00:03:39.405
we see that winning or losing an election,
gaining or losing a romantic partner,

00:03:39.429 --> 00:03:43.256
getting or not getting a promotion,
passing or not passing a college test,

00:03:43.280 --> 00:03:49.178
on and on, have far less impact,
less intensity and much less duration

00:03:49.202 --> 00:03:51.668
than people expect them to have.

00:03:52.972 --> 00:03:58.019
This almost floors me --

00:03:58.043 --> 00:04:02.529
a recent study showing
how major life traumas affect people

00:04:02.553 --> 00:04:05.529
suggests that if it happened
over three months ago,

00:04:05.553 --> 00:04:07.115
with only a few exceptions,

00:04:07.139 --> 00:04:09.897
it has no impact whatsoever
on your happiness.

00:04:11.756 --> 00:04:12.906
Why?

00:04:13.446 --> 00:04:17.079
Because happiness can be synthesized.

00:04:17.103 --> 00:04:21.389
Sir Thomas Brown wrote in 1642,
"I am the happiest man alive.

00:04:21.413 --> 00:04:26.529
I have that in me that can convert poverty
to riches, adversity to prosperity.

00:04:26.553 --> 00:04:31.499
I am more invulnerable than Achilles;
fortune hath not one place to hit me."

00:04:31.523 --> 00:04:34.712
What kind of remarkable machinery
does this guy have in his head?

00:04:34.736 --> 00:04:39.681
Well, it turns out it's precisely the same
remarkable machinery that all off us have.

00:04:40.733 --> 00:04:42.597
Human beings have something

00:04:42.621 --> 00:04:45.862
that we might think of
as a "psychological immune system."

00:04:45.886 --> 00:04:50.879
A system of cognitive processes, largely
non-conscious cognitive processes,

00:04:50.903 --> 00:04:54.337
that help them change
their views of the world,

00:04:54.361 --> 00:04:55.758
so that they can feel better

00:04:55.782 --> 00:04:58.710
about the worlds
in which they find themselves.

00:04:58.734 --> 00:05:00.600
Like Sir Thomas, you have this machine.

00:05:00.624 --> 00:05:04.529
Unlike Sir Thomas,
you seem not to know it.

00:05:05.444 --> 00:05:10.529
We synthesize happiness, but we think
happiness is a thing to be found.

00:05:10.553 --> 00:05:12.227
Now, you don't need me to give you

00:05:12.251 --> 00:05:16.339
too many examples of people
synthesizing happiness, I suspect.

00:05:16.363 --> 00:05:18.987
Though I'm going to show
you some experimental evidence,

00:05:19.011 --> 00:05:21.155
you don't have to look
very far for evidence.

00:05:21.179 --> 00:05:22.850
I took a copy of the New York Times

00:05:22.874 --> 00:05:26.058
and tried to find some instances
of people synthesizing happiness.

00:05:26.082 --> 00:05:28.095
Here are three guys
synthesizing happiness.

00:05:28.119 --> 00:05:30.800
"I'm better off physically,
financially, mentally ...

00:05:30.824 --> 00:05:33.873
"I don't have one minute's regret.
It was a glorious experience."

00:05:33.897 --> 00:05:35.828
"I believe it turned out for the best."

00:05:35.852 --> 00:05:38.101
Who are these characters
who are so damn happy?

00:05:38.125 --> 00:05:39.495
The first one is Jim Wright.

00:05:39.519 --> 00:05:41.390
Some of you are old enough to remember:

00:05:41.414 --> 00:05:43.877
he was the chairman
of the House of Representatives

00:05:43.901 --> 00:05:45.273
and he resigned in disgrace

00:05:45.297 --> 00:05:47.452
when this young Republican
named Newt Gingrich

00:05:47.476 --> 00:05:49.620
found out about a shady
book deal he had done.

00:05:49.644 --> 00:05:50.886
He lost everything.

00:05:50.910 --> 00:05:53.688
The most powerful Democrat
in the country lost everything.

00:05:53.712 --> 00:05:55.508
He lost his money, he lost his power.

00:05:55.532 --> 00:05:57.820
What does he have to say
all these years later?

00:05:57.844 --> 00:06:00.583
"I am so much better off physically,
financially, mentally

00:06:00.607 --> 00:06:02.408
and in almost every other way."

00:06:02.432 --> 00:06:04.671
What other way would there
be to be better off?

00:06:04.695 --> 00:06:06.523
Vegetably? Minerally? Animally?

00:06:06.547 --> 00:06:09.261
He's pretty much covered them there.

00:06:09.285 --> 00:06:11.766
Moreese Bickham is somebody
you've never heard of.

00:06:11.790 --> 00:06:14.470
Moreese Bickham uttered
these words upon being released.

00:06:14.494 --> 00:06:15.803
He was 78 years old.

00:06:15.827 --> 00:06:18.750
He'd spent 37 years
in a Louisiana State Penitentiary

00:06:18.774 --> 00:06:20.258
for a crime he didn't commit.

00:06:20.282 --> 00:06:22.115
[He was ultimately released

00:06:22.139 --> 00:06:24.408
for good behavior
halfway through his sentence.]

00:06:24.432 --> 00:06:26.408
What did he say about his experience?

00:06:26.432 --> 00:06:29.990
"I don't have one minute's regret.
It was a glorious experience." Glorious!

00:06:30.014 --> 00:06:31.264
He is not saying,

00:06:31.288 --> 00:06:33.684
"Well, there were some nice guys.
They had a gym."

00:06:33.708 --> 00:06:34.859
"Glorious,"

00:06:34.883 --> 00:06:38.161
a word we usually reserve for something
like a religious experience.

00:06:38.185 --> 00:06:41.914
Harry S. Langerman uttered these words,
and he's somebody you might have known

00:06:41.938 --> 00:06:45.547
but didn't, because in 1949
he read a little article in the paper

00:06:45.571 --> 00:06:48.537
about a hamburger stand owned
by two brothers named McDonalds.

00:06:48.561 --> 00:06:50.792
And he thought,
"That's a really neat idea!"

00:06:50.816 --> 00:06:52.498
So he went to find them. They said,

00:06:52.523 --> 00:06:55.067
"We can give you a franchise
on this for 3,000 bucks."

00:06:55.091 --> 00:06:58.331
Harry went back to New York,
asked his brother, an investment banker,

00:06:58.355 --> 00:07:01.263
to loan him the $3,000,
and his brother's immortal words were,

00:07:01.287 --> 00:07:03.005
"You idiot, nobody eats hamburgers."

00:07:03.029 --> 00:07:04.518
He wouldn't lend him the money,

00:07:04.542 --> 00:07:07.756
and of course, six months later
Ray Kroc had exactly the same idea.

00:07:07.780 --> 00:07:09.974
It turns out people do eat hamburgers,

00:07:09.998 --> 00:07:13.132
and Ray Kroc, for a while,
became the richest man in America.

00:07:13.822 --> 00:07:14.980
And then, finally,

00:07:15.004 --> 00:07:18.464
some of you recognize
this young photo of Pete Best,

00:07:18.488 --> 00:07:20.631
who was the original
drummer for the Beatles,

00:07:20.655 --> 00:07:24.480
until they, you know, sent him
out on an errand and snuck away

00:07:24.504 --> 00:07:26.464
and picked up Ringo on a tour.

00:07:26.488 --> 00:07:28.784
Well, in 1994, when Pete Best
was interviewed --

00:07:28.808 --> 00:07:31.844
yes, he's still a drummer;
yes, he's a studio musician --
