00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:14.958
Video: Narrator: An event seen from one point of view

00:00:14.958 --> 00:00:15.958
gives one impression.

00:00:19.958 --> 00:00:23.958
Seen from another point of view, it gives quite a different impression.

00:00:24.958 --> 00:00:28.958
But it's only when you get the whole picture you can fully understand

00:00:28.958 --> 00:00:31.958
what's going on.

00:00:31.958 --> 00:00:34.958
Sasha Vucinic: It's a great clip, isn't it?

00:00:34.958 --> 00:00:39.958
And I found that in 29 seconds, it tells more about

00:00:39.958 --> 00:00:42.958
the power of, and importance of, independent media

00:00:42.958 --> 00:00:45.958
than I could say in an hour.

00:00:45.958 --> 00:00:49.958
So I thought that it will be good to start with it.

00:00:49.958 --> 00:00:52.958
And also start with a little bit of statistics.

00:00:52.958 --> 00:00:58.958
According to relevant researchers, 83 percent of the population of this planet

00:00:58.958 --> 00:01:03.958
lives in the societies without independent press.

00:01:03.958 --> 00:01:08.958
Think about that number: 83 percent of the population on the whole planet

00:01:08.958 --> 00:01:12.958
does not really know what is going on in their countries.

00:01:12.958 --> 00:01:16.958
The information they get gets filtered through somebody

00:01:16.958 --> 00:01:20.958
who either twists that information, or colors that information,

00:01:20.958 --> 00:01:21.958
does something with it.

00:01:21.958 --> 00:01:26.958
So they're deprived of understanding their reality.

00:01:26.958 --> 00:01:32.958
That is just to understand how big and important this problem is.

00:01:32.958 --> 00:01:39.958
Now those of you who are lucky enough to live in those societies

00:01:39.958 --> 00:01:45.958
that represent 17 percent, I think should enjoy it until it lasts.

00:01:45.958 --> 00:01:49.958
You know, Sunday morning, you flick the paper, get your cappuccino.

00:01:49.958 --> 00:01:50.958
Enjoy it while it lasts.

00:01:50.958 --> 00:01:57.958
Because as we heard yesterday, countries can lose stars from their flags,

00:01:57.958 --> 00:02:00.958
but they can also lose press freedom,

00:02:00.958 --> 00:02:05.958
as I guess Americans among us can tell us more about.

00:02:05.958 --> 00:02:08.958
But that's totally another and separate topic.

00:02:08.958 --> 00:02:12.958
So I can go back to my story.

00:02:12.958 --> 00:02:17.958
My story starts -- the story I want to share -- starts in 1991.

00:02:17.958 --> 00:02:21.958
At that time I was running B92, the only independent,

00:02:21.958 --> 00:02:24.958
for that matter the only electronic media, in the country.

00:02:24.958 --> 00:02:29.958
And I guess we were sharing -- we had that regular life of the only

00:02:29.958 --> 00:02:35.958
independent media in the country, operating in hostile environment,

00:02:35.958 --> 00:02:39.958
where government really wants to make your life miserable.

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:40.958
And there are different ways.

00:02:40.958 --> 00:02:41.958
Yeah, it was the usual cocktail:

00:02:41.958 --> 00:02:44.958
a little bit of threats, a little bit of friendly advice,

00:02:44.958 --> 00:02:48.958
a little bit of financial police, a little bit of text control,

00:02:48.958 --> 00:02:52.958
so you always have somebody who never leaves your office.

00:02:52.958 --> 00:02:57.958
But what they really do, which is very powerful,

00:02:57.958 --> 00:03:01.958
and that is what governments in the late '90s started doing

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:03.958
if they don't like independent media companies --

00:03:03.958 --> 00:03:05.958
you know, they threaten your advertisers.

00:03:05.958 --> 00:03:10.958
Once they threaten your advertisers, market forces are actually,

00:03:10.958 --> 00:03:15.958
you know, destroyed, and the advertisers do not want to come --

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:18.958
no matter how much does it make sense for them --

00:03:18.958 --> 00:03:20.958
do not want to come and advertise.

00:03:20.958 --> 00:03:24.958
And you have a problem making ends meet.

00:03:24.958 --> 00:03:28.958
At that time at the beginning of the '90s, we had that problem,

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:30.958
which was, you know, survival below one side,

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:34.958
but what was really painful for me was,

00:03:34.958 --> 00:03:37.958
remember, the beginning of the '90s, Yugoslavia is falling apart.

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:40.958
We were sitting over there with a country in a downfall,

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:44.958
in a slow-motion downfall.

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:47.958
And we all had all of that on tapes.

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:50.958
We had the ability to understand what was going on.

00:03:50.958 --> 00:03:52.958
We were actually recording history.

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:57.958
The problem was that we had to re-tape that history a week later;

00:03:57.958 --> 00:04:01.958
because if we did not, we could not afford enough tapes

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:04.958
to keep archives of that history.

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:09.958
So if I gave you that picture, I don't want to go too long on that.

00:04:09.958 --> 00:04:13.958
In that context a gentleman came to my office at that time.

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:14.958
It was still 1991.

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:17.958
He was running a media systems organization

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:20.958
which is still in business, the gentleman is still in business.

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:23.958
And what did I know at that time about media systems?

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:26.958
I would think media systems were organizations,

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:30.958
which means they should help you.

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:33.958
So I prepared two plans for that meeting, two strategic plans:

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:35.958
the small one and the big one.

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:37.958
The small one was, I just wanted him

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:39.958
to help us get those damn tapes,

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:43.958
so we can keep that archive for the next 50 years.

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:48.958
The big plan was to ask him for a 1,000,000-dollar loan.

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:51.958
Because I thought, I still maintain,

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:55.958
that serious and independent media companies are great business.

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:59.958
And I thought that B92 will survive and be a great company

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:02.958
once Milosevic is gone, which turned out to be true.

00:05:02.958 --> 00:05:05.958
It's now probably either the biggest or the second biggest

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:07.958
media company in the country.

00:05:07.958 --> 00:05:10.958
And I thought that the only thing that we needed at that time

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:14.958
was 1,000,000-dollar loan to take us through those hard times.

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:18.958
To make a long story short, the gentleman comes into the office,

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:22.958
great suit and tie.

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:26.958
I gave him what I thought was a brilliant explanation

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:31.958
of the political situation and explained how hard and difficult

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:33.958
the war will be.

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:36.958
Actually, I underestimated the atrocities, I have to admit.

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:39.958
Anyway, after that whole, big, long explanation,

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:44.958
the only question he had for me -- and this is not a joke --

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:48.958
is, are we paying royalties after we broadcast music

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:52.958
of Michael Jackson?

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:54.958
That was really the only question he had.

00:05:54.958 --> 00:06:01.958
He left, and I remember being actually very angry at myself

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:05.958
because I thought there must be an institution in the world

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:08.958
that is providing loans to media companies.

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:11.958
It's so obvious, straight in your face,

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:12.958
and somebody must have thought of it.

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:15.958
Somebody must have started something like that.

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:19.958
And I thought, I'm just dumb and I cannot find it.

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:21.958
You know, in my defense, there was no Google at that time;

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:24.958
you could not just Google in '91.

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:28.958
So I thought that that's actually my problem.

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:32.958
Now we go from here, fast forward to 1995.

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:38.958
I have -- I left the country, I have a meeting with George Soros,

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:44.958
trying for the third time to convince him that

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:47.958
his foundation should invest in something that should

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:51.958
operate like a media bank.

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:54.958
And basically what I was saying is very simple.

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:55.958
You know, forget about charity; it doesn't work.

00:06:55.958 --> 00:07:00.958
Forget about handouts; 20,000 dollars do not help anybody.

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:04.958
What you should do is you should treat media companies as a business.

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:06.958
It's business anywhere.

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:09.958
Media business, or any other business, it needs to be capitalized.

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:14.958
And what these guys need, actually, is access to capital.

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:19.958
So third meeting, arguments are pretty well exercised.

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:21.958
At the end of the meeting he says,

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:25.958
look, it is not going to work; you will never see your money back;

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:30.958
but my foundations will put 500,000 dollars so you can test the idea.

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:35.958
See that it will not work.

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:37.958
He said, I'll give you a rope to hang yourself.

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:39.958
(Laughter)

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:42.958
I knew two things after that meeting.

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:46.958
First, under no circumstances I want to hang myself.

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:52.958
And second, that I have no idea how to make it work.

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:56.958
You see, at the level of a concept, it was a great concept.

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:58.958
But it's one thing to have a concept;

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:01.958
it's a totally separate thing to actually make it work.

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:05.958
So I had absolutely no idea how that could actually work.

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:08.958
Had the wrong idea; I thought that we can be a bank.

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:11.958
You see banks -- I don't know if there are any bankers over here;

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:15.958
I apologize in advance -- but it's the best job in the world.

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:18.958
You know, you find somebody who is respectable

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:19.958
and has a lot of money.

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:24.958
You give them more money; they repay you that over a time.

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:26.958
You collect interest and do nothing in between.

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:28.958
So I thought, why don't we get into that business?

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:30.958
(Laughter)

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:36.958
So here we are having our first client, brilliant.

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:38.958
First independent newspaper in Slovakia.

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:39.958
The government cutting them off

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:42.958
from all the printing facilities in Bratislava.

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:43.958
So here's the daily newspaper

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:47.958
that has to be printed 400 kilometers away from the capital.

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:51.958
It's a daily newspaper with a deadline of 4 p.m.

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:53.958
That means that they have no sports;

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:56.958
they have no latest news; circulation goes down.

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:59.958
It's a kind of very nice, sophisticated way

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:03.958
how to economically strangle a daily newspaper.

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:05.958
They come to us with a request for a loan.

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:07.958
They want to -- the only way for them to survive

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:09.958
is to get a printing press.

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:12.958
And we said, that's fine; let's meet;

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:16.958
you'll bring us your business plan, which eventually they did.

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:18.958
We start the meeting.

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:22.958
I get these two pieces of paper, not like this, A4 format,

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:24.958
so it's much bigger.

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:27.958
A lot of numbers there. A lot of numbers.

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:29.958
But however you put it, you know, the numbers

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:31.958
do not make any sense.

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:33.958
And that's the best they could do.

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:34.958
We were the best that they could do.

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:36.958
So that is how we understood what our method is.

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:39.958
It's not a bank. We had to actually

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:43.958
go into these companies and earn our return

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:46.958
by fixing them -- by establishing management systems,

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:48.958
by providing all that knowledge, how do you run a business

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:54.958
on one side -- while they all know how to run, how to create content.

00:09:54.958 --> 00:10:00.958
Just quickly on the results.

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:06.958
Over these 10 years, 40 million dollars in affordable financing,

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:09.958
average interest rate five percent to six percent.

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:15.958
Lately we are going wild, charging seven percent from time to time.

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:19.958
We do it in 17 countries of the developing world.

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:22.958
And here is the most stunning number.

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:28.958
Return rate -- the one that Soros was so worried about -- 97 percent.

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:33.958
97 percent of all the scheduled repayments came back to us on time.

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:34.958
What do we typically finance?

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:37.958
We finance anything that a media company would need,

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:42.958
from printing presses to transmitters.

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:47.958
What is most important is we do it

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:50.958
either in form of loans, equities, lease --

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:53.958
whatever is appropriate for, you know, supporting anybody.

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:58.958
But what is most important here is, who do we finance?

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:00.958
We believe that in the last 10 years companies

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:04.958
that we've financed are actually the best media companies

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:06.958
in the developing world.

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:08.958
That is a "Who is Who" list.

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:13.958
And I could spend hours talking about them,

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:14.958
because they're all kind of heroes.

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:17.958
And I can, but I'll give you just, maybe one,

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:20.958
and depending on time I may give you two examples

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:21.958
who we work with.

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:23.958
You see we started working in Eastern and Central Europe,

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:25.958
and moved to Russia.

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:28.958
Our first loan in Russia was in Chelyabinsk.

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:31.958
I'll bet half of you have never heard of that place.

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:34.958
In the south of Russia there's a guy called

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:36.958
Boris Nikolayevich Kirshin, who is running

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:38.958
an independent newspaper there.

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:40.958
The city was closed until early '90s

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:47.958
because, of all things, they were producing glass for Tupolev planes.

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:51.958
Anyway, he's running independent newspaper there.

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:53.958
After two years working with us, he becomes

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:59.958
the most respected newspaper in that small place.

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:01.958
Governor comes to him one day,

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:03.958
actually invites him to come to his office.

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:06.958
He goes and sees the governor. The governor says,

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:08.958
Boris Nikolayevich, I understand you are doing a great job,

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:14.958
and you are the most respected newspaper in our district.

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:18.958
And I want to offer you a deal.

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:21.958
Can you please give me your newspaper for the next nine months,

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:23.958
because I have elections --

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:26.958
there are elections coming up in nine months.

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:29.958
I will not run, but it's very important for me

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:31.958
who is going to succeed me.

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:33.958
So give me the paper for nine months. I'll give it back to you.

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:36.958
I have no interest in being in media business.

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:39.958
How much would that cost?

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:41.958
Boris Nikolayevich says, "It's not for sale."

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:44.958
The governor says, "We will close you."

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:46.958
Boris Nikolayevich says, "No, you cannot do it."

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:50.958
Six months later the newspaper was closed.

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:53.958
Luckily, we had enough time to help Boris Nikolayevich

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:57.958
take all the assets out of that company and bring him into a new one,

00:12:57.958 --> 00:13:01.958
to get all the subscription lists, rehire staff.

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:04.958
So what the governor got was an empty shell.

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:08.958
But that is what happens if you're in business of independent media,

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:12.958
and if you are a banker for independent media.

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:18.958
So it sounds like a great story.

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:22.958
Somewhere down the road we opened a media management center.

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:25.958
We started our media lab, sounds like a real great story.

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:28.958
But there is a second angle to that.

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:30.958
The second angle, like in this clip.

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:32.958
If you take the camera above, you start thinking

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:33.958
about these numbers again.

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:40.958
40 million dollars over 10 years spread over 17 countries.

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:42.958
That is not too much, is it?

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:44.958
It's actually just a drop in the sea.

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:46.958
Because when you think about the importance,

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:49.958
some of the issues that we were talking about last night --

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:51.958
this last session we had about Africa and his

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:56.958
hypothetical 50 billion dollars destined for Africa.

00:13:56.958 --> 00:14:02.958
All of those, not all, half of those problems mentioned last night --

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:07.958
government accountability, corruption, how do you fight corruption,

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:10.958
giving voice to unheard, to poor --

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:14.958
it's why independent media is in business.

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:16.958
And it's why it was invented.

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:19.958
So from that perspective, what we did is just really

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:26.958
one drop in the sea of that need that we can identify.

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:29.958
Now ours is just one story.

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:32.958
I'm sure that in this room there are, like, 15 other wonderful stories

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:35.958
of nonprofits doing spectacular work.

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:38.958
Here is where the problem is,

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:44.958
and I'll explain to you as well as I can what the problem is.

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:46.958
And it's called fundraising.

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:50.958
Imagine that this third of this room is filled

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:53.958
with people who represent different foundations.

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:58.958
Imagine two thirds over here running excellent organizations,

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:01.958
doing very important work.

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:03.958
Now imagine that every second person over here

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:08.958
is deaf, does not hear, and switch the lights off.

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:10.958
Now that is how difficult it is to match people

00:15:10.958 --> 00:15:12.958
from this side of the room

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:15.958
with people of that side of the room.

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:20.958
So we thought that some kind of a big idea is needed

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:25.958
to reform, to totally rethink fundraising.

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:27.958
You know, instead of people running in this dark,

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:30.958
trying to find their own match, who will be willing,

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:32.958
who has the same goals.

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:35.958
Instead of all of that we thought there is --

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:38.958
something new needs to be invented.

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:41.958
And we came up with this idea of issuing bonds,

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:42.958
press freedom bonds.

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:49.958
If there are investors willing to finance

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:51.958
U.S. government budget deficit,

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:54.958
why wouldn't we find investors willing to finance

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:57.958
press freedom deficit?

00:15:57.958 --> 00:15:59.958
We've decided to do it this fall; we will issue them,

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:02.958
probably in denominations of 1,000 dollars.

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:04.958
I don't want to advertise them too much; that's not the point.

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:08.958
But the point is, if we ever survive to actually issue them,

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:12.958
find enough investors that this can be considered a success,

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:15.958
there's nothing stopping the next organization

00:16:15.958 --> 00:16:20.958
to start to issue bonds next spring.

00:16:20.958 --> 00:16:22.958
And those can be environmental bonds.

00:16:22.958 --> 00:16:27.958
And then two weeks later, Iqbal Quadir can issue his

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:30.958
electricity in Bangladesh bonds.

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:33.958
And before you know it, any social cause

00:16:33.958 --> 00:16:36.958
can be actually financed in this way.

00:16:36.958 --> 00:16:41.958
Now we do daydreaming in 11:30 with 55 seconds left.

00:16:41.958 --> 00:16:43.958
But let's take the idea further.

00:16:43.958 --> 00:16:46.958
You do it, you start it in the States, because it's,

00:16:46.958 --> 00:16:49.958
you know, concepts are very, very close to American minds.

00:16:49.958 --> 00:16:51.958
But you can actually bring it to Europe, too.

00:16:51.958 --> 00:16:53.958
You can bring it to Asia.

00:16:53.958 --> 00:16:57.958
You can, once you have all of those different points,

00:16:57.958 --> 00:16:59.958
you can make it easy for investors.

00:16:59.958 --> 00:17:01.958
Put all of those bonds at one place

00:17:01.958 --> 00:17:03.958
and they sit down and click.

00:17:03.958 --> 00:17:05.958
Once you have more than 10 of them

00:17:05.958 --> 00:17:08.958
you have to develop some kind of a matrix.

00:17:08.958 --> 00:17:09.958
What do investors get?

00:17:09.958 --> 00:17:12.958
On one side financial, on the other side social.

00:17:12.958 --> 00:17:18.958
So that brings the idea of some kind of rating agency,

00:17:18.958 --> 00:17:20.958
Morningstar type.

00:17:20.958 --> 00:17:24.958
It says, you know, social impact over here is spectacular, five stars.

00:17:24.958 --> 00:17:28.958
Financial, they give you one percent, only one star.

00:17:28.958 --> 00:17:32.958
Now take it to the last step.

00:17:32.958 --> 00:17:34.958
Once you have all of that put together,

00:17:34.958 --> 00:17:39.958
there's not one reason why you couldn't actually have

00:17:39.958 --> 00:17:41.958
a marketplace for all of that,

00:17:41.958 --> 00:17:46.958
where you cannot dispose of all of those bonds in a pretty quick way.

00:17:46.958 --> 00:17:49.958
And in that way you organize the financing

00:17:49.958 --> 00:17:51.958
so there are no dark rooms, no blind people

00:17:51.958 --> 00:17:53.958
running around to find each other.

00:17:53.958 --> 00:17:54.958
Thank you.

title: How to rebuild a broken state
transcript: A public, Dewey long ago observed, is constituted through discussion and debate. If we are to call the tyranny of assumptions into question, and avoid doxa, the realm of the unquestioned, then we must be willing to subject our own assumptions to debate and discussion. It is in this spirit that I join into a discussion of one of the critical issues of our time, namely, how to mobilize different forms of capital for the project of state building.To put the assumptions very clearly: capitalism, after 150 years, has become acceptable, and so has democracy. If we looked in the world of 1945 and looked at the map of capitalist economies and democratic polities, they were the rare exception, not the norm. The question now, however, is both about which form of capitalism and which type of democratic participation. But we must acknowledge that this moment has brought about a rare consensus of assumptions. And that provides the ground for a type of action, because consensus of each moment allows us to act. And it is necessary, no matter how fragile or how provisional our consensus, to be able to move forward.But the majority of the world neither benefits from capitalism nor from democratic systems. Most of the globe experiences the state as repressive, as an organization that is concerned about denial of rights, about denial of justice, rather than provision of it. And in terms of experience of capitalism, there are two aspects that the rest of the globe experiences. First, extractive industry. Blood diamonds, smuggled emeralds, timber, that is cut right from under the poorest. Second is technical assistance. And technical assistance might shock you, but it's the worst form of — today — of the ugly face of the developed world to the developing countries. Tens of billions of dollars are supposedly spent on building capacity with people who are paid up to 1,500 dollars a day, who are incapable of thinking creatively, or organically.Next assumption — and of course the events of July 7, I express my deep sympathy, and before that, September 11 — have reminded us we do not live in three different worlds. We live in one world. But that's easily said. But we are not dealing with the implications of the one world that we are living in. And that is that if we want to have one world, this one world cannot be based on huge pockets of exclusion, and then inclusion for some. We must now finally come to think about the premises of a truly global world, in relationship to the regime of rights and responsibilities and accountabilities that are truly global in scope. Otherwise we will be missing this open moment in history, where we have a consensus on both the form of politics and the form of economics.What is one of these organizations to pick? We have three critical terms: economy, civil society and the state. I will not deal with those first two, except to say that uncritical transfer of assumptions, from one context to another, can only make for disaster. Economics taught in most of the elite universities are practically useless in my context. My country is dominated by drug economy and a mafia. Textbook economics does not work in my context, and I have very few recommendations from anybody as to how to put together a legal economy. The poverty of our knowledge must become the first basis of moving forward, and not imposition of the framework that works on the basis of mathematical modeling, for which I have enormous respect. My colleagues at Johns Hopkins were among the best.Second, instead of debating endlessly about what is the structure of the state, why don't we simplify and say, what are a series of functions that the state in the 21st century must perform? Clare Lockhart and I are writing a book on this; we hope to share that much widely with — and third is that we could actually construct an index to measure comparatively how well these functions that we would agree on are being performed in different places.So what are these functions? We propose 10. And it's legitimate monopoly of means of violence, administrative control, management of public finances, investment in human capital, provision of citizenship rights, provision of infrastructure, management of the tangible and intangible assets of the state through regulation, creation of the market, international agreements, including public borrowing, and then, most importantly, rule of law.I won't elaborate. I hope the questions will give me an opportunity. This is a feasible goal, basically because, contrary to widespread assumption, I would argue that we know how to do this. Who would have imagined that Germany would be either united or democratic today, if you looked at it from the perspective of Oxford of 1943? But people at Oxford prepared for a democratic Germany and engaged in planning. And there are lots of other examples.Now in order to do this — and this brings this group — we have to rethink the notion of capital. The least important form of capital, in this project, is financial capital — money. Money is not capital in most of the developing countries. It's just cash. Because it lacks the institutional, organizational, managerial forms to turn it into capital. And what is required is a combination of physical capital, institutional capital, human capital — and security, of course, is critical, but so is information.Now, the issue that should concern us here — and that's the challenge that I would like to pose to this group — is again, it takes 16 years in your countries to produce somebody with a B.S. degree. It takes 20 years to produce somebody with a Ph.D. The first challenge is to rethink, fundamentally, the issue of the time. Do we need to repeat the modalities that we have inherited? Our educational systems are inherited from the 19th century. What is it that we need to do fundamentally to re-engage in a project, that capital formation is rapid? The absolute majority of the world's population are below 20, and they are growing larger and faster. They need different ways of being approached, different ways of being enfranchised, different ways of being skilled. And that's the first thing.Second is, you're problem solvers, but you're not engaging your global responsibility. You've stayed away from the problems of corruption. You only want clean environments in which to function. But if you don't think through the problems of corruption, who will? You stay away from design for development. You're great designers, but your designs are selfish. It's for your own immediate use. The world in which I operate operates with designs regarding roads, or dams, or provision of electricity that have not been revisited in 60 years. This is not right. It requires thinking.But, particularly, what we need more than anything else from this group is your imagination to be brought to bear on problems the way a meme is supposed to work. As the work on paradigms, long time ago showed — Thomas Kuhn's work — it's in the intersection of ideas that new developments — true breakthroughs — occur. And I hope that this group would be able to deal with the issue of state and development and the empowerment of the majority of the world's poor, through this means. Thank you. (Applause)Chris Anderson: So, Ashraf, until recently, you were the finance minister of Afghanistan, a country right at the middle of much of the world's agenda. Is the country gonna make it? Will democracy flourish? What scares you most?Ashraf Ghani: What scares me most is — is you, lack of your engagement. (Laughter) You asked me. You know I always give the unconventional answer. No. But seriously, the issue of Afghanistan first has to be seen as, at least, a 10- to 20-year perspective. Today the world of globalization is on speed. Time has been compressed. And space does not exist for most people. But in my world — you know, when I went back to Afghanistan after 23 years, space had expanded. Every conceivable form of infrastructure had broken down. I rode — traveled — travel between two cities that used to take three hours now took 12. So the first is when the scale is that, we need to recognize that just the simple things that are infrastructure — it takes six years to deliver infrastructure. In our world. Any meaningful sort of thing. But the modality of attention, or what is happening today, what's happening tomorrow.Second is, when a country has been subjected to one of the most immense, brutal forms of exercise of power — we had the Red Army for 10 continuous years, 110,000 strong, literally terrorizing. The sky: every Afghan sees the sky as a source of fear. We were bombed practically out of existence. Then, tens of thousands of people were trained in terrorism — from all sides. The United States, Great Britain, joined for instance, Egyptian intelligence service to train thousands of people in resistance and urban terrorism. How to turn a bicycle into an instrument of terror. How to turn a donkey, a carthorse, anything. And the Russians, equally. So, when violence erupts in a country like Afghanistan, it's because of that legacy. But we have to understand that we've been incredibly lucky. I mean, I really can't believe how lucky I am here, standing in front of you, speaking. When I joined as finance minister, I thought that the chances of my living more than three years would not be more than five percent. Those were the risks. They were worth it.I think we can make it, and the reason we can make it is because of the people. You see, because, I mean — I give you one statistic. 91 percent of the men in Afghanistan, 86 percent of the women, listen to at least three radio stations a day. In terms of their discourse, in terms of their sophistication of knowledge of the world, I think that I would dare say, they're much more sophisticated than rural Americans with college degrees and the bulk of Europeans — because the world matters to them. And what is their predominant concern? Abandonment. Afghans have become deeply internationalist.You know, when I went back in December of 2001, I had absolutely no desire to work with the Afghan government because I'd lived as a nationalist. And I told them — my people, with the Americans here — separate. Yes, I have an advisory position with the U.N. I went through 10 Afghan provinces very rapidly. And everybody was telling me it was a different world. You know, they engage. They see engagement, global engagement, as absolutely necessary to the future of the ordinary people. And the thing that the ordinary Afghan is most concerned with is — Clare Lockhart is here, so I'll recite a discussion she had with an illiterate woman in Northern Afghanistan. And that woman said she didn't care whether she had food on her table. What she worried about was whether there was a plan for the future, where her children could really have a different life. That gives me hope. CA: How is Afghanistan going to provide alternative income to the many people who are making their living off the drugs trade?AG: Certainly. Well, the first is, instead of sending a billion dollars on drug eradication and paying it to a couple of security companies, they should give this hundred billion dollars to 50 of the most critically innovative companies in the world to ask them to create one million jobs. The key to the drug eradication is jobs. Look, there's a very little known fact: countries that have a legal average income per capita of 1,000 dollars don't produce drugs.Second, textile. Trade is the key, not aid. The U.S. and Europe should give us a zero percent tariff. The textile industry is incredibly mobile. If you want us to be able to compete with China and to attract investment, we could probably attract four to six billion dollars quite easily in the textile sector, if there was zero tariffs — would create the type of job. Cotton does not compete with opium; a t-shirt does. And we need to understand, it's the value chain. Look, the ordinary Afghan is sick and tired of hearing about microcredit. It is important, but what the ordinary women and men who engage in micro-production want is global access. They don't want to sell to the charity bazaars that are only for foreigners — and the same bloody shirt embroidered time and again. What we want is a partnership with the Italian design firms. Yeah, we have the best embroiderers in the world! Why can't we do what was done with northern Italy? With the Put Out system? So I think economically, the critical issue really is to now think through.And what I will say here is that aid doesn't work. You know, the aid system is broken. The aid system does not have the knowledge, the vision, the ability. I'm all for it; after all, I raised a lot of it. Yeah, to be exact, you know, I managed to persuade the world that they had to give my country 27.5 billion. They didn't want to give us the money.CA: And it still didn't work?AG: No. It's not that it didn't work. It's that a dollar of private investment, in my judgment, is equal at least to 20 dollars of aid, in terms of the dynamic that it generates. Second is that one dollar of aid could be 10 cents; it could be 20 cents; or it could be four dollars. It depends on what form it comes, what degrees of conditionalities are attached to it. You know, the aid system, at first, was designed to benefit entrepreneurs of the developed countries, not to generate growth in the poor countries. And this is, again, one of those assumptions — the way car seats are an assumption that we've inherited in governments, and doors. You would think that the US government would not think that American firms needed subsidizing to function in developing countries, provide advice, but they do. There's an entire weight of history vis-a-vis aid that now needs to be reexamined. If the goal is to build states that can credibly take care of themselves — and I'm putting that proposition equally; you know I'm very harsh on my counterparts — aid must end in each country in a definable period. And every year there must be progress on mobilization of domestic revenue and generation of the economy. Unless that kind of compact is entered into, you will not be able to sustain the consensus.

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:10.958

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:12.958
We have three critical terms:

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:14.958
economy,

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:16.958
civil society

00:04:16.958 --> 00:04:18.958
and the state.

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:21.958
I will not deal with those first two, except to say

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:24.958
that uncritical transfer of assumptions,

00:04:24.958 --> 00:04:26.958
from one context to another,

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:29.958
can only make for disaster.

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:32.958
Economics

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:35.958
taught in most of the elite universities

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:38.958
are practically useless in my context.

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:40.958
My country is dominated

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:43.958
by drug economy and a mafia.

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:45.958
Textbook economics does not work in my context,

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:48.958
and I have very few recommendations from anybody

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:51.958
as to how to put together a legal economy.

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:53.958
The poverty of our knowledge

00:04:53.958 --> 00:04:55.958
must become the first basis

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:57.958
of moving forward,

00:04:57.958 --> 00:05:00.958
and not imposition of the framework

00:05:00.958 --> 00:05:03.958
that works on the basis of mathematical modeling,

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:05.958
for which I have enormous respect.

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:08.958
My colleagues at Johns Hopkins were among the best.

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:11.958
Second,

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:14.958
instead of debating endlessly

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:16.958
about what is the structure of the state,

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:18.958
why don't we simplify

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:20.958
and say, what are a series of functions

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:23.958
that the state in the 21st century must perform?

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:26.958
Clare Lockhart and I are writing a book on this;

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:28.958
we hope to share that much widely with --

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:31.958
and third is that we could actually construct an index

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:34.958
to measure comparatively

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:37.958
how well these functions that we would agree on

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:39.958
are being performed in different places.

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:41.958
So what are these functions?

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:43.958
We propose 10.

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:46.958
And it's legitimate monopoly of means of violence,

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:49.958
administrative control, management of public finances,

00:05:49.958 --> 00:05:52.958
investment in human capital, provision of citizenship rights,

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:54.958
provision of infrastructure,

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:57.958
management of the tangible and intangible assets of the state

00:05:57.958 --> 00:05:59.958
through regulation, creation of the market,

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:02.958
international agreements, including public borrowing,

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:05.958
and then, most importantly, rule of law.

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:07.958
I won't elaborate.

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:10.958
I hope the questions will give me an opportunity.

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:12.958
This is a feasible goal,

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:15.958
basically because, contrary to widespread assumption,

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:18.958
I would argue that we know how to do this.

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:20.958
Who would have imagined that Germany

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:23.958
would be either united or democratic today,

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:27.958
if you looked at it from the perspective of Oxford of 1943?

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:31.958
But people at Oxford prepared for a democratic Germany

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:34.958
and engaged in planning.

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:37.958
And there are lots of other examples.

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:42.958
Now in order to do this -- and this brings this group --

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:45.958
we have to rethink the notion of capital.

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:49.958
The least important form of capital, in this project,

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:52.958
is financial capital -- money.

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:56.958
Money is not capital in most of the developing countries.

00:06:56.958 --> 00:06:58.958
It's just cash.

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:00.958
Because it lacks the institutional,

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:03.958
organizational, managerial forms

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:06.958
to turn it into capital.

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:09.958
And what is required

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:11.958
is a combination of physical capital,

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:13.958
institutional capital, human capital --

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:16.958
and security, of course, is critical,

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:18.958
but so is information.

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:21.958
Now, the issue that should concern us here --

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:23.958
and that's the challenge

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:26.958
that I would like to pose to this group --

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:30.958
is again, it takes 16 years

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:33.958
in your countries

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:36.958
to produce somebody with a B.S. degree.

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:38.958
It takes 20 years

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:40.958
to produce somebody with a Ph.D.

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:43.958
The first challenge is to rethink,

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:45.958
fundamentally,

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:49.958
the issue of the time.

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:53.958
Do we need to repeat

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:55.958
the modalities that we have inherited?

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:58.958
Our educational systems are inherited from the 19th century.

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:04.958
What is it that we need to do fundamentally

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:06.958
to re-engage in a project,

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:09.958
that capital formation is rapid?

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:12.958
The absolute majority of the world's population

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:14.958
are below 20,

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:17.958
and they are growing larger and faster.

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:20.958
They need different ways

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:22.958
of being approached,

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:25.958
different ways of being enfranchised,

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:27.958
different ways of being skilled.

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:29.958
And that's the first thing.

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:32.958
Second is, you're problem solvers,

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:35.958
but you're not engaging your global responsibility.

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:39.958
You've stayed away

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:41.958
from the problems of corruption.

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:44.958
You only want clean environments in which to function.

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:47.958
But if you don't think through the problems of corruption,

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:50.958
who will?

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:53.958
You stay away from design for development.

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:56.958
You're great designers,

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:59.958
but your designs are selfish.

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:02.958
It's for your own immediate use.

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:05.958
The world in which I operate

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:07.958
operates with designs

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:09.958
regarding roads, or dams,

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:11.958
or provision of electricity

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:14.958
that have not been revisited in 60 years.

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:18.958
This is not right. It requires thinking.

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:20.958
But, particularly, what we need

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:22.958
more than anything else from this group

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:24.958
is your imagination

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:26.958
to be brought to bear on problems

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:29.958
the way a meme is supposed to work.

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:33.958
As the work on paradigms, long time ago showed --

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:35.958
Thomas Kuhn's work --

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:37.958
it's in the intersection of ideas

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:39.958
that new developments --

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:41.958
true breakthroughs -- occur.

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:43.958
And I hope that this group

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:46.958
would be able to deal with the issue of state and development

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:48.958
and the empowerment of the majority of the world's poor,

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:50.958
through this means.

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:52.958
Thank you.

00:09:52.958 --> 00:10:00.958
(Applause)

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:04.958
Chris Anderson: So, Ashraf, until recently,

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:06.958
you were the finance minister of Afghanistan,

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:08.958
a country right at the middle

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:10.958
of much of the world's agenda.

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:12.958
Is the country gonna make it?

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:15.958
Will democracy flourish? What scares you most?

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:19.958
Ashraf Ghani: What scares me most is -- is you,

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:21.958
lack of your engagement.

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:26.958
(Laughter)

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:29.958
You asked me. You know I always give the unconventional answer.

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:31.958
No. But seriously,

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:33.958
the issue of Afghanistan

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:35.958
first has to be seen as,

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:38.958
at least, a 10- to 20-year perspective.

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:41.958
Today the world of globalization

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:43.958
is on speed.

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:45.958
Time has been compressed.

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:48.958
And space does not exist for most people.

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:50.958
But in my world --

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:53.958
you know, when I went back to Afghanistan after 23 years,

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:55.958
space had expanded.

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:58.958
Every conceivable form of infrastructure had broken down.

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:00.958
I rode -- traveled --

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:03.958
travel between two cities that used to take three hours

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:05.958
now took 12.

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:08.958
So the first is when the scale is that,

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:10.958
we need to recognize

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:13.958
that just the simple things that are infrastructure --

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:15.958
it takes six years to deliver infrastructure.

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:17.958
In our world.

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:20.958
Any meaningful sort of thing.

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:23.958
But the modality of attention,

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:26.958
or what is happening today, what's happening tomorrow.

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:28.958
Second is,

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:31.958
when a country has been subjected

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:34.958
to one of the most immense, brutal forms of exercise of power --

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:36.958
we had the Red Army

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:38.958
for 10 continuous years,

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:41.958
110,000 strong,

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:44.958
literally terrorizing.

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:46.958
The sky:

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:49.958
every Afghan

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:52.958
sees the sky as a source of fear.

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:55.958
We were bombed

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:58.958
practically out of existence.

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:03.958
Then, tens of thousands of people were trained in terrorism --

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:07.958
from all sides.

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:09.958
The United States, Great Britain, joined for instance,

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:11.958
Egyptian intelligence service

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:13.958
to train thousands of people

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:15.958
in resistance and urban terrorism.

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:19.958
How to turn a bicycle

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:22.958
into an instrument of terror.

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:25.958
How to turn a donkey, a carthorse, anything.

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:27.958
And the Russians, equally.

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:29.958
So, when violence erupts

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:31.958
in a country like Afghanistan,

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:33.958
it's because of that legacy.

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:35.958
But we have to understand

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:37.958
that we've been incredibly lucky.

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:40.958
I mean, I really can't believe how lucky I am here,

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:43.958
standing in front of you, speaking.

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:46.958
When I joined as finance minister,

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:50.958
I thought that the chances of my living more than three years

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:53.958
would not be more than five percent.

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:57.958
Those were the risks. They were worth it.

00:12:57.958 --> 00:12:59.958
I think we can make it,

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:01.958
and the reason we can make it

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:03.958
is because of the people.

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:06.958
You see, because, I mean -- I give you one statistic.

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:08.958
91 percent of the men in Afghanistan,

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:10.958
86 percent of the women,

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:13.958
listen to at least three radio stations a day.

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:17.958
In terms of their discourse,

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:20.958
in terms of their sophistication of knowledge of the world,

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:23.958
I think that I would dare say,

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:25.958
they're much more sophisticated

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:28.958
than rural Americans with college degrees

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:33.958
and the bulk of Europeans --

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:37.958
because the world matters to them.

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:39.958
And what is their predominant concern?

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:41.958
Abandonment.

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:45.958
Afghans have become deeply internationalist.

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:47.958
You know, when I went back in December of 2001,

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:50.958
I had absolutely no desire to work with the Afghan government

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:52.958
because I'd lived as a nationalist.

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:55.958
And I told them -- my people, with the Americans here --

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:57.958
separate.

00:13:57.958 --> 00:14:00.958
Yes, I have an advisory position with the U.N.

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:02.958
I went through 10 Afghan provinces very rapidly.

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:05.958
And everybody was telling me it was a different world.

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:07.958
You know, they engage.

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:10.958
They see engagement, global engagement,

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:13.958
as absolutely necessary to the future of the ordinary people.

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:16.958
And the thing that the ordinary Afghan is most concerned with is --

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:18.958
Clare Lockhart is here,

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:20.958
so I'll recite a discussion she had

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:23.958
with an illiterate woman in Northern Afghanistan.

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:25.958
And that woman said she didn't care

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:27.958
whether she had food on her table.

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:30.958
What she worried about was whether there was a plan for the future,

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:33.958
where her children could really have a different life.

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:36.958
That gives me hope.

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:39.958
CA: How is Afghanistan

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:41.958
going to provide alternative income

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:43.958
to the many people

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:45.958
who are making their living off the drugs trade?

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:47.958
AG: Certainly. Well, the first is,

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:50.958
instead of sending a billion dollars

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:52.958
on drug eradication

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:55.958
and paying it to a couple of security companies,

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:57.958
they should give this hundred billion dollars

00:14:57.958 --> 00:14:59.958
to 50

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:04.958
of the most critically innovative companies in the world

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:07.958
to ask them to create one million jobs.

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:09.958
The key to the drug eradication is jobs.

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:11.958
Look, there's a very little known fact:

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:14.958
countries that have a legal average income per capita of 1,000 dollars

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:16.958
don't produce drugs.

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:21.958
Second, textile.

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:24.958
Trade is the key, not aid.

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:26.958
The U.S. and Europe

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:28.958
should give us a zero percent tariff.

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:31.958
The textile industry is incredibly mobile.

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:34.958
If you want us to be able to compete with China and to attract investment,

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:36.958
we could probably attract

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:38.958
four to six billion dollars

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:40.958
quite easily in the textile sector,

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:42.958
if there was zero tariffs --

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:45.958
would create the type of job.

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:48.958
Cotton does not compete with opium;

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:50.958
a t-shirt does.

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:54.958
And we need to understand, it's the value chain.

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:57.958
Look, the ordinary Afghan is sick and tired

00:15:57.958 --> 00:15:59.958
of hearing about microcredit.

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:02.958
It is important,

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:05.958
but what the ordinary women and men who engage in micro-production want

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:07.958
is global access.

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:11.958
They don't want to sell to the charity bazaars

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:14.958
that are only for foreigners --

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:17.958
and the same bloody shirt

00:16:17.958 --> 00:16:19.958
embroidered time and again.

00:16:19.958 --> 00:16:21.958
What we want is a partnership

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:23.958
with the Italian design firms.

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:28.958
Yeah, we have the best embroiderers in the world!

00:16:29.958 --> 00:16:31.958
Why can't we do what was done with northern Italy?

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:34.958
With the Put Out system?

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:37.958
So I think economically,

00:16:37.958 --> 00:16:40.958
the critical issue really is to now think through.

00:16:40.958 --> 00:16:43.958
And what I will say here is that aid doesn't work.

00:16:43.958 --> 00:16:46.958
You know, the aid system is broken.

00:16:46.958 --> 00:16:48.958
The aid system does not have the knowledge,

00:16:48.958 --> 00:16:50.958
the vision, the ability.

00:16:50.958 --> 00:16:53.958
I'm all for it; after all, I raised a lot of it.

00:16:53.958 --> 00:16:55.958
Yeah, to be exact, you know,

00:16:55.958 --> 00:16:57.958
I managed to persuade the world that

00:16:57.958 --> 00:16:59.958
they had to give my country 27.5 billion.

00:16:59.958 --> 00:17:01.958
They didn't want to give us the money.

00:17:01.958 --> 00:17:03.958
CA: And it still didn't work?

00:17:03.958 --> 00:17:05.958
AG: No. It's not that it didn't work.

00:17:05.958 --> 00:17:07.958
It's that a dollar of private investment,

00:17:07.958 --> 00:17:09.958
in my judgment,

00:17:09.958 --> 00:17:12.958
is equal at least to 20 dollars of aid,

00:17:12.958 --> 00:17:15.958
in terms of the dynamic that it generates.

00:17:15.958 --> 00:17:18.958
Second is that one dollar of aid could be 10 cents;

00:17:18.958 --> 00:17:20.958
it could be 20 cents;

00:17:20.958 --> 00:17:22.958
or it could be four dollars.

00:17:22.958 --> 00:17:24.958
It depends on what form it comes,

00:17:24.958 --> 00:17:27.958
what degrees of conditionalities are attached to it.

00:17:27.958 --> 00:17:30.958
You know, the aid system, at first, was designed to benefit

00:17:30.958 --> 00:17:32.958
entrepreneurs of the developed countries,

00:17:32.958 --> 00:17:36.958
not to generate growth in the poor countries.

00:17:37.958 --> 00:17:39.958
And this is, again, one of those assumptions --

00:17:39.958 --> 00:17:42.958
the way car seats are an assumption

00:17:42.958 --> 00:17:45.958
that we've inherited in governments, and doors.

00:17:45.958 --> 00:17:47.958
You would think that the US government

00:17:47.958 --> 00:17:50.958
would not think that American firms needed subsidizing

00:17:50.958 --> 00:17:53.958

title: The real future of space exploration
transcript: I want to start off by saying, Houston, we have a problem. We're entering a second generation of no progress in terms of human flight in space. In fact, we've regressed. We stand a very big chance of losing our ability to inspire our youth to go out and continue this very important thing that we as a species have always done. And that is, instinctively we've gone out and climbed over difficult places, went to more hostile places, and found out later, maybe to our surprise, that that's the reason we survived. And I feel very strongly that it's not good enough for us to have generations of kids that think that it's OK to look forward to a better version of a cell phone with a video in it. They need to look forward to exploration; they need to look forward to colonization; they need to look forward to breakthroughs. We need to inspire them, because they need to lead us and help us survive in the future.I'm particularly troubled that what NASA's doing right now with this new Bush doctrine to — for this next decade and a half — oh shoot, I screwed up. We have real specific instructions here not to talk about politics.(Laughter)What we're looking forward to is —(Applause)what we're looking forward to is not only the inspiration of our children, but the current plan right now is not really even allowing the most creative people in this country — the Boeing's and Lockheed's space engineers — to go out and take risks and try new stuff. We're going to go back to the moon ... 50 years later? And we're going to do it very specifically planned to not learn anything new. I'm really troubled by that. But anyway that's — the basis of the thing that I want to share with you today, though, is that right back to where we inspire people who will be our great leaders later. That's the theme of my next 15 minutes here. And I think that the inspiration begins when you're very young: three-year-olds, up to 12-, 14-year-olds. What they look at is the most important thing.Let's take a snapshot at aviation. And there was a wonderful little short four-year time period when marvelous things happened. It started in 1908, when the Wright brothers flew in Paris, and everybody said, "Ooh, hey, I can do that." There's only a few people that have flown in early 1908. In four years, 39 countries had hundreds of airplanes, thousand of pilots. Airplanes were invented by natural selection. Now you can say that intelligent design designs our airplanes of today, but there was no intelligent design really designing those early airplanes. There were probably at least 30,000 different things tried, and when they crash and kill the pilot, don't try that again. The ones that flew and landed OK because there were no trained pilots who had good flying qualities by definition. So we, by making a whole bunch of attempts, thousands of attempts, in that four-year time period, we invented the concepts of the airplanes that we fly today. And that's why they're so safe, as we gave it a lot of chance to find what's good. That has not happened at all in space flying. There's only been two concepts tried — two by the U.S. and one by the Russians.Well, who was inspired during that time period? Aviation Week asked me to make a list of who I thought were the movers and shakers of the first 100 years of aviation. And I wrote them down and I found out later that every one of them was a little kid in that wonderful renaissance of aviation. Well, what happened when I was a little kid was — some pretty heavy stuff too. The jet age started: the missile age started. Von Braun was on there showing how to go to Mars — and this was before Sputnik. And this was at a time when Mars was a hell of a lot more interesting than it is now. We thought there'd be animals there; we knew there were plants there; the colors change, right? But, you know, NASA screwed that up because they've sent these robots and they've landed it only in the deserts.(Laughter)If you look at what happened — this little black line is as fast as man ever flew, and the red line is top-of-the-line military fighters and the blue line is commercial air transport. You notice here's a big jump when I was a little kid — and I think that had something to do with giving me the courage to go out and try something that other people weren't having the courage to try. Well, what did I do when I was a kid? I didn't do the hotrods and the girls and the dancing and, well, we didn't have drugs in those days. But I did competition model airplanes. I spent about seven years during the Vietnam War flight-testing airplanes for the Air Force. And then I went in and I had a lot of fun building airplanes that people could build in their garages. And some 3,000 of those are flying. Of course, one of them is around the world Voyager. I founded another company in '82, which is my company now. And we have developed more than one new type of airplane every year since 1982. And there's a lot of them that I actually can't show you on this chart.The most impressive airplane ever, I believe, was designed only a dozen years after the first operational jet. Stayed in service till it was too rusty to fly, taken out of service. We retreated in '98 back to something that was developed in '56. What? The most impressive spaceship ever, I believe, was a Grumman Lunar Lander. It was a — you know, it landed on the moon, take off of the moon, didn't need any maintenance guys — that's kind of cool. We've lost that capability. We abandoned it in '72. This thing was designed three years after Gagarin first flew in space in 1961. Three years, and we can't do that now. Crazy.Talk very briefly about innovation cycles, things that grow, have a lot of activity; they die out when they're replaced by something else. These things tend to happen every 25 years. 40 years long, with an overlap. You can put that statement on all kinds of different technologies. The interesting thing — by the way, the speed here, excuse me, higher-speed travel is the title of these innovation cycles. There is none here. These two new airplanes are the same speed as the DC8 that was done in 1958. Here's the biggie, and that is, you don't have innovation cycles if the government develops and the government uses it. You know, a good example, of course, is the DARPA net. Computers were used for artillery first, then IRS. But when we got it, now you have all the level of activity, all the benefit from it. Private sector has to do it. Keep that in mind. I put down innovation — I've looked for innovation cycles in space; I found none.The very first year, starting when Gagarin went in space, and a few weeks later Alan Shepherd, there were five manned space flights in the world — the very first year. In 2003, everyone that the United States sent to space was killed. There were only three or four flights in 2003. In 2004, there were only two flights: two Russian Soyuz flights to the international manned station. And I had to fly three in Mojave with my little group of a couple dozen people in order to get to a total of five, which was the number the same year back in 1961. There is no growth. There's no activity. There's no nothing.This is a picture here taken from SpaceShipOne. This is a picture here taken from orbit. Our goal is to make it so that you can see this picture and really enjoy that. We know how to do it for sub-orbital flying now, do it safe enough — at least as safe as the early airlines — so that can be done. And I think I want to talk a little bit about why we had the courage to go out and try that as a small company.Well, first of all, what's going to happen next? The first industry will be a high volume, a lot of players. There's another one announced just last week. And it will be sub-orbital. And the reason it has to be sub-orbital is, there is not solutions for adequate safety to fly the public to orbit. The governments have been doing this — three governments have been doing this for 45 years, and still four percent of the people that have left the atmosphere have died. That's — You don't want to run a business with that kind of a safety record. It'll be very high volume; we think 100,000 people will fly by 2020. I can't tell you when this will start, because I don't want my competition to know my schedule. But I think once it does, we will find solutions, and very quickly, you'll see those resort hotels in orbit. And that real easy thing to do, which is a swing around the moon so you have this cool view. And that will be really cool. Because the moon doesn't have an atmosphere — you can do an elliptical orbit and miss it by 10 feet if you want. Oh, it's going to be so much fun.(Laughter)OK. My critics say, "Hey, Rutan's just spending a lot of these billionaires' money for joyrides for billionaires. What's this? This is not a transportation system; it's just for fun." And I used to be bothered by that, and then I got to thinking, well, wait a minute. I bought my first Apple computer in 1978 and I bought it because I could say, "I got a computer at my house and you don't. 'What do you use it for?' Come over. It does Frogger." OK.(Laughter)Not the bank's computer or Lockheed's computer, but the home computer was for games. For a whole decade it was for fun — we didn't even know what it was for. But what happened, the fact that we had this big industry, big development, big improvement and capability and so on, and they get out there in enough homes — we were ripe for a new invention. And the inventor is in this audience. Al Gore invented the Internet and because of that, something that we used for a whole year — excuse me — a whole decade for fun, became everything — our commerce, our research, our communication and, if we let the Google guys think for another couple weekends, we can add a dozen more things to the list. (Laughter) And it won't be very long before you won't be able to convince kids that we didn't always have computers in our homes. So fun is defendable.OK, I want to show you kind of a busy chart, but in it is my prediction with what's going to happen. And in it also brings up another point, right here. There's a group of people that have come forward — and you don't know all of them — but the ones that have come forward were inspired as young children, this little three- to 15-year-old age, by us going to orbit and going to the moon here, right in this time period. Paul Allen, Elan Musk, Richard Branson, Jeff Bezos, the Ansari family, which is now funding the Russians' sub-orbital thing, Bob Bigelow, a private space station, and Carmack. These people are taking money and putting it in an interesting area, and I think it's a lot better than they put it in an area of a better cell phone or something — but they're putting it in very — areas and this will lead us into this kind of capability, and it will lead us into the next really big thing and it will allow us to explore. And I think eventually it will allow us to colonize and to keep us from going extinct.They were inspired by big progress. But look at the progress that's going on after that. There were a couple of examples here. The military fighters had a — highest-performance military airplane was the SR71. It went a whole life cycle, got too rusty to fly, and was taken out of service. The Concorde doubled the speed for airline travel. It went a whole life cycle without competition, took out of service. And we're stuck back here with the same kind of capability for military fighters and commercial airline travel that we had back in the late '50s.But something is out there to inspire our kids now. And I'm talking about if you've got a baby now, or if you've got a 10-year-old now. What's out there is there's something really interesting going to happen here. Relatively soon, you'll be able to buy a ticket and fly higher and faster than the highest-performance military operational airplane. It's never happened before. The fact that they have stuck here with this kind of performance has been, well, you know, you win the war in 12 minutes; why do you need something better? But I think when you guys start buying tickets and flying sub-orbital flights to space, very soon — wait a minute, what's happening here, we'll have military fighters with sub-orbital capability, and I think very soon this. But the interesting thing about it is the commercial guys are going to go first. OK, I look forward to a new "capitalist's space race," let's call it.You remember the space race in the '60s was for national prestige, because we lost the first two milestones. We didn't lose them technically. The fact that we had the hardware to put something in orbit when we let Von Braun fly it — you can argue that's not a technical loss. Sputnik wasn't a technical loss, but it was a prestige loss. America — the world saw America as not being the leader in technology, and that was a very strong thing. And then we flew Alan Shepherd weeks after Gagarin, not months or decades, or whatever. So we had the capability. But America lost. We lost. And because of that, we made a big jump to recover it.Well, again, what's interesting here is we've lost to the Russians on the first couple of milestones already. You cannot buy a ticket commercially to fly into space in America — can't do it. You can buy it in Russia. You can fly with Russian hardware. This is available because a Russian space program is starving, and it's nice for them to get 20 million here and there to take one of the seats. It's commercial. It can be defined as space tourism. They are also offering a trip to go on this whip around the moon, like Apollo 8 was done. 100 million bucks — hey, I can go to the moon. But, you know, would you have thought back in the '60s, when the space race was going on, that the first commercial capitalist-like thing to do to buy a ticket to go to the moon would be in Russian hardware? And would you have thought, would the Russians have thought, that when they first go to the moon in their developed hardware, the guys inside won't be Russians? Maybe it'll probably be a Japanese or an American billionaire? Well, that's weird: you know, it really is. But anyway, I think we need to beat them again.I think what we'll do is we'll see a successful, very successful, private space flight industry. Whether we're first or not really doesn't matter. The Russians actually flew a supersonic transport before the Concorde. And then they flew a few cargo flights, and took it out of service. I think you kind of see the same kind of parallel when the commercial stuff is offered.OK, we'll talk just a little bit about commercial development for human space flight. This little thing says here: five times what NASA's doing by 2020. I want to tell you, already there's about 1.5 billion to 1.7 billion investment in private space flight that is not government at all — already, worldwide. If you read — if you Google it, you'll find about half of that money, but there's twice of that being committed out there — not spent yet, but being committed and planned for the next few years. Hey, that's pretty big. I'm predicting, though, as profitable as this industry is going to be — and it certainly is profitable when you fly people at 200,000 dollars on something that you can actually operate at a tenth of that cost, or less — this is going to be very profitable. I predict, also, that the investment that will flow into this will be somewhere around half of what the U.S. taxpayer spends for NASA's manned spacecraft work. And every dollar that flows into that will be spent more efficiently by a factor of 10 to 15. And what that means is before we know it, the progress in human space flight, with no taxpayer dollars, will be at a level of about five times as much as the current NASA budgets for human space flight. And that is because it's us. It's private industry. You should never depend on the government to do this sort of stuff — and we've done it for a long time. The NACA, before NASA, never developed an airliner and never ran an airline. But NASA is developing the space liner, always has, and runs the only space line, OK. And we've shied away from it because we're afraid of it. But starting back in June of 2004, when I showed that a little group out there actually can do it, can get a start with it, everything changed after that time.OK, thank you very much.(Applause)

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:43.958
and a few weeks later Alan Shepherd, there were five manned

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:46.958
space flights in the world -- the very first year.

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:55.958
In 2003, everyone that the United States sent to space was killed.

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:57.958
There were only three or four flights in 2003.

00:07:57.958 --> 00:08:04.958
In 2004, there were only two flights: two Russian Soyuz flights

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:08.958
to the international manned station. And I had to fly three in Mojave

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:10.958
with my little group of a couple dozen people

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:12.958
in order to get to a total of five,

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:17.958
which was the number the same year back in 1961.

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:22.958
There is no growth. There's no activity. There's no nothing.

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:25.958
This is a picture here taken from SpaceShipOne.

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:27.958
This is a picture here taken from orbit.

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:33.958
Our goal is to make it so that you can see this picture and really enjoy that.

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:37.958
We know how to do it for sub-orbital flying now, do it safe enough --

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:41.958
at least as safe as the early airlines -- so that can be done.

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:46.958
And I think I want to talk a little bit about why we had the courage

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:53.958
to go out and try that as a small company.

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:56.958
Well, first of all, what's going to happen next?

00:08:56.958 --> 00:09:00.958
The first industry will be a high volume, a lot of players.

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:03.958
There's another one announced just last week.

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:09.958
And it will be sub-orbital. And the reason it has to be sub-orbital

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:12.958
is, there is not solutions for adequate safety

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:17.958
to fly the public to orbit. The governments have been doing this --

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:19.958
three governments have been doing this for 45 years,

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:23.958
and still four percent of the people that have left the atmosphere have died.

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:28.958
That's -- You don't want to run a business with that kind of a safety record.

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:34.958
It'll be very high volume; we think 100,000 people will fly by 2020.

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:36.958
I can't tell you when this will start,

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:39.958
because I don't want my competition to know my schedule.

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:44.958
But I think once it does, we will find solutions,

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:47.958
and very quickly, you'll see those resort hotels in orbit.

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:50.958
And that real easy thing to do, which is a swing around the moon

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:54.958
so you have this cool view. And that will be really cool.

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:56.958
Because the moon doesn't have an atmosphere --

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:59.958
you can do an elliptical orbit and miss it by 10 feet if you want.

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:01.958
Oh, it's going to be so much fun.

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:03.958
(Laughter)

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:07.958
OK. My critics say, "Hey, Rutan's just spending

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:12.958
a lot of these billionaires' money for joyrides for billionaires.

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:17.958
What's this? This is not a transportation system; it's just for fun."

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:20.958
And I used to be bothered by that, and then I got to thinking,

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:25.958
well, wait a minute. I bought my first Apple computer in 1978

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:31.958
and I bought it because I could say, "I got a computer at my house and you don't.

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:36.958
'What do you use it for?' Come over. It does Frogger." OK.

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:37.958
(Laughter)

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:40.958
Not the bank's computer or Lockheed's computer,

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:43.958
but the home computer was for games.

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:47.958
