00:01:29.958 --> 00:01:31.958
there were 500 million people living in poverty --

00:01:31.958 --> 00:01:34.958
that number now is under 200 million.

00:01:34.958 --> 00:01:37.958
The World Bank projects by 2011, it will be under 20 million,

00:01:37.958 --> 00:01:40.958
which is a reduction of 95 percent.

00:01:40.958 --> 00:01:43.958
I did enjoy Bono's comment

00:01:43.958 --> 00:01:47.958
linking Haight-Ashbury to Silicon Valley.

00:01:47.958 --> 00:01:50.958
Being from the Massachusetts high-tech community myself,

00:01:50.958 --> 00:01:54.958
I'd point out that we were hippies also in the 1960s,

00:01:55.958 --> 00:01:58.958
although we hung around Harvard Square.

00:01:58.958 --> 00:02:03.958
But we do have the potential to overcome disease and poverty,

00:02:03.958 --> 00:02:06.958
and I'm going to talk about those issues, if we have the will.

00:02:06.958 --> 00:02:09.958
Kevin Kelly talked about the acceleration of technology.

00:02:09.958 --> 00:02:12.958
That's been a strong interest of mine,

00:02:12.958 --> 00:02:15.958
and a theme that I've developed for some 30 years.

00:02:15.958 --> 00:02:20.958
I realized that my technologies had to make sense when I finished a project.

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:23.958
That invariably, the world was a different place

00:02:23.958 --> 00:02:25.958
when I would introduce a technology.

00:02:25.958 --> 00:02:27.958
And, I noticed that most inventions fail,

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:30.958
not because the R&D department can't get it to work --

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:33.958
if you look at most business plans, they will actually succeed

00:02:33.958 --> 00:02:37.958
if given the opportunity to build what they say they're going to build --

00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:40.958
and 90 percent of those projects or more will fail, because the timing is wrong --

00:02:40.958 --> 00:02:43.958
not all the enabling factors will be in place when they're needed.

00:02:43.958 --> 00:02:47.958
So I began to be an ardent student of technology trends,

00:02:47.958 --> 00:02:50.958
and track where technology would be at different points in time,

00:02:50.958 --> 00:02:53.958
and began to build the mathematical models of that.

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:55.958
It's kind of taken on a life of its own.

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:58.958
I've got a group of 10 people that work with me to gather data

00:02:58.958 --> 00:03:03.958
on key measures of technology in many different areas, and we build models.

00:03:03.958 --> 00:03:06.958
And you'll hear people say, well, we can't predict the future.

00:03:06.958 --> 00:03:08.958
And if you ask me,

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:11.958
will the price of Google be higher or lower than it is today three years from now,

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:13.958
that's very hard to say.

00:03:13.958 --> 00:03:16.958
Will WiMax CDMA G3

00:03:16.958 --> 00:03:18.958
be the wireless standard three years from now? That's hard to say.

00:03:18.958 --> 00:03:20.958
But if you ask me, what will it cost

00:03:20.958 --> 00:03:23.958
for one MIPS of computing in 2010,

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:26.958
or the cost to sequence a base pair of DNA in 2012,

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:30.958
or the cost of sending a megabyte of data wirelessly in 2014,

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:33.958
it turns out that those are very predictable.

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:35.958
There are remarkably smooth exponential curves

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:38.958
that govern price performance, capacity, bandwidth.

00:03:38.958 --> 00:03:40.958
And I'm going to show you a small sample of this,

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:42.958
but there's really a theoretical reason

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:47.958
why technology develops in an exponential fashion.

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:49.958
And a lot of people, when they think about the future, think about it linearly.

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:51.958
They think they're going to continue

00:03:51.958 --> 00:03:53.958
to develop a problem

00:03:53.958 --> 00:03:56.958
or address a problem using today's tools,

00:03:56.958 --> 00:03:58.958
at today's pace of progress,

00:03:58.958 --> 00:04:02.958
and fail to take into consideration this exponential growth.

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:05.958
The Genome Project was a controversial project in 1990.

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:07.958
We had our best Ph.D. students,

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:09.958
our most advanced equipment around the world,

00:04:09.958 --> 00:04:11.958
we got 1/10,000th of the project done,

00:04:11.958 --> 00:04:13.958
so how're we going to get this done in 15 years?

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:16.958
And 10 years into the project,

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:19.958
the skeptics were still going strong -- says, "You're two-thirds through this project,

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:21.958
and you've managed to only sequence

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:24.958
a very tiny percentage of the whole genome."

00:04:24.958 --> 00:04:26.958
But it's the nature of exponential growth

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:28.958
that once it reaches the knee of the curve, it explodes.

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:30.958
Most of the project was done in the last

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:32.958
few years of the project.

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:34.958
It took us 15 years to sequence HIV --

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:36.958
we sequenced SARS in 31 days.

00:04:36.958 --> 00:04:40.958
So we are gaining the potential to overcome these problems.

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:42.958
I'm going to show you just a few examples

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:45.958
of how pervasive this phenomena is.

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:49.958
The actual paradigm-shift rate, the rate of adopting new ideas,

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:52.958
is doubling every decade, according to our models.

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:55.958
These are all logarithmic graphs,

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:58.958
so as you go up the levels it represents, generally multiplying by factor of 10 or 100.

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:01.958
It took us half a century to adopt the telephone,

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:04.958
the first virtual-reality technology.

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:06.958
Cell phones were adopted in about eight years.

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:09.958
If you put different communication technologies

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:11.958
on this logarithmic graph,

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:13.958
television, radio, telephone

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:15.958
were adopted in decades.

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:18.958
Recent technologies -- like the PC, the web, cell phones --

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:20.958
were under a decade.

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:22.958
Now this is an interesting chart,

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:24.958
and this really gets at the fundamental reason why

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:28.958
an evolutionary process -- and both biology and technology are evolutionary processes --

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:30.958
accelerate.

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:33.958
They work through interaction -- they create a capability,

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:36.958
and then it uses that capability to bring on the next stage.

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:39.958
So the first step in biological evolution,

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:41.958
the evolution of DNA -- actually it was RNA came first --

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:43.958
took billions of years,

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:46.958
but then evolution used that information-processing backbone

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:48.958
to bring on the next stage.

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:51.958
So the Cambrian Explosion, when all the body plans of the animals were evolved,

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:55.958
took only 10 million years. It was 200 times faster.

00:05:55.958 --> 00:05:57.958
And then evolution used those body plans

00:05:57.958 --> 00:05:59.958
to evolve higher cognitive functions,

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:01.958
and biological evolution kept accelerating.

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:04.958
It's an inherent nature of an evolutionary process.

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:07.958
So Homo sapiens, the first technology-creating species,

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:09.958
the species that combined a cognitive function

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:11.958
with an opposable appendage --

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:15.958
and by the way, chimpanzees don't really have a very good opposable thumb --

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:17.958
so we could actually manipulate our environment with a power grip

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:19.958
and fine motor coordination,

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:21.958
and use our mental models to actually change the world

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:23.958
and bring on technology.

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:26.958
But anyway, the evolution of our species took hundreds of thousands of years,

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:28.958
and then working through interaction,

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:30.958
evolution used, essentially,

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:33.958
the technology-creating species to bring on the next stage,

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:36.958
which were the first steps in technological evolution.

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:39.958
And the first step took tens of thousands of years --

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:42.958
stone tools, fire, the wheel -- kept accelerating.

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:44.958
We always used then the latest generation of technology

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:46.958
to create the next generation.

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:48.958
Printing press took a century to be adopted;

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:52.958
the first computers were designed pen-on-paper -- now we use computers.

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:55.958
And we've had a continual acceleration of this process.

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:58.958
Now by the way, if you look at this on a linear graph, it looks like everything has just happened,

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:04.958
but some observer says, "Well, Kurzweil just put points on this graph

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:06.958
that fall on that straight line."

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:09.958
So, I took 15 different lists from key thinkers,

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:13.958
like the Encyclopedia Britannica, the Museum of Natural History, Carl Sagan's Cosmic Calendar

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:16.958
on the same -- and these people were not trying to make my point;

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:18.958
these were just lists in reference works,

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:21.958
and I think that's what they thought the key events were

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:24.958
in biological evolution and technological evolution.

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:27.958
And again, it forms the same straight line. You have a little bit of thickening in the line

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:30.958
because people do have disagreements, what the key points are,

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:32.958
there's differences of opinion when agriculture started,

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:35.958
or how long the Cambrian Explosion took.

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:37.958
But you see a very clear trend.

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:42.958
There's a basic, profound acceleration of this evolutionary process.

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:47.958
Information technologies double their capacity, price performance, bandwidth,

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:49.958
every year.

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:53.958
And that's a very profound explosion of exponential growth.

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:55.958
A personal experience, when I was at MIT --

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:57.958
computer taking up about the size of this room,

00:07:57.958 --> 00:08:02.958
less powerful than the computer in your cell phone.

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:06.958
But Moore's Law, which is very often identified with this exponential growth,

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:08.958
is just one example of many, because it's basically

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:13.958
a property of the evolutionary process of technology.

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:16.958
I put 49 famous computers on this logarithmic graph --

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:20.958
by the way, a straight line on a logarithmic graph is exponential growth --

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:22.958
that's another exponential.

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:25.958
It took us three years to double our price performance of computing in 1900,

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:28.958
two years in the middle; we're now doubling it every one year.

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:32.958
And that's exponential growth through five different paradigms.

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:34.958
Moore's Law was just the last part of that,

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:37.958
where we were shrinking transistors on an integrated circuit,

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:40.958
but we had electro-mechanical calculators,

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:42.958
relay-based computers that cracked the German Enigma Code,

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:46.958
vacuum tubes in the 1950s predicted the election of Eisenhower,

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:49.958
discreet transistors used in the first space flights

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:51.958
and then Moore's Law.

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:53.958
Every time one paradigm ran out of steam,

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:56.958
another paradigm came out of left field to continue the exponential growth.

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:59.958
They were shrinking vacuum tubes, making them smaller and smaller.

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:02.958
That hit a wall. They couldn't shrink them and keep the vacuum.

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:04.958
Whole different paradigm -- transistors came out of the woodwork.

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:07.958
In fact, when we see the end of the line for a particular paradigm,

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:11.958
it creates research pressure to create the next paradigm.

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:14.958
And because we've been predicting the end of Moore's Law

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:17.958
for quite a long time -- the first prediction said 2002, until now it says 2022.

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:20.958
But by the teen years,

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:23.958
the features of transistors will be a few atoms in width,

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:25.958
and we won't be able to shrink them any more.

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:28.958
That'll be the end of Moore's Law, but it won't be the end of

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:30.958
the exponential growth of computing, because chips are flat.

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:33.958
We live in a three-dimensional world; we might as well use the third dimension.

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:35.958
We will go into the third dimension

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:38.958
and there's been tremendous progress, just in the last few years,

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:42.958
of getting three-dimensional, self-organizing molecular circuits to work.

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:49.958
We'll have those ready well before Moore's Law runs out of steam.

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:51.958
Supercomputers -- same thing.

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:55.958
Processor performance on Intel chips,

00:09:55.958 --> 00:09:58.958
the average price of a transistor --

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:01.958
1968, you could buy one transistor for a dollar.

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:04.958
You could buy 10 million in 2002.

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:07.958
It's pretty remarkable how smooth

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:09.958
an exponential process that is.

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:12.958
I mean, you'd think this is the result of some tabletop experiment,

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:16.958
but this is the result of worldwide chaotic behavior --

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:18.958
countries accusing each other of dumping products,

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:20.958
IPOs, bankruptcies, marketing programs.

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:23.958
You would think it would be a very erratic process,

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:25.958
and you have a very smooth

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:27.958
outcome of this chaotic process.

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:29.958
Just as we can't predict

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:31.958
what one molecule in a gas will do --

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:34.958
it's hopeless to predict a single molecule --

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:36.958
yet we can predict the properties of the whole gas,

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:39.958
using thermodynamics, very accurately.

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:42.958
It's the same thing here. We can't predict any particular project,

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:44.958
but the result of this whole worldwide,

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:49.958
chaotic, unpredictable activity of competition

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:52.958
and the evolutionary process of technology is very predictable.

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:55.958
And we can predict these trends far into the future.

00:10:57.958 --> 00:10:59.958
Unlike Gertrude Stein's roses,

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:01.958
it's not the case that a transistor is a transistor.

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:03.958
As we make them smaller and less expensive,

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:05.958
the electrons have less distance to travel.

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:09.958
They're faster, so you've got exponential growth in the speed of transistors,

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:13.958
so the cost of a cycle of one transistor

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:16.958
has been coming down with a halving rate of 1.1 years.

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:19.958
You add other forms of innovation and processor design,

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:23.958
you get a doubling of price performance of computing every one year.

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:26.958
And that's basically deflation --

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:28.958
50 percent deflation.

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:31.958
And it's not just computers. I mean, it's true of DNA sequencing;

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:33.958
it's true of brain scanning;

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:35.958
it's true of the World Wide Web. I mean, anything that we can quantify,

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:38.958
we have hundreds of different measurements

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:41.958
of different, information-related measurements --

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:43.958
capacity, adoption rates --

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:46.958
and they basically double every 12, 13, 15 months,

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:48.958
depending on what you're looking at.

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:52.958
In terms of price performance, that's a 40 to 50 percent deflation rate.

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:55.958
And economists have actually started worrying about that. 


00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:57.958
We had deflation during the Depression,

00:11:57.958 --> 00:11:59.958
but that was collapse of the money supply,

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:02.958
collapse of consumer confidence, a completely different phenomena.

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:04.958
This is due to greater productivity,

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:07.958
but the economist says, "But there's no way you're going to be able to keep up with that.

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:10.958
If you have 50 percent deflation, people may increase their volume

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:12.958
30, 40 percent, but they won't keep up with it."

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:14.958
But what we're actually seeing is that

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:16.958
we actually more than keep up with it.

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:19.958
We've had 28 percent per year compounded growth in dollars

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:22.958
in information technology over the last 50 years.

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:26.958
I mean, people didn't build iPods for 10,000 dollars 10 years ago.

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:29.958
As the price performance makes new applications feasible,

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:31.958
new applications come to the market.

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:34.958
And this is a very widespread phenomena.

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:36.958
Magnetic data storage --

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:39.958
that's not Moore's Law, it's shrinking magnetic spots,

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:43.958
different engineers, different companies, same exponential process.

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:47.958
A key revolution is that we're understanding our own biology

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:49.958
in these information terms.

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:51.958
We're understanding the software programs

00:12:51.958 --> 00:12:53.958
that make our body run.

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:55.958
These were evolved in very different times --

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:57.958
we'd like to actually change those programs.

00:12:57.958 --> 00:12:59.958
One little software program, called the fat insulin receptor gene,

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:01.958
basically says, "Hold onto every calorie,

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:05.958
because the next hunting season may not work out so well."

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:08.958
That was in the interests of the species tens of thousands of years ago.

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:11.958
We'd like to actually turn that program off.

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:14.958
They tried that in animals, and these mice ate ravenously

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:16.958
and remained slim and got the health benefits of being slim.

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:19.958
They didn't get diabetes; they didn't get heart disease;

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:22.958
they lived 20 percent longer; they got the health benefits of caloric restriction

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:24.958
without the restriction.

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:27.958
Four or five pharmaceutical companies have noticed this,

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:30.958
felt that would be

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:33.958
interesting drug for the human market,

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:35.958
and that's just one of the 30,000 genes

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:38.958
that affect our biochemistry.

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:41.958
We were evolved in an era where it wasn't in the interests of people

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:44.958
at the age of most people at this conference, like myself,

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:48.958
to live much longer, because we were using up the precious resources

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:49.958
which were better deployed towards the children

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:51.958
and those caring for them.

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:53.958
So, life -- long lifespans --

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:55.958
like, that is to say, much more than 30 --

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:58.958
weren't selected for,

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:01.958
but we are learning to actually manipulate

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:03.958
and change these software programs

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:05.958
through the biotechnology revolution.

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:09.958
For example, we can inhibit genes now with RNA interference.

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:11.958
There are exciting new forms of gene therapy

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:13.958
that overcome the problem of placing the genetic material

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:15.958
in the right place on the chromosome.

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:18.958
There's actually a -- for the first time now,

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:21.958
something going to human trials, that actually cures pulmonary hypertension --

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:24.958
a fatal disease -- using gene therapy.

00:14:24.958 --> 00:14:27.958
So we'll have not just designer babies, but designer baby boomers.

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:30.958
And this technology is also accelerating.

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:33.958
It cost 10 dollars per base pair in 1990,

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:35.958
then a penny in 2000.

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:37.958
It's now under a 10th of a cent.

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:39.958
The amount of genetic data --

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:42.958
basically this shows that smooth exponential growth

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:44.958
doubled every year,

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:47.958
enabling the genome project to be completed.

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:50.958
Another major revolution: the communications revolution.

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:55.958
The price performance, bandwidth, capacity of communications measured many different ways;

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:58.958
wired, wireless is growing exponentially.

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:01.958
The Internet has been doubling in power and continues to,

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:03.958
measured many different ways.

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:05.958
This is based on the number of hosts.

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:07.958
Miniaturization -- we're shrinking the size of technology

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:09.958
at an exponential rate,

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:11.958
both wired and wireless.

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:15.958
These are some designs from Eric Drexler's book --

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:17.958
which we're now showing are feasible

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:19.958
with super-computing simulations,

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:21.958
where actually there are scientists building

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:23.958
molecule-scale robots.

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:25.958
One has one that actually walks with a surprisingly human-like gait,

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:28.958
that's built out of molecules.

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:32.958
There are little machines doing things in experimental bases.

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:35.958
The most exciting opportunity

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:37.958
is actually to go inside the human body

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:40.958
and perform therapeutic and diagnostic functions.

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:42.958
And this is less futuristic than it may sound.

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:44.958
These things have already been done in animals.

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:48.958
There's one nano-engineered device that cures type 1 diabetes. It's blood cell-sized.

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:50.958
They put tens of thousands of these

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:52.958
in the blood cell -- they tried this in rats --

00:15:52.958 --> 00:15:54.958
it lets insulin out in a controlled fashion,

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:56.958
and actually cures type 1 diabetes.

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:59.958
What you're watching is a design

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:01.958
of a robotic red blood cell,

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:03.958
and it does bring up the issue that our biology

00:16:03.958 --> 00:16:05.958
is actually very sub-optimal,

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:08.958
even though it's remarkable in its intricacy.

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:11.958
Once we understand its principles of operation,

00:16:11.958 --> 00:16:14.958
and the pace with which we are reverse-engineering biology is accelerating,

00:16:15.958 --> 00:16:17.958
we can actually design these things to be

00:16:17.958 --> 00:16:19.958
thousands of times more capable.

00:16:19.958 --> 00:16:23.958
An analysis of this respirocyte, designed by Rob Freitas,

00:16:24.958 --> 00:16:26.958
indicates if you replace 10 percent of your red blood cells with these robotic versions,

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:30.958
you could do an Olympic sprint for 15 minutes without taking a breath.

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:33.958
You could sit at the bottom of your pool for four hours --

00:16:33.958 --> 00:16:37.958
so, "Honey, I'm in the pool," will take on a whole new meaning.

00:16:37.958 --> 00:16:39.958
It will be interesting to see what we do in our Olympic trials.

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:41.958
Presumably we'll ban them,

00:16:41.958 --> 00:16:43.958
but then we'll have the specter of teenagers in their high schools gyms

00:16:43.958 --> 00:16:46.958
routinely out-performing the Olympic athletes.

00:16:48.958 --> 00:16:51.958
Freitas has a design for a robotic white blood cell.

00:16:51.958 --> 00:16:55.958
These are 2020-circa scenarios,

00:16:55.958 --> 00:16:57.958
but they're not as futuristic as it may sound.

00:16:57.958 --> 00:17:01.958
There are four major conferences on building blood cell-sized devices;

00:17:01.958 --> 00:17:03.958
there are many experiments in animals.

00:17:03.958 --> 00:17:05.958
There's actually one going into human trial,

00:17:05.958 --> 00:17:08.958
so this is feasible technology.

00:17:09.958 --> 00:17:11.958
If we come back to our exponential growth of computing,

00:17:11.958 --> 00:17:14.958
1,000 dollars of computing is now somewhere between an insect and a mouse brain.

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:17.958
It will intersect human intelligence

00:17:17.958 --> 00:17:20.958
in terms of capacity in the 2020s,

00:17:20.958 --> 00:17:22.958
but that'll be the hardware side of the equation.

00:17:22.958 --> 00:17:24.958
Where will we get the software?

00:17:24.958 --> 00:17:26.958
Well, it turns out we can see inside the human brain,

00:17:26.958 --> 00:17:28.958
and in fact not surprisingly,

00:17:28.958 --> 00:17:32.958
the spatial and temporal resolution of brain scanning is doubling every year.

00:17:32.958 --> 00:17:34.958
And with the new generation of scanning tools,

00:17:34.958 --> 00:17:36.958
for the first time we can actually see

00:17:36.958 --> 00:17:38.958
individual inter-neural fibers

00:17:38.958 --> 00:17:41.958
and see them processing and signaling in real time --

00:17:41.958 --> 00:17:43.958
but then the question is, OK, we can get this data now,

00:17:43.958 --> 00:17:45.958
but can we understand it?

00:17:45.958 --> 00:17:48.958
Doug Hofstadter wonders, well, maybe our intelligence

00:17:48.958 --> 00:17:51.958
just isn't great enough to understand our intelligence,

00:17:51.958 --> 00:17:54.958
and if we were smarter, well, then our brains would be that much more complicated,

00:17:54.958 --> 00:17:56.958
and we'd never catch up to it.

00:17:57.958 --> 00:18:00.958
It turns out that we can understand it.

00:18:00.958 --> 00:18:03.958
This is a block diagram of

00:18:03.958 --> 00:18:07.958
a model and simulation of the human auditory cortex

00:18:07.958 --> 00:18:09.958
that actually works quite well --

00:18:09.958 --> 00:18:11.958
in applying psychoacoustic tests, gets very similar results to human auditory perception.

00:18:13.958 --> 00:18:16.958
There's another simulation of the cerebellum --

00:18:16.958 --> 00:18:18.958
that's more than half the neurons in the brain --

00:18:18.958 --> 00:18:21.958
again, works very similarly to human skill formation.

00:18:22.958 --> 00:18:25.958
This is at an early stage, but you can show

00:18:25.958 --> 00:18:28.958
with the exponential growth of the amount of information about the brain

00:18:28.958 --> 00:18:30.958
and the exponential improvement

00:18:30.958 --> 00:18:32.958
in the resolution of brain scanning,

00:18:32.958 --> 00:18:35.958
we will succeed in reverse-engineering the human brain

00:18:35.958 --> 00:18:37.958
by the 2020s.

00:18:37.958 --> 00:18:40.958
We've already had very good models and simulation of about 15 regions

00:18:40.958 --> 00:18:43.958
out of the several hundred.

00:18:43.958 --> 00:18:45.958
All of this is driving

00:18:45.958 --> 00:18:47.958
exponentially growing economic progress.

00:18:47.958 --> 00:18:50.958
We've had productivity go from 30 dollars to 150 dollars per hour

00:18:52.958 --> 00:18:54.958
of labor in the last 50 years.

00:18:54.958 --> 00:18:57.958
E-commerce has been growing exponentially. It's now a trillion dollars.

00:18:57.958 --> 00:18:59.958
You might wonder, well, wasn't there a boom and a bust?

00:18:59.958 --> 00:19:01.958
That was strictly a capital-markets phenomena.

00:19:01.958 --> 00:19:05.958
Wall Street noticed that this was a revolutionary technology, which it was,

00:19:05.958 --> 00:19:08.958
but then six months later, when it hadn't revolutionized all business models,

00:19:08.958 --> 00:19:10.958
they figured, well, that was wrong,

00:19:10.958 --> 00:19:12.958
and then we had this bust.

00:19:13.958 --> 00:19:15.958
All right, this is a technology

00:19:15.958 --> 00:19:18.958
that we put together using some of the technologies we're involved in.

00:19:18.958 --> 00:19:22.958
This will be a routine feature in a cell phone.

00:19:22.958 --> 00:19:24.958
It would be able to translate from one language to another.

00:19:34.958 --> 00:19:36.958
So let me just end with a couple of scenarios.

00:19:36.958 --> 00:19:39.958
By 2010 computers will disappear.

00:19:40.958 --> 00:19:43.958
They'll be so small, they'll be embedded in our clothing, in our environment.

00:19:43.958 --> 00:19:45.958
Images will be written directly to our retina,

00:19:45.958 --> 00:19:47.958
providing full-immersion virtual reality,

00:19:47.958 --> 00:19:50.958
augmented real reality. We'll be interacting with virtual personalities.

00:19:51.958 --> 00:19:55.958
But if we go to 2029, we really have the full maturity of these trends,

00:19:55.958 --> 00:19:58.958
and you have to appreciate how many turns of the screw

00:19:58.958 --> 00:20:02.958
in terms of generations of technology, which are getting faster and faster, we'll have at that point.

00:20:02.958 --> 00:20:04.958
I mean, we will have two-to-the-25th-power

00:20:04.958 --> 00:20:07.958
greater price performance, capacity and bandwidth

00:20:07.958 --> 00:20:09.958
of these technologies, which is pretty phenomenal.

00:20:09.958 --> 00:20:11.958
It'll be millions of times more powerful than it is today.

00:20:11.958 --> 00:20:13.958
We'll have completed the reverse-engineering of the human brain,

00:20:14.958 --> 00:20:17.958
1,000 dollars of computing will be far more powerful

00:20:17.958 --> 00:20:21.958
than the human brain in terms of basic raw capacity.

00:20:21.958 --> 00:20:23.958
Computers will combine

00:20:23.958 --> 00:20:25.958
the subtle pan-recognition powers

00:20:25.958 --> 00:20:28.958
of human intelligence with ways in which machines are already superior,

00:20:28.958 --> 00:20:30.958
in terms of doing analytic thinking,

00:20:30.958 --> 00:20:32.958
remembering billions of facts accurately.

00:20:32.958 --> 00:20:34.958
Machines can share their knowledge very quickly.

00:20:34.958 --> 00:20:39.958
But it's not just an alien invasion of intelligent machines.

00:20:39.958 --> 00:20:41.958
We are going to merge with our technology.

00:20:41.958 --> 00:20:43.958
These nano-bots I mentioned

00:20:43.958 --> 00:20:47.958
will first be used for medical and health applications:

00:20:47.958 --> 00:20:50.958
cleaning up the environment, providing powerful fuel cells

00:20:50.958 --> 00:20:55.958
and widely distributed decentralized solar panels and so on in the environment.

00:20:55.958 --> 00:20:57.958
But they'll also go inside our brain,

00:20:57.958 --> 00:20:59.958
interact with our biological neurons.

00:20:59.958 --> 00:21:02.958
We've demonstrated the key principles of being able to do this.

00:21:02.958 --> 00:21:04.958
So, for example,

00:21:04.958 --> 00:21:06.958
full-immersion virtual reality from within the nervous system,

00:21:06.958 --> 00:21:09.958
the nano-bots shut down the signals coming from your real senses,

00:21:09.958 --> 00:21:12.958
replace them with the signals that your brain would be receiving

00:21:12.958 --> 00:21:14.958
if you were in the virtual environment,

00:21:14.958 --> 00:21:16.958
and then it'll feel like you're in that virtual environment.

00:21:16.958 --> 00:21:18.958
You can go there with other people, have any kind of experience

00:21:18.958 --> 00:21:20.958
with anyone involving all of the senses.

00:21:21.958 --> 00:21:24.958
"Experience beamers," I call them, will put their whole flow of sensory experiences

00:21:24.958 --> 00:21:27.958
in the neurological correlates of their emotions out on the Internet.

00:21:27.958 --> 00:21:30.958
You can plug in and experience what it's like to be someone else.

00:21:30.958 --> 00:21:32.958
But most importantly,

00:21:32.958 --> 00:21:34.958
it'll be a tremendous expansion

00:21:34.958 --> 00:21:38.958
of human intelligence through this direct merger with our technology,

00:21:38.958 --> 00:21:40.958
which in some sense we're doing already.

00:21:40.958 --> 00:21:42.958
We routinely do intellectual feats

00:21:42.958 --> 00:21:44.958
that would be impossible without our technology.

00:21:44.958 --> 00:21:47.958
Human life expectancy is expanding. It was 37 in 1800,

00:21:47.958 --> 00:21:52.958
and with this sort of biotechnology, nano-technology revolutions,

00:21:52.958 --> 00:21:54.958
this will move up very rapidly

00:21:54.958 --> 00:21:56.958
in the years ahead.

00:21:56.958 --> 00:22:00.958
My main message is that progress in technology

00:22:00.958 --> 00:22:03.958
is exponential, not linear.

00:22:03.958 --> 00:22:07.958
Many -- even scientists -- assume a linear model,

00:22:07.958 --> 00:22:09.958
so they'll say, "Oh, it'll be hundreds of years

00:22:09.958 --> 00:22:12.958
before we have self-replicating nano-technology assembly

00:22:12.958 --> 00:22:14.958
or artificial intelligence."

00:22:14.958 --> 00:22:17.958
If you really look at the power of exponential growth,

00:22:17.958 --> 00:22:20.958
you'll see that these things are pretty soon at hand.

00:22:20.958 --> 00:22:23.958
And information technology is increasingly encompassing

00:22:23.958 --> 00:22:27.958
all of our lives, from our music to our manufacturing

00:22:27.958 --> 00:22:31.958
to our biology to our energy to materials.

00:22:31.958 --> 00:22:34.958
We'll be able to manufacture almost anything we need in the 2020s,

00:22:34.958 --> 00:22:36.958
from information, in very inexpensive raw materials,

00:22:36.958 --> 00:22:39.958
using nano-technology.

00:22:39.958 --> 00:22:41.958
These are very powerful technologies.

00:22:41.958 --> 00:22:45.958
They both empower our promise and our peril.

00:22:45.958 --> 00:22:48.958
So we have to have the will to apply them to the right problems.

00:22:48.958 --> 00:22:49.958
Thank you very much.

00:22:49.958 --> 00:22:50.958
(Applause)

title: How technology evolves
transcript: I don't know about you, but I haven't quite figured out exactly what technology means in my life. I've spent the past year thinking about what it really should be about. Should I be pro-technology? Should I embrace it full arms? Should I be wary? Like you, I'm very tempted by the latest thing. But at the other hand, a couple of years ago I gave up all of my possessions, sold all my technology — except for a bicycle — and rode across 3,000 miles on the U.S. back roads under the power of my one body, fuelled mostly by Twinkies and junk food.(Laughter)And I've since then tried to keep technology at arm's length in many ways, so it doesn't master my life. At the same time, I run a website on cool tools, where I issue a daily obsession of the latest things in technology. So I'm still perplexed about what the true meaning of technology is as it relates to humanity, as it relates to nature, as it relates to the spiritual. And I'm not even sure we know what technology is. And one definition of technology is that which is first recorded. This is the first example of the modern use of technology that I can find. It was the suggested syllabus for dealing with the Applied Arts and Science at Cambridge University in 1829.Before that, obviously, technology didn't exist. But obviously it did. I like one of the definitions that Alan Kay has for technology. He says technology is anything that was invented after you were born.(Laughter)So it sums up a lot of what we're talking about. Danny Hillis actually has an update on that — he says technology is anything that doesn't quite work yet.(Laughter)Which also, I think, gets into a little bit of our current idea. But I was interested in another definition of technology. Something, again, that went back to something more fundamental. Something that was deeper. And as I struggled to understand that, I came up with a way of framing the question that seemed to work for me in my investigations. And I'm, this morning, going to talk about this for the first time. So this is a very rough attempt to think out loud.The question that I came up with was this question: what does technology want? And by that, I don't mean, does it want chocolate or vanilla? By what it wants, I mean, what are its inherent trends and biases? What are its tendencies over time? One way to think about this is thinking about biological organisms, which we've heard a lot about. And the trick that Richard Dawkins does, which is to say, to look at them as simply as genes, as vehicles for genes. So he's saying, what do genes want? The selfish gene. And I'm applying a similar trick to say, what if we looked at the universe in our culture through the eyes of technology? What does technology want? Obviously, this in an incomplete question, just as looking at an organism as only a gene is an incomplete way of looking at it. But it's still very, very productive. So I'm attempting to say, if we take technology's view of the world, what does it want? And I think once we ask that question we have to go back, actually, to life. Because obviously, if we keep extending the origins of technology far back, I think we come back to life at some point.So that's where I want to begin my little exploration, is in life. And like you heard from the previous speakers, we don't really know what life there is on Earth right now. We have really no idea. Craig Venter's tremendous and brilliant attempt to DNA sequence things in the ocean is great. Brian Farrell's work is all part of this agenda to try and actually discover all the species on Earth. And one of the things that we should do is just make a grid of the globe and randomly go and inspect all the places that the grid intersects, just to see what's on life. And if we did that with our little Martian probe, which we have not done on Earth, we would begin to see some incredible species.This is not on another planet. These are things that are hidden away on our planet. This is an ant that stores its colleagues' honey in its abdomen. Each one of these organisms that we've described — that you've seen from Jamie and others, these magnificent things — what they're doing, each one of them, is they're hacking the rules of life. I can't think of a single general principle of biology that does not have an exception somewhere by some organism. Every single thing that we can think of — and if you heard Olivia's talk about the sexual habits, you'll realize that there isn't anything we can say that's true for all life, because every single one of them is hacking something about it. This is a solar-powered sea slug. It's a nudibranch that has incorporated chloroplast inside it to drive its energy. This is another version of that. This is a sea dragon, and the one on the bottom, the blue one, is a juvenile that has not yet swallowed the acid, has not yet taken in the brown-green algae pond scum into its body to give it energy.These are hacks, and if we looked at the general shape of the approaches to hacking life there are, current consensus, six kingdoms. Six different broad approaches: the plants, the animals, the fungi, the protests — the little things — the bacteria and the Archaea bacteria. The Archaeas. Those are the general approaches to life. That's one way to look at life on Earth today.But a more interesting way, the current way to take the long view, is to look at it in an evolutionary perspective. And here we have a view of evolution where rather than having evolution go over the linear time, we have it coming out from the center. So in the center is the most primitive, and this is a genealogical chart of all life on earth. This is all the same six kingdoms. You see 4,000 representative species, and you can see where we are. But what I like about this is it shows that every living organism on Earth today is equally evolved. Those fungi and bacteria are as highly evolved as humans. They've been around just as long and gone through just the same kind of trial and error to get here. But we see that each one of these is actually hacking, and has a different way of finding out how to do life.And if we take the long-term trends of life, if we begin to say, what does evolution want? There's several things that we see. One of the things about evolution is that nowhere on Earth have we ever been where we don't find life. We find life at the bottom of every long-term, long-distance drilling core into the center of rock that we bring up — and there's bacteria in the pores of that rock. And wherever life is, it never retreats. It's ubiquitous and it wants to be more. More and more of the inert matter of the globe is being touched and animated by life.The second thing is is we see diversity. We also see specialization. We see the movement from a general-purpose cell to the more specific and specialized. And we see a drift towards complexity that's very intuitive. And actually, we have current data that does show that there is an actual drift towards complexity over time. And the last thing, I bring back this nudibranch. One of the things we see about life is that it moves from the inner to increasing sociability. And by that it means that there is more and more of life whose entire environment is other life. Like those chloroplast cells — they're completely surrounded by other life. They never touch the inner matter. There is more and more co-evolution. And so the general, long-term trends of evolution are roughly these five: ubiquity, diversity, specialization, complexity and socialization. Now, I took that and said, OK, what are the long-term trends in technology?And again, my question is, what does technology want? And so, remarkably, I discovered that there's also a drift toward specialization. That we see there's a general hammer, and hammers become more and more specific over time. There's obviously diversity. Huge numbers of things. This is all the contents of a Japanese home. I actually had my daughter — gave her a tally counter, and I gave her an assignment last summer to go around and count the number of species of technology in our household. And it came up with 6,000 different species of products. I did some research and found out that the King of England, Henry VIII, had only about 7,000 items in his household. And he was the King of England, and that was the entire wealth of England at the time. So we're seeing huge numbers of diversity in the kinds of things.This is a scene from Star Wars where the 3PO comes out and he sees machines making machines. How depraved! Well, this is actually what we're headed towards: world machines. And the technology is only being thrown out by other technologies. Most machines will only ever be in contact with other technology and not non-technology, or even life.And thirdly, the idea that machines are becoming biological and complex is at this point a cliche. And I'm happy to say, I was partly responsible for that cliche that machines are becoming biological, but that's pretty evident. So the major trends in technology evolution actually are the same as in biological evolution. The same drives that we see towards ubiquity, towards diversity, towards socialization, towards complexity. That is maybe not a big surprise because if we map out, say, the evolution of armor, you can actually follow a sort of an evolutionary-type cladistic tree. I suggest that, in fact, technology is the seventh kingdom of life. That its operations and how it works is so similar that we can think of it as the seventh kingdom. And so it would be sort of approximately up there, coming out of the animal kingdom. And if we were to do that, we would find out — we could actually approach technology in this way.This is Niles Eldredge. He was the co-developer with Stephen Jay Gould of the theory of punctuated equilibrium. But as a sideline, he happens to collect cornets. He has one of the world's largest collections — about 500 of them. And he has decided to treat them as if they were trilobites, or snails, and to do a morphological analysis, and try to derive their genealogical history over time. This is his chart, which is not quite published yet. But the most interesting aspect about this is that if you look at those red lines at the bottom, those indicate basically a parentage of a type of cornet that was no longer made. That does not happen in biology. When something is extinct, you can't have it as your parent. But that does happen in technology. And it turns out that that's so distinctive that you can actually look at this tree, and you can actually use it to determine that this is a technological system versus a biological system.In fact, this idea of resurrecting the whole idea is so important that I began to think about what happens with old technology. And it turns out that, in fact, technologies don't die. So I suggested this to an historian of science, and he said, "Well, what about, you know, come on, what about steam cars? They're not around anymore." Well actually, they are. In fact, they're so around that you can buy new parts for a Stanley steam automobile. And this is a website of a guy who's selling brand new parts for the Stanley automobile. And the thing that I liked is sort of this one-click, add-to-your-cart button —(Laughter) —for buying steam valves. I mean, it was just — it was really there. And so, I began to think about, well, maybe that's just a random sample. Maybe I should do this sort of in a more conservative way.So I took the great big 1895 Montgomery Ward's catalog and I randomly went through it. And I took a page — not quite a random page — I took a page that was actually more difficult than others because lots of the pages are filled with things that are still being made. But I took this page and I said, how many of these things are still being made? And not antiques. I want to know how many of these things are still in production. And the answer is: all of them. All of them are still being produced. So you've got corn shellers. I don't know who needs a corn sheller. Be it corn shellers — you've got ploughs; you've got fan mills; all these things — and these are not, again, antiques. These are — you can order these. You can go to the web and you can buy them now, brand-new made. So in a certain sense, technologies don't die. In fact, you can buy, for 50 bucks, a stone-age knife made exactly the same way that they were made 10,000 years ago. It's short, bone handle, 50 bucks. And in fact, what's important is that this information actually never died out. It's not just that it was resurrected. It's continued all along. And in Papua New Guinea, they were making stone axes until two decades ago, just as a course of practical matters.Even when we try to get rid of a technology, it's actually very hard. So we've all heard about the Amish giving up cars. We've heard about the Japanese giving up guns. We've heard about this and that. But I actually went back and took what I could find, the examples in history where there have been prohibitions against technology, and then I tried to find out when they came back in, because they always came back in. And it turns out that the time, the duration of when they were outlawed and prohibited, is decreasing over time. And that basically, you can delay technology, but you can't kill it. So this makes sense, because in a certain sense what culture is, is the accumulation of ideas. That's what it's for. It's so that ideas don't die out. And when we take that, we take this idea of what culture is doing and add it to what the long-term trajectory — again, in life's evolution — we find that each case — each of the major transitions in life — what they're really about is accelerating and changing the way in which evolution happens. They're actually changing the way in which ideas are generated.So all these steps in evolution are increasing, basically, the evolution of evolvability. So what's happening over time in life is that the ways in which you generate these new ideas, these new hacks, are increasing. And the real tricks are ways in which you kind of explore the way of exploring. And then what we see in the singularity, that prophesized by Kurzweil and others — his idea that technology is accelerating evolution. It's accelerating the way in which we search for ideas. So if you have life hacking — life means hacking, the game of survival — then evolution is a way to extend the game by changing the rules of the game. And what technology is really about is better ways to evolve. That is what we call an "infinite game." That's the definition of "infinite game." A finite game is play to win, and an infinite game is played to keep playing. And I believe that technology is actually a cosmic force.The origins of technology was not in 1829, but was actually at the beginning of the Big Bang, and at that moment the entire huge billions of stars in the universe were compressed. The entire universe was compressed into a little quantum dot, and it was so tight in there, there was no room for any difference at all. That's the definition. There was no temperature. There was no difference whatsoever. And at the Big Bang, what it expanded was the potential for difference. So as it expands and as things expand what we have is the potential for differences, diversity, options, choices, opportunities, possibilities and freedoms. Those are all basically the same thing. And those are the things that technology brings us. That's what technology is bringing us: choices, possibilities, freedoms. That's what it's about. It's this expansion of room to make differences. And so a hammer, when we grab a hammer, that's what we're grabbing. And that's why we continue to grab technology — because we want those things. Those things are good. Differences, freedom, choices, possibilities. And each time we make a new opportunity place, we're allowing a platform to make new ones.And I think it's really important. Because if you can imagine Mozart before the technology of the piano was invented — what a loss to society there would be. Imagine Van Gogh being born before the technologies of cheap oil paints. Imagine Hitchcock before the technologies of film. Somewhere, today, there are millions of young children being born whose technology of self-expression has not yet been invented. We have a moral obligation to invent technology so that every person on the globe has the potential to realize their true difference. We want a trillion zillion species of one individuals. That's what technology really wants.I'm going to skip through some of the objections because I don't have answers to why there's deforestation. I don't have an answer to the fact that there seem to be bad technologies. I don't have an answer to how this impacts on our dignity, other than to suggest that maybe the seventh kingdom, because it's so close to what life is about, maybe we can bring it back and have it help us monitor life. Maybe in some ways the fact that what we're trying to do with technology is find a good home for it. It's a terrible thing to spray DDT on cotton fields, but it's a really good thing to use to eliminate millions of cases of death due to malaria in a small village.Our humanity is actually defined by technology. All the things that we think that we really like about humanity is being driven by technology. This is the infinite game. That's what we're talking about. You see, technology is a way to evolve the evolution. It's a way to explore possibilities and opportunities and create more. And it's actually a way of playing the game, of playing all the games. That's what technology wants. And so when I think about what technology wants, I think that it has to do with the fact that every person here — and I really believe this — every person here has an assignment. And your assignment is to spend your life discovering what your assignment is. That recursive nature is the infinite game. And if you play that well, you'll have other people involved, so even that game extends and continues even when you're gone. That is the infinite game. And what technology is is the medium in which we play that infinite game. And so I think that we should embrace technology because it is an essential part of our journey in finding out who we are.Thank you.(Applause)

WEBVTT
