00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:15.958
I don't know about you, but I haven't quite figured out

00:00:15.958 --> 00:00:18.958
exactly what technology means in my life.

00:00:18.958 --> 00:00:25.958
I've spent the past year thinking about what it really should be about.

00:00:25.958 --> 00:00:28.958
Should I be pro-technology? Should I embrace it full arms?

00:00:28.958 --> 00:00:33.958
Should I be wary? Like you, I'm very tempted by the latest thing.

00:00:33.958 --> 00:00:35.958
But at the other hand, a couple of years ago

00:00:35.958 --> 00:00:38.958
I gave up all of my possessions,

00:00:38.958 --> 00:00:40.958
sold all my technology -- except for a bicycle --

00:00:40.958 --> 00:00:46.958
and rode across 3,000 miles on the U.S. back roads under the power of my one body,

00:00:46.958 --> 00:00:49.958
fuelled mostly by Twinkies and junk food.

00:00:49.958 --> 00:00:50.958
(Laughter)

00:00:50.958 --> 00:00:52.958
And I've since then tried to keep technology

00:00:52.958 --> 00:00:56.958
at arm's length in many ways, so it doesn't master my life.

00:00:56.958 --> 00:01:00.958
At the same time, I run a website on cool tools,

00:01:00.958 --> 00:01:04.958
where I issue a daily obsession of the latest things in technology.

00:01:04.958 --> 00:01:10.958
So I'm still perplexed about what the true meaning of technology is

00:01:10.958 --> 00:01:14.958
as it relates to humanity, as it relates to nature,

00:01:14.958 --> 00:01:17.958
as it relates to the spiritual.

00:01:17.958 --> 00:01:21.958
And I'm not even sure we know what technology is.

00:01:21.958 --> 00:01:27.958
And one definition of technology is that which is first recorded.

00:01:27.958 --> 00:01:32.958
This is the first example of the modern use of technology that I can find.

00:01:32.958 --> 00:01:36.958
It was the suggested syllabus for dealing with

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:42.958
the Applied Arts and Science at Cambridge University in 1829.

00:01:42.958 --> 00:01:47.958
Before that, obviously, technology didn't exist. But obviously it did.

00:01:47.958 --> 00:01:51.958
I like one of the definitions that Alan Kay has for technology.

00:01:51.958 --> 00:01:55.958
He says technology is anything that was invented after you were born.

00:01:55.958 --> 00:01:56.958
(Laughter)

00:01:56.958 --> 00:02:00.958
So it sums up a lot of what we're talking about.

00:02:00.958 --> 00:02:02.958
Danny Hillis actually has an update on that --

00:02:02.958 --> 00:02:06.958
he says technology is anything that doesn't quite work yet.

00:02:06.958 --> 00:02:07.958
(Laughter)

00:02:07.958 --> 00:02:12.958
Which also, I think, gets into a little bit of our current idea.

00:02:12.958 --> 00:02:15.958
But I was interested in another definition of technology.

00:02:15.958 --> 00:02:19.958
Something, again, that went back to something more fundamental.

00:02:19.958 --> 00:02:25.958
Something that was deeper. And as I struggled to understand that,

00:02:25.958 --> 00:02:28.958
I came up with a way of framing the question

00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:30.958
that seemed to work for me in my investigations.

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:33.958
And I'm, this morning, going to talk about this for the first time.

00:02:33.958 --> 00:02:38.958
So this is a very rough attempt to think out loud.

00:02:38.958 --> 00:02:42.958
The question that I came up with was this question:

00:02:42.958 --> 00:02:45.958
what does technology want? And by that, I don't mean,

00:02:45.958 --> 00:02:50.958
does it want chocolate or vanilla? By what it wants, I mean,

00:02:50.958 --> 00:02:52.958
what are its inherent trends and biases?

00:02:52.958 --> 00:02:57.958
What are its tendencies over time? One way to think about this is

00:02:57.958 --> 00:03:01.958
thinking about biological organisms, which we've heard a lot about.

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:04.958
And the trick that Richard Dawkins does, which is to say,

00:03:04.958 --> 00:03:08.958
to look at them as simply as genes, as vehicles for genes.

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:11.958
So he's saying, what do genes want? The selfish gene.

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:14.958
And I'm applying a similar trick to say,

00:03:14.958 --> 00:03:17.958
what if we looked at the universe in our culture

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:22.958
through the eyes of technology? What does technology want?

00:03:22.958 --> 00:03:24.958
Obviously, this in an incomplete question,

00:03:24.958 --> 00:03:26.958
just as looking at an organism as only a gene

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:28.958
is an incomplete way of looking at it.

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:32.958
But it's still very, very productive. So I'm attempting to say,

00:03:32.958 --> 00:03:36.958
if we take technology's view of the world, what does it want?

00:03:36.958 --> 00:03:39.958
And I think once we ask that question

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:44.958
we have to go back, actually, to life. Because obviously,

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:47.958
if we keep extending the origins of technology far back,

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:49.958
I think we come back to life at some point.

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:52.958
So that's where I want to begin my little exploration, is in life.

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:55.958
And like you heard from the previous speakers,

00:03:55.958 --> 00:03:58.958
we don't really know what life there is on Earth right now.

00:03:58.958 --> 00:04:00.958
We have really no idea.

00:04:00.958 --> 00:04:04.958
Craig Venter's tremendous and brilliant attempt

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:07.958
to DNA sequence things in the ocean is great.

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:10.958
Brian Farrell's work is all part of this agenda to try

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:12.958
and actually discover all the species on Earth.

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:15.958
And one of the things that we should do is just make a grid of the globe

00:04:15.958 --> 00:04:20.958
and randomly go and inspect all the places that the grid intersects,

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:22.958
just to see what's on life. And if we did that

00:04:22.958 --> 00:04:25.958
with our little Martian probe, which we have not done on Earth,

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:29.958
we would begin to see some incredible species.

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:31.958
This is not on another planet. These are things

00:04:31.958 --> 00:04:33.958
that are hidden away on our planet.

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:38.958
This is an ant that stores its colleagues' honey in its abdomen.

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:41.958
Each one of these organisms that we've described -- that you've seen

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:44.958
from Jamie and others, these magnificent things --

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:46.958
what they're doing, each one of them,

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:49.958
is they're hacking the rules of life.

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:54.958
I can't think of a single general principle of biology

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:58.958
that does not have an exception somewhere by some organism.

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:00.958
Every single thing that we can think of --

00:05:00.958 --> 00:05:03.958
and if you heard Olivia's talk about the sexual habits,

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:06.958
you'll realize that there isn't anything we can say that's true for all life,

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:10.958
because every single one of them is hacking something about it.

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:14.958
This is a solar-powered sea slug. It's a nudibranch

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:20.958
that has incorporated chloroplast inside it to drive its energy.

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:23.958
This is another version of that. This is a sea dragon,

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:29.958
and the one on the bottom, the blue one, is a juvenile that has not yet

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:31.958
swallowed the acid, has not yet taken in

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:38.958
the brown-green algae pond scum into its body to give it energy.

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:43.958
These are hacks, and if we looked at the general shape

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:47.958
of the approaches to hacking life there are, current consensus,

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:51.958
six kingdoms. Six different broad approaches: the plants,

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:54.958
the animals, the fungi, the protests -- the little things -- the bacteria

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:57.958
and the Archaea bacteria. The Archaeas.

00:05:57.958 --> 00:06:03.958
Those are the general approaches to life. That's one way to look at life on Earth today.

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:05.958
But a more interesting way,

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:08.958
the current way to take the long view,

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:11.958
is to look at it in an evolutionary perspective.

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:17.958
And here we have a view of evolution where rather than having evolution

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:20.958
go over the linear time, we have it coming out from the center.

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:24.958
So in the center is the most primitive, and this is a genealogical chart

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:28.958
of all life on earth. This is all the same six kingdoms.

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:32.958
You see 4,000 representative species, and you can see where we are.

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:33.958
But what I like about this is it shows that

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:39.958
every living organism on Earth today is equally evolved.

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:43.958
Those fungi and bacteria are as highly evolved as humans.

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:45.958
They've been around just as long and gone through

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:49.958
just the same kind of trial and error to get here.

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:54.958
But we see that each one of these is actually hacking,

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:56.958
and has a different way of finding out how to do life.

00:06:56.958 --> 00:07:00.958
And if we take the long-term trends of life, if we begin to say,

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:03.958
what does evolution want? There's several things that we see.

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:09.958
One of the things about evolution is that nowhere on Earth

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:13.958
have we ever been where we don't find life.

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:17.958
We find life at the bottom of every long-term,

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:20.958
long-distance drilling core into the center of rock

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:24.958
that we bring up -- and there's bacteria in the pores of that rock.

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:28.958
And wherever life is, it never retreats. It's ubiquitous and it wants to be more.

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:31.958
More and more of the inert matter of the globe

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:34.958
is being touched and animated by life.

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:38.958
The second thing is is we see diversity. We also see specialization.

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:41.958
We see the movement from a general-purpose cell

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:45.958
to the more specific and specialized.

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:49.958
And we see a drift towards complexity that's very intuitive.

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:51.958
And actually, we have current data that does show

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:55.958
that there is an actual drift towards complexity over time.

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:57.958
And the last thing, I bring back this nudibranch.

00:07:57.958 --> 00:08:00.958
One of the things we see about life is that it moves

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:04.958
from the inner to increasing sociability. And by that it means

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:08.958
that there is more and more of life whose entire environment is other life.

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:10.958
Like those chloroplast cells --

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:11.958
they're completely surrounded by other life.

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:17.958
They never touch the inner matter. There is more and more co-evolution.

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:20.958
And so the general, long-term trends of evolution

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:24.958
are roughly these five: ubiquity, diversity, specialization,

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:29.958
complexity and socialization. Now, I took that and said,

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:34.958
OK, what are the long-term trends in technology?

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:38.958
And again, my question is, what does technology want?

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:41.958
And so, remarkably, I discovered

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:44.958
that there's also a drift toward specialization.

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:47.958
That we see there's a general hammer,

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:50.958
and hammers become more and more specific over time.

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:55.958
There's obviously diversity. Huge numbers of things.

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:57.958
This is all the contents of a Japanese home.

00:08:57.958 --> 00:09:00.958
I actually had my daughter -- gave her a tally counter,

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:02.958
and I gave her an assignment last summer to go around

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:06.958
and count the number of species of technology in our household.

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:09.958
And it came up with 6,000 different species of products.

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:12.958
I did some research and found out that the King of England, Henry VIII,

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:15.958
had only about 7,000 items in his household.

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:16.958
And he was the King of England,

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:18.958
and that was the entire wealth of England at the time.

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:23.958
So we're seeing huge numbers of diversity in the kinds of things.

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:27.958
This is a scene from Star Wars where the 3PO comes out

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:30.958
and he sees machines making machines. How depraved!

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:34.958
Well, this is actually what we're headed towards: world machines.

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:37.958
And the technology is only being thrown out by other technologies.

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:40.958
Most machines will only ever be in contact with other technology

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:43.958
and not non-technology, or even life.

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:46.958
And thirdly, the idea that machines are becoming biological and complex

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:50.958
is at this point a cliche. And I'm happy to say,

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:52.958
I was partly responsible for that cliche

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:55.958
that machines are becoming biological, but that's pretty evident.

00:09:55.958 --> 00:10:01.958
So the major trends in technology evolution actually

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:06.958
are the same as in biological evolution. The same drives that we see

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:09.958
towards ubiquity, towards diversity, towards socialization,

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:13.958
towards complexity. That is maybe not a big surprise

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:18.958
because if we map out, say, the evolution of armor,

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:22.958
you can actually follow a sort of an evolutionary-type cladistic tree.

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:27.958
I suggest that, in fact, technology is the seventh kingdom of life.

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:31.958
That its operations and how it works is so similar

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:35.958
that we can think of it as the seventh kingdom.

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:38.958
And so it would be sort of approximately up there,

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:44.958
coming out of the animal kingdom. And if we were to do that,

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:47.958
we would find out -- we could actually approach technology in this way.

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:52.958
This is Niles Eldredge. He was the co-developer with Stephen Jay Gould

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:54.958
of the theory of punctuated equilibrium.

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:57.958
But as a sideline, he happens to collect cornets.

00:10:57.958 --> 00:11:01.958
He has one of the world's largest collections -- about 500 of them.

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:04.958
And he has decided to treat them as if they were trilobites, or snails,

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:06.958
and to do a morphological analysis,

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:10.958
and try to derive their genealogical history over time.

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:12.958
This is his chart, which is not quite published yet.

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:15.958
But the most interesting aspect about this

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:18.958
is that if you look at those red lines at the bottom,

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:25.958
those indicate basically a parentage of a type of cornet

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:29.958
that was no longer made. That does not happen in biology.

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:32.958
When something is extinct, you can't have it as your parent.

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:35.958
But that does happen in technology. And it turns out

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:39.958
that that's so distinctive that you can actually look at this tree,

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:42.958
and you can actually use it to determine

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:46.958
that this is a technological system versus a biological system.

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:50.958
In fact, this idea of resurrecting the whole idea is so important

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:54.958
that I began to think about what happens with old technology.

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:59.958
And it turns out that, in fact, technologies don't die.

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:01.958
So I suggested this to an historian of science, and he said,

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:06.958
"Well, what about, you know, come on, what about steam cars?

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:10.958
They're not around anymore." Well actually, they are.

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:17.958
In fact, they're so around that you can buy new parts for a Stanley steam automobile.

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:20.958
And this is a website of a guy who's selling brand new parts

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:24.958
for the Stanley automobile. And the thing that I liked

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:27.958
is sort of this one-click, add-to-your-cart button --

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:28.958
(Laughter) --

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:33.958
for buying steam valves. I mean, it was just -- it was really there.

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:38.958
And so, I began to think about, well, maybe that's just a random sample.

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:41.958
Maybe I should do this sort of in a more conservative way.

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:46.958
So I took the great big 1895 Montgomery Ward's catalog

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:49.958
and I randomly went through it. And I took a page -- not quite a random page --

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:52.958
I took a page that was actually more difficult than others

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:54.958
because lots of the pages are filled with things

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:57.958
that are still being made. But I took this page

00:12:57.958 --> 00:13:01.958
and I said, how many of these things are still being made?

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:06.958
And not antiques. I want to know how many of these things are still in production.

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:09.958
And the answer is: all of them.

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:16.958
All of them are still being produced. So you've got corn shellers.

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:18.958
I don't know who needs a corn sheller.

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:22.958
Be it corn shellers -- you've got ploughs; you've got fan mills;

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:25.958
all these things -- and these are not, again, antiques. These are --

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:28.958
you can order these. You can go to the web and you can buy them now,

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:33.958
brand-new made. So in a certain sense, technologies don't die.

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:40.958
In fact, you can buy, for 50 bucks, a stone-age knife

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:44.958
made exactly the same way that they were made 10,000 years ago.

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:48.958
It's short, bone handle, 50 bucks. And in fact,

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:51.958
what's important is that this information actually never died out.

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:53.958
It's not just that it was resurrected. It's continued all along.

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:56.958
And in Papua New Guinea, they were making stone axes

00:13:56.958 --> 00:14:03.958
until two decades ago, just as a course of practical matters.

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:07.958
Even when we try to get rid of a technology, it's actually very hard.

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:11.958
So we've all heard about the Amish giving up cars.

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:13.958
We've heard about the Japanese giving up guns.

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:15.958
We've heard about this and that. But I actually went back and

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:18.958
took what I could find, the examples in history

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:21.958
where there have been prohibitions against technology,

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:24.958
and then I tried to find out when they came back in,

00:14:24.958 --> 00:14:27.958
because they always came back in. And it turns out that the time,

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:29.958
the duration of when they were outlawed and prohibited,

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:34.958
is decreasing over time. And that basically, you can delay technology,

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:37.958
but you can't kill it. So this makes sense, because in a certain sense

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:42.958
what culture is, is the accumulation of ideas.

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:45.958
That's what it's for. It's so that ideas don't die out.

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:51.958
And when we take that, we take this idea of what culture is doing

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:57.958
and add it to what the long-term trajectory -- again, in life's evolution --

00:14:57.958 --> 00:15:00.958
we find that each case -- each of the major transitions in life --

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:03.958
what they're really about is accelerating and changing

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:06.958
the way in which evolution happens.

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:09.958
They're actually changing the way in which ideas are generated.

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:13.958
So all these steps in evolution are increasing, basically,

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:15.958
the evolution of evolvability.

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:17.958
So what's happening over time in life is

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:20.958
that the ways in which you generate these new ideas, these new hacks,

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:24.958
are increasing. And the real tricks are ways

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:27.958
in which you kind of explore the way of exploring.

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:29.958
And then what we see in the singularity,

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:32.958
that prophesized by Kurzweil and others --

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:36.958
his idea that technology is accelerating evolution.

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:39.958
It's accelerating the way in which we search for ideas.

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:42.958
So if you have life hacking --

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:44.958
life means hacking, the game of survival --

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:48.958
then evolution is a way to extend the game by changing the rules of the game.

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:52.958
And what technology is really about is better ways to evolve.

00:15:52.958 --> 00:15:55.958
That is what we call an "infinite game."

00:15:55.958 --> 00:15:58.958
That's the definition of "infinite game." A finite game is play to win,

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:01.958
and an infinite game is played to keep playing.

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:06.958
And I believe that technology is actually a cosmic force.

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:09.958
The origins of technology was not in 1829,

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:12.958
but was actually at the beginning of the Big Bang,

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:16.958
and at that moment the entire huge billions of stars in the universe

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:20.958
were compressed. The entire universe was compressed into a little quantum dot,

00:16:20.958 --> 00:16:23.958
and it was so tight in there, there was no room for any difference at all.

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:25.958
That's the definition. There was no temperature.

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:28.958
There was no difference whatsoever. And at the Big Bang,

00:16:28.958 --> 00:16:31.958
what it expanded was the potential for difference.

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:34.958
So as it expands and as things expand what we have

00:16:34.958 --> 00:16:39.958
is the potential for differences, diversity, options, choices,

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:41.958
opportunities, possibilities and freedoms.

00:16:41.958 --> 00:16:43.958
Those are all basically the same thing.

00:16:43.958 --> 00:16:47.958
And those are the things that technology brings us.

00:16:47.958 --> 00:16:51.958
That's what technology is bringing us: choices, possibilities, freedoms.

00:16:51.958 --> 00:16:55.958
That's what it's about. It's this expansion of room to make differences.

00:16:55.958 --> 00:16:59.958
And so a hammer, when we grab a hammer, that's what we're grabbing.

00:16:59.958 --> 00:17:02.958
And that's why we continue to grab technology --

00:17:02.958 --> 00:17:04.958
because we want those things. Those things are good.

00:17:04.958 --> 00:17:08.958
Differences, freedom, choices, possibilities.

00:17:08.958 --> 00:17:10.958
And each time we make a new opportunity place,

00:17:10.958 --> 00:17:14.958
we're allowing a platform to make new ones.

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:17.958
And I think it's really important. Because if you can imagine

00:17:17.958 --> 00:17:20.958
Mozart before the technology of the piano was invented --

00:17:20.958 --> 00:17:22.958
what a loss to society there would be.

00:17:22.958 --> 00:17:24.958
Imagine Van Gogh being born

00:17:24.958 --> 00:17:27.958
before the technologies of cheap oil paints.

00:17:27.958 --> 00:17:31.958
Imagine Hitchcock before the technologies of film.

00:17:31.958 --> 00:17:36.958
Somewhere, today, there are millions of young children being born

00:17:36.958 --> 00:17:41.958
whose technology of self-expression has not yet been invented.

00:17:41.958 --> 00:17:44.958
We have a moral obligation to invent technology

00:17:44.958 --> 00:17:46.958
so that every person on the globe has the potential

00:17:46.958 --> 00:17:49.958
to realize their true difference.

00:17:49.958 --> 00:17:52.958
We want a trillion zillion species of one individuals.

00:17:52.958 --> 00:17:55.958
That's what technology really wants.

00:17:55.958 --> 00:17:57.958
I'm going to skip through some of the objections

00:17:57.958 --> 00:18:01.958
because I don't have answers to why there's deforestation.

00:18:01.958 --> 00:18:04.958
I don't have an answer to the fact that there seem to be

00:18:04.958 --> 00:18:06.958
bad technologies. I don't have an answer to

00:18:06.958 --> 00:18:10.958
how this impacts on our dignity, other than to suggest that

00:18:10.958 --> 00:18:16.958
maybe the seventh kingdom, because it's so close to what life is about,

00:18:16.958 --> 00:18:19.958
maybe we can bring it back and have it help us monitor life.

00:18:19.958 --> 00:18:21.958
Maybe in some ways

00:18:21.958 --> 00:18:26.958
the fact that what we're trying to do with technology is find a good home for it.

00:18:26.958 --> 00:18:29.958
It's a terrible thing to spray DDT on cotton fields,

00:18:29.958 --> 00:18:31.958
but it's a really good thing to use

00:18:31.958 --> 00:18:35.958
to eliminate millions of cases of death due to malaria in a small village.

00:18:35.958 --> 00:18:38.958
Our humanity is actually defined by technology.

00:18:38.958 --> 00:18:41.958
All the things that we think that we really like about humanity

00:18:41.958 --> 00:18:46.958
is being driven by technology. This is the infinite game.

00:18:46.958 --> 00:18:48.958
That's what we're talking about.

00:18:48.958 --> 00:18:52.958
You see, technology is a way to evolve the evolution.

00:18:52.958 --> 00:18:58.958
It's a way to explore possibilities and opportunities and create more.

00:18:58.958 --> 00:19:03.958
And it's actually a way of playing the game, of playing all the games.

00:19:03.958 --> 00:19:05.958
That's what technology wants.

00:19:05.958 --> 00:19:08.958
And so when I think about what technology wants,

00:19:08.958 --> 00:19:13.958
I think that it has to do with the fact that every person here -- and I really believe this --

00:19:13.958 --> 00:19:18.958
every person here has an assignment. And your assignment is

00:19:18.958 --> 00:19:21.958
to spend your life discovering what your assignment is.

00:19:21.958 --> 00:19:24.958
That recursive nature is the infinite game.

00:19:24.958 --> 00:19:27.958
And if you play that well, you'll have other people involved,

00:19:27.958 --> 00:19:31.958
so even that game extends and continues even when you're gone.

00:19:31.958 --> 00:19:34.958
That is the infinite game. And what technology is

00:19:34.958 --> 00:19:37.958
is the medium in which we play that infinite game.

00:19:37.958 --> 00:19:40.958
And so I think that we should embrace technology

00:19:40.958 --> 00:19:43.958
because it is an essential part of our journey

00:19:43.958 --> 00:19:45.958
in finding out who we are.

00:19:45.958 --> 00:19:47.958
Thank you.

00:19:47.958 --> 00:19:48.958
(Applause)

title: Fight injustice with raw video
transcript: I love trees, and I'm very lucky, because we live near a wonderful arboretum, and Sundays, usually, I'd go there with my wife and now, with my four-year-old, and we'd climb in the trees, we'd play hide and seek. The second school I was at had big trees too, had a fantastic tulip tree, I think it was the biggest in the country, and it also had a lot of wonderful bushes and vegetation around it, around the playing fields.One day I was grabbed by some of my classmates, and taken in the bushes — I was stripped; I was attacked; I was abused; and this came out of the blue. Now, the reason I say that, because, afterwards, I was thinking — well, I went back into the school — I felt dirty; I felt betrayed; I felt ashamed, but mainly — mainly, I felt powerless. And 30 years later I was sitting in an airplane, next to a lady called Veronica, who came from Chile, and we were on a human rights tour, and she was starting to tell me what it was like to be tortured, and, from my very privileged position, this was the only reference point that I had. And it was an amazing learning experience because, for me, human rights have been something in which I had, you know, a part-time interest, but, mainly, it was something that happened to other people over there.But I got a phone call from Bono in 1985 and, as you know, he's a great singer, but he's a magnificent hustler, and —(Laughter) —a very hard guy to say no to, and he was saying, you know, just after I'd done the Biko song, we're going to do a tour for Amnesty, you have to be on it, and really that was the first time that I'd been out and started meeting people who'd watched their family being shot in front of them, who'd had a partner thrown out of an airplane into an ocean, and suddenly this world of human rights arrived in my world, and I couldn't really walk away in quite the same way as before.So I got involved with this tour, which was for Amnesty, and then in '88 I took over Bono's job trying to learn how to hustle. I didn't do it as well, but we managed to get Youssou N'Dour, Sting, Tracy Chapman, and Bruce Springsteen to go 'round the world for Amnesty, and it was an amazing experience. And, once again, I got an extraordinary education, and it was the first time, really, that I'd met a lot of these people in the different countries, and these human rights stories became very physical, and, again, I couldn't really walk away quite so comfortably.But the thing that really amazed me, that I had no idea, was that you could suffer in this way and then have your whole experience, your story, denied, buried and forgotten. And it seemed that whenever there was a camera around, or a video or film camera, it was a great deal harder to do — for those in power to bury the story. And Reebok set up a foundation after these Human Rights Now tours and there was a decision then — well, we made a proposal, for a couple of years, about trying to set up a division that was going to give cameras to human rights activists. It didn't really get anywhere, and then the Rodney King incident happened, and people thought, OK, if you have a camera in the right place at the right time, or, perhaps, the wrong time, depending who you are, then you can actually start doing something, and campaigning, and being heard, and telling people about what's going on.So, WITNESS was started in '92 and it's since given cameras out in over 60 countries. And we campaign with activist groups and help them tell their story and, in fact, I will show you in a moment one of the most recent campaigns, and I'm afraid it's a story from Uganda, and, although we had a wonderful story from Uganda yesterday, this one isn't quite so good. In the north of Uganda, there are something like 1.5 million internally displaced people, people who are not refugees in another country, but because of the civil war, which has been going on for about 20 years, they have nowhere to live. And 20,000 kids have been taken away to become child soldiers, and the International Criminal Court is going after five of the leaders of the — now, what's it called? I forget the name of the of the army — it's Lord's Resistance Army, I believe — but the government, also, doesn't have a clean sheet, so if we could run the first video.(Music) Woman: Life in the camp is never simple. Even today life is difficult. We stay because of the fear that what pushed us into the camp ... still exists back home. Text: "Between Two Fires: Torture and Displacement in Northern Uganda" Man: When we were at home, it was Kony's [rebel] soldiers disturbing us. At first, we were safe in the camp. But later the government soldiers began mistreating us a lot.(Chanting) Jennifer: A soldier walked onto the road, asking where we'd been. Evelyn and I hid behind my mother. Evelyn: He ordered us to sit down, so we sat down. The other soldier also came. Jennifer: The man came and started undressing me. The other one carried Evelyn aside. The one who was defiling me then left me and went to rape Evelyn. And the one who was raping Evelyn came and defiled me also. Man: The soldiers with clubs this long beat us to get a confession. They kept telling us, "Tell the truth!" as they beat us. Woman: They insisted that I was lying. At that moment, they fired and shot off my fingers. I fell. They ran to join the others ... leaving me for dead.(Music) Text: Uganda ratified the Convention Against Torture in 1986. Torture is defined as any act by which severe pain of suffering, whether physical or mental, is intentionally inflicted by a person acting in an official capacity to obtain information or a confession, to punish, coerce or intimidate.Peter Gabriel: So torture is not something that always happens on other soil. In my country, it was — we had been looking at pictures of British soldiers beating up young Iraqis; we've got Abu Ghraib; we've got Guantanamo Bay. I had a driver on my way to Newark Airport, and he told me a story that, in the middle of the night, 4 a.m., he'd been taken out of his home in Queens — taken to a place in the Midwest, that he was interrogated and tortured and returned to the street four weeks later, because he had the same — he was Middle Eastern, and he had the same name as one of the 9/11 pilots, and that may or may not be true — I didn't think he was a liar, though.And, I think, if we look around the world, as well as the polar ice caps melting, human rights, which have been fought for, for many hundreds of years in some cases, are, also, eroding very fast, and that is something that we need to take a look at and, maybe, start campaigning for. I mean, here, too, one of our partners was at Van Jones and the Books Not Bars project — they have managed, with their footage in California to change the youth correction systems employed, and it's much — much — I think, more humane methods are being looked at, how you should lock up young kids, and that's questionable to start off. And as the story of Mr. Morales, just down the road, excuse me, Mr. Gabriel, would you mind if we delayed your execution a little bit? No, not at all, no problem, take your time. But this, surely, whoever that man is, whatever he's done, this is cruel and unusual punishment.Anyway, WITNESS has been trying to arm the brave people who often put their lives at risk around the world, with cameras, and I'd like to show you just a little more of that. Thank you.(Thunder) Text: You can say a story is fabricated.(Music) Text: You can say a jury is corrupt. You can say a person is lying. You can say you don't trust newspapers. But you can't say what you just saw never happened. Help WITNESS give cameras to the world. Shoot a video; expose injustice; reveal the truth; show us what's wrong with the world; and maybe we can help make it right. WITNESS. All the video you have just seen was recorded by human rights groups working with WITNESS.(Applause)PG: WITNESS was born of technological innovation — in a sense the small, portable, DV cam was really what allowed it to come into being. And we've also been trying to get computers out to the world, so that groups can communicate much more effectively, campaign much more effectively, but now we have the wonderful possibility, which is given to us from the mobile phone with the camera in it, because that is cheap; it's ubiquitous; and it's moving fast all around the world — and it's very exciting for us.And so, the dream is that we could have a world in which anyone who has anything bad happen to them of this sort has a chance of getting their story uploaded, being seen, being watched, that they really know that they can be heard, that there would be a giant website, maybe, a little like Google Earth, and you could fly over and find out the realities of what's going, for the world's inhabitants. In a way what this technology is allowing is, really, that a lot of the problems of the world can have a human face, that we can actually see who's dying of AIDS or who's being beaten up, for the first time, and we can hear their stories in a way that the blogger culture — if we can move that into these sort of fields, I think we can really transform the world in all sorts of ways. There could be a new movement growing up, rising from the ground, reaching for the light, and growing strong, just like a tree. Thank you.

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:41.958
I will show you in a moment one of the most recent campaigns,

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:44.958
and I'm afraid it's a story from Uganda,

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:48.958
and, although we had a wonderful story from Uganda yesterday,

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:50.958
this one isn't quite so good.

00:04:50.958 --> 00:04:52.958
In the north of Uganda,

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:55.958
there are something like 1.5 million internally displaced people,

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:58.958
people who are not refugees in another country,

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:02.958
but because of the civil war, which has been going on for about 20 years,

00:05:02.958 --> 00:05:04.958
they have nowhere to live.

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:10.958
And 20,000 kids have been taken away to become child soldiers,

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:18.958
and the International Criminal Court is going after five of the leaders of the --

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:20.958
now, what's it called?

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:22.958
I forget the name of the of the army --

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:25.958
it's Lord's Resistance Army, I believe --

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:27.958
but the government, also, doesn't have a clean sheet,

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:29.958
so if we could run the first video.

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:31.958
(Music)

00:05:32.958 --> 00:05:35.958
Woman: Life in the camp is never simple. Even today life is difficult.

00:05:35.958 --> 00:05:39.958
We stay because of the fear that what pushed us into the camp ...

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:42.958
still exists back home.

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:52.958
Text: "Between Two Fires: Torture and Displacement in Northern Uganda"

00:05:56.958 --> 00:06:03.958
Man: When we were at home, it was Kony's [rebel] soldiers disturbing us.

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:06.958
At first, we were safe in the camp.

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:11.958
But later the government soldiers began mistreating us a lot.

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:13.958
(Chanting)

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:18.958
Jennifer: A soldier walked onto the road, asking where we'd been.

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:24.958
Evelyn and I hid behind my mother.

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:27.958
Evelyn: He ordered us to sit down, so we sat down.

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:30.958
The other soldier also came.

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:34.958
Jennifer: The man came and started undressing me.

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:37.958
The other one carried Evelyn aside.

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:42.958
The one who was defiling me then left me and went to rape Evelyn.

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:46.958
And the one who was raping Evelyn came and defiled me also.

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:54.958
Man: The soldiers with clubs this long beat us to get a confession.

00:06:54.958 --> 00:07:06.958
They kept telling us, "Tell the truth!" as they beat us.

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:11.958
Woman: They insisted that I was lying.

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:16.958
At that moment, they fired and shot off my fingers.

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:25.958
I fell. They ran to join the others ... leaving me for dead.

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:31.958
(Music)

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:40.958
Text: Uganda ratified the Convention Against Torture in 1986.

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:44.958
Torture is defined as any act by which severe pain of suffering,

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:47.958
whether physical or mental,

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:51.958
is intentionally inflicted by a person acting in an official capacity

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:57.958
to obtain information or a confession, to punish, coerce or intimidate.

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:04.958
Peter Gabriel: So torture is not something that always happens on other soil.

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:07.958
In my country, it was --

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:13.958
we had been looking at pictures of British soldiers beating up young Iraqis;

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:16.958
we've got Abu Ghraib; we've got Guantanamo Bay.

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:19.958
I had a driver on my way to Newark Airport,

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:25.958
and he told me a story that, in the middle of the night, 4 a.m.,

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:31.958
he'd been taken out of his home in Queens -- taken to a place in the Midwest,

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:35.958
that he was interrogated and tortured

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:39.958
and returned to the street four weeks later,

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:42.958
because he had the same -- he was Middle Eastern,

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:46.958
and he had the same name as one of the 9/11 pilots,

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:50.958
and that may or may not be true --

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:53.958
I didn't think he was a liar, though.

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:56.958
And, I think, if we look around the world,

00:08:57.958 --> 00:08:59.958
as well as the polar ice caps melting,

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:02.958
human rights, which have been fought for,

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:05.958
for many hundreds of years in some cases,

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:08.958
are, also, eroding very fast,

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:12.958
and that is something that we need to take a look at

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:16.958
and, maybe, start campaigning for.

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:21.958
I mean, here, too, one of our partners was at Van Jones

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:25.958
and the Books Not Bars project -- they have managed,

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:28.958
with their footage in California

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:33.958
to change the youth correction systems employed,

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:38.958
and it's much -- much -- I think, more humane methods

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:42.958
are being looked at, how you should lock up young kids,

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:44.958
and that's questionable to start off.

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:48.958
And as the story of Mr. Morales, just down the road,

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:52.958
excuse me, Mr. Gabriel,

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:56.958
would you mind if we delayed your execution a little bit?

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:59.958
No, not at all, no problem, take your time.

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:05.958
But this, surely, whoever that man is, whatever he's done,

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:08.958
this is cruel and unusual punishment.

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:15.958
Anyway, WITNESS has been trying to arm the brave people

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:19.958
who often put their lives at risk around the world, with cameras,

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:22.958
and I'd like to show you just a little more of that. Thank you.

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:29.958
(Thunder) Text: You can say a story is fabricated.

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:34.958
(Music)

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:36.958
Text: You can say a jury is corrupt.

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:41.958
You can say a person is lying.

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:48.958
You can say you don't trust newspapers.

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:54.958
But you can't say

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:01.958
what you just saw

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:04.958
never happened.

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:13.958
Help WITNESS give cameras to the world.

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:15.958
Shoot a video;

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:24.958
expose injustice;

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:30.958
reveal the truth;

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:35.958
show us what's wrong with the world;

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:40.958
and maybe

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:42.958
we can help

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:44.958
make it

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:49.958
right.

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:56.958
WITNESS.

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:00.958
All the video you have just seen was recorded by

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:03.958
human rights groups working with WITNESS.

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:06.958
(Applause)

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:12.958
PG: WITNESS was born of technological innovation --

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:14.958
in a sense the small, portable, DV cam

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:17.958
was really what allowed it to come into being.

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:22.958
And we've also been trying to get computers out to the world,

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:24.958
so that groups can communicate much more effectively,

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:26.958
campaign much more effectively,

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:30.958
but now we have the wonderful possibility,

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:36.958
which is given to us from the mobile phone with the camera in it,

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:41.958
because that is cheap; it's ubiquitous; and it's moving fast

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:44.958
all around the world -- and it's very exciting for us.

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:48.958
And so, the dream is that we could have a world

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:54.958
in which anyone who has anything bad happen to them of this sort

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:58.958
has a chance of getting their story uploaded,

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:01.958
being seen, being watched,

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:04.958
that they really know that they can be heard,

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:08.958
that there would be a giant website,

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:10.958
maybe, a little like Google Earth,

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:14.958
and you could fly over and find out the realities of what's going,

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:17.958
for the world's inhabitants. In a way

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:20.958
what this technology is allowing is, really,

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:24.958
that a lot of the problems of the world can have a human face,

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:27.958
that we can actually see who's dying of AIDS

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:32.958
or who's being beaten up, for the first time,

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:36.958
and we can hear their stories in a way that the blogger culture --

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:39.958
if we can move that into these sort of fields,

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:44.958
I think we can really transform the world in all sorts of ways.

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:50.958
There could be a new movement growing up,

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:55.958
rising from the ground, reaching for the light,

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:58.958
and growing strong, just like a tree. Thank you.

title: 8 secrets of success
transcript: This is really a two-hour presentation I give to high school students, cut down to three minutes. And it all started one day on a plane, on my way to TED, seven years ago. And in the seat next to me was a high school student, a teenager, and she came from a really poor family. And she wanted to make something of her life, and she asked me a simple little question. She said, "What leads to success?" And I felt really badly, because I couldn't give her a good answer.So I get off the plane, and I come to TED. And I think, jeez, I'm in the middle of a room of successful people! So why don't I ask them what helped them succeed, and pass it on to kids? So here we are, seven years, 500 interviews later, and I'm going to tell you what really leads to success and makes TEDsters tick.And the first thing is passion. Freeman Thomas says, "I'm driven by my passion." TEDsters do it for love; they don't do it for money.Carol Coletta says, "I would pay someone to do what I do." And the interesting thing is: if you do it for love, the money comes anyway.Work! Rupert Murdoch said to me, "It's all hard work. Nothing comes easily. But I have a lot of fun." Did he say fun? Rupert? Yes!(Laughter)TEDsters do have fun working. And they work hard. I figured, they're not workaholics. They're workafrolics.(Laughter)Good!(Applause)Alex Garden says, "To be successful, put your nose down in something and get damn good at it." There's no magic; it's practice, practice, practice.And it's focus. Norman Jewison said to me, "I think it all has to do with focusing yourself on one thing."And push! David Gallo says, "Push yourself. Physically, mentally, you've got to push, push, push." You've got to push through shyness and self-doubt.Goldie Hawn says, "I always had self-doubts. I wasn't good enough; I wasn't smart enough. I didn't think I'd make it."Now it's not always easy to push yourself, and that's why they invented mothers.(Laughter)(Applause) Frank Gehry said to me, "My mother pushed me."(Laughter)Serve! Sherwin Nuland says, "It was a privilege to serve as a doctor."A lot of kids want to be millionaires. The first thing I say is: "OK, well you can't serve yourself; you've got to serve others something of value. Because that's the way people really get rich."Ideas! TEDster Bill Gates says, "I had an idea: founding the first micro-computer software company." I'd say it was a pretty good idea. And there's no magic to creativity in coming up with ideas — it's just doing some very simple things. And I give lots of evidence.Persist! Joe Kraus says, "Persistence is the number one reason for our success." You've got to persist through failure. You've got to persist through crap! Which of course means "Criticism, Rejection, Assholes and Pressure."(Laughter)So, the answer to this question is simple: Pay 4,000 bucks and come to TED.(Laughter)Or failing that, do the eight things — and trust me, these are the big eight things that lead to success.Thank you TEDsters for all your interviews!(Applause)

title: If I controlled the Internet
transcript: I wrote this poem after hearing a pretty well known actress tell a very well known interviewer on television, "I'm really getting into the Internet lately. I just wish it were more organized." So ... (Laughter) If I controlled the Internet, you could auction your broken heart on eBay. Take the money; go to Amazon; buy a phonebook for a country you've never been to — call folks at random until you find someone who flirts really well in a foreign language.(Laughter)If I were in charge of the Internet, you could Mapquest your lover's mood swings. Hang left at cranky, right at preoccupied, U-turn on silent treatment, all the way back to tongue kissing and good lovin'. You could navigate and understand every emotional intersection. Some days, I'm as shallow as a baking pan, but I still stretch miles in all directions. If I owned the Internet, Napster, Monster and Friendster.com would be one big website. That way you could listen to cool music while you pretend to look for a job and you're really just chattin' with your pals.(Laughter)Heck, if I ran the Web, you could email dead people.(Laughter)They would not email you back (Laughter) — but you'd get an automated reply.(Laughter) Their name in your inbox (Laughter) — it's all you wanted anyway. And a message saying, "Hey, it's me. I miss you.(Laughter)Listen, you'll see being dead is dandy. Now you go back to raising kids and waging peace and craving candy." If I designed the Internet, childhood.com would be a loop of a boy in an orchard, with a ski pole for a sword, trashcan lid for a shield, shouting, "I am the emperor of oranges. I am the emperor of oranges. I am the emperor of oranges." Now follow me, OK?(Laughter)Grandma.com would be a recipe for biscuits and spit-bath instructions. One, two, three. That links with hotdiggitydog.com. That is my grandfather. They take you to gruff-ex-cop-on-his-fourth-marriage.dad. He forms an attachment to kind-of-ditzy-but-still-sends-ginger-snaps-for-Christmas.mom, who downloads the boy in the orchard, the emperor of oranges, who grows up to be me — the guy who usually goes too far. So if I were emperor of the Internet, I guess I'd still be mortal, huh? But at that point, I would probably already have the lowest possible mortgage and the most enlarged possible penis (Laughter) — so I would outlaw spam on my first day in office. I wouldn't need it. I'd be like some kind of Internet genius, and me, I'd like to upgrade to deity and maybe just like that — pop! — I'd go wireless.(Laughter)Huh? Maybe Google would hire this. I could zip through your servers and firewalls like a virus until the World Wide Web is as wise, as wild and as organized as I think a modern-day miracle/oracle can get, but, ooh-eee, you want to bet just how whack and un-PC your Mac or PC is going to be when I'm rocking hot-shit-hot-shot-god.net? I guess it's just like life. It is not a question of if you can — it's: do ya? We can interfere with the interface. We can make "You've got Hallelujah" the national anthem of cyberspace every lucky time we log on. You don't say a prayer. You don't write a psalm. You don't chant an "om." You send one blessed email to whomever you're thinking of at dah-da-la-dat-da-dah-da-la-dat.com. Thank you, TED.(Applause)

00:00:23.958 --> 00:00:24.958
So ...

00:00:24.958 --> 00:00:26.958
(Laughter)

00:00:28.958 --> 00:00:31.958
If I controlled the Internet,

00:00:31.958 --> 00:00:35.958
you could auction your broken heart on eBay.

00:00:35.958 --> 00:00:37.958
Take the money; go to Amazon;

00:00:37.958 --> 00:00:41.958
buy a phonebook for a country you've never been to -- call folks at random

00:00:41.958 --> 00:00:44.958
until you find someone who flirts really well in a foreign language.

00:00:44.958 --> 00:00:45.958
(Laughter)

00:00:45.958 --> 00:00:47.958
If I were in charge of the Internet,

00:00:47.958 --> 00:00:50.958
you could Mapquest your lover's mood swings.

00:00:50.958 --> 00:00:54.958
Hang left at cranky, right at preoccupied,

00:00:54.958 --> 00:00:56.958
U-turn on silent treatment,

00:00:56.958 --> 00:00:59.958
all the way back to tongue kissing and good lovin'.

00:00:59.958 --> 00:01:02.958
You could navigate and understand every emotional intersection.

00:01:02.958 --> 00:01:05.958
Some days, I'm as shallow as a baking pan,

00:01:05.958 --> 00:01:07.958
but I still stretch miles in all directions.

00:01:07.958 --> 00:01:13.958
If I owned the Internet, Napster, Monster and Friendster.com

00:01:13.958 --> 00:01:15.958
would be one big website.

00:01:15.958 --> 00:01:17.958
That way you could listen to cool music

00:01:17.958 --> 00:01:19.958
while you pretend to look for a job

00:01:19.958 --> 00:01:21.958
and you're really just chattin' with your pals.

00:01:21.958 --> 00:01:22.958
(Laughter)

00:01:22.958 --> 00:01:26.958
Heck, if I ran the Web, you could email dead people.

00:01:26.958 --> 00:01:28.958
(Laughter)

00:01:28.958 --> 00:01:30.958
They would not email you back

00:01:30.958 --> 00:01:31.958
(Laughter) --

00:01:31.958 --> 00:01:33.958
but you'd get an automated reply.

00:01:33.958 --> 00:01:35.958
(Laughter)

00:01:35.958 --> 00:01:37.958
Their name in your inbox

00:01:37.958 --> 00:01:38.958
(Laughter) --

00:01:38.958 --> 00:01:40.958
it's all you wanted anyway.

00:01:40.958 --> 00:01:43.958
And a message saying, "Hey, it's me. I miss you.

00:01:43.958 --> 00:01:44.958
(Laughter)

00:01:44.958 --> 00:01:47.958
Listen, you'll see being dead is dandy.

00:01:47.958 --> 00:01:51.958
Now you go back to raising kids and waging peace and craving candy."

00:01:51.958 --> 00:01:56.958
If I designed the Internet, childhood.com would be a loop

00:01:56.958 --> 00:02:01.958
of a boy in an orchard, with a ski pole for a sword,

00:02:01.958 --> 00:02:04.958
trashcan lid for a shield, shouting, "I am the emperor of oranges.

00:02:04.958 --> 00:02:07.958
I am the emperor of oranges. I am the emperor of oranges."

00:02:07.958 --> 00:02:08.958
Now follow me, OK?

00:02:08.958 --> 00:02:09.958
(Laughter)

00:02:09.958 --> 00:02:12.958
Grandma.com would be a recipe for biscuits and spit-bath instructions.

00:02:12.958 --> 00:02:14.958
One, two, three.

00:02:14.958 --> 00:02:16.958
That links with hotdiggitydog.com.

00:02:16.958 --> 00:02:18.958
That is my grandfather.

00:02:18.958 --> 00:02:20.958
They take you to gruff-ex-cop-on-his-fourth-marriage.dad.

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:21.958
He forms an attachment to

00:02:21.958 --> 00:02:23.958
kind-of-ditzy-but-still-sends-ginger-snaps-for-Christmas.mom,

00:02:23.958 --> 00:02:27.958
who downloads the boy in the orchard, the emperor of oranges,

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:30.958
who grows up to be me --

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:32.958
the guy who usually goes too far.

00:02:32.958 --> 00:02:35.958
So if I were emperor of the Internet,

00:02:35.958 --> 00:02:38.958
I guess I'd still be mortal, huh?

00:02:38.958 --> 00:02:40.958
But at that point, I would probably

00:02:40.958 --> 00:02:44.958
already have the lowest possible mortgage

00:02:44.958 --> 00:02:46.958
and the most enlarged possible penis

00:02:46.958 --> 00:02:47.958
(Laughter) --

00:02:47.958 --> 00:02:49.958
so I would outlaw spam on my first day in office.

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:51.958
I wouldn't need it.

00:02:51.958 --> 00:02:53.958
I'd be like some kind of Internet genius, and me,

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:57.958
I'd like to upgrade to deity and maybe just like that --

00:02:57.958 --> 00:03:00.958
pop! -- I'd go wireless.

00:03:00.958 --> 00:03:01.958
(Laughter)

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:03.958
Huh? Maybe Google would hire this.

00:03:03.958 --> 00:03:05.958
I could zip through your servers and firewalls like a virus

00:03:05.958 --> 00:03:09.958
until the World Wide Web is as wise, as wild and as organized

00:03:09.958 --> 00:03:14.958
as I think a modern-day miracle/oracle can get, but, ooh-eee,

00:03:14.958 --> 00:03:18.958
you want to bet just how whack and un-PC

00:03:18.958 --> 00:03:20.958
your Mac or PC is going to be when I'm rocking

00:03:20.958 --> 00:03:22.958
hot-shit-hot-shot-god.net?

00:03:22.958 --> 00:03:24.958
I guess it's just like life.

00:03:24.958 --> 00:03:26.958
It is not a question of if you can --

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:28.958
it's: do ya?

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:30.958
We can interfere with the interface.

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:33.958
We can make "You've got Hallelujah" the national anthem of cyberspace

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:35.958
every lucky time we log on.

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:37.958
You don't say a prayer.

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:39.958
You don't write a psalm.

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:41.958
You don't chant an "om."

00:03:41.958 --> 00:03:45.958
You send one blessed email to whomever you're thinking of

00:03:45.958 --> 00:03:51.958
at dah-da-la-dat-da-dah-da-la-dat.com.

00:03:51.958 --> 00:03:52.958
Thank you, TED.

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:55.958
(Applause)

title: The killer American diet that's sweeping the planet
transcript: With all the legitimate concerns about AIDS and avian flu — and we'll hear about that from the brilliant Dr. Brilliant later today — I want to talk about the other pandemic, which is cardiovascular disease, diabetes, hypertension — all of which are completely preventable for at least 95 percent of people just by changing diet and lifestyle.And what's happening is that there's a globalization of illness occurring, that people are starting to eat like us, and live like us, and die like us. And in one generation, for example, Asia's gone from having one of the lowest rates of heart disease and obesity and diabetes to one of the highest. And in Africa, cardiovascular disease equals the HIV and AIDS deaths in most countries. So there's a critical window of opportunity we have to make an important difference that can affect the lives of literally millions of people, and practice preventive medicine on a global scale.Heart and blood vessel diseases still kill more people — not only in this country, but also worldwide — than everything else combined, and yet it's completely preventable for almost everybody. It's not only preventable; it's actually reversible. And for the last almost 29 years, we've been able to show that by simply changing diet and lifestyle, using these very high-tech, expensive, state-of-the-art measures to prove how powerful these very simple and low-tech and low-cost interventions can be like — quantitative arteriography, before and after a year, and cardiac PET scans.We showed a few months ago — we published the first study showing you can actually stop or reverse the progression of prostate cancer by making changes in diet and lifestyle, and 70 percent regression in the tumor growth, or inhibition of the tumor growth, compared to only nine percent in the control group. And in the MRI and MR spectroscopy here, the prostate tumor activity is shown in red — you can see it diminishing after a year.Now there is an epidemic of obesity: two-thirds of adults and 15 percent of kids. What's really concerning to me is that diabetes has increased 70 percent in the past 10 years, and this may be the first generation in which our kids live a shorter life span than we do. That's pitiful, and it's preventable. Now these are not election returns, these are the people — the number of the people who are obese by state, beginning in '85, '86, '87 — these are from the CDC website — '88, '89, '90, '91 — you get a new category — '92, '93, '94, '95, '96, '97, '98, '99, 2000, 2001 — it gets worse. We're kind of devolving. (Laughter)Now what can we do about this? Well, you know, the diet that we've found that can reverse heart disease and cancer is an Asian diet. But the people in Asia are starting to eat like we are, which is why they're starting to get sick like we are. So I've been working with a lot of the big food companies. They can make it fun and sexy and hip and crunchy and convenient to eat healthier foods, like — I chair the advisory boards to McDonald's, and PepsiCo, and ConAgra, and Safeway, and soon Del Monte, and they're finding that it's good business. The salads that you see at McDonald's came from the work — they're going to have an Asian salad. At Pepsi, two-thirds of their revenue growth came from their better foods.And so if we can do that, then we can free up resources for buying drugs that you really do need for treating AIDS and HIV and malaria and for preventing avian flu. Thank you.
