00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:09.958
is equated to the canopy of the forest

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:11.958
upon which the people depend.

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:14.958
They have a curious language and marriage rule

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:16.958
which is called "linguistic exogamy:"

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:19.958
you must marry someone who speaks a different language.

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:21.958
And this is all rooted in the mythological past,

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:23.958
yet the curious thing is in these long houses,

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:25.958
where there are six or seven languages spoken

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:27.958
because of intermarriage,

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:30.958
you never hear anyone practicing a language.

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:33.958
They simply listen and then begin to speak.

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:35.958
Or, one of the most fascinating tribes I ever lived with,

00:05:35.958 --> 00:05:39.958
the Waorani of northeastern Ecuador,

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:42.958
an astonishing people first contacted peacefully in 1958.

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:46.958
In 1957, five missionaries attempted contact

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:47.958
and made a critical mistake.

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:48.958
They dropped from the air

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:50.958
8 x 10 glossy photographs of themselves

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:52.958
in what we would say to be friendly gestures,

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:54.958
forgetting that these people of the rainforest

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:57.958
had never seen anything two-dimensional in their lives.

00:05:57.958 --> 00:05:59.958
They picked up these photographs from the forest floor,

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:02.958
tried to look behind the face to find the form or the figure,

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:04.958
found nothing, and concluded that these were calling cards

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:07.958
from the devil, so they speared the five missionaries to death.

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:10.958
But the Waorani didn't just spear outsiders.

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:11.958
They speared each other.

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:14.958
54 percent of their mortality was due to them spearing each other.

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:17.958
We traced genealogies back eight generations,

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:19.958
and we found two instances of natural death

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:21.958
and when we pressured the people a little bit about it,

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:23.958
they admitted that one of the fellows had gotten so old

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:27.958
that he died getting old, so we speared him anyway. (Laughter)

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:30.958
But at the same time they had a perspicacious knowledge

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:31.958
of the forest that was astonishing.

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:34.958
Their hunters could smell animal urine at 40 paces

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:37.958
and tell you what species left it behind.

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:39.958
In the early '80s, I had a really astonishing assignment

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:41.958
when I was asked by my professor at Harvard

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:43.958
if I was interested in going down to Haiti,

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:46.958
infiltrating the secret societies

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:48.958
which were the foundation of Duvalier's strength

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:49.958
and Tonton Macoutes,

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:52.958
and securing the poison used to make zombies.

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:55.958
In order to make sense out of sensation, of course,

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:58.958
I had to understand something about this remarkable faith

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:01.958
of Vodoun. And Voodoo is not a black magic cult.

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:04.958
On the contrary, it's a complex metaphysical worldview.

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:05.958
It's interesting.

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:06.958
If I asked you to name the great religions of the world,

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:07.958
what would you say?

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:10.958
Christianity, Islam, Buddhism, Judaism, whatever.

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:12.958
There's always one continent left out,

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:14.958
the assumption being that sub-Saharan Africa

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:16.958
had no religious beliefs. Well, of course, they did

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:18.958
and Voodoo is simply the distillation

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:20.958
of these very profound religious ideas

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:23.958
that came over during the tragic Diaspora of the slavery era.

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:25.958
But, what makes Voodoo so interesting

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:27.958
is that it's this living relationship

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:28.958
between the living and the dead.

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:29.958
So, the living give birth to the spirits.

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:32.958
The spirits can be invoked from beneath the Great Water,

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:34.958
responding to the rhythm of the dance

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:36.958
to momentarily displace the soul of the living,

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:40.958
so that for that brief shining moment, the acolyte becomes the god.

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:42.958
That's why the Voodooists like to say

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:45.958
that "You white people go to church and speak about God.

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:47.958
We dance in the temple and become God."

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:50.958
And because you are possessed, you are taken by the spirit --

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:51.958
how can you be harmed?

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:54.958
So you see these astonishing demonstrations:

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:56.958
Voodoo acolytes in a state of trance

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:59.958
handling burning embers with impunity,

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:02.958
a rather astonishing demonstration of the ability of the mind

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:03.958
to affect the body that bears it

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:06.958
when catalyzed in the state of extreme excitation.

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:09.958
Now, of all the peoples that I've ever been with,

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:11.958
the most extraordinary are the Kogi

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:14.958
of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta in northern Colombia.

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:17.958
Descendants of the ancient Tairona civilization

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:20.958
which once carpeted the Caribbean coastal plain of Colombia,

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:21.958
in the wake of the conquest,

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:24.958
these people retreated into an isolated volcanic massif

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:26.958
that soars above the Caribbean coastal plain.

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:28.958
In a bloodstained continent,

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:31.958
these people alone were never conquered by the Spanish.

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:34.958
To this day, they remain ruled by a ritual priesthood

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:36.958
but the training for the priesthood is rather extraordinary.

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:39.958
The young acolytes are taken away from their families

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:41.958
at the age of three and four,

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:43.958
sequestered in a shadowy world of darkness

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:47.958
in stone huts at the base of glaciers for 18 years:

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:48.958
two nine-year periods

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:51.958
deliberately chosen to mimic the nine months of gestation

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:53.958
they spend in their natural mother's womb;

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:56.958
now they are metaphorically in the womb of the great mother.

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:57.958
And for this entire time,

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:01.958
they are inculturated into the values of their society,

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:03.958
values that maintain the proposition that their prayers

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:06.958
and their prayers alone maintain the cosmic --

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:08.958
or we might say the ecological -- balance.

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:10.958
And at the end of this amazing initiation,

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:12.958
one day they're suddenly taken out

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:15.958
and for the first time in their lives, at the age of 18,

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:19.958
they see a sunrise. And in that crystal moment of awareness

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:22.958
of first light as the Sun begins to bathe the slopes

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:23.958
of the stunningly beautiful landscape,

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:26.958
suddenly everything they have learned in the abstract

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:29.958
is affirmed in stunning glory. And the priest steps back

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:31.958
and says, "You see? It's really as I've told you.

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:34.958
It is that beautiful. It is yours to protect."

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:36.958
They call themselves the "elder brothers"

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:39.958
and they say we, who are the younger brothers,

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:42.958
are the ones responsible for destroying the world.

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:45.958
Now, this level of intuition becomes very important.

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:47.958
Whenever we think of indigenous people and landscape,

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:49.958
we either invoke Rousseau

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:52.958
and the old canard of the "noble savage,"

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:54.958
which is an idea racist in its simplicity,

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:57.958
or alternatively, we invoke Thoreau

00:09:57.958 --> 00:09:59.958
and say these people are closer to the Earth than we are.

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:01.958
Well, indigenous people are neither sentimental

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:03.958
nor weakened by nostalgia.

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:05.958
There's not a lot of room for either

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:07.958
in the malarial swamps of the Asmat

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:10.958
or in the chilling winds of Tibet, but they have, nevertheless,

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:14.958
through time and ritual, forged a traditional mystique of the Earth

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:17.958
that is based not on the idea of being self-consciously close to it,

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:19.958
but on a far subtler intuition:

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:22.958
the idea that the Earth itself can only exist

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:25.958
because it is breathed into being by human consciousness.

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:27.958
Now, what does that mean?

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:29.958
It means that a young kid from the Andes

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:31.958
who's raised to believe that that mountain is an Apu spirit

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:33.958
that will direct his or her destiny

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:36.958
will be a profoundly different human being

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:39.958
and have a different relationship to that resource

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:41.958
or that place than a young kid from Montana

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:44.958
raised to believe that a mountain is a pile of rock

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:45.958
ready to be mined.

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:49.958
Whether it's the abode of a spirit or a pile of ore is irrelevant.

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:52.958
What's interesting is the metaphor that defines the relationship

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:54.958
between the individual and the natural world.

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:56.958
I was raised in the forests of British Columbia

00:10:56.958 --> 00:10:58.958
to believe those forests existed to be cut.

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:00.958
That made me a different human being

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:02.958
than my friends amongst the Kwagiulth

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:04.958
who believe that those forests were the abode of Huxwhukw

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:05.958
and the Crooked Beak of Heaven

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:08.958
and the cannibal spirits that dwelled at the north end of the world,

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:12.958
spirits they would have to engage during their Hamatsa initiation.

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:14.958
Now, if you begin to look at the idea

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:16.958
that these cultures could create different realities,

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:17.958
you could begin to understand

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:22.958
some of their extraordinary discoveries. Take this plant here.

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:24.958
It's a photograph I took in the Northwest Amazon just last April.

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:27.958
This is ayahuasca, which many of you have heard about,

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:30.958
the most powerful psychoactive preparation

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:32.958
of the shaman's repertoire.

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:34.958
What makes ayahuasca fascinating

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:38.958
is not the sheer pharmacological potential of this preparation,

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:42.958
but the elaboration of it. It's made really of two different sources:

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:44.958
on the one hand, this woody liana

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:46.958
which has in it a series of beta-carbolines,

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:49.958
harmine, harmaline, mildly hallucinogenic --

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:51.958
to take the vine alone

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:53.958
is rather to have sort of blue hazy smoke

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:55.958
drift across your consciousness --

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:58.958
but it's mixed with the leaves of a shrub in the coffee family

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:00.958
called Psychotria viridis.

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:03.958
This plant had in it some very powerful tryptamines,

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:07.958
very close to brain serotonin, dimethyltryptamine,

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:08.958
5-methoxydimethyltryptamine.

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:10.958
If you've ever seen the Yanomami

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:12.958
blowing that snuff up their noses,

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:15.958
that substance they make from a different set of species

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:19.958
also contains methoxydimethyltryptamine.

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:21.958
To have that powder blown up your nose

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:25.958
is rather like being shot out of a rifle barrel

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:32.958
lined with baroque paintings and landing on a sea of electricity. (Laughter)

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:34.958
It doesn't create the distortion of reality;

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:35.958
it creates the dissolution of reality.

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:38.958
In fact, I used to argue with my professor, Richard Evan Shultes --

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:40.958
who is a man who sparked the psychedelic era

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:42.958
with his discovery of the magic mushrooms

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:44.958
in Mexico in the 1930s --

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:46.958
I used to argue that you couldn't classify these tryptamines

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:49.958
as hallucinogenic because by the time you're under the effects

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:53.958
there's no one home anymore to experience a hallucination. (Laughter)

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:56.958
But the thing about tryptamines is they cannot be taken orally

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:58.958
because they're denatured by an enzyme

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:01.958
found naturally in the human gut called monoamine oxidase.

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:04.958
They can only be taken orally if taken in conjunction

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:07.958
with some other chemical that denatures the MAO.

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:08.958
Now, the fascinating things

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:12.958
are that the beta-carbolines found within that liana

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:15.958
are MAO inhibitors of the precise sort necessary

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:19.958
to potentiate the tryptamine. So you ask yourself a question.

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:23.958
How, in a flora of 80,000 species of vascular plants,

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:27.958
do these people find these two morphologically unrelated plants

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:28.958
that when combined in this way,

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:30.958
created a kind of biochemical version

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:32.958
of the whole being greater than the sum of the parts?

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:35.958
Well, we use that great euphemism, "trial and error,"

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:36.958
which is exposed to be meaningless.

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:40.958
But you ask the Indians, and they say, "The plants talk to us."

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:41.958
Well, what does that mean?

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:45.958
This tribe, the Cofan, has 17 varieties of ayahuasca,

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:48.958
all of which they distinguish a great distance in the forest,

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:53.958
all of which are referable to our eye as one species.

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:55.958
And then you ask them how they establish their taxonomy

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:58.958
and they say, "I thought you knew something about plants.

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:00.958
I mean, don't you know anything?" And I said, "No."

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:03.958
Well, it turns out you take each of the 17 varieties

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:06.958
in the night of a full moon, and it sings to you in a different key.

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:08.958
Now, that's not going to get you a Ph.D. at Harvard,

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:12.958
but it's a lot more interesting than counting stamens. (Laughter)

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:13.958
Now --

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:16.958
(Applause) --

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:18.958
the problem -- the problem is that even those of us

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:20.958
sympathetic with the plight of indigenous people

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:21.958
view them as quaint and colorful

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:23.958
but somehow reduced to the margins of history

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:26.958
as the real world, meaning our world, moves on.

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:28.958
Well, the truth is the 20th century, 300 years from now,

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:31.958
is not going to be remembered for its wars

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:32.958
or its technological innovations,

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:34.958
but rather as the era in which we stood by

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:37.958
and either actively endorsed or passively accepted

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:40.958
the massive destruction of both biological and cultural diversity

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:43.958
on the planet. Now, the problem isn't change.

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:45.958
All cultures through all time

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:48.958
have constantly been engaged in a dance

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:49.958
with new possibilities of life.

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:52.958
And the problem is not technology itself.

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:55.958
The Sioux Indians did not stop being Sioux

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:56.958
when they gave up the bow and arrow

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:58.958
any more than an American stopped being an American

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:00.958
when he gave up the horse and buggy.

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:01.958
It's not change or technology

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:05.958
that threatens the integrity of the ethnosphere. It is power,

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:07.958
the crude face of domination.

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:09.958
Wherever you look around the world,

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:12.958
you discover that these are not cultures destined to fade away;

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:14.958
these are dynamic living peoples

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:17.958
being driven out of existence by identifiable forces

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:19.958
that are beyond their capacity to adapt to:

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:21.958
whether it's the egregious deforestation

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:24.958
in the homeland of the Penan --

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:27.958
a nomadic people from Southeast Asia, from Sarawak --

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:31.958
a people who lived free in the forest until a generation ago,

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:34.958
and now have all been reduced to servitude and prostitution

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:36.958
on the banks of the rivers,

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:40.958
where you can see the river itself is soiled with the silt

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:42.958
that seems to be carrying half of Borneo away

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:43.958
to the South China Sea,

00:15:43.958 --> 00:15:45.958
where the Japanese freighters hang light in the horizon

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:49.958
ready to fill their holds with raw logs ripped from the forest --

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:50.958
or, in the case of the Yanomami,

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:52.958
it's the disease entities that have come in,

00:15:52.958 --> 00:15:54.958
in the wake of the discovery of gold.

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:56.958
Or if we go into the mountains of Tibet,

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:58.958
where I'm doing a lot of research recently,

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:02.958
you'll see it's a crude face of political domination.

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:04.958
You know, genocide, the physical extinction of a people

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:06.958
is universally condemned, but ethnocide,

00:16:07.958 --> 00:16:10.958
the destruction of people's way of life, is not only not condemned,

00:16:10.958 --> 00:16:13.958
it's universally, in many quarters, celebrated

00:16:13.958 --> 00:16:15.958
as part of a development strategy.

00:16:15.958 --> 00:16:18.958
And you cannot understand the pain of Tibet

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:20.958
until you move through it at the ground level.

00:16:20.958 --> 00:16:24.958
I once travelled 6,000 miles from Chengdu in Western China

00:16:24.958 --> 00:16:27.958
overland through southeastern Tibet to Lhasa

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:31.958
with a young colleague, and it was only when I got to Lhasa

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:34.958
that I understood the face behind the statistics

00:16:34.958 --> 00:16:35.958
you hear about:

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:39.958
6,000 sacred monuments torn apart to dust and ashes,

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:42.958
1.2 million people killed by the cadres

00:16:42.958 --> 00:16:43.958
during the Cultural Revolution.

00:16:44.958 --> 00:16:46.958
This young man's father had been ascribed to the Panchen Lama.

00:16:46.958 --> 00:16:48.958
That meant he was instantly killed

00:16:48.958 --> 00:16:50.958
at the time of the Chinese invasion.

00:16:50.958 --> 00:16:52.958
His uncle fled with His Holiness in the Diaspora

00:16:52.958 --> 00:16:55.958
that took the people to Nepal.

00:16:55.958 --> 00:16:57.958
His mother was incarcerated

00:16:57.958 --> 00:16:59.958
for the crime of being wealthy.

00:17:00.958 --> 00:17:02.958
He was smuggled into the jail at the age of two

00:17:02.958 --> 00:17:04.958
to hide beneath her skirt tails

00:17:04.958 --> 00:17:06.958
because she couldn't bear to be without him.

00:17:06.958 --> 00:17:08.958
The sister who had done that brave deed

00:17:08.958 --> 00:17:09.958
was put into an education camp.

00:17:09.958 --> 00:17:11.958
One day she inadvertently stepped on an armband

00:17:12.958 --> 00:17:14.958
of Mao, and for that transgression,

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:17.958
she was given seven years of hard labor.

00:17:17.958 --> 00:17:20.958
The pain of Tibet can be impossible to bear,

00:17:20.958 --> 00:17:23.958
but the redemptive spirit of the people is something to behold.

00:17:24.958 --> 00:17:27.958
And in the end, then, it really comes down to a choice:

00:17:27.958 --> 00:17:30.958
do we want to live in a monochromatic world of monotony

00:17:30.958 --> 00:17:33.958
or do we want to embrace a polychromatic world of diversity?

00:17:33.958 --> 00:17:36.958
Margaret Mead, the great anthropologist, said, before she died,

00:17:36.958 --> 00:17:39.958
that her greatest fear was that as we drifted towards

00:17:39.958 --> 00:17:41.958
this blandly amorphous generic world view

00:17:41.958 --> 00:17:46.958
not only would we see the entire range of the human imagination

00:17:46.958 --> 00:17:50.958
reduced to a more narrow modality of thought,

00:17:50.958 --> 00:17:51.958
but that we would wake from a dream one day

00:17:51.958 --> 00:17:54.958
having forgotten there were even other possibilities.

00:17:55.958 --> 00:17:58.958
And it's humbling to remember that our species has, perhaps,

00:17:58.958 --> 00:18:00.958
been around for [150,000] years.

00:18:00.958 --> 00:18:03.958
The Neolithic Revolution -- which gave us agriculture,

00:18:03.958 --> 00:18:05.958
at which time we succumbed to the cult of the seed;

00:18:05.958 --> 00:18:07.958
the poetry of the shaman was displaced

00:18:07.958 --> 00:18:08.958
by the prose of the priesthood;

00:18:08.958 --> 00:18:11.958
we created hierarchy specialization surplus --

00:18:11.958 --> 00:18:13.958
is only 10,000 years ago.

00:18:13.958 --> 00:18:15.958
The modern industrial world as we know it

00:18:15.958 --> 00:18:17.958
is barely 300 years old.

00:18:17.958 --> 00:18:19.958
Now, that shallow history doesn't suggest to me

00:18:19.958 --> 00:18:22.958
that we have all the answers for all of the challenges

00:18:22.958 --> 00:18:24.958
that will confront us in the ensuing millennia.

00:18:24.958 --> 00:18:26.958
When these myriad cultures of the world

00:18:26.958 --> 00:18:29.958
are asked the meaning of being human,

00:18:29.958 --> 00:18:31.958
they respond with 10,000 different voices.

00:18:31.958 --> 00:18:37.958
And it's within that song that we will all rediscover the possibility

00:18:37.958 --> 00:18:40.958
of being what we are: a fully conscious species,

00:18:40.958 --> 00:18:43.958
fully aware of ensuring that all peoples and all gardens

00:18:43.958 --> 00:18:49.958
find a way to flourish. And there are great moments of optimism.

00:18:49.958 --> 00:18:52.958
This is a photograph I took at the northern tip of Baffin Island

00:18:52.958 --> 00:18:54.958
when I went narwhal hunting with some Inuit people,

00:18:55.958 --> 00:18:58.958
and this man, Olayuk, told me a marvelous story of his grandfather.

00:18:59.958 --> 00:19:01.958
The Canadian government has not always been kind

00:19:01.958 --> 00:19:03.958
to the Inuit people, and during the 1950s,

00:19:03.958 --> 00:19:06.958
to establish our sovereignty, we forced them into settlements.

00:19:06.958 --> 00:19:10.958
This old man's grandfather refused to go.

00:19:10.958 --> 00:19:14.958
The family, fearful for his life, took away all of his weapons,

00:19:14.958 --> 00:19:15.958
all of his tools.

00:19:16.958 --> 00:19:18.958
Now, you must understand that the Inuit did not fear the cold;

00:19:18.958 --> 00:19:19.958
they took advantage of it.

00:19:19.958 --> 00:19:22.958
The runners of their sleds were originally made of fish

00:19:22.958 --> 00:19:23.958
wrapped in caribou hide.

00:19:23.958 --> 00:19:28.958
So, this man's grandfather was not intimidated by the Arctic night

00:19:28.958 --> 00:19:30.958
or the blizzard that was blowing.

00:19:30.958 --> 00:19:33.958
He simply slipped outside, pulled down his sealskin trousers

00:19:34.958 --> 00:19:37.958
and defecated into his hand. And as the feces began to freeze,

00:19:37.958 --> 00:19:40.958
he shaped it into the form of a blade.

00:19:40.958 --> 00:19:42.958
He put a spray of saliva on the edge of the shit knife

00:19:42.958 --> 00:19:45.958
and as it finally froze solid, he butchered a dog with it.

00:19:45.958 --> 00:19:48.958
He skinned the dog and improvised a harness,

00:19:48.958 --> 00:19:51.958
took the ribcage of the dog and improvised a sled,

00:19:52.958 --> 00:19:53.958
harnessed up an adjacent dog,

00:19:53.958 --> 00:19:57.958
and disappeared over the ice floes, shit knife in belt.

00:19:57.958 --> 00:20:01.958
Talk about getting by with nothing. (Laughter)

00:20:01.958 --> 00:20:02.958
And this, in many ways --

00:20:02.958 --> 00:20:04.958
(Applause) --

00:20:04.958 --> 00:20:06.958
is a symbol of the resilience of the Inuit people

00:20:06.958 --> 00:20:09.958
and of all indigenous people around the world.

00:20:09.958 --> 00:20:11.958
The Canadian government in April of 1999

00:20:11.958 --> 00:20:14.958
gave back to total control of the Inuit

00:20:14.958 --> 00:20:17.958
an area of land larger than California and Texas put together.

00:20:17.958 --> 00:20:19.958
It's our new homeland. It's called Nunavut.

00:20:20.958 --> 00:20:23.958
It's an independent territory. They control all mineral resources.

00:20:23.958 --> 00:20:25.958
An amazing example of how a nation-state

00:20:25.958 --> 00:20:29.958
can seek restitution with its people.

00:20:30.958 --> 00:20:33.958
And finally, in the end, I think it's pretty obvious

00:20:33.958 --> 00:20:34.958
at least to all of all us who've traveled

00:20:34.958 --> 00:20:36.958
in these remote reaches of the planet,

00:20:38.958 --> 00:20:39.958
to realize that they're not remote at all.

00:20:39.958 --> 00:20:41.958
They're homelands of somebody.

00:20:41.958 --> 00:20:43.958
They represent branches of the human imagination

00:20:43.958 --> 00:20:47.958
that go back to the dawn of time. And for all of us,

00:20:47.958 --> 00:20:50.958
the dreams of these children, like the dreams of our own children,

00:20:50.958 --> 00:20:53.958
become part of the naked geography of hope.

00:20:53.958 --> 00:20:57.958
So, what we're trying to do at the National Geographic, finally,

00:20:57.958 --> 00:21:01.958
is, we believe that politicians will never accomplish anything.

00:21:01.958 --> 00:21:02.958
We think that polemics --

00:21:02.958 --> 00:21:04.958
(Applause) --

00:21:04.958 --> 00:21:06.958
we think that polemics are not persuasive,

00:21:06.958 --> 00:21:09.958
but we think that storytelling can change the world,

00:21:09.958 --> 00:21:12.958
and so we are probably the best storytelling institution

00:21:12.958 --> 00:21:15.958
in the world. We get 35 million hits on our website every month.

00:21:15.958 --> 00:21:18.958
156 nations carry our television channel.

00:21:19.958 --> 00:21:21.958
Our magazines are read by millions.

00:21:21.958 --> 00:21:24.958
And what we're doing is a series of journeys

00:21:24.958 --> 00:21:26.958
to the ethnosphere where we're going to take our audience

00:21:26.958 --> 00:21:28.958
to places of such cultural wonder

00:21:29.958 --> 00:21:31.958
that they cannot help but come away dazzled

00:21:31.958 --> 00:21:33.958
by what they have seen, and hopefully, therefore,

00:21:33.958 --> 00:21:36.958
embrace gradually, one by one,

00:21:36.958 --> 00:21:38.958
the central revelation of anthropology:

00:21:38.958 --> 00:21:42.958
that this world deserves to exist in a diverse way,

00:21:42.958 --> 00:21:43.958
that we can find a way to live

00:21:43.958 --> 00:21:46.958
in a truly multicultural, pluralistic world

00:21:46.958 --> 00:21:48.958
where all of the wisdom of all peoples

00:21:48.958 --> 00:21:51.958
can contribute to our collective well-being.

00:21:51.958 --> 00:21:52.958
Thank you very much.

00:21:52.958 --> 00:21:54.958
(Applause)

title: Photos of endangered cultures
transcript: A fact came out of MIT, couple of years ago. Ken Hale, who's a linguist, said that of the 6,000 languages spoken on Earth right now, 3,000 aren't spoken by the children. So that in one generation, we're going to halve our cultural diversity. He went on to say that every two weeks, an elder goes to the grave carrying the last spoken word of that culture. So an entire philosophy, a body of knowledge about the natural world that had been empirically gleaned over centuries, goes away. And this happens every two weeks.So for the last 20 years, since my dental experience, I have been traveling the world and coming back with stories about some of these people. What I'd like to do right now is share some of those stories with you. This is Tamdin. She is a 69-year-old nun. She was thrown in prison in Tibet for two years for putting up a little tiny placard protesting the occupation of her country. And when I met her, she had just taken a walk over the Himalayas from Lhasa, the capital of Tibet, into Nepal, across to India — 30 days — to meet her leader, the Dalai Lama. The Dalai Lama lives in Dharamsala, India. So I took this picture three days after she arrived, and she had this beat-up pair of tennis shoes on, with her toes sticking out. And she crossed in March, and there's a lot of snow at 18,500 feet in March.This is Paldin. Paldin is a 62-year-old monk. And he spent 33 years in prison. His whole monastery was thrown into prison at the time of the uprising, when the Dalai Lama had to leave Tibet. And he was beaten, starved, tortured — lost all his teeth while in prison. And when I met him, he was a kind gentle old man. And it really impressed me — I met him two weeks after he got out of prison — that he went through that experience, and ended up with the demeanor that he had.So I was in Dharamsala meeting these people, and I'd spent about five weeks there, and I was hearing these similar stories of these refugees that had poured out of Tibet into Dharamsala. And it just so happened, on the fifth week, there was a public teaching by the Dalai Lama. And I was watching this crowd of monks and nuns, many of which I had just interviewed, and heard their stories, and I watched their faces, and they gave us a little FM radio, and we could listen to the translation of his teachings. And what he said was: treat your enemies as if they were precious jewels, because it's your enemies that build your tolerance and patience on the road to your enlightenment. That hit me so hard, telling these people that had been through this experience.So, two months later, I went into Tibet, and I started interviewing the people there, taking my photographs. That's what I do. I interview and do portraits. And this is a little girl. I took her portrait up on top of the Jokhang Temple. And I'd snuck in — because it's totally illegal to have a picture of the Dalai Lama in Tibet — it's the quickest way you can get arrested. So I snuck in a bunch of little wallet-sized pictures of the Dalai Lama, and I would hand them out. And when I gave them to the people, they'd either hold them to their heart, or they'd hold them up to their head and just stay there. And this is — well, at the time — I did this 10 years ago — that was 36 years after the Dalai Lama had left.So I was going in, interviewing these people and doing their portraits. This is Jigme and her sister, Sonam. And they live up on the Chang Tang, the Tibetan Plateau, way in the western part of the country. This is at 17,000 feet. And they had just come down from the high pastures, at 18,000 feet. Same thing: gave her a picture, she held it up to her forehead. And I usually hand out Polaroids when I do these, because I'm setting up lights, and checking my lights, and when I showed her her Polaroid, she screamed and ran into her tent.This is Tenzin Gyatso; he was found to be the Buddha of Compassion at the age of two, out in a peasant's house, way out in the middle of nowhere. At the age of four, he was installed as the 14th Dalai Lama. As a teenager, he faced the invasion of his country, and had to deal with it — he was the leader of the country. Eight years later, when they discovered there was a plot to kill him, they dressed him up like a beggar and snuck him out of the country on horseback, and took the same trip that Tamdin did. And he's never been back to his country since. And if you think about this man, 46 years later, still sticking to this non-violent response to a severe political and human rights issue. And the young people, young Tibetans, are starting to say, listen, this doesn't work. You know, violence as a political tool is all the rage right now. And he still is holding this line. So this is our icon to non-violence in our world — one of our living icons.This is another leader of his people. This is Moi. This is in the Ecuadorian Amazon. And Moi is 35 years old. And this area of the Ecuadorian Amazon — oil was discovered in 1972. And in this period of time — since that time — as much oil, or twice as much oil as was spilled in the Exxon Valdez accident, was spilled in this little area of the Amazon, and the tribes in this area have constantly had to move. And Moi belongs to the Huaorani tribe, and they're known as very fierce, they're known as "auca." And they've managed to keep out the seismologists and the oil workers with spears and blowguns. And we spent — I was with a team — two weeks with these guys out in the jungle watching them hunt. This was on a monkey hunt, hunting with curare-tipped darts. And the knowledge that these people have about the natural environment is incredible. They could hear things, smell things, see things I couldn't see. And I couldn't even see the monkeys that they were getting with these darts.This is Yadira, and Yadira is five years old. She's in a tribe that's neighboring the Huaorani. And her tribe has had to move three times in the last 10 years because of the oil spills. And we never hear about that. And the latest infraction against these people is, as part of Plan Colombia, we're spraying Paraquat or Round Up, whatever it is — we're defoliating thousands of acres of the Ecuadorian Amazon in our war on drugs. And these people are the people who take the brunt of it.This is Mengatoue. He's the shaman of the Huaorani, and he said to us, you know, I'm an older man now; I'm getting tired, you know; I'm tired of spearing these oil workers. I wish they would just go away. And I was — I usually travel alone when I do my work, but I did this — I hosted a program for Discovery, and when I went down with the team, I was quite concerned about going in with a whole bunch of people, especially into the Huaorani, deep into the Huaorani tribe. And as it turned out, these guys really taught me a thing or two about blending in with the locals. (Laughter)One of the things I did just before 9/11 — August of 2001 — I took my son, Dax, who was 16 at the time, and I took him to Pakistan. Because at first I wanted — you know, I've taken him on a couple of trips, but I wanted him to see people that live on a dollar a day or less. I wanted him to get an experience in the Islamic world and I also wanted him to — I was going there to work with a group, do a story on a group called the Kalash, that are a group of animists, 3,000 animists, that live — very small area — surrounded by Islam — there's 3,000 of these Kalash left; they're incredible people. So it was a great experience for him. He stayed up all night with them, drumming and dancing. And he brought a soccer ball, and we had soccer every night in this little village.And then we went up and met their shaman. By the way, Mengatoue was the shaman of his tribe as well. And this is John Doolikahn, who's the shaman of the Kalash. And he's up in the mountains, right on the border with Afghanistan. In fact, on that other side is the area, Tora Bora, the area where Osama bin Laden's supposed to be. This is the tribal area. And we watched and stayed with John Doolikahn. And the shaman — I did a whole series on shamanism, which is an interesting phenomenon. But around the world, they go into trance in different ways, and in Pakistan, the way they do it is they burn juniper leaves and they sacrifice an animal, pour the blood of the animal on the leaves and then inhale the smoke. And they're all praying to the mountain gods as they go into trance.You know, getting kids used to different realities, I think, is so important. What Dan Dennett said the other day — having a curriculum where they study different religions, just to make a mental flexibility, give them a mental flexibility in different belief systems — I think this is so necessary in our world today as you see these clash of beliefs taking place. And all the security issues they cause us. So, one thing we did five years ago: we started a program that links kids in indigenous communities with kids in the United States. So we first hooked up a spot in the Navajo Nation with a classroom in Seattle. We now have 15 sites. We have one in Kathmandu, Nepal; Dharamsala, India; Takaungu, Kenya — Takaungu is one-third Christian, one-third Muslim and one-third animist, the community is — Ollantaytambo, Peru, and Arctic Village, Alaska.This is Daniel; he's one of our students in Arctic Village, Alaska. He lives in this log cabin — no running water, no heat other than — no windows and high-speed Internet connection. And this is — I see this rolling out all over — this is our site in Ollantaytambo, Peru, four years ago, where they first saw their first computers; now they have computers in their classrooms. And the way we've done this — we teach digital storytelling to these kids. And we have them tell stories about issues in their community in their community that they care about. And this is in Peru, where the kids told the story about a river that they cleaned up. And the way we do it is, we do it in workshops, and we bring people who want to learn digital workflow and storytelling, and have them work with the kids. And just this last year we've taken a group of teenagers in, and this has worked the best. So our dream is to bring teenagers together, so they'll have a community service experience as well as a cross-cultural experience, as they teach kids in these areas and help them build their communication infrastructure.This is teaching Photoshop in the Tibetan children's village in Dharamsala. We have the website, where the kids all get their homepage. This is all their movies. We've got about 60 movies that these kids have made, and they're quite incredible. The one I want to show you — after we get them to make the movies, we have a night where we show the movies to the community. And this is in Takaungu — we've got a generator and a digital projector, and we're projecting it up against a barn, and showing one of the movies that they made. And if you get a chance, you can go to our website, and you'll see the incredible work these kids do.The other thing: I wanted to give indigenous people a voice. That was one of the big motivating factors. But the other motivating factor is the insular nature of our country. National Geographic just did a Roper Study of 18 to 26 year olds in our country and in nine other industrialized countries. It was a two million dollar study. United States came in second to last in geographic knowledge. 70 percent of the kids couldn't find Afghanistan or Iraq on a map; 60 percent couldn't find India; 30 percent couldn't find the Pacific Ocean. And this is a study that was just done a couple of years ago.So what I'd like to show you now, in the couple of minutes I have left, is a film that a student made in Guatemala. We just had a workshop in Guatemala. A week before we got to the workshop, a massive landslide, caused by Hurricane Stan, last October, came in and buried 600 people alive in their village. And this kid lived in the village — he wasn't there at the time — and this is the little movie he put together about that. And he hadn't seen a computer before we did this movie. We taught him Photoshop and — yeah, we can play it.This is an old Mayan funeral chant that he got from his grandfather.Thank you very much. (Applause)

00:02:59.958 --> 00:03:02.958
And it just so happened, on the fifth week,

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:06.958
there was a public teaching by the Dalai Lama.

00:03:06.958 --> 00:03:08.958
And

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:11.958
I was watching this crowd of monks and nuns,

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:13.958
many of which I had just interviewed,

00:03:13.958 --> 00:03:15.958
and heard their stories,

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:18.958
and I watched their faces,

00:03:18.958 --> 00:03:20.958
and they gave us a little FM radio,

00:03:20.958 --> 00:03:23.958
and we could listen to the translation of his teachings.

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:25.958
And what he said was:

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:29.958
treat your enemies as if they were precious jewels,

00:03:29.958 --> 00:03:31.958
because it's your enemies

00:03:31.958 --> 00:03:34.958
that build your tolerance and patience

00:03:34.958 --> 00:03:38.958
on the road to your enlightenment.

00:03:38.958 --> 00:03:41.958
That hit me so hard,

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:45.958
telling these people that had been through this experience.

00:03:46.958 --> 00:03:49.958
So, two months later, I went into

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:51.958
Tibet, and I started

00:03:51.958 --> 00:03:54.958
interviewing the people there, taking my photographs. That's what I do.

00:03:54.958 --> 00:03:57.958
I interview and do portraits.

00:03:57.958 --> 00:03:59.958
And this is a little girl.

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:02.958
I took her portrait up on top of the Jokhang Temple.

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:04.958
And I'd snuck in --

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:09.958
because it's totally illegal to have a picture of the Dalai Lama in Tibet --

00:04:09.958 --> 00:04:12.958
it's the quickest way you can get arrested.

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:15.958
So I snuck in a bunch of little wallet-sized pictures of the Dalai Lama,

00:04:15.958 --> 00:04:17.958
and I would hand them out.

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:20.958
And when I gave them to the people,

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:22.958
they'd either hold them to their heart,

00:04:22.958 --> 00:04:25.958
or they'd hold them up to their head and just stay there.

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:27.958
And this is --

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:29.958
well, at the time -- I did this 10 years ago --

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:32.958
that was 36 years after the Dalai Lama had left.

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:35.958
So

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:39.958
I was going in, interviewing these people and doing their portraits.

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:41.958
This is Jigme and her sister, Sonam.

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:44.958
And they live up on the Chang Tang, the Tibetan Plateau,

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:47.958
way in the western part of the country.

00:04:47.958 --> 00:04:49.958
This is at 17,000 feet.

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:52.958
And they had just come down from the high pastures,

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:54.958
at 18,000 feet.

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:56.958
Same thing: gave her a picture,

00:04:56.958 --> 00:04:58.958
she held it up to her forehead.

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:01.958
And I usually hand out Polaroids

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:03.958
when I do these, because I'm setting up lights,

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:05.958
and checking my lights,

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:08.958
and when I showed her her Polaroid, she screamed and ran into her tent.

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:12.958
This is Tenzin Gyatso;

00:05:12.958 --> 00:05:16.958
he was found to be the Buddha of Compassion at the age of two,

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:19.958
out in a peasant's house,

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:21.958
way out in the middle of nowhere.

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:23.958
At the age of four, he was installed

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:26.958
as the 14th Dalai Lama.

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:28.958
As a teenager, he faced

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:30.958
the invasion of his country,

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:33.958
and had to deal with it -- he was the leader of the country.

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:35.958
Eight years later, when they discovered there was a plot

00:05:35.958 --> 00:05:37.958
to kill him,

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:39.958
they dressed him up like a beggar

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:42.958
and snuck him out of the country on horseback,

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:45.958
and took the same trip that Tamdin did.

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:49.958
And he's never been back to his country since.

00:05:49.958 --> 00:05:51.958
And

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:53.958
if you think about this man,

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:55.958
46 years later,

00:05:55.958 --> 00:05:57.958
still sticking

00:05:57.958 --> 00:06:01.958
to this non-violent response

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:05.958
to a severe political and human rights issue.

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:07.958
And the young people,

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:10.958
young Tibetans, are starting to say, listen, this doesn't work.

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:12.958
You know, violence as a political tool

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:14.958
is all the rage right now.

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:17.958
And

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:19.958
he still is holding this line.

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:21.958
So this is our icon

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:24.958
to non-violence in our world --

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:26.958
one of our living icons.

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:29.958
This is another leader of his people.

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:32.958
This is Moi. This is in the Ecuadorian Amazon.

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:35.958
And Moi is 35 years old.

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:37.958
And

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:39.958
this area of the Ecuadorian Amazon --

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:42.958
oil was discovered in 1972.

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:45.958
And in this period of time -- since that time --

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:48.958
as much oil, or twice as much oil

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:51.958
as was spilled in the Exxon Valdez accident,

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:54.958
was spilled in this little area of the Amazon,

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:58.958
and the tribes in this area have constantly had to move.

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:00.958
And Moi

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:02.958
belongs to the Huaorani tribe,

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:04.958
and they're known as

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:06.958
very fierce, they're known as "auca."

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:09.958
And they've managed to keep out

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:11.958
the seismologists and the oil workers

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:14.958
with spears and blowguns.

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:16.958
And we spent --

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:19.958
I was with a team --

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:22.958
two weeks with these guys out in the jungle

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:24.958
watching them hunt.

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:26.958
This was on a monkey hunt,

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:29.958
hunting with curare-tipped darts.

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:32.958
And the knowledge that these people have

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:34.958
about the natural environment is incredible.

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:38.958
They could hear things, smell things, see things I couldn't see.

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:40.958
And I couldn't even see the monkeys

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:42.958
that they were

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:46.958
getting with these darts.

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:48.958
This is Yadira,

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:50.958
and Yadira is

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:53.958
five years old. She's in a

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:56.958
tribe that's neighboring the Huaorani.

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:58.958
And her tribe has had to move

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:02.958
three times in the last 10 years because of the oil spills.

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:05.958
And we never hear about that. And the latest

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:08.958
infraction against these people is,

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:10.958
as part of Plan Colombia,

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:13.958
we're spraying Paraquat or Round Up, whatever it is --

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:16.958
we're defoliating thousands of acres

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:18.958
of the Ecuadorian Amazon

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:20.958
in our war on drugs.

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:24.958
And these people are the people who take the brunt of it.

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:26.958
This is Mengatoue.

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:28.958
He's the shaman of the Huaorani,

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:31.958
and

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:34.958
he said to us, you know, I'm an older man now;

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:36.958
I'm getting tired, you know; I'm tired

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:38.958
of spearing these oil workers.

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:41.958
I wish they would just go away.

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:46.958
And I was -- I usually travel alone

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:49.958
when I do my work, but I did this --

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:51.958
I hosted a program for Discovery,

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:54.958
and when I went down with the team,

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:57.958
I was quite concerned about

00:08:57.958 --> 00:09:00.958
going in with a whole bunch of people, especially into the Huaorani,

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:02.958
deep into the Huaorani tribe.

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:04.958
And

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:06.958
as it turned out, these guys really

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:09.958
taught me a thing or two about blending in

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:11.958
with the locals.

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:14.958
(Laughter)

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:17.958
One of the things I did

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:20.958
just before 9/11 --

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:22.958
August of 2001 --

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:24.958
I took my son, Dax,

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:27.958
who was 16 at the time,

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:29.958
and I took him to Pakistan.

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:31.958
Because at first I wanted --

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:33.958
you know, I've taken him on a couple of trips,

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:35.958
but I wanted him to see

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:38.958
people that live on a dollar a day or less.

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:40.958
I wanted him to get an experience

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:42.958
in the Islamic world

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:45.958
and I also wanted him to --

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:47.958
I was going there to work with a group,

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:49.958
do a story on a group called the Kalash,

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:51.958
that are a group of animists, 3,000 animists,

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:55.958
that live -- very small area --

00:09:55.958 --> 00:09:58.958
surrounded by Islam -- there's 3,000

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:02.958
of these Kalash left; they're incredible people.

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:05.958
So it was a great experience for him. He stayed up all night with them,

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:07.958
drumming and dancing.

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:09.958
And he brought a soccer ball,

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:12.958
and we had soccer every night in this little village.

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:14.958
And then we went up

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:16.958
and met their shaman.

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:18.958
By the way, Mengatoue was the shaman

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:20.958
of his tribe as well.

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:22.958
And this is John Doolikahn,

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:25.958
who's the shaman of the Kalash.

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:27.958
And he's up in the mountains,

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:29.958
right on the border with Afghanistan.

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:32.958
In fact, on that other side is the area, Tora Bora,

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:35.958
the area where

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:38.958
Osama bin Laden's supposed to be. This is the tribal area.

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:41.958
And we watched

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:43.958
and stayed with

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:45.958
John Doolikahn.

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:48.958
And the shaman -- I did a whole series on shamanism,

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:50.958
which is

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:52.958
an interesting phenomenon.

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:54.958
But around the world,

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:56.958
they go into trance in different ways,

00:10:56.958 --> 00:10:58.958
and in Pakistan,

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:01.958
the way they do it is they burn juniper leaves

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:04.958
and they sacrifice an animal,

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:06.958
pour the blood of the animal on the leaves

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:08.958
and then inhale the smoke.

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:11.958
And they're all praying

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:14.958
to the mountain gods

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:17.958
as they go into trance.

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:20.958
You know,

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:24.958
getting kids used to different realities,

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:27.958
I think, is so important. What Dan Dennett said the other day --

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:31.958
having a curriculum where they study different religions,

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:33.958
just to make a mental flexibility,

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:35.958
give them a mental flexibility

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:37.958
in different belief systems --

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:40.958
I think this is so necessary in our world today

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:44.958
as you see these clash of beliefs taking place.

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:48.958
And all the security issues they cause us.

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:51.958
So, one thing we did five years ago:

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:53.958
we started a program that links kids

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:56.958
in indigenous communities with kids in the United States.

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:59.958
So we first hooked up

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:04.958
a spot in the Navajo Nation with a classroom in Seattle.

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:07.958
We now have 15 sites.

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:10.958
We have one in Kathmandu, Nepal;

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:12.958
Dharamsala, India; Takaungu, Kenya --

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:15.958
Takaungu is one-third Christian, one-third Muslim

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:18.958
and one-third animist, the community is --

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:20.958
Ollantaytambo, Peru,

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:22.958
and Arctic Village, Alaska.

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:24.958
This is Daniel; he's one of our students

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:26.958
in Arctic Village, Alaska.

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:28.958
He lives in this log cabin --

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:31.958
no running water, no heat other than --

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:33.958
no windows

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:35.958
and high-speed Internet connection.

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:37.958
And this is --

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:39.958
I see this rolling out all over --

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:41.958
this is our site in Ollantaytambo, Peru, four years ago,

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:44.958
where they first saw their first computers;

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:47.958
now they have computers in their classrooms.

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:49.958
And the way we've done this --

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:52.958
we teach digital storytelling to these kids.

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:55.958
And we have them tell stories about issues in their community

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:57.958
in their community that they care about.

00:12:57.958 --> 00:12:59.958
And this is in Peru, where the kids told the story

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:01.958
about a river that they cleaned up.

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:04.958
And the way we do it is, we do it in workshops,

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:07.958
and we bring people who want to learn

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:10.958
digital workflow and storytelling,

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:13.958
and have them

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:15.958
work with the kids.

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:19.958
And just this last year we've taken a group of teenagers in,

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:21.958
and this has worked the best.

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:23.958
So our dream is to bring teenagers together,

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:26.958
so they'll have a community service experience

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:29.958
as well as a cross-cultural experience,

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:31.958
as they teach kids in these areas

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:34.958
and help them build their communication infrastructure.

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:37.958
This is teaching Photoshop

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:41.958
in the Tibetan children's village in Dharamsala.

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:44.958
We have the website, where the kids all get their homepage.

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:46.958
This is all their movies. We've got about 60 movies

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:48.958
that these kids have made,

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:50.958
and they're quite incredible.

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:52.958
The one I want to show you --

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:55.958
after we get them to make the movies,

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:58.958
we have a night where we show the movies to the community.

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:00.958
And this is in Takaungu --

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:02.958
we've got a generator and a digital projector,

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:04.958
and we're projecting it up against a barn,

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:07.958
and showing one of the movies that they made.

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:10.958
And if you get a chance, you can go to our website, and you'll see

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:13.958
the incredible work these kids do.

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:16.958
The other thing:

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:18.958
I wanted to give indigenous people a voice.

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:21.958
That was one of the big motivating factors.

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:23.958
But the other motivating factor is

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:26.958
the insular nature of our country.

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:29.958
National Geographic just did a Roper Study

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:32.958
of 18 to 26 year olds

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:34.958
in our country

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:37.958
and in nine other industrialized countries.

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:39.958
It was a two million dollar study.

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:42.958
United States came in second to last

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:44.958
in geographic knowledge.

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:46.958
70 percent of the kids couldn't find

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:49.958
Afghanistan or Iraq on a map;

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:52.958
60 percent couldn't find India;

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:55.958
30 percent couldn't find the Pacific Ocean.

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:57.958
And this is a study

00:14:57.958 --> 00:15:00.958
that was just done a couple of years ago.

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:03.958
So what I'd like to show you now,

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:06.958
in the couple of minutes I have left,

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:08.958
is a film that a student made in Guatemala.

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:11.958
We just had a workshop in Guatemala.

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:14.958
A week before we got to the workshop,

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:18.958
a massive landslide, caused by Hurricane Stan,

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:20.958
last October, came in and buried

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:22.958
600 people alive in their village.

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:24.958
And this kid lived in the village --

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:26.958
he wasn't there at the time --

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:30.958
and this is the little movie he put together about that.

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:32.958
And he hadn't seen a computer before

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:36.958
we did this movie. We taught him Photoshop and --

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:38.958
yeah, we can play it.

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:04.958
This is an old Mayan funeral chant

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:06.958
that he got from his grandfather.

00:18:24.958 --> 00:18:26.958
Thank you very much.

00:18:26.958 --> 00:18:27.958
(Applause)

title: Is this our final century?
transcript: If you take 10,000 people at random, 9,999 have something in common: their interests in business lie on or near the Earth's surface. The odd one out is an astronomer, and I am one of that strange breed. (Laughter) My talk will be in two parts. I'll talk first as an astronomer, and then as a worried member of the human race. But let's start off by remembering that Darwin showed how we're the outcome of four billion years of evolution. And what we try to do in astronomy and cosmology is to go back before Darwin's simple beginning, to set our Earth in a cosmic context.And let me just run through a few slides. And we can see places where stars are forming, like the Eagle Nebula. We see stars dying. In six billion years, the sun will look like that. And some stars die spectacularly in a supernova explosion, leaving remnants like that.On a still bigger scale, we see entire galaxies of stars. We see entire ecosystems where gas is being recycled. This picture shows a patch of sky so small that it would take about 100 patches like it to cover the full moon in the sky. Through a small telescope, this would look quite blank, but you see here hundreds of little, faint smudges. Each is a galaxy, fully like ours or Andromeda, which looks so small and faint because its light has taken 10 billion light-years to get to us. The stars in those galaxies probably don't have planets around them. There's scant chance of life there — that's because there's been no time for the nuclear fusion in stars to make silicon and carbon and iron, the building blocks of planets and of life. We believe that all of this emerged from a Big Bang — a hot, dense state. So how did that amorphous Big Bang turn into our complex cosmos?I'm going to show you a movie simulation 16 powers of 10 faster than real time, which shows a patch of the universe where the expansions have subtracted out. But you see, as time goes on in gigayears at the bottom, you will see structures evolve as gravity feeds on small, dense irregularities, and structures develop. And we'll end up after 13 billion years with something looking rather like our own universe. And we compare simulated universes like that — I'll show you a better simulation at the end of my talk — with what we actually see in the sky. Well, we can trace things back to the earlier stages of the Big Bang, but we still don't know what banged and why it banged.That's a challenge for 21st-century science. If my research group had a logo, it would be this picture here: an ouroboros, where you see the micro-world on the left — the world of the quantum — and on the right the large-scale universe of planets, stars and galaxies. We know our universes are united though — links between left and right. The everyday world is determined by atoms, how they stick together to make molecules. Stars are fueled by how the nuclei in those atoms react together. And, as we've learned in the last few years, galaxies are held together by the gravitational pull of so-called dark matter: particles in huge swarms, far smaller even than atomic nuclei. But we'd like to know the synthesis symbolized at the very top. The micro-world of the quantum is understood. On the right hand side, gravity holds sway. Einstein explained that. But the unfinished business for 21st-century science is to link together cosmos and micro-world with a unified theory — symbolized, as it were, gastronomically at the top of that picture. One idea is that our three-dimensional universe may be embedded in a high-dimensional space, just as you can imagine on these sheets of paper. There's one challenge symbolized at the top, but there's another challenge to science symbolized at the bottom. You want to not only synthesize the very large and the very small, but we want to understand the very complex. And the most complex things are ourselves, midway between atoms and stars. We depend on stars to make the atoms we're made of. We depend on chemistry to determine our complex structure. We clearly have to be large, compared to atoms, to have layer upon layer of complex structure. We clearly have to be small, compared to stars and planets — otherwise we'd be crushed by gravity.
