Bio- and cybertechnologies are environmentally benign

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:07.958
in that they offer marvelous prospects,

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:10.958
while, nonetheless, reducing pressure on energy and resources.

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:13.958
But they will have a dark side.

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:18.958
In our interconnected world, novel technology could empower

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:20.958
just one fanatic,

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:24.958
or some weirdo with a mindset of those who now design computer viruses,

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:26.958
to trigger some kind on disaster.

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:30.958
Indeed, catastrophe could arise simply from technical misadventure --

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:32.958
error rather than terror.

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:37.958
And even a tiny probability of catastrophe is unacceptable

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:40.958
when the downside could be of global consequence.

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:46.958
In fact, some years ago, Bill Joy wrote an article

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:50.958
expressing tremendous concern about robots taking us over, etc.

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:51.958
I don't go along with all that,

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:53.958
but it's interesting that he had a simple solution.

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:56.958
It was what he called "fine-grained relinquishment."

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:59.958
He wanted to give up the dangerous kind of science

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:03.958
and keep the good bits. Now, that's absurdly naive for two reasons.

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:07.958
First, any scientific discovery has benign consequences

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:09.958
as well as dangerous ones.

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:12.958
And also, when a scientist makes a discovery,

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:16.958
he or she normally has no clue what the applications are going to be.

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:21.958
And so what this means is that we have to accept the risks

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:25.958
if we are going to enjoy the benefits of science.

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:27.958
We have to accept that there will be hazards.

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:34.958
And I think we have to go back to what happened in the post-War era,

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:37.958
post-World War II, when the nuclear scientists

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:39.958
who'd been involved in making the atomic bomb,

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:43.958
in many cases were concerned that they should do all they could

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:45.958
to alert the world to the dangers.

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:49.958
And they were inspired not by the young Einstein,

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:54.958
who did the great work in relativity, but by the old Einstein,

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:57.958
the icon of poster and t-shirt,

00:10:57.958 --> 00:11:01.958
who failed in his scientific efforts to unify the physical laws.

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:04.958
He was premature. But he was a moral compass --

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:09.958
an inspiration to scientists who were concerned with arms control.

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:11.958
And perhaps the greatest living person

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:14.958
is someone I'm privileged to know, Joe Rothblatt.

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:17.958
Equally untidy office there, as you can see.

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:21.958
He's 96 years old, and he founded the Pugwash movement.

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:23.958
He persuaded Einstein, as his last act,

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:26.958
to sign the famous memorandum of Bertrand Russell.

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:30.958
And he sets an example of the concerned scientist.

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:34.958
And I think to harness science optimally,

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:37.958
to choose which doors to open and which to leave closed,

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:42.958
we need latter-day counterparts of people like Joseph Rothblatt.

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:44.958
We need not just campaigning physicists,

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:46.958
but we need biologists, computer experts

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:48.958
and environmentalists as well.

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:52.958
And I think academics and independent entrepreneurs

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:54.958
have a special obligation because they have more freedom

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:56.958
than those in government service,

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:59.958
or company employees subject to commercial pressure.

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:04.958
I wrote my book, "Our Final Century," as a scientist,

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:07.958
just a general scientist. But there's one respect, I think,

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:11.958
in which being a cosmologist offered a special perspective,

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:15.958
and that's that it offers an awareness of the immense future.

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:18.958
The stupendous time spans of the evolutionary past

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:21.958
are now part of common culture --

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:24.958
outside the American Bible Belt, anyway --

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:25.958
(Laughter)

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:29.958
but most people, even those who are familiar with evolution,

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:32.958
aren't mindful that even more time lies ahead.

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:36.958
The sun has been shining for four and a half billion years,

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:40.958
but it'll be another six billion years before its fuel runs out.

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:45.958
On that schematic picture, a sort of time-lapse picture, we're halfway.

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:51.958
And it'll be another six billion before that happens,

00:12:51.958 --> 00:12:55.958
and any remaining life on Earth is vaporized.

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:59.958
There's an unthinking tendency to imagine that humans will be there,

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:01.958
experiencing the sun's demise,

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:04.958
but any life and intelligence that exists then

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:08.958
will be as different from us as we are from bacteria.

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:10.958
The unfolding of intelligence and complexity

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:15.958
still has immensely far to go, here on Earth and probably far beyond.

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:19.958
So we are still at the beginning of the emergence of complexity

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:21.958
in our Earth and beyond.

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:26.958
If you represent the Earth's lifetime by a single year,

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:29.958
say from January when it was made to December,

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:34.958
the 21st-century would be a quarter of a second in June --

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:37.958
a tiny fraction of the year.

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:42.958
But even in this concertinaed cosmic perspective,

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:44.958
our century is very, very special,

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:49.958
the first when humans can change themselves and their home planet.

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:53.958
As I should have shown this earlier,

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:56.958
it will not be humans who witness the end point of the sun;

00:13:56.958 --> 00:13:59.958
it will be creatures as different from us as we are from bacteria.

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:04.958
When Einstein died in 1955,

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:07.958
one striking tribute to his global status was this cartoon

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:09.958
by Herblock in the Washington Post.

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:12.958
The plaque reads, "Albert Einstein lived here."

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:17.958
And I'd like to end with a vignette, as it were, inspired by this image.

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:23.958
We've been familiar for 40 years with this image:

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:26.958
the fragile beauty of land, ocean and clouds,

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:28.958
contrasted with the sterile moonscape

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:31.958
on which the astronauts left their footprints.

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:36.958
But let's suppose some aliens had been watching our pale blue dot

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:40.958
in the cosmos from afar, not just for 40 years,

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:44.958
but for the entire 4.5 billion-year history of our Earth.

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:47.958
What would they have seen?

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:49.958
Over nearly all that immense time,

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:52.958
Earth's appearance would have changed very gradually.

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:54.958
The only abrupt worldwide change

00:14:54.958 --> 00:15:00.958
would have been major asteroid impacts or volcanic super-eruptions.

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:04.958
Apart from those brief traumas, nothing happens suddenly.

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:07.958
The continental landmasses drifted around.

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:09.958
Ice cover waxed and waned.

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:12.958
Successions of new species emerged, evolved and became extinct.

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:17.958
But in just a tiny sliver of the Earth's history,

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:20.958
the last one-millionth part, a few thousand years,

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:24.958
the patterns of vegetation altered much faster than before.

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:27.958
This signaled the start of agriculture.

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:31.958
Change has accelerated as human populations rose.

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:33.958
Then other things happened even more abruptly.

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:35.958
Within just 50 years --

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:39.958
that's one hundredth of one millionth of the Earth's age --

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:43.958
the amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere started to rise,

00:15:43.958 --> 00:15:45.958
and ominously fast.

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:47.958
The planet became an intense emitter of radio waves --

00:15:47.958 --> 00:15:51.958
the total output from all TV and cell phones

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:54.958
and radar transmissions. And something else happened.

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:59.958
Metallic objects -- albeit very small ones, a few tons at most --

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:02.958
escaped into orbit around the Earth.

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:04.958
Some journeyed to the moons and planets.

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:06.958
A race of advanced extraterrestrials

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:09.958
watching our solar system from afar

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:14.958
could confidently predict Earth's final doom in another six billion years.

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:18.958
But could they have predicted this unprecedented spike

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:21.958
less than halfway through the Earth's life?

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:23.958
These human-induced alterations

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:27.958
occupying overall less than a millionth of the elapsed lifetime

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:30.958
and seemingly occurring with runaway speed?

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:32.958
If they continued their vigil,

00:16:32.958 --> 00:16:34.958
what might these hypothetical aliens witness

00:16:34.958 --> 00:16:36.958
in the next hundred years?

00:16:37.958 --> 00:16:40.958
Will some spasm foreclose Earth's future?

00:16:40.958 --> 00:16:42.958
Or will the biosphere stabilize?

00:16:43.958 --> 00:16:46.958
Or will some of the metallic objects launched from the Earth

00:16:46.958 --> 00:16:50.958
spawn new oases, a post-human life elsewhere?

00:16:50.958 --> 00:16:53.958
The science done by the young Einstein will continue

00:16:53.958 --> 00:16:58.958
as long as our civilization, but for civilization to survive,

00:16:58.958 --> 00:17:00.958
we'll need the wisdom of the old Einstein --

00:17:00.958 --> 00:17:02.958
humane, global and farseeing.

00:17:02.958 --> 00:17:07.958
And whatever happens in this uniquely crucial century

00:17:07.958 --> 00:17:13.958
will resonate into the remote future and perhaps far beyond the Earth,

00:17:13.958 --> 00:17:15.958
far beyond the Earth as depicted here.

00:17:15.958 --> 00:17:17.958
Thank you very much.

00:17:17.958 --> 00:17:20.958
(Applause)

title: Progress is not a zero-sum game
transcript: I've got apparently 18 minutes to convince you that history has a direction, an arrow; that in some fundamental sense, it's good; that the arrow points to something positive. Now, when the TED people first approached me about giving this upbeat talk — (Laughter) — that was before the cartoon of Muhammad had triggered global rioting. It was before the avian flu had reached Europe. It was before Hamas had won the Palestinian election, eliciting various counter-measures by Israel. And to be honest, if I had known when I was asked to give this upbeat talk that even as I was giving the upbeat talk, the apocalypse would be unfolding — (Laughter) — I might have said, "Is it okay if I talk about something else?" But I didn't, OK. So we're here. I'll do what I can. I'll do what I can.I've got to warn you: the sense in which my worldview is upbeat has always been kind of subtle, sometimes even elusive. (Laughter) The sense in which I can be uplifting and inspiring — I mean, there's always been a kind of a certain grim dimension to the way I try to uplift, so if grim inspiration — (Laughter) — if grim inspiration is not a contradiction in terms, that is, I'm afraid, the most you can hope for. OK, today — that's if I succeed. I'll see what I can do. OK?Now, in one sense, the claim that history has a direction is not that controversial. If you're just talking about social structure, OK, clearly that's gotten more complex a little over the last 10,000 years — has reached higher and higher levels. And in fact, that's actually sustaining a long-standing trend that predates human beings, OK, that biological evolution was doing for us. Because what happened in the beginning, this stuff encases itself in a cell, then cells start hanging out together in societies. Eventually they get so close, they form multicellular organisms, then you get complex multicellular organisms; they form societies.But then at some point, one of these multicellular organisms does something completely amazing with this stuff, which is it launches a whole second kind of evolution: cultural evolution. And amazingly, that evolution sustains the trajectory that biological evolution had established toward greater complexity. By cultural evolution we mean the evolution of ideas. A lot of you have heard the term "memes." The evolution of technology, I pay a lot of attention to, so, you know, one of the first things you got was a little hand axe. Generations go by, somebody says, hey, why don't we put it on a stick? (Laughter) Just absolutely delights the little ones. Next best thing to a video game.This may not seem to impress, but technological evolution is progressive, so another 10, 20,000 years, and armaments technology takes you here. (Laughter) Impressive. And the rate of technological evolution speeds up, so a mere quarter of a century after this, you get this, OK. (Laughter) And this. (Laughter) I'm sorry — it was a cheap laugh, but I wanted to find a way to transition back to this idea of the unfolding apocalypse, and I thought that might do it. (Applause)So, what threatens to happen with this unfolding apocalypse is the collapse of global social organization. Now, first let me remind you how much work it took to get us where we are, to be on the brink of true global social organization. Originally, you had the most complex societies, the hunter-gatherer village. Stonehenge is the remnant of a chiefdom, which is what you get with the invention of agriculture: multi-village polity with centralized rule. With the invention of writing, you start getting cities. This is blurry. I kind of like that because it makes it look like a one-celled organism and reminds you how many levels organic organization has already moved through to get to this point. And then you get to, you know, you get empires.I want to stress, you know, social organization can transcend political bounds. This is the Silk Road connecting the Chinese Empire and the Roman Empire. So you had social complexity spanning the whole continent, even if no polity did similarly. Today, you've got nation states. Point is: there's obviously collaboration and organization going on beyond national bounds. This is actually just a picture of the earth at night, and I'm just putting it up because I think it's pretty. Does kind of convey the sense that this is an integrated system.Now, I explained this growth of complexity by reference to something called "non-zero sumness." Assuming that a few of you did not do the assigned reading, very quickly, the key idea is the distinction between zero-sum games, in which correlations are inverse: always a winner and a loser. Non-zero-sum games in which correlations can be positive, OK. So like in tennis, usually it's win-lose; it always adds up to zero-zero-sum. But if you're playing doubles, the person on your side of the net, they're in the same boat as you, so you're playing a non-zero-sum game with them. It's either for the better or for the worse, OK. A lot of forms of non-zero-sum behavior in the realm of economics and so on in everyday life often leads to cooperation.The argument I make is basically that, well, non-zero-sum games have always been part of life. You have them in hunter-gatherer societies, but then through technological evolution, new forms of technology arise that facilitate or encourage the playing of non-zero-sum games, involving more people over larger territory. Social structure adapts to accommodate this possibility and to harness this productive potential, so you get cities, you know, and you get all the non-zero-sum games you don't think about that are being played across the world. Like, have you ever thought when you buy a car, how many people on how many different continents contributed to the manufacture of that car? Those are people in effect you're playing a non-zero-sum game with. I mean, there are certainly plenty of them around.Now, this sounds like an intrinsically upbeat worldview in a way, because when you think of non-zero, you think win-win, you know, that's good. Well, there are a few reasons that actually it's not intrinsically upbeat. First of all, it can accommodate; it doesn't deny the existence of inequality exploitation war. But there's a more fundamental reason that it's not intrinsically upbeat, because a non-zero-sum game, all it tells you for sure is that the fortunes will be correlated for better or worse. It doesn't necessarily predict a win-win outcome.So, in a way, the question is: on what grounds am I upbeat at all about history? And the answer is, first of all, on balance I would say people have played their games to more win-win outcomes than lose-lose outcomes. On balance, I think history is a net positive in the non-zero-sum game department. And a testament to this is the thing that most amazes me, most impresses me, and most uplifts me, which is that there is a moral dimension to history; there is a moral arrow. We have seen moral progress over time.2,500 years ago, members of one Greek city-state considered members of another Greek city-state subhuman and treated them that way. And then this moral revolution arrived, and they decided that actually, no, Greeks are human beings. It's just the Persians who aren't fully human and don't deserve to be treated very nicely.But this was progress — you know, give them credit. And now today, we've seen more progress. I think — I hope — most people here would say that all people everywhere are human beings, deserve to be treated decently, unless they do something horrendous, regardless of race or religion. And you have to read your ancient history to realize what a revolution that has been, OK. This was not a prevalent view, few thousand years ago, and I attribute it to this non-zero-sum dynamic. I think that's the reason there is as much tolerance toward nationalities, ethnicities, religions as there is today. If you asked me, you know, why am I not in favor of bombing Japan, well, I'm only half-joking when I say they built my car. We have this non-zero-sum relationship, and I think that does lead to a kind of a tolerance to the extent that you realize that someone else's welfare is positively correlated with yours — you're more likely to cut them a break.I kind of think this is a kind of a business-class morality. Unfortunately, I don't fly trans-Atlantic business class often enough to know, or any other kind of business class really, but I assume that in business class, you don't hear many expressions of, you know, bigotry about racial groups or ethnic groups, because the people who are flying trans-Atlantic business class are doing business with all these people; they're making money off all these people. And I really do think that, in that sense at least, capitalism has been a constructive force, and more fundamentally, it's a non-zero-sumness that has been a constructive force in expanding people's realm of moral awareness. I think the non-zero-sum dynamic, which is not only economic by any means — it's not always commerce — but it has driven us to the verge of a moral truth, which is the fundamental equality of everyone. It has done that. As it has moved global, moved us toward a global level of social organization, it has driven us toward moral truth. I think that's wonderful.Now, back to the unfolding apocalypse. And you may wonder, OK, that's all fine, sounds great — moral direction in history — but what about this so-called clash of civilizations? Well, first of all, I would emphasize that it fits into the non-zero-sum framework, OK. If you look at the relationship between the so-called Muslim world and Western world — two terms I don't like, but can't really avoid; in such a short span of time, they're efficient if nothing else — it is non-zero-sum. And by that I mean, if people in the Muslim world get more hateful, more resentful, less happy with their place in the world, it'll be bad for the West. If they get more happy, it'll be good for the West. So that is a non-zero-sum dynamic.And I would say the non-zero-sum dynamic is only going to grow more intense over time because of technological trends, but more intense in a kind of negative way. It's the downside correlation of their fortunes that will become more and more possible. And one reason is because of something I call the "growing lethality of hatred." More and more, it's possible for grassroots hatred abroad to manifest itself in the form of organized violence on American soil. And that's pretty new, and I think it's probably going to get a lot worse — this capacity — because of trends in information technology, in technologies that can be used for purposes of munitions like biotechnology and nanotechnology. We may be hearing more about that today.And there's something I worry about especially, which is that this dynamic will lead to a kind of a feedback cycle that puts us on a slippery slope. What I have in mind is: terrorism happens here; we overreact to it. That, you know, we're not sufficiently surgical in our retaliation leads to more hatred abroad, more terrorism. We overreact because being human, we feel like retaliating, and it gets worse and worse and worse. You could call this the positive feedback of negative vibes, but I think in something so spooky, we really shouldn't have the word positive there at all, even in a technical sense. So let's call it the death spiral of negativity. (Laughter) I assure you if it happens, at the end, both the West and the Muslim world will have suffered.So, what do we do? Well, first of all, we can do a lot more with arms control, the international regulation of dangerous technologies. I have a whole global governance sermon that I will spare you right now, because I don't think that's going to be enough anyway, although it's essential. I think we're going to have to have a major round of moral progress in the world. I think you're just going to have to see less hatred among groups, less bigotry, and, you know, racial groups, religious groups, whatever. I've got to admit I feel silly saying that. It sounds so kind of Pollyannaish. I feel like Rodney King, you know, saying, why can't we all just get along? But hey, I don't really see any alternative, given the way I read the situation. There's going to have to be moral progress. There's going to have to be a lessening of the amount of hatred in the world, given how dangerous it's becoming. In my defense, I'd say, as naive as this may sound, it's ultimately grounded in cynicism.That is to say — (Laughter) — thank you, thank you. That is to say, remember: my whole view of morality is that it boils down to self-interest. It's when people's fortunes are correlated. It's when your welfare conduces to mine, that I decide, oh yeah, I'm all in favor of your welfare. That's what's responsible for this growth of this moral progress so far, and I'm saying we once again have a correlation of fortunes, and if people respond to it intelligently, we will see the development of tolerance and so on — the norms that we need, you know. We will see the further evolution of this kind of business-class morality.So, these two things, you know, if they get people's attention and drive home the positive correlation and people do what's in their self-interests, which is further the moral evolution, then they could actually have a constructive effect. And that's why I lump growing lethality of hatred and death spiral of negativity under the general rubric, reasons to be cheerful. (Laughter) Doing the best I can, OK. (Laughter) I never called myself Mr. Uplift. I'm just doing what I can here. (Laughter)Now, launching a moral revolution has got to be hard, right? I mean, what do you do? And I think the answer is a lot of different people are going to have to do a lot of different things. We all start where we are. Speaking as an American who has children whose security 10, 20, 30 years down the road I worry about — what I personally want to start out doing is figuring out why so many people around the world hate us, OK. I think that's a worthy research project myself. I also like it because it's an intrinsically kind of morally redeeming exercise. Because to understand why somebody in a very different culture does something — somebody you're kind of viewing as alien, who's doing things you consider strange in a culture you consider strange — to really understand why they do the things they do is a morally redeeming accomplishment, because you've got to relate their experience to yours. To really understand it, you've got to say, "Oh, I get it. So when they feel resentful, it's kind of like the way I feel resentful when this happens, and for somewhat the same reasons." That's true understanding. And I think that is an expansion of your moral compass when you manage to do that.It's especially hard to do when people hate you, OK, because you don't really, in a sense, want to completely understand why people hate you. I mean, you want to hear the reason, but you don't want to be able to relate to it. You don't want it to make sense, right? (Laughter) You don't want to say, "Well, yeah, I can kind of understand how a human being in those circumstances would hate the country I live in." That's not a pleasant thing, but I think it's something that we're going to have to get used to andwork on. Now, I want to stress that to understand, you know — there are people who don't like this whole business of understanding the grassroots, the root causes of things; they don't want to know why people hate us. I want to understand it. The reason you're trying to understand why they hate us, is to get them to quit hating us. The idea when you go through this moral exercise of really coming to appreciate their humanity and better understand them, is part of an effort to get them to appreciate your humanity in the long run. I think it's the first step toward that. That's the long-term goal.There are people who worry about this, and in fact, I, myself, apparently, was denounced on national TV a couple of nights ago because of an op-ed I'd written. It was kind of along these lines, and the allegation was that I have, quote, "affection for terrorists." Now, the good news is that the person who said it was Ann Coulter. (Laughter) (Applause) I mean, if you've got to have an enemy, do make it Ann Coulter. (Laughter) But it's not a crazy concern, OK, because understanding behavior can lead to a kind of empathy, and it can make it a little harder to deliver tough love, and so on. But I think we're a lot closer to erring on the side of not comprehending the situation clearly enough, than in comprehending it so clearly that we just can't, you know, get the army out to kill terrorists.So I'm not really worried about it. So — (Laughter) — I mean, we're going to have to work on a lot of fronts, but if we succeed — if we succeed — then once again, non-zero-sumness and the recognition of non-zero-sum dynamics will have forced us to a higher moral level. And a kind of saving higher moral level, something that kind of literally saves the world. If you look at the word "salvation" in the Bible — the Christian usage that we're familiar with — saving souls, that people go to heaven — that's actually a latecomer. The original meaning of the word "salvation" in the Bible is about saving the social system. "Yahweh is our Savior" means "He has saved the nation of Israel," which at the time, was a pretty high-level social organization.Now, social organization has reached the global level, and I guess, if there's good news I can say I'm bringing you, it's just that all the salvation of the world requires is the intelligent pursuit of self-interests in a disciplined and careful way. It's going to be hard. I say we give it a shot anyway because we've just come too far to screw it up now. Thanks. (Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:12.958 --> 00:00:14.958
I've got apparently 18 minutes

00:00:14.958 --> 00:00:17.958
to convince you that history has a direction, an arrow;

00:00:17.958 --> 00:00:20.958
that in some fundamental sense, it's good;

00:00:20.958 --> 00:00:23.958
that the arrow points to something positive.

00:00:23.958 --> 00:00:27.958
Now, when the TED people first approached me about giving this upbeat talk --

00:00:27.958 --> 00:00:28.958
(Laughter)

00:00:28.958 --> 00:00:34.958
-- that was before the cartoon of Muhammad had triggered global rioting.

00:00:34.958 --> 00:00:36.958
It was before the avian flu had reached Europe.

00:00:36.958 --> 00:00:38.958
It was before Hamas had won the Palestinian election,

00:00:38.958 --> 00:00:42.958
eliciting various counter-measures by Israel.

00:00:42.958 --> 00:00:46.958
And to be honest, if I had known when I was asked to give this upbeat talk

00:00:46.958 --> 00:00:49.958
that even as I was giving the upbeat talk,

00:00:49.958 --> 00:00:52.958
the apocalypse would be unfolding --

00:00:52.958 --> 00:00:53.958
(Laughter)

00:00:53.958 --> 00:00:57.958
-- I might have said, "Is it okay if I talk about something else?"

00:00:57.958 --> 00:01:02.958
But I didn't, OK. So we're here. I'll do what I can. I'll do what I can.

00:01:03.958 --> 00:01:05.958
I've got to warn you:

00:01:05.958 --> 00:01:12.958
the sense in which my worldview is upbeat has always been kind of subtle,

00:01:12.958 --> 00:01:14.958
sometimes even elusive.

00:01:14.958 --> 00:01:15.958
(Laughter)

00:01:15.958 --> 00:01:18.958
The sense in which I can be uplifting and inspiring --

00:01:18.958 --> 00:01:21.958
I mean, there's always been a kind of a certain grim dimension

00:01:21.958 --> 00:01:25.958
to the way I try to uplift, so if grim inspiration --

00:01:25.958 --> 00:01:26.958
(Laughter)

00:01:26.958 --> 00:01:30.958
-- if grim inspiration is not a contradiction in terms, that is, I'm afraid,

00:01:30.958 --> 00:01:34.958
the most you can hope for. OK, today -- that's if I succeed.

00:01:34.958 --> 00:01:36.958
I'll see what I can do. OK?

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:38.958
Now, in one sense,

00:01:38.958 --> 00:01:41.958
the claim that history has a direction is not that controversial.

00:01:41.958 --> 00:01:44.958
If you're just talking about social structure,

00:01:44.958 --> 00:01:46.958
OK, clearly that's gotten more complex

00:01:46.958 --> 00:01:49.958
a little over the last 10,000 years -- has reached higher and higher levels.

00:01:49.958 --> 00:01:51.958
And in fact, that's actually sustaining

00:01:51.958 --> 00:01:55.958
a long-standing trend that predates human beings, OK,

00:01:55.958 --> 00:01:58.958
that biological evolution was doing for us.

00:01:58.958 --> 00:02:03.958
Because what happened in the beginning, this stuff encases itself in a cell,

00:02:03.958 --> 00:02:06.958
then cells start hanging out together in societies.

00:02:06.958 --> 00:02:09.958
Eventually they get so close, they form multicellular organisms,

00:02:09.958 --> 00:02:14.958
then you get complex multicellular organisms; they form societies.

00:02:14.958 --> 00:02:17.958
But then at some point, one of these multicellular organisms

00:02:17.958 --> 00:02:20.958
does something completely amazing with this stuff, which is

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:25.958
it launches a whole second kind of evolution: cultural evolution.

00:02:25.958 --> 00:02:28.958
And amazingly, that evolution sustains the trajectory

00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:33.958
that biological evolution had established toward greater complexity.

00:02:33.958 --> 00:02:36.958
By cultural evolution we mean the evolution of ideas.

00:02:36.958 --> 00:02:39.958
A lot of you have heard the term "memes." The evolution of technology,

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:41.958
I pay a lot of attention to, so, you know,

00:02:41.958 --> 00:02:45.958
one of the first things you got was a little hand axe.

00:02:45.958 --> 00:02:50.958
Generations go by, somebody says, hey, why don't we put it on a stick?

00:02:50.958 --> 00:02:53.958
(Laughter)

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:56.958
Just absolutely delights the little ones.

00:02:56.958 --> 00:02:58.958
Next best thing to a video game.

00:02:58.958 --> 00:03:00.958
This may not seem to impress,

00:03:00.958 --> 00:03:04.958
but technological evolution is progressive, so another 10, 20,000 years,

00:03:04.958 --> 00:03:06.958
and armaments technology takes you here.

00:03:06.958 --> 00:03:07.958
(Laughter)

00:03:07.958 --> 00:03:11.958
Impressive. And the rate of technological evolution speeds up,

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:15.958
so a mere quarter of a century after this, you get this, OK.

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:17.958
(Laughter)

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:19.958
And this.

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:20.958
(Laughter)

00:03:20.958 --> 00:03:23.958
I'm sorry -- it was a cheap laugh, but I wanted to find a way

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:26.958
to transition back to this idea of the unfolding apocalypse,

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:28.958
and I thought that might do it.

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:35.958
(Applause)

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:40.958
So, what threatens to happen with this unfolding apocalypse

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:44.958
is the collapse of global social organization.

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:47.958
Now, first let me remind you how much work it took to get us where we are,

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:50.958
to be on the brink of true global social organization.

00:03:50.958 --> 00:03:56.958
Originally, you had the most complex societies, the hunter-gatherer village.

00:03:56.958 --> 00:03:58.958
Stonehenge is the remnant of a chiefdom,

00:03:58.958 --> 00:04:01.958
which is what you get with the invention of agriculture: multi-village polity

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:04.958
with centralized rule.

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:09.958
With the invention of writing, you start getting cities. This is blurry. I kind of like that

00:04:09.958 --> 00:04:12.958
because it makes it look like a one-celled organism and reminds you

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:16.958
how many levels organic organization has already moved through

00:04:16.958 --> 00:04:22.958
to get to this point. And then you get to, you know, you get empires.

00:04:22.958 --> 00:04:26.958
I want to stress, you know, social organization can transcend political bounds.

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:30.958
This is the Silk Road connecting the Chinese Empire and the Roman Empire.

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:33.958
So you had social complexity spanning the whole continent,

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:38.958
even if no polity did similarly. Today, you've got nation states.

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:41.958
Point is: there's obviously collaboration and organization going on

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:43.958
beyond national bounds.

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:46.958
This is actually just a picture of the earth at night,

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:48.958
and I'm just putting it up because I think it's pretty.

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:53.958
Does kind of convey the sense that this is an integrated system.

00:04:53.958 --> 00:04:59.958
Now, I explained this growth of complexity by reference to something

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:03.958
called "non-zero sumness."

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:08.958
Assuming that a few of you did not do the assigned reading, very quickly,

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:13.958
the key idea is the distinction between zero-sum games, in which correlations

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:16.958
are inverse: always a winner and a loser.

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:20.958
Non-zero-sum games in which correlations can be positive, OK.

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:24.958
So like in tennis, usually it's win-lose;

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:27.958
it always adds up to zero-zero-sum. But if you're playing doubles,

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:29.958
the person on your side of the net, they're in the same boat as you,

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:31.958
so you're playing a non-zero-sum game with them.

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:34.958
It's either for the better or for the worse, OK.

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:39.958
A lot of forms of non-zero-sum behavior in the realm of economics and so on

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:43.958
in everyday life often leads to cooperation.

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:45.958
The argument I make is basically that, well,

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:47.958
non-zero-sum games have always been part of life.

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:49.958
You have them in hunter-gatherer societies,

00:05:49.958 --> 00:05:54.958
but then through technological evolution, new forms of technology arise

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:59.958
that facilitate or encourage the playing of non-zero-sum games,

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:02.958
involving more people over larger territory.

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:06.958
Social structure adapts to accommodate this possibility and

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:09.958
to harness this productive potential, so you get cities, you know,

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:12.958
and you get all the non-zero-sum games you don't think about

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:13.958
that are being played across the world.

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:16.958
Like, have you ever thought when you buy a car,

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:18.958
how many people on how many different continents contributed

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:23.958
to the manufacture of that car? Those are people in effect

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:25.958
you're playing a non-zero-sum game with.

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:32.958
I mean, there are certainly plenty of them around.

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:35.958
Now, this sounds like an intrinsically upbeat worldview in a way,

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:38.958
because when you think of non-zero, you think win-win, you know,

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:40.958
that's good. Well, there are a few reasons

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:43.958
that actually it's not intrinsically upbeat.

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:47.958
First of all, it can accommodate; it doesn't deny the existence

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:50.958
of inequality exploitation war.

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:52.958
But there's a more fundamental reason

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:55.958
that it's not intrinsically upbeat, because a non-zero-sum game,

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:59.958
all it tells you for sure is that the fortunes will be correlated for better or worse.

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:05.958
It doesn't necessarily predict a win-win outcome.

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:07.958
So, in a way, the question is: on what grounds

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:11.958
am I upbeat at all about history? And the answer is,

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:15.958
first of all, on balance I would say people have played their games

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:19.958
to more win-win outcomes than lose-lose outcomes. On balance,

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:25.958
I think history is a net positive in the non-zero-sum game department.

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:30.958
And a testament to this is the thing that most amazes me,

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:32.958
most impresses me, and most uplifts me,

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:37.958
which is that there is a moral dimension to history;

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:40.958
there is a moral arrow. We have seen moral progress over time.

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:44.958
2,500 years ago, members of one Greek city-state

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:47.958
considered members of another Greek city-state subhuman

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:52.958
and treated them that way. And then this moral revolution arrived,

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:56.958
and they decided that actually, no, Greeks are human beings.

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:59.958
It's just the Persians who aren't fully human

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:01.958
and don't deserve to be treated very nicely.

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:04.958
But this was progress -- you know, give them credit. And now today,

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:07.958
we've seen more progress. I think -- I hope -- most people here would say

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:10.958
that all people everywhere are human beings,

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:13.958
deserve to be treated decently,

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:17.958
unless they do something horrendous, regardless of race or religion.

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:21.958
And you have to read your ancient history to realize what a revolution that has been,

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:23.958
OK. This was not a prevalent view,

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:28.958
few thousand years ago, and I attribute it to this non-zero-sum dynamic.

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:32.958
I think that's the reason there is as much tolerance toward nationalities,

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:37.958
ethnicities, religions as there is today. If you asked me,

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:39.958
you know, why am I not in favor of bombing Japan,

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:42.958
well, I'm only half-joking when I say they built my car.

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:44.958
We have this non-zero-sum relationship,

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:50.958
and I think that does lead to a kind of a tolerance to the extent that you realize

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:54.958
that someone else's welfare is positively correlated with yours --

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:56.958
you're more likely to cut them a break.

00:08:56.958 --> 00:09:01.958
I kind of think this is a kind of a business-class morality.

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:05.958
Unfortunately, I don't fly trans-Atlantic business class often enough

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:08.958
to know, or any other kind of business class really,

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:12.958
but I assume that in business class, you don't hear many expressions of, you know,

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:15.958
bigotry about racial groups or ethnic groups,

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:18.958
because the people who are flying trans-Atlantic business class

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:20.958
are doing business with all these people; they're making money

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:24.958
off all these people. And I really do think that, in that sense at least,

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:27.958
capitalism has been a constructive force,

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:29.958
and more fundamentally, it's a non-zero-sumness

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:33.958
that has been a constructive force in expanding people's realm

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:38.958
of moral awareness. I think the non-zero-sum dynamic,

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:42.958
which is not only economic by any means -- it's not always commerce --

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:47.958
but it has driven us to the verge of a moral truth,

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:50.958
which is the fundamental equality of everyone. It has done that.

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:55.958
As it has moved global, moved us toward a global level of social organization,

00:09:55.958 --> 00:09:57.958
it has driven us toward moral truth.

00:09:57.958 --> 00:10:00.958
I think that's wonderful.

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:03.958
Now, back to the unfolding apocalypse.

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:05.958
And you may wonder, OK, that's all fine,

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:07.958
sounds great -- moral direction in history --

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:16.958
but what about this so-called clash of civilizations? Well, first of all,

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:19.958
I would emphasize that it fits into the non-zero-sum framework,

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:21.958
OK. If you look at the relationship

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:24.958
between the so-called Muslim world and Western world --

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:27.958
two terms I don't like, but can't really avoid;

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:31.958
in such a short span of time, they're efficient if nothing else --

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:34.958
it is non-zero-sum. And by that I mean,

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:38.958
if people in the Muslim world get more hateful, more resentful,

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:39.958
less happy with their place in the world,

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:43.958
it'll be bad for the West. If they get more happy, it'll be good for the West.

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:48.958
So that is a non-zero-sum dynamic.

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:52.958
And I would say the non-zero-sum dynamic is only going to grow more intense over time

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:57.958
because of technological trends, but more intense in a kind of negative way.

00:10:57.958 --> 00:11:03.958
It's the downside correlation of their fortunes that will become more and more possible.

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:08.958
And one reason is because of something I call the "growing lethality of hatred."

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:12.958
More and more, it's possible for grassroots hatred abroad

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:17.958
to manifest itself in the form of organized violence on American soil.

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:20.958
And that's pretty new, and I think it's probably going to get a lot worse

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:23.958
-- this capacity -- because of

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:27.958
trends in information technology, in technologies that can be used

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:33.958
for purposes of munitions like biotechnology and nanotechnology.

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:35.958
We may be hearing more about that today.

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:38.958
And there's something I worry about especially, which is that

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:44.958
this dynamic will lead to a kind of a feedback cycle that puts us on a slippery slope.

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:47.958
What I have in mind is: terrorism happens here; we overreact to it.

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:51.958
That, you know, we're not sufficiently surgical in our retaliation

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:53.958
leads to more hatred abroad, more terrorism.

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:57.958
We overreact because being human, we feel like retaliating,

00:11:57.958 --> 00:11:59.958
and it gets worse and worse and worse.

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:03.958
You could call this the positive feedback of negative vibes,

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:05.958
but I think in something so spooky,

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:08.958
we really shouldn't have the word positive there at all, even in a technical sense.

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:11.958
So let's call it the death spiral of negativity.

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:13.958
(Laughter)

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:15.958
I assure you if it happens, at the end, both the West

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:18.958
and the Muslim world will have suffered.

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:24.958
So, what do we do? Well, first of all, we can do a lot more with arms control,

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:26.958
the international regulation of dangerous technologies.

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:28.958
I have a whole global governance sermon

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:30.958
that I will spare you right now,

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:33.958
because I don't think that's going to be enough anyway, although it's essential.

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:35.958
I think we're going to have to have a major round

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:37.958
of moral progress in the world.

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:42.958
I think you're just going to have to see less hatred among groups,

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:48.958
less bigotry, and, you know, racial groups, religious groups, whatever.

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:50.958
I've got to admit I feel silly saying that.

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:53.958
It sounds so kind of Pollyannaish. I feel like Rodney King, you know,

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:55.958
saying, why can't we all just get along?

00:12:55.958 --> 00:13:01.958
But hey, I don't really see any alternative, given the way I read the situation.

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:04.958
There's going to have to be moral progress.

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:08.958
There's going to have to be a lessening of the amount of hatred in the world,

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:12.958
given how dangerous it's becoming.

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:15.958
In my defense, I'd say, as naive as this may sound,

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:18.958
it's ultimately grounded in cynicism.

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:19.958
That is to say --

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:20.958
(Laughter)

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:25.958
-- thank you, thank you. That is to say, remember: my whole view

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:28.958
of morality is that it boils down to self-interest.

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:30.958
It's when people's fortunes are correlated.

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:33.958
It's when your welfare conduces to mine, that I decide, oh yeah,

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:37.958
I'm all in favor of your welfare. That's what's responsible

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:40.958
for this growth of this moral progress so far,

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:43.958
and I'm saying we once again have a correlation of fortunes,

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:47.958
and if people respond to it intelligently, we will see

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:50.958
the development of tolerance and so on --

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:53.958
the norms that we need, you know.

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:57.958
We will see the further evolution of this kind of business-class morality.

00:13:57.958 --> 00:14:03.958
So, these two things, you know, if they get people's attention

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:06.958
and drive home the positive correlation and people do what's in their self-interests,

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:10.958
which is further the moral evolution,

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:13.958
then they could actually have a constructive effect.

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:16.958
And that's why I lump growing lethality of hatred

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:19.958
and death spiral of negativity under the general rubric,

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:21.958
reasons to be cheerful.

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:23.958
(Laughter)

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:25.958
Doing the best I can, OK.

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:26.958
(Laughter)

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:28.958
I never called myself Mr. Uplift.

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:31.958
I'm just doing what I can here.

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:32.958
(Laughter)

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:35.958
Now, launching a moral revolution has got to be hard, right?

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:37.958
I mean, what do you do?

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:39.958
And I think the answer is a lot of different people

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:42.958
are going to have to do a lot of different things.

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:47.958
We all start where we are. Speaking as an American

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:51.958
who has children whose security 10, 20, 30 years down the road

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:54.958
I worry about -- what I personally want to start out doing

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:58.958
is figuring out why so many people around the world hate us, OK.

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:02.958
I think that's a worthy research project myself.

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:07.958
I also like it because it's an intrinsically kind of morally redeeming exercise.

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:09.958
Because to understand why somebody

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:11.958
in a very different culture does something --

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:13.958
somebody you're kind of viewing as alien,

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:15.958
who's doing things you consider strange

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:19.958
in a culture you consider strange -- to really understand why they do

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:23.958
the things they do is a morally redeeming accomplishment,

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:25.958
because you've got to relate their experience to yours.

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:29.958
To really understand it, you've got to say, "Oh, I get it.

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:31.958
So when they feel resentful, it's kind of like

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:33.958
the way I feel resentful when this happens,

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:37.958
and for somewhat the same reasons." That's true understanding.

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:43.958
And I think that is an expansion of your moral compass when you manage to do that.

00:15:43.958 --> 00:15:46.958
It's especially hard to do when people hate you, OK,

00:15:46.958 --> 00:15:49.958
because you don't really, in a sense, want

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:51.958
to completely understand why people hate you.

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:53.958
I mean, you want to hear the reason, but you don't want to be able to relate to it.

00:15:53.958 --> 00:15:55.958
You don't want it to make sense, right? (Laughter)

00:15:55.958 --> 00:15:57.958
You don't want to say, "Well, yeah, I can kind of understand

00:15:57.958 --> 00:15:59.958
how a human being in those circumstances

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:02.958
would hate the country I live in." That's not a pleasant thing,

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:08.958
but I think it's something that we're going to have to get used to and

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:19.958
work on. Now, I want to stress that to understand, you know --

00:16:19.958 --> 00:16:22.958
there are people who don't like this whole business of understanding

00:16:22.958 --> 00:16:26.958
the grassroots, the root causes of things; they don't want to know

00:16:26.958 --> 00:16:29.958
why people hate us. I want to understand it.

00:16:29.958 --> 00:16:31.958
The reason you're trying to understand why they hate us,

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:34.958
is to get them to quit hating us. The idea

00:16:34.958 --> 00:16:38.958
when you go through this moral exercise of really coming to appreciate

00:16:38.958 --> 00:16:43.958
their humanity and better understand them, is part of an effort

00:16:43.958 --> 00:16:45.958
to get them to appreciate your humanity in the long run.

00:16:45.958 --> 00:16:49.958
I think it's the first step toward that. That's the long-term goal.

00:16:49.958 --> 00:16:54.958
There are people who worry about this, and in fact,

00:16:54.958 --> 00:16:59.958
I, myself, apparently, was denounced on national TV

00:16:59.958 --> 00:17:03.958
a couple of nights ago because of an op-ed I'd written.

00:17:03.958 --> 00:17:05.958
It was kind of along these lines, and the allegation was

00:17:05.958 --> 00:17:09.958
that I have, quote, "affection for terrorists."

00:17:09.958 --> 00:17:12.958
Now, the good news is that the person who said it was Ann Coulter.

00:17:12.958 --> 00:17:14.958
(Laughter)

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:16.958
(Applause)

00:17:16.958 --> 00:17:18.958
I mean, if you've got to have an enemy, do make it Ann Coulter.

00:17:18.958 --> 00:17:19.958
(Laughter)

00:17:19.958 --> 00:17:23.958
But it's not a crazy concern, OK, because understanding behavior

00:17:23.958 --> 00:17:25.958
can lead to a kind of empathy,

00:17:25.958 --> 00:17:28.958
and it can make it a little harder to deliver tough love, and so on.

00:17:28.958 --> 00:17:35.958
But I think we're a lot closer to erring on the side of not comprehending

00:17:35.958 --> 00:17:39.958
the situation clearly enough, than in comprehending it so clearly

00:17:39.958 --> 00:17:42.958
that we just can't, you know, get the army out to kill terrorists.

00:17:42.958 --> 00:17:45.958
So I'm not really worried about it. So --

00:17:45.958 --> 00:17:47.958
(Laughter)

00:17:47.958 --> 00:17:52.958
-- I mean, we're going to have to work on a lot of fronts,

00:17:52.958 --> 00:17:59.958
but if we succeed -- if we succeed -- then once again,

00:17:59.958 --> 00:18:03.958
non-zero-sumness and the recognition of non-zero-sum dynamics

00:18:03.958 --> 00:18:07.958
will have forced us to a higher moral level.

00:18:07.958 --> 00:18:12.958
And a kind of saving higher moral level,

00:18:12.958 --> 00:18:14.958
something that kind of literally saves the world.

00:18:14.958 --> 00:18:17.958
If you look at the word "salvation" in the Bible --

00:18:17.958 --> 00:18:20.958
the Christian usage that we're familiar with --

00:18:20.958 --> 00:18:23.958
saving souls, that people go to heaven -- that's actually a latecomer.

00:18:23.958 --> 00:18:29.958
The original meaning of the word "salvation" in the Bible is about saving the social system.

00:18:29.958 --> 00:18:32.958
"Yahweh is our Savior" means "He has saved the nation of Israel,"

00:18:32.958 --> 00:18:35.958
which at the time, was a pretty high-level social organization.

00:18:35.958 --> 00:18:39.958
Now, social organization has reached the global level, and I guess,

00:18:39.958 --> 00:18:43.958
if there's good news I can say I'm bringing you, it's just that

00:18:43.958 --> 00:18:49.958
all the salvation of the world requires is the intelligent pursuit

00:18:49.958 --> 00:18:55.958
of self-interests in a disciplined and careful way.

00:18:55.958 --> 00:18:58.958
It's going to be hard. I say we give it a shot anyway

00:18:58.958 --> 00:19:01.958
because we've just come too far to screw it up now.

00:19:01.958 --> 00:19:03.958
Thanks.

00:19:03.958 --> 00:19:05.958
(Applause)

title: How the "ghost map" helped end a killer disease
transcript: If you haven't ordered yet, I generally find the rigatoni with the spicy tomato sauce goes best with diseases of the small intestine.(Laughter)So, sorry — it just feels like I should be doing stand-up up here because of the setting. No, what I want to do is take you back to 1854 in London for the next few minutes, and tell the story — in brief — of this outbreak, which in many ways, I think, helped create the world that we live in today, and particularly the kind of city that we live in today. This period in 1854, in the middle part of the 19th century, in London's history, is incredibly interesting for a number of reasons. But I think the most important one is that London was this city of 2.5 million people, and it was the largest city on the face of the planet at that point. But it was also the largest city that had ever been built.And so the Victorians were trying to live through and simultaneously invent a whole new scale of living: this scale of living that we, you know, now call "metropolitan living." And it was in many ways, at this point in the mid-1850s, a complete disaster. They were basically a city living with a modern kind of industrial metropolis with an Elizabethan public infrastructure. So people, for instance, just to gross you out for a second, had cesspools of human waste in their basement. Like, a foot to two feet deep. And they would just kind of throw the buckets down there and hope that it would somehow go away, and of course it never really would go away. And all of this stuff, basically, had accumulated to the point where the city was incredibly offensive to just walk around in.It was an amazingly smelly city. Not just because of the cesspools, but also the sheer number of livestock in the city would shock people. Not just the horses, but people had cows in their attics that they would use for milk, that they would hoist up there and keep them in the attic until literally their milk ran out and they died, and then they would drag them off to the bone boilers down the street. So, you would just walk around London at this point and just be overwhelmed with this stench. And what ended up happening is that an entire emerging public health system became convinced that it was the smell that was killing everybody, that was creating these diseases that would wipe through the city every three or four years. And cholera was really the great killer of this period.It arrived in London in 1832, and every four or five years another epidemic would take 10,000, 20,000 people in London and throughout the U.K. And so the authorities became convinced that this smell was this problem. We had to get rid of the smell. And so, in fact, they concocted a couple of early, you know, founding public-health interventions in the system of the city, one of which was called the "Nuisances Act," which they got everybody as far as they could to empty out their cesspools and just pour all that waste into the river. Because if we get it out of the streets, it'll smell much better, and — oh right, we drink from the river. So what ended up happening, actually, is they ended up increasing the outbreaks of cholera because, as we now know, cholera is actually in the water. It's a waterborne disease, not something that's in the air. It's not something you smell or inhale; it's something you ingest.And so one of the founding moments of public health in the 19th century effectively poisoned the water supply of London much more effectively than any modern day bioterrorist could have ever dreamed of doing. So this was the state of London in 1854, and in the middle of all this carnage and offensive conditions, and in the midst of all this scientific confusion about what was actually killing people, it was a very talented classic 19th century multi-disciplinarian named John Snow, who was a local doctor in Soho in London, who had been arguing for about four or five years that cholera was, in fact, a waterborne disease, and had basically convinced nobody of this. The public health authorities had largely ignored what he had to say. And he'd made the case in a number of papers and done a number of studies, but nothing had really stuck. And part of — what's so interesting about this story to me is that in some ways, it's a great case study in how cultural change happens, how a good idea eventually comes to win out over much worse ideas. And Snow labored for a long time with this great insight that everybody ignored.And then on one day, August 28th of 1854, a young child, a five-month-old girl whose first name we don't know, we know her only as Baby Lewis, somehow contracted cholera, came down with cholera at 40 Broad Street. You can't really see it in this map, but this is the map that becomes the central focus in the second half of my book. It's in the middle of Soho, in this working class neighborhood, this little girl becomes sick and it turns out that the cesspool, that they still continue to have, despite the Nuisances Act, bordered on an extremely popular water pump, local watering hole that was well known for the best water in all of Soho, that all the residents from Soho and the surrounding neighborhoods would go to.And so this little girl inadvertently ended up contaminating the water in this popular pump, and one of the most terrifying outbreaks in the history of England erupted about two or three days later. Literally, 10 percent of the neighborhood died in seven days, and much more would have died if people hadn't fled after the initial outbreak kicked in. So it was this incredibly terrifying event. You had these scenes of entire families dying over the course of 48 hours of cholera, alone in their one-room apartments, in their little flats. Just an extraordinary, terrifying scene. Snow lived near there, heard about the outbreak, and in this amazing act of courage went directly into the belly of the beast because he thought an outbreak that concentrated could actually potentially end up convincing people that, in fact, the real menace of cholera was in the water supply and not in the air. He suspected an outbreak that concentrated would probably involve a single point source. One single thing that everybody was going to because it didn't have the traditional slower path of infections that you might expect.And so he went right in there and started interviewing people. He eventually enlisted the help of this amazing other figure, who's kind of the other protagonist of the book — this guy, Henry Whitehead, who was a local minister, who was not at all a man of science, but was incredibly socially connected; he knew everybody in the neighborhood. And he managed to track down, Whitehead did, many of the cases of people who had drunk water from the pump, or who hadn't drunk water from the pump. And eventually Snow made a map of the outbreak. He found increasingly that people who drank from the pump were getting sick. People who hadn't drunk from the pump were not getting sick. And he thought about representing that as a kind of a table of statistics of people living in different neighborhoods, people who hadn't, you know, percentages of people who hadn't, but eventually he hit upon the idea that what he needed was something that you could see. Something that would take in a sense a higher-level view of all this activity that had been happening in the neighborhood.And so he created this map, which basically ended up representing all the deaths in the neighborhoods as black bars at each address. And you can see in this map, the pump right at the center of it and you can see that one of the residences down the way had about 15 people dead. And the map is actually a little bit bigger. As you get further and further away from the pump, the deaths begin to grow less and less frequent. And so you can see this something poisonous emanating out of this pump that you could see in a glance. And so, with the help of this map, and with the help of more evangelizing that he did over the next few years and that Whitehead did, eventually, actually, the authorities slowly started to come around. It took much longer than sometimes we like to think in this story, but by 1866, when the next big cholera outbreak came to London, the authorities had been convinced — in part because of this story, in part because of this map — that in fact the water was the problem.And they had already started building the sewers in London, and they immediately went to this outbreak and they told everybody to start boiling their water. And that was the last time that London has seen a cholera outbreak since. So, part of this story, I think — well, it's a terrifying story, it's a very dark story and it's a story that continues on in many of the developing cities of the world. It's also a story really that is fundamentally optimistic, which is to say that it's possible to solve these problems if we listen to reason, if we listen to the kind of wisdom of these kinds of maps, if we listen to people like Snow and Whitehead, if we listen to the locals who understand what's going on in these kinds of situations. And what it ended up doing is making the idea of large-scale metropolitan living a sustainable one.When people were looking at 10 percent of their neighborhoods dying in the space of seven days, there was a widespread consensus that this couldn't go on, that people weren't meant to live in cities of 2.5 million people. But because of what Snow did, because of this map, because of the whole series of reforms that happened in the wake of this map, we now take for granted that cities have 10 million people, cities like this one are in fact sustainable things. We don't worry that New York City is going to collapse in on itself quite the way that, you know, Rome did, and be 10 percent of its size in 100 years or 200 years. And so that in a way is the ultimate legacy of this map. It's a map of deaths that ended up creating a whole new way of life, the life that we're enjoying here today. Thank you very much.
