00:01:31.958 --> 00:01:34.958
used by the people in Watergate, moral slippage --

00:01:34.958 --> 00:01:36.958
it's a gradual kind of thing, combination of things.

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:39.958
You see, we also have the technology.

00:01:39.958 --> 00:01:42.958
I say, less and less the human touch.

00:01:42.958 --> 00:01:45.958
"Oh, let me kind of tell you a funny little play bit.

00:01:45.958 --> 00:01:47.958
The Atlanta airport is a modern airport,

00:01:47.958 --> 00:01:48.958
and they should leave the gate there.

00:01:48.958 --> 00:01:53.958
These trains that take you out to a concourse and on to a destination.

00:01:53.958 --> 00:01:55.958
And these trains are smooth,

00:01:55.958 --> 00:01:58.958
and they're quiet and they're efficient.

00:01:58.958 --> 00:02:02.958
And there's a voice on the train, you know the voice was a human voice.

00:02:02.958 --> 00:02:07.958
You see in the old days we had robots, robots imitated humans.

00:02:07.958 --> 00:02:12.958
Now we have humans imitating robots.

00:02:12.958 --> 00:02:18.958
So we got this voice on this train: Concourse One: Omaha, Lincoln.

00:02:18.958 --> 00:02:21.958
Concourse Two: Dallas, Fort Worth. Same voice.

00:02:21.958 --> 00:02:26.958
Just as a train is about to go, a young couple rush in

00:02:26.958 --> 00:02:29.958
and they're just about to close the pneumatic doors.

00:02:29.958 --> 00:02:32.958
And that voice, without losing a beat, says,

00:02:32.958 --> 00:02:35.958
'Because of late entry, we're delayed 30 seconds.'

00:02:35.958 --> 00:02:40.958
Just then, everybody's looking at this couple with hateful eyes

00:02:40.958 --> 00:02:42.958
and the couple's going like this, you know, shrinking.

00:02:42.958 --> 00:02:45.958
Well, I'd happened to have had a couple of drinks before boarding --

00:02:45.958 --> 00:02:48.958
I do that to steel my nerves -- and so

00:02:48.958 --> 00:02:51.958
I imitate a train call, holding my hand on my --

00:02:51.958 --> 00:02:55.958
'George Orwell, your time has come,' you see.

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:57.958
Well, some of you are laughing. Everybody laughs

00:02:57.958 --> 00:03:01.958
when I say that, but not on this train. Silence.

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:02.958
And so suddenly they're looking at me.

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:05.958
So here I am with the couple, the three of us

00:03:05.958 --> 00:03:09.958
shrinking at the foot of Calvary about to be up, you know.

00:03:09.958 --> 00:03:16.958
"Just then I see a baby, a little baby in the lap of a mother.

00:03:16.958 --> 00:03:21.958
I know it's Hispanic because she's speaking Spanish to her companion.

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:24.958
So I'm going to talk to the baby. So I say to the baby,

00:03:24.958 --> 00:03:28.958
holding my hand over my mouth because my breath must be 100 proof,

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:32.958
I say to the baby, 'Sir or Madam,

00:03:32.958 --> 00:03:37.958
what is your considered opinion of the human species?'

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:39.958
And the baby looks, you know, the way babies look at you clearly,

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:40.958
starts laughing,

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:43.958
starts busting out with this crazy little laugh.

00:03:43.958 --> 00:03:47.958
I say, 'Thank God for a human reaction, we haven't lost yet.'

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:49.958
"But you see, the human touch, you see, it's disappearing.

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:52.958
You know, you see, you've got to question the official truth.

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:55.958
You know the thing that was so great about Mark Twain --

00:03:55.958 --> 00:03:59.958
you know we honor Mark Twain, but we don't read him.

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:02.958
We read 'Huck Finn,' of course, we read 'Huck Finn' of course.

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:04.958
I mean, Huck, of course, was tremendous.

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:07.958
Remember that great scene on the raft, remember what Huck did?

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:10.958
You see, here's Huck; he's an illiterate kid; he's had no schooling,

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:12.958
but there's something in him.

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:15.958
And the official truth, the truth was, the law was,

00:04:15.958 --> 00:04:18.958
that a black man was a property, was a thing, you see.

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:22.958
And Huck gets on the raft with a property named Jim, a slave, see.

00:04:22.958 --> 00:04:26.958
And he hears that Jim is going to go and take his wife and kids

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:28.958
and steal them from the woman who owns them,

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:32.958
and Huck says, 'Ooh, oh my God, ooh, ooh --

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:35.958
that woman, that woman never did anybody any harm.

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:36.958
Ooh, he's going to steal; he's going to steal;

00:04:36.958 --> 00:04:38.958
he's going to do a terrible thing.'

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:43.958
Just then, two slavers caught up, guys chasing slaves, looking for Jim.

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:52.958
'Anybody up on that raft with you?' Huck says, 'Yeah.'

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:59.958
'Is he black or white?' 'White.' And they go off.

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:03.958
And Huck said, 'Oh my God, oh my God, I lied, I lied, ooh,

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:08.958
I did a terrible thing, did a terrible thing -- why do I feel so good?'

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:10.958
"But it's the goodness of Huck, that stuff that Huck's been made of,

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:12.958
you see, all been buried; it's all been buried.

00:05:12.958 --> 00:05:15.958
So the human touch, you see, it's disappearing.

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:17.958
So you ask about a defining moment --

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:19.958
ain't no defining moment in American history for me.

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:22.958
It's an accretion of moments that add up to where we are now,

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:24.958
where trivia becomes news.

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:30.958
And more and more, less and less awareness of the pain of the other.

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:34.958
Huh. You know, I don't know if you could use this or not,

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:38.958
but I was quoting Wright Morris, a writer from Nebraska, who says,

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:41.958
'We're more and more into communications

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:46.958
and less and less into communication.'

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:51.958
Okay, kids, I got to scram, got to go see my cardiologist."

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:52.958
And that's Studs Terkel.

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:58.958
(Applause)

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:05.958
So, talk about risk taking. I'm going to do somebody that nobody likes.

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:10.958
You know, most actors want to do characters that are likeable --

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:13.958
well, not always, but the notion, especially at a conference like this,

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:15.958
I like to inspire people.

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:17.958
But since this was called "risk taking,"

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:21.958
I'm doing somebody who I never do, because she's so unlikeable

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:22.958
that one person actually came backstage

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:26.958
and told me to take her out of the show she was in.

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:29.958
And I'm doing her because I think we think of risk,

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:31.958
at a conference like this, as a good thing.

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:34.958
But there are certain other connotations to the word "risk,"

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:37.958
and the same thing about the word "nature." What is nature?

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:40.958
Maxine Greene, who's a wonderful philosopher

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:44.958
who's as old as Studs, and was the head of a philosophy --

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:48.958
great, big philosophy kind of an organization --

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:50.958
I went to her and asked her what are the two things

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:53.958
that she doesn't know, that she still wants to know.

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:55.958
And she said, "Well, personally, I still feel like I have to curtsey

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:58.958
when I see the president of my university.

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:00.958
And I still feel as though I've got to get coffee

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:02.958
for my male colleagues, even though I've outlived most of them."

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:05.958
And she said, "And then intellectually,

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:08.958
I don't know enough about the negative imagination.

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:10.958
And September 11th certainly taught us

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:12.958
that that's a whole area we don't investigate."

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:15.958
So this piece is about a negative imagination.

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:19.958
It raises questions about what nature is, what Mother Nature is,

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:21.958
and about what a risk can be.

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:23.958
And I got this in the Maryland Correctional Institute for Women.

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:26.958
Everything I do is word for word off a tape.

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:30.958
And I title things because I think people speak in organic poems,

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:31.958
and this is called "A Mirror to Her Mouth."

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:34.958
And this is an inmate named Paulette Jenkins.

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:46.958
"I began to learn how to cover it up,

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:51.958
because I didn't want nobody to know that this was happening in my home.

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:54.958
I want everybody to think we were a normal family.

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:57.958
I mean we had all the materialistic things,

00:07:57.958 --> 00:08:00.958
but that didn't make my children pain any less;

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:03.958
that didn't make their fears subside.

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:06.958
I ran out of excuses about how we got black eyes

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:10.958
and busted lips and bruises. I didn't had no more excuses.

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:13.958
And he beat me too. But that didn't change the fact

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:17.958
that it was a nightmare for my family; it was a nightmare.

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:19.958
And I failed them dramatically,

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:23.958
because I allowed it to go on and on and on.

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:25.958
"But the night that Myesha got killed --

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:29.958
and the intensity just grew and grew and grew,

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:34.958
until one night we came home from getting drugs,

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:37.958
and he got angry with Myesha, and he started beating her,

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:40.958
and he put her in a bathtub. Oh, he would use a belt.

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:43.958
He had a belt because he had this warped perverted thing

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:45.958
that Myesha was having sex with her little brother

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:47.958
and they was fondling each other -- that would be his reason.

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:51.958
I'm just talking about the particular night that she died.

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:54.958
And so he put her in the bathtub,

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:55.958
and I was in the bedroom with the baby.

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:59.958
"And four months before this happened, four months before Myesha died,

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:05.958
I thought I could really fix this man. So I had a baby by him -- insane --

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:08.958
thinking that if I gave him his own kid, he would leave mine alone.

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:12.958
And it didn't work, didn't work.

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:16.958
And I ended up with three children, Houston, Myesha and Dominic,

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:19.958
who was four months old when I came to jail.

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:21.958
"And I was in the bedroom. Like I said, he had her in the bathroom

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:26.958
and he -- he -- every time he hit her, she would fall.

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:31.958
And she would hit her head on the tub. It happened continuously, repeatedly.

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:35.958
I could hear it, but I dared not to move. I didn't move.

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:37.958
I didn't even go and see what was happening.

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:40.958
I just sat there and listened.

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:45.958
And then he put her in the hallway.

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:52.958
He told her, just set there. And so she set there for about four or five hours.

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:55.958
And then he told her, get up.

00:09:55.958 --> 00:09:58.958
And when she got up, she says she couldn't see.

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:03.958
Her face was bruised. She had a black eye.

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:05.958
All around her head was just swollen;

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:11.958
her head was about two sizes of its own size.

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:18.958
I told him, 'Let her go to sleep.' He let her go to sleep.

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:23.958
"The next morning she was dead.

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:26.958
He went in to check on her for school, and he got very excited.

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:28.958
He says, 'She won't breathe.'

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:32.958
I knew immediately that she was dead.

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:35.958
I didn't even want to accept the fact that she was dead, so I went in

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:37.958
and I put a mirror to her mouth --

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:41.958
there was no thing, nothing, coming out of her mouth.

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:42.958
He said, he said, he said,

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:44.958
'We can't, we can't let nobody find out about this.'

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:48.958
He say, 'You've got to help me.' I agree. I agree.

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:51.958
"I mean, I've been keeping a secret for years and years and years,

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:55.958
so it just seemed like second hand to me, just to keep on keeping it a secret.

00:10:55.958 --> 00:11:01.958
So we went to the mall and we told a police that we had, like, lost her,

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:04.958
that she was missing.

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:10.958
We told a security guard that she was missing,

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:12.958
though she wasn't missing.

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:14.958
And we told the security guard what we had put on her

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:17.958
and we went home and we dressed her in exactly the same thing

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:21.958
that we had told the security guard that we had put on her.

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:26.958
"And then we got the baby and my other child,

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:33.958
and we drove out to, like, I-95.

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:36.958
I was so petrified and so numb,

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:41.958
all I could look was in the rear-view mirror.

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:51.958
And he just laid her right on the shoulder of the highway.

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:57.958
My own child, I let that happen to."

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:06.958
So that's an investigation of the negative imagination.

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:11.958
(Applause)

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:13.958
When I started this project

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:15.958
called "On the Road: A Search For an American Character"

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:17.958
with my tape recorder, I thought that I was going to go around America

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:22.958
and find it in all its aspects -- bull riders, cowboys, pig farmers,

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:26.958
drum majorettes -- but I sort of got tripped on race relations,

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:29.958
because my first big show was a show about a race riot.

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:32.958
And so I went to both -- two race riots,

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:35.958
one of which was the Los Angeles riot. And this next piece is from that.

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:37.958
Because this is what I would say

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:41.958
I've learned the most about race relations, from this piece.

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:45.958
It's a kind of an aria, I would say, and in many tapes that I have.

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:48.958
Everybody knows that the Los Angeles riots happened

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:51.958
because four cops beat up a black man named Rodney King.

00:12:51.958 --> 00:12:53.958
It was captured on videotape -- technology --

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:55.958
and it was played all over the world.

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:56.958
Everybody thought the four cops would go to jail.

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:59.958
They did not, so there were riots.

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:01.958
And what a lot of people forget, is there was a second trial,

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:03.958
ordered by George Bush, Sr.

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:08.958
And that trial came back with two cops going to jail

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:11.958
and two cops declared innocent. I was at that trial.

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:13.958
And I mean, the people just danced in the streets

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:15.958
because they were afraid there was going to be another riot.

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:18.958
Explosion of joy that this verdict had come back this way.

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:22.958
So there was a community that didn't -- the Korean-Americans,

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:24.958
whose stores had been burned to the ground.

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:26.958
And so this woman, Mrs. Young-Soon Han,

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:30.958
I suppose will have taught me the most that I have learned about race.

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:33.958
And she asks also a question that Studs talks about:

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:36.958
this notion of the "official truth," to question the "official truth."

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:38.958
So what she's questioning here, she's taking a chance

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:41.958
and questioning what justice is in society.

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:45.958
And this is called, "Swallowing the Bitterness."

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:50.958
"I used to believe America was the best.

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:58.958
I watched in Korea many luxurious Hollywood lifestyle movie.

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:03.958
I never saw any poor man, any black.

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:07.958
Until 1992, I used to believe America was the best -- I still do;

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:11.958
I don't deny that because I am a victim.

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:16.958
But at the end of '92, when we were in such turmoil,

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:20.958
and having all the financial problems, and all the mental problems,

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:24.958
I began to really realize that Koreans

00:14:24.958 --> 00:14:31.958
are completely left out of this society and we are nothing.

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:34.958
Why? Why do we have to be left out?

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:40.958
We didn't qualify for medical treatment, no food stamp, no GR,

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:47.958
no welfare, anything. Many African-Americans who never work

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:51.958
got minimum amount of money to survive.

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:59.958
We didn't get any because we have a car and a house.

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:10.958
And we are high taxpayer. Where do I find justice?

00:15:10.958 --> 00:15:17.958
"OK. OK? OK. OK.

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:21.958
Many African-Americans probably think that they won by the trial.

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:24.958
I was sitting here watching them the morning after the verdict,

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:28.958
and all the day they were having a party, they celebrated,

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:31.958
all of South Central, all the churches. And they say,

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:37.958
'Well, finally justice has been done in this society.'

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:40.958
Well, what about victims' rights?

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:47.958
They got their rights by destroying innocent Korean merchants.

00:15:53.958 --> 00:16:00.958
They have a lot of respect, as I do, for Dr. Martin King.

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:07.958
He is the only model for black community; I don't care Jesse Jackson.

00:16:07.958 --> 00:16:11.958
He is the model of non-violence, non-violence --

00:16:11.958 --> 00:16:16.958
and they would all like to be in his spirit.

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:23.958
"But what about 1992? They destroyed innocent people.

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:27.958
And I wonder if that is really justice

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:34.958
for them, to get their rights in that way.

00:16:34.958 --> 00:16:43.958
I was swallowing the bitterness, sitting here alone and watching them.

00:16:43.958 --> 00:16:50.958
They became so hilarious, but I was happy for them.

00:16:50.958 --> 00:16:55.958
I was glad for them. At least they got something back, OK.

00:16:55.958 --> 00:17:02.958
Let's just forget about Korean victims and other victims

00:17:02.958 --> 00:17:07.958
who were destroyed by them.

00:17:07.958 --> 00:17:16.958
They fought for their rights for over two centuries,

00:17:16.958 --> 00:17:19.958
and maybe because they sacrifice other minorities,

00:17:19.958 --> 00:17:24.958
Hispanic, Asian, we would suffer more in the mainstream.

00:17:24.958 --> 00:17:25.958
That's why I understand;

00:17:25.958 --> 00:17:28.958
that's why I have a mixed feeling about the verdict.

00:17:28.958 --> 00:17:33.958
"But I wish that, I wish that, I wish that

00:17:33.958 --> 00:17:36.958
I could be part of the enjoyment.

00:17:36.958 --> 00:17:43.958
I wish that I could live together with black people.

00:17:43.958 --> 00:17:53.958
But after the riot, it's too much difference.

00:17:53.958 --> 00:18:00.958
The fire is still there. How do you say it? [Unclear].

00:18:00.958 --> 00:18:08.958
Igniting, igniting, igniting fire. Igniting fire.

00:18:08.958 --> 00:18:15.958
It's still there; it can burst out anytime."

00:18:20.958 --> 00:18:22.958
Mrs. Young-Soon Han.

00:18:22.958 --> 00:18:30.958
(Applause)

00:18:30.958 --> 00:18:33.958
The other reason that I don't wear shoes

00:18:34.958 --> 00:18:37.958
is just in case I really feel like I have to cuddle up

00:18:37.958 --> 00:18:39.958
and get into the feet of somebody,

00:18:39.958 --> 00:18:41.958
walking really in somebody else's shoes.

00:18:41.958 --> 00:18:44.958
And I told you that in -- you know, I didn't give you the year,

00:18:44.958 --> 00:18:47.958
but in '79 I thought that I was going to go around

00:18:47.958 --> 00:18:49.958
and find bull riders and pig farmers and people like that,

00:18:49.958 --> 00:18:52.958
and I got sidetracked on race relations.

00:18:52.958 --> 00:18:55.958
Finally, I did find a bull rider, two years ago.

00:18:55.958 --> 00:18:58.958
And I've been going to the rodeos with him, and we've bonded.

00:18:58.958 --> 00:19:03.958
And he's the lead in an op-ed I did about the Republican Convention.

00:19:03.958 --> 00:19:08.958
He's a Republican -- I won't say anything about my party affiliation, but anyway --

00:19:08.958 --> 00:19:12.958
so this is my dear, dear Brent Williams,

00:19:12.958 --> 00:19:13.958
and this is on toughness,

00:19:13.958 --> 00:19:16.958
in case anybody needs to know about being tough

00:19:16.958 --> 00:19:19.958
for the work that you do. I think there's a real lesson in this.

00:19:19.958 --> 00:19:22.958
And this is called "Toughness."

00:19:22.958 --> 00:19:27.958
"Well, I'm an optimist. I mean basically I'm an optimist.

00:19:27.958 --> 00:19:29.958
I mean, you know, I mean, it's like my wife, Jolene,

00:19:29.958 --> 00:19:31.958
her family's always saying,

00:19:31.958 --> 00:19:33.958
you know, you ever think he's just a born loser?

00:19:33.958 --> 00:19:35.958
It seems like he has so much bad luck, you know.

00:19:35.958 --> 00:19:37.958
But then when that bull stepped on my kidney, you know,

00:19:37.958 --> 00:19:39.958
I didn't lose my kidney -- I could have lost my kidney,

00:19:39.958 --> 00:19:41.958
I kept my kidney, so I don't think I'm a born loser.

00:19:41.958 --> 00:19:42.958
I think that's good luck.

00:19:42.958 --> 00:19:44.958
(Laughter)

00:19:44.958 --> 00:19:46.958
"And, I mean, funny things like this happen.

00:19:46.958 --> 00:19:50.958
I was in a doctor's office last CAT scan,

00:19:50.958 --> 00:19:53.958
and there was a Reader's Digest, October 2002.

00:19:53.958 --> 00:19:56.958
It was like, 'seven ways to get lucky.' And it says

00:19:56.958 --> 00:19:57.958
if you want to get lucky,

00:19:57.958 --> 00:19:59.958
you know, you've got to be around positive people.

00:19:59.958 --> 00:20:03.958
I mean, like even when I told my wife that you want to come out here

00:20:03.958 --> 00:20:05.958
and talk to me, she's like, 'She's just talking;

00:20:05.958 --> 00:20:07.958
she's just being nice to you. She's not going to do that.'

00:20:07.958 --> 00:20:09.958
"And then you called me up and you said you wanted to come out here

00:20:09.958 --> 00:20:11.958
and interview me and she went and looked you up on the Internet.

00:20:11.958 --> 00:20:13.958
She said, 'Look who she is.

00:20:13.958 --> 00:20:15.958
You're not even going to be able to answer her questions.'

00:20:15.958 --> 00:20:19.958
(Laughter)

00:20:19.958 --> 00:20:21.958
And she was saying you're going to make me look like an idiot

00:20:21.958 --> 00:20:22.958
because I've never been to college,

00:20:22.958 --> 00:20:24.958
and I wouldn't be talking professional or anything.

00:20:24.958 --> 00:20:26.958
I said, 'Well look, the woman talked to me for four hours.

00:20:26.958 --> 00:20:28.958
You know, if I wasn't talking -- you know,

00:20:28.958 --> 00:20:29.958
like, you know, she wanted me to talk,

00:20:29.958 --> 00:20:34.958
I don't think she would even come out here.'

00:20:34.958 --> 00:20:37.958
"Confidence? Well, I think I ride

00:20:37.958 --> 00:20:40.958
more out of determination than confidence.

00:20:40.958 --> 00:20:41.958
I mean, confidence is like, you know,

00:20:41.958 --> 00:20:43.958
you've been on that bull before; you know you can ride him.

00:20:43.958 --> 00:20:47.958
I mean, confidence is kind of like being cocky, but in a good way.

00:20:47.958 --> 00:20:50.958
But determination, you know, it's like just, you know, 'Fuck the form,

00:20:50.958 --> 00:20:52.958
get the horn.'

00:20:52.958 --> 00:20:56.958
(Laughter)

00:20:56.958 --> 00:20:58.958
That's Tuff Hedeman, in the movie '8 Seconds.'

00:20:58.958 --> 00:21:00.958
I mean, like, Pat O'Mealey always said when I was a boy,

00:21:00.958 --> 00:21:03.958
he say, 'You know, you got more try than any kid I ever seen.'

00:21:03.958 --> 00:21:05.958
And try and determination is the same thing.

00:21:05.958 --> 00:21:07.958
Determination is, like, you're going to hang on that bull,

00:21:07.958 --> 00:21:09.958
even if you're riding upside down.

00:21:09.958 --> 00:21:11.958
Determination's like, you're going to ride

00:21:11.958 --> 00:21:14.958
till your head hits the back of the dirt.

00:21:14.958 --> 00:21:18.958
"Freedom? It would have to be the rodeo.

00:21:18.958 --> 00:21:23.958
"Beauty? I don't think I know what beauty is.

00:21:23.958 --> 00:21:25.958
Well, you know, I guess that'd have to be the rodeo too.

00:21:25.958 --> 00:21:26.958
I mean, look how we are, the roughy family,

00:21:26.958 --> 00:21:29.958
palling around and shaking hands and wrestling around me.

00:21:29.958 --> 00:21:32.958
It's like, you know, racking up our credit cards on entry fees and gas.

00:21:32.958 --> 00:21:35.958
We ride together, we, you know, we, we eat together

00:21:35.958 --> 00:21:36.958
and we sleep together.

00:21:36.958 --> 00:21:39.958
I mean, I can't even imagine what it's going to be like

00:21:39.958 --> 00:21:41.958
the last day I rodeo. I mean, I'll be alright.

00:21:41.958 --> 00:21:42.958
I mean, I have my ranch and everything,

00:21:42.958 --> 00:21:45.958
but I actually don't even want to think the day that comes.

00:21:45.958 --> 00:21:47.958
I mean, I guess it just be like --

00:21:47.958 --> 00:21:51.958
I guess it be like the day my brother died.

00:21:51.958 --> 00:21:56.958
"Toughness? Well, we was in West Jordan, Utah, and this bull

00:21:56.958 --> 00:21:59.958
shoved my face right through the metal shoots in a --

00:21:59.958 --> 00:22:02.958
you know, busted my face all up and had to go to the hospital.

00:22:02.958 --> 00:22:04.958
And they had to sew me up and straighten my nose out.

00:22:04.958 --> 00:22:06.958
And I had to go and ride in the rodeo that night,

00:22:06.958 --> 00:22:09.958
so I didn't want them to put me under anesthesia,

00:22:09.958 --> 00:22:12.958
or whatever you call it. And so they sewed my face up.

00:22:12.958 --> 00:22:14.958
And then they had to straighten out my nose,

00:22:14.958 --> 00:22:17.958
and they took these rods and shoved them up my nose

00:22:17.958 --> 00:22:19.958
and went up through my brains

00:22:19.958 --> 00:22:21.958
and felt like it was coming out the top of my head,

00:22:21.958 --> 00:22:23.958
and everybody said that it should have killed me,

00:22:23.958 --> 00:22:27.958
but it didn't, because I guess I have a high tolerance for pain.

00:22:27.958 --> 00:22:30.958
(Laughter)

00:22:30.958 --> 00:22:33.958
But the good thing was, once they shoved those rods up there

00:22:33.958 --> 00:22:35.958
and straightened my nose out, I could breathe,

00:22:35.958 --> 00:22:37.958
and I hadn't been able to breathe

00:22:37.958 --> 00:22:40.958
since I broke my nose in the high school rodeo."

00:22:40.958 --> 00:22:42.958
Thank you.

00:22:42.958 --> 00:22:59.958
(Applause)

title: Everyday inventions
transcript: So anyway, who am I? I usually say to people, when they say, "What do you do?" I say, "I do hardware," because it sort of conveniently encompasses everything I do. And I recently said that to a venture capitalist casually at some Valley event, to which he replied, "How quaint."(Laughter)And I sort of really was dumbstruck. And I really should have said something smart. And now I've had a little bit of time to think about it, I would have said, "Well, you know, if we look at the next 100 years and we've seen all these problems in the last few days, most of the big issues — clean water, clean energy — and they're interchangeable in some respects — and cleaner, more functional materials — they all look to me to be hardware problems. This doesn't mean we should ignore software, or information, or computation." And that's in fact probably what I'm going to try and tell you about.So, this talk is going to be about how do we make things and what are the new ways that we're going to make things in the future. Now, TED sends you a lot of spam if you're a speaker about "do this, do that" and you fill out all these forms, and you don't actually know how they're going to describe you, and it flashed across my desk that they were going to introduce me as a futurist. And I've always been nervous about the term "futurist," because you seem doomed to failure because you can't really predict it. And I was laughing about this with the very smart colleagues I have, and said, "You know, well, if I have to talk about the future, what is it?" And George Homsey, a great guy, said, "Oh, the future is amazing. It is so much stranger than you think. We're going to reprogram the bacteria in your gut, and we're going to make your poo smell like peppermint."(Laughter)So, you may think that's sort of really crazy, but there are some pretty amazing things that are happening that make this possible. So, this isn't my work, but it's work of good friends of mine at MIT. This is called the registry of standard biological parts. This is headed by Drew Endy and Tom Knight and a few other very, very bright individuals. Basically, what they're doing is looking at biology as a programmable system. Literally, think of proteins as subroutines that you can string together to execute a program. Now, this is actually becoming such an interesting idea. This is a state diagram. That's an extremely simple computer.This one is a two-bit counter. So that's essentially the computational equivalent of two light switches. And this is being built by a group of students at Zurich for a design competition in biology. And from the results of the same competition last year, a University of Texas team of students programmed bacteria so that they can detect light and switch on and off. So this is interesting in the sense that you can now do "if-then-for" statements in materials, in structure. This is a pretty interesting trend, because we used to live in a world where everyone's said glibly, "Form follows function," but I think I've sort of grown up in a world — you listened to Neil Gershenfeld yesterday; I was in a lab associated with his — where it's really a world where information defines form and function.I spent six years thinking about that, but to show you the power of art over science — this is actually one of the cartoons I write. These are called "HowToons." I work with a fabulous illustrator called Nick Dragotta. Took me six years at MIT, and about that many pages to describe what I was doing, and it took him one page. And so this is our muse Tucker. He's an interesting little kid — and his sister, Celine — and what he's doing here is observing the self-assembly of his Cheerios in his cereal bowl. And in fact you can program the self-assembly of things, so he starts chocolate-dipping edges, changing the hydrophobicity and the hydrophylicity. In theory, if you program those sufficiently, you should be able to do something pretty interesting and make a very complex structure. In this case, he's done self-replication of a complex 3D structure. And that's what I thought about for a long time, because this is how we currently make things. This is a silicon wafer, and essentially that's just a whole bunch of layers of two-dimensional stuff, sort of layered up. The feature side is — you know, people will say, [unclear] down around about 65 nanometers now.On the right, that's a radiolara. That's a unicellular organism ubiquitous in the oceans. And that has feature sizes down to about 20 nanometers, and it's a complex 3D structure. We could do a lot more with computers and things generally if we knew how to build things this way. The secret to biology is, it builds computation into the way it makes things. So this little thing here, polymerase, is essentially a supercomputer designed for replicating DNA. And the ribosome here is another little computer that helps in the translation of the proteins. I thought about this in the sense that it's great to build in biological materials, but can we do similar things? Can we get self-replicating-type behavior? Can we get complex 3D structure automatically assembling in inorganic systems? Because there are some advantages to inorganic systems, like higher speed semiconductors, etc.So, this is some of my work on how do you do an autonomously self-replicating system. And this is sort of Babbage's revenge. These are little mechanical computers. These are five-state state machines. So, that's about three light switches lined up. In a neutral state, they won't bind at all. Now, if I make a string of these, a bit string, they will be able to replicate. So we start with white, blue, blue, white. That encodes; that will now copy. From one comes two, and then from two comes three. And so you've got this sort of replicating system. It was work actually by Lionel Penrose, father of Roger Penrose, the tiles guy. He did a lot of this work in the '60s, and so a lot of this logic theory lay fallow as we went down the digital computer revolution, but it's now coming back.So now I'm going to show you the hands-free, autonomous self-replication. So we've tracked in the video the input string, which was green, green, yellow, yellow, green. We set them off on this air hockey table. You know, high science uses air hockey tables —(Laughter)— and if you watch this thing long enough you get dizzy, but what you're actually seeing is copies of that original string emerging from the parts bin that you have here. So we've got autonomous replication of bit strings. So, why would you want to replicate bit strings? Well, it turns out biology has this other very interesting meme, that you can take a linear string, which is a convenient thing to copy, and you can fold that into an arbitrarily complex 3D structure. So I was trying to, you know, take the engineer's version: Can we build a mechanical system in inorganic materials that will do the same thing?So what I'm showing you here is that we can make a 2D shape — the B — assemble from a string of components that follow extremely simple rules. And the whole point of going with the extremely simple rules here, and the incredibly simple state machines in the previous design, was that you don't need digital logic to do computation. And that way you can scale things much smaller than microchips. So you can literally use these as the tiny components in the assembly process.So, Neil Gershenfeld showed you this video on Wednesday, I believe, but I'll show you again. This is literally the colored sequence of those tiles. Each different color has a different magnetic polarity, and the sequence is uniquely specifying the structure that is coming out. Now, hopefully, those of you who know anything about graph theory can look at that, and that will satisfy you that that can also do arbitrary 3D structure, and in fact, you know, I can now take a dog, carve it up and then reassemble it so it's a linear string that will fold from a sequence. And now I can actually define that three-dimensional object as a sequence of bits. So, you know, it's a pretty interesting world when you start looking at the world a little bit differently. And the universe is now a compiler. And so I'm thinking about, you know, what are the programs for programming the physical universe? And how do we think about materials and structure, sort of as an information and computation problem? Not just where you attach a micro-controller to the end point, but that the structure and the mechanisms are the logic, are the computers.Having totally absorbed this philosophy, I started looking at a lot of problems a little differently. With the universe as a computer, you can look at this droplet of water as having performed the computations. You set a couple of boundary conditions, like gravity, the surface tension, density, etc., and then you press "execute," and magically, the universe produces you a perfect ball lens. So, this actually applied to the problem of — so there's a half a billion to a billion people in the world don't have access to cheap eyeglasses. So can you make a machine that could make any prescription lens very quickly on site? This is a machine where you literally define a boundary condition. If it's circular, you make a spherical lens. If it's elliptical, you can make an astigmatic lens. You then put a membrane on that and you apply pressure — so that's part of the extra program. And literally with only those two inputs — so, the shape of your boundary condition and the pressure — you can define an infinite number of lenses that cover the range of human refractive error, from minus 12 to plus eight diopters, up to four diopters of cylinder. And then literally, you now pour on a monomer. You know, I'll do a Julia Childs here. This is three minutes of UV light. And you reverse the pressure on your membrane once you've cooked it. Pop it out. I've seen this video, but I still don't know if it's going to end right.(Laughter)So you reverse this. This is a very old movie, so with the new prototypes, actually both surfaces are flexible, but this will show you the point. Now you've finished the lens, you literally pop it out. That's next year's Yves Klein, you know, eyeglasses shape. And you can see that that has a mild prescription of about minus two diopters. And as I rotate it against this side shot, you'll see that that has cylinder, and that was programmed in — literally into the physics of the system. So, this sort of thinking about structure as computation and structure as information leads to other things, like this.This is something that my people at SQUID Labs are working on at the moment, called "electronic rope." So literally, you think about a rope. It has very complex structure in the weave. And under no load, it's one structure. Under a different load, it's a different structure. And you can actually exploit that by putting in a very small number of conducting fibers to actually make it a sensor. So this is now a rope that knows the load on the rope at any particular point in the rope. Just by thinking about the physics of the world, materials as the computer, you can start to do things like this.I'm going to segue a little here. I guess I'm just going to casually tell you the types of things that I think about with this. One thing I'm really interested about this right now is, how, if you're really taking this view of the universe as a computer, how do we make things in a very general sense, and how might we share the way we make things in a general sense the same way you share open source hardware? And a lot of talks here have espoused the benefits of having lots of people look at problems, share the information and work on those things together. So, a convenient thing about being a human is you move in linear time, and unless Lisa Randall changes that, we'll continue to move in linear time. So that means anything you do, or anything you make, you produce a sequence of steps — and I think Lego in the '70s nailed this, and they did it most elegantly. But they can show you how to build things in sequence. So, I'm thinking about, how can we generalize the way we make all sorts of things, so you end up with this sort of guy, right? And I think this applies across a very broad — sort of, a lot of concepts.You know, Cameron Sinclair yesterday said, "How do I get everyone to collaborate on design globally to do housing for humanity?" And if you've seen Amy Smith, she talks about how you get students at MIT to work with communities in Haiti. And I think we have to sort of redefine and rethink how we define structure and materials and assembly things, so that we can really share the information on how you do those things in a more profound way and build on each other's source code for structure. I don't know exactly how to do this yet, but, you know, it's something being actively thought about.So, you know, that leads to questions like, is this a compiler? Is this a sub-routine? Interesting things like that. Maybe I'm getting a little too abstract, but you know, this is the sort of — returning to our comic characters — this is sort of the universe, or a different universe view, that I think is going to be very prevalent in the future — from biotech to materials assembly. It was great to hear Bill Joy. They're starting to invest in materials science, but these are the new things in materials science. How do we put real information and real structure into new ideas, and see the world in a different way? And it's not going to be binary code that defines the computers of the universe — it's sort of an analog computer. But it's definitely an interesting new worldview.I've gone too far. So that sounds like it's it. I've probably got a couple of minutes of questions, or I can show — I think they also said that I do extreme stuff in the introduction, so I may have to explain that. So maybe I'll do that with this short video.So this is actually a 3,000-square-foot kite, which also happens to be a minimal energy surface. So returning to the droplet, again, thinking about the universe in a new way. This is a kite designed by a guy called Dave Kulp. And why do you want a 3,000-square-foot kite? So that's a kite the size of your house. And so you want that to tow boats very fast. So I've been working on this a little, also, with a couple of other guys. But, you know, this is another way to look at the — if you abstract again, this is a structure that is defined by the physics of the universe. You could just hang it as a bed sheet, but again, the computation of all the physics gives you the aerodynamic shape. And so you can actually sort of almost double your boat speed with systems like that. So that's sort of another interesting aspect of the future.(Applause)

00:02:33.958 --> 00:02:36.958
And this is being built by a group of students at Zurich

00:02:36.958 --> 00:02:38.958
for a design competition in biology.

00:02:38.958 --> 00:02:41.958
And from the results of the same competition last year,

00:02:41.958 --> 00:02:45.958
a University of Texas team of students programmed bacteria

00:02:45.958 --> 00:02:48.958
so that they can detect light and switch on and off.

00:02:48.958 --> 00:02:50.958
So this is interesting in the sense that you can now

00:02:50.958 --> 00:02:55.958
do "if-then-for" statements in materials, in structure.

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:57.958
This is a pretty interesting trend,

00:02:57.958 --> 00:02:59.958
because we used to live in a world where everyone's said glibly,

00:02:59.958 --> 00:03:03.958
"Form follows function," but I think I've sort of grown up in a world

00:03:03.958 --> 00:03:06.958
-- you listened to Neil Gershenfeld yesterday;

00:03:06.958 --> 00:03:10.958
I was in a lab associated with his -- where it's really a world

00:03:10.958 --> 00:03:13.958
where information defines form and function.

00:03:13.958 --> 00:03:17.958
I spent six years thinking about that,

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:19.958
but to show you the power of art over science --

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:22.958
this is actually one of the cartoons I write. These are called "HowToons."

00:03:22.958 --> 00:03:24.958
I work with a fabulous illustrator called Nick Dragotta.

00:03:24.958 --> 00:03:26.958
Took me six years at MIT,

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:30.958
and about that many pages to describe what I was doing,

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:35.958
and it took him one page. And so this is our muse Tucker.

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:37.958
He's an interesting little kid -- and his sister, Celine --

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:39.958
and what he's doing here

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:43.958
is observing the self-assembly of his Cheerios in his cereal bowl.

00:03:43.958 --> 00:03:46.958
And in fact you can program the self-assembly of things,

00:03:46.958 --> 00:03:48.958
so he starts chocolate-dipping edges,

00:03:48.958 --> 00:03:50.958
changing the hydrophobicity and the hydrophylicity.

00:03:50.958 --> 00:03:52.958
In theory, if you program those sufficiently,

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:54.958
you should be able to do something pretty interesting

00:03:54.958 --> 00:03:56.958
and make a very complex structure.

00:03:56.958 --> 00:04:01.958
In this case, he's done self-replication of a complex 3D structure.

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:04.958
And that's what I thought about for a long time,

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:06.958
because this is how we currently make things.

00:04:06.958 --> 00:04:08.958
This is a silicon wafer, and essentially

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:12.958
that's just a whole bunch of layers of two-dimensional stuff, sort of layered up.

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:14.958
The feature side is -- you know, people will say,

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:16.958
[unclear] down around about 65 nanometers now.

00:04:16.958 --> 00:04:18.958
On the right, that's a radiolara.

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:21.958
That's a unicellular organism ubiquitous in the oceans.

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:25.958
And that has feature sizes down to about 20 nanometers,

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:27.958
and it's a complex 3D structure.

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:31.958
We could do a lot more with computers and things generally

00:04:31.958 --> 00:04:34.958
if we knew how to build things this way.

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:37.958
The secret to biology is, it builds computation

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:40.958
into the way it makes things. So this little thing here, polymerase,

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:45.958
is essentially a supercomputer designed for replicating DNA.

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:48.958
And the ribosome here is another little computer

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:50.958
that helps in the translation of the proteins.

00:04:50.958 --> 00:04:51.958
I thought about this

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:54.958
in the sense that it's great to build in biological materials,

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:56.958
but can we do similar things?

00:04:56.958 --> 00:04:58.958
Can we get self-replicating-type behavior?

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:02.958
Can we get complex 3D structure automatically assembling

00:05:02.958 --> 00:05:04.958
in inorganic systems?

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:06.958
Because there are some advantages to inorganic systems,

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:08.958
like higher speed semiconductors, etc.

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:10.958
So, this is some of my work

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:16.958
on how do you do an autonomously self-replicating system.

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:18.958
And this is sort of Babbage's revenge.

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:19.958
These are little mechanical computers.

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:22.958
These are five-state state machines.

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:25.958
So, that's about three light switches lined up.

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:27.958
In a neutral state, they won't bind at all.

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:31.958
Now, if I make a string of these, a bit string,

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:33.958
they will be able to replicate.

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:34.958
So we start with white, blue, blue, white.

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:40.958
That encodes; that will now copy. From one comes two,

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:42.958
and then from two comes three.

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:46.958
And so you've got this sort of replicating system.

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:48.958
It was work actually by Lionel Penrose,

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:51.958
father of Roger Penrose, the tiles guy.

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:53.958
He did a lot of this work in the '60s,

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:55.958
and so a lot of this logic theory lay fallow

00:05:55.958 --> 00:05:58.958
as we went down the digital computer revolution, but it's now coming back.

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:02.958
So now I'm going to show you the hands-free, autonomous self-replication.

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:04.958
So we've tracked in the video the input string,

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:06.958
which was green, green, yellow, yellow, green.

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:10.958
We set them off on this air hockey table.

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:12.958
You know, high science uses air hockey tables --

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:13.958
(Laughter)

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:15.958
-- and if you watch this thing long enough you get dizzy,

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:18.958
but what you're actually seeing is copies of that original string

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:21.958
emerging from the parts bin that you have here.

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:26.958
So we've got autonomous replication of bit strings.

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:29.958
So, why would you want to replicate bit strings?

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:32.958
Well, it turns out biology has this other very interesting meme,

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:35.958
that you can take a linear string, which is a convenient thing to copy,

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:39.958
and you can fold that into an arbitrarily complex 3D structure.

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:42.958
So I was trying to, you know, take the engineer's version:

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:45.958
Can we build a mechanical system in inorganic materials

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:46.958
that will do the same thing?

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:51.958
So what I'm showing you here is that we can make a 2D shape --

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:55.958
the B -- assemble from a string of components

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:57.958
that follow extremely simple rules.

00:06:57.958 --> 00:07:00.958
And the whole point of going with the extremely simple rules here,

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:03.958
and the incredibly simple state machines in the previous design,

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:06.958
was that you don't need digital logic to do computation.

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:10.958
And that way you can scale things much smaller than microchips.

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:14.958
So you can literally use these as the tiny components in the assembly process.

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:19.958
So, Neil Gershenfeld showed you this video on Wednesday, I believe,

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:21.958
but I'll show you again.

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:24.958
This is literally the colored sequence of those tiles.

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:27.958
Each different color has a different magnetic polarity,

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:32.958
and the sequence is uniquely specifying the structure that is coming out.

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:35.958
Now, hopefully, those of you who know anything about graph theory

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:37.958
can look at that, and that will satisfy you

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:40.958
that that can also do arbitrary 3D structure,

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:45.958
and in fact, you know, I can now take a dog, carve it up

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:47.958
and then reassemble it so it's a linear string

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:49.958
that will fold from a sequence. And now

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:56.958
I can actually define that three-dimensional object as a sequence of bits.

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:59.958
So, you know, it's a pretty interesting world

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:01.958
when you start looking at the world a little bit differently.

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:04.958
And the universe is now a compiler.

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:06.958
And so I'm thinking about, you know, what are the programs

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:09.958
for programming the physical universe?

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:12.958
And how do we think about materials and structure,

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:15.958
sort of as an information and computation problem?

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:18.958
Not just where you attach a micro-controller to the end point,

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:23.958
but that the structure and the mechanisms are the logic, are the computers.

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:28.958
Having totally absorbed this philosophy,

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:31.958
I started looking at a lot of problems a little differently.

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:32.958
With the universe as a computer,

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:34.958
you can look at this droplet of water

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:36.958
as having performed the computations.

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:38.958
You set a couple of boundary conditions, like gravity,

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:42.958
the surface tension, density, etc., and then you press "execute,"

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:47.958
and magically, the universe produces you a perfect ball lens.

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:49.958
So, this actually applied to the problem

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:52.958
of -- so there's a half a billion to a billion people in the world

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:54.958
don't have access to cheap eyeglasses.

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:56.958
So can you make a machine

00:08:56.958 --> 00:09:00.958
that could make any prescription lens very quickly on site?

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:04.958
This is a machine where you literally define a boundary condition.

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:07.958
If it's circular, you make a spherical lens.

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:10.958
If it's elliptical, you can make an astigmatic lens.

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:13.958
You then put a membrane on that and you apply pressure --

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:15.958
so that's part of the extra program.

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:18.958
And literally with only those two inputs --

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:20.958
so, the shape of your boundary condition and the pressure --

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:22.958
you can define an infinite number of lenses

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:24.958
that cover the range of human refractive error,

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:29.958
from minus 12 to plus eight diopters, up to four diopters of cylinder.

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:32.958
And then literally, you now pour on a monomer.

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:35.958
You know, I'll do a Julia Childs here.

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:38.958
This is three minutes of UV light.

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:41.958
And you reverse the pressure on your membrane

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:44.958
once you've cooked it. Pop it out.

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:47.958
I've seen this video, but I still don't know if it's going to end right.

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:50.958
(Laughter)

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:52.958
So you reverse this. This is a very old movie,

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:56.958
so with the new prototypes, actually both surfaces are flexible,

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:58.958
but this will show you the point.

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:00.958
Now you've finished the lens, you literally pop it out.

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:07.958
That's next year's Yves Klein, you know, eyeglasses shape.

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:10.958
And you can see that that has a mild prescription of about minus two diopters.

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:14.958
And as I rotate it against this side shot, you'll see that that has cylinder,

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:15.958
and that was programmed in --

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:19.958
literally into the physics of the system.

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:22.958
So, this sort of thinking about structure as computation

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:27.958
and structure as information leads to other things, like this.

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:30.958
This is something that my people at SQUID Labs

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:32.958
are working on at the moment, called "electronic rope."

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:36.958
So literally, you think about a rope. It has very complex structure in the weave.

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:38.958
And under no load, it's one structure.

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:41.958
Under a different load, it's a different structure. And you can actually exploit that

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:43.958
by putting in a very small number of

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:45.958
conducting fibers to actually make it a sensor.

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:48.958
So this is now a rope that knows the load on the rope

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:50.958
at any particular point in the rope.

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:53.958
Just by thinking about the physics of the world,

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:55.958
materials as the computer,

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:58.958
you can start to do things like this.

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:01.958
I'm going to segue a little here.

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:03.958
I guess I'm just going to casually tell you the types of things

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:04.958
that I think about with this.

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:08.958
One thing I'm really interested about this right now is, how,

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:12.958
if you're really taking this view of the universe as a computer,

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:14.958
how do we make things in a very general sense,

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:18.958
and how might we share the way we make things in a general sense

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:21.958
the same way you share open source hardware?

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:24.958
And a lot of talks here have espoused the benefits

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:26.958
of having lots of people look at problems,

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:29.958
share the information and work on those things together.

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:32.958
So, a convenient thing about being a human is you move in linear time,

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:34.958
and unless Lisa Randall changes that,

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:37.958
we'll continue to move in linear time.

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:39.958
So that means anything you do, or anything you make,

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:41.958
you produce a sequence of steps --

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:44.958
and I think Lego in the '70s nailed this,

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:45.958
and they did it most elegantly.

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:49.958
But they can show you how to build things in sequence.

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:52.958
So, I'm thinking about, how can we generalize

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:54.958
the way we make all sorts of things,

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:56.958
so you end up with this sort of guy, right?

00:11:56.958 --> 00:12:01.958
And I think this applies across a very broad -- sort of, a lot of concepts.

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:03.958
You know, Cameron Sinclair yesterday said,

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:05.958
"How do I get everyone to collaborate on design

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:08.958
globally to do housing for humanity?"

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:10.958
And if you've seen Amy Smith,

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:14.958
she talks about how you get students at MIT

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:16.958
to work with communities in Haiti.

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:18.958
And I think we have to sort of redefine and rethink

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:22.958
how we define structure and materials and assembly things,

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:24.958
so that we can really share the information

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:26.958
on how you do those things in a more profound way

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:29.958
and build on each other's source code for structure.

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:30.958
I don't know exactly how to do this yet,

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:35.958
but, you know, it's something being actively thought about.

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:37.958
So, you know, that leads to questions

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:41.958
like, is this a compiler? Is this a sub-routine?

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:42.958
Interesting things like that.

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:45.958
Maybe I'm getting a little too abstract, but you know,

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:48.958
this is the sort of -- returning to our comic characters --

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:50.958
this is sort of the universe, or a different universe view,

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:52.958
that I think is going to be very prevalent in the future --

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:55.958
from biotech to materials assembly. It was great to hear Bill Joy.

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:58.958
They're starting to invest in materials science,

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:00.958
but these are the new things in materials science.

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:04.958
How do we put real information and real structure into new ideas,

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:07.958
and see the world in a different way? And it's not going to be binary code

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:09.958
that defines the computers of the universe --

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:11.958
it's sort of an analog computer.

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:16.958
But it's definitely an interesting new worldview.

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:19.958
I've gone too far. So that sounds like it's it.

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:21.958
I've probably got a couple of minutes of questions,

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:25.958
or I can show -- I think they also said that I do extreme stuff

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:29.958
in the introduction, so I may have to explain that.

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:32.958
So maybe I'll do that with this short video.

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:38.958
So this is actually a 3,000-square-foot kite,

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:40.958
which also happens to be a minimal energy surface.

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:42.958
So returning to the droplet, again,

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:44.958
thinking about the universe in a new way.

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:46.958
This is a kite designed by a guy called Dave Kulp.

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:48.958
And why do you want a 3,000-square-foot kite?

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:50.958
So that's a kite the size of your house.

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:54.958
And so you want that to tow boats very fast.

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:57.958
So I've been working on this a little, also,

00:13:57.958 --> 00:13:59.958
with a couple of other guys.

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:01.958
But, you know, this is another way to look at the --

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:03.958
if you abstract again,

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:07.958
this is a structure that is defined by the physics of the universe.

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:08.958
You could just hang it as a bed sheet,

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:10.958
but again, the computation of all the physics

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:12.958
gives you the aerodynamic shape.

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:15.958
And so you can actually sort of almost double your boat speed

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:22.958
with systems like that. So that's sort of another interesting aspect of the future.

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:23.958
(Applause)

title: Unleash your creativity in a Fab Lab
transcript: This meeting has really been about a digital revolution, but I'd like to argue that it's done; we won. We've had a digital revolution but we don't need to keep having it. And I'd like to look after that, to look what comes after the digital revolution. So, let me start projecting forward. These are some projects I'm involved in today at MIT, looking what comes after computers.This first one, Internet Zero, up here — this is a web server that has the cost and complexity of an RFID tag — about a dollar — that can go in every light bulb and doorknob, and this is getting commercialized very quickly. And what's interesting about it isn't the cost; it's the way it encodes the Internet. It uses a kind of a Morse code for the Internet so you could send it optically; you can communicate acoustically through a power line, through RF. It takes the original principle of the Internet, which is inter-networking computers, and now lets devices inter-network. That we can take the whole idea that gave birth to the Internet and bring it down to the physical world in this Internet Zero, this internet of devices.So this is the next step from there to here, and this is getting commercialized today. A step after that is a project on fungible computers. Fungible goods in economics can be extended and traded. So, half as much grain is half as much useful, but half a baby or half a computer is less useful than a whole baby or a whole computer, and we've been trying to make computers that work that way. So, what you see in the background is a prototype. This was from a thesis of a student, Bill Butow, now at Intel, who wondered why, instead of making bigger and bigger chips, you don't make small chips, put them in a viscous medium, and pour out computing by the pound or by the square inch. And that's what you see here. On the left was postscript being rendered by a conventional computer; on the right is postscript being rendered from the first prototype we made, but there's no frame buffer, IO processor, any of that stuff — it's just this material. Unlike this screen where the dots are placed carefully, this is a raw material. If you add twice as much of it, you have twice as much display. If you shoot a gun through the middle, nothing happens. If you need more resource, you just apply more computer.So, that's the step after this — of computing as a raw material. That's still conventional bits, the step after that is — this is an earlier prototype in the lab; this is high-speed video slowed down. Now, integrating chemistry in computation, where the bits are bubbles. This is showing making bits, this is showing — once again, slowed down so you can see it, bits interacting to do logic and multiplexing and de-multiplexing. So, now we can compute that the output arranges material as well as information. And, ultimately, these are some slides from an early project I did, computing where the bits are stored quantum-mechanically in the nuclei of atoms, so programs rearrange the nuclear structure of molecules. All of these are in the lab pushing further and further and further, not as metaphor but literally integrating bits and atoms, and they lead to the following recognition.We all know we've had a digital revolution, but what is that? Well, Shannon took us, in the '40s, from here to here: from a telephone being a speaker wire that degraded with distance to the Internet. And he proved the first threshold theorem, that shows if you add information and remove it to a signal, you can compute perfectly with an imperfect device. And that's when we got the Internet. Von Neumann, in the '50s, did the same thing for computing; he showed you can have an unreliable computer but restore its state to make it perfect. This was the last great analog computer at MIT: a differential analyzer, and the more you ran it, the worse the answer got.After Von Neumann, we have the Pentium, where the billionth transistor is as reliable as the first one. But all our fabrication is down in this lower left corner. A state-of-the-art airplane factory rotating metal wax at fixed metal, or you maybe melt some plastic. A 10-billion-dollar chip fab uses a process a village artisan would recognize — you spread stuff around and bake it. All the intelligence is external to the system; the materials don't have information. Yesterday you heard about molecular biology, which fundamentally computes to build. It's an information processing system. We've had digital revolutions in communication and computation, but precisely the same idea, precisely the same math Shannon and Von Neuman did, hasn't yet come out to the physical world. So, inspired by that, colleagues in this program — the Center for Bits and Atoms at MIT — which is a group of people, like me, who never understood the boundary between physical science and computer science. I would even go further and say computer science is one of the worst things that ever happened to either computers or to science — (Laughter) — because the canon — computer science — many of them are great but the canon of computer science prematurely froze a model of computation based on technology that was available in 1950, and nature's a much more powerful computer than that.So, you'll hear, tomorrow, from Saul Griffith. He was one of the first students to emerge from this program. We started to figure out how you can compute to fabricate. This was just a proof of principle he did of tiles that interact magnetically, where you write a code, much like protein folding, that specifies their structure. So, there's no feedback to a tool metrology; the material itself codes for its structure in just the same ways that protein are fabricated. So, you can, for example, do that. You can do other things. That's in 2D. It works in 3D. The video on the upper right — I won't show for time — shows self-replication, templating so something can make something that can make something, and we're doing that now over, maybe, nine orders of magnitude. Those ideas have been used to show the best fidelity and direct rate DNA to make an organism, in functionalizing nanoclusters with peptide tails that code for their assembly — so, much like the magnets, but now on nanometer scales. Laser micro-machining: essentially 3D printers that digitally fabricate functional systems, all the way up to building buildings, not by having blueprints, but having the parts code for the structure of the building.So, these are early examples in the lab of emerging technologies to digitize fabrication. Computers that don't control tools but computers that are tools, where the output of a program rearranges atoms as well as bits. Now, to do that — with your tax dollars, thank you — I bought all these machines. We made a modest proposal to the NSF. We wanted to be able to make anything on any length scale, all in one place, because you can't segregate digital fabrication by a discipline or a length scale. So we put together focused nano beam writers and supersonic water jet cutters and excimer micro-machining systems.But I had a problem. Once I had all these machines, I was spending too much time teaching students to use them. So I started teaching a class, modestly called, "How To Make Almost Anything." And that wasn't meant to be provocative; it was just for a few research students. But the first day of class looked like this. You know, hundreds of people came in begging, all my life I've been waiting for this class; I'll do anything to do it. Then they'd ask, can you teach it at MIT? It seems too useful? And then the next — (Laughter) — surprising thing was they weren't there to do research. They were there because they wanted to make stuff. They had no conventional technical background. At the end of a semester they integrated their skills.I'll show an old video. Kelly was a sculptor, and this is what she did with her semester project.(Video): Kelly: Hi, I'm Kelly and this is my scream buddy. Do you ever find yourself in a situation where you really have to scream, but you can't because you're at work, or you're in a classroom, or you're watching your children, or you're in any number of situations where it's just not permitted? Well, scream buddy is a portable space for screaming. When a user screams into scream buddy, their scream is silenced. It is also recorded for later release where, when and how the user chooses. (Scream) (Laughter) (Applause)So, Einstein would like this. This student made a web browser for parrots — lets parrots surf the Net and talk to other parrots. This student's made an alarm clock you wrestle to prove you're awake; this is one that defends — a dress that defends your personal space. This isn't technology for communication; it's technology to prevent it. This is a device that lets you see your music. This is a student who made a machine that makes machines, and he made it by making Lego bricks that do the computing. Just year after year — and I finally realized the students were showing the killer app of personal fabrication is products for a market of one person. You don't need this for what you can get in Wal-Mart; you need this for what makes you unique. Ken Olsen famously said, nobody needs a computer in the home. But you don't use it for inventory and payroll; DEC is now twice bankrupt. You don't need personal fabrication in the home to buy what you can buy because you can buy it. You need it for what makes you unique, just like personalization. So, with that, in turn, 20 million dollars today does this; 20 years from now we'll make Star Trek replicators that make anything. The students hijacked all the machines I bought to do personal fabrication.Today, when you spend that much of your money, there's a government requirement to do outreach, which often means classes at a local school, a website — stuff that's just not that exciting. So, I made a deal with my NSF program managers that instead of talking about it, I'd give people the tools. This wasn't meant to be provocative or important, but we put together these Fab Labs. It's about 20,000 dollars in equipment that approximate both what the 20 million dollars does and where it's going. A laser cutter to do press-fit assembly with 3D from 2D, a sign cutter to plot in copper to do electromagnetics, a micron scale, numerically-controlled milling machine for precise structures, programming tools for less than a dollar, 100-nanosecond microcontrollers. It lets you work from microns and microseconds on up, and they exploded around the world. This wasn't scheduled, but they went from inner-city Boston to Pobal in India, to Secondi-Takoradi on Ghana's coast to Soshanguve in a township in South Africa, to the far north of Norway, uncovering, or helping uncover, for all the attention to the digital divide, we would find unused computers in all these places. A farmer in a rural village — a kid needs to measure and modify the world, not just get information about it on a screen. That there's really a fabrication and an instrumentation divide bigger than the digital divide. And the way you close it is not IT for the masses but IT development for the masses.So, in place after place we saw this same progression: that we'd open one of these Fab Labs, where we didn't — this is too crazy to think of. We didn't think this up, that we would get pulled to these places; we'd open it. The first step was just empowerment. You can see it in their face, just this joy of, I can do it. This is a girl in inner-city Boston who had just done a high-tech on-demand craft sale in the inner city community center. It goes on from there to serious hands-on technical education informally, out of schools. In Ghana we had set up one of these labs. We designed a network sensor, and kids would show up and refuse to leave the lab. There was a girl who insisted we stay late at night — (Video): Kids: I love the Fab Lab. — her first night in the lab because she was going to make the sensor. So she insisted on fabbing the board, learning how to stuff it, learning how to program it. She didn't really know what she was doing or why she was doing it, but she knew she just had to do it. There was something electric about it. This is late at, you know, 11 o'clock at night and I think I was the only person surprised when what she built worked the first time. And I've shown this to engineers at big companies, and they say they can't do this. Any one thing she's doing, they can do better, but it's distributed over many people and many sites and they can't do in an afternoon what this little girl in rural Ghana is doing. And, again, that was just for the joy of it.Then these labs started doing serious problem solving — instrumentation for agriculture in India, steam turbines for energy conversion in Ghana, high-gain antennas in thin client computers. And then, in turn, businesses started to grow, like making these antennas. And finally, the lab started doing invention. We're learning more from them than we're giving them. I was showing my kids in a Fab Lab how to use it. They invented a way to do a construction kit out of a cardboard box — which, as you see up there, that's becoming a business — but their design was better than Saul's design at MIT, so there's now three students at MIT doing their theses on scaling the work of eight-year-old children because they had better designs.
