They were tens of thousands of dollars, hard to use, but they brought computing down to work groups, and everything we do today happened there. These Fab Labs are the cost and complexity of a PDP. The projection of digital fabrication isn't a projection for the future; we are now in the PDP era. We talked in hushed tones about the great discoveries then. It was very chaotic, it wasn't, sort of, clear what was going on. In the same sense we are now, today, in the minicomputer era of digital fabrication. The only problem with that is it breaks everybody's boundaries.In DC, I go to every agency that wants to talk, you know; in the Bay Area, I go to every organization you can think of — they all want to talk about it, but it breaks their organizational boundaries. In fact, it's illegal for them, in many cases, to equip ordinary people to create rather than consume technology. And that problem is so severe that the ultimate invention coming from this community surprised me: it's the social engineering. That the lab in far north of Norway — this is so far north its satellite dishes look at the ground rather than the sky because that's where the satellites are — the lab outgrew the little barn that it was in. It was there because they wanted to find animals in the mountains but it outgrew it, so they built this extraordinary village for the lab. This isn't a university; it's not a company. It's essentially a village for invention; it's a village for the outliers in society, and those have been growing up around these Fab Labs all around the world.So this program has split into an NGO foundation, a Fab Foundation to support the scaling, a micro VC fund. The person who runs it nicely describes it as "machines that make machines need businesses that make businesses:" it's a cross between micro-finance and VC to do fan-out, and then the research partnerships back at MIT for what's making it possible.So I'd like to leave you with two thoughts. There's been a sea change in aid, from top-down mega-projects to bottom-up, grassroots, micro-finance investing in the roots, so that everybody's got that that's what works. But we still look at technology as top-down mega-projects. Computing, communication, energy for the rest of the planet are these top-down mega-projects. If this room full of heroes is just clever enough, you can solve the problems. The message coming from the Fab Labs is that the other five billion people on the planet aren't just technical sinks; they're sources. The real opportunity is to harness the inventive power of the world to locally design and produce solutions to local problems. I thought that's the projection 20 years hence into the future, but it's where we are today. It breaks every organizational boundary we can think of. The hardest thing at this point is the social engineering and the organizational engineering, but it's here today.And, finally, any talk like this on the future of computing is required to show Moore's law, but my favorite version — this is Gordon Moore's original one from his original paper — and what's happened is, year after year after year, we've scaled and we've scaled and we've scaled and we've scaled, and we've scaled and we've scaled, and we've scaled and we've scaled, and there's this looming bug of what's going to happen at the end of Moore's law; this ultimate bug is coming. But we're coming to appreciate, is the transition from 2D to 3D, from programming bits to programming atoms, turns the ends of Moore's law scaling from the ultimate bug to the ultimate feature. So, we're just at the edge of this digital revolution in fabrication, where the output of computation programs the physical world. So, together, these two projects answer questions I hadn't asked carefully. The class at MIT shows the killer app for personal fabrication in the developed world is technology for a market of one: personal expression in technology that touches a passion unlike anything I've seen in technology for a very long time. And the killer app for the rest of the planet is the instrumentation and the fabrication divide: people locally developing solutions to local problems. Thank you.

At the end of a semester they integrated their skills.

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:24.958
I'll show an old video. Kelly was a sculptor, and this is what she did

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:26.958
with her semester project.

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:29.958
(Video): Kelly: Hi, I'm Kelly and this is my scream buddy.

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:34.958
Do you ever find yourself in a situation

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:39.958
where you really have to scream, but you can't because you're at work,

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:42.958
or you're in a classroom, or you're watching your children,

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:47.958
or you're in any number of situations where it's just not permitted?

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:51.958
Well, scream buddy is a portable space for screaming.

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:56.958
When a user screams into scream buddy, their scream is silenced.

00:07:56.958 --> 00:08:00.958
It is also recorded for later release where, when and how

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:01.958
the user chooses.

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:24.958
(Scream)

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:29.958
(Laughter) (Applause)

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:31.958
So, Einstein would like this.

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:32.958
This student made a web browser for parrots --

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:35.958
lets parrots surf the Net and talk to other parrots.

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:37.958
This student's made an alarm clock you wrestle

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:39.958
to prove you're awake; this is one that defends --

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:41.958
a dress that defends your personal space.

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:43.958
This isn't technology for communication;

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:45.958
it's technology to prevent it.

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:48.958
This is a device that lets you see your music.

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:51.958
This is a student who made a machine that makes machines,

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:54.958
and he made it by making Lego bricks that do the computing.

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:56.958
Just year after year -- and I finally realized

00:08:56.958 --> 00:09:00.958
the students were showing the killer app of personal fabrication

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:02.958
is products for a market of one person.

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:04.958
You don't need this for what you can get in Wal-Mart;

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:05.958
you need this for what makes you unique.

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:09.958
Ken Olsen famously said, nobody needs a computer in the home.

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:11.958
But you don't use it for inventory and payroll;

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:14.958
DEC is now twice bankrupt. You don't need personal fabrication

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:16.958
in the home to buy what you can buy because you can buy it.

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:20.958
You need it for what makes you unique, just like personalization.

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:24.958
So, with that, in turn, 20 million dollars today does this;

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:28.958
20 years from now we'll make Star Trek replicators that make anything.

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:32.958
The students hijacked all the machines I bought to do personal fabrication.

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:34.958
Today, when you spend that much of your money,

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:37.958
there's a government requirement to do outreach, which often means

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:40.958
classes at a local school, a website -- stuff that's just not that exciting.

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:44.958
So, I made a deal with my NSF program managers that

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:46.958
instead of talking about it, I'd give people the tools.

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:48.958
This wasn't meant to be provocative or important,

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:52.958
but we put together these Fab Labs. It's about 20,000 dollars in equipment

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:57.958
that approximate both what the 20 million dollars does and where it's going.

00:09:57.958 --> 00:10:00.958
A laser cutter to do press-fit assembly with 3D from 2D,

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:02.958
a sign cutter to plot in copper to do electromagnetics,

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:04.958
a micron scale,

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:06.958
numerically-controlled milling machine for precise structures,

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:09.958
programming tools for less than a dollar,

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:12.958
100-nanosecond microcontrollers. It lets you work from microns

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:16.958
and microseconds on up, and they exploded around the world.

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:18.958
This wasn't scheduled, but they went from inner-city Boston

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:22.958
to Pobal in India, to Secondi-Takoradi on Ghana's coast

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:25.958
to Soshanguve in a township in South Africa,

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:29.958
to the far north of Norway, uncovering, or helping uncover,

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:32.958
for all the attention to the digital divide,

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:36.958
we would find unused computers in all these places.

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:39.958
A farmer in a rural village -- a kid needs to measure and modify

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:43.958
the world, not just get information about it on a screen.

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:45.958
That there's really a fabrication and an instrumentation divide

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:48.958
bigger than the digital divide.

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:51.958
And the way you close it is not IT for the masses but IT development for the masses.

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:54.958
So, in place after place

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:57.958
we saw this same progression: that we'd open one of these Fab Labs,

00:10:57.958 --> 00:11:00.958
where we didn't -- this is too crazy to think of.

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:03.958
We didn't think this up, that we would get pulled to these places;

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:05.958
we'd open it. The first step was just empowerment.

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:08.958
You can see it in their face, just this joy of, I can do it.

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:10.958
This is a girl in inner-city Boston who had just done a high-tech

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:14.958
on-demand craft sale in the inner city community center.

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:18.958
It goes on from there to serious hands-on technical education

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:23.958
informally, out of schools. In Ghana we had set up one of these labs.

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:25.958
We designed a network sensor, and kids would show up

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:26.958
and refuse to leave the lab.

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:29.958
There was a girl who insisted we stay late at night --

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:31.958
(Video): Kids: I love the Fab Lab.

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:34.958
-- her first night in the lab because she was going to make the sensor.

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:37.958
So she insisted on fabbing the board, learning how to stuff it,

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:39.958
learning how to program it. She didn't really know

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:41.958
what she was doing or why she was doing it, but she knew

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:44.958
she just had to do it. There was something electric about it.

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:46.958
This is late at, you know, 11 o'clock at night

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:49.958
and I think I was the only person surprised when what she built

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:51.958
worked the first time.

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:53.958
And I've shown this to engineers at big companies, and they say

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:56.958
they can't do this. Any one thing she's doing, they can do better,

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:59.958
but it's distributed over many people and many sites

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:00.958
and they can't do in an afternoon

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:03.958
what this little girl in rural Ghana is doing.

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:23.958
(Video): Girl: My name is Valentina Kofi; I am eight years old.

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:26.958
I made a stacking board.

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:29.958
And, again, that was just for the joy of it.

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:32.958
Then these labs started doing serious problem solving --

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:34.958
instrumentation for agriculture in India,

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:36.958
steam turbines for energy conversion in Ghana,

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:40.958
high-gain antennas in thin client computers.

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:41.958
And then, in turn, businesses started to grow,

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:42.958
like making these antennas.

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:44.958
And finally, the lab started doing invention.

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:46.958
We're learning more from them than we're giving them.

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:49.958
I was showing my kids in a Fab Lab how to use it.

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:53.958
They invented a way to do a construction kit out of a cardboard box --

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:55.958
which, as you see up there, that's becoming a business --

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:58.958
but their design was better than Saul's design at MIT,

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:01.958
so there's now three students at MIT doing their theses on

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:04.958
scaling the work of eight-year-old children

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:05.958
because they had better designs.

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:08.958
Real invention is happening in these labs.

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:10.958
And I still kept -- so, in the last year I've been spending time with

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:13.958
heads of state and generals and tribal chiefs who all want this,

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:15.958
and I keep saying, but this isn't the real thing.

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:17.958
Wait, like, 20 years and then we'll be done.

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:20.958
And I finally got what's been going on. This is Kernigan and Ritchie

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:23.958
inventing UNIX on a PDP.

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:25.958
PDPs came between mainframes and minicomputers.

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:28.958
They were tens of thousands of dollars, hard to use,

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:30.958
but they brought computing down to work groups,

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:32.958
and everything we do today happened there.

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:35.958
These Fab Labs are the cost and complexity of a PDP.

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:37.958
The projection of digital fabrication

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:40.958
isn't a projection for the future; we are now in the PDP era.

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:43.958
We talked in hushed tones about the great discoveries then.

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:46.958
It was very chaotic, it wasn't, sort of, clear what was going on.

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:49.958
In the same sense we are now, today, in the minicomputer era

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:51.958
of digital fabrication.

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:55.958
The only problem with that is it breaks everybody's boundaries.

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:58.958
In DC, I go to every agency that wants to talk, you know;

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:00.958
in the Bay Area, I go to every organization you can think of --

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:02.958
they all want to talk about it, but it breaks

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:05.958
their organizational boundaries. In fact, it's illegal for them,

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:09.958
in many cases, to equip ordinary people to create

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:10.958
rather than consume technology.

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:14.958
And that problem is so severe that the ultimate invention

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:17.958
coming from this community surprised me:

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:21.958
it's the social engineering. That the lab in far north of Norway --

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:23.958
this is so far north its satellite dishes look at the ground

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:27.958
rather than the sky because that's where the satellites are --

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:28.958
the lab outgrew the little barn that it was in.

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:31.958
It was there because they wanted to find animals in the mountains

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:35.958
but it outgrew it, so they built this extraordinary village for the lab.

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:37.958
This isn't a university; it's not a company. It's essentially

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:42.958
a village for invention; it's a village for the outliers in society,

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:44.958
and those have been growing up around these Fab Labs

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:45.958
all around the world.

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:49.958
So this program has split into an NGO foundation,

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:53.958
a Fab Foundation to support the scaling, a micro VC fund.

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:54.958
The person who runs it nicely describes it as

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:58.958
"machines that make machines need businesses that make businesses:"

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:01.958
it's a cross between micro-finance and VC to do fan-out,

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:03.958
and then the research partnerships back at MIT for what's

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:06.958
making it possible.

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:08.958
So I'd like to leave you with two thoughts.

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:13.958
There's been a sea change in aid, from top-down mega-projects

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:17.958
to bottom-up, grassroots, micro-finance investing in the roots,

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:20.958
so that everybody's got that that's what works.

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:23.958
But we still look at technology as top-down mega-projects.

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:26.958
Computing, communication, energy for the rest of the planet

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:28.958
are these top-down mega-projects.

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:30.958
If this room full of heroes is just clever enough,

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:32.958
you can solve the problems.

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:34.958
The message coming from the Fab Labs is that

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:36.958
the other five billion people on the planet

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:38.958
aren't just technical sinks; they're sources.

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:41.958
The real opportunity is to harness the inventive power of the world

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:45.958
to locally design and produce solutions to local problems.

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:48.958
I thought that's the projection 20 years hence into the future,

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:50.958
but it's where we are today.

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:52.958
It breaks every organizational boundary we can think of.

00:15:52.958 --> 00:15:55.958
The hardest thing at this point is the social engineering

00:15:55.958 --> 00:15:58.958
and the organizational engineering, but it's here today.

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:00.958
And, finally, any talk like this on the future of computing

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:04.958
is required to show Moore's law, but my favorite version --

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:09.958
this is Gordon Moore's original one from his original paper --

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:11.958
and what's happened is, year after year after year,

00:16:11.958 --> 00:16:12.958
we've scaled and we've scaled and we've scaled

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:16.958
and we've scaled, and we've scaled and we've scaled,

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:17.958
and we've scaled and we've scaled,

00:16:17.958 --> 00:16:19.958
and there's this looming bug of what's going to happen

00:16:19.958 --> 00:16:23.958
at the end of Moore's law; this ultimate bug is coming.

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:28.958
But we're coming to appreciate, is the transition from 2D to 3D,

00:16:28.958 --> 00:16:31.958
from programming bits to programming atoms,

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:33.958
turns the ends of Moore's law scaling from the ultimate bug

00:16:33.958 --> 00:16:35.958
to the ultimate feature.

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:39.958
So, we're just at the edge of this digital revolution in fabrication,

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:42.958
where the output of computation programs the physical world.

00:16:42.958 --> 00:16:45.958
So, together, these two projects answer questions

00:16:45.958 --> 00:16:49.958
I hadn't asked carefully. The class at MIT shows the killer app

00:16:49.958 --> 00:16:51.958
for personal fabrication in the developed world

00:16:51.958 --> 00:16:55.958
is technology for a market of one: personal expression in technology

00:16:55.958 --> 00:16:58.958
that touches a passion unlike anything I've seen in technology

00:16:58.958 --> 00:17:00.958
for a very long time.

00:17:00.958 --> 00:17:04.958
And the killer app for the rest of the planet is the instrumentation

00:17:04.958 --> 00:17:07.958
and the fabrication divide: people locally developing solutions

00:17:07.958 --> 00:17:09.958
to local problems. Thank you.

title: In praise of slowness
transcript: What I'd like to start off with is an observation, which is that if I've learned anything over the last year, it's that the supreme irony of publishing a book about slowness is that you have to go around promoting it really fast. I seem to spend most of my time these days zipping from city to city, studio to studio, interview to interview, serving up the book in really tiny bite-size chunks. Because everyone these days wants to know how to slow down, but they want to know how to slow down really quickly. So ... so I did a spot on CNN the other day where I actually spent more time in makeup than I did talking on air. And I think that — that's not really surprising though, is it? Because that's kind of the world that we live in now, a world stuck in fast-forward.A world obsessed with speed, with doing everything faster, with cramming more and more into less and less time. Every moment of the day feels like a race against the clock. To borrow a phrase from Carrie Fisher, which is in my bio there; I'll just toss it out again — "These days even instant gratification takes too long." (Laughter) And if you think about how we to try to make things better, what do we do? No, we speed them up, don't we? So we used to dial; now we speed dial. We used to read; now we speed read. We used to walk; now we speed walk. And of course, we used to date and now we speed date. And even things that are by their very nature slow — we try and speed them up too. So I was in New York recently, and I walked past a gym that had an advertisement in the window for a new course, a new evening course. And it was for, you guessed it, speed yoga. So this — the perfect solution for time-starved professionals who want to, you know, salute the sun, but only want to give over about 20 minutes to it. I mean, these are sort of the extreme examples, and they're amusing and good to laugh at.But there's a very serious point, and I think that in the headlong dash of daily life, we often lose sight of the damage that this roadrunner form of living does to us. We're so marinated in the culture of speed that we almost fail to notice the toll it takes on every aspect of our lives — on our health, our diet, our work, our relationships, the environment and our community. And sometimes it takes a wake-up call, doesn't it, to alert us to the fact that we're hurrying through our lives, instead of actually living them; that we're living the fast life, instead of the good life. And I think for many people, that wake-up call takes the form of an illness. You know, a burnout, or eventually the body says, "I can't take it anymore," and throws in the towel. Or maybe a relationship goes up in smoke because we haven't had the time, or the patience, or the tranquility, to be with the other person, to listen to them.And my wake-up call came when I started reading bedtime stories to my son, and I found that at the end of day, I would go into his room and I just couldn't slow down — you know, I'd be speed reading "The Cat In The Hat." I'd be — you know, I'd be skipping lines here, paragraphs there, sometimes a whole page, and of course, my little boy knew the book inside out, so we would quarrel. And what should have been the most relaxing, the most intimate, the most tender moment of the day, when a dad sits down to read to his son, became instead this kind of gladiatorial battle of wills, a clash between my speed and his slowness. And this went on for some time, until I caught myself scanning a newspaper article with timesaving tips for fast people. And one of them made reference to a series of books called "The One-Minute Bedtime Story." And I wince saying those words now, but my first reaction at the time was very different. My first reflex was to say, "Hallelujah — what a great idea! This is exactly what I'm looking for to speed up bedtime even more." But thankfully, a light bulb went on over my head, and my next reaction was very different, and I took a step back, and I thought, "Whoa — you know, has it really come to this? Am I really in such a hurry that I'm prepared to fob off my son with a sound byte at the end of the day?" And I put away the newspaper — and I was getting on a plane — and I sat there, and I did something I hadn't done for a long time — which is I did nothing. I just thought, and I thought long and hard. And by the time I got off that plane, I'd decided I wanted to do something about it. I wanted to investigate this whole roadrunner culture, and what it was doing to me and to everyone else.And I had two questions in my head. The first was, how did we get so fast? And the second is, is it possible, or even desirable, to slow down? Now, if you think about how our world got so accelerated, the usual suspects rear their heads. You think of, you know, urbanization, consumerism, the workplace, technology. But I think if you cut through those forces, you get to what might be the deeper driver, the nub of the question, which is how we think about time itself. In other cultures, time is cyclical. It's seen as moving in great, unhurried circles. It's always renewing and refreshing itself. Whereas in the West, time is linear. It's a finite resource; it's always draining away. You either use it, or lose it. "Time is money," as Benjamin Franklin said. And I think what that does to us psychologically is it creates an equation. Time is scarce, so what do we do? Well — well, we speed up, don't we? We try and do more and more with less and less time. We turn every moment of every day into a race to the finish line — a finish line, incidentally, that we never reach, but a finish line nonetheless. And I guess that the question is, is it possible to break free from that mindset? And thankfully, the answer is yes, because what I discovered, when I began looking around, that there is a global backlash against this culture that tells us that faster is always better, and that busier is best.Right across the world, people are doing the unthinkable: they're slowing down, and finding that, although conventional wisdom tells you that if you slow down, you're road kill, the opposite turns out to be true: that by slowing down at the right moments, people find that they do everything better. They eat better; they make love better; they exercise better; they work better; they live better. And, in this kind of cauldron of moments and places and acts of deceleration, lie what a lot of people now refer to as the "International Slow Movement."Now if you'll permit me a small act of hypocrisy, I'll just give you a very quick overview of what's going on inside the Slow Movement. If you think of food, many of you will have heard of the Slow Food movement. Started in Italy, but has spread across the world, and now has 100,000 members in 50 countries. And it's driven by a very simple and sensible message, which is that we get more pleasure and more health from our food when we cultivate, cook and consume it at a reasonable pace. I think also the explosion of the organic farming movement, and the renaissance of farmers' markets, are other illustrations of the fact that people are desperate to get away from eating and cooking and cultivating their food on an industrial timetable. They want to get back to slower rhythms. And out of the Slow Food movement has grown something called the Slow Cities movement, which has started in Italy, but has spread right across Europe and beyond. And in this, towns begin to rethink how they organize the urban landscape, so that people are encouraged to slow down and smell the roses and connect with one another. So they might curb traffic, or put in a park bench, or some green space.And in some ways, these changes add up to more than the sum of their parts, because I think when a Slow City becomes officially a Slow City, it's kind of like a philosophical declaration. It's saying to the rest of world, and to the people in that town, that we believe that in the 21st century, slowness has a role to play. In medicine, I think a lot of people are deeply disillusioned with the kind of quick-fix mentality you find in conventional medicine. And millions of them around the world are turning to complementary and alternative forms of medicine, which tend to tap into sort of slower, gentler, more holistic forms of healing. Now, obviously the jury is out on many of these complementary therapies, and I personally doubt that the coffee enema will ever, you know, gain mainstream approval. But other treatments such as acupuncture and massage, and even just relaxation, clearly have some kind of benefit. And blue-chip medical colleges everywhere are starting to study these things to find out how they work, and what we might learn from them.Sex. There's an awful lot of fast sex around, isn't there? I was coming to — well — no pun intended there. I was making my way, let's say, slowly to Oxford, and I went through a news agent, and I saw a magazine, a men's magazine, and it said on the front, "How to bring your partner to orgasm in 30 seconds." So, you know, even sex is on a stopwatch these days. Now, you know, I like a quickie as much as the next person, but I think that there's an awful lot to be gained from slow sex — from slowing down in the bedroom. You know, you tap into that — those deeper, sort of, psychological, emotional, spiritual currents, and you get a better orgasm with the buildup. You can get more bang for your buck, let's say. I mean, the Pointer Sisters said it most eloquently, didn't they, when they sang the praises of "a lover with a slow hand." Now, we all laughed at Sting a few years ago when he went Tantric, but you fast-forward a few years, and now you find couples of all ages flocking to workshops, or maybe just on their own in their own bedrooms, finding ways to put on the brakes and have better sex. And of course, in Italy where — I mean, Italians always seem to know where to find their pleasure — they've launched an official Slow Sex movement.The workplace. Right across much of the world — North America being a notable exception — working hours have been coming down. And Europe is an example of that, and people finding that their quality of life improves as they're working less, and also that their hourly productivity goes up. Now, clearly there are problems with the 35-hour workweek in France — too much, too soon, too rigid. But other countries in Europe, notably the Nordic countries, are showing that it's possible to have a kick-ass economy without being a workaholic. And Norway, Sweden, Denmark and Finland now rank among the top six most competitive nations on Earth, and they work the kind of hours that would make the average American weep with envy. And if you go beyond sort of the country level, down at the micro-company level, more and more companies now are realizing that they need to allow their staff either to work fewer hours or just to unplug — to take a lunch break, or to go sit in a quiet room, to switch off their Blackberrys and laptops — you at the back — mobile phones, during the work day or on the weekend, so that they have time to recharge and for the brain to slide into that kind of creative mode of thought.It's not just, though, these days, adults who overwork, though, is it? It's children, too. I'm 37, and my childhood ended in the mid-'80s, and I look at kids now, and I'm just amazed by the way they race around with more homework, more tutoring, more extracurriculars than we would ever have conceived of a generation ago. And some of the most heartrending emails that I get on my website are actually from adolescents hovering on the edge of burnout, pleading with me to write to their parents, to help them slow down, to help them get off this full-throttle treadmill. But thankfully, there is a backlash there in parenting as well, and you're finding that, you know, towns in the United States are now banding together and banning extracurriculars on a particular day of the month, so that people can, you know, decompress and have some family time, and slow down.Homework is another thing. There are homework bans springing up all over the developed world in schools which had been piling on the homework for years, and now they're discovering that less can be more. So there was a case up in Scotland recently where a fee-paying, high-achieving private school banned homework for everyone under the age of 13, and the high-achieving parents freaked out and said, "What are you — you know, our kids will fall" — the headmaster said, "No, no, your children need to slow down at the end of the day." And just this last month, the exam results came in, and in math, science, marks went up 20 percent on average last year. And I think what's very revealing is that the elite universities, who are often cited as the reason that people drive their kids and hothouse them so much, are starting to notice the caliber of students coming to them is falling. These kids have wonderful marks; they have CVs jammed with extracurriculars, to the point that would make your eyes water. But they lack spark; they lack the ability to think creatively and think outside — they don't know how to dream. And so what these Ivy League schools, and Oxford and Cambridge and so on, are starting to send a message to parents and students that they need to put on the brakes a little bit. And in Harvard, for instance, they send out a letter to undergraduates — freshmen — telling them that they'll get more out of life, and more out of Harvard, if they put on the brakes, if they do less, but give time to things, the time that things need, to enjoy them, to savor them. And even if they sometimes do nothing at all. And that letter is called — very revealing, I think — "Slow Down!" — with an exclamation mark on the end.So wherever you look, the message, it seems to me, is the same: that less is very often more, that slower is very often better. But that said, of course, it's not that easy to slow down, is it? I mean, you heard that I got a speeding ticket while I was researching my book on the benefits of slowness, and that's true, but that's not all of it. I was actually en route to a dinner held by Slow Food at the time. And if that's not shaming enough, I got that ticket in Italy. And if any of you have ever driven on an Italian highway, you'll have a pretty good idea of how fast I was going.(Laughter)But why is it so hard to slow down? I think there are various reasons. One is that speed is fun, you know, speed is sexy. It's all that adrenaline rush. It's hard to give it up. I think there's a kind of metaphysical dimension — that speed becomes a way of walling ourselves off from the bigger, deeper questions. We fill our head with distraction, with busyness, so that we don't have to ask, am I well? Am I happy? Are my children growing up right? Are politicians making good decisions on my behalf? Another reason — although I think, perhaps, the most powerful reason — why we find it hard to slow down is the cultural taboo that we've erected against slowing down. "Slow" is a dirty word in our culture. It's a byword for "lazy," "slacker," for being somebody who gives up. You know, "he's a bit slow." It's actually synonymous with being stupid.I guess what the Slow Movement — the purpose of the Slow Movement, or its main goal, really, is to tackle that taboo, and to say that yes, sometimes slow is not the answer, that there is such a thing as "bad slow." You know, I got stuck on the M25, which is a ring road around London, recently, and spent three-and-a-half hours there. And I can tell you, that's really bad slow. But the new idea, the sort of revolutionary idea, of the Slow Movement, is that there is such a thing as "good slow," too. And good slow is, you know, taking the time to eat a meal with your family, with the TV switched off. Or taking the time to look at a problem from all angles in the office to make the best decision at work. Or even simply just taking the time to slow down and savor your life.Now, one of the things that I found most uplifting about all of this stuff that's happened around the book since it came out, is the reaction to it. And I knew that when my book on slowness came out, it would be welcomed by the New Age brigade, but it's also been taken up, with great gusto, by the corporate world — you know, business press, but also big companies and leadership organizations. Because people at the top of the chain, people like you, I think, are starting to realize that there's too much speed in the system, there's too much busyness, and it's time to find, or get back to that lost art of shifting gears. Another encouraging sign, I think, is that it's not just in the developed world that this idea's been taken up. In the developing world, in countries that are on the verge of making that leap into first world status — China, Brazil, Thailand, Poland, and so on — these countries have embraced the idea of the Slow Movement, many people in them, and there's a debate going on in their media, on the streets. Because I think they're looking at the West, and they're saying, "Well, we like that aspect of what you've got, but we're not so sure about that."So all of that said, is it, I guess, is it possible? That's really the main question before us today. Is it possible to slow down? And I'm happy to be able to say to you that the answer is a resounding yes. And I present myself as Exhibit A, a kind of reformed and rehabilitated speed-aholic. I still love speed. You know, I live in London, and I work as a journalist, and I enjoy the buzz and the busyness, and the adrenaline rush that comes from both of those things. I play squash and ice hockey, two very fast sports, and I wouldn't give them up for the world. But I've also, over the last year or so, got in touch with my inner tortoise.(Laughter)And what that means is that I no longer overload myself gratuitously. My default mode is no longer to be a rush-aholic. I no longer hear time's winged chariot drawing near, or at least not as much as I did before. I can actually hear it now, because I see my time is ticking off. And the upshot of all of that is that I actually feel a lot happier, healthier, more productive than I ever have. I feel like I'm living my life rather than actually just racing through it. And perhaps, the most important measure of the success of this is that I feel that my relationships are a lot deeper, richer, stronger.And for me, I guess, the litmus test for whether this would work, and what it would mean, was always going to be bedtime stories, because that's sort of where the journey began. And there too the news is rosy. You know, at the end of the day, I go into my son's room. I don't wear a watch. I switch off my computer, so I can't hear the email pinging into the basket, and I just slow down to his pace and we read. And because children have their own tempo and internal clock, they don't do quality time, where you schedule 10 minutes for them to open up to you. They need you to move at their rhythm. I find that 10 minutes into a story, you know, my son will suddenly say, "You know, something happened in the playground today that really bothered me." And we'll go off and have a conversation on that. And I now find that bedtime stories used to be a box on my to-do list, something that I dreaded, because it was so slow and I had to get through it quickly. It's become my reward at the end of the day, something I really cherish. And I have a kind of Hollywood ending to my talk this afternoon, which goes a little bit like this:a few months ago, I was getting ready to go on another book tour, and I had my bags packed. I was downstairs by the front door, and I was waiting for a taxi, and my son came down the stairs and he'd made a card for me. And he was carrying it. He'd gone and stapled two cards, very like these, together, and put a sticker of his favorite character, Tintin, on the front. And he said to me, or he handed this to me, and I read it, and it said, "To Daddy, love Benjamin." And I thought, "Aw, that's really sweet. Is that a good luck on the book tour card?" And he said, "No, no, no, Daddy — this is a card for being the best story reader in the world." And I thought, "Yeah, you know, this slowing down thing really does work."Thank you very much.
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:12.958 --> 00:00:14.958
What I'd like to start off with is an observation,

00:00:14.958 --> 00:00:16.958
which is that if I've learned anything over the last year,

00:00:16.958 --> 00:00:18.958
it's that the supreme irony

00:00:18.958 --> 00:00:20.958
of publishing a book about slowness

00:00:20.958 --> 00:00:22.958
is that you have to go around promoting it really fast.

00:00:23.958 --> 00:00:25.958
I seem to spend most of my time these days

00:00:25.958 --> 00:00:28.958
zipping from city to city, studio to studio,

00:00:28.958 --> 00:00:30.958
interview to interview,

00:00:30.958 --> 00:00:32.958
serving up the book in really tiny bite-size chunks.

00:00:32.958 --> 00:00:34.958
Because everyone these days

00:00:34.958 --> 00:00:36.958
wants to know how to slow down,

00:00:36.958 --> 00:00:39.958
but they want to know how to slow down really quickly. So ...

00:00:39.958 --> 00:00:41.958
so I did a spot on CNN the other day

00:00:41.958 --> 00:00:44.958
where I actually spent more time in makeup than I did talking on air.

00:00:45.958 --> 00:00:47.958
And I think that -- that's not really surprising though, is it?

00:00:47.958 --> 00:00:49.958
Because that's kind of the world that we live in now,

00:00:49.958 --> 00:00:52.958
a world stuck in fast-forward.

00:00:52.958 --> 00:00:54.958
A world obsessed with speed,

00:00:54.958 --> 00:00:57.958
with doing everything faster, with cramming more and more

00:00:57.958 --> 00:00:59.958
into less and less time.

00:00:59.958 --> 00:01:01.958
Every moment of the day feels like

00:01:01.958 --> 00:01:03.958
a race against the clock.

00:01:03.958 --> 00:01:05.958
To borrow a phrase from Carrie Fisher, which is

00:01:05.958 --> 00:01:07.958
in my bio there; I'll just toss it out again --

00:01:07.958 --> 00:01:10.958
"These days even instant gratification takes too long." (Laughter)

00:01:10.958 --> 00:01:12.958
And

00:01:12.958 --> 00:01:14.958
if you think about how we to try to make things better, what do we do?

00:01:14.958 --> 00:01:17.958
No, we speed them up, don't we? So we used to dial; now we speed dial.

00:01:17.958 --> 00:01:20.958
We used to read; now we speed read. We used to walk; now we speed walk.

00:01:20.958 --> 00:01:23.958
And of course, we used to date and now we speed date.

00:01:23.958 --> 00:01:26.958
And even things that are by their very nature slow --

00:01:26.958 --> 00:01:29.958
we try and speed them up too.

00:01:29.958 --> 00:01:31.958
So I was in New York recently, and I walked past a gym

00:01:31.958 --> 00:01:33.958
that had an advertisement in the window for a new course, a new evening course.

00:01:34.958 --> 00:01:37.958
And it was for, you guessed it, speed yoga.

00:01:37.958 --> 00:01:40.958
So this -- the perfect solution for time-starved professionals

00:01:40.958 --> 00:01:42.958
who want to, you know, salute the sun,

00:01:42.958 --> 00:01:44.958
but only want to give over about 20 minutes to it.

00:01:45.958 --> 00:01:47.958
I mean, these are sort of the extreme examples,

00:01:47.958 --> 00:01:49.958
and they're amusing and good to laugh at.

00:01:49.958 --> 00:01:51.958
But there's a very serious point,

00:01:51.958 --> 00:01:54.958
and I think that in the headlong dash of daily life,

00:01:54.958 --> 00:01:57.958
we often lose sight of the damage

00:01:57.958 --> 00:02:00.958
that this roadrunner form of living does to us.

00:02:00.958 --> 00:02:03.958
We're so marinated in the culture of speed

00:02:03.958 --> 00:02:05.958
that we almost fail to notice the toll it takes

00:02:05.958 --> 00:02:07.958
on every aspect of our lives --

00:02:07.958 --> 00:02:09.958
on our health, our diet, our work,

00:02:09.958 --> 00:02:12.958
our relationships, the environment and our community.

00:02:12.958 --> 00:02:14.958
And sometimes it takes

00:02:14.958 --> 00:02:16.958
a wake-up call, doesn't it,

00:02:16.958 --> 00:02:19.958
to alert us to the fact that we're hurrying through our lives,

00:02:19.958 --> 00:02:21.958
instead of actually living them; that we're

00:02:21.958 --> 00:02:23.958
living the fast life, instead of the good life.

00:02:23.958 --> 00:02:25.958
And I think for many people, that wake-up call

00:02:25.958 --> 00:02:27.958
takes the form of an illness.

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:30.958
You know, a burnout, or eventually the body says,

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:32.958
"I can't take it anymore," and throws in the towel.

00:02:32.958 --> 00:02:34.958
Or maybe a relationship goes up in smoke

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:36.958
because we haven't had the time, or the patience,

00:02:36.958 --> 00:02:38.958
or the tranquility,

00:02:38.958 --> 00:02:40.958
to be with the other person, to listen to them.

00:02:40.958 --> 00:02:42.958
And my wake-up call came when I started

00:02:42.958 --> 00:02:45.958
reading bedtime stories to my son,

00:02:45.958 --> 00:02:47.958
and I found that at the end of day,

00:02:47.958 --> 00:02:50.958
I would go into his room and I just couldn't slow down -- you know,

00:02:50.958 --> 00:02:52.958
I'd be speed reading "The Cat In The Hat."

00:02:52.958 --> 00:02:54.958
I'd be -- you know, I'd be skipping lines here,

00:02:54.958 --> 00:02:56.958
paragraphs there, sometimes a whole page,

00:02:56.958 --> 00:02:59.958
and of course, my little boy knew the book inside out, so we would quarrel.

00:02:59.958 --> 00:03:02.958
And what should have been the most relaxing, the most intimate,

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:04.958
the most tender moment of the day,

00:03:04.958 --> 00:03:07.958
when a dad sits down to read to his son,

00:03:07.958 --> 00:03:10.958
became instead this kind of gladiatorial battle of wills,

00:03:10.958 --> 00:03:12.958
a clash between my speed

00:03:12.958 --> 00:03:15.958
and his slowness.

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:17.958
And this went on for some time,

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:19.958
until I caught myself scanning a newspaper article

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:21.958
with timesaving tips for fast people.

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:23.958
And one of them made reference to a series of books called

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:25.958
"The One-Minute Bedtime Story."

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:28.958
And I wince saying those words now,

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:30.958
but my first reaction at the time was very different.

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:32.958
My first reflex was to say,

00:03:32.958 --> 00:03:34.958
"Hallelujah -- what a great idea!

00:03:34.958 --> 00:03:37.958
This is exactly what I'm looking for to speed up bedtime even more."

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:39.958
But thankfully,

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:41.958
a light bulb went on over my head, and my next reaction was very different,

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:44.958
and I took a step back, and I thought,

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:46.958
"Whoa -- you know, has it really come to this?

00:03:46.958 --> 00:03:48.958
Am I really in such a hurry that I'm prepared

00:03:48.958 --> 00:03:51.958
to fob off my son with a sound byte at the end of the day?"

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:54.958
And I put away the newspaper --

00:03:54.958 --> 00:03:56.958
and I was getting on a plane -- and I sat there,

00:03:56.958 --> 00:03:58.958
and I did something I hadn't done for a long time -- which is I did nothing.

00:03:58.958 --> 00:04:01.958
I just thought, and I thought long and hard.

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:04.958
And by the time I got off that plane, I'd decided I wanted to do something about it.

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:07.958
I wanted to investigate this whole roadrunner culture,

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:10.958
and what it was doing to me and to everyone else.

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:12.958
And I had two questions in my head.

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:15.958
The first was, how did we get so fast?

00:04:15.958 --> 00:04:17.958
And the second is, is it possible,

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:20.958
or even desirable, to slow down?

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:22.958
Now, if you think about

00:04:22.958 --> 00:04:25.958
how our world got so accelerated, the usual suspects rear their heads.

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:27.958
You think of, you know, urbanization,

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:30.958
consumerism, the workplace, technology.

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:32.958
But I think if you cut through

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:35.958
those forces, you get to what might be the deeper

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:38.958
driver, the nub of the question,

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:40.958
which is how we think about time itself.

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:43.958
In other cultures, time is cyclical.

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:46.958
It's seen as moving in great,

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:48.958
unhurried circles.

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:50.958
It's always renewing and refreshing itself.

00:04:50.958 --> 00:04:52.958
Whereas in the West, time is linear.

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:54.958
It's a finite resource;

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:56.958
it's always draining away.

00:04:56.958 --> 00:04:58.958
You either use it, or lose it.

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:01.958
"Time is money," as Benjamin Franklin said.

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:03.958
And I think what that does to us psychologically

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:05.958
is it creates an equation.

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:07.958
Time is scarce, so what do we do?

00:05:07.958 --> 00:05:09.958
Well -- well, we speed up, don't we?

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:11.958
We try and do more and more with less and less time.

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:13.958
We turn every moment of every day

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:15.958
into a race to the finish line --

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:18.958
a finish line, incidentally, that we never reach,

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:20.958
but a finish line nonetheless.

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:22.958
And I guess that the question is,

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:24.958
is it possible to break free from that mindset?

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:26.958
And thankfully, the answer is yes, because

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:28.958
what I discovered, when I began looking around, that there is

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:31.958
a global backlash against this culture that

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:34.958
tells us that faster is always better, and that busier is best.

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:37.958
Right across the world, people are doing the unthinkable:

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:39.958
they're slowing down, and finding that,

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:42.958
although conventional wisdom tells you that if you slow down, you're road kill,

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:44.958
the opposite turns out to be true:

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:46.958
that by slowing down at the right moments,

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:48.958
people find that they do everything better.

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:51.958
They eat better; they make love better; they exercise better;

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:54.958
they work better; they live better.

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:57.958
And, in this kind of cauldron

00:05:57.958 --> 00:06:00.958
of moments and places and acts of deceleration,

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:03.958
lie what a lot of people now refer to as

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:05.958
the "International Slow Movement."

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:08.958
Now if you'll permit me a small act of hypocrisy,

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:13.958
I'll just give you a very quick overview of

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:16.958
what's going on inside the Slow Movement. If you think of food,

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:18.958
many of you will have heard of the Slow Food movement.

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:20.958
Started in Italy, but has spread across the world,

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:22.958
and now has 100,000 members

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:24.958
in 50 countries.

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:27.958
And it's driven by a very simple and sensible message,

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:30.958
which is that we get more pleasure and more health

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:32.958
from our food when we

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:36.958
cultivate, cook and consume it at a reasonable pace.

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:38.958
I think also the explosion of

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:41.958
the organic farming movement, and the renaissance of farmers' markets,

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:44.958
are other illustrations

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:47.958
of the fact that people are desperate to get away from

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:49.958
eating and cooking and cultivating their food

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:51.958
on an industrial timetable.

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:54.958
They want to get back to slower rhythms.

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:57.958
And out of the Slow Food movement has grown something

00:06:57.958 --> 00:07:00.958
called the Slow Cities movement, which has started in Italy,

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:02.958
but has spread right across Europe and beyond.

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:04.958
And in this, towns

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:07.958
begin to rethink how they organize the urban landscape,

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:10.958
so that people are encouraged to slow down

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:12.958
and smell the roses and connect with one another.

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:14.958
So they might curb traffic,

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:17.958
or put in a park bench, or some green space.

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:20.958
And in some ways, these changes add up to more than the sum of their parts,

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:23.958
because I think when a Slow City becomes officially a Slow City,

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:25.958
it's kind of like a philosophical declaration.

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:28.958
It's saying to the rest of world, and to the people in that town,

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:30.958
that we believe that in the 21st century,

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:34.958

slowness has a role to play.

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:36.958
In medicine, I think a lot of people are deeply disillusioned

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:38.958
with the kind of quick-fix mentality

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:40.958
you find in conventional medicine.

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:42.958
And millions of them around the world are turning

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:45.958
to complementary and alternative forms of medicine,

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:47.958
which tend to tap into sort of

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:50.958
slower, gentler, more holistic forms of healing.

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:53.958
Now, obviously the jury is out on many of these complementary therapies,

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:56.958
and I personally doubt that the coffee enema

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:59.958
will ever, you know, gain mainstream approval.

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:01.958
But other treatments

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:04.958
such as acupuncture and massage, and even just relaxation,

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:06.958
clearly have some kind of benefit.

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:08.958
And blue-chip medical colleges everywhere

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:11.958
are starting to study these things to find out how they work,

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:13.958
and what we might learn from them.

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:15.958
Sex. There's an awful lot of fast sex around, isn't there?

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:18.958
I was coming to --

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:21.958
well -- no pun intended there.

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:24.958
I was making my way, let's say, slowly to Oxford,

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:26.958
and I went through a news agent, and I saw a magazine,

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:28.958
a men's magazine, and it said on the front,

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:31.958
"How to bring your partner to orgasm in 30 seconds."

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:33.958
So, you know, even sex

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:35.958
is on a stopwatch these days.

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:37.958
Now, you know,

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:39.958
I like a quickie as much as the next person,

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:42.958
but I think that there's an awful lot to be gained

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:44.958
from slow sex -- from slowing down in the bedroom.

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:47.958
You know, you tap into that -- those deeper,

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:50.958
sort of, psychological, emotional, spiritual currents,

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:53.958
and you get a better orgasm with the buildup.

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:55.958
You can get more bang for your buck, let's say.

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:58.958
I mean, the Pointer Sisters said it most eloquently, didn't they,

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:01.958
when they sang the praises of "a lover with a slow hand."

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:03.958
Now, we all laughed at Sting

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:05.958
a few years ago when he went Tantric,

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:08.958
but you fast-forward a few years, and now you find couples of all ages

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:10.958
flocking to workshops, or maybe just

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:13.958
on their own in their own bedrooms, finding ways

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:16.958
to put on the brakes and have better sex.

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:18.958
And of course, in Italy where -- I mean, Italians always seem to know

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:20.958
where to find their pleasure --

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:23.958
they've launched an official Slow Sex movement.

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:26.958
The workplace.

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:28.958
Right across much of the world --

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:30.958
North America being a notable exception --

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:32.958
working hours have been coming down.

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:34.958
And Europe is an example of that,

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:37.958
and people finding that their quality of life improves

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:39.958
as they're working less, and also

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:41.958
that their hourly productivity goes up.

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:43.958
Now, clearly there are problems with

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:45.958
the 35-hour workweek in France --

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:47.958
too much, too soon, too rigid.

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:50.958
But other countries in Europe, notably the Nordic countries,

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:52.958
are showing that it's possible

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:54.958
to have a kick-ass economy

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:56.958
without being a workaholic.

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:58.958
And Norway, Sweden,

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:00.958
Denmark and Finland now rank

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:03.958
among the top six most competitive nations on Earth,

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:05.958
and they work the kind of hours that would make the average American

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:07.958
weep with envy.

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:10.958
And if you go beyond sort of the country level,

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:12.958
down at the micro-company level,

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:13.958
more and more companies now are realizing

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:15.958
that they need to allow their staff

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:17.958
either to work fewer hours or just to unplug --

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:20.958
to take a lunch break, or to go sit in a quiet room,

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:24.958
to switch off their Blackberrys and laptops -- you at the back --

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:27.958
mobile phones,

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:30.958
during the work day or on the weekend, so that they have time to recharge

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:32.958
and for the brain to slide into that

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:35.958
kind of creative mode of thought.

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:39.958
It's not just, though, these days,

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:41.958
adults who overwork, though, is it? It's children, too.

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:45.958
I'm 37, and my childhood ended in the mid-'80s,

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:47.958
and I look at kids now, and I'm just amazed by the way they

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:49.958
race around with more homework,

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:51.958
more tutoring, more extracurriculars

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:54.958
than we would ever have conceived of a generation ago.

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:56.958
And some of the most heartrending emails

00:10:56.958 --> 00:10:58.958
that I get on my website

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:01.958
are actually from adolescents

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:03.958
hovering on the edge of burnout, pleading with me

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:05.958
to write to their parents,

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:08.958
to help them slow down, to help them get off this

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:11.958
full-throttle treadmill.

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:13.958
But thankfully, there is a backlash there in parenting as well,

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:15.958
and you're finding that, you know, towns in the United States

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:18.958
are now banding together and banning extracurriculars

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:20.958
on a particular day of the month, so that people can,

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:23.958
you know, decompress and have some family time, and slow down.

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:27.958
Homework is another thing. There are homework bans

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:30.958
springing up all over the developed world

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:33.958
in schools which had been piling on the homework for years,

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:35.958
and now they're discovering that less can be more.

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:37.958
So there was a case up in Scotland recently

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:39.958
where a fee-paying, high-achieving private school

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:41.958
banned homework

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:43.958
for everyone under the age of 13,

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:45.958
and the high-achieving parents freaked out and said,

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:47.958
"What are you -- you know, our kids will fall" -- the headmaster said,

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:50.958
"No, no, your children need to slow down at the end of the day."

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:53.958
And just this last month, the exam results came in,

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:56.958
and in math, science, marks went up 20 percent

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:58.958
on average last year.

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:00.958
And I think what's very revealing is that

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:03.958
the elite universities, who are often cited as the reason

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:05.958
that people drive their kids and hothouse them so much,

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:08.958
are starting to notice the caliber of students

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:11.958
coming to them is falling. These kids have wonderful marks;

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:14.958
they have CVs jammed with extracurriculars,

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:16.958
to the point that would make your eyes water.

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:18.958
But they lack spark; they lack

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:20.958
the ability to think creatively and think outside --

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:23.958
they don't know how to dream. And so what these Ivy League schools,

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:25.958
and Oxford and Cambridge and so on, are starting to send a message

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:28.958
to parents and students that they need to put on the brakes a little bit.

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:31.958
And in Harvard, for instance, they send out

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:34.958
a letter to undergraduates -- freshmen --

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:37.958
telling them that they'll get more out of life, and more out of Harvard,

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:39.958
if they put on the brakes, if they do less,

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:42.958
but give time to things, the time that things need,

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:44.958
to enjoy them, to savor them.

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:46.958
And even if they sometimes do nothing at all.

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:48.958
And that letter is called -- very revealing, I think --

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:51.958
"Slow Down!" -- with an exclamation mark on the end.

00:12:51.958 --> 00:12:54.958
So wherever you look, the message, it seems to me, is the same:

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:56.958
that less is very often more,

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:59.958
that slower is very often

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:01.958
better. But that said, of course,

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:03.958
it's not that easy to slow down, is it?

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:05.958
I mean, you heard that I got a speeding ticket

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:07.958
while I was researching my book on the benefits of slowness,

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:09.958
and that's true, but that's not all of it.

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:11.958
I was actually en route to a dinner

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:13.958
held by Slow Food at the time.

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:16.958
And if that's not shaming enough, I got that ticket in Italy.

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:19.958
And if any of you have ever driven on an Italian highway,

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:21.958
you'll have a pretty good idea of how fast I was going.

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:24.958
(Laughter)

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:26.958
But why is it so hard to slow down?

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:28.958
I think there are various reasons.

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:31.958
One is that speed is fun, you know, speed is sexy.

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:34.958
It's all that adrenaline rush. It's hard to give it up.

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:36.958
I think there's a kind of metaphysical dimension --

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:38.958
that speed becomes a way of walling ourselves off

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:40.958
from the bigger, deeper questions.

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:42.958
We fill our head with distraction, with busyness,

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:44.958
so that we don't have to ask,

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:47.958
am I well? Am I happy? Are my children growing up right?

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:50.958
Are politicians making good decisions on my behalf?

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:53.958
Another reason -- although I think, perhaps, the most powerful reason --

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:56.958
why we find it hard to slow down is the cultural taboo

00:13:56.958 --> 00:13:59.958
that we've erected against slowing down.

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:01.958
"Slow" is a dirty word in our culture.

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:03.958
It's a byword for "lazy," "slacker,"

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:05.958
for being somebody who gives up.

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:07.958
You know, "he's a bit slow." It's actually synonymous

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:10.958
with being stupid.

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:12.958
I guess what the Slow Movement -- the purpose of the Slow Movement,

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:14.958
or its main goal, really, is to tackle that taboo,

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:17.958
and to say that yes,

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:19.958
sometimes slow is not the answer,

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:21.958
that there is such a thing as "bad slow."

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:23.958
You know, I got stuck on the M25,

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:25.958
which is a ring road around London, recently,

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:27.958
and spent three-and-a-half hours there. And I can tell you,

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:29.958
that's really bad slow.

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:31.958
But the new idea,

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:33.958
the sort of revolutionary idea, of the Slow Movement,

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:35.958
is that there is such a thing as "good slow," too.

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:37.958
And good slow is, you know, taking the time

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:40.958
to eat a meal with your family, with the TV switched off.

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:43.958
Or taking the time to look at a problem from all angles

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:45.958
in the office to make the best decision

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:47.958
at work.

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:49.958
Or even simply just taking the time

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:51.958
to slow down

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:53.958
and savor your life.

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:56.958
Now, one of the things that I found most uplifting

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:59.958
about all of this stuff that's happened around the book

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:02.958
since it came out, is the reaction to it.

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:04.958
And I knew that when my book on slowness came out,

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:06.958
it would be welcomed by the New Age brigade,

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:09.958
but it's also been taken up, with great gusto,

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:11.958
by the corporate world -- you know,

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:13.958
business press, but also

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:15.958
big companies and leadership organizations.

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:18.958
Because people at the top of the chain, people like you, I think,

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:20.958
are starting to realize that there's too much

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:22.958
speed in the system,

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:25.958
there's too much busyness, and it's time to find,

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:29.958
or get back to that lost art of shifting gears.

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:31.958
Another encouraging sign, I think,

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:33.958
is that it's not just in the developed world

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:36.958
that this idea's been taken up. In the developing world,

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:38.958
in countries that are on the verge of making that leap

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:40.958
into first world status -- China, Brazil,

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:42.958
Thailand, Poland, and so on --

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:45.958
these countries have embraced the idea of the Slow Movement,

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:48.958
many people in them, and there's a debate going on

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:50.958
in their media, on the streets.

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:52.958
Because I think they're looking at the West, and they're saying,

00:15:52.958 --> 00:15:55.958
"Well, we like that aspect of what you've got,

00:15:55.958 --> 00:15:57.958
but we're not so sure about that."

00:15:57.958 --> 00:15:59.958
So all of that said, is it,

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:02.958
I guess, is it possible?

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:05.958
That's really the main question before us today. Is it possible

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:07.958
to slow down? And

00:16:07.958 --> 00:16:09.958
I'm happy to be able to say to you

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:11.958
that the answer is a resounding yes.

00:16:11.958 --> 00:16:14.958
And I present myself as Exhibit A,

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:17.958
a kind of reformed and rehabilitated

00:16:17.958 --> 00:16:19.958
speed-aholic.

00:16:19.958 --> 00:16:21.958
I still love speed. You know, I live in London,

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:23.958
and I work as a journalist,

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:25.958
and I enjoy the buzz and the busyness,

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:27.958
and the adrenaline rush that comes from both of those things.

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:29.958
I play squash and ice hockey,

00:16:29.958 --> 00:16:32.958
two very fast sports, and I wouldn't give them up for the world.

00:16:33.958 --> 00:16:36.958
But I've also, over the last year or so,

00:16:36.958 --> 00:16:38.958
got in touch with my inner tortoise.

00:16:38.958 --> 00:16:39.958
(Laughter)

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:41.958
And what that means is that

00:16:41.958 --> 00:16:44.958
I no longer

00:16:44.958 --> 00:16:47.958
overload myself gratuitously.

00:16:47.958 --> 00:16:50.958
My default mode is no longer

00:16:50.958 --> 00:16:52.958
to be a rush-aholic.

00:16:53.958 --> 00:16:55.958
I no longer hear

00:16:55.958 --> 00:16:57.958
time's winged chariot drawing near,

00:16:57.958 --> 00:16:59.958
or at least not as much as I did before.

00:16:59.958 --> 00:17:02.958
I can actually hear it now, because I see my time is ticking off.

00:17:03.958 --> 00:17:05.958
And the upshot of all of that is that

00:17:05.958 --> 00:17:08.958
I actually feel a lot happier, healthier,

00:17:08.958 --> 00:17:11.958
more productive than I ever have.

00:17:11.958 --> 00:17:13.958
I feel like I'm living

00:17:13.958 --> 00:17:16.958
my life rather than actually just racing through it.

00:17:17.958 --> 00:17:19.958
And perhaps, the most important

00:17:19.958 --> 00:17:21.958
measure of the success of this

00:17:21.958 --> 00:17:24.958
is that I feel that my relationships are a lot deeper,

00:17:24.958 --> 00:17:26.958
richer, stronger.

00:17:26.958 --> 00:17:29.958
And for me, I guess, the litmus test

00:17:29.958 --> 00:17:31.958
for whether this would work, and what it would mean,

00:17:31.958 --> 00:17:34.958
was always going to be bedtime stories, because that's sort of where

00:17:34.958 --> 00:17:37.958
the journey began. And there too the news is

00:17:37.958 --> 00:17:39.958
rosy. You know,

00:17:39.958 --> 00:17:41.958
at the end of the day, I go into my son's room.

00:17:41.958 --> 00:17:43.958
I don't wear a watch. I switch off my computer,

00:17:43.958 --> 00:17:45.958
so I can't hear the email pinging into the basket,

00:17:45.958 --> 00:17:48.958
and I just slow down to his pace and we read.

00:17:49.958 --> 00:17:52.958
And because children have their own tempo and internal clock,

00:17:52.958 --> 00:17:54.958
they don't do quality time,

00:17:54.958 --> 00:17:56.958
where you schedule 10 minutes for them to open up to you.

00:17:56.958 --> 00:17:59.958
They need you to move at their rhythm.

00:17:59.958 --> 00:18:01.958
I find that 10 minutes into a story, you know,

00:18:01.958 --> 00:18:03.958
my son will suddenly say, "You know,

00:18:03.958 --> 00:18:05.958
something happened in the playground today that really bothered me."

00:18:05.958 --> 00:18:08.958
And we'll go off and have a conversation on that.

00:18:08.958 --> 00:18:11.958
And I now find that bedtime stories

00:18:11.958 --> 00:18:13.958
used to be

00:18:13.958 --> 00:18:16.958
a box on my to-do list, something that I dreaded,

00:18:16.958 --> 00:18:18.958
because it was so slow and I had to get through it quickly.

00:18:18.958 --> 00:18:20.958
It's become my reward at the end of the day,

00:18:20.958 --> 00:18:22.958
something I really cherish.

00:18:22.958 --> 00:18:24.958
And I have a kind of Hollywood ending

00:18:24.958 --> 00:18:26.958
to my talk this afternoon,

00:18:26.958 --> 00:18:28.958
which goes a little bit like this:

00:18:28.958 --> 00:18:31.958
a few months ago, I was getting ready to go on

00:18:31.958 --> 00:18:34.958
another book tour, and I had my bags packed.

00:18:34.958 --> 00:18:37.958
I was downstairs by the front door, and I was waiting for a taxi,

00:18:37.958 --> 00:18:39.958
and my son came down the stairs and

00:18:39.958 --> 00:18:41.958
he'd made a card for me. And he was carrying it.

00:18:41.958 --> 00:18:43.958
He'd gone and stapled two cards, very like these, together,

00:18:43.958 --> 00:18:46.958
and put a sticker of his favorite

00:18:46.958 --> 00:18:48.958
character, Tintin, on the front.
