title: My wish: Rebuilding Rwanda
transcript: I thought in getting up to my TED wish I would try to begin by putting in  perspective what I try to do and how it fits with what they try to do. We live in a world that everyone knows is interdependent, but insufficient in three major ways. It is, first of all, profoundly unequal: half the world's people still living on less than two dollars a day; a billion people with no access to clean water; two and a half billion no access to sanitation; a billion going to bed hungry every night; one in four deaths every year from AIDS, TB, malaria and the variety of infections associated with dirty water — 80 percent of them under five years of age.Even in wealthy countries it is common now to see inequality growing. In the United States, since 2001 we've had five years of economic growth, five years of productivity growth in the workplace, but median wages are stagnant and the percentage of working families dropping below the poverty line is up by four percent. The percentage of working families without health care up by four percent. So this interdependent world which has been pretty good to most of us — which is why we're all here in Northern California doing what we do for a living, enjoying this evening — is profoundly unequal. It is also unstable. Unstable because of the threats of terror, weapons of mass destruction, the spread of global disease and a sense that we are vulnerable to it in a way that we weren't not so many years ago. And perhaps most important of all, it is unsustainable because of climate change, resource depletion and species destruction.When I think about the world I would like to leave to my daughter and the grandchildren I hope to have, it is a world that moves away from unequal, unstable, unsustainable interdependence to integrated communities — locally, nationally and globally — that share the characteristics of all successful communities: a broadly shared, accessible set of opportunities, a shared sense of responsibility for the success of the common enterprise and a genuine sense of belonging. All easier said than done. When the terrorist incidents occurred in the United Kingdom a couple of years ago, I think even though they didn't claim as many lives as we lost in the United States on 9/11, I think the thing that troubled the British most was that the perpetrators were not invaders, but homegrown citizens whose religious and political identities were more important to them than the people they grew up with, went to school with, worked with, shared weekends with, shared meals with. In other words, they thought their differences were more important than their common humanity. It is the central psychological plague of humankind in the 21st century.Into this mix, people like us, who are not in public office, have more power to do good than at any time in history, because more than half the world's people live under governments they voted in and can vote out. And even non-democratic governments are more sensitive to public opinion. Because primarily of the power of the Internet, people of modest means can band together and amass vast sums of money that can change the world for some public good if they all agree. When the tsunami hit South Asia, the United States contributed 1.2 billion dollars. 30 percent of our households gave. Half of them gave over the Internet. The median contribution was somewhere around 57 dollars. And thirdly, because of the rise of non-governmental organizations. They, businesses, other citizens' groups, have enormous power to affect the lives of our fellow human beings. When I became president in 1993, there were none of these organizations in Russia. There are now a couple of hundred thousand. None in India. There are now at least a half a million active. None in China. There are now 250,000 registered with the government, probably twice again that many who are not registered for political reasons.When I organized my foundation, and I thought about the world as it is and the world that I hope to leave to the next generation, and I tried to be realistic about what I had cared about all my life that I could still have an impact on. I wanted to focus on activities that would help to alleviate poverty, fight disease, combat climate change, bridge the religious, racial and other divides that torment the world, but to do it in a way that would either use whatever particular skills we could put together in our group to change the way some public good function was performed so that it would sweep across the world more.You saw one reference to that in what we were able to do with AIDS drugs. And I want to say that the head of our AIDS effort, and the person who also is primarily active in the wish I'll make tonight, Ira Magaziner, is here with me and I want to thank him for everything he's done. He's over there. (Applause) When I got out of office and was asked to work, first in the Caribbean, to try to help deal with the AIDS crisis, generic drugs were available for about 500 dollars a person a year. If you bought them in vast bulks, you could get them at a little under 400 dollars. The first country we went to work in, the Bahamas, was paying 3,500 dollars for these drugs. The market was so terribly disorganized that they were buying this medicine through two agents who were gigging them sevenfold. So the very first week we were working, we got the price down to 500 dollars. And all of a sudden, they could save seven times as many lives for the same amount of money.Then we went to work with the manufacturers of AIDS medicines, one of whom was cited in the film, and negotiated a whole different change in business strategy, because even at 500 dollars, these drugs were being sold on a high-margin, low-volume, uncertain-payment basis. So we worked on improving the productivity of the operations and the supply chain, and went to a low-margin, high-volume, absolutely certain-payment business. I joked that the main contribution we made to the battle against AIDS was to get the manufacturers to change from a jewelry store to a grocery store strategy. But the price went to 140 dollars from 500. And pretty soon, the average price was 192 dollars. Now we can get it for about 100 dollars. Children's medicine was 600 dollars, because nobody could afford to buy any of it. We negotiated it down to 190. Then, the French imposed their brilliantly conceived airline tax to create a something called UNITAID, got a bunch of other countries to help. That children's medicine is now 60 dollars a person a year.The only thing that is keeping us from basically saving the lives of everybody who needs the medicine to stay alive are the absence of systems necessary to diagnose, treat and care for people and deliver this medicine. We started a childhood obesity initiative with the Heart Association in America. We tried to do the same thing by negotiating industry-right deals with the soft drink and the snack food industry to cut the caloric and other dangerous content of food going to our children in the schools. We just reorganized the markets. And it occurred to me that in this whole non-governmental world, somebody needs to be thinking about organizing public goods markets. And that is now what we're trying to do, and working with this large cities group to fight climate change, to negotiate huge, big, volume deals that will enable cities which generate 75 percent of the world's greenhouse gases, to drastically and quickly reduce greenhouse gas emissions in a way that is good economics. And this whole discussion as if it's some sort of economic burden, is a mystery to me. I think it's a bird's nest on the ground.When Al Gore won his well-deserved Oscar for the "Inconvenient Truth" movie, I was thrilled, but I had urged him to make a second movie quickly. For those of you who saw "An Inconvenient Truth," the most important slide in the Gore lecture is the last one, which shows here's where greenhouse gases are going if we don't do anything, here's where they could go. And then there are six different categories of things we can do to change the trajectory. We need a movie on those six categories. And all of you need to have it embedded in your brains and to organize yourselves around it. So we're trying to do that.So organizing these markets is one thing we try to do. Now we have taken on a second thing, and this gets to my wish. It has been my experience in working in developing countries that while the headlines may all be — the pessimistic headlines may say, well, we can't do this, that or the other thing because of corruption — I think incapacity is a far bigger problem in poor countries than corruption, and feeds corruption. We now have the money, given these low prices, to distribute AIDS drugs all over the world to people we cannot presently reach. Today these low prices are available in the 25 countries where we work, and in a total of 62 countries, and about 550,000 people are getting the benefits of them. But the money is there to reach others. The systems are not there to reach the people.So what we have been trying to do, working first in Rwanda and then in Malawi and other places — but I want to talk about Rwanda tonight — is to develop a model for rural health care in a very poor area that can be used to deal with AIDS, TB, malaria, other infectious diseases, maternal and child health, and a whole range of health issues poor people are grappling with in the developing world, that can first be scaled for the whole nation of Rwanda, and then will be a model that could literally be implemented in any other poor country in the world.And the test is: one, will it do the job? Will it provide high quality care? And two, will it do it at a price that will enable the country to sustain a health care system without foreign donors after five to 10 years? Because the longer I deal with these problems, the more convinced I am that we have to — whether it's economics, health, education, whatever — we have to build systems. And the absence of systems that function break the connection which got you all in this seat tonight. You think about whatever your life has been, however many obstacles you have faced in your life, at critical junctures you always knew there was a predictable connection between the effort you exerted and the result you achieved. In a world with no systems, with chaos, everything becomes a guerilla struggle, and this predictability is not there. And it becomes almost impossible to save lives, educate kids, develop economies, whatever.The person, in my view, who has done the best job of this in the health care area, of building a system in a very poor area, is Dr. Paul Farmer, who, many of you know, has worked for now 20 years with his group, Partners in Health, primarily in Haiti where he started, but they've also worked in Russia, in Peru and other places around the world. As poor as Haiti is, in the area where Farmer's clinic is active — and they serve a catchment area far greater than the medical professionals they have would indicate they could serve — since 1988, they have not lost one person to tuberculosis, not one. And they've achieved a lot of other amazing health results. So when we decided to work in Rwanda on trying to dramatically increase the income of the country and fight the AIDS problem, we wanted to build a healthcare network, because it had been totally destroyed during the genocide in 1994, and the per capita income was still under a dollar a day. So I rang up, asked Paul Farmer if he would help. Because it seemed to me if we could prove there was a model in Haiti and a model in Rwanda that we could then take all over the country, number one, it would be a wonderful thing for a country that has suffered as much as any on Earth in the last 15 years, and number two, we would have something that could then be adapted to any other poor country anywhere in the world. And so we have set about doing that.Now, we started working together 18 months ago. And we're working in an area called Southern Kayonza, which is one of the poorest areas in Rwanda, with a group that originally includes about 400,000 people. We're essentially implementing what Paul Farmer did in Haiti: he develops and trains paid community health workers who are able to identify health problems, ensure that people who have AIDS or TB are properly diagnosed and take their medicine regularly, who work on bringing about health education, clean water and sanitation, providing nutritional supplements and moving people up the chain of health care if they have problems of the severity that require it. The procedures that make this work have been perfected, as I said, by Paul Farmer and his team in their work in rural Haiti over the last 20 years. Recently we did an evaluation of the first 18 months of our efforts in Rwanda. And the results were so good that the Rwandan government has now agreed to adopt the model for the entire country, and has strongly supported and put the full resources of the government behind it.I'll tell you a little bit about our team because it's indicative of what we do. We have about 500 people around the world working in our AIDS program, some of them for nothing — just for transportation, room and board. And then we have others working in these other related programs. Our business plan in Rwanda was put together under the leadership of Diana Noble, who is an unusually gifted woman, but not unusual in the type of people who have been willing to do this kind of work. She was the youngest partner at Schroder Ventures in London in her 20s. She was CEO of a successful e-venture — she started and built Reed Elsevier Ventures — and at 45 she decided she wanted to do something different with her life. So she now works full-time on this for very little pay. She and her team of former business people have created a business plan that will enable us to scale this health system up for the whole country. And it would be worthy of the kind of private equity work she used to do when she was making a lot more money for it.When we came to this rural area, 45 percent of the children under the age of five had stunted growth due to malnutrition. 23 percent of them died before they reached the age of five. Mortality at birth was over two-and-a-half percent. Over 15 percent of the deaths among adults and children occurred because of intestinal parasites and diarrhea from dirty water and inadequate sanitation — all entirely preventable and treatable. Over 13 percent of the deaths were from respiratory illnesses — again, all preventable and treatable. And not a single soul in this area was being treated for AIDS or tuberculosis.Within the first 18 months, the following things happened: we went from zero to about 2,000 people being treated for AIDS. That's 80 percent of the people who need treatment in this area. Listen to this: less than four-tenths of one percent of those being treated stopped taking their medicine or otherwise defaulted on treatment. That's lower than the figure in the United States. Less than three-tenths of one percent had to transfer to the more expensive second-line drugs. 400,000 pregnant women were brought into counseling and will give birth for the first time within an organized healthcare system. That's about 43 percent of all the pregnancies. About 40 percent of all the people — I said 400,000. I meant 40,000. About 40 percent of all the people who need TB treatment are now getting it — in just 18 months, up from zero when we started. 43 percent of the children in need of an infant feeding program to prevent malnutrition and early death are now getting the food supplements they need to stay alive and to grow.We've started the first malaria treatment programs they've ever had there. Patients admitted to a hospital that was destroyed during the genocide that we have renovated along with four other clinics, complete with solar power generators, good lab technology. We now are treating 325 people a month, despite the fact that almost 100 percent of the AIDS patients are now treated at home. And the most important thing is because we've implemented Paul Farmer's model, using community health workers, we estimate that this system could be put into place for all of Rwanda for between five and six percent of GDP, and that the government could sustain that without depending on foreign aid after five or six years. And for those of you who understand healthcare economics you know that all wealthy countries spend between nine and 11 percent of GDP on health care, except for the United States, we spend 16 — but that's a story for another day. (Laughter)We're now working with Partners in Health and the Ministry of Health in Rwanda and our Foundation folks to scale this system up. We're also beginning to do this in Malawi and Lesotho. And we have similar projects in Tanzania, Mozambique, Kenya and Ethiopia with other partners trying to achieve the same thing: to save as many lives as quickly as we can, but to do it in a systematic way that can be implemented nationwide and then with a model that can be implemented in any country in the world. We need initial upfront investment to train doctors, nurses, health administration and community health workers throughout the country, to set up the information technology, the solar energy, the water and sanitation, the transportation infrastructure. But over a five- to 10-year period, we will take down the need for outside assistance and eventually it will be phased out.My wish is that TED assist us in our work and help us to build a high-quality rural health system in a poor country, Rwanda, that can be a model for Africa, and indeed, for any poor country anywhere in the world. My belief is that this will help us to build a more integrated world with more partners and fewer terrorists, with more productive citizens and fewer haters, a place we'd all want our kids and our grandchildren to grow up in. It has been an honor for me, particularly, to work in Rwanda where we also have a major economic development project in partnership with Sir Tom Hunter, the Scottish philanthropist, where last year we, using the same thing with AIDS drugs, cut the cost of fertilizer and the interest rates on microcredit loans by 30 percent and achieved three- to four-hundred percent increases in crop yields with the farmers.These people have been through a lot and none of us, most of all me, helped them when they were on the verge of destroying each other. We're undoing that now, and they are so over it and so into their future. We're doing this in an environmentally responsible way. I'm doing my best to convince them not to run the electric grid to the 35 percent of the people that have no access, but to do it with clean energy. To have responsible reforestation projects, the Rwandans, interestingly enough, have been quite good, Mr. Wilson, in preserving their topsoil. There's a couple of guys from southern farming families — the first thing I did when I went out to this place was to get down on my hands and knees and dig in the dirt and see what they'd done with it.We have a chance here to prove that a country that almost slaughtered itself out of existence can practice reconciliation, reorganize itself, focus on tomorrow and provide comprehensive, quality health care with minimal outside help. I am grateful for this prize, and I will use it to that end. We could use some more help to do this, but think of what it would mean if we could have a world-class health system in Rwanda — in a country with a less-than-one-dollar-a-day-per-capita income, one that could save hundreds of millions of lives over the next decade if applied to every similarly situated country on Earth. It's worth a try and I believe it would succeed. Thank you and God bless you. (Applause)

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:49.958

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:51.958
because nobody could afford to buy any of it.

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:54.958
We negotiated it down to 190.

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:58.958
Then, the French imposed their brilliantly conceived airline tax

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:00.958
to create a something called UNITAID,

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:02.958
got a bunch of other countries to help.

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:05.958
That children's medicine is now 60 dollars a person a year.

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:10.958
The only thing that is keeping us from basically saving the lives

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:12.958
of everybody who needs the medicine to stay alive

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:15.958
are the absence of systems necessary to diagnose, treat and care

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:19.958
for people and deliver this medicine.

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:23.958
We started a childhood obesity initiative with the Heart Association in America.

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:26.958
We tried to do the same thing by negotiating industry-right deals

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:31.958
with the soft drink and the snack food industry to cut the caloric

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:35.958
and other dangerous content of food going to our children in the schools.

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:38.958
We just reorganized the markets.

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:43.958
And it occurred to me that in this whole non-governmental world,

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:48.958
somebody needs to be thinking about organizing public goods markets.

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:50.958
And that is now what we're trying to do,

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:53.958
and working with this large cities group to fight climate change,

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:58.958
to negotiate huge, big, volume deals that will enable cities

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:01.958
which generate 75 percent of the world's greenhouse gases,

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:04.958
to drastically and quickly reduce greenhouse gas emissions

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:07.958
in a way that is good economics.

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:12.958
And this whole discussion as if it's some sort of economic burden,

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:13.958
is a mystery to me.

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:15.958
I think it's a bird's nest on the ground.

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:19.958
When Al Gore won his well-deserved Oscar

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:23.958
for the "Inconvenient Truth" movie, I was thrilled,

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:27.958
but I had urged him to make a second movie quickly.

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:31.958
For those of you who saw "An Inconvenient Truth,"

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:36.958
the most important slide in the Gore lecture is the last one,

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:39.958
which shows here's where greenhouse gases are going

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:41.958
if we don't do anything, here's where they could go.

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:43.958
And then there are six different categories

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:45.958
of things we can do to change the trajectory.

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:48.958
We need a movie on those six categories.

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:51.958
And all of you need to have it embedded in your brains

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:54.958
and to organize yourselves around it.

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:56.958
So we're trying to do that.

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:59.958
So organizing these markets is one thing we try to do.

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:03.958
Now we have taken on a second thing, and this gets to my wish.

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:07.958
It has been my experience in working in developing countries

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:12.958
that while the headlines may all be -- the pessimistic headlines may say,

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:16.958
well, we can't do this, that or the other thing because of corruption --

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:22.958
I think incapacity is a far bigger problem in poor countries than corruption,

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:25.958
and feeds corruption.

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:29.958
We now have the money, given these low prices, to distribute

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:34.958
AIDS drugs all over the world to people we cannot presently reach.

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:40.958
Today these low prices are available in the 25 countries where we work,

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:42.958
and in a total of 62 countries,

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:46.958
and about 550,000 people are getting the benefits of them.

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:49.958
But the money is there to reach others.

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:52.958
The systems are not there to reach the people.

00:10:52.958 --> 00:11:00.958
So what we have been trying to do,

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:06.958
working first in Rwanda and then in Malawi and other places --

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:08.958
but I want to talk about Rwanda tonight --

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:16.958
is to develop a model for rural health care in a very poor area

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:20.958
that can be used to deal with AIDS, TB, malaria, other infectious diseases,

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:23.958
maternal and child health, and a whole range of health issues

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:26.958
poor people are grappling with in the developing world,

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:30.958
that can first be scaled for the whole nation of Rwanda,

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:32.958
and then will be a model that could literally

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:34.958
be implemented in any other poor country in the world.

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:36.958
And the test is: one, will it do the job?

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:39.958
Will it provide high quality care?

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:41.958
And two, will it do it at a price

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:45.958
that will enable the country to sustain a health care system

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:49.958
without foreign donors after five to 10 years?

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:53.958
Because the longer I deal with these problems,

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:55.958
the more convinced I am that we have to --

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:58.958
whether it's economics, health, education, whatever --

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:00.958
we have to build systems.

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:03.958
And the absence of systems that function

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:07.958
break the connection which got you all in this seat tonight.

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:09.958
You think about whatever your life has been,

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:12.958
however many obstacles you have faced in your life,

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:15.958
at critical junctures you always knew

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:19.958
there was a predictable connection between the effort you exerted

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:21.958
and the result you achieved.

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:26.958
In a world with no systems, with chaos,

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:29.958
everything becomes a guerilla struggle,

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:32.958
and this predictability is not there.

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:35.958
And it becomes almost impossible to save lives,

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:38.958
educate kids, develop economies, whatever.

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:41.958
The person, in my view,

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:46.958
who has done the best job of this in the health care area,

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:50.958
of building a system in a very poor area, is Dr. Paul Farmer,

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:55.958
who, many of you know, has worked for now 20 years with his group,

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:59.958
Partners in Health, primarily in Haiti where he started,

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:01.958
but they've also worked in Russia, in Peru

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:03.958
and other places around the world.

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:08.958
As poor as Haiti is, in the area where Farmer's clinic is active --

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:10.958
and they serve a catchment area far greater

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:14.958
than the medical professionals they have would indicate they could serve --

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:21.958
since 1988, they have not lost one person to tuberculosis, not one.

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:26.958
And they've achieved a lot of other amazing health results.

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:30.958
So when we decided to work in Rwanda

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:35.958
on trying to dramatically increase the income of the country and fight the AIDS problem,

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:37.958
we wanted to build a healthcare network,

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:41.958
because it had been totally destroyed during the genocide in 1994,

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:44.958
and the per capita income was still under a dollar a day.

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:49.958
So I rang up, asked Paul Farmer if he would help.

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:53.958
Because it seemed to me if we could prove there was a model in Haiti

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:57.958
and a model in Rwanda that we could then take all over the country,

00:13:57.958 --> 00:13:59.958
number one, it would be a wonderful thing for a country

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:03.958
that has suffered as much as any on Earth in the last 15 years,

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:07.958
and number two, we would have something that could then be adapted

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:10.958
to any other poor country anywhere in the world.

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:15.958
And so we have set about doing that.

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:19.958
Now, we started working together 18 months ago.

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:23.958
And we're working in an area called Southern Kayonza,

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:27.958
which is one of the poorest areas in Rwanda,

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:33.958
with a group that originally includes about 400,000 people.

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:38.958
We're essentially implementing what Paul Farmer did in Haiti:

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:43.958
he develops and trains paid community health workers

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:47.958
who are able to identify health problems,

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:51.958
ensure that people who have AIDS or TB are properly diagnosed

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:53.958
and take their medicine regularly,

00:14:53.958 --> 00:15:00.958
who work on bringing about health education, clean water and sanitation,

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:05.958
providing nutritional supplements and moving people up the chain of health care

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:09.958
if they have problems of the severity that require it.

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:14.958
The procedures that make this work have been perfected,

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:17.958
as I said, by Paul Farmer and his team

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:20.958
in their work in rural Haiti over the last 20 years.

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:26.958
Recently we did an evaluation of the first 18 months of our efforts in Rwanda.

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:31.958
And the results were so good that the Rwandan government

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:34.958
has now agreed to adopt the model for the entire country,

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:39.958
and has strongly supported and put the full resources of the government behind it.

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:44.958
I'll tell you a little bit about our team because it's indicative of what we do.

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:47.958
We have about 500 people around the world

00:15:47.958 --> 00:15:51.958
working in our AIDS program, some of them for nothing --

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:53.958
just for transportation, room and board.

00:15:53.958 --> 00:15:57.958
And then we have others working in these other related programs.

00:15:57.958 --> 00:15:59.958
Our business plan in Rwanda

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:02.958
was put together under the leadership of Diana Noble,

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:05.958
who is an unusually gifted woman,

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:10.958
but not unusual in the type of people who have been willing to do this kind of work.

00:16:10.958 --> 00:16:15.958
She was the youngest partner at Schroder Ventures in London in her 20s.

00:16:15.958 --> 00:16:17.958
She was CEO of a successful e-venture --

00:16:17.958 --> 00:16:21.958
she started and built Reed Elsevier Ventures --

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:24.958
and at 45 she decided she wanted to do something different with her life.

00:16:24.958 --> 00:16:28.958
So she now works full-time on this for very little pay.

00:16:28.958 --> 00:16:32.958
She and her team of former business people have created a business plan

00:16:32.958 --> 00:16:36.958
that will enable us to scale this health system up for the whole country.

00:16:36.958 --> 00:16:41.958
And it would be worthy of the kind of private equity work

00:16:41.958 --> 00:16:45.958
she used to do when she was making a lot more money for it.

00:16:45.958 --> 00:16:50.958
When we came to this rural area, 45 percent of the children under the age of five

00:16:50.958 --> 00:16:55.958
had stunted growth due to malnutrition.

00:16:55.958 --> 00:17:01.958
23 percent of them died before they reached the age of five.

00:17:03.958 --> 00:17:06.958
Mortality at birth was over two-and-a-half percent.

00:17:06.958 --> 00:17:10.958
Over 15 percent of the deaths among adults and children occurred

00:17:10.958 --> 00:17:15.958
because of intestinal parasites and diarrhea from dirty water and inadequate sanitation --

00:17:15.958 --> 00:17:18.958
all entirely preventable and treatable.

00:17:18.958 --> 00:17:22.958
Over 13 percent of the deaths were from respiratory illnesses --

00:17:22.958 --> 00:17:25.958
again, all preventable and treatable.

00:17:25.958 --> 00:17:30.958
And not a single soul in this area was being treated for AIDS or tuberculosis.

00:17:31.958 --> 00:17:35.958
Within the first 18 months, the following things happened:

00:17:35.958 --> 00:17:39.958
we went from zero to about 2,000 people being treated for AIDS.

00:17:39.958 --> 00:17:43.958
That's 80 percent of the people who need treatment in this area.

00:17:43.958 --> 00:17:48.958
Listen to this: less than four-tenths of one percent of those being treated

00:17:48.958 --> 00:17:52.958
stopped taking their medicine or otherwise defaulted on treatment.

00:17:52.958 --> 00:17:55.958
That's lower than the figure in the United States.

00:17:55.958 --> 00:17:57.958
Less than three-tenths of one percent

00:17:57.958 --> 00:18:02.958
had to transfer to the more expensive second-line drugs.

00:18:02.958 --> 00:18:06.958
400,000 pregnant women were brought into counseling

00:18:06.958 --> 00:18:11.958
and will give birth for the first time within an organized healthcare system.

00:18:11.958 --> 00:18:16.958
That's about 43 percent of all the pregnancies.

00:18:16.958 --> 00:18:20.958
About 40 percent of all the people -- I said 400,000. I meant 40,000.

00:18:20.958 --> 00:18:24.958
About 40 percent of all the people who need TB treatment are now getting it --

00:18:24.958 --> 00:18:28.958
in just 18 months, up from zero when we started.

00:18:28.958 --> 00:18:31.958
43 percent of the children in need of an infant feeding program

00:18:31.958 --> 00:18:33.958
to prevent malnutrition and early death

00:18:33.958 --> 00:18:36.958
are now getting the food supplements they need to stay alive and to grow.

00:18:36.958 --> 00:18:40.958
We've started the first malaria treatment programs they've ever had there.

00:18:40.958 --> 00:18:45.958
Patients admitted to a hospital that was destroyed during the genocide

00:18:45.958 --> 00:18:50.958
that we have renovated along with four other clinics,

00:18:50.958 --> 00:18:55.958
complete with solar power generators, good lab technology.

00:18:55.958 --> 00:19:00.958
We now are treating 325 people a month,

00:19:00.958 --> 00:19:05.958
despite the fact that almost 100 percent of the AIDS patients are now treated at home.

00:19:06.958 --> 00:19:09.958
And the most important thing is

00:19:09.958 --> 00:19:14.958
because we've implemented Paul Farmer's model, using community health workers,

00:19:14.958 --> 00:19:20.958
we estimate that this system could be put into place for all of Rwanda

00:19:20.958 --> 00:19:24.958
for between five and six percent of GDP,

00:19:24.958 --> 00:19:28.958
and that the government could sustain that

00:19:28.958 --> 00:19:33.958
without depending on foreign aid after five or six years.

00:19:34.958 --> 00:19:36.958
And for those of you who understand healthcare economics

00:19:36.958 --> 00:19:41.958
you know that all wealthy countries spend between nine and 11 percent of GDP

00:19:41.958 --> 00:19:43.958
on health care, except for the United States, we spend 16 --

00:19:43.958 --> 00:19:45.958
but that's a story for another day.

00:19:46.958 --> 00:19:47.958
(Laughter)

00:19:48.958 --> 00:19:53.958
We're now working with Partners in Health and the Ministry of Health in Rwanda

00:19:53.958 --> 00:19:57.958
and our Foundation folks to scale this system up.

00:19:57.958 --> 00:20:03.958
We're also beginning to do this in Malawi and Lesotho.

00:20:03.958 --> 00:20:07.958
And we have similar projects in Tanzania, Mozambique,

00:20:07.958 --> 00:20:12.958
Kenya and Ethiopia with other partners trying to achieve the same thing:

00:20:12.958 --> 00:20:14.958
to save as many lives as quickly as we can,

00:20:14.958 --> 00:20:17.958
but to do it in a systematic way that can be implemented nationwide

00:20:17.958 --> 00:20:21.958
and then with a model that can be implemented in any country in the world.

00:20:21.958 --> 00:20:25.958
We need initial upfront investment to train doctors, nurses,

00:20:25.958 --> 00:20:28.958
health administration and community health workers throughout the country,

00:20:28.958 --> 00:20:31.958
to set up the information technology, the solar energy,

00:20:31.958 --> 00:20:34.958
the water and sanitation, the transportation infrastructure.

00:20:34.958 --> 00:20:37.958
But over a five- to 10-year period,

00:20:37.958 --> 00:20:39.958
we will take down the need for outside assistance

00:20:39.958 --> 00:20:41.958
and eventually it will be phased out.

00:20:42.958 --> 00:20:50.958
My wish is that TED assist us in our work and help us to build

00:20:50.958 --> 00:20:54.958
a high-quality rural health system in a poor country, Rwanda,

00:20:54.958 --> 00:20:56.958
that can be a model for Africa,

00:20:56.958 --> 00:21:01.958
and indeed, for any poor country anywhere in the world.

00:21:01.958 --> 00:21:07.958
My belief is that this will help us to build a more integrated world

00:21:07.958 --> 00:21:10.958
with more partners and fewer terrorists,

00:21:10.958 --> 00:21:13.958
with more productive citizens and fewer haters,

00:21:13.958 --> 00:21:18.958
a place we'd all want our kids and our grandchildren to grow up in.

00:21:19.958 --> 00:21:25.958
It has been an honor for me, particularly, to work in Rwanda

00:21:25.958 --> 00:21:28.958
where we also have a major economic development project

00:21:28.958 --> 00:21:33.958
in partnership with Sir Tom Hunter, the Scottish philanthropist,

00:21:33.958 --> 00:21:36.958
where last year we, using the same thing with AIDS drugs,

00:21:36.958 --> 00:21:42.958
cut the cost of fertilizer and the interest rates on microcredit loans by 30 percent

00:21:42.958 --> 00:21:46.958
and achieved three- to four-hundred percent increases

00:21:46.958 --> 00:21:48.958
in crop yields with the farmers.

00:21:48.958 --> 00:21:54.958
These people have been through a lot and none of us, most of all me,

00:21:54.958 --> 00:21:57.958
helped them when they were on the verge of destroying each other.

00:21:58.958 --> 00:22:04.958
We're undoing that now, and they are so over it and so into their future.

00:22:04.958 --> 00:22:08.958
We're doing this in an environmentally responsible way.

00:22:08.958 --> 00:22:12.958
I'm doing my best to convince them not to run the electric grid

00:22:12.958 --> 00:22:15.958
to the 35 percent of the people that have no access,

00:22:15.958 --> 00:22:20.958
but to do it with clean energy. To have responsible reforestation projects,

00:22:20.958 --> 00:22:24.958
the Rwandans, interestingly enough, have been quite good, Mr. Wilson,

00:22:24.958 --> 00:22:26.958
in preserving their topsoil.

00:22:26.958 --> 00:22:30.958
There's a couple of guys from southern farming families --

00:22:30.958 --> 00:22:32.958
the first thing I did when I went out to this place

00:22:32.958 --> 00:22:34.958
was to get down on my hands and knees and dig in the dirt

00:22:34.958 --> 00:22:36.958
and see what they'd done with it.

00:22:36.958 --> 00:22:40.958
We have a chance here to prove that a country

00:22:40.958 --> 00:22:45.958
that almost slaughtered itself out of existence

00:22:46.958 --> 00:22:53.958
can practice reconciliation, reorganize itself, focus on tomorrow

00:22:53.958 --> 00:23:00.958
and provide comprehensive, quality health care with minimal outside help.

00:23:00.958 --> 00:23:06.958
I am grateful for this prize, and I will use it to that end.

00:23:06.958 --> 00:23:10.958
We could use some more help to do this,

00:23:10.958 --> 00:23:14.958
but think of what it would mean if we could have a world-class health system

00:23:14.958 --> 00:23:19.958
in Rwanda -- in a country with a less-than-one-dollar-a-day-per-capita income,

00:23:19.958 --> 00:23:23.958
one that could save hundreds of millions of lives

00:23:23.958 --> 00:23:30.958
over the next decade if applied to every similarly situated country on Earth.

00:23:30.958 --> 00:23:34.958
It's worth a try and I believe it would succeed.

00:23:34.958 --> 00:23:37.958
Thank you and God bless you.

00:23:37.958 --> 00:23:49.958
(Applause)

title: My wish: Build the Encyclopedia of Life
transcript: I have all my life wondered what "mind-boggling" meant. After two days here, I declare myself boggled, and enormously impressed, and feel that you are one of the great hopes — not just for American achievement in science and technology, but for the whole world. I've come, however, on a special mission on behalf of my constituency, which are the 10-to-the-18th-power — that's a million trillion — insects and other small creatures, and to make a plea for them. If we were to wipe out insects alone, just that group alone, on this planet — which we are trying hard to do — the rest of life and humanity with it would mostly disappear from the land. And within a few months. Now, how did I come to this particular position of advocacy?As a little boy, and through my teenage years, I became increasingly fascinated by the diversity of life. I had a butterfly period, a snake period, a bird period, a fish period, a cave period and finally and definitively, an ant period. By my college years, I was a devoted myrmecologist, a specialist on the biology of ants, but my attention and research continued to make journeys across the great variety of life on Earth in general — including all that it means to us as a species, how little we understand it and how pressing a danger that our activities have created for it.Out of that broader study has emerged a concern and an ambition, crystallized in the wish that I'm about to make to you. My choice is the culmination of a lifetime commitment that began with growing up on the Gulf Coast of Alabama, on the Florida peninsula. As far back as I can remember, I was enchanted by the natural beauty of that region and the almost tropical exuberance of the plants and animals that grow there. One day when I was only seven years old and fishing, I pulled a "pinfish," they're called, with sharp dorsal spines, up too hard and fast, and I blinded myself in one eye. I later discovered I was also hard of hearing, possibly congenitally, in the upper registers. So in planning to be a professional naturalist — I never considered anything else in my entire life — I found that I was lousy at bird watching and couldn't track frog calls either. So I turned to the teeming small creatures that can be held between the thumb and forefinger: the little things that compose the foundation of our ecosystems, the little things, as I like to say, who run the world. Consider the nematode roundworm, the most abundant of all animals. Four out of five animals on Earth are nematode worms — if all solid materials except nematode worms were to be eliminated, you could still see the ghostly outline of most of it in nematode worms. Already what were thought to be bacteria for generations have been found to compose, instead, two great domains of microorganisms: true bacteria and one-celled organisms the archaea, which are closer than other bacteria to the eukaryota, the group that we belong to.Some serious biologists, and I count myself among them, have begun to wonder that among the enormous and still unknown diversity of microorganisms, one might — just might — find aliens among them. 00:18:27.958 --> 00:18:31.958
Sadly, our knowledge of biodiversity is so incomplete

00:18:31.958 --> 00:18:36.958
that we are at risk of losing a great deal of it before it is even discovered.

00:18:36.958 --> 00:18:45.958
For example, even in the United States, the 200,000 species known currently

00:18:45.958 --> 00:18:52.958
actually has been found to be only partial in coverage;

00:18:52.958 --> 00:18:57.958
it is mostly unknown to us in basic biology.

00:18:57.958 --> 00:19:04.958
Only about 15 percent of the known species have been studied well enough to evaluate their status.

00:19:04.958 --> 00:19:10.958
Of the 15 percent evaluated, 20 percent are classified as "in peril,"

00:19:10.958 --> 00:19:12.958
that is, in danger of extinction.

00:19:12.958 --> 00:19:14.958
That's in the United States.

00:19:14.958 --> 00:19:21.958
We are, in short, flying blind into our environmental future.

00:19:21.958 --> 00:19:23.958
We urgently need to change this.

00:19:23.958 --> 00:19:27.958
We need to have the biosphere properly explored

00:19:27.958 --> 00:19:31.958
so that we can understand and competently manage it.

00:19:31.958 --> 00:19:35.958
We need to settle down before we wreck the planet.

00:19:35.958 --> 00:19:36.958
And we need that knowledge.

00:19:36.958 --> 00:19:41.958
This should be a big science project equivalent to the Human Genome Project.

00:19:41.958 --> 00:19:46.958
It should be thought of as a biological moonshot with a timetable.

00:19:46.958 --> 00:19:50.958
So this brings me to my wish for TEDsters,

00:19:50.958 --> 00:19:53.958
and to anyone else around the world who hears this talk.

00:19:53.958 --> 00:19:59.958
I wish we will work together to help create the key tools

00:19:59.958 --> 00:20:03.958
that we need to inspire preservation of Earth's biodiversity.

00:20:03.958 --> 00:20:07.958
And let us call it the "Encyclopedia of Life."

00:20:07.958 --> 00:20:11.958
What is the "Encyclopedia of Life?" A concept that has already taken hold

00:20:11.958 --> 00:20:15.958
and is beginning to spread and be looked at seriously?

00:20:15.958 --> 00:20:18.958
It is an encyclopedia that lives on the Internet

00:20:18.958 --> 00:20:23.958
and is contributed to by thousands of scientists around the world.

00:20:23.958 --> 00:20:26.958
Amateurs can do it also.

00:20:26.958 --> 00:20:31.958
It has an indefinitely expandable page for each species.

00:20:31.958 --> 00:20:37.958
It makes all key information about life on Earth accessible to anyone,

00:20:37.958 --> 00:20:39.958
on demand, anywhere in the world.

00:20:39.958 --> 00:20:43.958
I've written about this idea before,

00:20:43.958 --> 00:20:50.958
and I know there are people in this room who have expended significant effort on it in the past.

00:20:50.958 --> 00:20:58.958
But what excites me is that since I first put forward this particular idea in that form,

00:20:58.958 --> 00:21:00.958
science has advanced.

00:21:00.958 --> 00:21:03.958
Technology has moved forward.

00:21:03.958 --> 00:21:07.958
Today, the practicalities of making such an encyclopedia,

00:21:07.958 --> 00:21:13.958
regardless of the magnitude of the information put into it, are within reach.

00:21:13.958 --> 00:21:17.958
Indeed, in the past year, a group of influential scientific institutions

00:21:17.958 --> 00:21:21.958
have begun mobilizing to realize this dream.

00:21:21.958 --> 00:21:24.958
I wish you would help them.

00:21:24.958 --> 00:21:27.958
Working together, we can make this real.

00:21:28.958 --> 00:21:33.958
The encyclopedia will quickly pay for itself in practical applications.

00:21:33.958 --> 00:21:39.958
It will address transcendent qualities in the human consciousness, and sense of human need.

00:21:39.958 --> 00:21:45.958
It will transform the science of biology in ways of obvious benefit to humanity.

00:21:45.958 --> 00:21:50.958
And most of all, it can inspire a new generation of biologists

00:21:50.958 --> 00:21:55.958
to continue the quest that started, for me personally, 60 years ago:

00:21:55.958 --> 00:22:00.958
to search for life, to understand it and finally, above all, to preserve it.

00:22:00.958 --> 00:22:02.958
That is my wish. Thank you.

title: My wish: Let my photographs bear witness
transcript: As someone who has spent his entire career trying to be invisiblestanding in front of an audience is a cross between an out-of-body experience and a deer caught in the headlights, so please forgive me for violating one of the TED commandments by relying on words on paper, and I only hope I'm not struck by lightning bolts before I'm done. I'd like to begin by talking about some of the ideas that motivated me to become a documentary photographer.I was a student in the '60s, a time of social upheaval and questioning, and on a personal level, an awakening sense of idealism. The war in Vietnam was raging; the Civil Rights Movement was under way; and pictures had a powerful influence on me. Our political and military leaders were telling us one thing, and photographers were telling us another. I believed the photographers, and so did millions of other Americans. Their images fueled resistance to the war and to racism. They not only recorded history; they helped change the course of history. Their pictures became part of our collective consciousness and, as consciousness evolved into a shared sense of conscience, change became not only possible, but inevitable.I saw that the free flow of information represented by journalism, specifically visual journalism, can bring into focus both the benefits and the cost of political policies. It can give credit to sound decision-making, adding momentum to success. In the face of poor political judgment or political inaction, it becomes a kind of intervention, assessing the damage and asking us to reassess our behavior. It puts a human face on issues which from afar can appear abstract or ideological or monumental in their global impact. What happens at ground level, far from the halls of power, happens to ordinary citizens one by one.And I understood that documentary photography has the ability to interpret events from their point of view. It gives a voice to those who otherwise would not have a voice. And as a reaction, it stimulates public opinion and gives impetus to public debate, thereby preventing the interested parties from totally controlling the agenda, much as they would like to. Coming of age in those days made real the concept that the free flow of information is absolutely vital for a free and dynamic society to function properly. The press is certainly a business, and in order to survive it must be a successful business, but the right balance must be found between marketing considerations and journalistic responsibility.Society's problems can't be solved until they're identified. On a higher plane, the press is a service industry, and the service it provides is awareness. Every story does not have to sell something. There's also a time to give. That was a tradition I wanted to follow. Seeing the war created such incredibly high stakes for everyone involved and that visual journalism could actually become a factor in conflict resolution — I wanted to be a photographer in order to be a war photographer. But I was driven by an inherent sense that a picture that revealed the true face of war would almost by definition be an anti-war photograph.I'd like to take you on a visual journey through some of the events and issues I've been involved in over the past 25 years. In 1981, I went to Northern Ireland. 10 IRA prisoners were in the process of starving themselves to death in protest against conditions in jail. The reaction on the streets was violent confrontation. I saw that the front lines of contemporary wars are not on isolated battlefields, but right where people live. During the early '80s, I spent a lot of time in Central America, which was engulfed by civil wars that straddled the ideological divide of the Cold War.In Guatemala, the central government — controlled by a oligarchy of European decent — was waging a scorched Earth campaign against an indigenous rebellion, and I saw an image that reflected the history of Latin America: conquest through a combination of the Bible and the sword. An anti-Sandinista guerrilla was mortally wounded as Commander Zero attacked a town in Southern Nicaragua. A destroyed tank belonging to Somoza's national guard was left as a monument in a park in Managua, and was transformed by the energy and spirit of a child. At the same time, a civil war was taking place in El Salvador, and again, the civilian population was caught up in the conflict.I've been covering the Palestinian-Israeli conflict since 1981. This is a moment from the beginning of the second intifada, in 2000, when it was still stones and Molotovs against an army. In 2001, the uprising escalated into an armed conflict, and one of the major incidents was the destruction of the Palestinian refugee camp in the West Bank town of Jenin. Without the political will to find common ground, the continual friction of tactic and counter-tactic only creates suspicion and hatred and vengeance, and perpetuates the cycle of violence.In the '90s, after the breakup of the Soviet Union, Yugoslavia fractured along ethnic fault lines, and civil war broke out between Bosnia, Croatia and Serbia. This is a scene of house-to-house fighting in Mostar, neighbor against neighbor. A bedroom, the place where people share intimacy, where life itself is conceived, became a battlefield. A mosque in northern Bosnia was destroyed by Serbian artillery and was used as a makeshift morgue. Dead Serbian soldiers were collected after a battle and used as barter for the return of prisoners or Bosnian soldiers killed in action. This was once a park. The Bosnian soldier who guided me told me that all of his friends were there now.At the same time in South Africa, after Nelson Mandela had been released from prison, the black population commenced the final phase of liberation from apartheid. One of the things I had to learn as a journalist was what to do with my anger. I had to use it, channel its energy, turn it into something that would clarify my vision, instead of clouding it. In Transkei, I witnessed a rite of passage into manhood, of the Xhosa tribe. Teenage boys lived in isolation, their bodies covered with white clay. After several weeks, they washed off the white and took on the full responsibilities of men. It was a very old ritual that seemed symbolic of the political struggle that was changing the face of South Africa.Children in Soweto playing on a trampoline. Elsewhere in Africa there was famine. In Somalia, the central government collapsed and clan warfare broke out. Farmers were driven off their land, and crops and livestock were destroyed or stolen. Starvation was being used as a weapon of mass destruction — primitive but extremely effective. Hundreds of thousands of people were exterminated, slowly and painfully. The international community responded with massive humanitarian relief, and hundreds of thousands of more lives were saved. American troops were sent to protect the relief shipments, but they were eventually drawn into the conflict, and after the tragic battle in Mogadishu, they were withdrawn. In southern Sudan, another civil war saw similar use of starvation as a means of genocide.Again, international NGOs, united under the umbrella of the U.N., staged a massive relief operation and thousands of lives were saved. I'm a witness, and I want my testimony to be honest and uncensored. I also want it to be powerful and eloquent, and to do as much justice as possible to the experience of the people I'm photographing. This man was in an NGO feeding center, being helped as much as he could be helped. He literally had nothing. He was a virtual skeleton, yet he could still summon the courage and the will to move. He had not given up, and if he didn't give up, how could anyone in the outside world ever dream of losing hope? In 1994, after three months of covering the South African election, I saw the inauguration of Nelson Mandela, and it was the most uplifting thing I've ever seen. It exemplified the best that humanity has to offer. The next day I left for Rwanda, and it was like taking the express elevator to hell.This man had just been liberated from a Hutu death camp. He allowed me to photograph him for quite a long time, and he even turned his face toward the light, as if he wanted me to see him better. I think he knew what the scars on his face would say to the rest of the world. This time, maybe confused or discouraged by the military disaster in Somalia, the international community remained silent, and somewhere around 800,000 people were slaughtered by their own countrymen — sometimes their own neighbors — using farm implements as weapons.Perhaps because a lesson had been learned by the weak response to the war in Bosnia and the failure in Rwanda, when Serbia attacked Kosovo, international action was taken much more decisively. NATO forces went in, and the Serbian army withdrew. Ethnic Albanians had been murdered, their farms destroyed and a huge number of people forcibly deported. They were received in refugee camps set up by NGOs in Albania and Macedonia. The imprint of a man who had been burned inside his own home. The image reminded me of a cave painting, and echoed how primitive we still are in so many ways.Between 1995 and '96, I covered the first two wars in Chechnya from inside Grozny. This is a Chechen rebel on the front line against the Russian army. The Russians bombarded Grozny constantly for weeks, killing mainly the civilians who were still trapped inside. I found a boy from the local orphanage wandering around the front line. My work has evolved from being concerned mainly with war to a focus on critical social issues as well. After the fall of Ceausescu, I went to Romania and discovered a kind of gulag of children, where thousands of orphans were being kept in medieval conditions. Ceausescu had imposed a quota on the number of children to be produced by each family, thereby making women's bodies an instrument of state economic policy. Children who couldn't be supported by their families were raised in government orphanages. Children with birth defects were labeled incurables, and confined for life to inhuman conditions.As reports began to surface, again international aid went in. Going deeper into the legacy of the Eastern European regimes, I worked for several months on a story about the effects of industrial pollution, where there had been no regard for the environment or the health of either workers or the general population. An aluminum factory in Czechoslovakia was filled with carcinogenic smoke and dust, and four out of five workers came down with cancer.After the fall of Suharto in Indonesia, I began to explore conditions of poverty in a country that was on its way towards modernization. I spent a good deal of time with a man who lived with his family on a railway embankment and had lost an arm and a leg in a train accident. When the story was published, unsolicited donations poured in. A trust fund was established, and the family now lives in a house in the countryside and all their basic necessities are taken care of. It was a story that wasn't trying to sell anything. Journalism had provided a channel for people's natural sense of generosity, and the readers responded. I met a band of homeless children who'd come to Jakarta from the countryside, and ended up living in a train station. By the age of 12 or 14, they'd become beggars and drug addicts. The rural poor had become the urban poor, and in the process, they'd become invisible.These heroin addicts in detox in Pakistan reminded me of figures in a play by Beckett: isolated, waiting in the dark, but drawn to the light. Agent Orange was a defoliant used during the Vietnam War to deny cover to the Vietcong and the North Vietnamese army. The active ingredient was dioxin, an extremely toxic chemical that was sprayed in vast quantities, and whose effects passed through the genes to the next generation. In 2000, I began documenting global health issues, concentrating first on AIDS in Africa. I tried to tell the story through the work of caregivers. I thought it was important to emphasize that people were being helped, whether by international NGOs or by local grassroots organizations.So many children have been orphaned by the epidemic that grandmothers have taken the place of parents, and a lot of children had been born with HIV. A hospital in Zambia. I began documenting the close connection between HIV/AIDS and tuberculosis. This is an MSF hospital in Cambodia. My pictures can play a supporting role to the work of NGOs by shedding light on the critical social problems they're trying to deal with. I went to Congo with MSF, and contributed to a book and an exhibition that focused attention on a forgotten war in which millions of people have died, and exposure to disease without treatment is used as a weapon. A malnourished child being measured as part of the supplemental feeding program.In the fall of 2004 I went to Darfur. This time I was on assignment for a magazine, but again worked closely with MSF. The international community still hasn't found a way to create the pressure necessary to stop this genocide. An MSF hospital in a camp for displaced people. I've been working on a long project on crime and punishment in America. This is a scene from New Orleans. A prisoner on a chain gang in Alabama was punished by being handcuffed to a post in the midday sun. This experience raised a lot of questions, among them questions about race and equality and for whom in our country opportunities and options are available. In the yard of a chain gang in Alabama.I didn't see either of the planes hit, and when I glanced out my window, I saw the first tower burning, and I thought it might have been an accident. A few minutes later when I looked again and saw the second tower burning, I knew we were at war. In the midst of the wreckage at Ground Zero, I had a realization. I'd been photographing in the Islamic world since 1981 — not only in the Middle East, but also in Africa, Asia and Europe. At the time I was photographing in these different places, I thought I was covering separate stories, but on 9/11 history crystallized, and I understood I'd actually been covering a single story for more than 20 years, and the attack on New York was its latest manifestation.The central commercial district of Kabul, Afghanistan at the end of the civil war, shortly before the city fell to the Taliban. Land mine victims being helped at the Red Cross rehab center being run by Alberto Cairo. A boy who lost a leg to a leftover mine. I'd witnessed immense suffering in the Islamic world from political oppression, civil war, foreign invasions, poverty, famine. I understood that in its suffering, the Islamic world had been crying out. Why weren't we listening? A Taliban fighter shot during a battle as the Northern Alliance entered the city of Kunduz. When war with Iraq was imminent, I realized the American troops would be very well covered, so I decided to cover the invasion from inside Baghdad. A marketplace was hit by a mortar shell that killed several members of a single family. A day after American forces entered Baghdad, a company of Marines began rounding up bank robbers and were cheered on by the crowds — a hopeful moment that was short lived.For the first time in years, Shi'ites were allowed to make the pilgrimage to Karbala to observe Ashura, and I was amazed by the sheer number of people and how fervently they practiced their religion. A group of men march through the streets cutting themselves with knives. It was obvious that the Shi'ites were a force to be reckoned with, and we would do well to understand them and learn how to deal with them. Last year I spent several months documenting our wounded troops, from the battlefield in Iraq all the way home.This is a helicopter medic giving CPR to a soldier who had been shot in the head. Military medicine has become so efficient that the percentage of troops who survive after being wounded is much higher in this war than in any other war in our history. The signature weapon of the war is the IED, and the signature wound is severe leg damage. After enduring extreme pain and trauma, the wounded face a grueling physical and psychological struggle in rehab. The spirit they displayed was absolutely remarkable. I tried to imagine myself in their place, and I was totally humbled by their courage and determination in the face of such catastrophic loss. Good people had been put in a very bad situation for questionable results. One day in rehab someone, started talking about surfing and all these guys who'd never surfed before said, "Hey, let's go." And they went surfing.Photographers go to the extreme edges of human experience to show people what's going on. Sometimes they put their lives on the line, because they believe your opinions and your influence matter. They aim their pictures at your best instincts, generosity, a sense of right and wrong, the ability and the willingness to identify with others, the refusal to accept the unacceptable. My TED wish: there's a vital story that needs to be told, and I wish for TED to help me gain access to it and then to help me come up with innovative and exciting ways to use news photography in the digital era. Thank you very much.(Applause)

between Bosnia, Croatia and Serbia.

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:08.958
This is a scene of house-to-house fighting in Mostar,

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:10.958
neighbor against neighbor.

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:13.958
A bedroom, the place where people share intimacy,

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:17.958
where life itself is conceived, became a battlefield.

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:24.958
A mosque in northern Bosnia was destroyed by Serbian artillery

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:26.958
and was used as a makeshift morgue.

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:36.958
Dead Serbian soldiers were collected after a battle

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:39.958
and used as barter for the return of prisoners

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:41.958
or Bosnian soldiers killed in action.

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:45.958
This was once a park.

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:47.958
The Bosnian soldier who guided me

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:50.958
told me that all of his friends were there now.

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:53.958
At the same time in South Africa,

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:56.958
after Nelson Mandela had been released from prison,

00:06:56.958 --> 00:06:59.958
the black population commenced the final phase

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:01.958
of liberation from apartheid.

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:05.958
One of the things I had to learn as a journalist

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:07.958
was what to do with my anger.

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:12.958
I had to use it, channel its energy, turn it into something

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:15.958
that would clarify my vision, instead of clouding it.

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:21.958
In Transkei, I witnessed a rite of passage into manhood, of the Xhosa tribe.

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:25.958
Teenage boys lived in isolation, their bodies covered with white clay.

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:28.958
After several weeks, they washed off the white

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:31.958
and took on the full responsibilities of men.

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:35.558
It was a very old ritual that seemed symbolic

00:07:35.573 --> 00:07:39.958
of the political struggle that was changing the face of South Africa.

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:45.958
Children in Soweto playing on a trampoline.

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:51.958
Elsewhere in Africa there was famine.

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:55.958
In Somalia, the central government collapsed and clan warfare broke out.

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:58.958
Farmers were driven off their land,

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:02.958
and crops and livestock were destroyed or stolen.

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:06.958
Starvation was being used as a weapon of mass destruction --

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:08.958
primitive but extremely effective.

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:11.958
Hundreds of thousands of people were exterminated,

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:13.958
slowly and painfully.

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:19.958
The international community responded with massive humanitarian relief,

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:23.958
and hundreds of thousands of more lives were saved.

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:26.958
American troops were sent to protect the relief shipments,

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:29.958
but they were eventually drawn into the conflict,

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:32.958
and after the tragic battle in Mogadishu, they were withdrawn.

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:37.958
In southern Sudan, another civil war saw similar use of starvation

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:39.958
as a means of genocide.

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:44.958
Again, international NGOs, united under the umbrella of the U.N.,

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:49.958
staged a massive relief operation and thousands of lives were saved.

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:56.958
I'm a witness, and I want my testimony to be honest and uncensored.

00:08:57.958 --> 00:09:00.958
I also want it to be powerful and eloquent,

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:02.958
and to do as much justice as possible

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:05.958
to the experience of the people I'm photographing.

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:08.958
This man was in an NGO feeding center,

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:10.958
being helped as much as he could be helped.

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:15.958
He literally had nothing. He was a virtual skeleton,

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:19.958
yet he could still summon the courage and the will to move.

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:22.958
He had not given up, and if he didn't give up,

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:27.958
how could anyone in the outside world ever dream of losing hope?

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:33.958
In 1994, after three months of covering the South African election,

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:36.958
I saw the inauguration of Nelson Mandela,

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:39.958
and it was the most uplifting thing I've ever seen.

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:43.958
It exemplified the best that humanity has to offer.

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:46.958
The next day I left for Rwanda,

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:49.958
and it was like taking the express elevator to hell.

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:53.958
This man had just been liberated from a Hutu death camp.

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:57.958
He allowed me to photograph him for quite a long time,

00:09:57.958 --> 00:10:00.958
and he even turned his face toward the light,

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:02.958
as if he wanted me to see him better.

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:07.958
I think he knew what the scars on his face would say to the rest of the world.

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:11.958
This time, maybe confused or discouraged

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:14.958
by the military disaster in Somalia,

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:17.958
the international community remained silent,

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:20.958
and somewhere around 800,000 people were slaughtered

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:23.958
by their own countrymen -- sometimes their own neighbors --

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:26.958
using farm implements as weapons.

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:30.604
Perhaps because a lesson had been learned

00:10:30.620 --> 00:10:32.958
by the weak response to the war in Bosnia

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:34.958
and the failure in Rwanda,

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:36.958
when Serbia attacked Kosovo,

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:40.650
international action was taken much more decisively.

00:10:40.650 --> 00:10:44.958
NATO forces went in, and the Serbian army withdrew.

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:47.681
Ethnic Albanians had been murdered,

00:10:47.681 --> 00:10:51.958
their farms destroyed and a huge number of people forcibly deported.

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:55.958
They were received in refugee camps

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:58.958
set up by NGOs in Albania and Macedonia.

00:11:00.496 --> 00:11:03.958
The imprint of a man who had been burned inside his own home.

00:11:04.543 --> 00:11:07.512
The image reminded me of a cave painting,

00:11:07.512 --> 00:11:11.958
and echoed how primitive we still are in so many ways.

00:11:13.435 --> 00:11:17.481
Between 1995 and '96, I covered the first two wars

00:11:17.481 --> 00:11:19.958
in Chechnya from inside Grozny.

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:23.958
This is a Chechen rebel on the front line against the Russian army.

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:29.604
The Russians bombarded Grozny constantly for weeks,

00:11:29.604 --> 00:11:32.958
killing mainly the civilians who were still trapped inside.

00:11:34.127 --> 00:11:36.435
I found a boy from the local orphanage

00:11:36.435 --> 00:11:38.958
wandering around the front line.

00:11:40.266 --> 00:11:43.958
My work has evolved from being concerned mainly with war

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:47.650
to a focus on critical social issues as well.

00:11:48.235 --> 00:11:50.958
After the fall of Ceausescu, I went to Romania

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:54.958
and discovered a kind of gulag of children,

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:57.958
where thousands of orphans were being kept in medieval conditions.

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:00.958
Ceausescu had imposed a quota

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:03.958
on the number of children to be produced by each family,

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:07.958
thereby making women's bodies an instrument of state economic policy.

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:11.958
Children who couldn't be supported by their families

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:14.958
were raised in government orphanages.

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:17.958
Children with birth defects were labeled incurables,

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:21.958
and confined for life to inhuman conditions.

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:25.958
As reports began to surface, again international aid went in.

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:31.958
Going deeper into the legacy of the Eastern European regimes,

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:35.958
I worked for several months on a story about the effects of industrial pollution,

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:38.958
where there had been no regard for the environment

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:42.958
or the health of either workers or the general population.

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:45.958
An aluminum factory in Czechoslovakia

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:48.958
was filled with carcinogenic smoke and dust,

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:52.958
and four out of five workers came down with cancer.

00:12:54.358 --> 00:12:56.620
After the fall of Suharto in Indonesia,

00:12:56.620 --> 00:12:59.389
I began to explore conditions of poverty

00:12:59.389 --> 00:13:02.620
in a country that was on its way towards modernization.

00:13:02.620 --> 00:13:05.958
I spent a good deal of time with a man

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:07.958
who lived with his family on a railway embankment

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:11.958
and had lost an arm and a leg in a train accident.

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:16.958
When the story was published, unsolicited donations poured in.

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:18.958
A trust fund was established,

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:21.958
and the family now lives in a house in the countryside

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:24.958
and all their basic necessities are taken care of.

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:27.958
It was a story that wasn't trying to sell anything.

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:30.958
Journalism had provided a channel

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:34.958
for people's natural sense of generosity, and the readers responded.

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:39.958
I met a band of homeless children who'd come to Jakarta from the countryside,

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:42.958
and ended up living in a train station.

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:47.958
By the age of 12 or 14, they'd become beggars and drug addicts.

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:49.958
The rural poor had become the urban poor,

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:53.958
and in the process, they'd become invisible.

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:58.558
These heroin addicts in detox in Pakistan

00:13:58.558 --> 00:14:01.450
reminded me of figures in a play by Beckett:

00:14:01.450 --> 00:14:04.958
isolated, waiting in the dark, but drawn to the light.

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:12.143
Agent Orange was a defoliant used during the Vietnam War

00:14:12.143 --> 00:14:16.081
to deny cover to the Vietcong and the North Vietnamese army.

00:14:16.081 --> 00:14:20.958
The active ingredient was dioxin, an extremely toxic chemical

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:22.958
that was sprayed in vast quantities,

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:26.958
and whose effects passed through the genes to the next generation.

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:31.620
In 2000, I began documenting global health issues,

00:14:31.620 --> 00:14:34.789
concentrating first on AIDS in Africa.

00:14:34.789 --> 00:14:37.958
I tried to tell the story through the work of caregivers.

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:41.958
I thought it was important to emphasize that people were being helped,

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:46.404
whether by international NGOs or by local grassroots organizations.

00:14:46.404 --> 00:14:48.958
So many children have been orphaned by the epidemic

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:51.958
that grandmothers have taken the place of parents,

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:54.958
and a lot of children had been born with HIV.

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:57.958
A hospital in Zambia.

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:03.958
I began documenting the close connection

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:06.958
between HIV/AIDS and tuberculosis.

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:09.958
This is an MSF hospital in Cambodia.

00:15:14.558 --> 00:15:17.296
My pictures can play a supporting role to the work of NGOs

00:15:17.296 --> 00:15:21.958
by shedding light on the critical social problems they're trying to deal with.

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:24.958
I went to Congo with MSF,

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:26.958
and contributed to a book and an exhibition

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:29.958
that focused attention on a forgotten war

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:31.958
in which millions of people have died,

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:35.958
and exposure to disease without treatment is used as a weapon.

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:38.958
A malnourished child being measured

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:40.958
as part of the supplemental feeding program.

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:45.958
In the fall of 2004 I went to Darfur.

00:15:46.958 --> 00:15:48.958
This time I was on assignment for a magazine,

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:50.958
but again worked closely with MSF.

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:53.958
The international community still hasn't found a way

00:15:53.958 --> 00:15:57.958
to create the pressure necessary to stop this genocide.

00:15:59.020 --> 00:16:02.958
An MSF hospital in a camp for displaced people.

00:16:04.312 --> 00:16:08.958
I've been working on a long project on crime and punishment in America.

00:16:09.127 --> 00:16:11.958
This is a scene from New Orleans.

00:16:13.958 --> 00:16:16.296
A prisoner on a chain gang in Alabama

00:16:16.296 --> 00:16:19.958
was punished by being handcuffed to a post in the midday sun.

00:16:22.958 --> 00:16:24.958
This experience raised a lot of questions,

00:16:24.958 --> 00:16:27.958
among them questions about race and equality

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:32.958
and for whom in our country opportunities and options are available.

00:16:32.958 --> 00:16:35.958
In the yard of a chain gang in Alabama.

00:16:38.235 --> 00:16:40.389
I didn't see either of the planes hit,
