00:16:40.389 --> 00:16:43.958
and when I glanced out my window, I saw the first tower burning,

00:16:43.958 --> 00:16:46.958
and I thought it might have been an accident.

00:16:46.958 --> 00:16:48.958
A few minutes later when I looked again

00:16:48.958 --> 00:16:52.958
and saw the second tower burning, I knew we were at war.

00:16:53.958 --> 00:16:56.958
In the midst of the wreckage at Ground Zero, I had a realization.

00:16:57.173 --> 00:17:01.958
I'd been photographing in the Islamic world since 1981 --

00:17:01.958 --> 00:17:06.604
not only in the Middle East, but also in Africa, Asia and Europe.

00:17:06.604 --> 00:17:09.573
At the time I was photographing in these different places,

00:17:09.573 --> 00:17:11.604
I thought I was covering separate stories,

00:17:11.604 --> 00:17:14.958
but on 9/11 history crystallized, and I understood

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:19.204
I'd actually been covering a single story for more than 20 years,

00:17:19.358 --> 00:17:22.958
and the attack on New York was its latest manifestation.

00:17:23.958 --> 00:17:26.958
The central commercial district of Kabul, Afghanistan

00:17:26.958 --> 00:17:28.958
at the end of the civil war,

00:17:28.958 --> 00:17:31.958
shortly before the city fell to the Taliban.

00:17:34.343 --> 00:17:36.958
Land mine victims being helped

00:17:36.958 --> 00:17:39.958
at the Red Cross rehab center being run by Alberto Cairo.

00:17:41.958 --> 00:17:44.573
A boy who lost a leg to a leftover mine.

00:17:44.573 --> 00:17:47.958
I'd witnessed immense suffering in the Islamic world

00:17:47.958 --> 00:17:52.958
from political oppression, civil war, foreign invasions, poverty, famine.

00:17:52.958 --> 00:17:54.958
I understood that in its suffering,

00:17:54.958 --> 00:17:59.958
the Islamic world had been crying out. Why weren't we listening?

00:18:02.589 --> 00:18:04.958
A Taliban fighter shot during a battle

00:18:04.958 --> 00:18:08.958
as the Northern Alliance entered the city of Kunduz.

00:18:14.696 --> 00:18:16.958
When war with Iraq was imminent,

00:18:16.958 --> 00:18:19.958
I realized the American troops would be very well covered,

00:18:19.958 --> 00:18:22.958
so I decided to cover the invasion from inside Baghdad.

00:18:28.958 --> 00:18:30.958
A marketplace was hit by a mortar shell

00:18:30.958 --> 00:18:33.958
that killed several members of a single family.

00:18:35.958 --> 00:18:38.958
A day after American forces entered Baghdad,

00:18:38.958 --> 00:18:40.958
a company of Marines began rounding up bank robbers

00:18:40.958 --> 00:18:42.958
and were cheered on by the crowds --

00:18:43.958 --> 00:18:45.958
a hopeful moment that was short lived.

00:18:47.158 --> 00:18:49.327
For the first time in years,

00:18:49.327 --> 00:18:51.650
Shi'ites were allowed to make the pilgrimage

00:18:51.650 --> 00:18:53.958
to Karbala to observe Ashura,

00:18:53.958 --> 00:18:56.543
and I was amazed by the sheer number of people

00:18:56.543 --> 00:18:58.958
and how fervently they practiced their religion.

00:19:01.958 --> 00:19:04.958
A group of men march through the streets cutting themselves with knives.

00:19:04.958 --> 00:19:08.958
It was obvious that the Shi'ites were a force to be reckoned with,

00:19:08.958 --> 00:19:13.958
and we would do well to understand them and learn how to deal with them.

00:19:15.958 --> 00:19:19.650
Last year I spent several months documenting our wounded troops,

00:19:19.650 --> 00:19:21.958
from the battlefield in Iraq all the way home.

00:19:23.204 --> 00:19:25.666
This is a helicopter medic giving CPR

00:19:25.666 --> 00:19:27.958
to a soldier who had been shot in the head.

00:19:30.020 --> 00:19:32.543
Military medicine has become so efficient

00:19:32.543 --> 00:19:36.358
that the percentage of troops who survive after being wounded

00:19:36.358 --> 00:19:39.958
is much higher in this war than in any other war in our history.

00:19:41.604 --> 00:19:44.958
The signature weapon of the war is the IED,

00:19:44.958 --> 00:19:47.958
and the signature wound is severe leg damage.

00:19:49.327 --> 00:19:52.527
After enduring extreme pain and trauma,

00:19:52.527 --> 00:19:54.958
the wounded face a grueling physical

00:19:54.958 --> 00:19:56.958
and psychological struggle in rehab.

00:19:59.327 --> 00:20:02.958
The spirit they displayed was absolutely remarkable.

00:20:03.496 --> 00:20:05.958
I tried to imagine myself in their place,

00:20:05.958 --> 00:20:09.958
and I was totally humbled by their courage and determination

00:20:09.958 --> 00:20:12.958
in the face of such catastrophic loss.

00:20:13.420 --> 00:20:18.958
Good people had been put in a very bad situation for questionable results.

00:20:21.450 --> 00:20:24.958
One day in rehab someone, started talking about surfing

00:20:24.958 --> 00:20:29.296
and all these guys who'd never surfed before said, "Hey, let's go."

00:20:29.296 --> 00:20:30.958
And they went surfing.

00:20:34.543 --> 00:20:37.958
Photographers go to the extreme edges of human experience

00:20:37.958 --> 00:20:39.958
to show people what's going on.

00:20:39.958 --> 00:20:42.958
Sometimes they put their lives on the line,

00:20:42.958 --> 00:20:46.958
because they believe your opinions and your influence matter.

00:20:46.958 --> 00:20:50.958
They aim their pictures at your best instincts,

00:20:50.958 --> 00:20:53.958
generosity, a sense of right and wrong,

00:20:53.958 --> 00:20:57.958
the ability and the willingness to identify with others,

00:20:57.958 --> 00:21:00.958
the refusal to accept the unacceptable.

00:21:02.958 --> 00:21:04.958
My TED wish:

00:21:04.958 --> 00:21:07.958
there's a vital story that needs to be told,

00:21:07.958 --> 00:21:11.958
and I wish for TED to help me gain access to it

00:21:11.958 --> 00:21:15.958
and then to help me come up with innovative and exciting ways

00:21:15.958 --> 00:21:18.958
to use news photography in the digital era.

00:21:18.958 --> 00:21:20.958
Thank you very much.

00:21:21.958 --> 00:21:36.958
(Applause)

title: What separates us from chimpanzees?
transcript: Good morning everyone. First of all, it's been fantastic being here over these past few days. And secondly, I feel it's a great honor to kind of wind up this extraordinary gathering of people, these amazing talks that we've had. I feel that I've fitted in, in many ways, to some of the things that I've heard. I came directly here from the deep, deep tropical rainforest in Ecuador, where I was out — you could only get there by a plane — with indigenous people with paint on their faces and parrot feathers on their headdresses, where these people are fighting to try and keep the oil companies, and keep the roads, out of their forests. They're fighting to develop their own way of living within the forest in a world that's clean, a world that isn't contaminated, a world that isn't polluted. And what was so amazing to me, and what fits right in with what we're all talking about here at TED, is that there, right in the middle of this rainforest, was some solar panels — the first in that part of Ecuador — and that was mainly to bring water up by pump so that the women wouldn't have to go down. The water was cleaned, but because they got a lot of batteries, they were able to store a lot of electricity. So every house — and there were, I think, eight houses in this little community — could have light for, I think it was about half an hour each evening. And there is the Chief, in all his regal finery, with a laptop computer. (Laughter) And this man, he has been outside, but he's gone back, and he was saying, "You know, we have suddenly jumped into a whole new era, and we didn't even know about the white man 50 years ago, and now here we are with laptop computers, and there are some things we want to learn from the modern world. We want to know about health care. We want to know about what other people do — we're interested in it. And we want to learn other languages. We want to know English and French and perhaps Chinese, and we're good at languages." So there he is with his little laptop computer, but fighting against the might of the pressures — because of the debt, the foreign debt of Ecuador — fighting the pressure of World Bank, IMF, and of course the people who want to exploit the forests and take out the oil. And so, coming directly from there to here. But, of course, my real field of expertise lies in an even different kind of civilization — I can't really call it a civilization. A different way of life, a different being. We've talked earlier — this wonderful talk by Wade Davis about the different cultures of the humans around the world — but the world is not composed only of human beings; there are also other animal beings. And I propose to bring into this TED conference, as I always do around the world, the voice of the animal kingdom. Too often we just see a few slides, or a bit of film, but these beings have voices that mean something. And so, I want to give you a greeting, as from a chimpanzee in the forests of Tanzania — Ooh, ooh, ooh, ooh, ooh, ooh, ooh, ooh, ooh, ooh, ooh, ooh, ooh, ooh, ooh! (Applause) I've been studying chimpanzees in Tanzania since 1960. During that time, there have been modern technologies that have really transformed the way that field biologists do their work. For example, for the first time, a few years ago, by simply collecting little fecal samples we were able to have them analyzed — to have DNA profiling done — so for the first time, we actually know which male chimps are the fathers of each individual infant. Because the chimps have a very promiscuous mating society. So this opens up a whole new avenue of research. And we use GSI — geographic whatever it is, GSI — to determine the range of the chimps. And we're using — you can see that I'm not really into this kind of stuff — but we're using satellite imagery to look at the deforestation in the area. And of course, there's developments in infrared, so you can watch animals at night, and equipment for recording by video, and tape recording is getting lighter and better. So in many, many ways, we can do things today that we couldn't do when I began in 1960. Especially when chimpanzees, and other animals with large brains, are studied in captivity, modern technology is helping us to search for the upper levels of cognition in some of these non-human animals. So that we know today, they're capable of performances that would have been thought absolutely impossible by science when I began. I think the chimpanzee in captivity who is the most skilled in intellectual performance is one called Ai in Japan — her name means love — and she has a wonderfully sensitive partner working with her. She loves her computer — she'll leave her big group, and her running water, and her trees and everything. And she'll come in to sit at this computer — it's like a video game for a kid; she's hooked. She's 28, by the way, and she does things with her computer screen and a touch pad that she can do faster than most humans. She does very complex tasks, and I haven't got time to go into them, but the amazing thing about this female is she doesn't like making mistakes. If she has a bad run, and her score isn't good, she'll come and reach up and tap on the glass — because she can't see the experimenter — which is asking to have another go. And her concentration — she's already concentrated hard for 20 minutes or so, and now she wants to do it all over again, just for the satisfaction of having done it better. And the food is not important — she does get a tiny reward, like one raisin for a correct response — but she will do it for nothing, if you tell her beforehand. So here we are, a chimpanzee using a computer. Chimpanzees, gorillas, orangutans also learn human sign language. But the point is that when I was first in Gombe in 1960 — I remember so well, so vividly, as though it was yesterday — the first time, when I was going through the vegetation, the chimpanzees were still running away from me, for the most part, although some were a little bit acclimatized — and I saw this dark shape, hunched over a termite mound, and I peered with my binoculars. It was, fortunately, one adult male whom I'd named David Greybeard — and by the way, science at that time was telling me that I shouldn't name the chimps; they should all have numbers; that was more scientific. Anyway, David Greybeard — and I saw that he was picking little pieces of grass and using them to fish termites from their underground nest. And not only that — he would sometimes pick a leafy twig and strip the leaves — modifying an object to make it suitable for a specific purpose — the beginning of tool-making. The reason this was so exciting and such a breakthrough is at that time, it was thought that humans, and only humans, used and made tools. When I was at school, we were defined as man, the toolmaker. So that when Louis Leakey, my mentor, heard this news, he said, "Ah, we must now redefine 'man,' redefine 'tool,' or accept chimpanzees as humans." (Laughter) We now know that at Gombe alone, there are nine different ways in which chimpanzees use different objects for different purposes. Moreover, we know that in different parts of Africa, wherever chimps have been studied, there are completely different tool-using behaviors. And because it seems that these patterns are passed from one generation to the next, through observation, imitation and practice — that is a definition of human culture. What we find is that over these 40-odd years that I and others have been studying chimpanzees and the other great apes, and, as I say, other mammals with complex brains and social systems, we have found that after all, there isn't a sharp line dividing humans from the rest of the animal kingdom. It's a very wuzzy line. It's getting wuzzier all the time as we find animals doing things that we, in our arrogance, used to think was just human. The chimps — there's no time to discuss their fascinating lives — but they have this long childhood, five years of suckling and sleeping with the mother, and then another three, four or five years of emotional dependence on her, even when the next child is born. The importance of learning in that time, when behavior is flexible — and there's an awful lot to learn in chimpanzee society. The long-term affectionate supportive bonds that develop throughout this long childhood with the mother, with the brothers and sisters, and which can last through a lifetime, which may be up to 60 years. They can actually live longer than 60 in captivity, so we've only done 40 years in the wild so far. And we find chimps are capable of true compassion and altruism. We find in their non-verbal communication — this is very rich — they have a lot of sounds, which they use in different circumstances, but they also use touch, posture, gesture, and what do they do? They kiss; they embrace; they hold hands. They pat one another on the back; they swagger; they shake their fist — the kind of things that we do, and they do them in the same kind of context. They have very sophisticated cooperation. Sometimes they hunt — not that often, but when they hunt, they show sophisticated cooperation, and they share the prey. We find that they show emotions, similar to — maybe sometimes the same — as those that we describe in ourselves as happiness, sadness, fear, despair. They know mental as well as physical suffering. And I don't have time to go into the information that will prove some of these things to you, save to say that there are very bright students, in the best universities, studying emotions in animals, studying personalities in animals. We know that chimpanzees and some other creatures can recognize themselves in mirrors — "self" as opposed to "other." They have a sense of humor, and these are the kind of things which traditionally have been thought of as human prerogatives. But this teaches us a new respect — and it's a new respect not only for the chimpanzees, I suggest, but some of the other amazing animals with whom we share this planet. Once we're prepared to admit that after all, we're not the only beings with personalities, minds and above all feelings, and then we start to think about ways we use and abuse so many other sentient, sapient creatures on this planet, it really gives cause for deep shame, at least for me. So, the sad thing is that these chimpanzees — who've perhaps taught us, more than any other creature, a little humility — are in the wild, disappearing very fast. They're disappearing for the reasons that all of you in this room know only too well. The deforestation, the growth of human populations, needing more land. They're disappearing because some timber companies go in with clear-cutting. They're disappearing in the heart of their range in Africa because the big multinational logging companies have come in and made roads — as they want to do in Ecuador and other parts where the forests remain untouched — to take out oil or timber. And this has led in Congo basin, and other parts of the world, to what is known as the bush-meat trade. This means that although for hundreds, perhaps thousands of years, people have lived in those forests, or whatever habitat it is, in harmony with their world, just killing the animals they need for themselves and their families — now, suddenly, because of the roads, the hunters can go in from the towns. They shoot everything, every single thing that moves that's bigger than a small rat; they sun-dry it or smoke it. And now they've got transport; they take it on the logging trucks or the mining trucks into the towns where they sell it. And people will pay more for bush-meat, as it's called, than for domestic meat — it's culturally preferred. And it's not sustainable, and the huge logging camps in the forest are now demanding meat, so the Pygmy hunters in the Congo basin who've lived there with their wonderful way of living for so many hundreds of years are now corrupted. They're given weapons; they shoot for the logging camps; they get money. Their culture is being destroyed, along with the animals upon whom they depend. So, when the logging camp moves, there's nothing left. We talked already about the loss of human cultural diversity, and I've seen it happening with my own eyes. And the grim picture in Africa — I love Africa, and what do we see in Africa? We see deforestation; we see the desert spreading; we see massive hunger; we see disease and we see population growth in areas where there are more people living on a certain piece of land than the land can possibly support, and they're too poor to buy food from elsewhere. Were the people that we heard about yesterday, on the Easter Island, who cut down their last tree — were they stupid? Didn't they know what was happening? Of course, but if you've seen the crippling poverty in some of these parts of the world it isn't a question of "Let's leave the tree for tomorrow." "How am I going to feed my family today? Maybe I can get just a few dollars from this last tree which will keep us going a little bit longer, and then we'll pray that something will happen to save us from the inevitable end." So, this is a pretty grim picture. The one thing we have, which makes us so different from chimpanzees or other living creatures, is this sophisticated spoken language — a language with which we can tell children about things that aren't here. We can talk about the distant past, plan for the distant future, discuss ideas with each other, so that the ideas can grow from the accumulated wisdom of a group. We can do it by talking to each other; we can do it through video; we can do it through the written word. And we are abusing this great power we have to be wise stewards, and we're destroying the world. In the developed world, in a way, it's worse, because we have so much access to knowledge of the stupidity of what we're doing. Do you know, we're bringing little babies into a world where, in many places, the water is poisoning them? And the air is harming them, and the food that's grown from the contaminated land is poisoning them. And that's not just in the far-away developing world; that's everywhere. Do you know we all have about 50 chemicals in our bodies we didn't have about 50 years ago? And so many of these diseases, like asthma and certain kinds of cancers, are on the increase around places where our filthy toxic waste is dumped. We're harming ourselves around the world, as well as harming the animals, as well as harming nature herself — Mother Nature, that brought us into being; Mother Nature, where I believe we need to spend time, where there's trees and flowers and birds for our good psychological development. And yet, there are hundreds and hundreds of children in the developed world who never see nature, because they're growing up in concrete and all they know is virtual reality, with no opportunity to go and lie in the sun, or in the forest, with the dappled sun-specks coming down from the canopy above. As I was traveling around the world, you know, I had to leave the forest — that's where I love to be. I had to leave these fascinating chimpanzees for my students and field staff to continue studying because, finding they dwindled from about two million 100 years ago to about 150,000 now, I knew I had to leave the forest to do what I could to raise awareness around the world. And the more I talked about the chimpanzees' plight, the more I realized the fact that everything's interconnected, and the problems of the developing world so often stem from the greed of the developed world, and everything was joining together, and making — not sense, hope lies in sense, you said — it's making a nonsense. How can we do it? Somebody said that yesterday. And as I was traveling around, I kept meeting young people who'd lost hope. They were feeling despair, they were feeling, "Well, it doesn't matter what we do; eat, drink and be merry, for tomorrow we die. Everything is hopeless — we're always being told so by the media." And then I met some who were angry, and anger that can turn to violence, and we're all familiar with that. And I have three little grandchildren, and when some of these students would say to me at high school or university, they'd say, "We're angry," or "We're filled with despair, because we feel you've compromised our future, and there's nothing we can do about it." And I looked in the eyes of my little grandchildren, and think how much we've harmed this planet since I was their age. I feel this deep shame, and that's why in 1991 in Tanzania, I started a program that's called Roots and Shoots. There's little brochures all around outside, and if any of you have anything to do with children and care about their future, I beg that you pick up that brochure. And Roots and Shoots is a program for hope. Roots make a firm foundation. Shoots seem tiny, but to reach the sun they can break through brick walls. See the brick walls as all the problems that we've inflicted on this planet. Then, you see, it is a message of hope. Hundreds and thousands of young people around the world can break through, and can make this a better world. And the most important message of Roots and Shoots is that every single individual makes a difference. Every individual has a role to play. Every one of us impacts the world around us everyday, and you scientists know that you can't actually — even if you stay in bed all day, you're breathing oxygen and giving out CO2, and probably going to the loo, and things like that — you're making a difference in the world. So, the Roots and Shoots program involves youth in three kinds of projects. And these are projects to make the world around them a better place. One project to show care and concern for your own human community. One for animals, including domestic animals — and I have to say, I learned everything I know about animal behavior even before I got to Gombe and the chimps from my dog, Rusty, who was my childhood companion. And the third kind of project: something for the local environment. So what the kids do depends first of all, how old are they — and we go now from pre-school right through university. It's going to depend whether they're inner-city or rural. It's going to depend if they're wealthy or impoverished. It's going to depend which part, say, of America they're in. We're in every state now, and the problems in Florida are different from the problems in New York. It's going to depend on which country they're in — and we're already in 60-plus countries, with about 5,000 active groups — and there are groups all over the place that I keep hearing about that I've never even heard of, because the kids are taking the program and spreading it themselves. Why? Because they're buying into it, and they're the ones who get to decide what they're going to do. It isn't something that their parents tell them, or their teachers tell them. That's effective, but if they decide themselves, "We want to clean this river and put the fish back that used to be there. We want to clear away the toxic soil from this area and have an organic garden. We want to go and spend time with the old people and hear their stories and record their oral histories. We want to go and work in a dog shelter. We want to learn about animals. We want ... " You know, it goes on and on, and this is very hopeful for me. As I travel around the world 300 days a year, everywhere there's a group of Roots and Shoots of different ages. Everywhere there are children with shining eyes saying, "Look at the difference we've made." And now comes the technology into it, because with this new way of communicating electronically these kids can communicate with each other around the world. And if anyone is interested to help us, we've got so many ideas but we need help — we need help to create the right kind of system that will help these young people to communicate their excitement. But also — and this is so important — to communicate their despair, to say, "We've tried this and it doesn't work, and what shall we do?" And then, lo and behold, there's another group answering these kids who may be in America, or maybe this is a group in Israel, saying, "Yeah, you did it a little bit wrong. This is how you should do it." The philosophy is very simple. We do not believe in violence. No violence, no bombs, no guns. That's not the way to solve problems. Violence leads to violence, at least in my view. So how do we solve? The tools for solving the problems are knowledge and understanding. Know the facts, but see how they fit in the big picture. Hard work and persistence —don't give up — and love and compassion leading to respect for all life. How many more minutes? Two, one? Chris Anderson: One — one to two. Jane Goodall: Two, two, I'm going to take two. (Laughter) Are you going to come and drag me off? (Laughter) Anyway — so basically, Roots and Shoots is beginning to change young people's lives. It's what I'm devoting most of my energy to. And I believe that a group like this can have a very major impact, not just because you can share technology with us, but because so many of you have children. And if you take this program out, and give it to your children, they have such a good opportunity to go out and do good, because they've got parents like you. And it's been so clear how much you all care about trying to make this world a better place. It's very encouraging. But the kids do ask me — and this won't take more than two minutes, I promise — the kids say, "Dr. Jane, do you really have hope for the future? You travel, you see all these horrible things happening." Firstly, the human brain — I don't need to say anything about that. Now that we know what the problems are around the world, human brains like yours are rising to solve those problems. And we've talked a lot about that. Secondly, the resilience of nature. We can destroy a river, and we can bring it back to life. We can see a whole area desolated, and it can be brought back to bloom again, with time or a little help. And thirdly, the last speaker talked about — or the speaker before last, talked about the indomitable human spirit. We are surrounded by the most amazing people who do things that seem to be absolutely impossible. Nelson Mandela — I take a little piece of limestone from Robben Island Prison, where he labored for 27 years, and came out with so little bitterness, he could lead his people from the horror of apartheid without a bloodbath. Even after the 11th of September — and I was in New York and I felt the fear — nevertheless, there was so much human courage, so much love and so much compassion. And then as I went around the country after that and felt the fear — the fear that was leading to people feeling they couldn't worry about the environment any more, in case they seemed not to be patriotic — and I was trying to encourage them, somebody came up with a little quotation from Mahatma Gandhi, "If you look back through human history, you see that every evil regime has been overcome by good." And just after that a woman brought me this little bell, and I want to end on this note. She said, "If you're talking about hope and peace, ring this. This bell is made from metal from a defused landmine, from the killing fields of Pol Pot — one of the most evil regimes in human history — where people are now beginning to put their lives back together after the regime has crumbled. So, yes, there is hope, and where is the hope? Is it out there with the politicians? It's in our hands. It's in your hands and my hands and those of our children. It's really up to us. We're the ones who can make a difference. If we lead lives where we consciously leave the lightest possible ecological footprints, if we buy the things that are ethical for us to buy and don't buy the things that are not, we can change the world overnight. Thank you.
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:12.958 --> 00:00:16.958
Good morning everyone. First of all, it's been fantastic

00:00:16.958 --> 00:00:19.958
being here over these past few days.

00:00:19.958 --> 00:00:23.958
And secondly, I feel it's a great honor to kind of wind up

00:00:23.958 --> 00:00:25.958
this extraordinary gathering of people,

00:00:25.958 --> 00:00:28.958
these amazing talks that we've had.

00:00:28.958 --> 00:00:31.958
I feel that I've fitted in, in many ways,

00:00:31.958 --> 00:00:34.958
to some of the things that I've heard.

00:00:34.958 --> 00:00:38.958
I came directly here

00:00:38.958 --> 00:00:42.958
from the deep, deep tropical rainforest in Ecuador,

00:00:43.958 --> 00:00:46.958
where I was out -- you could only get there by a plane --

00:00:46.958 --> 00:00:49.958
with indigenous people with paint on their faces

00:00:50.958 --> 00:00:52.958
and parrot feathers on their headdresses,

00:00:52.958 --> 00:00:57.958
where these people are fighting to try and keep the oil companies,

00:00:57.958 --> 00:01:01.958
and keep the roads, out of their forests.

00:01:01.958 --> 00:01:05.958
They're fighting to develop their own way of living within the forest

00:01:05.958 --> 00:01:08.958
in a world that's clean, a world that isn't contaminated,

00:01:08.958 --> 00:01:11.958
a world that isn't polluted.

00:01:11.958 --> 00:01:14.958
And what was so amazing to me, and what fits right in

00:01:14.958 --> 00:01:17.958
with what we're all talking about here at TED,

00:01:17.958 --> 00:01:20.958
is that there, right in the middle of this rainforest,

00:01:20.958 --> 00:01:24.958
was some solar panels -- the first in that part of Ecuador --

00:01:25.958 --> 00:01:28.958
and that was mainly to bring water up by pump

00:01:28.958 --> 00:01:30.958
so that the women wouldn't have to go down.

00:01:30.958 --> 00:01:33.958
The water was cleaned, but because they got a lot of batteries,

00:01:33.958 --> 00:01:36.958
they were able to store a lot of electricity.

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:38.958
So every house -- and there were, I think, eight houses

00:01:38.958 --> 00:01:41.958
in this little community -- could have light

00:01:41.958 --> 00:01:43.958
for, I think it was about half an hour each evening.

00:01:44.958 --> 00:01:50.958
And there is the Chief, in all his regal finery, with a laptop computer.

00:01:50.958 --> 00:01:52.958
(Laughter)

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:57.958
And this man, he has been outside, but he's gone back,

00:01:57.958 --> 00:02:03.958
and he was saying, "You know, we have suddenly jumped into

00:02:03.958 --> 00:02:07.958
a whole new era, and we didn't even know about the white man

00:02:07.958 --> 00:02:10.958
50 years ago, and now here we are with laptop computers,

00:02:10.958 --> 00:02:13.958
and there are some things we want to learn from the modern world.

00:02:13.958 --> 00:02:16.958
We want to know about health care.

00:02:16.958 --> 00:02:20.958
We want to know about what other people do -- we're interested in it.

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:22.958
And we want to learn other languages.

00:02:22.958 --> 00:02:26.958
We want to know English and French and perhaps Chinese,

00:02:26.958 --> 00:02:28.958
and we're good at languages."

00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:32.958
So there he is with his little laptop computer,

00:02:32.958 --> 00:02:36.958
but fighting against the might of the pressures --

00:02:36.958 --> 00:02:39.958
because of the debt, the foreign debt of Ecuador --

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:43.958
fighting the pressure of World Bank, IMF, and of course

00:02:43.958 --> 00:02:47.958
the people who want to exploit the forests and take out the oil.

00:02:48.958 --> 00:02:52.958
And so, coming directly from there to here.

00:02:52.958 --> 00:02:55.958
But, of course, my real field of expertise

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:59.958
lies in an even different kind of civilization --

00:02:59.958 --> 00:03:02.958
I can't really call it a civilization.

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:05.958
A different way of life, a different being.

00:03:06.958 --> 00:03:11.958
We've talked earlier -- this wonderful talk by Wade Davis

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:14.958
about the different cultures of the humans around the world --

00:03:14.958 --> 00:03:19.958
but the world is not composed only of human beings;

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:21.958
there are also other animal beings.

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:24.958
And I propose to bring into this TED conference,

00:03:24.958 --> 00:03:28.958
as I always do around the world, the voice of the animal kingdom.

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:31.958
Too often we just see a few slides, or a bit of film,

00:03:31.958 --> 00:03:34.958
but these beings have voices that mean something.

00:03:34.958 --> 00:03:36.958
And so, I want to give you a greeting,

00:03:36.958 --> 00:03:39.958
as from a chimpanzee in the forests of Tanzania --

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:46.958
Ooh, ooh, ooh, ooh, ooh, ooh, ooh, ooh, ooh, ooh, ooh, ooh, ooh, ooh, ooh!

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:55.958
(Applause)

00:03:56.958 --> 00:04:01.958
I've been studying chimpanzees in Tanzania since 1960.

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:05.958
During that time, there have been modern technologies

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:07.958
that have really transformed the way

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:10.958
that field biologists do their work.

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:13.958
For example, for the first time, a few years ago,

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:16.958
by simply collecting little fecal samples

00:04:16.958 --> 00:04:21.958
we were able to have them analyzed -- to have DNA profiling done --

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:25.958
so for the first time, we actually know which male chimps

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:28.958
are the fathers of each individual infant.

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:32.958
Because the chimps have a very promiscuous mating society.

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:35.958
So this opens up a whole new avenue of research.

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:42.958
And we use GSI -- geographic whatever it is, GSI --

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:46.958
to determine the range of the chimps.

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:52.958
And we're using -- you can see that I'm not really into this kind of stuff --

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:55.958
but we're using satellite imagery

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:58.958
to look at the deforestation in the area.

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:01.958
And of course, there's developments in infrared,

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:03.958
so you can watch animals at night,

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:06.958
and equipment for recording by video,

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:09.958
and tape recording is getting lighter and better.

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:12.958
So in many, many ways, we can do things today

00:05:12.958 --> 00:05:16.958
that we couldn't do when I began in 1960.

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:20.958
Especially when chimpanzees, and other animals

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:22.958
with large brains, are studied in captivity,

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:27.958
modern technology is helping us to search

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:31.958
for the upper levels of cognition in some of these non-human animals.

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:35.958
So that we know today, they're capable of performances

00:05:35.958 --> 00:05:37.958
that would have been thought absolutely impossible

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:39.958
by science when I began.

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:44.958
I think the chimpanzee in captivity who is the most skilled

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:48.958
in intellectual performance is one called Ai in Japan --

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:50.958
her name means love --

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:54.958
and she has a wonderfully sensitive partner working with her.

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:56.958
She loves her computer --

00:05:56.958 --> 00:05:59.958
she'll leave her big group, and her running water,

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:01.958
and her trees and everything.

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:03.958
And she'll come in to sit at this computer --

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:05.958
it's like a video game for a kid; she's hooked.

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:09.958
She's 28, by the way, and she does things with her computer screen

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:15.958
and a touch pad that she can do faster than most humans.

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:20.958
She does very complex tasks, and I haven't got time to go into them,

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:22.958
but the amazing thing about this female is

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:26.958
she doesn't like making mistakes.

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:29.958
If she has a bad run, and her score isn't good,

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:31.958
she'll come and reach up and tap on the glass --

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:33.958
because she can't see the experimenter --

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:36.958
which is asking to have another go.

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:39.958
And her concentration -- she's already concentrated hard

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:43.958
for 20 minutes or so, and now she wants to do it all over again,

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:46.958
just for the satisfaction of having done it better.

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:49.958
And the food is not important -- she does get a tiny reward,

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:52.958
like one raisin for a correct response --

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:56.958
but she will do it for nothing, if you tell her beforehand.

00:06:56.958 --> 00:07:01.958
So here we are, a chimpanzee using a computer.

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:05.958
Chimpanzees, gorillas, orangutans also learn human sign language.

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:10.958
But the point is that when I was first in Gombe in 1960 --

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:14.958
I remember so well, so vividly, as though it was yesterday --

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:17.958
the first time, when I was going through the vegetation,

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:20.958
the chimpanzees were still running away from me, for the most part,

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:24.958
although some were a little bit acclimatized --

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:28.958
and I saw this dark shape, hunched over a termite mound,

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:30.958
and I peered with my binoculars.

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:35.958
It was, fortunately, one adult male whom I'd named David Greybeard --

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:38.958
and by the way, science at that time was telling me that I shouldn't name the chimps;

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:40.958
they should all have numbers; that was more scientific.

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:43.958
Anyway, David Greybeard -- and I saw that

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:47.958
he was picking little pieces of grass and using them

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:50.958
to fish termites from their underground nest.

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:53.958
And not only that -- he would sometimes pick a leafy twig

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:55.958
and strip the leaves --

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:58.958
modifying an object to make it suitable for a specific purpose --

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:00.958
the beginning of tool-making.

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:03.958
The reason this was so exciting and such a breakthrough

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:06.958
is at that time, it was thought that humans,

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:09.958
and only humans, used and made tools.

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:13.958
When I was at school, we were defined as man, the toolmaker.

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:17.958
So that when Louis Leakey, my mentor, heard this news,

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:20.958
he said, "Ah, we must now redefine 'man,' redefine 'tool,'

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:23.958
or accept chimpanzees as humans."

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:25.958
(Laughter)

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:29.958
We now know that at Gombe alone, there are nine different ways

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:32.958
in which chimpanzees use different objects for different purposes.

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:35.958
Moreover, we know that in different parts of Africa,

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:37.958
wherever chimps have been studied,

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:42.958
there are completely different tool-using behaviors.

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:45.958
And because it seems that these patterns are passed

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:48.958
from one generation to the next, through observation,

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:53.958
imitation and practice -- that is a definition of human culture.

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:57.958
What we find is that over these 40-odd years

00:08:57.958 --> 00:09:00.958
that I and others have been studying chimpanzees

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:03.958
and the other great apes, and, as I say, other mammals

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:06.958
with complex brains and social systems,

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:10.958
we have found that after all, there isn't a sharp line

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:13.958
dividing humans from the rest of the animal kingdom.

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:15.958
It's a very wuzzy line.

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:18.958
It's getting wuzzier all the time as we find animals doing things

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:23.958
that we, in our arrogance, used to think was just human.

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:27.958
The chimps -- there's no time to discuss their fascinating lives --

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:30.958
but they have this long childhood, five years

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:32.958
of suckling and sleeping with the mother,

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:34.958
and then another three, four or five years

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:39.958
of emotional dependence on her, even when the next child is born.

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:42.958
The importance of learning in that time, when behavior is flexible --

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:46.958
and there's an awful lot to learn in chimpanzee society.

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:49.958
The long-term affectionate supportive bonds

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:52.958
that develop throughout this long childhood with the mother,

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:54.958
with the brothers and sisters,

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:57.958
and which can last through a lifetime,

00:09:57.958 --> 00:09:59.958
which may be up to 60 years.

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:02.958
They can actually live longer than 60 in captivity,

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:05.958
so we've only done 40 years in the wild so far.

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:10.958
And we find chimps are capable of true compassion and altruism.

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:15.958
We find in their non-verbal communication -- this is very rich --

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:20.958
they have a lot of sounds, which they use in different circumstances,

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:22.958
but they also use touch, posture, gesture,

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:24.958
and what do they do?

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:26.958
They kiss; they embrace; they hold hands.

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:29.958
They pat one another on the back; they swagger; they shake their fist --

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:32.958
the kind of things that we do,

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:34.958
and they do them in the same kind of context.

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:37.958
They have very sophisticated cooperation.

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:40.958
Sometimes they hunt -- not that often,

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:43.958
but when they hunt, they show sophisticated cooperation,

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:45.958
and they share the prey.

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:52.958
We find that they show emotions, similar to -- maybe sometimes the same --

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:57.958
as those that we describe in ourselves as happiness, sadness, fear, despair.

00:10:57.958 --> 00:10:59.958
They know mental as well as physical suffering.

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:02.958
And I don't have time to go into the information

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:04.958
that will prove some of these things to you,

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:08.958
save to say that there are very bright students, in the best universities,

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:12.958
studying emotions in animals, studying personalities in animals.

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:15.958
We know that chimpanzees and some other creatures

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:20.958
can recognize themselves in mirrors -- "self" as opposed to "other."

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:24.958
They have a sense of humor, and these are the kind of things

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:30.958
which traditionally have been thought of as human prerogatives.

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:35.958
But this teaches us a new respect -- and it's a new respect

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:38.958
not only for the chimpanzees, I suggest,

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:42.958
but some of the other amazing animals with whom we share this planet.

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:45.958
Once we're prepared to admit that after all,

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:48.958
we're not the only beings with personalities, minds

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:50.958
and above all feelings, and then we start to think

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:52.958
about ways we use and abuse

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:58.958
so many other sentient, sapient creatures on this planet,

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:03.958
it really gives cause for deep shame, at least for me.

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:09.958
So, the sad thing is that these chimpanzees --

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:13.958
who've perhaps taught us, more than any other creature, a little humility --

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:16.958
are in the wild, disappearing very fast.

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:18.958
They're disappearing for the reasons

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:21.958
that all of you in this room know only too well.

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:26.958
The deforestation, the growth of human populations, needing more land.

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:29.958
They're disappearing because some timber companies

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:31.958
go in with clear-cutting.

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:35.958
They're disappearing in the heart of their range in Africa

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:40.958
because the big multinational logging companies have come in and made roads --

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:42.958
as they want to do in Ecuador

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:44.958
and other parts where the forests remain untouched --

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:49.958
to take out oil or timber.

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:54.958
And this has led in Congo basin, and other parts of the world,

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:56.958
to what is known as the bush-meat trade.

00:12:56.958 --> 00:13:00.958
This means that although for hundreds, perhaps thousands of years,

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:04.958
people have lived in those forests, or whatever habitat it is,

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:07.958
in harmony with their world, just killing the animals they need

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:09.958
for themselves and their families --

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:12.958
now, suddenly, because of the roads,

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:14.958
the hunters can go in from the towns.

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:17.958
They shoot everything, every single thing that moves

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:22.958
that's bigger than a small rat; they sun-dry it or smoke it.

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:25.958
And now they've got transport; they take it on the logging trucks

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:29.958
or the mining trucks into the towns where they sell it.

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:34.958
And people will pay more for bush-meat, as it's called,

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:37.958
than for domestic meat -- it's culturally preferred.

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:41.958
And it's not sustainable, and the huge logging camps in the forest

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:45.958
are now demanding meat, so the Pygmy hunters in the Congo basin

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:49.958
who've lived there with their wonderful way of living

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:52.958
for so many hundreds of years are now corrupted.

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:55.958
They're given weapons; they shoot for the logging camps; they get money.

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:58.958
Their culture is being destroyed,

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:01.958
along with the animals upon whom they depend.

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:04.958
So, when the logging camp moves, there's nothing left.

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:07.958
We talked already about the loss of human cultural diversity,

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:10.958
and I've seen it happening with my own eyes.

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:14.958
And the grim picture in Africa -- I love Africa,

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:16.958
and what do we see in Africa?

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:19.958
We see deforestation;

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:24.958
we see the desert spreading; we see massive hunger;

00:14:24.958 --> 00:14:28.958
we see disease and we see population growth in areas

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:32.958
where there are more people living on a certain piece of land

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:34.958
than the land can possibly support,

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:37.958
and they're too poor to buy food from elsewhere.

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:40.958
Were the people that we heard about yesterday,

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:44.958
on the Easter Island, who cut down their last tree -- were they stupid?

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:46.958
Didn't they know what was happening?

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:48.958
Of course, but if you've seen the crippling poverty

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:50.958
in some of these parts of the world

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:53.958
it isn't a question of "Let's leave the tree for tomorrow."

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:55.958
"How am I going to feed my family today?

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:58.958
Maybe I can get just a few dollars from this last tree

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:00.958
which will keep us going a little bit longer,

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:03.958
and then we'll pray that something will happen

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:06.958
to save us from the inevitable end."

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:09.958
So, this is a pretty grim picture.

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:13.958
The one thing we have, which makes us so different

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:15.958
from chimpanzees or other living creatures,

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:18.958
is this sophisticated spoken language --

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:20.958
a language with which we can tell children

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:22.958
about things that aren't here.

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:26.958
We can talk about the distant past, plan for the distant future,

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:28.958
discuss ideas with each other,

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:32.958
so that the ideas can grow from the accumulated wisdom of a group.

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:34.958
We can do it by talking to each other;

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:38.958
we can do it through video; we can do it through the written word.

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:43.958
And we are abusing this great power we have to be wise stewards,

00:15:43.958 --> 00:15:45.958
and we're destroying the world.

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:48.958
In the developed world, in a way, it's worse,

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:51.958
because we have so much access to knowledge

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:53.958
of the stupidity of what we're doing.

00:15:53.958 --> 00:15:56.958
Do you know, we're bringing little babies

00:15:56.958 --> 00:16:01.958
into a world where, in many places, the water is poisoning them?

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:05.958
And the air is harming them, and the food that's grown

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:08.958
from the contaminated land is poisoning them.

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:12.958
And that's not just in the far-away developing world; that's everywhere.

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:14.958
Do you know we all have about 50 chemicals

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:18.958
in our bodies we didn't have about 50 years ago?

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:22.958
And so many of these diseases, like asthma

00:16:22.958 --> 00:16:25.958
and certain kinds of cancers, are on the increase

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:30.958
around places where our filthy toxic waste is dumped.

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:33.958
We're harming ourselves around the world,

00:16:33.958 --> 00:16:37.958
as well as harming the animals, as well as harming nature herself --

00:16:37.958 --> 00:16:40.958
Mother Nature, that brought us into being;

00:16:40.958 --> 00:16:44.958
Mother Nature, where I believe we need to spend time,

00:16:44.958 --> 00:16:46.958
where there's trees and flowers and birds

00:16:46.958 --> 00:16:49.958
for our good psychological development.

00:16:49.958 --> 00:16:52.958
And yet, there are hundreds and hundreds of children

00:16:52.958 --> 00:16:54.958
in the developed world who never see nature,

00:16:54.958 --> 00:16:56.958
because they're growing up in concrete

00:16:56.958 --> 00:16:58.958
and all they know is virtual reality,

00:16:58.958 --> 00:17:02.958
with no opportunity to go and lie in the sun,

00:17:02.958 --> 00:17:05.958
or in the forest, with the dappled sun-specks

00:17:05.958 --> 00:17:08.958
coming down from the canopy above.

00:17:08.958 --> 00:17:11.958
As I was traveling around the world, you know,

00:17:11.958 --> 00:17:14.958
I had to leave the forest -- that's where I love to be.

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:17.958
I had to leave these fascinating chimpanzees

00:17:17.958 --> 00:17:21.958
for my students and field staff to continue studying

00:17:21.958 --> 00:17:24.958
because, finding they dwindled from about two million

00:17:24.958 --> 00:17:28.958
100 years ago to about 150,000 now,

00:17:28.958 --> 00:17:31.958
I knew I had to leave the forest to do what I could

00:17:31.958 --> 00:17:33.958
to raise awareness around the world.

00:17:33.958 --> 00:17:36.958
And the more I talked about the chimpanzees' plight,

00:17:36.958 --> 00:17:41.958
the more I realized the fact that everything's interconnected,

00:17:41.958 --> 00:17:43.958
and the problems of the developing world

00:17:43.958 --> 00:17:46.958
so often stem from the greed of the developed world,

00:17:46.958 --> 00:17:51.958
and everything was joining together, and making -- not sense,

00:17:51.958 --> 00:17:55.958
hope lies in sense, you said -- it's making a nonsense.

00:17:55.958 --> 00:17:56.958
How can we do it?

00:17:56.958 --> 00:17:58.958
Somebody said that yesterday.

00:17:58.958 --> 00:18:03.958
And as I was traveling around, I kept meeting young people who'd lost hope.

00:18:03.958 --> 00:18:06.958
They were feeling despair,

00:18:06.958 --> 00:18:09.958
they were feeling, "Well, it doesn't matter what we do;

00:18:09.958 --> 00:18:11.958
eat, drink and be merry, for tomorrow we die.

00:18:11.958 --> 00:18:15.958
Everything is hopeless -- we're always being told so by the media."

00:18:15.958 --> 00:18:18.958
And then I met some who were angry,

00:18:18.958 --> 00:18:20.958
and anger that can turn to violence,

00:18:20.958 --> 00:18:23.958
and we're all familiar with that.

00:18:23.958 --> 00:18:27.958
And I have three little grandchildren,

00:18:27.958 --> 00:18:30.958
and when some of these students would say to me

00:18:30.958 --> 00:18:33.958
at high school or university, they'd say, "We're angry,"

00:18:33.958 --> 00:18:36.958
or "We're filled with despair, because we feel

00:18:36.958 --> 00:18:40.958
you've compromised our future, and there's nothing we can do about it."

00:18:40.958 --> 00:18:42.958
And I looked in the eyes of my little grandchildren,

00:18:42.958 --> 00:18:46.958
and think how much we've harmed this planet since I was their age.

00:18:46.958 --> 00:18:52.958
I feel this deep shame, and that's why in 1991 in Tanzania,

00:18:52.958 --> 00:18:55.958
I started a program that's called Roots and Shoots.

00:18:55.958 --> 00:18:59.958
There's little brochures all around outside,

00:18:59.958 --> 00:19:03.958
and if any of you have anything to do with children and care about their future,

00:19:03.958 --> 00:19:06.958
I beg that you pick up that brochure.

00:19:06.958 --> 00:19:10.958
And Roots and Shoots is a program for hope.

00:19:10.958 --> 00:19:12.958
Roots make a firm foundation.

00:19:12.958 --> 00:19:14.958
Shoots seem tiny,

00:19:14.958 --> 00:19:17.958
but to reach the sun they can break through brick walls.

00:19:17.958 --> 00:19:19.958
See the brick walls as all the problems

00:19:19.958 --> 00:19:21.958
that we've inflicted on this planet.

00:19:21.958 --> 00:19:25.958
Then, you see, it is a message of hope.

00:19:25.958 --> 00:19:27.958
Hundreds and thousands of young people around the world

00:19:27.958 --> 00:19:31.958
can break through, and can make this a better world.

00:19:31.958 --> 00:19:34.958
And the most important message of Roots and Shoots

00:19:34.958 --> 00:19:38.958
is that every single individual makes a difference.

00:19:38.958 --> 00:19:40.958
Every individual has a role to play.

00:19:40.958 --> 00:19:44.958
Every one of us impacts the world around us everyday,

00:19:44.958 --> 00:19:47.958
and you scientists know that you can't actually --

00:19:47.958 --> 00:19:50.958
even if you stay in bed all day, you're breathing oxygen

00:19:50.958 --> 00:19:54.958
and giving out CO2, and probably going to the loo,

00:19:54.958 --> 00:19:56.958
and things like that --

00:19:56.958 --> 00:19:58.958
you're making a difference in the world.

00:19:58.958 --> 00:20:01.958
So, the Roots and Shoots program

00:20:01.958 --> 00:20:06.958
involves youth in three kinds of projects.

00:20:06.958 --> 00:20:10.958
And these are projects to make the world around them a better place.

00:20:10.958 --> 00:20:16.958
One project to show care and concern for your own human community.

00:20:16.958 --> 00:20:20.958
One for animals, including domestic animals -- and I have to say,

00:20:20.958 --> 00:20:22.958
I learned everything I know about animal behavior

00:20:22.958 --> 00:20:26.958
even before I got to Gombe and the chimps from my dog, Rusty,

00:20:26.958 --> 00:20:29.958
who was my childhood companion.

00:20:29.958 --> 00:20:33.958
And the third kind of project: something for the local environment.

00:20:34.958 --> 00:20:38.958
So what the kids do depends first of all, how old are they --

00:20:38.958 --> 00:20:42.958
and we go now from pre-school right through university.

00:20:42.958 --> 00:20:45.958
It's going to depend whether they're inner-city or rural.

00:20:45.958 --> 00:20:50.958
It's going to depend if they're wealthy or impoverished.

00:20:50.958 --> 00:20:53.958
It's going to depend which part, say, of America they're in.

00:20:53.958 --> 00:20:56.958
We're in every state now, and the problems in Florida

00:20:56.958 --> 00:20:58.958
are different from the problems in New York.

00:20:59.958 --> 00:21:01.958
It's going to depend on which country they're in --

00:21:01.958 --> 00:21:07.958
and we're already in 60-plus countries, with about 5,000 active groups --

00:21:07.958 --> 00:21:11.958
and there are groups all over the place that I keep hearing about

00:21:11.958 --> 00:21:14.958
that I've never even heard of, because the kids are taking the program

00:21:14.958 --> 00:21:16.958
and spreading it themselves.

00:21:16.958 --> 00:21:18.958
Why?

00:21:18.958 --> 00:21:20.958
Because they're buying into it,

00:21:20.958 --> 00:21:23.958
and they're the ones who get to decide what they're going to do.

00:21:23.958 --> 00:21:25.958
It isn't something that their parents tell them,

00:21:25.958 --> 00:21:27.958
or their teachers tell them.

00:21:27.958 --> 00:21:30.958
That's effective, but if they decide themselves,

00:21:30.958 --> 00:21:33.958
"We want to clean this river

00:21:33.958 --> 00:21:35.958
and put the fish back that used to be there.

00:21:35.958 --> 00:21:40.958
We want to clear away the toxic soil

00:21:40.958 --> 00:21:42.958
from this area and have an organic garden.

00:21:42.958 --> 00:21:45.958
We want to go and spend time with the old people

00:21:45.958 --> 00:21:49.958
and hear their stories and record their oral histories.

00:21:50.958 --> 00:21:52.958
We want to go and work in a dog shelter.

00:21:52.958 --> 00:21:54.958
We want to learn about animals. We want ... "

00:21:54.958 --> 00:21:58.958
You know, it goes on and on, and this is very hopeful for me.

00:21:58.958 --> 00:22:02.958
As I travel around the world 300 days a year,

00:22:02.958 --> 00:22:05.958
everywhere there's a group of Roots and Shoots of different ages.

00:22:05.958 --> 00:22:07.958
Everywhere there are children with shining eyes saying,

00:22:07.958 --> 00:22:10.958
"Look at the difference we've made."

00:22:10.958 --> 00:22:12.958
And now comes the technology into it,

00:22:12.958 --> 00:22:17.958
because with this new way of communicating electronically

00:22:17.958 --> 00:22:21.958
these kids can communicate with each other around the world.

00:22:21.958 --> 00:22:24.958
And if anyone is interested to help us, we've got so many ideas

00:22:24.958 --> 00:22:30.958
but we need help -- we need help to create the right kind of system

00:22:30.958 --> 00:22:34.958
that will help these young people to communicate their excitement.

00:22:34.958 --> 00:22:39.958
But also -- and this is so important -- to communicate their despair,

00:22:39.958 --> 00:22:42.958
to say, "We've tried this and it doesn't work, and what shall we do?"

00:22:42.958 --> 00:22:46.958
And then, lo and behold, there's another group answering these kids

00:22:46.958 --> 00:22:49.958
who may be in America, or maybe this is a group in Israel,

00:22:49.958 --> 00:22:54.958
saying, "Yeah, you did it a little bit wrong. This is how you should do it."

00:22:54.958 --> 00:22:57.958
The philosophy is very simple.

00:22:57.958 --> 00:23:00.958
We do not believe in violence.

00:23:00.958 --> 00:23:03.958
No violence, no bombs, no guns.

00:23:03.958 --> 00:23:05.958
That's not the way to solve problems.

00:23:05.958 --> 00:23:09.958
Violence leads to violence, at least in my view.

00:23:09.958 --> 00:23:11.958
So how do we solve?

00:23:11.958 --> 00:23:16.958
The tools for solving the problems are knowledge and understanding.

00:23:16.958 --> 00:23:19.958
Know the facts, but see how they fit in the big picture.

00:23:19.958 --> 00:23:22.958
Hard work and persistence --don't give up --

00:23:22.958 --> 00:23:27.958
and love and compassion leading to respect for all life.

00:23:27.958 --> 00:23:29.958
How many more minutes? Two, one?

00:23:29.958 --> 00:23:31.958
Chris Anderson: One -- one to two.

00:23:31.958 --> 00:23:33.958
Jane Goodall: Two, two, I'm going to take two.

00:23:33.958 --> 00:23:34.958
(Laughter)

00:23:34.958 --> 00:23:36.958
Are you going to come and drag me off?

00:23:36.958 --> 00:23:38.958
(Laughter)

00:23:38.958 --> 00:23:42.958
Anyway -- so basically, Roots and Shoots

00:23:42.958 --> 00:23:45.958
is beginning to change young people's lives.

00:23:45.958 --> 00:23:49.958
It's what I'm devoting most of my energy to.

00:23:49.958 --> 00:23:56.958
And I believe that a group like this can have a very major impact,

00:23:56.958 --> 00:23:59.958
not just because you can share technology with us,

00:23:59.958 --> 00:24:02.958
but because so many of you have children.

00:24:02.958 --> 00:24:07.958
And if you take this program out, and give it to your children,

00:24:07.958 --> 00:24:11.958
they have such a good opportunity to go out and do good,

00:24:11.958 --> 00:24:13.958
because they've got parents like you.

00:24:13.958 --> 00:24:17.958
And it's been so clear how much you all care

00:24:17.958 --> 00:24:19.958
about trying to make this world a better place.

00:24:19.958 --> 00:24:21.958
It's very encouraging.

00:24:21.958 --> 00:24:23.958
But the kids do ask me --

00:24:23.958 --> 00:24:25.958
and this won't take more than two minutes, I promise --

00:24:25.958 --> 00:24:30.958
the kids say, "Dr. Jane, do you really have hope for the future?

00:24:30.958 --> 00:24:34.958
You travel, you see all these horrible things happening."

00:24:34.958 --> 00:24:38.958
Firstly, the human brain -- I don't need to say anything about that.

00:24:38.958 --> 00:24:41.958
Now that we know what the problems are around the world,

00:24:41.958 --> 00:24:45.958
human brains like yours are rising to solve those problems.

00:24:45.958 --> 00:24:47.958
And we've talked a lot about that.

00:24:47.958 --> 00:24:50.958
Secondly, the resilience of nature.

00:24:50.958 --> 00:24:52.958
We can destroy a river,

00:24:52.958 --> 00:24:54.958
and we can bring it back to life.

00:24:54.958 --> 00:24:59.958
We can see a whole area desolated,

00:24:59.958 --> 00:25:04.958
and it can be brought back to bloom again, with time or a little help.

00:25:04.958 --> 00:25:10.958
And thirdly, the last speaker talked about -- or the speaker before last,

00:25:10.958 --> 00:25:13.958
talked about the indomitable human spirit.

00:25:13.958 --> 00:25:17.958
We are surrounded by the most amazing people

00:25:17.958 --> 00:25:21.958
who do things that seem to be absolutely impossible.

00:25:21.958 --> 00:25:24.958
Nelson Mandela -- I take a little piece of limestone

00:25:24.958 --> 00:25:27.958
from Robben Island Prison, where he labored for 27 years,

00:25:27.958 --> 00:25:32.958
and came out with so little bitterness, he could lead his people

00:25:32.958 --> 00:25:35.958
from the horror of apartheid without a bloodbath.

00:25:35.958 --> 00:25:39.958
Even after the 11th of September -- and I was in New York

00:25:39.958 --> 00:25:45.958
and I felt the fear -- nevertheless, there was so much human courage,

00:25:45.958 --> 00:25:48.958
so much love and so much compassion.

00:25:48.958 --> 00:25:52.958
And then as I went around the country after that and felt the fear --

00:25:52.958 --> 00:25:54.958
the fear that was leading to people feeling

00:25:54.958 --> 00:25:56.958
they couldn't worry about the environment any more,

00:25:56.958 --> 00:25:59.958
in case they seemed not to be patriotic --

00:25:59.958 --> 00:26:01.958
and I was trying to encourage them,

00:26:01.958 --> 00:26:04.958
somebody came up with a little quotation from Mahatma Gandhi,

00:26:04.958 --> 00:26:07.958
"If you look back through human history,

00:26:07.958 --> 00:26:10.958
you see that every evil regime has been overcome by good."

00:26:11.958 --> 00:26:15.958
And just after that a woman brought me this little bell,

00:26:15.958 --> 00:26:17.958
and I want to end on this note.

00:26:17.958 --> 00:26:20.958
She said, "If you're talking about hope and peace, ring this.

00:26:22.958 --> 00:26:28.958
This bell is made from metal from a defused landmine,

00:26:28.958 --> 00:26:31.958
from the killing fields of Pol Pot --

00:26:31.958 --> 00:26:34.958
one of the most evil regimes in human history --

00:26:34.958 --> 00:26:38.958
where people are now beginning to put their lives back together

00:26:38.958 --> 00:26:41.958
after the regime has crumbled.

00:26:41.958 --> 00:26:45.958
So, yes, there is hope, and where is the hope?

00:26:45.958 --> 00:26:48.958
Is it out there with the politicians?

00:26:49.958 --> 00:26:51.958
It's in our hands.

00:26:51.958 --> 00:26:53.958
It's in your hands and my hands

00:26:53.958 --> 00:26:55.958
and those of our children.

00:26:55.958 --> 00:26:57.958
It's really up to us.

00:26:57.958 --> 00:26:59.958
We're the ones who can make a difference.

00:26:59.958 --> 00:27:01.958
If we lead lives where we consciously leave

00:27:01.958 --> 00:27:05.958
the lightest possible ecological footprints,

00:27:05.958 --> 00:27:08.958
if we buy the things that are ethical for us to buy

00:27:08.958 --> 00:27:11.958
and don't buy the things that are not,

00:27:11.958 --> 00:27:14.958
we can change the world overnight.

00:27:14.958 --> 00:27:15.958
Thank you.

title: How to get your ideas to spread
transcript: I'm going to give you four specific examples, I'm going to cover at the end about how a company called Silk tripled their sales; how an artist named Jeff Koons went from being a nobody to making a whole bunch of money and having a lot of impact; to how Frank Gehry redefined what it meant to be an architect. And one of my biggest failures as a marketer in the last few years — a record label I started that had a CD called "Sauce."Before I can do that I've got to tell you about sliced bread, and a guy named Otto Rohwedder. Now, before sliced bread was invented in the 1910s I wonder what they said? Like the greatest invention since the telegraph or something. But this guy named Otto Rohwedder invented sliced bread, and he focused, like most inventors did, on the patent part and the making part. And the thing about the invention of sliced bread is this — that for the first 15 years after sliced bread was available no one bought it; no one knew about it; it was a complete and total failure. And the reason is that until Wonder came along and figured out how to spread the idea of sliced bread, no one wanted it. That the success of sliced bread, like the success of almost everything we've talked about at this conference, is not always about what the patent is like, or what the factory is like — it's about can you get your idea to spread, or not. And I think that the way you're going to get what you want, or cause the change that you want to change, to happen, is to figure out a way to get your ideas to spread.And it doesn't matter to me whether you're running a coffee shop or you're an intellectual, or you're in business, or you're flying hot air balloons. I think that all this stuff applies to everybody regardless of what we do. That what we are living in is a century of idea diffusion. That people who can spread ideas, regardless of what those ideas are, win. When I talk about it I usually pick business, because they make the best pictures that you can put in your presentation, and because it's the easiest sort of way to keep score. But I want you to forgive me when I use these examples because I'm talking about anything that you decide to spend your time to do.At the heart of spreading ideas is TV and stuff like TV. TV and mass media made it really easy to spread ideas in a certain way. I call it the "TV-industrial complex." The way the TV-industrial complex works, is you buy some ads, interrupt some people, that gets you distribution. You use the distribution you get to sell more products. You take the profit from that to buy more ads. And it goes around and around and around, the same way that the military-industrial complex worked a long time ago. That model of, and we heard it yesterday — if we could only get onto the homepage of Google, if we could only figure out how to get promoted there, or grab that person by the throat, and tell them about what we want to do. If we did that then everyone would pay attention, and we would win. Well, this TV-industrial complex informed my entire childhood and probably yours. I mean, all of these products succeeded because someone figured out how to touch people in a way they weren't expecting, in a way they didn't necessarily want, with an ad, over and over again until they bought it.And the thing that's happened is, they canceled the TV-industrial complex. That just over the last few years, what anybody who markets anything has discovered is that it's not working the way that it used to. This picture is really fuzzy, I apologize; I had a bad cold when I took it.(Laughter)But the product in the blue box in the center is my poster child. I go to the deli; I'm sick; I need to buy some medicine. The brand manager for that blue product spent 100 million dollars trying to interrupt me in one year. 100 million dollars interrupting me with TV commercials and magazine ads and Spam and coupons and shelving allowances and spiff — all so I could ignore every single message. And I ignored every message because I don't have a pain reliever problem. I buy the stuff in the yellow box because I always have. And I'm not going to invest a minute of my time to solve her problem, because I don't care.Here's a magazine called "Hydrate." It's 180 pages about water.(Laughter)Articles about water, ads about water. Imagine what the world was like 40 years ago, with just the Saturday Evening Post and Time and Newsweek. Now there are magazines about water. New product from Coke Japan: water salad.(Laughter)Coke Japan comes out with a new product every three weeks, because they have no idea what's going to work and what's not. I couldn't have written this better myself. It came out four days ago — I circled the important parts so you can see them here. They've come out... Arby's is going to spend 85 million dollars promoting an oven mitt with the voice of Tom Arnold, hoping that that will get people to go to Arby's and buy a roast beef sandwich.(Laughter)Now, I had tried to imagine what could possibly be in an animated TV commercial featuring Tom Arnold, that would get you to get in your car, drive across town and buy a roast beef sandwich.(Laughter)Now, this is Copernicus, and he was right, when he was talking to anyone who needs to hear your idea. "The world revolves around me." Me, me, me, me. My favorite person — me. I don't want to get email from anybody; I want to get "memail."(Laughter)So consumers, and I don't just mean people who buy stuff at the Safeway; I mean people at the Defense Department who might buy something, or people at, you know, the New Yorker who might print your article. Consumers don't care about you at all; they just don't care. Part of the reason is — they've got way more choices than they used to, and way less time. And in a world where we have too many choices and too little time, the obvious thing to do is just ignore stuff. And my parable here is you're driving down the road and you see a cow, and you keep driving because you've seen cows before. Cows are invisible. Cows are boring. Who's going to stop and pull over and say — "Oh, look, a cow." Nobody.(Laughter)But if the cow was purple — isn't that a great special effect? I could do that again if you want. If the cow was purple, you'd notice it for a while. I mean, if all cows were purple you'd get bored with those, too. The thing that's going to decide what gets talked about, what gets done, what gets changed, what gets purchased, what gets built, is: "Is it remarkable?" And "remarkable" is a really cool word, because we think it just means "neat," but it also means "worth making a remark about." And that is the essence of where idea diffusion is going. That two of the hottest cars in the United States is a 55,000-dollar giant car, big enough to hold a Mini in its trunk. People are paying full price for both, and the only thing they have in common is that they don't have anything in common.(Laughter)Every week, the number one best-selling DVD in America changes. It's never "The Godfather," it's never "Citizen Kane," it's always some third-rate movie with some second-rate star. But the reason it's number one is because that's the week it came out. Because it's new, because it's fresh. People saw it and said "I didn't know that was there" and they noticed it. Two of the big success stories of the last 20 years in retail — one sells things that are super-expensive in a blue box, and one sells things that are as cheap as they can make them. The only thing they have in common is that they're different.We're now in the fashion business, no matter what we do for a living, we're in the fashion business. And people in the fashion business know what it's like to be in the fashion business — they're used to it. The rest of us have to figure out how to think that way. How to understand that it's not about interrupting people with big full-page ads, or insisting on meetings with people. But it's a totally different sort of process that determines which ideas spread, and which ones don't. They sold a billion dollars' worth of Aeron chairs by reinventing what it meant to sell a chair. They turned a chair from something the purchasing department bought, to something that was a status symbol about where you sat at work. This guy, Lionel Poilâne, the most famous baker in the world — he died two and a half months ago, and he was a hero of mine and a dear friend. He lived in Paris. Last year, he sold 10 million dollars' worth of French bread. Every loaf baked in a bakery he owned, by one baker at a time, in a wood-fired oven. And when Lionel started his bakery, the French pooh-pooh-ed it. They didn't want to buy his bread. It didn't look like "French bread." It wasn't what they expected. It was neat; it was remarkable; and slowly, it spread from one person to another person until finally, it became the official bread of three-star restaurants in Paris. Now he's in London, and he ships by FedEx all around the world.What marketers used to do is make average products for average people. That's what mass marketing is. Smooth out the edges; go for the center; that's the big market. They would ignore the geeks, and God forbid, the laggards. It was all about going for the center. But in a world where the TV-industrial complex is broken, I don't think that's a strategy we want to use any more. I think the strategy we want to use is to not market to these people because they're really good at ignoring you. But market to these people because they care. These are the people who are obsessed with something. And when you talk to them, they'll listen, because they like listening — it's about them. And if you're lucky, they'll tell their friends on the rest of the curve, and it'll spread. It'll spread to the entire curve.They have something I call "otaku" — it's a great Japanese word. It describes the desire of someone who's obsessed to say, drive across Tokyo to try a new ramen noodle place, because that's what they do: they get obsessed with it. To make a product, to market an idea, to come up with any problem you want to solve that doesn't have a constituency with an otaku, is almost impossible. Instead, you have to find a group that really, desperately cares about what it is you have to say. Talk to them and make it easy for them to tell their friends. There's a hot sauce otaku, but there's no mustard otaku. That's why there's lots and lots of kinds of hot sauces, and not so many kinds of mustard. Not because it's hard to make interesting mustard — you could make interesting mustard — but people don't, because no one's obsessed with it, and thus no one tells their friends. Krispy Kreme has figured this whole thing out.
