It has a strategy, and what they do is, they enter a city, they talk to the people, with the otaku, and then they spread through the city to the people who've just crossed the street.This yoyo right here cost 112 dollars, but it sleeps for 12 minutes. Not everybody wants it but they don't care. They want to talk to the people who do, and maybe it'll spread. These guys make the loudest car stereo in the world.(Laughter)It's as loud as a 747 jet.You can't get in, the car's got bulletproof glass, because it'll blow out the windshield otherwise. But the fact remains that when someone wants to put a couple of speakers in their car, if they've got the otaku or they've heard from someone who does, they go ahead and they pick this.It's really simple — you sell to the people who are listening, and just maybe, those people tell their friends. So when Steve Jobs talks to 50,000 people at his keynote, who are all tuned in from 130 countries watching his two-hour commercial — that's the only thing keeping his company in business — it's that those 50,000 people care desperately enough to watch a two-hour commercial, and then tell their friends. Pearl Jam, 96 albums released in the last two years. Every one made a profit. How? They only sell them on their website. Those people who buy them have the otaku, and then they tell their friends, and it spreads and it spreads. This hospital crib cost 10,000 dollars, 10 times the standard. But hospitals are buying it faster than any other model. Hard Candy nail polish, doesn't appeal to everybody, but to the people who love it, they talk about it like crazy. This paint can right here saved the Dutch Boy paint company, making them a fortune. It costs 35 percent more than regular paint because Dutch Boy made a can that people talk about, because it's remarkable. They didn't just slap a new ad on the product; they changed what it meant to build a paint product. AmIhotornot.com — everyday 250,000 people go to this site, run by two volunteers, and I can tell you they are hard graders —(Laughter)They didn't get this way by advertising a lot. They got this way by being remarkable, sometimes a little too remarkable. And this picture frame has a cord going out the back, and you plug it into the wall. My father has this on his desk, and he sees his grandchildren everyday, changing constantly. And every single person who walks into his office hears the whole story of how this thing ended up on his desk. And one person at a time, the idea spreads. These are not diamonds, not really. They're made from "cremains." After you're cremated you can have yourself made into a gem.(Laughter)Oh, you like my ring? It's my grandmother.(Laughter)Fastest-growing business in the whole mortuary industry. But you don't have to be Ozzie Osborne — you don't have to be super-outrageous to do this. What you have to do is figure out what people really want and give it to them.A couple of quick rules to wrap up. The first one is: Design is free when you get to scale. The people who come up with stuff that's remarkable more often than not figure out how to put design to work for them. Number two: The riskiest thing you can do now is be safe. Proctor and Gamble knows this, right? The whole model of being Proctor and Gamble is always about average products for average people. That's risky. The safe thing to do now is to be at the fringes, be remarkable. And being very good is one of the worst things you can possibly do. Very good is boring. Very good is average. It doesn't matter whether you're making a record album, or you're an architect, or you have a tract on sociology. If it's very good, it's not going to work, because no one's going to notice it.So my three stories. Silk put a product that does not need to be in the refrigerated section next to the milk in the refrigerated section. Sales tripled. Why? Milk, milk, milk, milk, milk — not milk. For the people who were there and looking at that section, it was remarkable. They didn't triple their sales with advertising; they tripled it by doing something remarkable. That is a remarkable piece of art. You don't have to like it, but a 40-foot tall dog made out of bushes in the middle of New York City is remarkable.(Laughter)Frank Gehry didn't just change a museum; he changed an entire city's economy by designing one building that people from all over the world went to see. Now, at countless meetings at, you know, the Portland City Council, or who knows where, they said, we need an architect — can we get Frank Gehry? Because he did something that was at the fringes. And my big failure? I came out with an entire —(Music)A record album and hopefully a whole bunch of record albums in SACD, this remarkable new format — and I marketed it straight to people with 20,000-dollar stereos. People with 20,000-dollar stereos don't like new music.(Laughter)So what you need to do is figure out who does care. Who is going to raise their hand and say, "I want to hear what you're doing next," and sell something to them. The last example I want to give you. This is a map of Soap Lake, Washington. As you can see, if that's nowhere, it's in the middle of it.(Laughter)But they do have a lake. And people used to come from miles around to swim in the lake. They don't anymore. So the founding fathers said, "We've got some money to spend. What can we build here?" And like most committees, they were going to build something pretty safe. And then an artist came to them — this is a true artist's rendering — he wants to build a 55-foot tall lava lamp in the center of town. That's a purple cow; that's something worth noticing. I don't know about you, but if they build it, that's where I'm going to go.Thank you very much for your attention.

is not always about what the patent
is like, or what the factory is like --

00:01:32.792 --> 00:01:35.434
it's about can you get
your idea to spread, or not.

00:01:36.192 --> 00:01:39.446
And I think that the way
you're going to get what you want,

00:01:39.470 --> 00:01:42.390
or cause the change that you want
to change, to happen,

00:01:42.414 --> 00:01:44.882
is to figure out a way
to get your ideas to spread.

00:01:44.906 --> 00:01:48.154
And it doesn't matter to me
whether you're running a coffee shop

00:01:48.178 --> 00:01:50.468
or you're an intellectual,
or you're in business,

00:01:50.492 --> 00:01:52.733
or you're flying hot air balloons.

00:01:53.035 --> 00:01:58.780
I think that all this stuff applies
to everybody regardless of what we do.

00:01:59.200 --> 00:02:03.994
That what we are living in
is a century of idea diffusion.

00:02:04.018 --> 00:02:08.276
That people who can spread ideas,
regardless of what those ideas are, win.

00:02:08.681 --> 00:02:10.852
When I talk about it
I usually pick business,

00:02:10.876 --> 00:02:14.381
because they make the best pictures
that you can put in your presentation,

00:02:14.405 --> 00:02:17.071
and because it's the easiest
sort of way to keep score.

00:02:17.095 --> 00:02:19.653
But I want you to forgive me
when I use these examples

00:02:19.677 --> 00:02:23.278
because I'm talking about anything
that you decide to spend your time to do.

00:02:23.302 --> 00:02:27.744
At the heart of spreading ideas
is TV and stuff like TV.

00:02:28.306 --> 00:02:34.904
TV and mass media made it really easy
to spread ideas in a certain way.

00:02:34.928 --> 00:02:36.944
I call it the "TV-industrial complex."

00:02:37.277 --> 00:02:40.396
The way the TV-industrial complex works,
is you buy some ads,

00:02:40.420 --> 00:02:42.983
interrupt some people,
that gets you distribution.

00:02:43.493 --> 00:02:46.729
You use the distribution you get
to sell more products.

00:02:47.261 --> 00:02:50.872
You take the profit
from that to buy more ads.

00:02:50.896 --> 00:02:52.872
And it goes around and around and around,

00:02:52.896 --> 00:02:56.373
the same way that the military-industrial
complex worked a long time ago.

00:02:56.397 --> 00:02:58.444
That model of,
and we heard it yesterday --

00:02:58.468 --> 00:03:00.761
if we could only get
onto the homepage of Google,

00:03:00.785 --> 00:03:03.324
if we could only figure out
how to get promoted there,

00:03:03.348 --> 00:03:05.062
or grab that person by the throat,

00:03:05.086 --> 00:03:07.851
and tell them about what we want to do.

00:03:07.875 --> 00:03:11.434
If we did that then everyone would pay
attention, and we would win.

00:03:11.827 --> 00:03:17.233
Well, this TV-industrial complex informed
my entire childhood and probably yours.

00:03:17.257 --> 00:03:22.026
I mean, all of these products succeeded
because someone figured out

00:03:22.050 --> 00:03:25.114
how to touch people in a way
they weren't expecting,

00:03:25.138 --> 00:03:27.478
in a way they didn't
necessarily want, with an ad,

00:03:27.502 --> 00:03:29.731
over and over again until they bought it.

00:03:29.755 --> 00:03:33.689
And the thing that's happened is,
they canceled the TV-industrial complex.

00:03:34.260 --> 00:03:36.562
That just over the last few years,

00:03:36.586 --> 00:03:39.410
what anybody who markets
anything has discovered

00:03:39.434 --> 00:03:41.854
is that it's not working
the way that it used to.

00:03:41.878 --> 00:03:45.467
This picture is really fuzzy, I apologize;
I had a bad cold when I took it.

00:03:45.491 --> 00:03:47.046
(Laughter)

00:03:47.070 --> 00:03:50.565
But the product in the blue box
in the center is my poster child.

00:03:50.589 --> 00:03:53.557
I go to the deli; I'm sick;
I need to buy some medicine.

00:03:53.978 --> 00:03:57.315
The brand manager for that blue product
spent 100 million dollars

00:03:57.339 --> 00:03:59.022
trying to interrupt me in one year.

00:03:59.046 --> 00:04:02.312
100 million dollars interrupting me
with TV commercials

00:04:02.336 --> 00:04:04.204
and magazine ads and Spam

00:04:04.228 --> 00:04:07.028
and coupons and shelving
allowances and spiff --

00:04:07.052 --> 00:04:09.434
all so I could ignore
every single message.

00:04:09.972 --> 00:04:12.005
And I ignored every message

00:04:12.029 --> 00:04:14.147
because I don't have
a pain reliever problem.

00:04:14.171 --> 00:04:16.827
I buy the stuff in the yellow box
because I always have.

00:04:16.851 --> 00:04:21.106
And I'm not going to invest a minute
of my time to solve her problem,

00:04:21.130 --> 00:04:22.435
because I don't care.

00:04:23.114 --> 00:04:28.677
Here's a magazine called "Hydrate."
It's 180 pages about water.

00:04:28.701 --> 00:04:29.702
(Laughter)

00:04:29.726 --> 00:04:32.416
Articles about water, ads about water.

00:04:32.440 --> 00:04:35.552
Imagine what the world
was like 40 years ago,

00:04:35.576 --> 00:04:38.300
with just the Saturday Evening Post
and Time and Newsweek.

00:04:38.324 --> 00:04:40.088
Now there are magazines about water.

00:04:40.112 --> 00:04:42.836
New product from Coke Japan: water salad.

00:04:43.294 --> 00:04:44.319
(Laughter)

00:04:44.343 --> 00:04:48.977
Coke Japan comes out
with a new product every three weeks,

00:04:49.001 --> 00:04:52.517
because they have no idea
what's going to work and what's not.

00:04:52.541 --> 00:04:54.626
I couldn't have written
this better myself.

00:04:54.650 --> 00:04:56.168
It came out four days ago --

00:04:56.192 --> 00:04:58.764
I circled the important parts
so you can see them here.

00:05:00.064 --> 00:05:01.223
They've come out...

00:05:01.247 --> 00:05:05.788
Arby's is going to spend
85 million dollars promoting an oven mitt

00:05:05.812 --> 00:05:08.137
with the voice of Tom Arnold,

00:05:08.161 --> 00:05:13.009
hoping that that will get people to go
to Arby's and buy a roast beef sandwich.

00:05:13.033 --> 00:05:14.039
(Laughter)

00:05:14.063 --> 00:05:19.587
Now, I had tried to imagine what could
possibly be in an animated TV commercial

00:05:19.611 --> 00:05:23.119
featuring Tom Arnold,
that would get you to get in your car,

00:05:23.143 --> 00:05:26.333
drive across town
and buy a roast beef sandwich.

00:05:26.357 --> 00:05:27.730
(Laughter)

00:05:27.754 --> 00:05:31.134
Now, this is Copernicus, and he was right,

00:05:31.158 --> 00:05:33.895
when he was talking to anyone
who needs to hear your idea.

00:05:33.919 --> 00:05:35.571
"The world revolves around me."

00:05:35.595 --> 00:05:38.195
Me, me, me, me. My favorite person -- me.

00:05:38.610 --> 00:05:41.896
I don't want to get email
from anybody; I want to get "memail."

00:05:41.920 --> 00:05:43.434
(Laughter)

00:05:43.458 --> 00:05:49.108
So consumers, and I don't just mean
people who buy stuff at the Safeway;

00:05:49.132 --> 00:05:52.244
I mean people at the Defense Department
who might buy something,

00:05:52.268 --> 00:05:55.490
or people at, you know, the New Yorker
who might print your article.

00:05:55.514 --> 00:06:00.309
Consumers don't care about you
at all; they just don't care.

00:06:00.333 --> 00:06:04.126
Part of the reason is -- they've got
way more choices than they used to,

00:06:04.150 --> 00:06:05.975
and way less time.

00:06:06.298 --> 00:06:10.267
And in a world where we have
too many choices and too little time,

00:06:10.291 --> 00:06:13.675
the obvious thing to do
is just ignore stuff.

00:06:14.826 --> 00:06:18.381
And my parable here
is you're driving down the road

00:06:18.405 --> 00:06:22.254
and you see a cow, and you keep driving
because you've seen cows before.

00:06:22.278 --> 00:06:25.112
Cows are invisible. Cows are boring.

00:06:25.136 --> 00:06:28.538
Who's going to stop and pull over
and say -- "Oh, look, a cow."

00:06:28.562 --> 00:06:29.713
Nobody.

00:06:29.737 --> 00:06:31.434
(Laughter)

00:06:31.458 --> 00:06:35.102
But if the cow was purple --
isn't that a great special effect?

00:06:35.126 --> 00:06:36.785
I could do that again if you want.

00:06:36.809 --> 00:06:41.434
If the cow was purple,
you'd notice it for a while.

00:06:41.458 --> 00:06:44.506
I mean, if all cows were purple
you'd get bored with those, too.

00:06:44.831 --> 00:06:48.326
The thing that's going to decide
what gets talked about,

00:06:48.350 --> 00:06:50.053
what gets done, what gets changed,

00:06:50.077 --> 00:06:52.511
what gets purchased, what gets built,

00:06:52.535 --> 00:06:54.825
is: "Is it remarkable?"

00:06:55.460 --> 00:06:57.797
And "remarkable" is a really cool word,

00:06:57.821 --> 00:06:59.866
because we think it just means "neat,"

00:06:59.890 --> 00:07:03.226
but it also means
"worth making a remark about."

00:07:03.734 --> 00:07:07.545
And that is the essence
of where idea diffusion is going.

00:07:08.036 --> 00:07:11.031
That two of the hottest cars
in the United States

00:07:11.055 --> 00:07:14.212
is a 55,000-dollar giant car,

00:07:14.236 --> 00:07:17.347
big enough to hold a Mini in its trunk.

00:07:17.371 --> 00:07:19.464
People are paying full price for both,

00:07:19.488 --> 00:07:22.277
and the only thing they have in common

00:07:22.301 --> 00:07:25.237
is that they don't have
anything in common.

00:07:25.261 --> 00:07:26.435
(Laughter)

00:07:26.459 --> 00:07:31.581
Every week, the number one
best-selling DVD in America changes.

00:07:32.160 --> 00:07:34.985
It's never "The Godfather,"
it's never "Citizen Kane,"

00:07:35.009 --> 00:07:38.849
it's always some third-rate movie
with some second-rate star.

00:07:38.873 --> 00:07:43.434
But the reason it's number one
is because that's the week it came out.

00:07:43.458 --> 00:07:45.434
Because it's new, because it's fresh.

00:07:45.458 --> 00:07:47.938
People saw it and said
"I didn't know that was there"

00:07:47.962 --> 00:07:49.209
and they noticed it.

00:07:49.233 --> 00:07:52.386
Two of the big success stories
of the last 20 years in retail --

00:07:52.410 --> 00:07:55.372
one sells things that are
super-expensive in a blue box,

00:07:55.396 --> 00:07:58.433
and one sells things that are
as cheap as they can make them.

00:07:58.872 --> 00:08:01.738
The only thing they have in common
is that they're different.

00:08:01.762 --> 00:08:05.094
We're now in the fashion business,
no matter what we do for a living,

00:08:05.118 --> 00:08:06.648
we're in the fashion business.

00:08:06.672 --> 00:08:08.434
And people in the fashion business

00:08:08.458 --> 00:08:11.861
know what it's like to be in the fashion
business -- they're used to it.

00:08:11.885 --> 00:08:14.512
The rest of us have to figure out
how to think that way.

00:08:14.536 --> 00:08:15.758
How to understand

00:08:15.782 --> 00:08:19.065
that it's not about interrupting
people with big full-page ads,

00:08:19.089 --> 00:08:21.667
or insisting on meetings with people.

00:08:21.691 --> 00:08:24.507
But it's a totally different
sort of process

00:08:24.531 --> 00:08:27.434
that determines which ideas spread,
and which ones don't.

00:08:27.458 --> 00:08:31.404
They sold a billion dollars'
worth of Aeron chairs

00:08:31.428 --> 00:08:34.794
by reinventing
what it meant to sell a chair.

00:08:34.818 --> 00:08:38.039
They turned a chair from something
the purchasing department bought,

00:08:38.063 --> 00:08:41.300
to something that was a status symbol
about where you sat at work.

00:08:42.650 --> 00:08:45.879
This guy, Lionel Poilâne,
the most famous baker in the world --

00:08:45.903 --> 00:08:47.990
he died two and a half months ago,

00:08:48.014 --> 00:08:50.062
and he was a hero of mine
and a dear friend.

00:08:50.086 --> 00:08:51.276
He lived in Paris.

00:08:51.300 --> 00:08:55.203
Last year, he sold 10 million dollars'
worth of French bread.

00:08:55.546 --> 00:08:58.034
Every loaf baked in a bakery he owned,

00:08:58.058 --> 00:09:00.868
by one baker at a time,
in a wood-fired oven.

00:09:01.178 --> 00:09:04.956
And when Lionel started his bakery,
the French pooh-pooh-ed it.

00:09:04.980 --> 00:09:06.640
They didn't want to buy his bread.

00:09:06.664 --> 00:09:08.405
It didn't look like "French bread."

00:09:08.429 --> 00:09:09.810
It wasn't what they expected.

00:09:09.834 --> 00:09:12.704
It was neat; it was remarkable;

00:09:12.728 --> 00:09:16.041
and slowly, it spread
from one person to another person

00:09:16.065 --> 00:09:20.331
until finally, it became the official
bread of three-star restaurants in Paris.

00:09:20.355 --> 00:09:23.355
Now he's in London, and he ships
by FedEx all around the world.

00:09:23.925 --> 00:09:28.719
What marketers used to do is make
average products for average people.

00:09:29.092 --> 00:09:30.885
That's what mass marketing is.

00:09:30.909 --> 00:09:35.037
Smooth out the edges; go for the center;
that's the big market.

00:09:35.061 --> 00:09:39.434
They would ignore the geeks,
and God forbid, the laggards.

00:09:39.458 --> 00:09:41.434
It was all about going for the center.

00:09:41.957 --> 00:09:45.125
But in a world where
the TV-industrial complex is broken,

00:09:45.149 --> 00:09:47.769
I don't think that's a strategy
we want to use any more.

00:09:47.793 --> 00:09:51.567
I think the strategy we want to use
is to not market to these people

00:09:51.591 --> 00:09:53.877
because they're really good
at ignoring you.

00:09:53.901 --> 00:09:56.655
But market to these
people because they care.

00:09:57.458 --> 00:10:01.123
These are the people
who are obsessed with something.

00:10:01.638 --> 00:10:03.678
And when you talk to them, they'll listen,

00:10:03.702 --> 00:10:06.321
because they like listening --
it's about them.

00:10:06.345 --> 00:10:10.300
And if you're lucky, they'll tell
their friends on the rest of the curve,

00:10:10.324 --> 00:10:11.511
and it'll spread.

00:10:11.535 --> 00:10:13.314
It'll spread to the entire curve.

00:10:13.338 --> 00:10:16.977
They have something I call "otaku" --
it's a great Japanese word.

00:10:17.001 --> 00:10:19.999
It describes the desire
of someone who's obsessed to say,

00:10:20.023 --> 00:10:22.856
drive across Tokyo to try
a new ramen noodle place,

00:10:22.880 --> 00:10:25.452
because that's what they do:
they get obsessed with it.

00:10:25.838 --> 00:10:28.195
To make a product, to market an idea,

00:10:28.219 --> 00:10:30.315
to come up with any problem
you want to solve

00:10:30.339 --> 00:10:33.648
that doesn't have
a constituency with an otaku,

00:10:33.672 --> 00:10:34.894
is almost impossible.

00:10:35.259 --> 00:10:38.901
Instead, you have to find
a group that really, desperately cares

00:10:38.925 --> 00:10:40.568
about what it is you have to say.

00:10:40.592 --> 00:10:43.675
Talk to them and make it easy
for them to tell their friends.

00:10:43.699 --> 00:10:47.143
There's a hot sauce otaku,
but there's no mustard otaku.

00:10:47.841 --> 00:10:50.516
That's why there's lots and lots
of kinds of hot sauces,

00:10:50.540 --> 00:10:52.127
and not so many kinds of mustard.

00:10:52.151 --> 00:10:54.634
Not because it's hard
to make interesting mustard --

00:10:54.658 --> 00:10:56.449
you could make interesting mustard --

00:10:56.473 --> 00:10:58.948
but people don't,
because no one's obsessed with it,

00:10:58.972 --> 00:11:00.753
and thus no one tells their friends.

00:11:00.777 --> 00:11:03.156
Krispy Kreme has figured
this whole thing out.

00:11:03.180 --> 00:11:05.060
It has a strategy, and what they do is,

00:11:05.084 --> 00:11:07.891
they enter a city, they talk
to the people, with the otaku,

00:11:07.915 --> 00:11:09.837
and then they spread through the city

00:11:09.861 --> 00:11:11.957
to the people who've just
crossed the street.

00:11:11.981 --> 00:11:16.415
This yoyo right here cost 112 dollars,
but it sleeps for 12 minutes.

00:11:16.439 --> 00:11:18.476
Not everybody wants it
but they don't care.

00:11:18.500 --> 00:11:22.027
They want to talk to the people
who do, and maybe it'll spread.

00:11:22.051 --> 00:11:25.434
These guys make the loudest
car stereo in the world.

00:11:25.458 --> 00:11:27.434
(Laughter)

00:11:27.458 --> 00:11:29.602
It's as loud as a 747 jet.

00:11:29.626 --> 00:11:32.577
You can't get in,
the car's got bulletproof glass,

00:11:32.601 --> 00:11:34.840
because it'll blow out
the windshield otherwise.

00:11:34.864 --> 00:11:36.167
But the fact remains

00:11:36.191 --> 00:11:39.325
that when someone wants to put
a couple of speakers in their car,

00:11:39.349 --> 00:11:42.349
if they've got the otaku
or they've heard from someone who does,

00:11:42.373 --> 00:11:44.030
they go ahead and they pick this.

00:11:44.054 --> 00:11:47.045
It's really simple -- you sell
to the people who are listening,

00:11:47.069 --> 00:11:49.391
and just maybe,
those people tell their friends.

00:11:49.415 --> 00:11:52.672
So when Steve Jobs talks
to 50,000 people at his keynote,

00:11:52.696 --> 00:11:55.316
who are all tuned in from 130 countries

00:11:55.340 --> 00:11:57.434
watching his two-hour commercial --

00:11:57.458 --> 00:12:00.078
that's the only thing keeping
his company in business --

00:12:00.102 --> 00:12:02.751
it's that those 50,000 people
care desperately enough

00:12:02.775 --> 00:12:05.585
to watch a two-hour commercial,
and then tell their friends.

00:12:05.609 --> 00:12:08.290
Pearl Jam, 96 albums released
in the last two years.

00:12:08.314 --> 00:12:10.671
Every one made a profit. How?

00:12:10.695 --> 00:12:12.482
They only sell them on their website.

00:12:12.506 --> 00:12:14.608
Those people who buy them have the otaku,

00:12:14.632 --> 00:12:17.685
and then they tell their friends,
and it spreads and it spreads.

00:12:17.709 --> 00:12:21.667
This hospital crib cost 10,000 dollars,
10 times the standard.

00:12:22.040 --> 00:12:24.714
But hospitals are buying it
faster than any other model.

00:12:24.738 --> 00:12:27.434
Hard Candy nail polish,
doesn't appeal to everybody,

00:12:27.458 --> 00:12:30.937
but to the people who love it,
they talk about it like crazy.

00:12:30.961 --> 00:12:36.604
This paint can right here saved
the Dutch Boy paint company,

00:12:36.628 --> 00:12:37.917
making them a fortune.

00:12:37.941 --> 00:12:39.988
It costs 35 percent more
than regular paint

00:12:40.012 --> 00:12:44.053
because Dutch Boy made a can that people
talk about, because it's remarkable.

00:12:44.077 --> 00:12:46.220
They didn't just slap
a new ad on the product;

00:12:46.244 --> 00:12:48.737
they changed what it meant
to build a paint product.

00:12:48.761 --> 00:12:53.434
AmIhotornot.com -- everyday
250,000 people go to this site,

00:12:53.458 --> 00:12:57.434
run by two volunteers, and I can
tell you they are hard graders --

00:12:57.458 --> 00:13:01.268
(Laughter)

00:13:01.292 --> 00:13:04.340
They didn't get this way
by advertising a lot.

00:13:04.364 --> 00:13:07.128
They got this way by being remarkable,

00:13:07.152 --> 00:13:08.917
sometimes a little too remarkable.

00:13:08.941 --> 00:13:13.240
And this picture frame
has a cord going out the back,

00:13:13.264 --> 00:13:14.913
and you plug it into the wall.

00:13:14.937 --> 00:13:16.786
My father has this on his desk,

00:13:16.810 --> 00:13:21.246
and he sees his grandchildren
everyday, changing constantly.

00:13:21.270 --> 00:13:23.817
And every single person
who walks into his office

00:13:23.841 --> 00:13:26.770
hears the whole story
of how this thing ended up on his desk.

00:13:26.794 --> 00:13:29.434
And one person at a time,
the idea spreads.

00:13:29.458 --> 00:13:32.237
These are not diamonds, not really.

00:13:32.690 --> 00:13:34.434
They're made from "cremains."

00:13:34.785 --> 00:13:37.595
After you're cremated you can
have yourself made into a gem.

00:13:37.619 --> 00:13:38.666
(Laughter)

00:13:38.690 --> 00:13:40.976
Oh, you like my ring? It's my grandmother.

00:13:41.000 --> 00:13:46.689
(Laughter)

00:13:46.713 --> 00:13:49.697
Fastest-growing business
in the whole mortuary industry.

00:13:50.202 --> 00:13:52.227
But you don't have to be Ozzie Osborne --

00:13:52.251 --> 00:13:54.537
you don't have to be
super-outrageous to do this.

00:13:54.561 --> 00:13:55.775
What you have to do

00:13:55.799 --> 00:13:58.566
is figure out what people
really want and give it to them.

00:13:58.590 --> 00:14:00.257
A couple of quick rules to wrap up.

00:14:00.281 --> 00:14:04.000
The first one is: Design
is free when you get to scale.

00:14:04.024 --> 00:14:06.412
The people who come up
with stuff that's remarkable

00:14:06.436 --> 00:14:09.626
more often than not figure out
how to put design to work for them.

00:14:09.650 --> 00:14:14.506
Number two: The riskiest thing
you can do now is be safe.

00:14:14.530 --> 00:14:16.434
Proctor and Gamble knows this, right?

00:14:16.458 --> 00:14:18.506
The whole model of being
Proctor and Gamble

00:14:18.530 --> 00:14:20.961
is always about average products
for average people.

00:14:20.985 --> 00:14:22.151
That's risky.

00:14:22.479 --> 00:14:25.333
The safe thing to do now
is to be at the fringes,

00:14:25.357 --> 00:14:26.520
be remarkable.

00:14:27.068 --> 00:14:30.502
And being very good is one
of the worst things you can possibly do.

00:14:31.139 --> 00:14:33.941
Very good is boring. Very good is average.

00:14:33.965 --> 00:14:36.544
It doesn't matter whether
you're making a record album,

00:14:36.568 --> 00:14:39.265
or you're an architect,
or you have a tract on sociology.

00:14:39.289 --> 00:14:43.157
If it's very good, it's not going to work,
because no one's going to notice it.

00:14:43.181 --> 00:14:44.557
So my three stories.

00:14:44.581 --> 00:14:49.073
Silk put a product that does not need
to be in the refrigerated section

00:14:49.097 --> 00:14:51.414
next to the milk
in the refrigerated section.

00:14:51.438 --> 00:14:53.224
Sales tripled. Why?

00:14:53.248 --> 00:14:55.787
Milk, milk, milk, milk, milk -- not milk.

00:14:56.620 --> 00:14:59.688
For the people who were there
and looking at that section,

00:14:59.712 --> 00:15:00.918
it was remarkable.

00:15:00.942 --> 00:15:03.181
They didn't triple their sales
with advertising;

00:15:03.205 --> 00:15:05.387
they tripled it by doing
something remarkable.

00:15:05.411 --> 00:15:07.171
That is a remarkable piece of art.

00:15:07.195 --> 00:15:08.465
You don't have to like it,

00:15:08.489 --> 00:15:13.053
but a 40-foot tall dog made out of bushes
in the middle of New York City

00:15:13.077 --> 00:15:14.228
is remarkable.

00:15:14.252 --> 00:15:15.323
(Laughter)

00:15:15.347 --> 00:15:17.265
Frank Gehry didn't just change a museum;

00:15:17.289 --> 00:15:20.175
he changed an entire city's economy

00:15:20.199 --> 00:15:24.757
by designing one building that people
from all over the world went to see.

00:15:24.781 --> 00:15:26.686
Now, at countless meetings at, you know,

00:15:26.710 --> 00:15:29.434
the Portland City Council,
or who knows where,

00:15:29.458 --> 00:15:32.719
they said, we need an architect --
can we get Frank Gehry?

00:15:32.743 --> 00:15:35.434
Because he did something
that was at the fringes.

00:15:35.458 --> 00:15:37.701
And my big failure?
I came out with an entire --

00:15:37.725 --> 00:15:40.434
(Music)

00:15:40.458 --> 00:15:43.225
A record album and hopefully
a whole bunch of record albums

00:15:43.249 --> 00:15:45.894
in SACD, this remarkable new format --

00:15:45.918 --> 00:15:49.219
and I marketed it straight to people
with 20,000-dollar stereos.

00:15:49.243 --> 00:15:54.339
People with 20,000-dollar stereos
don't like new music.

00:15:54.363 --> 00:15:58.822
(Laughter)

00:15:58.846 --> 00:16:03.547
So what you need to do
is figure out who does care.

00:16:04.095 --> 00:16:06.086
Who is going to raise their hand and say,

00:16:06.110 --> 00:16:08.039
"I want to hear what you're doing next,"

00:16:08.063 --> 00:16:09.490
and sell something to them.

00:16:09.923 --> 00:16:11.638
The last example I want to give you.

00:16:11.662 --> 00:16:13.867
This is a map of Soap Lake, Washington.

00:16:13.891 --> 00:16:17.434
As you can see, if that's nowhere,
it's in the middle of it.

00:16:17.458 --> 00:16:22.977
(Laughter)

00:16:23.001 --> 00:16:25.386
But they do have a lake.

00:16:25.410 --> 00:16:28.316
And people used to come from miles
around to swim in the lake.

00:16:28.340 --> 00:16:29.505
They don't anymore.

00:16:29.529 --> 00:16:32.412
So the founding fathers said,
"We've got some money to spend.

00:16:32.436 --> 00:16:33.887
What can we build here?"

00:16:33.911 --> 00:16:35.405
And like most committees,

00:16:35.429 --> 00:16:37.621
they were going to build
something pretty safe.

00:16:37.645 --> 00:16:40.979
And then an artist came to them --
this is a true artist's rendering --

00:16:41.003 --> 00:16:46.580
he wants to build a 55-foot tall
lava lamp in the center of town.

00:16:46.604 --> 00:16:49.882
That's a purple cow;
that's something worth noticing.

00:16:49.906 --> 00:16:51.065
I don't know about you,

00:16:51.089 --> 00:16:53.470
but if they build it,
that's where I'm going to go.

00:16:53.494 --> 00:16:55.494
Thank you very much for your attention.

title: How we discovered DNA
transcript: Well, I thought there would be a podium, so I'm a bit scared. (Laughter) Chris asked me to tell again how we found the structure of DNA. And since, you know, I follow his orders, I'll do it. But it slightly bores me. (Laughter) And, you know, I wrote a book. So I'll say something — (Laughter) — I'll say a little about, you know, how the discovery was made, and why Francis and I found it. And then, I hope maybe I have at least five minutes to say what makes me tick now.In back of me is a picture of me when I was 17. I was at the University of Chicago, in my third year, and I was in my third year because the University of Chicago let you in after two years of high school. So you — it was fun to get away from high school — (Laughter) — because I was very small, and I was no good in sports, or anything like that.But I should say that my background — my father was, you know, raised to be an Episcopalian and Republican, but after one year of college, he became an atheist and a Democrat. (Laughter) And my mother was Irish Catholic, and — but she didn't take religion too seriously. And by the age of 11, I was no longer going to Sunday Mass, and going on birdwatching walks with my father. So early on, I heard of Charles Darwin. I guess, you know, he was the big hero. And, you know, you understand life as it now exists through evolution.And at the University of Chicago I was a zoology major, and thought I would end up, you know, if I was bright enough, maybe getting a Ph.D. from Cornell in ornithology. Then, in the Chicago paper, there was a review of a book called "What is Life?" by the great physicist, Schrodinger. And that, of course, had been a question I wanted to know. You know, Darwin explained life after it got started, but what was the essence of life?And Schrodinger said the essence was information present in our chromosomes, and it had to be present on a molecule. I'd never really thought of molecules before. You know chromosomes, but this was a molecule, and somehow all the information was probably present in some digital form. And there was the big question of, how did you copy the information?So that was the book. And so, from that moment on, I wanted to be a geneticist — understand the gene and, through that, understand life. So I had, you know, a hero at a distance. It wasn't a baseball player; it was Linus Pauling. And so I applied to Caltech and they turned me down. (Laughter) So I went to Indiana, which was actually as good as Caltech in genetics, and besides, they had a really good basketball team. (Laughter) So I had a really quite happy life at Indiana. And it was at Indiana I got the impression that, you know, the gene was likely to be DNA. And so when I got my Ph.D., I should go and search for DNA.So I first went to Copenhagen because I thought, well, maybe I could become a biochemist, but I discovered biochemistry was very boring. It wasn't going anywhere toward, you know, saying what the gene was; it was just nuclear science. And oh, that's the book, little book. You can read it in about two hours. And — but then I went to a meeting in Italy. And there was an unexpected speaker who wasn't on the program, and he talked about DNA. And this was Maurice Wilkins. He was trained as a physicist, and after the war he wanted to do biophysics, and he picked DNA because DNA had been determined at the Rockefeller Institute to possibly be the genetic molecules on the chromosomes. Most people believed it was proteins. But Wilkins, you know, thought DNA was the best bet, and he showed this x-ray photograph. Sort of crystalline. So DNA had a structure, even though it owed it to probably different molecules carrying different sets of instructions. So there was something universal about the DNA molecule. So I wanted to work with him, but he didn't want a former birdwatcher, and I ended up in Cambridge, England.So I went to Cambridge, because it was really the best place in the world then for x-ray crystallography. And x-ray crystallography is now a subject in, you know, chemistry departments. I mean, in those days it was the domain of the physicists. So the best place for x-ray crystallography was at the Cavendish Laboratory at Cambridge. And there I met Francis Crick. I went there without knowing him. He was 35. I was 23. And within a day, we had decided that maybe we could take a shortcut to finding the structure of DNA. Not solve it like, you know, in rigorous fashion, but build a model, an electro-model, using some coordinates of, you know, length, all that sort of stuff from x-ray photographs. But just ask what the molecule — how should it fold up?And the reason for doing so, at the center of this photograph, is Linus Pauling. About six months before, he proposed the alpha helical structure for proteins. And in doing so, he banished the man out on the right, Sir Lawrence Bragg, who was the Cavendish professor. This is a photograph several years later, when Bragg had cause to smile. He certainly wasn't smiling when I got there, because he was somewhat humiliated by Pauling getting the alpha helix, and the Cambridge people failing because they weren't chemists. And certainly, neither Crick or I were chemists, so we tried to build a model. And he knew, Francis knew Wilkins. So Wilkins said he thought it was the helix. X-ray diagram, he thought was comparable with the helix.So we built a three-stranded model. The people from London came up. Wilkins and this collaborator, or possible collaborator, Rosalind Franklin, came up and sort of laughed at our model. They said it was lousy, and it was. So we were told to build no more models; we were incompetent. (Laughter) And so we didn't build any models, and Francis sort of continued to work on proteins. And basically, I did nothing. And — except read. You know, basically, reading is a good thing; you get facts. And we kept telling the people in London that Linus Pauling's going to move on to DNA. If DNA is that important, Linus will know it. He'll build a model, and then we're going to be scooped.And, in fact, he'd written the people in London: Could he see their x-ray photograph? And they had the wisdom to say "no." So he didn't have it. But there was ones in the literature. Actually, Linus didn't look at them that carefully. But about, oh, 15 months after I got to Cambridge, a rumor began to appear from Linus Pauling's son, who was in Cambridge, that his father was now working on DNA. And so, one day Peter came in and he said he was Peter Pauling, and he gave me a copy of his father's manuscripts. And boy, I was scared because I thought, you know, we may be scooped. I have nothing to do, no qualifications for anything. (Laughter)And so there was the paper, and he proposed a three-stranded structure. And I read it, and it was just — it was crap. (Laughter) So this was, you know, unexpected from the world's — (Laughter) — and so, it was held together by hydrogen bonds between phosphate groups. Well, if the peak pH that cells have is around seven, those hydrogen bonds couldn't exist. We rushed over to the chemistry department and said, "Could Pauling be right?" And Alex Hust said, "No." So we were happy. (Laughter)And, you know, we were still in the game, but we were frightened that somebody at Caltech would tell Linus that he was wrong. And so Bragg said, "Build models." And a month after we got the Pauling manuscript — I should say I took the manuscript to London, and showed the people. Well, I said, Linus was wrong and that we're still in the game and that they should immediately start building models. But Wilkins said "no." Rosalind Franklin was leaving in about two months, and after she left he would start building models. And so I came back with that news to Cambridge, and Bragg said, "Build models." Well, of course, I wanted to build models. And there's a picture of Rosalind. She really, you know, in one sense she was a chemist, but really she would have been trained — she didn't know any organic chemistry or quantum chemistry. She was a crystallographer.And I think part of the reason she didn't want to build models was, she wasn't a chemist, whereas Pauling was a chemist. And so Crick and I, you know, started building models, and I'd learned a little chemistry, but not enough. Well, we got the answer on the 28th February '53. And it was because of a rule, which, to me, is a very good rule: Never be the brightest person in a room, and we weren't. We weren't the best chemists in the room. I went in and showed them a pairing I'd done, and Jerry Donohue — he was a chemist — he said, it's wrong. You've got — the hydrogen atoms are in the wrong place. I just put them down like they were in the books. He said they were wrong.So the next day, you know, after I thought, "Well, he might be right." So I changed the locations, and then we found the base pairing, and Francis immediately said the chains run in absolute directions. And we knew we were right. So it was a pretty, you know, it all happened in about two hours. From nothing to thing. And we knew it was big because, you know, if you just put A next to T and G next to C, you have a copying mechanism. So we saw how genetic information is carried. It's the order of the four bases. So in a sense, it is a sort of digital-type information. And you copy it by going from strand-separating. So, you know, if it didn't work this way, you might as well believe it, because you didn't have any other scheme. (Laughter)But that's not the way most scientists think. Most scientists are really rather dull. They said, we won't think about it until we know it's right. But, you know, we thought, well, it's at least 95 percent right or 99 percent right. So think about it. The next five years, there were essentially something like five references to our work in "Nature" — none. And so we were left by ourselves, and trying to do the last part of the trio: how do you — what does this genetic information do? It was pretty obvious that it provided the information to an RNA molecule, and then how do you go from RNA to protein? For about three years we just — I tried to solve the structure of RNA. It didn't yield. It didn't give good x-ray photographs. I was decidedly unhappy; a girl didn't marry me. It was really, you know, sort of a shitty time. (Laughter)So there's a picture of Francis and I before I met the girl, so I'm still looking happy. (Laughter) But there is what we did when we didn't know where to go forward: we formed a club and called it the RNA Tie Club. George Gamow, also a great physicist, he designed the tie. He was one of the members. The question was: How do you go from a four-letter code to the 20-letter code of proteins? Feynman was a member, and Teller, and friends of Gamow. But that's the only — no, we were only photographed twice. And on both occasions, you know, one of us was missing the tie. There's Francis up on the upper right, and Alex Rich — the M.D.-turned-crystallographer — is next to me. This was taken in Cambridge in September of 1955. And I'm smiling, sort of forced, I think, because the girl I had, boy, she was gone. (Laughter)And so I didn't really get happy until 1960, because then we found out, basically, you know, that there are three forms of RNA. And we knew, basically, DNA provides the information for RNA. RNA provides the information for protein. And that let Marshall Nirenberg, you know, take RNA — synthetic RNA — put it in a system making protein. He made polyphenylalanine, polyphenylalanine. So that's the first cracking of the genetic code, and it was all over by 1966. So there, that's what Chris wanted me to do, it was — so what happened since then? Well, at that time — I should go back. When we found the structure of DNA, I gave my first talk at Cold Spring Harbor. The physicist, Leo Szilard, he looked at me and said, "Are you going to patent this?" And — but he knew patent law, and that we couldn't patent it, because you couldn't. No use for it. (Laughter)And so DNA didn't become a useful molecule, and the lawyers didn't enter into the equation until 1973, 20 years later, when Boyer and Cohen in San Francisco and Stanford came up with their method of recombinant DNA, and Stanford patented it and made a lot of money. At least they patented something which, you know, could do useful things. And then, they learned how to read the letters for the code. And, boom, we've, you know, had a biotech industry. And, but we were still a long ways from, you know, answering a question which sort of dominated my childhood, which is: How do you nature-nurture?And so I'll go on. I'm already out of time, but this is Michael Wigler, a very, very clever mathematician turned physicist. And he developed a technique which essentially will let us look at sample DNA and, eventually, a million spots along it. There's a chip there, a conventional one. Then there's one made by a photolithography by a company in Madison called NimbleGen, which is way ahead of Affymetrix. And we use their technique. And what you can do is sort of compare DNA of normal segs versus cancer. And you can see on the top that cancers which are bad show insertions or deletions. So the DNA is really badly mucked up, whereas if you have a chance of surviving, the DNA isn't so mucked up. So we think that this will eventually lead to what we call "DNA biopsies." Before you get treated for cancer, you should really look at this technique, and get a feeling of the face of the enemy. It's not a — it's only a partial look, but it's a — I think it's going to be very, very useful.So, we started with breast cancer because there's lots of money for it, no government money. And now I have a sort of vested interest: I want to do it for prostate cancer. So, you know, you aren't treated if it's not dangerous. But Wigler, besides looking at cancer cells, looked at normal cells, and made a really sort of surprising observation. Which is, all of us have about 10 places in our genome where we've lost a gene or gained another one. So we're sort of all imperfect. And the question is well, if we're around here, you know, these little losses or gains might not be too bad. But if these deletions or amplifications occurred in the wrong gene, maybe we'll feel sick.So the first disease he looked at is autism. And the reason we looked at autism is we had the money to do it. Looking at an individual is about 3,000 dollars. And the parent of a child with Asperger's disease, the high-intelligence autism, had sent his thing to a conventional company; they didn't do it. Couldn't do it by conventional genetics, but just scanning it we began to find genes for autism. And you can see here, there are a lot of them. So a lot of autistic kids are autistic because they just lost a big piece of DNA. I mean, big piece at the molecular level. We saw one autistic kid, about five million bases just missing from one of his chromosomes. We haven't yet looked at the parents, but the parents probably don't have that loss, or they wouldn't be parents. Now, so, our autism study is just beginning. We got three million dollars. I think it will cost at least 10 to 20 before you'd be in a position to help parents who've had an autistic child, or think they may have an autistic child, and can we spot the difference? So this same technique should probably look at all. It's a wonderful way to find genes.And so, I'll conclude by saying we've looked at 20 people with schizophrenia. And we thought we'd probably have to look at several hundred before we got the picture. But as you can see, there's seven out of 20 had a change which was very high. And yet, in the controls there were three. So what's the meaning of the controls? Were they crazy also, and we didn't know it? Or, you know, were they normal? I would guess they're normal. And what we think in schizophrenia is there are genes of predisposure, and whether this is one that predisposes — and then there's only a sub-segment of the population that's capable of being schizophrenic.Now, we don't have really any evidence of it, but I think, to give you a hypothesis, the best guess is that if you're left-handed, you're prone to schizophrenia. 30 percent of schizophrenic people are left-handed, and schizophrenia has a very funny genetics, which means 60 percent of the people are genetically left-handed, but only half of it showed. I don't have the time to say. Now, some people who think they're right-handed are genetically left-handed. OK. I'm just saying that, if you think, oh, I don't carry a left-handed gene so therefore my, you know, children won't be at risk of schizophrenia. You might. OK? (Laughter)So it's, to me, an extraordinarily exciting time. We ought to be able to find the gene for bipolar; there's a relationship. And if I had enough money, we'd find them all this year. I thank you.

It wasn't going anywhere toward, you know, saying what the gene was;

00:03:55.958 --> 00:03:59.958
it was just nuclear science. And oh, that's the book, little book.

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:01.958
You can read it in about two hours.

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:05.958
And -- but then I went to a meeting in Italy.

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:10.958
And there was an unexpected speaker who wasn't on the program,

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:12.958
and he talked about DNA.

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:15.958
And this was Maurice Wilkins. He was trained as a physicist,

00:04:15.958 --> 00:04:19.958
and after the war he wanted to do biophysics, and he picked DNA

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:22.958
because DNA had been determined at the Rockefeller Institute

00:04:22.958 --> 00:04:26.958
to possibly be the genetic molecules on the chromosomes.

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:27.958
Most people believed it was proteins.

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:31.958
But Wilkins, you know, thought DNA was the best bet,

00:04:31.958 --> 00:04:35.958
and he showed this x-ray photograph.

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:39.958
Sort of crystalline. So DNA had a structure,

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:42.958
even though it owed it to probably different molecules

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:44.958
carrying different sets of instructions.

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:46.958
So there was something universal about the DNA molecule.

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:51.958
So I wanted to work with him, but he didn't want a former birdwatcher,

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:52.958
and I ended up in Cambridge, England.

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:54.958
So I went to Cambridge,

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:57.958
because it was really the best place in the world then

00:04:57.958 --> 00:05:01.958
for x-ray crystallography. And x-ray crystallography is now a subject

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:03.958
in, you know, chemistry departments.

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:06.958
I mean, in those days it was the domain of the physicists.

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:10.958
So the best place for x-ray crystallography

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:13.958
was at the Cavendish Laboratory at Cambridge.

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:19.958
And there I met Francis Crick.

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:22.958
I went there without knowing him. He was 35. I was 23.

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:27.958
And within a day, we had decided that

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:32.958
maybe we could take a shortcut to finding the structure of DNA.

00:05:32.958 --> 00:05:38.958
Not solve it like, you know, in rigorous fashion, but build a model,

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:42.958
an electro-model, using some coordinates of, you know,

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:45.958
length, all that sort of stuff from x-ray photographs.

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:48.958
But just ask what the molecule -- how should it fold up?

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:52.958
And the reason for doing so, at the center of this photograph,

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:55.958
is Linus Pauling. About six months before, he proposed

00:05:55.958 --> 00:05:59.958
the alpha helical structure for proteins. And in doing so,

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:01.958
he banished the man out on the right,

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:04.958
Sir Lawrence Bragg, who was the Cavendish professor.

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:06.958
This is a photograph several years later,

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:08.958
when Bragg had cause to smile.

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:10.958
He certainly wasn't smiling when I got there,

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:14.958
because he was somewhat humiliated by Pauling getting the alpha helix,

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:18.958
and the Cambridge people failing because they weren't chemists.

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:23.958
And certainly, neither Crick or I were chemists,

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:29.958
so we tried to build a model. And he knew, Francis knew Wilkins.

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:31.958
So Wilkins said he thought it was the helix.

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:34.958
X-ray diagram, he thought was comparable with the helix.

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:36.958
So we built a three-stranded model.

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:38.958
The people from London came up.

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:43.958
Wilkins and this collaborator, or possible collaborator,

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:46.958
Rosalind Franklin, came up and sort of laughed at our model.

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:48.958
They said it was lousy, and it was.

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:53.958
So we were told to build no more models; we were incompetent.

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:57.958
(Laughter)

00:06:57.958 --> 00:06:59.958
And so we didn't build any models,

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:02.958
and Francis sort of continued to work on proteins.

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:08.958
And basically, I did nothing. And -- except read.

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:11.958
You know, basically, reading is a good thing; you get facts.

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:14.958
And we kept telling the people in London

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:16.958
that Linus Pauling's going to move on to DNA.

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:18.958
If DNA is that important, Linus will know it.

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:20.958
He'll build a model, and then we're going to be scooped.

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:22.958
And, in fact, he'd written the people in London:

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:25.958
Could he see their x-ray photograph?

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:28.958
And they had the wisdom to say "no." So he didn't have it.

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:30.958
But there was ones in the literature.

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:32.958
Actually, Linus didn't look at them that carefully.

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:38.958
But about, oh, 15 months after I got to Cambridge,

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:41.958
a rumor began to appear from Linus Pauling's son,

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:45.958
who was in Cambridge, that his father was now working on DNA.

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:49.958
And so, one day Peter came in and he said he was Peter Pauling,

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:51.958
and he gave me a copy of his father's manuscripts.

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:57.958
And boy, I was scared because I thought, you know, we may be scooped.

00:07:57.958 --> 00:08:00.958
I have nothing to do, no qualifications for anything.

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:02.958
(Laughter)

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:08.958
And so there was the paper, and he proposed a three-stranded structure.

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:10.958
And I read it, and it was just -- it was crap.

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:15.958
(Laughter)

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:18.958
So this was, you know, unexpected from the world's --

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:20.958
(Laughter)

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:23.958
-- and so, it was held together by hydrogen bonds

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:25.958
between phosphate groups.

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:29.958
Well, if the peak pH that cells have is around seven,

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:32.958
those hydrogen bonds couldn't exist.

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:34.958
We rushed over to the chemistry department and said,

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:40.958
"Could Pauling be right?" And Alex Hust said, "No." So we were happy.

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:42.958
(Laughter)

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:45.958
And, you know, we were still in the game, but we were frightened

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:49.958
that somebody at Caltech would tell Linus that he was wrong.

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:51.958
And so Bragg said, "Build models."

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:55.958
And a month after we got the Pauling manuscript --

00:08:55.958 --> 00:09:00.958
I should say I took the manuscript to London, and showed the people.

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:03.958
Well, I said, Linus was wrong and that we're still in the game

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:05.958
and that they should immediately start building models.

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:10.958
But Wilkins said "no." Rosalind Franklin was leaving in about two months,

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:13.958
and after she left he would start building models.

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:17.958
And so I came back with that news to Cambridge,

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:18.958
and Bragg said, "Build models."

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:19.958
Well, of course, I wanted to build models.

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:25.958
And there's a picture of Rosalind. She really, you know,

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:27.958
in one sense she was a chemist,

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:29.958
but really she would have been trained --

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:32.958
she didn't know any organic chemistry or quantum chemistry.

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:33.958
She was a crystallographer.

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:38.958
And I think part of the reason she didn't want to build models

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:41.958
was, she wasn't a chemist, whereas Pauling was a chemist.

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:46.958
And so Crick and I, you know, started building models,

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:49.958
and I'd learned a little chemistry, but not enough.

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:53.958
Well, we got the answer on the 28th February '53.

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:57.958
And it was because of a rule, which, to me, is a very good rule:

00:09:57.958 --> 00:10:03.958
Never be the brightest person in a room, and we weren't.

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:05.958
We weren't the best chemists in the room.

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:07.958
I went in and showed them a pairing I'd done,

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:11.958
and Jerry Donohue -- he was a chemist -- he said, it's wrong.

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:14.958
You've got -- the hydrogen atoms are in the wrong place.

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:17.958
I just put them down like they were in the books.

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:18.958
He said they were wrong.

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:22.958
So the next day, you know, after I thought, "Well, he might be right."

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:26.958
So I changed the locations, and then we found the base pairing,

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:29.958
and Francis immediately said the chains run in absolute directions.

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:31.958
And we knew we were right.

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:38.958
So it was a pretty, you know, it all happened in about two hours.

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:42.958
From nothing to thing.

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:47.958
And we knew it was big because, you know, if you just put A next to T

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:50.958
and G next to C, you have a copying mechanism.

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:54.958
So we saw how genetic information is carried.

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:55.958
It's the order of the four bases.

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:59.958
So in a sense, it is a sort of digital-type information.

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:04.958
And you copy it by going from strand-separating.

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:12.958
So, you know, if it didn't work this way, you might as well believe it,

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:13.958
because you didn't have any other scheme.

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:16.958
(Laughter)

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:19.958
But that's not the way most scientists think.

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:22.958
Most scientists are really rather dull.

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:24.958
They said, we won't think about it until we know it's right.

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:30.958
But, you know, we thought, well, it's at least 95 percent right or 99 percent right.

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:34.958
So think about it. The next five years,

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:36.958
there were essentially something like five references

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:38.958
to our work in "Nature" -- none.

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:41.958
And so we were left by ourselves,

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:46.958
and trying to do the last part of the trio: how do you --

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:50.958
what does this genetic information do?

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:54.958
It was pretty obvious that it provided the information

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:57.958
to an RNA molecule, and then how do you go from RNA to protein?

00:11:57.958 --> 00:12:02.958
For about three years we just -- I tried to solve the structure of RNA.

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:05.958
It didn't yield. It didn't give good x-ray photographs.

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:08.958
I was decidedly unhappy; a girl didn't marry me.

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:11.958
It was really, you know, sort of a shitty time.

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:14.958
(Laughter)

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:18.958
So there's a picture of Francis and I before I met the girl,

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:19.958
so I'm still looking happy.

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:22.958
(Laughter)

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:25.958
But there is what we did when we didn't know

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:31.958
where to go forward: we formed a club and called it the RNA Tie Club.

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:35.958
George Gamow, also a great physicist, he designed the tie.

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:38.958
He was one of the members. The question was:

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:40.958
How do you go from a four-letter code

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:42.958
to the 20-letter code of proteins?

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:47.958
Feynman was a member, and Teller, and friends of Gamow.

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:53.958
But that's the only -- no, we were only photographed twice.

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:56.958
And on both occasions, you know, one of us was missing the tie.

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:59.958
There's Francis up on the upper right,

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:04.958
and Alex Rich -- the M.D.-turned-crystallographer -- is next to me.

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:08.958
This was taken in Cambridge in September of 1955.

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:14.958
And I'm smiling, sort of forced, I think,

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:17.958
because the girl I had, boy, she was gone.

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:21.958
(Laughter)

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:26.958
And so I didn't really get happy until 1960,

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:30.958
because then we found out, basically, you know,

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:32.958
that there are three forms of RNA.

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:35.958
And we knew, basically, DNA provides the information for RNA.

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:37.958
RNA provides the information for protein.

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:42.958
And that let Marshall Nirenberg, you know, take RNA -- synthetic RNA --

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:48.958
put it in a system making protein. He made polyphenylalanine,

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:56.958
polyphenylalanine. So that's the first cracking of the genetic code,

00:13:56.958 --> 00:13:58.958
and it was all over by 1966.

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:01.958
So there, that's what Chris wanted me to do, it was --

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:05.958
so what happened since then?

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:08.958
Well, at that time -- I should go back.

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:13.958
When we found the structure of DNA, I gave my first talk

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:16.958
at Cold Spring Harbor. The physicist, Leo Szilard,

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:19.958
he looked at me and said, "Are you going to patent this?"

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:24.958
And -- but he knew patent law, and that we couldn't patent it,

00:14:24.958 --> 00:14:26.958
because you couldn't. No use for it.

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:28.958
(Laughter)

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:32.958
And so DNA didn't become a useful molecule,

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:37.958
and the lawyers didn't enter into the equation until 1973,

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:42.958
20 years later, when Boyer and Cohen in San Francisco

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:44.958
and Stanford came up with their method of recombinant DNA,

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:47.958
and Stanford patented it and made a lot of money.

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:48.958
At least they patented something

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:51.958
which, you know, could do useful things.

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:54.958
And then, they learned how to read the letters for the code.

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:59.958
And, boom, we've, you know, had a biotech industry. And,

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:06.958
but we were still a long ways from, you know,

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:08.958
answering a question which sort of dominated my childhood,

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:13.958
which is: How do you nature-nurture?

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:17.958
And so I'll go on. I'm already out of time,

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:20.958
but this is Michael Wigler, a very, very clever mathematician

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:23.958
turned physicist. And he developed a technique

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:27.958
which essentially will let us look at sample DNA

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:29.958
and, eventually, a million spots along it.

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:32.958
There's a chip there, a conventional one. Then there's one

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:35.958
made by a photolithography by a company in Madison

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:40.958
called NimbleGen, which is way ahead of Affymetrix.

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:42.958
And we use their technique.

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:47.958
And what you can do is sort of compare DNA of normal segs versus cancer.

00:15:47.958 --> 00:15:51.958
And you can see on the top

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:56.958
that cancers which are bad show insertions or deletions.

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:59.958
So the DNA is really badly mucked up,

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:01.958
whereas if you have a chance of surviving,

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:03.958
the DNA isn't so mucked up.

00:16:03.958 --> 00:16:06.958
So we think that this will eventually lead to what we call

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:10.958
"DNA biopsies." Before you get treated for cancer,

00:16:10.958 --> 00:16:12.958
you should really look at this technique,

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:15.958
and get a feeling of the face of the enemy.

00:16:15.958 --> 00:16:18.958
It's not a -- it's only a partial look, but it's a --

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:21.958
I think it's going to be very, very useful.

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:23.958
So, we started with breast cancer

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:26.958
because there's lots of money for it, no government money.

00:16:26.958 --> 00:16:30.958
And now I have a sort of vested interest:

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:32.958
I want to do it for prostate cancer. So, you know,

00:16:32.958 --> 00:16:35.958
you aren't treated if it's not dangerous.

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:41.958
But Wigler, besides looking at cancer cells, looked at normal cells,

00:16:41.958 --> 00:16:44.958
and made a really sort of surprising observation.

00:16:44.958 --> 00:16:48.958
Which is, all of us have about 10 places in our genome

00:16:48.958 --> 00:16:50.958
where we've lost a gene or gained another one.

00:16:51.958 --> 00:16:57.958
So we're sort of all imperfect. And the question is well,

00:16:57.958 --> 00:16:59.958
if we're around here, you know,

00:16:59.958 --> 00:17:02.958
these little losses or gains might not be too bad.

00:17:02.958 --> 00:17:07.958
But if these deletions or amplifications occurred in the wrong gene,

00:17:07.958 --> 00:17:08.958
maybe we'll feel sick.

00:17:08.958 --> 00:17:12.958
So the first disease he looked at is autism.

00:17:12.958 --> 00:17:17.958
And the reason we looked at autism is we had the money to do it.

00:17:17.958 --> 00:17:22.958
Looking at an individual is about 3,000 dollars. And the parent of a child

00:17:22.958 --> 00:17:24.958
with Asperger's disease, the high-intelligence autism,

00:17:24.958 --> 00:17:29.958
had sent his thing to a conventional company; they didn't do it.

00:17:29.958 --> 00:17:32.958
Couldn't do it by conventional genetics, but just scanning it

00:17:32.958 --> 00:17:35.958
we began to find genes for autism.

00:17:35.958 --> 00:17:39.958
And you can see here, there are a lot of them.

00:17:39.958 --> 00:17:43.958
So a lot of autistic kids are autistic

00:17:43.958 --> 00:17:45.958
because they just lost a big piece of DNA.

00:17:45.958 --> 00:17:47.958
I mean, big piece at the molecular level.

00:17:47.958 --> 00:17:49.958
We saw one autistic kid,

00:17:49.958 --> 00:17:52.958
about five million bases just missing from one of his chromosomes.

00:17:52.958 --> 00:17:55.958
We haven't yet looked at the parents, but the parents probably

00:17:55.958 --> 00:17:58.958
don't have that loss, or they wouldn't be parents.

00:17:58.958 --> 00:18:05.958
Now, so, our autism study is just beginning. We got three million dollars.

00:18:05.958 --> 00:18:09.958
I think it will cost at least 10 to 20 before you'd be in a position

00:18:09.958 --> 00:18:12.958
to help parents who've had an autistic child,

00:18:12.958 --> 00:18:14.958
or think they may have an autistic child,

00:18:14.958 --> 00:18:16.958
and can we spot the difference?

00:18:16.958 --> 00:18:19.958
So this same technique should probably look at all.

00:18:19.958 --> 00:18:23.958
It's a wonderful way to find genes.

00:18:23.958 --> 00:18:25.958
And so, I'll conclude by saying

00:18:25.958 --> 00:18:27.958
we've looked at 20 people with schizophrenia.

00:18:27.958 --> 00:18:31.958
And we thought we'd probably have to look at several hundred

00:18:31.958 --> 00:18:33.958
before we got the picture. But as you can see,

00:18:33.958 --> 00:18:37.958
there's seven out of 20 had a change which was very high.

00:18:37.958 --> 00:18:40.958
And yet, in the controls there were three.

00:18:40.958 --> 00:18:42.958
So what's the meaning of the controls?

00:18:42.958 --> 00:18:44.958
Were they crazy also, and we didn't know it?

00:18:44.958 --> 00:18:48.958
Or, you know, were they normal? I would guess they're normal.

00:18:48.958 --> 00:18:55.958
And what we think in schizophrenia is there are genes of predisposure,

00:18:55.958 --> 00:19:01.958
and whether this is one that predisposes --

00:19:01.958 --> 00:19:05.958
and then there's only a sub-segment of the population

title: Visual illusions that show how we (mis)think
transcript: We're going to talk — my — a new lecture, just for TED — and I'm going show you some illusions that we've created for TED, and I'm going to try to relate this to happiness. What I was thinking about with happiness is, what gives happiness — or happiness, which I equate with joy in my particular area, and I think there's something very fundamental. And I was thinking about this. And it's in terms of both illusions and movies that we go see and jokes and magic shows is that there's something about these things where our expectations are violated in some sort of pleasing way. You go see a movie. And it has an unexpected twist — something that you didn't expect — and you find a joyful experience. You look at those sort of illusions in my book and it's not as what you'd expect. And there's something joyful about it. And it's the same thing with jokes and all these sorts of things. So, what I'm going to try and do in my lecture is go a little bit further and see if I can violate your expectations in a pleasing way. I mean, sometimes expectations that are violated are not pleasant, but I'm going to try to do it in a pleasant way, in a very primal way, so I can make the audience here happy.So I'm going to show you some ways that we can violate your expectations. First of all, I want to show you the particular illusion here. I want you first of all when it pops up on the screen to notice that the two holes are perpendicular to each other. These are all perceptual tricks. These are real objects that I'm going to show you. Now I'm going to show you how it is done. I've looped the film here so you can get a very interesting experience. I want you to see how this illusion is constructed, and it's going to rotate so you see that it's inside out. Now watch, as it rotates back, how quickly your perception snaps. OK now. Watch it as it rotates back again. And this is a very bright audience, all right? See if you can stop it from happening, even though you know 100 percent it's true that — bam! You can't undo it. What does that tell you about yourselves? We're going to do it again. No doubt about it. See if you can stop it from happening. No. It's difficult.And we can violate your expectations in a whole variety of ways about representation, about shape, about color and so forth and it's very primal. And it's an interesting question to ponder, why these things — we find these things joyful. Why would we find them joyful? So, here's something that Lionel did a while ago. I like these sort of little things like this.Again, this is not an optical trick. This is what you would see. In other words, it's not a camera cut. It's a perceptual trick. OK. We can violate your expectations about shape. We can violate your expectations on representation — what an image represents. What do you see here? How many of you here see dolphins? Raise your hand if you see dolphins. OK, those people who raised their hands, afterwards, the rest of the audience, go talk to them, all right? Actually, this is the best example of priming by experience that I know. If you are a child under the age of 10 who haven't been ruined yet, you will look at this image and see dolphins. Now, some of you adults here are saying, "What dolphins? What dolphins?" But in fact, if you reversed the figure ground — in other words, the dark areas here — I forgot to ask for a pointer — but if you reverse it, you'll see a whole series of little dolphins. By the way, if you're also a student at CalTech — they also tend to just see the dolphins. It's based on experience.Now, something like this can be used because this is after all talk about design, too. This was done by Saatchi and Saatchi, and they actually got away with this ad in Australia. So, if you look at this ad for beer, all those people are in sort of provocative positions. But they got it passed, and actually won the Clio awards, so it's funny how you can do these things. Remember that sort of, um. This is the joke I did when the Florida ballot was going around. You know, count the dots for Gore; count the dots for Bush; count 'em again ...You can violate your expectations about experience. Here is an outside water fountain that I created with some friends of mine, but you can stop the water in drops and — actually make all the drops levitate. This is something we're building for, you know, amusement parks and that kind of stuff. Now let's take a static image. Can you see this? Do you see the middle section moving down and the outer sections moving up? It's completely static. It's a static image. How many people see this illusion? It's completely static. Right. Now, when — it's interesting that when we look at an image we see, you know, color, depth, texture. And you can look at this whole scene and analyze it. You can see the woman is in closer than the wall and so forth. But the whole thing is actually flat. It's painted. It's trompe l'oeil. And it was such a good trompe l'oeil that people got irritated when they tried to talk to the woman and she wouldn't respond.Now, you can make design mistakes. Like this building in New York. So that when you see it from this side, it looks like the balconies tilt up, and when you walk around to the other side it looks like the balconies go down. So there are cases where you have mistakes in design that incorporate illusions. Or, you take this particular un-retouched photograph. Now, interestingly enough, I get a lot of emails from people who say, "Is there any perceptual difference between males and females?" And I really say, "No." I mean, women can navigate through the world just as well as males can — and why wouldn't they? However, this is the one illusion that women can consistently do better than males: in matching which head because they rely on fashion cues. They can match the hat.Okay, now getting to a part — I want to show design in illusions. I believe that the first example of illusions being used purposely was by da Vinci in this anamorphic image of an eye. So that when you saw from one little angle was like this. And this little technique got popular in the 16th century and the 17th century to disguise hidden meanings, where you could flip the image and see it from one little point of view like this. But these are early incorporations of illusions brought to — sort of high point with Hans Holbein's "Ambassadors." And Hans Holbein worked for Henry VIII. This was hung on a wall where you could walk down from the stair and you can see this hidden skull.All right, now I'm going to show you some designers who work with illusions to give that element of surprise. One of my favorites is Scott Kim. I worked with Scott to create some illusions for TED that I hope you will enjoy. We have one here on TED and happiness. OK now. Arthur [Ganson] hasn't talked yet, but his is going to be a delightful talk and he has some of his really fantastic machines outside. And so, we — Scott created this wonderful tribute to Arthur Ganson.Well, there's analog and digital. Thought that was appropriate here. And figure goes to ground. And for the musicians. And of course, since happiness — we want "joy to the world." Now, another great designer — he's very well known in Japan — Shigeo Fukuda. And he just builds some fantastic things. This is simply amazing. This is a pile of junk that when you view it from one particular angle, you see its reflection in the mirror as a perfect piano. Pianist transforms to violinist. This is really wild. This assemblage of forks, knives and spoons and various cutlery, welded together. It gives a shadow of a motorcycle. You learn something in the sort of thing that I do, which is there are people out there with a lot of time on their hands.Ken Knowlton does wonderful composite images, like creating Jacques Cousteau out of seashells — un-retouched seashells, but just by rearranging them. He did Einstein out of dice because, after all, Einstein said, "God does not play dice with the universe." Bert Herzog out of un-retouched keyboards. Will Shortz, crossword puzzle. John Cederquist does these wonderful trompe l'oeil cabinets.Now, I'm going to skip ahead since I'm sort of running [behind]. I want to show you quickly what I've created, some new type of illusions. I've done something with taking the Pixar-type illusions. So you see these kids the same size here, running down the hall. The two table tops of the same size. They're looking out two directions at once. You have a larger piece fitting in with a smaller. And that's something for you to think about, all right? So you see larger pieces fitting in within smaller pieces here. Does everyone see that? Which is impossible. You can see the two kids are looking out simultaneously out of two different directions at once. Now can you believe these two table tops are the same size and shape? They are. So, if you measured them, they would be. And as I say, those two figures are identical in size and shape. And it's interesting, by doing this in this sort of rendered fashion, how much stronger the illusions are. Any case, I hope this has brought you a little joy and happiness, and if you're interested in seeing more cool effects, see me outside. I'd be happy to show you lots of things.
