title: To invent is to give
transcript: As you pointed out, every time you come here, you learn something. This morning, the world's experts from I guess three or four different companies on building seats, I think concluded that ultimately, the solution is, people shouldn't sit down. I could have told them that. (Laughter) Yesterday, the automotive guys gave us some new insights. They pointed out that, I believe it was between 30 and 50 years from today, they will be steering cars by wire, without all that mechanical stuff. (Laughter) That's reassuring. (Applause) They then pointed out that there'd be, sort of, the other controls by wire, to get rid of all that mechanical stuff. That's pretty good, but why not get rid of the wires? Then you don't need anything to control the car, except thinking about it. I would love to talk about the technology, and sometime, in what's past the 15 minutes, I'll be happy to talk to all the techno-geeks around here about what's in here. But if I had one thing to say about this, before we get to first, it would be that from the time we started building this, the big idea wasn't the technology. It really was a big idea in technology when we started applying it in the iBOT for the disabled community. The big idea here is, I think, a new piece of a solution to a fairly big problem in transportation. And maybe to put that in perspective: there's so much data on this, I'll be happy to give it to you in different forms. You never know what strikes the fancy of whom, but everybody is perfectly willing to believe the car changed the world. And Henry Ford, just about 100 years ago, started cranking out Model Ts. What I don't think most people think about is the context of how technology is applied. For instance, in that time, 91 percent of America lived either on farms or in small towns. So, the car — the horseless carriage that replaced the horse and carriage — was a big deal; it went twice as fast as a horse and carriage. It was half as long. And it was an environmental improvement, because, for instance, in 1903 they outlawed horses and buggies in downtown Manhattan, because you can imagine what the roads look like when you have a million horses, and a million of them urinating and doing other things, and the typhoid and other problems created were almost unimaginable. So the car was the clean environmental alternative to a horse and buggy. It also was a way for people to get from their farm to a farm, or their farm to a town, or from a town to a city. It all made sense, with 91 percent of the people living there. By the 1950s, we started connecting all the towns together with what a lot of people claim is the eighth wonder of the world, the highway system. And it is certainly a wonder. And by the way, as I take shots at old technologies, I want to assure everybody, and particularly the automotive industry — who's been very supportive of us — that I don't think this in any way competes with airplanes, or cars. But think about where the world is today. 50 percent of the global population now lives in cities. That's 3.2 billion people. We've solved all the transportation problems that have changed the world to get it to where we are today. 500 years ago, sailing ships started getting reliable enough; we found a new continent. 150 years ago, locomotives got efficient enough, steam power, that we turned the continent into a country. Over the last hundred years, we started building cars, and then over the 50 years we've connected every city to every other city in an extraordinarily efficient way, and we have a very high standard of living as a consequence of that. But during that entire process, more and more people have been born, and more and more people are moving to cities. China alone is going to move four to six hundred million people into cities in the next decade and a half. And so, nobody, I think, would argue that airplanes, in the last 50 years, have turned the continent and the country now into a neighborhood. And if you just look at how technology has been applied, we've solved all the long-range, high-speed, high-volume, large-weight problems of moving things around. Nobody would want to give them up. And I certainly wouldn't want to give up my airplane, or my helicopter, or my Humvee, or my Porsche. I love them all. I don't keep any of them in my living room. The fact is, the last mile is the problem, and half the world now lives in dense cities. And people spend, depending on who they are, between 90 and 95 percent of their energy getting around on foot. I think there's — I don't know what data would impress you, but how about, 43 percent of the refined fuel produced in the world is consumed by cars in metropolitan areas in the United States. Three million people die every year in cities due to bad air, and almost all particulate pollution on this planet is produced by transportation devices, particularly sitting in cities. And again, I say that not to attack any industry, I think — I really do — I love my airplane, and cars on highways moving 60 miles an hour are extraordinarily efficient, both from an engineering point of view, an energy consumption point of view, and a utility point of view. And we all love our cars, and I do. The problem is, you get into the city and you want to go four blocks, it's neither fun nor efficient nor productive. It's not sustainable. If — in China, in the year 1998, 417 million people used bicycles; 1.7 million people used cars. If five percent of that population became, quote, middle class, and wanted to go the way we've gone in the last hundred years at the same time that 50 percent of their population are moving into cities of the size and density of Manhattan, every six weeks — it isn't sustainable environmentally; it isn't sustainable economically — there just ain't enough oil — and it's not sustainable politically. I mean, what are we fighting over right now? We can make it complicated, but what's the world fighting over right now? So it seemed to me that somebody had to work on that last mile, and it was dumb luck. We were working on iBOTs, but once we made this, we instantly decided it could be a great alternative to jet skis. You don't need the water. Or snowmobiles. You don't need the snow. Or skiing. It's just fun, and people love to move around doing fun things. And every one of those industries, by the way — just golf carts alone is a multi-billion-dollar industry. But rather than go license this off, which is what we normally do, it seemed to me that if we put all our effort not into the technology, but into an understanding of a world that's solved all its other problems, but has somehow come to accept that cities — which, right back from ancient Greece on, were meant to walk around, cities that were architected and built for people — now have a footprint that, while we've solved every other transportation problem — and it's like Moore's law. I mean, look at the time it took to cross a continent in a Conestoga wagon, then on a railroad, then an airplane. Every other form of transportation's been improved. In 5,000 years, we've gone backwards in getting around cities. They've gotten bigger; they're spread out. The most expensive real estate on this planet in every city — Wilshire Boulevard, or Fifth Avenue, or Tokyo, or Paris — the most expensive real estate is their downtowns. 65 percent of the landmass of our cities are parked cars. The 20 largest cities in the world. So you wonder, what if cities could give to their pedestrians what we take for granted as we now go between cities? What if you could make them fun, attractive, clean, environmentally friendly? What if it would make it a little bit more palatable to have access via this, as that last link to mass transit, to get out to your cars so we can all live in the suburbs and use our cars the way we want, and then have our cities energized again? We thought it would be really neat to do that, and one of the problems we really were worried about is: how do we get legal on the sidewalk? Because technically I've got motors; I've got wheels — I'm a motor vehicle. I don't look like a motor vehicle. I have the same footprint as a pedestrian; I have the same unique capability to deal with other pedestrians in a crowded space. I took this down to Ground Zero, and knocked my way through crowds for an hour. I'm a pedestrian. But the law typically lags technology by a generation or two, and if we get told we don't belong on the sidewalk, we have two choices. We're a recreational vehicle that doesn't really matter, and I don't spend my time doing that kind of stuff. Or maybe we should be out in the street in front of a Greyhound bus or a vehicle. We've been so concerned about that, we went to the Postmaster General of the United States, as the first person we ever showed on the outside, and said, "Put your people on it. Everybody trusts their postman. And they belong on the sidewalks, and they'll use it seriously." He agreed. We went to a number of police departments that want their police officers back in the neighborhood on the beat, carrying 70 pounds of stuff. They love it. And I can't believe a policeman is going to give themselves a ticket. (Laughter) So we've been working really, really hard, but we knew that the technology would not be as hard to develop as an attitude about what's important, and how to apply the technology. We went out and we found some visionary people with enough money to let us design and build these things, and in hopefully enough time to get them accepted. So, I'm happy, really, I am happy to talk about this technology as much as you want. And yes, it's really fun, and yes, you should all go out and try it. But if I could ask you to do one thing, it's not to think about it as a piece of technology, but just imagine that, although we all understand somehow that it's reasonable that we use our 4,000-pound machine, which can go 60 miles an hour, that can bring you everywhere you want to go, and somehow it's also what we used for the last mile, and it's broken, and it doesn't work. One of the more exciting things that occurred to us about why it might get accepted, happened out here in California. A few weeks ago, after we launched it, we were here with a news crew on Venice Beach, zipping up and back, and he's marveling at the technology, and meanwhile bicycles are zipping by, and skateboarders are zipping by, and a little old lady — I mean, if you looked in the dictionary, a little old lady — came by me — and now that I'm on this, I'm the height of a normal adult now — and she just stops, and the camera is there, and she looks up at me and says, "Can I try that?" And what was I — you know, how are you going to say anything? And so I said, "Sure." So I get off, and she gets on, and with a little bit of the usual, ah, then she turns around, and she goes about 20 feet, and she turns back around, and she's all smiles. And she comes back to me and she stops, and she says, "Finally, they made something for us." And the camera is looking down at her. I'm thinking, "Wow, that was great — (Laughter) — please lady, don't say another word." (Laughter) And the camera is down at her, and this guy has to put the microphone in her face, said, "What do you mean by that?" And I figured, "It's all over now," and she looks up and she says, "Well," she's still watching these guys go; she says, "I can't ride a bike," no, she says, "I can't use a skateboard, and I've never used roller blades," she knew them by name; she says, "And it's been 50 years since I rode a bicycle." Then she looks up, she's looking up, and she says, "And I'm 81 years old, and I don't drive a car anymore. I still have to get to the store, and I can't carry a lot of things." And it suddenly occurred to me, that among my many fears, were not just that the bureaucracy and the regulators and the legislators might not get it — it was that, fundamentally, you believe there's pressure among the people not to invade the most precious little bit of space left, the sidewalks in these cities. When you look at the 36 inches of legal requirement for sidewalk, then the eight foot for the parked car, then the three lanes, and then the other eight feet — it's — that little piece is all that's there. But she looks up and says this, and it occurs to me, well, kids aren't going to mind these things, and they don't vote, and business people and then young adults aren't going to mind these things — they're pretty cool — so I guess subliminally I was worried that it's the older population that's going to worry. So, having seen this, and having worried about it for eight years, the first thing I do is pick up my phone and ask our marketing and regulatory guys, call AARP, get an appointment right away. We've got to show them this thing. And they took it to Washington; they showed them; and they're going to be involved now, watching how these things get absorbed in a number of cities, like Atlanta, where we're doing trials to see if it really can, in fact, help re-energize their downtown. (Applause) The bottom line is, whether you believe the United Nations, or any of the other think tanks — in the next 20 years, all human population growth on this planet will be in cities. In Asia alone, it will be over a billion people. They learned to start with cell phones. They didn't have to take the 100-year trip we took. They start at the top of the technology food chain. We've got to start building cities and human environments where a 150-pound person can go a couple of miles in a dense, rich, green-space environment, without being in a 4,000-pound machine to do it. Cars were not meant for parallel parking; they're wonderful machines to go between cities, but just think about it: we've solved all the long-range, high-speed problems. The Greeks went from the theater of Dionysus to the Parthenon in their sandals. You do it in your sneakers. Not much has changed. If this thing goes only three times as fast as walking — three times — a 30-minute walk becomes 10 minutes. Your choice, when living in a city, if it's now 10 minutes — because at 30 minutes you want an alternative, whether it's a bus, a train — we've got to build an infrastructure — a light rail — or you're going to keep parking those cars. But if you could put a pin in most cities, and imagine how far you could, if you had the time, walk in one half-hour, it's the city. If you could make it fun, and make it eight or 10 minutes, you can't find your car, un-park your car, move your car, re-park your car and go somewhere; you can't get to a cab or a subway. We could change the way people allocate their resources, the way this planet uses its energy, make it more fun. And we're hoping to some extent history will say we were right. That's Segway. This is a Stirling cycle engine; this had been confused by a lot of things we're doing. This little beast, right now, is producing a few hundred watts of electricity. Yes, it could be attached to this, and yes, on a kilogram of propane, you could drive from New York to Boston if you so choose. Perhaps more interesting about this little engine is it'll burn any fuel, because some of you might be skeptical about the capability of this to have an impact, where most of the world you can't simply plug into your 120-volt outlet. We've been working on this, actually, as an alternative energy source, starting way back with Johnson & Johnson, to run an iBOT, because the best batteries you could get — 10 watt-hours per kilogram in lead, 20 watt-hours per kilogram nickel-cadmium, 40 watt-hours per kilogram in nickel-metal hydride, 60 watt-hours per kilogram in lithium, 8,750 watt-hours of energy in every kilogram of propane or gasoline — which is why nobody drives electric cars. But, in any event, if you can burn it with the same efficiency — because it's external combustion — as your kitchen stove, if you can burn any fuel, it turns out to be pretty neat. It makes just enough electricity to, for instance, do this, which at night is enough electricity, in the rest of the world, as Mr. Holly — Dr. Holly — pointed out, can run computers and a light bulb. But more interestingly, the thermodynamics of this say, you're never going to get more than 20 percent efficiency. It doesn't matter much — it says if you get 200 watts of electricity, you'll get 700 or 800 watts of heat. If you wanted to boil water and re-condense it at a rate of 10 gallons an hour, it takes about 25, a little over 25.3 kilowatt — 25,000 watts of continuous power — to do it. That's so much energy, you couldn't afford to desalinate or clean water in this country that way. Certainly, in the rest of the world, your choice is to devastate the place, turning everything that will burn into heat, or drink the water that's available. The number one cause of death on this planet among humans is bad water. Depending on whose numbers you believe, it's between 60 and 85,000 people per day. We don't need sophisticated heart transplants around the world. We need water. And women shouldn't have to spend four hours a day looking for it, or watching their kids die. We figured out how to put a vapor-compression distiller on this thing, with a counter-flow heat exchanger to take the waste heat, then using a little bit of the electricity control that process, and for 450 watts, which is a little more than half of its waste heat, it will make 10 gallons an hour of distilled water from anything that comes into it to cool it. So if we put this box on here in a few years, could we have a solution to transportation, electricity, and communication, and maybe drinkable water in a sustainable package that weighs 60 pounds? I don't know, but we'll try it. I better shut up. (Applause)

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:18.958
The problem is, you get into the city and you want to go four blocks,

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:22.958
it's neither fun nor efficient nor productive.

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:24.958
It's not sustainable.

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:30.958
If -- in China, in the year 1998, 417 million people used bicycles;

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:33.958
1.7 million people used cars.

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:38.958
If five percent of that population became, quote, middle class,

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:43.958
and wanted to go the way we've gone in the last hundred years

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:46.958
at the same time that 50 percent of their population are moving into cities

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:50.958
of the size and density of Manhattan, every six weeks --

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:52.958
it isn't sustainable environmentally;

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:56.958
it isn't sustainable economically -- there just ain't enough oil --

00:06:56.958 --> 00:06:58.958
and it's not sustainable politically.

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:00.958
I mean, what are we fighting over right now?

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:04.958
We can make it complicated, but what's the world fighting over right now?

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:11.958
So it seemed to me that somebody had to work on that last mile,

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:14.958
and it was dumb luck. We were working on iBOTs,

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:16.958
but once we made this, we instantly decided

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:20.958
it could be a great alternative to jet skis. You don't need the water.

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:22.958
Or snowmobiles. You don't need the snow.

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:28.958
Or skiing. It's just fun, and people love to move around doing fun things.

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:31.958
And every one of those industries, by the way --

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:34.958
just golf carts alone is a multi-billion-dollar industry.

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:37.958
But rather than go license this off, which is what we normally do,

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:41.958
it seemed to me that if we put all our effort not into the technology,

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:45.958
but into an understanding of a world that's solved all its other problems,

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:50.958
but has somehow come to accept that cities -- which,

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:53.958
right back from ancient Greece on, were meant to walk around,

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:56.958
cities that were architected and built for people --

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:58.958
now have a footprint that,

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:00.958
while we've solved every other transportation problem --

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:02.958
and it's like Moore's law.

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:07.958
I mean, look at the time it took to cross a continent in a Conestoga wagon,

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:10.958
then on a railroad, then an airplane.

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:13.958
Every other form of transportation's been improved.

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:18.958
In 5,000 years, we've gone backwards in getting around cities.

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:21.958
They've gotten bigger; they're spread out.

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:26.958
The most expensive real estate on this planet in every city --

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:30.958
Wilshire Boulevard, or Fifth Avenue, or Tokyo, or Paris --

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:33.958
the most expensive real estate is their downtowns.

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:37.958
65 percent of the landmass of our cities are parked cars.

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:39.958
The 20 largest cities in the world.

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:44.958
So you wonder, what if cities could give to their pedestrians

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:48.958
what we take for granted as we now go between cities?

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:52.958
What if you could make them fun, attractive, clean,

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:54.958
environmentally friendly?

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:59.958
What if it would make it a little bit more palatable

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:05.958
to have access via this, as that last link to mass transit,

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:08.958
to get out to your cars so we can all live in the suburbs

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:10.958
and use our cars the way we want,

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:14.958
and then have our cities energized again?

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:17.958
We thought it would be really neat to do that,

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:19.958
and one of the problems we really were worried about

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:22.958
is: how do we get legal on the sidewalk?

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:26.958
Because technically I've got motors; I've got wheels -- I'm a motor vehicle.

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:28.958
I don't look like a motor vehicle.

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:30.958
I have the same footprint as a pedestrian;

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:34.958
I have the same unique capability

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:36.958
to deal with other pedestrians in a crowded space.

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:38.958
I took this down to Ground Zero,

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:41.958
and knocked my way through crowds for an hour.

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:46.958
I'm a pedestrian. But the law typically lags technology by a generation or two,

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:52.958
and if we get told we don't belong on the sidewalk, we have two choices.

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:54.958
We're a recreational vehicle that doesn't really matter,

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:59.958
and I don't spend my time doing that kind of stuff.

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:01.958
Or maybe we should be out in the street

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:04.958
in front of a Greyhound bus or a vehicle.

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:07.958
We've been so concerned about that,

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:09.958
we went to the Postmaster General of the United States,

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:12.958
as the first person we ever showed on the outside,

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:16.958
and said, "Put your people on it. Everybody trusts their postman.

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:21.958
And they belong on the sidewalks, and they'll use it seriously."

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:24.958
He agreed. We went to a number of police departments

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:26.958
that want their police officers back in the neighborhood

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:30.958
on the beat, carrying 70 pounds of stuff. They love it.

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:34.958
And I can't believe a policeman is going to give themselves a ticket.

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:37.958
(Laughter)

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:39.958
So we've been working really, really hard,

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:42.958
but we knew that the technology would not be as hard to develop

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:47.958
as an attitude about what's important, and how to apply the technology.

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:50.958
We went out and we found some visionary people

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:55.958
with enough money to let us design and build these things,

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:59.958
and in hopefully enough time to get them accepted.

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:04.958
So, I'm happy, really, I am happy to talk about this technology as much as you want.

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:08.958
And yes, it's really fun, and yes, you should all go out and try it.

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:10.958
But if I could ask you to do one thing,

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:12.958
it's not to think about it as a piece of technology,

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:16.958
but just imagine that, although we all understand somehow

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:20.958
that it's reasonable that we use our 4,000-pound machine,

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:22.958
which can go 60 miles an hour,

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:24.958
that can bring you everywhere you want to go,

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:30.958
and somehow it's also what we used for the last mile,

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:33.958
and it's broken, and it doesn't work.

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:36.958
One of the more exciting things that occurred to us

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:41.958
about why it might get accepted, happened out here in California.

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:43.958
A few weeks ago, after we launched it,

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:48.958
we were here with a news crew on Venice Beach, zipping up and back,

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:50.958
and he's marveling at the technology,

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:52.958
and meanwhile bicycles are zipping by,

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:54.958
and skateboarders are zipping by,

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:58.958
and a little old lady -- I mean, if you looked in the dictionary,

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:01.958
a little old lady -- came by me --

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:05.958
and now that I'm on this, I'm the height of a normal adult now --

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:11.958
and she just stops, and the camera is there, and she looks up at me

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:14.958
and says, "Can I try that?"

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:17.958
And what was I -- you know, how are you going to say anything?

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:19.958
And so I said, "Sure."

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:25.958
So I get off, and she gets on, and with a little bit of the usual, ah,

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:30.958
then she turns around, and she goes about 20 feet,

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:33.958
and she turns back around, and she's all smiles.

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:39.958
And she comes back to me and she stops, and she says,

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:43.958
"Finally, they made something for us."

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:45.958
And the camera is looking down at her.

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:47.958
I'm thinking, "Wow, that was great --

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:48.958
(Laughter)

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:50.958
-- please lady, don't say another word."

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:53.958
(Laughter)

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:55.958
And the camera is down at her,

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:57.958
and this guy has to put the microphone in her face,

00:12:57.958 --> 00:12:59.958
said, "What do you mean by that?"

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:01.958
And I figured, "It's all over now,"

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:05.958
and she looks up and she says, "Well,"

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:08.958
she's still watching these guys go; she says, "I can't ride a bike," no,

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:12.958
she says, "I can't use a skateboard, and I've never used roller blades,"

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:14.958
she knew them by name;

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:17.958
she says, "And it's been 50 years since I rode a bicycle."

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:21.958
Then she looks up, she's looking up, and she says,

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:25.958
"And I'm 81 years old, and I don't drive a car anymore.

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:29.958
I still have to get to the store, and I can't carry a lot of things."

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:33.958
And it suddenly occurred to me, that among my many fears,

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:36.958
were not just that the bureaucracy and the regulators

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:39.958
and the legislators might not get it --

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:44.958
it was that, fundamentally, you believe there's pressure among the people

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:47.958
not to invade the most precious little bit of space left,

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:49.958
the sidewalks in these cities.

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:53.958
When you look at the 36 inches of legal requirement for sidewalk,

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:56.958
then the eight foot for the parked car, then the three lanes,

00:13:56.958 --> 00:13:58.958
and then the other eight feet -- it's --

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:02.958
that little piece is all that's there.

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:04.958
But she looks up and says this,

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:06.958
and it occurs to me, well, kids aren't going to mind these things,

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:10.958
and they don't vote, and business people and then young adults

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:12.958
aren't going to mind these things -- they're pretty cool --

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:14.958
so I guess subliminally I was worried

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:17.958
that it's the older population that's going to worry.

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:22.958
So, having seen this, and having worried about it for eight years,

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:26.958
the first thing I do is pick up my phone and ask our marketing and regulatory guys,

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:29.958
call AARP, get an appointment right away.

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:31.958
We've got to show them this thing.

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:34.958
And they took it to Washington; they showed them;

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:36.958
and they're going to be involved now,

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:40.958
watching how these things get absorbed in a number of cities,

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:44.958
like Atlanta, where we're doing trials to see if it really can, in fact,

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:47.958
help re-energize their downtown.

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:54.958
(Applause)

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:59.958
The bottom line is, whether you believe the United Nations,

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:01.958
or any of the other think tanks --

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:05.958
in the next 20 years, all human population growth on this planet

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:07.958
will be in cities.

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:10.958
In Asia alone, it will be over a billion people.

00:15:10.958 --> 00:15:14.958
They learned to start with cell phones.

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:17.958
They didn't have to take the 100-year trip we took.

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:20.958
They start at the top of the technology food chain.

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:23.958
We've got to start building cities and human environments

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:26.958
where a 150-pound person can go a couple of miles

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:29.958
in a dense, rich, green-space environment,

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:33.958
without being in a 4,000-pound machine to do it.

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:36.958
Cars were not meant for parallel parking;

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:40.958
they're wonderful machines to go between cities, but just think about it:

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:45.958
we've solved all the long-range, high-speed problems.

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:50.958
The Greeks went from the theater of Dionysus to the Parthenon in their sandals.

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:52.958
You do it in your sneakers.

00:15:52.958 --> 00:15:54.958
Not much has changed.

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:59.958
If this thing goes only three times as fast as walking -- three times --

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:01.958
a 30-minute walk becomes 10 minutes.

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:06.958
Your choice, when living in a city, if it's now 10 minutes --

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:10.958
because at 30 minutes you want an alternative, whether it's a bus, a train --

00:16:10.958 --> 00:16:12.958
we've got to build an infrastructure -- a light rail --

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:14.958
or you're going to keep parking those cars.

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:17.958
But if you could put a pin in most cities,

00:16:17.958 --> 00:16:23.958
and imagine how far you could, if you had the time, walk in one half-hour, it's the city.

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:25.958
If you could make it fun, and make it eight or 10 minutes,

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:28.958
you can't find your car, un-park your car, move your car,

00:16:28.958 --> 00:16:30.958
re-park your car and go somewhere;

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:33.958
you can't get to a cab or a subway.

00:16:33.958 --> 00:16:36.958
We could change the way people allocate their resources,

00:16:36.958 --> 00:16:39.958
the way this planet uses its energy,

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:41.958
make it more fun.

00:16:41.958 --> 00:16:45.958
And we're hoping to some extent history will say we were right.

00:16:46.958 --> 00:16:49.958
That's Segway. This is a Stirling cycle engine;

00:16:49.958 --> 00:16:53.958
this had been confused by a lot of things we're doing.

00:16:53.958 --> 00:16:58.958
This little beast, right now, is producing a few hundred watts of electricity.

00:16:58.958 --> 00:17:00.958
Yes, it could be attached to this,

00:17:00.958 --> 00:17:03.958
and yes, on a kilogram of propane,

00:17:03.958 --> 00:17:08.958
you could drive from New York to Boston if you so choose.

00:17:08.958 --> 00:17:12.958
Perhaps more interesting about this little engine is it'll burn any fuel,

00:17:12.958 --> 00:17:14.958
because some of you might be skeptical

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:18.958
about the capability of this to have an impact,

00:17:18.958 --> 00:17:22.958
where most of the world you can't simply plug into your 120-volt outlet.

00:17:22.958 --> 00:17:24.958
We've been working on this,

00:17:24.958 --> 00:17:26.958
actually, as an alternative energy source,

00:17:26.958 --> 00:17:28.958
starting way back with Johnson & Johnson, to run an iBOT,

00:17:28.958 --> 00:17:32.958
because the best batteries you could get --

00:17:32.958 --> 00:17:34.958
10 watt-hours per kilogram in lead,

00:17:34.958 --> 00:17:36.958
20 watt-hours per kilogram nickel-cadmium,

00:17:36.958 --> 00:17:38.958
40 watt-hours per kilogram in nickel-metal hydride,

00:17:38.958 --> 00:17:41.958
60 watt-hours per kilogram in lithium,

00:17:41.958 --> 00:17:46.958
8,750 watt-hours of energy in every kilogram of propane or gasoline --

00:17:46.958 --> 00:17:48.958
which is why nobody drives electric cars.

00:17:48.958 --> 00:17:54.958
But, in any event, if you can burn it with the same efficiency --

00:17:54.958 --> 00:17:57.958
because it's external combustion -- as your kitchen stove,

00:17:57.958 --> 00:18:00.958
if you can burn any fuel, it turns out to be pretty neat.

00:18:00.958 --> 00:18:03.958
It makes just enough electricity to, for instance, do this,

00:18:03.958 --> 00:18:06.958
which at night is enough electricity, in the rest of the world,

00:18:06.958 --> 00:18:09.958
as Mr. Holly -- Dr. Holly -- pointed out,

00:18:09.958 --> 00:18:12.958
can run computers and a light bulb.

00:18:12.958 --> 00:18:16.958
But more interestingly, the thermodynamics of this say,

00:18:16.958 --> 00:18:19.958
you're never going to get more than 20 percent efficiency.

00:18:19.958 --> 00:18:22.958
It doesn't matter much -- it says if you get 200 watts of electricity,

00:18:22.958 --> 00:18:25.958
you'll get 700 or 800 watts of heat.

00:18:25.958 --> 00:18:30.958
If you wanted to boil water and re-condense it at a rate of 10 gallons an hour,

00:18:30.958 --> 00:18:33.958
it takes about 25, a little over 25.3 kilowatt --

00:18:33.958 --> 00:18:37.958
25,000 watts of continuous power -- to do it.

00:18:37.958 --> 00:18:39.958
That's so much energy, you couldn't afford to desalinate

00:18:39.958 --> 00:18:41.958
or clean water in this country that way.

00:18:41.958 --> 00:18:45.958
Certainly, in the rest of the world, your choice is to devastate the place,

00:18:45.958 --> 00:18:50.958
turning everything that will burn into heat, or drink the water that's available.

00:18:50.958 --> 00:18:54.958
The number one cause of death on this planet among humans is bad water.

00:18:54.958 --> 00:18:56.958
Depending on whose numbers you believe,

00:18:56.958 --> 00:18:59.958
it's between 60 and 85,000 people per day.

00:18:59.958 --> 00:19:02.958
We don't need sophisticated heart transplants around the world.

00:19:02.958 --> 00:19:04.958
We need water.

00:19:04.958 --> 00:19:07.958
And women shouldn't have to spend four hours a day looking for it,

00:19:07.958 --> 00:19:09.958
or watching their kids die.

00:19:09.958 --> 00:19:12.958
We figured out how to put a vapor-compression distiller on this thing,

00:19:12.958 --> 00:19:15.958
with a counter-flow heat exchanger to take the waste heat,

00:19:15.958 --> 00:19:19.958
then using a little bit of the electricity control that process,

00:19:19.958 --> 00:19:25.958
and for 450 watts, which is a little more than half of its waste heat,

00:19:25.958 --> 00:19:27.958
it will make 10 gallons an hour of distilled water

00:19:27.958 --> 00:19:29.958
from anything that comes into it to cool it.

00:19:29.958 --> 00:19:32.958
So if we put this box on here in a few years,

00:19:32.958 --> 00:19:38.958
could we have a solution to transportation, electricity,

00:19:38.958 --> 00:19:42.958
and communication, and maybe drinkable water

00:19:42.958 --> 00:19:46.958
in a sustainable package that weighs 60 pounds?

00:19:46.958 --> 00:19:48.958
I don't know, but we'll try it.

00:19:48.958 --> 00:19:50.958
I better shut up.

00:19:50.958 --> 00:20:00.958
(Applause)

title: The life code that will reshape the future
transcript: I'm supposed to scare you, because it's about fear, right? And you should be really afraid, but not for the reasons why you think you should be. You should be really afraid that — if we stick up the first slide on this thing — there we go — that you're missing out. Because if you spend this week thinking about Iraq and thinking about Bush and thinking about the stock market, you're going to miss one of the greatest adventures that we've ever been on. And this is what this adventure's really about. This is crystallized DNA. Every life form on this planet — every insect, every bacteria, every plant, every animal, every human, every politician — (Laughter) is coded in that stuff. And if you want to take a single crystal of DNA, it looks like that. And we're just beginning to understand this stuff. And this is the single most exciting adventure that we have ever been on. It's the single greatest mapping project we've ever been on. If you think that the mapping of America's made a difference, or landing on the moon, or this other stuff, it's the map of ourselves and the map of every plant and every insect and every bacteria that really makes a difference. And it's beginning to tell us a lot about evolution. (Laughter)It turns out that what this stuff is — and Richard Dawkins has written about this — is, this is really a river out of Eden. So, the 3.2 billion base pairs inside each of your cells is really a history of where you've been for the past billion years. And we could start dating things, and we could start changing medicine and archeology. It turns out that if you take the human species about 700 years ago, white Europeans diverged from black Africans in a very significant way. White Europeans were subject to the plague. And when they were subject to the plague, most people didn't survive, but those who survived had a mutation on the CCR5 receptor. And that mutation was passed on to their kids because they're the ones that survived, so there was a great deal of population pressure. In Africa, because you didn't have these cities, you didn't have that CCR5 population pressure mutation. We can date it to 700 years ago. That is one of the reasons why AIDS is raging across Africa as fast as it is, and not as fast across Europe. And we're beginning to find these little things for malaria, for sickle cell, for cancers. 00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:19.958
and it was eating iron when the earth was part of a melted core.

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:24.958
So, it's not just dogs and cats and whales and dolphins

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:28.958
that you should be aware of and interested in on this little journey.

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:31.958
Your fear should be that you are not,

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:34.958
that you're paying attention to stuff which is temporal.

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:39.958
I mean, George Bush -- he's going to be gone, alright? Life isn't.

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:43.958
Whether the humans survive or don't survive,

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:46.958
these things are going to be living on this planet or other planets.

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:50.958
And it's just beginning to understand this code of DNA

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:53.958
that's really the most exciting intellectual adventure

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:56.958
that we've ever been on.

00:06:56.958 --> 00:07:00.958
And you can do strange things with this stuff. This is a baby gaur.

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:02.958
Conservation group gets together,

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:06.958
tries to figure out how to breed an animal that's almost extinct.

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:10.958
They can't do it naturally, so what they do with this thing is

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:15.958
they take a spoon, take some cells out of an adult gaur's mouth, code,

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:20.958
take the cells from that and insert it into a fertilized cow's egg,

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:24.958
reprogram cow's egg -- different gene code.

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:29.958
When you do that, the cow gives birth to a gaur.

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:36.958
We are now experimenting with bongos, pandas, elands, Sumatran tigers,

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:39.958
and the Australians -- bless their hearts --

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:40.958
are playing with these things.

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:44.958
Now, the last of these things died in September 1936.

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:48.958
These are Tasmanian tigers. The last known one died at the Hobart Zoo.

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:51.958
But it turns out that as we learn more about gene code

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:53.958
and how to reprogram species,

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:58.958
we may be able to close the gene gaps in deteriorate DNA.

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:01.958
And when we learn how to close the gene gaps,

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:03.958
then we can put a full string of DNA together.

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:08.958
And if we do that, and insert this into a fertilized wolf's egg,

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:11.958
we may give birth to an animal

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:13.958
that hasn't walked the earth since 1936.

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:16.958
And then you can start going back further,

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:18.958
and you can start thinking about dodos,

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:20.958
and you can think about other species.

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:24.958
And in other places, like Maryland, they're trying to figure out

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:26.958
what the primordial ancestor is.

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:29.958
Because each of us contains our entire gene code

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:32.958
of where we've been for the past billion years,

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:34.958
because we've evolved from that stuff,

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:36.958
you can take that tree of life and collapse it back,

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:39.958
and in the measure that you learn to reprogram,

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:41.958
maybe we'll give birth to something

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:43.958
that is very close to the first primordial ooze.

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:45.958
And it's all coming out of things that look like this.

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:47.958
These are companies that didn't exist five years ago.

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:51.958
Huge gene sequencing facilities the size of football fields.

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:53.958
Some are public. Some are private.

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:56.958
It takes about 5 billion dollars to sequence a human being the first time.

00:08:57.958 --> 00:08:59.958
Takes about 3 million dollars the second time.

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:03.958
We will have a 1,000-dollar genome within the next five to eight years.

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:07.958
That means each of you will contain on a CD your entire gene code.

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:10.958
And it will be really boring. It will read like this.

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:13.958
(Laughter)

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:15.958
The really neat thing about this stuff is that's life.

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:18.958
And Laurie's going to talk about this one a little bit.

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:20.958
Because if you happen to find this one inside your body,

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:22.958
you're in big trouble, because that's the source code for Ebola.

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:26.958
That's one of the deadliest diseases known to humans.

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:28.958
But plants work the same way and insects work the same way,

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:30.958
and this apple works the same way.

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:32.958
This apple is the same thing as this floppy disk.

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:34.958
Because this thing codes ones and zeros,

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:36.958
and this thing codes A, T, C, Gs, and it sits up there,

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:39.958
absorbing energy on a tree, and one fine day

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:43.958
it has enough energy to say, execute, and it goes [thump]. Right?

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:46.958
(Laughter)

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:50.958
And when it does that, pushes a .EXE, what it does is,

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:53.958
it executes the first line of code, which reads just like that,

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:56.958
AATCAGGGACCC, and that means: make a root.

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:58.958
Next line of code: make a stem.

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:01.958
Next line of code, TACGGGG: make a flower that's white,

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:04.958
that blooms in the spring, that smells like this.

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:06.958
In the measure that you have the code

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:09.958
and the measure that you read it --

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:11.958
and, by the way, the first plant was read two years ago;

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:13.958
the first human was read two years ago;

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:15.958
the first insect was read two years ago.

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:18.958
The first thing that we ever read was in 1995:

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:20.958
a little bacteria called Haemophilus influenzae.

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:24.958
In the measure that you have the source code, as all of you know,

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:26.958
you can change the source code, and you can reprogram life forms

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:28.958
so that this little thingy becomes a vaccine,

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:31.958
or this little thingy starts producing biomaterials,

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:34.958
which is why DuPont is now growing a form of polyester

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:36.958
that feels like silk in corn.

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:42.958
This changes all rules. This is life, but we're reprogramming it.

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:48.958
This is what you look like. This is one of your chromosomes.

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:50.958
And what you can do now is,

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:53.958
you can outlay exactly what your chromosome is,

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:56.958
and what the gene code on that chromosome is right here,

00:10:56.958 --> 00:10:59.958
and what those genes code for, and what animals they code against,

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:01.958
and then you can tie it to the literature.

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:04.958
And in the measure that you can do that, you can go home today,

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:06.958
and get on the Internet, and access

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:09.958
the world's biggest public library, which is a library of life.

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:12.958
And you can do some pretty strange things

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:14.958
because in the same way as you can reprogram this apple,

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:17.958
if you go to Cliff Tabin's lab at the Harvard Medical School,

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:22.958
he's reprogramming chicken embryos to grow more wings.

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:27.958
Why would Cliff be doing that? He doesn't have a restaurant.

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:28.958
(Laughter)

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:32.958
The reason why he's reprogramming that animal to have more wings

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:35.958
is because when you used to play with lizards as a little child,

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:39.958
and you picked up the lizard, sometimes the tail fell off, but it regrew.

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:42.958
Not so in human beings:

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:45.958
you cut off an arm, you cut off a leg -- it doesn't regrow.

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:49.958
But because each of your cells contains your entire gene code,

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:54.958
each cell can be reprogrammed, if we don't stop stem cell research

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:56.958
and if we don't stop genomic research,

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:59.958
to express different body functions.

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:03.958
And in the measure that we learn how chickens grow wings,

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:05.958
and what the program is for those cells to differentiate,

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:08.958
one of the things we're going to be able to do

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:11.958
is to stop undifferentiated cells, which you know as cancer,

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:14.958
and one of the things we're going to learn how to do

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:17.958
is how to reprogram cells like stem cells

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:23.958
in such a way that they express bone, stomach, skin, pancreas.

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:27.958
And you are likely to be wandering around -- and your children --

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:30.958
on regrown body parts in a reasonable period of time,

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:34.958
in some places in the world where they don't stop the research.

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:41.958
How's this stuff work? If each of you differs

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:44.958
from the person next to you by one in a thousand, but only three percent codes,

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:46.958
which means it's only one in a thousand times three percent,

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:49.958
very small differences in expression and punctuation

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:52.958
can make a significant difference. Take a simple declarative sentence.

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:56.958
(Laughter)

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:57.958
Right?

00:12:57.958 --> 00:13:01.958
That's perfectly clear. So, men read that sentence,

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:03.958
and they look at that sentence, and they read this.

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:10.958
Okay?

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:14.958
Now, women look at that sentence and they say, uh-uh, wrong.

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:16.958
This is the way it should be seen.

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:26.958
(Laughter)

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:27.958
That's what your genes are doing.

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:32.958
That's why you differ from this person over here by one in a thousand.

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:35.958
Right? But, you know, he's reasonably good looking, but...

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:37.958
I won't go there.

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:41.958
You can do this stuff even without changing the punctuation.

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:46.958
You can look at this, right?

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:48.958
And they look at the world a little differently.

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:50.958
They look at the same world and they say...

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:56.958
(Laughter)

00:13:56.958 --> 00:14:00.958
That's how the same gene code -- that's why you have 30,000 genes,

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:03.958
mice have 30,000 genes, husbands have 30,000 genes.

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:06.958
Mice and men are the same. Wives know that, but anyway.

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:09.958
You can make very small changes in gene code

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:11.958
and get really different outcomes,

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:15.958
even with the same string of letters.

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:19.958
That's what your genes are doing every day.

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:22.958
That's why sometimes a person's genes

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:24.958
don't have to change a lot to get cancer.

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:32.958
These little chippies, these things are the size of a credit card.

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:35.958
They will test any one of you for 60,000 genetic conditions.

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:39.958
That brings up questions of privacy and insurability

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:41.958
and all kinds of stuff, but it also allows us to start going after diseases,

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:45.958
because if you run a person who has leukemia through something like this,

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:48.958
it turns out that three diseases with

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:52.958
completely similar clinical syndromes

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:54.958
are completely different diseases.

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:57.958
Because in ALL leukemia, that set of genes over there over-expresses.

00:14:57.958 --> 00:14:59.958
In MLL, it's the middle set of genes,

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:01.958
and in AML, it's the bottom set of genes.

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:06.958
And if one of those particular things is expressing in your body,

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:08.958
then you take Gleevec and you're cured.

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:11.958
If it is not expressing in your body,

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:13.958
if you don't have one of those types --

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:16.958
a particular one of those types -- don't take Gleevec.

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:17.958
It won't do anything for you.

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:20.958
Same thing with Receptin if you've got breast cancer.

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:24.958
Don't have an HER-2 receptor? Don't take Receptin.

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:28.958
Changes the nature of medicine. Changes the predictions of medicine.

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:30.958
Changes the way medicine works.

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:33.958
The greatest repository of knowledge when most of us went to college

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:35.958
was this thing, and it turns out that

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:37.958
this is not so important any more.

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:41.958
The U.S. Library of Congress, in terms of its printed volume of data,

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:45.958
contains less data than is coming out of a good genomics company

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:48.958
every month on a compound basis.

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:51.958
Let me say that again: A single genomics company

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:54.958
generates more data in a month, on a compound basis,

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:57.958
than is in the printed collections of the Library of Congress.

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:02.958
This is what's been powering the U.S. economy. It's Moore's Law.

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:07.958
So, all of you know that the price of computers halves every 18 months

00:16:07.958 --> 00:16:09.958
and the power doubles, right?

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:13.958
Except that when you lay that side by side with the speed

00:16:13.958 --> 00:16:16.958
with which gene data's being deposited in GenBank,

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:20.958
Moore's Law is right here: it's the blue line.

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:25.958
This is on a log scale, and that's what superexponential growth means.

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:29.958
This is going to push computers to have to grow faster

00:16:29.958 --> 00:16:31.958
than they've been growing, because so far,

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:34.958
there haven't been applications that have been required

00:16:34.958 --> 00:16:37.958
that need to go faster than Moore's Law. This stuff does.

00:16:37.958 --> 00:16:39.958
And here's an interesting map.

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:43.958
This is a map which was finished at the Harvard Business School.

00:16:43.958 --> 00:16:46.958
One of the really interesting questions is, if all this data's free,

00:16:46.958 --> 00:16:50.958
who's using it? This is the greatest public library in the world.

00:16:50.958 --> 00:16:53.958
Well, it turns out that there's about 27 trillion bits

00:16:53.958 --> 00:16:56.958
moving inside from the United States to the United States;

00:16:56.958 --> 00:17:00.958
about 4.6 trillion is going over to those European countries;

00:17:00.958 --> 00:17:03.958
about 5.5's going to Japan; there's almost no communication

00:17:03.958 --> 00:17:07.958
between Japan, and nobody else is literate in this stuff.

00:17:07.958 --> 00:17:12.958
It's free. No one's reading it. They're focusing on the war;

00:17:12.958 --> 00:17:14.958
they're focusing on Bush; they're not interested in life.

00:17:15.958 --> 00:17:17.958
So, this is what a new map of the world looks like.

00:17:18.958 --> 00:17:24.958
That is the genomically literate world. And that is a problem.

00:17:24.958 --> 00:17:26.958
In fact, it's not a genomically literate world.

00:17:26.958 --> 00:17:28.958
You can break this out by states.

00:17:28.958 --> 00:17:30.958
And you can watch states rise and fall depending on

00:17:30.958 --> 00:17:32.958
their ability to speak a language of life,

00:17:32.958 --> 00:17:34.958
and you can watch New York fall off a cliff,

00:17:34.958 --> 00:17:36.958
and you can watch New Jersey fall off a cliff,

00:17:36.958 --> 00:17:39.958
and you can watch the rise of the new empires of intelligence.

00:17:40.958 --> 00:17:43.958
And you can break it out by counties, because it's specific counties.

00:17:43.958 --> 00:17:45.958
And if you want to get more specific,

00:17:45.958 --> 00:17:47.958
it's actually specific zip codes.

00:17:47.958 --> 00:17:49.958
(Laughter)

00:17:49.958 --> 00:17:52.958
So, you want to know where life is happening?

00:17:52.958 --> 00:17:57.958
Well, in Southern California it's happening in 92121. And that's it.

00:17:58.958 --> 00:18:03.958
And that's the triangle between Salk, Scripps, UCSD,

00:18:03.958 --> 00:18:05.958
and it's called Torrey Pines Road.

00:18:05.958 --> 00:18:08.958
That means you don't need to be a big nation to be successful;

00:18:08.958 --> 00:18:10.958
it means you don't need a lot of people to be successful;

00:18:10.958 --> 00:18:13.958
and it means you can move most of the wealth of a country

00:18:13.958 --> 00:18:16.958
in about three or four carefully picked 747s.

00:18:17.958 --> 00:18:21.958
Same thing in Massachusetts. Looks more spread out but --

00:18:21.958 --> 00:18:24.958
oh, by the way, the ones that are the same color are contiguous.

00:18:25.958 --> 00:18:27.958
What's the net effect of this?

00:18:27.958 --> 00:18:29.958
In an agricultural society, the difference between

00:18:29.958 --> 00:18:30.958
the richest and the poorest,

00:18:31.958 --> 00:18:35.958
the most productive and the least productive, was five to one. Why?

00:18:35.958 --> 00:18:37.958
Because in agriculture, if you had 10 kids

00:18:37.958 --> 00:18:40.958
and you grow up a little bit earlier and you work a little bit harder,

00:18:40.958 --> 00:18:42.958
you could produce about five times more wealth, on average,

00:18:42.958 --> 00:18:43.958
than your neighbor.

00:18:44.958 --> 00:18:47.958
In a knowledge society, that number is now 427 to 1.

00:18:48.958 --> 00:18:52.958
It really matters if you're literate, not just in reading and writing

00:18:52.958 --> 00:18:54.958
in English and French and German,

00:18:54.958 --> 00:18:56.958
but in Microsoft and Linux and Apple.

00:18:57.958 --> 00:19:01.958
And very soon it's going to matter if you're literate in life code.

00:19:01.958 --> 00:19:03.958
So, if there is something you should fear,

00:19:03.958 --> 00:19:06.958
it's that you're not keeping your eye on the ball.

00:19:06.958 --> 00:19:08.958
Because it really matters who speaks life.

00:19:09.958 --> 00:19:11.958
That's why nations rise and fall.

00:19:12.958 --> 00:19:15.958
And it turns out that if you went back to the 1870s,

00:19:15.958 --> 00:19:18.958
the most productive nation on earth was Australia, per person.

00:19:18.958 --> 00:19:21.958
And New Zealand was way up there. And then the U.S. came in about 1950,

00:19:21.958 --> 00:19:24.958
and then Switzerland about 1973, and then the U.S. got back on top --

00:19:25.958 --> 00:19:27.958
beat up their chocolates and cuckoo clocks.

00:19:29.958 --> 00:19:32.958
And today, of course, you all know that the most productive nation

00:19:32.958 --> 00:19:35.958
on earth is Luxembourg, producing about one third more wealth

00:19:35.958 --> 00:19:37.958
per person per year than America.

00:19:38.958 --> 00:19:42.958
Tiny landlocked state. No oil. No diamonds. No natural resources.

00:19:42.958 --> 00:19:47.958
Just smart people moving bits. Different rules.

00:19:48.958 --> 00:19:51.958
Here's differential productivity rates.

00:19:52.958 --> 00:19:55.958
Here's how many people it takes to produce a single U.S. patent.

So, about 3,000 Americans, 6,000 Koreans, 14,000 Brits,

You can take a Harvard-educated Ivy League economist,

stick him in charge of Argentina. He still crashes the country

because he doesn't understand how the rules have changed.

Oh, yeah, and it takes about 5.6 million Indians.

because they didn't get this change,

because they kept treating their people like serfs

instead of like shareholders of a common project.

title: Happiness by design
transcript: About 15 years ago, I went to visit a friend in Hong Kong. And at the time I was very superstitious. So, upon landing — this was still at the old Hong Kong airport that's Kai Tak, when it was smack in the middle of the city — I thought, "If I see something good, I'm going to have a great time here in my two weeks. And if I see something negative, I'm going to be miserable, indeed."So the plane landed in between the buildings and got to a full stop in front of this little billboard. (Laughter) And I actually went to see some of the design companies in Hong Kong in my stay there. And it turned out that — I just went to see, you know, what they are doing in Hong Kong.But I actually walked away with a great job offer. And I flew back to Austria, packed my bags, and, another week later, I was again on my way to Hong Kong still superstitions and thinking, "Well, if that 'Winner' billboard is still up, I'm going to have a good time working here. (Laughter) But if it's gone, it's going to be really miserable and stressful." So it turned out that not only was the billboard still up but they had put this one right next to it. (Laughter) On the other hand, it also taught me where superstition gets me because I really had a terrible time in Hong Kong. (Laughter)However, I did have a number of real moments of happiness in my life — of, you know, I think what the conference brochure refers to as "moments that take your breath away." And since I'm a big list maker, I actually listed them all. (Laughter) Now, you don't have to go through the trouble of reading them and I won't read them for you. I know that it's incredibly boring to hear about other people's happinesses. (Laughter)What I did do, though is, I actually looked at them from a design standpoint and just eliminated all the ones that had nothing to do with design. And, very surprisingly, over half of them had, actually, something to do with design.So there are, of course, two different possibilities. There's one from a consumer's point of view — where I was happy while experiencing design. And I'll just give you one example. I had gotten my first Walkman. This is 1983. My brother had this great Yamaha motorcycle that he was willing to borrow to me freely. And The Police's "Synchronicity" cassette had just been released and there was no helmet law in my hometown of Bregenz. So you could drive up into the mountains freely blasting The Police on the new Sony Walkman. (Laughter) And I remember it as a true moment of happiness. You know, of course, they are related to this combination of at least two of them being, you know, design objects. And, you know, there's a scale of happiness when you talk about in design but the motorcycle incident would definitely be, you know, situated somewhere here — right in there between Delight and Bliss.Now, there is the other part, from a designer's standpoint — if you're happy while actually doing it. And one way to see how happy designers are when they're designing could be to look at the authors' photos on the back of their monographs? (Laughter) So, according to this, the Australians and the Japanese as well as the Mexicans are very happy. (Laughter) While, somewhat, the Spaniards ... and, I think, particularly, the Swiss (Laughter), don't seem to be doing all that well. (Laughter)Last November, a museum opened in Tokyo called The Mori Museum, in a skyscraper, up on the 56th floor. And their inaugural exhibit was called "Happiness." And I went, very eagerly, to see it, because — well, also, with an eye on this conference. And they interestingly sectioned the exhibit off into four different areas. Under "Arcadia," they showed things like this, from the Edo period — a hundred ways to write "happiness" in different forms. Or they had this apple by Yoko Ono — that, of course, later on was, you know, made into the label for The Beatles.Under "Nirvana" they showed this Constable painting. And there was a little — an interesting theory about abstraction. This is a blue field — it's actually an Yves Klein painting. And the theory was that if you abstract an image, you really, you know open as much room for the un-representable — and, therefore, you know, are able to involve the viewer more.Then, under "Desire," they showed these Shunsho paintings — also from the Edo period — ink on silk. And, lastly, under "Harmony," they had this 13th-century mandala from Tibet.Now, what I took away from the exhibit was that maybe with the exception of the mandala most of the pieces in there were actually about the visualization of happiness and not about happiness. And I felt a little bit cheated, because the visualization — that's a really easy thing to do. And, you know, my studio — we've done it all the time. This is, you know, a book. A happy dog — and you take it out, it's an aggressive dog. It's a happy David Byrne and an angry David Byrne. Or a jazz poster with a happy face and a more aggressive face. You know, that's not a big deal to accomplish.It has gotten to the point where, you know, within advertising or within the movie industry, "happy" has gotten such a bad reputation that if you actually want to do something with the subject and still appear authentic, you almost would have to, you know, do it from a cynical point of view. This is, you know, the movie poster. Or we, a couple of weeks ago, designed a box set for The Talking Heads where the happiness visualized on the cover definitely has, very much, a dark side to it.Much, much more difficult is this, where the designs actually can evoke happiness — and I'm going to just show you three that actually did this for me. This is a campaign done by a young artist in New York, who calls himself "True." Everybody who has ridden the New York subway system will be familiar with these signs? True printed his own version of these signs. Met every Wednesday at a subway stop with 20 of his friends. They divided up the different subway lines and added their own version. (Laughter) So this is one. (Laughter)Now, the way this works in the system is that nobody ever looks at these signs. So you're (Laughter) you're really bored in the subway, and you kind of stare at something. And it takes you a while until it actually — you realize that this says something different than what it normally says. (Laughter) I mean, that's, at least, how it made me happy. (Laughter)Now, True is a real humanitarian. He didn't want any of his friends to be arrested, so he supplied everybody with this fake volunteer card. (Laughter) And also gave this fake letter from the MTA to everybody — sort of like pretending that it's an art project financed by The Metropolitan Transit Authority. (Laughter)Another New York project. This is at P.S. 1 — a sculpture that's basically a square room by James Turrell, that has a retractable ceiling. Opens up at dusk and dawn every day. You don't see the horizon. You're just in there, watching the incredible, subtle changes of color in the sky. And the room is truly something to be seen. People's demeanor changes when they go in there. And, for sure, I haven't looked at the sky in the same way after spending an hour in there.There are, of course, more than those three projects that I'm showing here. I would definitely say that observing Vik Muniz' "Cloud" a couple of years ago in Manhattan for sure made me happy, as well. But my last project is, again, from a young designer in New York. He's from Korea originally. And he took it upon himself to print 55,000 speech bubbles — empty speech bubbles stickers, large ones and small ones. And he goes around New York and just puts them, empty as they are, on posters. (Laughter) And other people go and fill them in. (Laughter)This one says, "Please let me die in peace." (Laughter) I think that was — the most surprising to myself was that the writing was actually so good. This is on a musician poster, that says: "I am concerned that my CD will not sell more than 200,000 units and that, as a result, my recoupable advance from my label will be taken from me, after which, my contract will be cancelled, and I'll be back doing Journey covers on Bleecker Street." (Laughter)I think the reason this works so well is because everybody involved wins. Jee gets to have his project; the public gets a sweeter environment; and different public gets a place to express itself; and the advertisers finally get somebody to look at their ads. (Laughter)Well, there was a question, of course, that was on my mind for a while: You know, can I do more of the things that I like doing in design and less of the ones that I don't like to be doing? Which brought me back to my list making — you know, just to see what I actually like about my job.You know, one is: just working without pressure. Then: working concentrated, without being frazzled. Or, as Nancy said before, like really immerse oneself into it. Try not to get stuck doing the same thing — or try not get stuck behind the computer all day. This is, you know, related to it: getting out of the studio. Then, of course, trying to, you know, work on things where the content is actually important for me. And being able to enjoy the end results.And then I found another list in one of my diaries that actually contained all the things that I thought I learned in my life so far. And, just about at that time, an Austrian magazine called and asked if we would want to do six spreads — design six spreads that work like dividing pages between the different chapters in the magazine? And the whole thing just fell together. So I just picked one of the things that I thought I learned — in this case, "Everything I do always comes back to me" — and we made these spreads right out of this. So it was: "Everything I do always comes back to me."A couple of weeks ago, a (Laughter) French company asked us to design five billboards for them. Again, we could supply the content for it. So I just picked another one. And this was two weeks ago. We flew to Arizona — the designer who works with me, and myself — and photographed this one. So it's: "Trying to look good limits my life."And then we did one more of these. This is, again, for a magazine, dividing pages. This is: "Having" — this is the same thing; it's just, you know, photographed from the side. This is from the front. Then it's: "guts." Again, it's the same thing — "guts" is just the same room, reworked. Then it's: "always works out." Then it's "for," with the light on. (Laughter) And it's "me."Thank you so much. (Applause)

People's demeanor changes when they go in there.

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:13.958
And, for sure, I haven't looked at the sky in the same way

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:16.958
after spending an hour in there.

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:21.958
There are, of course, more than those three projects that I'm showing here.

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:25.958
I would definitely say that observing Vik Muniz' "Cloud"

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:29.958
a couple of years ago in Manhattan for sure made me happy, as well.

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:34.958
But my last project is, again, from a young designer in New York.

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:35.958
He's from Korea originally.

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:43.958
And he took it upon himself to print 55,000 speech bubbles --

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:46.958
empty speech bubbles stickers, large ones and small ones.

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:51.958
And he goes around New York and just puts them, empty as they are, on posters.

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:53.958
(Laughter)

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:56.958
And other people go and fill them in.

00:10:56.958 --> 00:10:59.958
(Laughter)

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:02.958
This one says, "Please let me die in peace."

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:09.958
(Laughter)

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:11.958
I think that was --

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:16.958
the most surprising to myself was that the writing was actually so good.

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:19.958
This is on a musician poster, that says:

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:23.958
"I am concerned that my CD will not sell more than 200,000 units

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:27.958
and that, as a result, my recoupable advance

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:29.958
from my label will be taken from me,

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:31.958
after which, my contract will be cancelled,

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:34.958
and I'll be back doing Journey covers on Bleecker Street."

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:53.958
(Laughter)

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:58.958
I think the reason this works so well is because everybody involved wins.

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:00.958
Jee gets to have his project;

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:04.958
the public gets a sweeter environment;

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:08.958
and different public gets a place to express itself;

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:12.958
and the advertisers finally get somebody to look at their ads.

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:19.958
(Laughter)

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:25.958
Well, there was a question, of course, that was on my mind for a while:

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:30.958
You know, can I do more of the things that I like doing in design

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:34.958
and less of the ones that I don't like to be doing?

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:38.958
Which brought me back to my list making --

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:41.958
you know, just to see what I actually like about my job.

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:45.958
You know, one is: just working without pressure.

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:49.958
Then: working concentrated, without being frazzled.

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:55.958
Or, as Nancy said before, like really immerse oneself into it.

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:58.958
Try not to get stuck doing the same thing --

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:02.958
or try not get stuck behind the computer all day.

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:06.958
This is, you know, related to it: getting out of the studio.

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:09.958
Then, of course, trying to, you know, work on things

where the content is actually important for me.

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:18.958

I do

comes
