00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:42.958
And I've nothing wrong with cake decoration and cake decorators,

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:44.958
if anybody's involved in cake decorations --

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:46.958
it's not what I'm interested in doing. (Laughter)

00:03:46.958 --> 00:03:51.958
And so, in the formation of things, in giving it form,

00:03:51.958 --> 00:03:54.958
in concretizing these things,

00:03:54.958 --> 00:03:57.958
it starts with some notion of how one organizes.

00:03:57.958 --> 00:04:02.958
And I've had for 30 years an interest in a series of complexities

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:05.958
where a series of forces are brought to bear,

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:09.958
and to understand the nature of the final result of that,

00:04:09.958 --> 00:04:11.958
representing the building itself.

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:16.958
There's been a continual relationship between inventions,

00:04:16.958 --> 00:04:20.958
which are private, and reality, which has been important to me.

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:25.958
A project which is part of an exhibition in Copenhagen 10 years ago,

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:27.958
which was the modeling of a hippocampus --

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:30.958
the territory of the brain that records short-term memory --

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:34.958
and the documentation of that, the imaginative and documentation of that

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:39.958
through a series of drawings which literally attempt to organize that experience.

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:43.958
And it had to do with the notion of walking a kilometer,

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:46.958
observing every kilometer a particular object of desire,

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:48.958
and then placing that within this.

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:51.958
And the notion was that I could make an organization

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:57.958
not built on normal coherencies, but built on non-sequiturs, built on randomness.

00:04:57.958 --> 00:05:00.958
And I'd been extremely interested in this notion of randomness

00:05:00.958 --> 00:05:02.958
as it produces architectural work

00:05:02.958 --> 00:05:04.958
and as it definitely connects to the notion of the city,

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:06.958
an accretional notion of the city,

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:09.958
and that led to various ideas of organization.

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:12.958
And then this led to broader ideas of buildings

00:05:12.958 --> 00:05:16.958
that come together through the multiplicity of systems.

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:19.958
And it's not any single system that makes the work.

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:22.958
It's the relationship -- it's the dynamics between the systems --

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:25.958
which have the power to transform and invent

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:29.958
and produce an architecture that is -- that would otherwise not exist.

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:33.958
And those systems could be identified,

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:34.958
and they could be grouped together.

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:37.958
And of course, today, with the technology of the computer

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:41.958
and with the rapid prototyping, etc., we have the mechanisms

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:44.958
to understand and to respond to these systems,

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:49.958
and to allow them to adjust to the various accommodations of functionalities

00:05:49.958 --> 00:05:51.958
because that's all we do.

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:54.958
We're producing spaces that accommodate human activity.

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:57.958
And what I'm interested in is not the styling of that,

00:05:57.958 --> 00:06:02.958
but the relationship of that as it enhances that activity.

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:06.958
And that directly connects to ideas of city-making.

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:08.958
This is a project that we just finished in Penang

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:12.958
for a very, very large city project that came directly out of this process,

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:16.958
which is the result of the multiplicity of forces that produce it.

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:20.958
And the project -- again, enormous, enormous competition --

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:22.958
on the Hudson River and in New York

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:25.958
that we were asked to do three years ago, which uses these processes.

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:28.958
And what you're looking at are possibilities that have to do

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:34.958
with the generation of the city as one applies a methodology

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:37.958
that uses notions of these multiple forces,

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:42.958
that deals with the enormity of the problem, the complexity of the problem,

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:45.958
when we're designing cities at larger and larger aggregates.

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:47.958
Because one of the issues today is

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:52.958
that the economic aggregate is driving the development aggregate,

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:54.958
and as the aggregates get larger we require

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:59.958
more and more complex investigation processes to solve these problems.

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:02.958
And that led us directly to the Olympic Village.

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:05.958
I was in New York on Monday presenting it to the IOC.

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:09.958
We won the competition -- what was it, nine months ago?

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:12.958
Again, a direct reflection from using these processes

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:17.958
to develop extremely complicated, very large-scale organisms.

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:20.958
And then, also, was working with broad strategies.

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:25.958
In this case, we only used 15 of the 60 acres of land,

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:29.958
and the 45 acres was a park and would become the legacy of the Olympic Village.

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:33.958
And it would become the second largest park in the boroughs, etc.

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:37.958
Its position, of course, in the middle of Manhattan -- it's on Hunter's Point.

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:41.958
And then the broader ideas of city-making

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:44.958
start having direct influences on architecture,

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:47.958
on the elements that make up the broader scheme,

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:50.958
the buildings themselves, and start guiding us.

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:56.958
Architecture for me has been an investigation of a multiplicity of forces

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:58.958
that could come from literally any place.

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:02.958
And so I can start this discussion in any number of places,

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:05.958
and I've chosen three or four to talk about.

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:10.958
And it has also to do with an interest in

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:14.958
the vast kind of territory that architecture touches.

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:19.958
It literally is connected to anything in terms of knowledge base.

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:22.958
There's just no place that it doesn't somehow

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:24.958
have a connective tissue to.

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:27.958
This is Jim Dine, and it's the absence of presence, etc.

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:31.958
It's the clothing, the skin, without the presence of the character.

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:35.958
It became kind of an idea for the notion of the surface of a work,

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:40.958
and it was used in a project where we could unravel that surface,

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:44.958
and it was a figurative idea that was going to be folded

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:47.958
and made into a very, kind of complex space.

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:50.958
And the idea was the relationship of the space,

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:53.958
which was made up of the fold of the image,

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:58.958
and the dialectic or the conflict between the figuration,

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:00.958
and the clarity of the image

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:03.958
and the complexity of the space, which were in dialog.

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:06.958
And it made us rethink the whole notion of how we work

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:08.958
and how we make things,

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:14.958
and it led us to ideas that were closer to fashion design as we flattened out surfaces,

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:17.958
and then brought them back together as they could make spatial combinations.

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:20.958
And this was the first prototype in Korea,

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:23.958
as we're dealing with a dynamic envelope,

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:26.958
and then the same characteristic of the fabric.

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:31.958
It has a material identity and it's translucent and it's porous,

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:35.958
and it allows us for a very different notion of what a skin of a building is.

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:37.958
And that turned right away into another project.

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:40.958
This is the Caltrans building in Los Angeles.

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:44.958
And now we're seeing as the skin and the body is differentiated.

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:46.958
Again, it's a very, very simple notion.

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:48.958
If you look at most buildings,

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:50.958
what you look at is the building, the facade, and it is the building.

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:52.958
And all of a sudden we're kind of moving away,

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:54.958
and we're separating the skin from the body,

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:56.958
and that's going to lead to broader performance criteria,

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:58.958
which I'm going to talk about in a minute.

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:00.958
And you're looking at how it drapes over

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:02.958
and differentiates from the body.

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:05.958
And then, again, the building itself,

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:08.958
middle of Los Angeles, right across from City Hall.

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:11.958
And as it moves, it takes pieces of the earth with it. It bends up.

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:13.958
It's part of a sign system,

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:15.958
which was part of the kind of legacy of Los Angeles --

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:18.958
the two-dimension, three-dimension signing, etc.

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:23.958
And then it allows one to penetrate the work itself.

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:27.958
It's transparent, and it allows you to understand, I think,

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:29.958
what is always the most interesting thing in any building,

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:32.958
which is the actual constructional processes that make it.

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:37.958
And it's probably the most intense kind of territory

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:39.958
of the work, which is not occupied,

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:42.958
because architecture is always the most interesting in some mechanism

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:44.958
when it's separated from function,

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:46.958
and this is an area that allows for that.

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:49.958
And then the skin starts transforming into other materials.

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:51.958
We're using light as a building material in this case.

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:53.958
We're working with Keith Sonnier in New York,

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:55.958
and we're making this large outside room,

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:59.958
which is possible in Los Angeles, and which is very much reflective

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:02.958
of the urban, the contemporary urban environments

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:05.958
that you would find in Shibuya or you'd find in Mexico City

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:07.958
or Sao Paulo, etc.,

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:11.958
that have to do with activating the city over a longer span of time.

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:13.958
And that was very much part of the notion

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:16.958
of the urban objective of this project in Los Angeles.

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:21.958
And, again, all of it promoting transparency.

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:28.958
And an image which may be closest talks about the use of light as a medium,

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:31.958
that light becomes literally a building material.

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:35.958
Well, that immediately turned into something much broader, and as a scope.

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:39.958
And again, we're looking at an early sketch

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:41.958
where I'm understanding now

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:44.958
that the skin can be a transition between the ground and the tower.

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:47.958
This is a building in San Francisco which is under construction.

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:51.958
And now it turned into something much, much broader as a problem,

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:53.958
and it has to do with performance.

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:56.958
This will be the first building in the United States that took --

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:58.958
well, I can't say it took the air conditioning out. It's a hybrid.

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:00.958
I wanted a pure thing, and I can't get it.

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:03.958
It's a wrong attitude, actually, because the hybrid is probably more interesting.

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:05.958
But we took the air conditioning out of the tower.

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:07.958
There's some air conditioning left in the base,

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:09.958
but the skin now moves on hydraulics.

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:13.958
It forces air through a Venturi force if there's no wind.

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:16.958
It adjusts continually. And we removed the air conditioning.

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:20.958
Huge, huge thing. Half a million dollars a year delta.

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:22.958
10 of these -- it's just under a million square feet --

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:24.958
800 and some thousand square feet --

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:27.958
10 of these would power Sausalito -- the delta on this.

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:30.958
And so now what we're looking at, as the projects get larger in scale,

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:35.958
as they interface with broader problems,

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:38.958
that they expand the capabilities

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:40.958
in terms of their performance.

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:43.958
Well, I could also start here.

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:45.958
We could talk about the relationship

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:49.958
at a more biological sense of the relationship of building and ground.

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:52.958
Well, our research -- my generation for sure,

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:54.958
people who were going to school in the late '60s --

00:12:54.958 --> 00:13:00.958
made very much a shift out of the internal focus of architecture,

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:02.958
looking at architecture within its own territory,

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:04.958
and we were much more affected by film,

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:06.958
by what was going on in the art world, etc.

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:08.958
This is, of course, Michael Heizer.

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:12.958
And when I saw this, first an image and then visited,

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:16.958
it completely changed the way I thought after that point.

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:18.958
And I understood that building really could be

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:20.958
the augmentation of the Earth's surface,

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:25.958
and it completely shifted the notion of building ground in the most basic sense.

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:28.958
And then -- well, he was probably looking at this -- this is Nazca;

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:35.958
this is 700 years ago -- the most amazing four-kilometer land sculptures.

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:37.958
They're just totally incredible.

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:41.958
And that led us to then completely rethinking how we draw, how we work.

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:44.958
This is the first sketch of a high school in Pomona --

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:48.958
well, whatever it is, a model, a conceptual, kind of idea.

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:52.958
And it's the reshaping of the Earth to make it occupiable.

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:57.958
So it puts 200,000 square feet of stuff that make a high school work

00:13:57.958 --> 00:13:59.958
in the surface of that Earth.

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:02.958
There it is modeled as it was developing into a piece of work.

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:06.958
And there it is, again, as it's starting to get resolved tectonically,

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:08.958
and then there's the school.

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:10.958
And, of course,

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:12.958
we're interested in participating with education.

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:14.958
I have absolutely no interest in producing a building

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:16.958
that just accommodates X, Y and Z function.

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:18.958
What I'm interested in are how these ideas

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:21.958
participate in the educational process of young people.

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:23.958
It demands some sort of notion of inquiry

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:25.958
because it's a system that's developed not sculpturally.

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:28.958
It's an idea that started from my first discussion.

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:31.958
It has to do with a broad, consistent logic,

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:35.958
and that logic could be understood as one occupies the building.

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:37.958
And there's an overt -- at least,

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:40.958
there's an attempt to make a very overt notion of a building

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:42.958
that connects to the land in a very different way

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:45.958
because I was interested in a very didactic approach to the problem,

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:47.958
as one would understand that.

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:49.958
And the second project that was just finished in Los Angeles

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:53.958
that uses some of the same ideas. It uses landscape as a major idea.

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:56.958
Then, again, we're doing the headquarters for NOAA --

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:59.958
National Oceanographic and Atmospheric Agency --

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:01.958
outside of Washington in Maryland.

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:03.958
And this is how they see the world.

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:07.958
They have 22 satellites zipping around at plus or minus 100 miles,

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:09.958
and the site's in red.

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:12.958
And what we really want to do -- well, the architects,

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:15.958
if there are architects out there, this is the Laugier Hut;

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:17.958
this is the primitive hut that's been around for so long --

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:19.958
and what we wanted to do is really build this,

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:23.958
because they see themselves as the caretakers of the world,

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:25.958
and we wanted them to look down at their satellite,

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:27.958
how they see their own site, that eight-acre site,

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:30.958
and we wanted nothing left. We wanted it to stay green.

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:32.958
There's actually three baseball fields on it right now,

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:33.958
and they're going to stay there.

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:35.958
We put one piece directly north-south,

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:38.958
and it holds the dishes at the ears, right?

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:41.958
And then right below that the processing, and the mission lift,

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:45.958
and the mission control room, and all the other spaces are underground.

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:47.958
And what you look at is an aircraft carrier

00:15:47.958 --> 00:15:51.958
that's performance-driven by the cone vision of these satellite dishes.

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:55.958
And that the building itself is occupied in the lower portion,

00:15:55.958 --> 00:15:57.958
broken up by a series of courts,

00:15:57.958 --> 00:16:00.958
and it's five acres of uninterrupted, horizontal space

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:03.958
for their administrative offices.

00:16:03.958 --> 00:16:06.958
And then that, in turn, propelled us to look at

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:10.958
larger-scale projects where this notion of landscape building interface

00:16:10.958 --> 00:16:12.958
becomes a connective tissue.

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:18.958
The new capital competition for Berlin, four years ago.

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:20.958
And again we just finished the ECB --

00:16:20.958 --> 00:16:23.958
actually Coop Himmelblau in Vienna just won this project,

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:29.958
where the building was separated into a series of landscape elements

00:16:29.958 --> 00:16:32.958
that became part of a connective tissue of a park,

00:16:32.958 --> 00:16:38.958
which is parallel to the river, and develops ideas of the buildings themselves

00:16:38.958 --> 00:16:41.958
and becomes part of the connective fabric --

00:16:41.958 --> 00:16:46.958
the social, cultural and the landscape, recreational fabric of the city.

00:16:46.958 --> 00:16:48.958
And the building is no longer seen as an autonomous thing,

00:16:48.958 --> 00:16:50.958
but something that's only inextricably connected

00:16:50.958 --> 00:16:52.958
to this city and this place at this time.

00:16:52.958 --> 00:16:56.958
And a project that was realized in Austria, the Hooper Bank,

00:16:56.958 --> 00:16:59.958
which again used this idea of connecting typology,

00:16:59.958 --> 00:17:02.958
the traditional buildings, and morphology,

00:17:02.958 --> 00:17:05.958
or the relationship of the development of land as an idea,

00:17:05.958 --> 00:17:09.958
into a complex, which is a piece of a city where we can see part of it

00:17:09.958 --> 00:17:11.958
is literally just this augmenting,

00:17:11.958 --> 00:17:14.958
this movement of the land that's a very simple idea of

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:15.958
just lifting it up and occupying it,

00:17:15.958 --> 00:17:18.958
and other parts are much more energetic and intense.

00:17:18.958 --> 00:17:20.958
And talk about that intensity

00:17:20.958 --> 00:17:24.958
in terms of the collisions of the kind of events they make

00:17:24.958 --> 00:17:26.958
that have to do with putting a series of systems together,

00:17:26.958 --> 00:17:30.958
and then where part of it is in the ground, part of it is oppositional lifts.

00:17:30.958 --> 00:17:33.958
One enters the building as it lifts off the ground,

00:17:33.958 --> 00:17:35.958
and it becomes part of the idea.

00:17:35.958 --> 00:17:38.958
And then the skin -- the edges of this --

00:17:38.958 --> 00:17:41.958
all promote the dynamic, the movement of the building

00:17:41.958 --> 00:17:46.958
as a series of seismic shifts, geologic shifts. Right?

00:17:46.958 --> 00:17:50.958
And it makes for event space and then it breaks in places

00:17:50.958 --> 00:17:53.958
that allow you to peer into the interior, and those interiors, again,

00:17:53.958 --> 00:17:55.958
are promoting transparency for the workplace,

00:17:55.958 --> 00:17:58.958
which has been a continual interest of ours.

00:18:00.958 --> 00:18:03.958
And then, again, in a more, kind of traditional setting,

00:18:03.958 --> 00:18:05.958
this is a graduate student housing in Toronto,

00:18:05.958 --> 00:18:09.958
and it's very much about the relationship of a building

00:18:09.958 --> 00:18:11.958
as it makes a connective tissue to the city.

00:18:11.958 --> 00:18:14.958
The main idea was the gateway, where it breaks the site,

00:18:14.958 --> 00:18:18.958
and the building occupies both the public space and the private space.

00:18:18.958 --> 00:18:22.958
And it's that territory of -- it's this thing.

00:18:22.958 --> 00:18:25.958
I visited the site many times, and everybody, kind of --

00:18:25.958 --> 00:18:29.958
you can see this from two kilometers away; it's an exact center of the street,

00:18:29.958 --> 00:18:31.958
and the whole notion is to engage the public,

00:18:31.958 --> 00:18:36.958
to engage buildings as part of the public tissue of the city.

00:18:37.958 --> 00:18:41.958
And finally, one of the most interesting projects -- it's a courthouse.

00:18:41.958 --> 00:18:44.958
And what I want to talk about -- this is the Supreme Court, of course --

00:18:44.958 --> 00:18:48.958
and, well, I'm dealing with Michael Hogan, the Chief Justice of Oregon.

00:18:48.958 --> 00:18:52.958
You could not proceed without making this negotiation

00:18:52.958 --> 00:18:56.958
between one's own values and the relationship

00:18:56.958 --> 00:19:00.958
of the character you're working with and how he understands the court,

00:19:00.958 --> 00:19:03.958
because I'm showing him, of course, Corbusier at Savoy,

00:19:03.958 --> 00:19:06.958
which is 1928, which is the beginning of modern architecture.

00:19:06.958 --> 00:19:09.958
Well, then we get to this image.

00:19:09.958 --> 00:19:13.958
And this is where the project started. Because I'm going,

00:19:13.958 --> 00:19:18.958
I'm interested in the phenomenon that's taking place in here.

00:19:18.958 --> 00:19:22.958
And really what we're talking about is constructing reality.

00:19:22.958 --> 00:19:24.958
And I'm a character that's extremely interested

00:19:24.958 --> 00:19:27.958
in understanding the nature of that constructed reality

00:19:27.958 --> 00:19:31.958
because there's no such thing as nature any more. Nature is gone.

00:19:31.958 --> 00:19:33.958
Nature in the 19th-century sense, alright?

00:19:33.958 --> 00:19:36.958
Nature is only a cultural edifice today, right?

00:19:36.958 --> 00:19:39.958
We construct it and we construct those ideas.

00:19:39.958 --> 00:19:42.958
And then of course, this one, our governor at the moment.

00:19:42.958 --> 00:19:47.958
And we spent some time with Conan, believe it or not,

00:19:47.958 --> 00:19:51.958
and then that led us to, kind of, the very differences of our worlds

00:19:51.958 --> 00:19:53.958
from a legal and an artistic, architectural.

00:19:53.958 --> 00:19:57.958
And it forced us to talk about notions of how we work,

00:19:57.958 --> 00:20:00.958
and the dynamics of that, and what other sources of the work is.

00:20:00.958 --> 00:20:03.958
And it led us to the project, the courthouse,

00:20:03.958 --> 00:20:06.958
which is absolutely a part of a negotiation

00:20:06.958 --> 00:20:09.958
between tradition and pieces of the traditional courthouse.

00:20:09.958 --> 00:20:11.958
You'll find a stair that's the same length as the Supreme Court.

00:20:11.958 --> 00:20:14.958
Here's a piano nobile, which is a device used in the Renaissance.

00:20:14.958 --> 00:20:18.958
The courts were made of that. The skin is this series of layers

00:20:18.958 --> 00:20:21.958
that reflect even rusticated stonework,

00:20:21.958 --> 00:20:25.958
but which were embedded with fragments of the Constitution,

00:20:25.958 --> 00:20:27.958
which were part of the little process,

00:20:27.958 --> 00:20:29.958
all set on a plinth that defined it from the community.

00:20:29.958 --> 00:20:31.958
Thank you so much.

00:20:31.958 --> 00:20:34.958
(Applause)

title: Great cars are great art
transcript: What I want to talk about is, as background, is the idea that cars are art. This is actually quite meaningful to me, because car designers tend to be a little bit low on the totem pole — we don't do coffee table books with just one lamp inside of it — and cars are thought so much as a product that it's a little bit difficult to get into the aesthetic side under the same sort of terminology that one would discuss art. And so cars, as art, brings it into an emotional plane — if you accept that — that you have to deal with on the same level you would with art with a capital A.Now at this point you're going to see a picture of Michelangelo. This is completely different than automobiles. Automobiles are self-moving things, right? Elevators are automobiles. And they're not very emotional; they solve a purpose; and certainly automobiles have been around for 100 years and have made our lives functionally a lot better in many ways; they've also been a real pain in the ass, because automobiles are really the thing we have to solve. We have to solve the pollution, we have to solve the congestion — but that's not what interests me in this speech.What interests me in this speech is cars. Automobiles may be what you use, but cars are what we are, in many ways. And as long as we can solve the problems of automobiles, and I believe we can, with fuel cells or hydrogen, like BMW is really hip on, and lots of other things, then I think we can look past that and try and understand why this hook is in many of us — of this car-y-ness — and what that means, what we can learn from it. That's what I want to get to. Cars are not a suit of clothes; cars are an avatar. Cars are an expansion of yourself: they take your thoughts, your ideas, your emotions, and they multiply it — your anger, whatever. It's an avatar. It's a super-waldo that you happen to be inside of, and if you feel sexy, the car is sexy. And if you're full of road rage, you've got a "Chevy: Like a Rock," right?Cars are a sculpture — did you know this? That every car you see out there is sculpted by hand. Many people think, "Well, it's computers, and it's done by machines and stuff like that." Well, they reproduce it, but the originals are all done by hand. It's done by men and women who believe a lot in their craft. And they put that same kind of tension into the sculpting of a car that you do in a great sculpture that you would go and look at in a museum. That tension between the need to express, the need to discover, then you put something new into it, and at the same time you have bounds of craftsmanship. Rules that say, this is how you handle surfaces; this is what control is all about; this is how you show you're a master of your craft. And that tension, that discovery, that push for something new — and at the same time, that sense of obligation to the regards of craftsmanship — that's as strong in cars as it is in anything. We work in clay, which hasn't changed much since Michelangelo started screwing around with it, and there's a very interesting analogy to that too. Real quickly — Michelangelo once said he's there to "discover the figure within," OK? There we go, the automobile. That was 100 years right there — did you catch that? Between that one there, and that one there, it changed a lot didn't it? OK, it's not marketing; there's a very interesting car concept here, but the marketing part is not what I want to talk about here. I want to talk about this. Why it means you have to wash a car, what is it, that sensuality you have to touch about it? That's the sculpture that goes into it. That sensuality. And it's done by men and women working just like this, making cars.Now this little quote about sculpture from Henry Moore, I believe that that "pressure within" that Moore's talking about — at least when it comes to cars — comes right back to this idea of the mean. It's that will to live, that need to survive, to express itself, that comes in a car, and takes over people like me. And we tell other people, "Do this, do this, do this," until this thing comes alive. We are completely infected. And beauty can be the result of this infectiousness; it's quite wonderful. This sculpture is, of course, at the heart of all of it, and it's really what puts the craftsmanship into our cars. And it's not a whole lot different, really, when they're working like this, or when somebody works like this. It's that same kind of commitment, that same kind of beauty.Now, now I get to the point. I want to talk about cars as art. Art, in the Platonic sense, is truth; it's beauty, and love. Now this is really where designers in car business diverge from the engineers. We don't really have a problem talking about love. We don't have a problem talking about truth or beauty in that sense. That's what we're searching for — when we're working our craft, we are really trying to find that truth out there. We're not trying to find vanity and beauty. We're trying to find the beauty in the truth. However, engineers tend to look at things a little bit more Newtonian, instead of this quantum approach. We're dealing with irrationalisms, and we're dealing with paradoxes that we admit exist, and the engineers tend to look things a little bit more like two and two is four, and if you get 4.0 it's better, and 4.000 is even better. And that sometimes leads to bit of a divergence in why we're doing what we're doing. We've pretty much accepted the fact, though, that we are the women in the organization at BMW — BMW is a very manly type business, — men, men, men; it's engineers. And we're kind of the female side to that. That's OK, that's cool. You go off and be manly. We're going to be a little bit more female. Because what we're interested in is finding form that's more than just a function.We're interested in finding beauty that's more than just an aesthetic; it's really a truth. And I think this idea of soul, as being at the heart of great cars, is very applicable. You all know it. You know a car when you've seen it, with soul. You know how strong this is. Well, this experience of love, and the experience of design, to me, are interchangeable. And now I'm coming to my story.I discovered something about love and design through a project called Deep Blue. And first of all, you have to go with me for a second, and say, you know, you could take the word "love" out of a lot of things in our society, put the word "design" in, and it still works, like this quote here, you know. It kind of works, you know? You can understand that. It works in truisms. "All is fair in design and war." Certainly we live in a competitive society. I think this one here, there's a pop song that really describes Philippe Starck for me, you know, this is like you know, this is like puppy love, you know, this is cool right? Toothbrush, cool. It really only gets serious when you look at something like this. OK?(Laughter)This is one substitution that I believe all of us, in design management, are guilty of. And this idea that there is more to love, more to design, when it gets down to your neighbor, your other, it can be physical like this, and maybe in the future it will be. But right now it's in dealing with our own people, our own teams who are doing the creating. So, to my story. The idea of people-work is what we work with here, and I have to make a bond with my designers when we're creating BMWs. We have to have a shared intimacy, a shared vision — that means we have to work as one family; we have to understand ourselves that way. There's good times; there's interesting times; and there's some stress times too. You want to do cars, you've got to go outside. You've got to do cars in the rain; you've got to do cars in the snow. That's, by the way, is a presentation we made to our board of directors. We haul their butts out in the snow, too. You want to know cars outside? Well, you've got to stand outside to do this. And because these are artists, they have very artistic temperaments. All right? Now one thing about art is, art is discovery, and art is discovering yourself through your art. Right? And one thing about cars is we're all a little bit like Pygmalion, we are completely in love with our own creations. This is one of my favorite paintings, it really describes our relationship with cars. This is sick beyond belief.(Laughter)But because of this, the intimacy with which we work together as a team takes on a new dimension, a new meaning. We have a shared center; we have a shared focus — that car stays at the middle of all our relationships. And it's my job, in the competitive process, to narrow this down. I heard today about Joseph's death genes that have to go in and kill cell reproduction. You know, that's what I have to do sometimes. We start out with 10 cars; we narrow it down to five cars, down to three cars, down to two cars, down to one car, and I'm in the middle of that killing, basically. Someone's love, someone's baby. This is very difficult, and you have to have a bond with your team that permits you to do this, because their life is wrapped up in that too. They've got that gene infected in them as well, and they want that to live, more than anything else.Well, this project, Deep Blue, put me in contact with my team in a way that I never expected, and I want to pass it on to you, because I want you to reflect on this, perhaps in your own relationships. We wanted to a do a car which was a complete leap of faith for BMW. We wanted to do a team which was so removed from the way we'd done it, that I only had a phone number that connected me to them. So, what we did was: instead of having a staff of artists that are just your wrist, we decided to free up a team of creative designers and engineers to find out what's the successor to the SUV phenomenon in America. This is 1996 we did this project. And so we sent them off with this team name, Deep Blue. Now many people know Deep Blue from IBM — we actually stole it from them because we figured if anybody read our faxes they'd think we're talking about computers. It turned out it was quite clever because Deep Blue, in a company like BMW, has a hook — "Deep Blue," wow, cool name. So people get wrapped up in it. And we took a team of designers, and we sent them off to America. And we gave them a budget, what we thought was a set of deliverables, a timetable, and nothing else. Like I said, I just had a phone number that connected me to them.And a group of engineers worked in Germany, and the idea was they would work separately on this problem of what's the successor to the SUV. They would come together, compare notes. Then they would work apart, come together, and they would produce together a monumental set of diverse opinions that didn't pollute each other's ideas — but at the same time came together and resolved the problems. Hopefully, really understand the customer at its heart, where the customer is, live with them in America. So — sent the team off, and actually something different happened. They went other places.(Laughter)They disappeared, quite honestly, and all I got was postcards. Now, I got some postcards of these guys in Las Vegas, and I got some postcards of these guys in the Grand Canyon, and I got these postcards of Niagara Falls, and pretty soon they're in New York, and I don't know where else. And I'm telling myself, "This is going to be a great car, they're doing research that I've never even thought about before." Right? And they decided that instead of, like, having a studio, and six or seven apartments, it was cheaper to rent Elizabeth Taylor's ex-house in Malibu. And — at least they told me it was her house, I guess it was at one time, she had a party there or something. But anyway, this was the house, and they all lived there. Now this is 24/7 living, half-a-dozen people who'd left their — some had left their wives behind and families behind, and they literally lived in this house for the entire six months the project was in America, but the first three months were the most intensive. And one of the young women in the project, she was a fantastic lady, she actually built her room in the bathroom. The bathroom was so big, she built the bed over the bathtub — it's quite fascinating.On the other hand, I didn't know anything about this. OK? Nothing. This is all going on, and all I'm getting is postcards of these guys in Las Vegas, or whatever, saying, "Don't worry Chris, this is really going to be good." OK? So my concept of what a design studio was probably — I wasn't up to speed on where these guys were.However, the engineers back in Munich had taken on this kind of Newtonian solution, and they were trying to find how many cup holders can dance on the head of a pin, and, you know, these really serious questions that are confronting the modern consumer. And one was hoping that these two teams would get together, and this collusion of incredible creativity, under these incredible surroundings, and these incredibly stressed-out engineers, would create some incredible solutions. Well, what I didn't know was, and what we found out was — these guys, they can't even like talk to each other under those conditions. You get a divergence of Newtonian and quantum thinking at that point, you have a split in your dialog that is so deep, and so far, that they cannot bring this together at all.And so we had our first meeting, after three months, in Tiburon, which is just up the road from here — you know Tiburon? And the idea was after the first three months of this independent research they would present it all to Dr. Goschel — who is now my boss, and at that time he was co-mentor on the project — and they would present their results. We would see where we were going, we would see the first indication of what could be the successive phenomenon to the SUV in America. And so I had these ideas in my head, that this is going to be great. I mean, I'm going to see so much work, it's so intense — I know probably Las Vegas meant a lot about it, and I'm not really sure where the Grand Canyon came in either — but somehow all this is going to come together, and I'm going to see some really great product. So we went to Tiburon, after three months, and the team had gotten together the week before, many days ahead of time. The engineers flew over, and designers got together with them, and they put their presentation together.Well, it turns out that the engineers hadn't done anything. And they hadn't done anything because — kind of, like in car business, engineers are there to solve problems, and we were asking them to create a problem. And the engineers were waiting for the designers to say, "This is the problem that we've created, now help us solve it." And they couldn't talk about it. So what happened was, the engineers showed up with nothing. And the engineers told the designers, "If you go in with all your stuff, we'll walk out, we'll walk right out of the project."So I didn't know any of this, and we got a presentation that had an agenda, looked like this. There was a whole lot of dialog. We spent four hours being told all about vocabulary that needs to be built between engineers and designers. And here I'm expecting at any moment, "OK, they're going to turn the page, and I'm going to see the cars, I'm going to see the sketches, I'm going to see maybe some idea of where it's going." Dialog kept on going, with mental maps of words, and pretty soon it was becoming obvious that instead of being dazzled with brilliance, I was seriously being baffled with bullshit. And if you can imagine what this is like, to have these months of postcard indication of how great this team is working, and they're out there spending all this money, and they're learning, and they're doing all this stuff. I went fucking ballistic, right? I went nuts. You can probably remember Tiburon, it used to look like this.After four hours of this, I stood up, and I took this team apart. I screamed at them, I yelled at them, "What the hell are you doing? You're letting me down, you're my designers, you're supposed to be the creative ones, what the hell is going on around here?" It was probably one of my better tirades, I have some good ones, but this was probably one of my better ones. And I went into these people; how could they take BMW's money, how could they have a holiday for three months and produce nothing, nothing? Because of course they didn't tell us that they had three station wagons full of drawings, model concepts, pictures — everything I wanted, they'd locked up in the cars, because they had shown solidarity with the engineers — and they'd decided not to show me anything, in order to give the chance for problem solving a chance to start, because they hadn't realized, of course, that they couldn't do problem creating. So we went to lunch —(Laughter)And I've got to tell you, this was one seriously quiet lunch. The engineers all sat at one end of the table, the designers and I sat at the other end of the table, really quiet. And I was just fucking furious, furious. OK? Probably because they had all the fun and I didn't, you know. That's what you get furious about right? And somebody asked me about Catherine, my wife, you know, did she fly out with me or something? I said, "No," and it triggered a set of thoughts about my wife. And I recalled that when Catherine and I were married, the priest gave a very nice sermon, and he said something very important. He said, "Love is not selfish," he said, "Love does not mean counting how many times I say, 'I love you.' It doesn't mean you had sex this many times this month, and it's two times less than last month, so that means you don't love me as much. Love is not selfish." And I thought about this, and I thought, "You know, I'm not showing love here. I'm seriously not showing love. I'm in the air, I'm in the air without trust. This cannot be. This cannot be that I'm expecting a certain number of sketches, and to me that's my quantification method for qualifying a team. This cannot be."So I told them this story. I said, "Guys, I'm thinking about something here, this isn't right. I can't have a relationship with you guys based on a premise that is a quantifiable one. Based on a dictate premise that says, 'I'm a boss, you do what I say, without trust.'" I said "This can't be." Actually, we all broke down into tears, to be quite honest about it, because they still could not tell me how much frustration they had built up inside of them, not being able to show me what I wanted, and merely having to ask me to trust them that it would come. And I think we felt much closer that day, we cut a lot of strings that didn't need to be there, and we forged the concept for what real team and creativity is all about. We put the car back at the center of our thoughts, and we put love, I think, truly back into the center of the process.By the way, that team went on to create six different concepts for the next model of what would be the proposal for the next generation after SUVs in America. One of those was the idea of a crossover coupes — you see it downstairs, the X Coupe — they had a lot of fun with that. It was the rendition of our motorcycle, the GS, as Carl Magnusson says, "brute-iful," as the idea of what could be a motorcycle, if you add two more wheels. And so, in conclusion, my lesson that I wanted to pass on to you, was this one here. I'm also going to steal a little quote out of "Little Prince." There's a lot to be said about trust and love, if you know that those two words are synonymous for design. I had a very, very meaningful relationship with my team that day, and it's stayed that way ever since. And I hope that you too find that there's more to design, and more towards the art of the design, than doing it yourself. It's true that the trust and the love, that makes it worthwhile.Thanks so much.(Applause)

We work in clay, which hasn't changed much

00:02:58.958 --> 00:03:01.958
since Michelangelo started screwing around with it,

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:04.958
and there's a very interesting analogy to that too.

00:03:04.958 --> 00:03:10.958
Real quickly -- Michelangelo once said he's there to "discover the figure within," OK?

00:03:10.958 --> 00:03:12.958
There we go, the automobile.

00:03:12.958 --> 00:03:14.958
That was 100 years right there -- did you catch that?

00:03:14.958 --> 00:03:17.958
Between that one there, and that one there, it changed a lot didn't it?

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:21.958
OK, it's not marketing; there's a very interesting car concept here,

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:23.958
but the marketing part is not what I want to talk about here.

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:25.958
I want to talk about this.

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:27.958
Why it means you have to wash a car, what is it, that sensuality

00:03:27.958 --> 00:03:32.958
you have to touch about it? That's the sculpture that goes into it. That sensuality.

00:03:32.958 --> 00:03:37.958
And it's done by men and women working just like this, making cars.

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:39.958
Now this little quote about sculpture from Henry Moore,

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:42.958
I believe that that "pressure within" that Moore's talking about --

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:44.958
at least when it comes to cars --

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:47.958
comes right back to this idea of the mean.

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:50.958
It's that will to live, that need to survive, to express itself,

00:03:50.958 --> 00:03:52.958
that comes in a car, and takes over people like me.

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:56.958
And we tell other people, "Do this, do this, do this," until this thing comes alive.

00:03:56.958 --> 00:04:00.958
We are completely infected. And beauty can be the result

00:04:00.958 --> 00:04:02.958
of this infectiousness; it's quite wonderful.

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:05.958
This sculpture is, of course, at the heart of all of it,

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:08.958
and it's really what puts the craftsmanship into our cars.

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:12.958
And it's not a whole lot different, really, when they're working like this,

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:14.958
or when somebody works like this.

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:17.958
It's that same kind of commitment, that same kind of beauty.

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:20.958
Now, now I get to the point. I want to talk about cars as art.

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:24.958
Art, in the Platonic sense, is truth; it's beauty, and love.

00:04:24.958 --> 00:04:28.958
Now this is really where designers in car business diverge from the engineers.

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:30.958
We don't really have a problem talking about love.

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:33.958
We don't have a problem talking about truth or beauty in that sense.

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:35.958
That's what we're searching for --

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:38.958
when we're working our craft, we are really trying to find that truth out there.

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:40.958
We're not trying to find vanity and beauty.

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:42.958
We're trying to find the beauty in the truth.

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:46.958
However, engineers tend to look at things a little bit more Newtonian,

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:48.958
instead of this quantum approach.

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:50.958
We're dealing with irrationalisms,

00:04:50.958 --> 00:04:52.958
and we're dealing with paradoxes that we admit exist,

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:54.958
and the engineers tend to look things a little bit more like

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:59.958
two and two is four, and if you get 4.0 it's better, and 4.000 is even better.

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:03.958
And that sometimes leads to bit of a divergence

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:05.958
in why we're doing what we're doing.

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:07.958
We've pretty much accepted the fact, though,

00:05:07.958 --> 00:05:09.958
that we are the women in the organization at BMW --

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:12.958
BMW is a very manly type business, -- men, men, men; it's engineers.

00:05:12.958 --> 00:05:15.958
And we're kind of the female side to that. That's OK,

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:18.958
that's cool. You go off and be manly. We're going to be a little bit more female.

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:25.958
Because what we're interested in is finding form that's more than just a function.

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:28.958
We're interested in finding beauty that's more than just an aesthetic;

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:30.958
it's really a truth.

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:33.958
And I think this idea of soul, as being at the heart of great cars,

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:36.958
is very applicable. You all know it. You know a car when you've seen it,

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:38.958
with soul. You know how strong this is.

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:42.958
Well, this experience of love, and the experience of design, to me,

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:45.958
are interchangeable. And now I'm coming to my story.

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:50.958
I discovered something about love and design through a project called Deep Blue.

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:54.958
And first of all, you have to go with me for a second, and say,

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:57.958
you know, you could take the word "love" out of a lot of things in our society,

00:05:57.958 --> 00:05:59.958
put the word "design" in, and it still works,

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:02.958
like this quote here, you know. It kind of works, you know?

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:05.958
You can understand that. It works in truisms.

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:07.958
"All is fair in design and war."

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:09.958
Certainly we live in a competitive society.

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:11.958
I think this one here, there's a pop song

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:15.958
that really describes Philippe Starck for me, you know, this is like

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:18.958
you know, this is like puppy love, you know, this is cool right?

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:20.958
Toothbrush, cool.

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:23.958
It really only gets serious when you look at something like this. OK?

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:25.958
(Laughter)

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:27.958
This is one substitution that I believe

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:29.958
all of us, in design management, are guilty of.

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:33.958
And this idea that there is more to love,

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:39.958
more to design, when it gets down to your neighbor, your other,

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:42.958
it can be physical like this, and maybe in the future it will be.

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:44.958
But right now it's in dealing with our own people,

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:48.958
our own teams who are doing the creating. So, to my story.

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:52.958
The idea of people-work is what we work with here,

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:56.958
and I have to make a bond with my designers when we're creating BMWs.

00:06:56.958 --> 00:06:59.958
We have to have a shared intimacy, a shared vision --

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:01.958
that means we have to work as one family;

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:03.958
we have to understand ourselves that way.

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:06.958
There's good times; there's interesting times;

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:08.958
and there's some stress times too.

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:10.958
You want to do cars, you've got to go outside.

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:13.958
You've got to do cars in the rain; you've got to do cars in the snow.

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:16.958
That's, by the way, is a presentation we made to our board of directors.

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:19.958
We haul their butts out in the snow, too. You want to know cars outside?

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:21.958
Well, you've got to stand outside to do this.

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:26.958
And because these are artists, they have very artistic temperaments.

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:31.958
All right? Now one thing about art is, art is discovery,

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:34.958
and art is discovering yourself through your art. Right?

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:38.958
And one thing about cars is we're all a little bit like Pygmalion,

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:41.958
we are completely in love with our own creations.

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:46.958
This is one of my favorite paintings, it really describes our relationship with cars.

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:48.958
This is sick beyond belief.

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:50.958
(Laughter)

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:54.958
But because of this, the intimacy with which we work together as a team

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:57.958
takes on a new dimension, a new meaning.

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:01.958
We have a shared center; we have a shared focus --

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:05.958
that car stays at the middle of all our relationships.

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:10.958
And it's my job, in the competitive process, to narrow this down.

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:14.958
I heard today about Joseph's death genes

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:17.958
that have to go in and kill cell reproduction.

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:20.958
You know, that's what I have to do sometimes.

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:23.958
We start out with 10 cars; we narrow it down to five cars,

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:26.958
down to three cars, down to two cars, down to one car,

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:30.958
and I'm in the middle of that killing, basically.

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:32.958
Someone's love, someone's baby.

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:35.958
This is very difficult, and you have to have a bond with your team

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:39.958
that permits you to do this, because their life is wrapped up in that too.

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:42.958
They've got that gene infected in them as well,

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:46.958
and they want that to live, more than anything else.

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:49.958
Well, this project, Deep Blue, put me in contact with my team

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:52.958
in a way that I never expected, and I want to pass it on to you,

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:54.958
because I want you to reflect on this, perhaps in your own relationships.

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:59.958
We wanted to a do a car which was a complete leap of faith for BMW.

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:03.958
We wanted to do a team which was so removed from the way we'd done it,

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:06.958
that I only had a phone number that connected me to them.

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:11.958
So, what we did was: instead of having a staff of artists that are just your wrist,

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:15.958
we decided to free up a team of creative designers and engineers

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:19.958
to find out what's the successor to the SUV phenomenon in America.

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:25.958
This is 1996 we did this project. And so we sent them off with this team name,

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:27.958
Deep Blue. Now many people know Deep Blue from IBM --

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:29.958
we actually stole it from them because we figured

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:32.958
if anybody read our faxes they'd think we're talking about computers.

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:34.958
It turned out it was quite clever because Deep Blue,

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:38.958
in a company like BMW, has a hook -- "Deep Blue," wow, cool name.

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:41.958
So people get wrapped up in it. And we took a team of designers,

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:44.958
and we sent them off to America. And we gave them a budget,

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:46.958
what we thought was a set of deliverables,

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:48.958
a timetable, and nothing else.

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:50.958
Like I said, I just had a phone number that connected me to them.

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:53.958
And a group of engineers worked in Germany,

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:55.958
and the idea was they would work separately

00:09:55.958 --> 00:09:58.958
on this problem of what's the successor to the SUV.

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:01.958
They would come together, compare notes. Then they would work apart,

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:03.958
come together, and they would produce together

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:07.958
a monumental set of diverse opinions that didn't pollute each other's ideas --

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:10.958
but at the same time came together and resolved the problems.

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:13.958
Hopefully, really understand the customer at its heart,

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:19.958
where the customer is, live with them in America. So -- sent the team off,

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:23.958
and actually something different happened. They went other places.

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:26.958
(Laughter)

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:32.958
They disappeared, quite honestly, and all I got was postcards.

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:36.958
Now, I got some postcards of these guys in Las Vegas,

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:38.958
and I got some postcards of these guys in the Grand Canyon,

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:40.958
and I got these postcards of Niagara Falls,

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:43.958
and pretty soon they're in New York, and I don't know where else.

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:47.958
And I'm telling myself, "This is going to be a great car,

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:52.958
they're doing research that I've never even thought about before."

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:59.958
Right? And they decided that instead of, like, having a studio,

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:02.958
and six or seven apartments,

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:06.958
it was cheaper to rent Elizabeth Taylor's ex-house in Malibu.

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:09.958
And -- at least they told me it was her house,

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:12.958
I guess it was at one time, she had a party there or something.

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:17.958
But anyway, this was the house, and they all lived there.

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:22.958
Now this is 24/7 living, half-a-dozen people who'd left their --

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:25.958
some had left their wives behind and families behind,

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:27.958
and they literally lived in this house

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:30.958
for the entire six months the project was in America,

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:33.958
but the first three months were the most intensive.

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:35.958
And one of the young women in the project,

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:39.958
she was a fantastic lady, she actually built her room in the bathroom.

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:42.958
The bathroom was so big, she built the bed over the bathtub --

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:44.958
it's quite fascinating.

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:48.958
On the other hand, I didn't know anything about this. OK?

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:51.958
Nothing. This is all going on, and all I'm getting is postcards

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:53.958
of these guys in Las Vegas, or whatever,

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:56.958
saying, "Don't worry Chris, this is really going to be good." OK?

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:59.958
So my concept of what a design studio was probably --

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:02.958
I wasn't up to speed on where these guys were.

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:05.958
However, the engineers back in Munich

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:09.958
had taken on this kind of Newtonian solution,

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:11.958
and they were trying to find how many cup holders

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:13.958
can dance on the head of a pin, and, you know,

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:18.958
these really serious questions that are confronting the modern consumer.

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:21.958
And one was hoping that these two teams would get together,

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:23.958
and this collusion of incredible creativity,

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:25.958
under these incredible surroundings,

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:28.958
and these incredibly stressed-out engineers,

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:31.958
would create some incredible solutions.

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:34.958
Well, what I didn't know was, and what we found out was --

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:39.958
these guys, they can't even like talk to each other under those conditions.

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:43.958
You get a divergence of Newtonian and quantum thinking at that point,

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:49.958
you have a split in your dialog that is so deep, and so far,

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:53.958
that they cannot bring this together at all.

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:57.958
And so we had our first meeting, after three months, in Tiburon,

00:12:57.958 --> 00:13:00.958
which is just up the road from here -- you know Tiburon?

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:03.958
And the idea was after the first three months of this independent research

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:05.958
they would present it all to Dr. Goschel --

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:08.958
who is now my boss, and at that time he was co-mentor on the project --

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:10.958
and they would present their results.

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:12.958
We would see where we were going,

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:14.958
we would see the first indication of what could be

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:18.958
the successive phenomenon to the SUV in America.

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:21.958
And so I had these ideas in my head, that this is going to be great.

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:23.958
I mean, I'm going to see so much work, it's so intense --

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:26.958
I know probably Las Vegas meant a lot about it,

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:28.958
and I'm not really sure where the Grand Canyon came in either --

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:31.958
but somehow all this is going to come together,

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:33.958
and I'm going to see some really great product.

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:35.958
So we went to Tiburon, after three months,

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:38.958
and the team had gotten together the week before,

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:41.958
many days ahead of time.

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:45.958
The engineers flew over, and designers got together with them,

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:48.958
and they put their presentation together.

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:54.958
Well, it turns out that the engineers hadn't done anything.

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:57.958
And they hadn't done anything because --

00:13:57.958 --> 00:14:02.958
kind of, like in car business, engineers are there to solve problems,

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:05.958
and we were asking them to create a problem.

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:08.958
And the engineers were waiting for the designers to say,

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:12.958
"This is the problem that we've created, now help us solve it."

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:16.958
And they couldn't talk about it. So what happened was,

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:19.958
the engineers showed up with nothing.

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:21.958
And the engineers told the designers,

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:25.958
"If you go in with all your stuff, we'll walk out,

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:28.958
we'll walk right out of the project."

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:30.958
So I didn't know any of this,

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:32.958
and we got a presentation that had an agenda, looked like this.

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:35.958
There was a whole lot of dialog.

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:38.958
We spent four hours being told all about vocabulary

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:42.958
that needs to be built between engineers and designers.

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:45.958
And here I'm expecting at any moment, "OK, they're going to turn the page,

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:47.958
and I'm going to see the cars, I'm going to see the sketches,

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:50.958
I'm going to see maybe some idea of where it's going."

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:55.958
Dialog kept on going, with mental maps of words, and pretty soon

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:58.958
it was becoming obvious that instead of being dazzled with brilliance,

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:02.958
I was seriously being baffled with bullshit.

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:04.958
And if you can imagine what this is like,

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:08.958
to have these months of postcard indication of how great this team is working,

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:10.958
and they're out there spending all this money, and they're learning,

00:15:10.958 --> 00:15:13.958
and they're doing all this stuff.

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:19.958
I went fucking ballistic, right? I went nuts.

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:24.958
You can probably remember Tiburon, it used to look like this.

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:29.958
After four hours of this, I stood up, and I took this team apart.

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:33.958
I screamed at them, I yelled at them, "What the hell are you doing?

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:35.958
You're letting me down, you're my designers,

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:37.958
you're supposed to be the creative ones,

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:39.958
what the hell is going on around here?"

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:42.958
It was probably one of my better tirades, I have some good ones,

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:45.958
but this was probably one of my better ones. And I went into these people;

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:47.958
how could they take BMW's money,

00:15:47.958 --> 00:15:53.958
how could they have a holiday for three months and produce nothing, nothing?

00:15:53.958 --> 00:15:58.958
Because of course they didn't tell us that they had three station wagons

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:05.958
full of drawings, model concepts, pictures -- everything I wanted,

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:10.958
they'd locked up in the cars, because they had shown solidarity with the engineers --

00:16:10.958 --> 00:16:13.958
and they'd decided not to show me anything,

00:16:13.958 --> 00:16:16.958
in order to give the chance for problem solving a chance to start,

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:18.958
because they hadn't realized, of course,

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:20.958
that they couldn't do problem creating.

00:16:20.958 --> 00:16:22.958
So we went to lunch --

00:16:22.958 --> 00:16:27.958
(Laughter)

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:30.958
And I've got to tell you, this was one seriously quiet lunch.

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:32.958
The engineers all sat at one end of the table,

00:16:32.958 --> 00:16:35.958
the designers and I sat at the other end of the table, really quiet.

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:42.958
And I was just fucking furious, furious. OK?

00:16:42.958 --> 00:16:44.958
Probably because they had all the fun and I didn't, you know.

00:16:44.958 --> 00:16:46.958
That's what you get furious about right?

00:16:46.958 --> 00:16:48.958
And somebody asked me about Catherine, my wife, you know,

00:16:48.958 --> 00:16:50.958
did she fly out with me or something?

00:16:50.958 --> 00:16:54.958
I said, "No," and it triggered a set of thoughts about my wife.

00:16:54.958 --> 00:16:58.958
And I recalled that when Catherine and I were married,

00:16:58.958 --> 00:17:03.958
the priest gave a very nice sermon, and he said something very important.

00:17:03.958 --> 00:17:06.958
He said, "Love is not selfish," he said,

00:17:06.958 --> 00:17:10.958
"Love does not mean counting how many times I say, 'I love you.'

00:17:10.958 --> 00:17:13.958
It doesn't mean you had sex this many times this month,

00:17:13.958 --> 00:17:15.958
and it's two times less than last month,

00:17:15.958 --> 00:17:17.958
so that means you don't love me as much.

00:17:17.958 --> 00:17:22.958
Love is not selfish." And I thought about this, and I thought,

00:17:22.958 --> 00:17:30.958
"You know, I'm not showing love here. I'm seriously not showing love.

00:17:30.958 --> 00:17:34.958
I'm in the air, I'm in the air without trust.

00:17:34.958 --> 00:17:39.958
This cannot be. This cannot be that I'm expecting a certain number of sketches,

00:17:39.958 --> 00:17:44.958
and to me that's my quantification method for qualifying a team.

00:17:44.958 --> 00:17:46.958
This cannot be."

00:17:46.958 --> 00:17:49.958
So I told them this story. I said, "Guys, I'm thinking about something here,

00:17:49.958 --> 00:17:53.958
this isn't right. I can't have a relationship with you guys

00:17:53.958 --> 00:17:56.958
based on a premise that is a quantifiable one.

00:17:56.958 --> 00:18:04.958
Based on a dictate premise that says, 'I'm a boss, you do what I say, without trust.'"

00:18:04.958 --> 00:18:06.958
I said "This can't be."

00:18:06.958 --> 00:18:12.958
Actually, we all broke down into tears, to be quite honest about it,

00:18:12.958 --> 00:18:17.958
because they still could not tell me how much frustration they had built up

00:18:17.958 --> 00:18:21.958
inside of them, not being able to show me what I wanted,

00:18:21.958 --> 00:18:26.958
and merely having to ask me to trust them that it would come.

00:18:26.958 --> 00:18:29.958
And I think we felt much closer that day,

00:18:29.958 --> 00:18:32.958
we cut a lot of strings that didn't need to be there,

00:18:32.958 --> 00:18:37.958
and we forged the concept for what real team and creativity is all about.

00:18:37.958 --> 00:18:41.958
We put the car back at the center of our thoughts, and we put love,

00:18:41.958 --> 00:18:45.958
I think, truly back into the center of the process.

00:18:45.958 --> 00:18:48.958
By the way, that team went on to create six different concepts

00:18:48.958 --> 00:18:51.958
for the next model of what would be the proposal

00:18:51.958 --> 00:18:54.958
for the next generation after SUVs in America.

00:18:54.958 --> 00:18:58.958
One of those was the idea of a crossover coupes --

00:18:58.958 --> 00:19:03.958
you see it downstairs, the X Coupe -- they had a lot of fun with that.

00:19:03.958 --> 00:19:06.958
It was the rendition of our motorcycle,

00:19:06.958 --> 00:19:10.958
the GS, as Carl Magnusson says, "brute-iful,"

00:19:10.958 --> 00:19:15.958
as the idea of what could be a motorcycle, if you add two more wheels.

00:19:15.958 --> 00:19:19.958
And so, in conclusion, my lesson that I wanted to pass on to you,

00:19:19.958 --> 00:19:23.958
was this one here. I'm also going to steal a little quote out of "Little Prince."

00:19:23.958 --> 00:19:26.958
There's a lot to be said about trust and love,

00:19:26.958 --> 00:19:29.958
if you know that those two words are synonymous for design.

00:19:29.958 --> 00:19:33.958
I had a very, very meaningful relationship with my team that day,

00:19:33.958 --> 00:19:35.958
and it's stayed that way ever since.

00:19:35.958 --> 00:19:39.958
And I hope that you too find that there's more to design,

00:19:39.958 --> 00:19:43.958
and more towards the art of the design, than doing it yourself.

00:19:43.958 --> 00:19:47.958
It's true that the trust and the love, that makes it worthwhile.

00:19:47.958 --> 00:19:49.958
Thanks so much.

00:19:49.958 --> 00:19:51.958
(Applause)
